name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the report by Giovanni La Via, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 as regards the possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory (COM(2015)0177 - C8-0107/2015 - 2015/0093(COD)) (A8-0305/2015).

name: Giovanni La Via
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Andriukaitis, the issue of GMOs always provokes a lively debate in public opinion, mainly on the possible consequences for human health. To date, there is insufficient evidence to show that the consumption of GMO foods can have consequences for human health and the environment. EFSA expresses its position, but as you know in Europe we apply the precautionary principle and therefore, of course, we have a very careful position on this issue. Before I go into the substance of the proposal, however, allow me to thank my fellow Members who have worked with me on what has been done to date. On 22 April, the European Commission presented its proposal to amend the regulation on genetically modified food and feed, which provides for the possibility for Member States to take national decisions to restrict or prohibit the use of GMOs in food or feed, once such use has been authorised at EU level, the so-called 'opt-out'. The ENVI Commission has spoken out loud against the proposal, albeit for a number of reasons for its rejection. However, the majority was large, with 47 votes in favour. In recent months, serious concerns have been expressed about the lack of an impact assessment, the compatibility of the measures taken by the Member States with the internal market, and the practicability of the proposal.  The proposal was not preceded by an assessment of all the possible consequences and alternative options available. We therefore have no means of judging with certainty the consequences that the proposal could have for the functioning of the internal market in food and feed and for the competitiveness of the Union's agricultural sector.  I believe that the proposal could seriously damage livestock production and also have a negative impact on agriculture in the European Union, given that the European Union is still heavily dependent on the supply of protein from genetically modified sources, and considering that the proposal is likely to have an indirect negative effect on imports. I also have serious doubts, already expressed on several occasions in comparison with the Commission, about the implementation of the proposal, given the absence of controls at the Borders of the European Union. The reintroduction of these internal controls, with barriers between Member States, would be tantamount to erasing the economic achievements of the European Customs Union and the single market. And we cannot expect to have an internal market in a leopard spot, after all the efforts that have enabled us over the years to remove internal barriers, the EU's internal borders. It is also unclear how Member States using the opt-out can guarantee compliance with the measures on their territory on a practical basis.  Today, therefore, we are in plenary to take a decision in this Parliament and the rapporteur's request to colleagues is to reject the proposal. We will also have to vote on some amendments to the legislative resolution: some require a new proposal from the Commission and others call for a moratorium until there is a new proposal. As rapporteur, I would also ask you to vote against these amendments, because I believe that the legislation in force is good legislation, but the Member States must have the courage to implement it. The Member States must, of course, take responsibility.  With today's vote, therefore, we are sending a great signal to the Commission, and I hope that in the course of the debate my fellow Members will be able to make a clear statement of our opposition.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President,  honourable Members of Parliament, I am pleased to have this opportunity to set out the aims and substance of the Commission’s proposal to amend the Regulation on genetically modified food and feed prior to the vote later today. Let me recall that this proposal derives directly from the set of political guidelines on the basis of which this Commission was appointed, especially under the heading of a Union of democratic change – this is very important, a Union of democratic change.  We are in a very paradoxical situation and our proposal aims to solve it. On the one hand, European Union citizens seem to be sceptical about GMOs in many Member States, and yet GMOs are authorised in the European Union only after a comprehensive risk assessment which confirms a high level of safety. But part of European Union society is still against GMOs and this creates a democratic deficit in the European Union. On the other hand, EU livestock protein producers are extremely dependent on imports of protein crops, which are mostly genetically modified soya. These GMOs are widely used to feed animals, even in the Member States who vote against GMO products, and European Union livestock producers need a legally sound authorisation mechanism.  Let me recall that before the Commission takes its decision on GMO authorisation it consults Member States, first in a Standing Committee and then, if there is no clear opinion from the Standing Committee, in the Appeal Committee. In this way the Member States twice have the possibility to express their views. Under comitology rules, if Member States reach a qualified majority in favour of a draft Commission authorisation, the Commission adopts it. If the Member States reach a qualified majority against the draft, the Commission cannot adopt its draft authorisation. In case of no opinion, GMO and comitology legislation requires the Commission to adopt a decision alone.  In the specific case of GMOs, Member States have never reached a qualified majority either in favour or against the draft authorisation proposed by the Commission. The result has been a ‘no opinion’ for the 67 GM food and feed authorisations granted. Most of the Member States who voted against or abstained did not challenge the risk assessment, but instead openly invoked national political reasons. Therefore, by failing to draw the line between yes and no, Member States leave the final decision solely to the Commission.  This situation is indeed unique because thousands of other decisions are adopted without difficulty under the comitology procedure in other sectors. This situation creates tensions and deepens a democratic deficit in the European Union. It is highly unsatisfactory as it contributes to a climate of distrust against the European Union and its institutions. Mr President, honourable Members, the time has come for everyone to step up and take their full responsibilities. The Commission’s proposal sets out a pragmatic and legally—sound way forward, consistent with the subsidiarity principle. Member States are already using the Directive on GMO cultivation – thanks to this House, because the directive was adopted here – and it shows that this model provides a workable framework to give the possibility to Member States to better take account of national circumstances. Today’s proposal follows the same logic. The legislative proposal on GM food and feed would give clear roles to the Commission and Member States. The Commission would retain responsibility for granting European marketing authorisations for safe GMOs, while Member States would hold full responsibility for deciding whether or not to use them on their territory in respect of their national political reasons.  I am not aware of an alternative approach that could properly address the challenge at stake and respect at the same time the European Union institutional framework. For example, changing the Comitology Regulation just for GMOs would clearly pose a problem of equal treatment compared with other systems of pre-authorisation. This would also run the risk of not allowing the Commission to take a decision, be it an approval or a rejection, on an application. Changing the voting rules would also be problematic. These rules are set out in the Treaty to ensure the democratic balance between the respective weights of the 28 Member States.  Some suggested that what is needed is not to change the system of authorisation but to improve the risk assessment of GMOs. Let me recall that continuous efforts are made by the Commission and EFSA to ensure that GMO risk assessments are based on the very highest standards of science and independence. The most recent development was the adoption two years ago of a regulation reinforcing and clarifying the requirements of GM food and feed applications. It was supported by a qualified majority of Member States, but this adoption had no influence on the voting behaviour of the same Member States which continue to invoke political reasons. Mr President, honourable Members, I am well aware of the questions this House has raised regarding this proposal, and that Members are considering the adoption of a resolution to reject it. I would regret that very much. I believe an open and serious debate would be beneficial to our institutions and would bring the European Union closer to its citizens and solve problems of democratic deficit.  Should you choose to reject this proposal, the Commission will continue to apply the legislation which was adopted by the European Parliament and by the Council. The Member States will still not take a clear position, they will remain led by national political considerations and, without challenging the European Union risk assessment or demonstrating that GMOs are unsafe, they will not give a clear vote but leave full responsibility for this decision only to the Commission. Farmers will continue using GMOs to feed their livestock, willingly or unwillingly, and European citizens will be sceptical about GMOs in many Member States. This would be a last opportunity to give a concrete answer to genuine and legitimate concerns of European citizens, which undermine not just the GMO authorisation system but also confidence in the European Union itself. I therefore urge you to reflect again very carefully on the full consequences of your decision before proceeding to vote. We are proposing an additional democratic mechanism to reinforce the legitimacy of the European Union decisions on GMOs.

name: Albert Deß
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. The Commission has proposed that Member States should be responsible for importing food and feed in the event of genetic modification. Commissioner, we cannot agree to such a proposal. I was ten years old when the Treaty of Rome was signed in 1957. One of the great achievements of the European Union is a free internal market. If we were to allow national authorisation here again, then border controls would basically be necessary again in Europe. The other discussion on border controls in Europe is enough. We do not need border controls on the import of animal feed.  The Committee on Agriculture and Development rejected this proposal by a large majority.  I am in favour of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, for which I am also speaking, saying very clearly that we are rejecting this Commission proposal, because we do not want production to be moved from Europe to other countries, to other parts of the world. We depend on imports of animal feed. We have only 30% self-sufficiency in protein feed. Your proposal would jeopardise animal husbandry in Europe, so I am in favour of us rejecting this proposal.

name: Peter Liese
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Congratulations, Giovanni La Via! Of course, the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats supports the report and we support it in the way that ENVI and AGRI have adopted it, that is, without amendments. The Commission's proposal goes against all the principles that this Commission and we in the European Union have given ourselves. It has no impact assessment, nor is it feasible. I support what Albert Dess said: we do not want to introduce new border controls either. But without border controls, the proposal would not be feasible. We will have huge problems with third countries. Or, of course, this question is also in the air, is the proposal not meant seriously in the end? Are the limits for the Member States, which are also included, so strict that no one could do it in the end? But then it would not be serious either. That is why we will reject it.  I find it particularly absurd that the Commission is still sticking to this proposal and, on the other hand, telling us that the European Parliament's demands are unworkable when it comes to animal cloning. They refuse to accept a regulation for re-productive material, semen and embryos. You are even refusing to accept first-generation labelling because you say that this is not feasible.  This is child's play compared to the proposal we are discussing this morning. Of course, the breeders know the reproductive material and they can also say whether it is from cloned animals or not. Otherwise they would not pay for it if they did not know that this is particularly good material. So, commissioner, withdraw this GMO proposal and go to Parliament on other proposals, then you are on the right track!

name: Guillaume Balas
text: on behalf of the Group of S and D. - Mr President, Commissioner, there is - as you can see - unanimity today that will be against your proposal. In any case, we are moving in that direction. So, of course, this indicates two things: on the one hand, that the Commission must rework this subject, that it cannot stop there. On the other hand, if there is unanimity, it is also because the reasons may be different for different groups to reject this proposal. But it is true that today, renationalising trade policies within the Union in a more general context where it is clear that there is a threat, a fragility on the issue of free movement, whether that of human beings or that of goods, does not correspond to the idea we have, we in any case social democrats , what the European Union should be.  And I confess that I was somewhat stunned earlier when, in support of your argument, you raised the democratic question. For if we are now at European level to consider that we cannot establish democratic rules to make choices, especially on such important elements as GMOs and their marketing, and to ensure that these choices can be understood by the people, and that for this reason we should renationalise our policies, Commissioner , we are embarking on a path that is being promoted by many here, at least in front of me, but not on this side of the Chamber, and which is not the pro-European tradition in which we are part of it. It is precisely at the level of the European Union and the Commission that we must know how to build democratic choices today so that they can be affirmed.  In this sense, the proposal you are making today cannot be accepted, but we cannot leave it at that either, and that is why, Commissioner, we, the Social Democrats , and probably others here - will urge that a new proposal be prepared from, of course, what has already been done, from the work of Parliament; but we can't stay as it is. I conclude by saying that the question of the agricultural model is still being asked. It is not a question of dreaming of complete self-sufficiency, for example with regard to animal feed. However, as we can see, we cannot be in an agricultural system today that pushes for production, and therefore the massive importation of GMOs, without people even knowing. This is the case, for example, in the country I know best, France. I think many citizens would be surprised to know that the animals they eat eat GMOs themselves; I am not sure they know.  So, and to conclude, Commissioner, we ask you not to stop today, but rather to continue the work. And so take our position rather as, I was going to say, an encouragement to deepen the work with us, so that a new proposal can be made quickly on this subject of the marketing of GMOs.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Speaking in the debate on allowing Member States to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory, I would like to point out that the ECR Group will vote against the European Commission's proposal on this matter. However, we believe that similar arrangements should be introduced for genetically modified food and feed as for the cultivation of genetically modified plants. After all, the GMO Cultivation Directive, agreed by all EU institutions, gives Member States the possibility to prohibit or restrict cultivation on their territory, provided that certain requirements described in the Directive are met. If we want to apply the principle of subsidiarity – as is known in the European Union – similar solutions should be applied to GMO food and feed. I hope that the Commission will present appropriate solutions in this regard in the short term.

name: Gesine Meissner
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Thank you very much, Mr President. Commissioner, I know that this is not an easy thing to do with this proposal.  You have tried to resolve a situation that seems to be very difficult. When it comes to genetic engineering, it is the case at the moment that, in principle, EFSA, on behalf of the Commission, must find a solution and scientifically examine whether something is safe or not. That is the way it is at the moment. Then the Member States will have to say whether they want to follow the Council. And, you mentioned it, there is never a qualified majority in the Standing Committee. It is usually the case: one third is in favour, a third is against and a third abstain. This is a problem for you, because then you have to find solutions and just make a decision. You yourself said that this is unsatisfactory for the Commission, it is also unique – especially in the case of genetically modified organisms – and you want to have a solution.  Now President Juncker has promised us, Parliament, that he will try to change the voting behaviour in the standing committee. But that did not happen. If we had a better solution, we may have moved on now. And that is precisely not the case in this case. You said that it is problematic to change the procedure or the voting behaviour. But it is the case that at the moment you continue to spin in circles, and it is almost a question of who should have the Black Peter. The Commission does not want to have the Buck Peter, we say it in German. But it must find a solution.  That is the case again with the Member States or with us, with Parliament. We believe that the proposal you have made does not take us any further. But the situation we have at the moment is not good either. It's a pretty deadlocked story. That is why I really think that you should reconsider whether you can make a new, better proposal that really no longer requires border controls, which allows the internal market and which also puts into the room the scientific knowledge that the Commission wants to promote, so that it can be implemented. I know it is a difficult task for you. But I don't think it's insoluble. That is why I will be advocating for my group to ask you for a new proposal. Simply because we think that this proposal is not the right solution that can be taken. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - I would like to turn to a Congresswoman. We agree that this proposal needs to be worked on even further, but I would prefer that we, as Parliament, give the Commission a direction. A direction that shows you what ways to look. I did not really take it out of your speech that you would now prohibit or authorise genetically modified substances?

name: Gesine Meissner (ALDE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. It is not a question of banning or allowing GMOs. It is a question of actually getting the decisions that the Commission is now proposing to implement. That is not the way to go. I have said that, above all, we need what Juncker promised: a voting procedure for the standing committee, which is really effective. We do not have that at the moment. It is therefore not a question of banning or allowing genetic engineering. That is precisely the point that divides us here now – I know that – which also divides the Member States. It is a question of having a procedure that is actually in line with the internal market.

name: Lynn Boylan
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, in July 2014 the then candidate for the Commission Presidency, Jean-Claude Juncker, promised Parliament that he was going to address the democratic deficit in relation to EU GM authorisations, and he stated that he would not want the Commission to take a decision where the majority of Member States had not encouraged it to do so. Here we are – fast forward one year – and the promise to tackle the issue has been well and truly fudged. I welcome the votes by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety and the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development to reject this half-baked proposal, and I call on all MEPs now to do the same. However, I urge colleagues not to allow the Commission off the hook on this issue. It must go back to the drawing board and come up with a new proposal which is fit for purpose. Citizens and environmental groups have genuine concerns surrounding GM foods, including about their environmental impact and their implications for food sovereignty, and these are clearly reflected in the decision by 19 Member States to opt out of GM cultivation. With this weak proposal the Commission has missed a good opportunity to address one of the weak spots – namely in relation to the authorisation procedure and the European Food Safety Authority’s risk assessment procedure, which must be reformed. Parliament itself, in its resolution on GM product 1507, called for a freeze on any new authorisations until the risk assessment procedure had been improved. It is a rarity when biotech companies and environmental NGOs are in agreement. This proposal has more legal loopholes than a string vest, and I believe that the only people willing it to pass are the lawyers who will be cleaning up in the aftermath. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: John Stuart Agnew (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – You are obviously from Ireland. I would like to ask you whether you would like to ban the use of GM protein for Irish livestock, bearing in mind that your country is very heavily dependent on livestock for its own livelihood? Most of your cows are fed GM protein, as are all your pigs and most of your poultry. Is it your wish to stop that happening?

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: blue-card answer. – Our wish, certainly in my party, is that the risk assessment for approving these products stands up to scrutiny. I do not believe it does that at the moment. This is about Member States’ ability to choose whether or not they want that feed coming into their country or not.

name: Bart Staes
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. Commissioner, like Mrs Boylan, I want to go back in time with you for a moment, when President-design candidate Juncker solemnly promised here that he would democratise the decision-making process on GMOs. The political guidelines were later followed. I read to them for a moment: "It is simply not right that under the current rules the Commission is legally forced to authorise new organisms for import and processing even though a clear majority of member states is against." Commissioner, the proposal before us does not fulfil that promise. Your proposal is simply a renationalisation of policy. That is not a democratisation of the decision-making process. Moreover, your proposal is simply not applicable. Imagine: a boat with 55 000 tons of soya enters the port of Antwerp. A truck is loaded. France has opted for an opt-out. How are you going to prevent that truck from entering France from Antwerp? I've tried to understand your reasoning. I have invoked the Public Administration Act, requested all documents that have used your services, and checked what meetings they all had to understand your reasoning. Twelve options were on the table. I got this pack of paper. But in these documents, everything is simply blackened. You don't even see what the proposals are. This is ridiculous, this is not public administration. I ask you to withdraw your proposal. I ask you to restart the discussion and, together with the European Parliament, to look at what these 12 options were and what would be a good solution in order to fulfil the proposals that Mr Juncker has made to democratise decision-making.

name: Eleonora Evi
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too agree with the appeals made by Mr Boylan and Mr Staes. Commissioner Andriukaitis, Mr Juncker last year pledged to make the GMO authorisation process more democratic. This proposal does not stand, it lacks impact assessment. There has therefore been a lack of political will to make a serious effort to resolve this situation.  Parliament is expressing itself in its text. We have tried to propose amendments to make suggestions on how to resolve this situation, to fuel a debate. We, as the 5-star Movement, believe that, if necessary, risk management could be left to the Member States again, so that they can be free to manage the health risk that may be caused by the release into the environment of these genetically modified organisms. Or we could accept the Greens' proposal to amend the comitology rules by means of Regulation (EU) No 182/2011.  So there are possibilities and solutions that we can put in place, which we strongly urge the Commission to listen to so that we can finally come up with a proposal that is as democratic as possible that will enable The Member States and those who want to obtain and market GMOs to have GMOs on their market, and those who do not want them to finally have legal certainty.

name: Jean-François Jalkh
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the process of authorising the cultivation of GMOs is stalling, and that is all the better! But we are only saving time against an implacable logic: that of the right to sell and produce without limit and above all without precaution. The balance of power is still favourable to the party of prudence, because it is based on public opinion.  Nevertheless, support for agriculture and the trade in GMOs is of formidable importance, and their influence in decision-making places and among opinion-makers is increasing. Let us remember the researcher Gilles-Eric Séralini, who in 2012 demonstrated the harmfulness of GMOs after feeding rats for several weeks; a controversy led by the major industrial groups had disavowed it. This was not for scientific reasons but for reasons of commercial interest, and public health questions found no other answers than those of industrialists.  Therefore, there will be no status quo, nor a middle ground. We must demand a ban on GMOs - trade as well as culture - or risk seeing them soon dumped and cultivated throughout Europe. The Commission is moving more slowly, but in the same direction as the big sellers of GMOs: what is in favour of globalised trade inevitably finds a guilty tenderness and favour in this institution. So let's be clairvoyant and look where we're going. At stake is absolute control of food production and the chain of life. That the more a fruit or vegetable is produced by nature, the more a seed, the more a bread without royalty to the industry: that is the challenge. The aim is to put an end to the free cultivation that produces crops without chemistry, genetics and banking. This is the GMO project: a global colonization by patent holders and living owners against the interests of the peoples!

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – The Commission's proposal to ban GM food and feed in the Member States is rejected by the pro-GMO people. They are representatives of large-scale agriculture and livestock production. For them, economic performance, profit is their priority. By restricting GMO feedstuffs, they fear a loss of competitiveness. The other side, to which I belong, is committed to quality, GMO-free European agriculture and food.  The Commission's proposal does not give the possibility of a real ban. The prohibition should not be infree an international treaty, such as the WTO, or, god forbid, TTIP, if concluded, and there is little scientific evidence to justify it in the Member States. We need compelling, compelling reasons. It's a rubber act! A real ban on Member States would be necessary so that Member States can take advantage of this option.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the issue of GMOs is once again back on the table. This is a particularly important issue which worries our fellow citizens and totally divides the Member States.  I would like to strongly support the position of my group and that of our rapporteur- Mr La Via - which is to reject the Commission's proposal, because we are not satisfied. After the introduction of a two-tiered system for cultivation permits which threatens to create a real distortion of competition between our farmers, the Commission is now re-offending with marketing authorisations. However, we see the results: an impressive number of Member States have already called for a ban on GMO crops on their territory. The Commission definitely wants to send the hot potato back to national governments, in order to break the deadlock.  But we're going the wrong way. To avoid a difficult debate, we will set up an illegible hybrid system, in which GMO products, even considered safe by EFSA, could be marketed in one Member State, but not in another. This, in my view, poses a major legal security problem. There are about 50 imported GMO products that are marketed in the European Union. We are thus undermining the cohesion of the single market, when in reality we would need to have a serene debate and get out of the trap of passionate debate, trapped in an often inadequate precautionary principle that prevents us from moving forward.  What is important is that the risk assessment, entrusted to the European Food Safety Authority, remains science-based and continues to be conducted at European level to ensure harmonised consumer protection. In short, it is the interest of the single market, consumer protection and research that requires that we have common rules, certainly not renationalisation. Commissioner, we will need a new proposal. (The speaker agreed to answer two "blue card" questions (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: the blue card. – I would like to ask a dear colleague: what would be your opinion on mandatory labelling of all production produced using genetically modified feed?

name: Gesine Meissner (ALDE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mrs Grossetéte! It has already been said, as we know, that the Member States are divided. After all, it is not the majority that would be against GMOs, for example, and then we would have a clear majority. It's really very undecided. You have just mentioned that EFSA is making scientific decisions. After that, GMOs are already taken into account, for example in the case of animal feed, as Mr Des said a short while ago. It has now been proposed to impose a moratorium until a new proposal is in place. What do you think this would have?

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, it is clear how extremely sensitive this debate on GMOs is, and the questions of my colleagues are proof of this. On the first issue of labelling, of course we want transparency. The consumer must be informed, it is fundamental that there is labelling. We already have regulations on GMOs on this subject. With respect to the second question, I did not fully understand the content, so I would have a little difficulty answering it. I will just point out that on this issue of GMOs, I think it is important that we have a thorough reflection based on science, because ideology cannot lead to interesting and pragmatic answers. So let us rely on science, trust the European Food Safety Authority, in order to move forward on this issue of GMOs. But what is important today, as we are talking about the single market, is to say that we are really dealing with this single market.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the proposal to give Member States the possibility to limit or prohibit the use of genetically modified organisms authorised by the European Union in food or feed on their territory is a serious mistake and a political setback and must therefore be rejected.  This proposal exemplifies an example where the principle of subsidiarity is not applicable, given the practical impossibility of delimiting territorial borders within a single market framework, where the free movement of persons and goods is a basic principle. And this impossibility of delimiting borders, even if costly control systems were developed, would lead to a breach of transparency and certainly would ultimately seriously undermine the competitiveness of the agricultural sector in the European Union and weaken consumer confidence, both within Europe and beyond.  European policy towards genetically modified organisms must be a European policy, and in that sense the Commission should put forward a proposal to review the European policy of authorising these bodies and it is not in this area of unaccountability that we need. We need more Europe and all the knowledge available to protect our agricultural sector and consumers.

name: Richard Ashworth (ECR).
text: – Mr President, providing food for a growing world population is going to be a big challenge, and it is clear that new technology, including GM, will have to be a significant part of the solution.  But I am not persuaded by the Commission’s proposal as it stands. Commissioner, if you allow approval or rejection to be based at individual Member State level you will create two problems. First, we would be allowing food policy to be based on emotion, not on sound, evidence-based science. Second, we would expose some sectors – and I am thinking particularly of the livestock sector here – to exclusion to much of the single market. Those two points of principle must prevail: the Single Market and sound evidence-based policymaking. I therefore support Mr La Via and his rejection of the Commission proposal.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – I welcome Mr Ashworth’s decision to reject this proposal but, as a fellow British MEP, I would like to draw his attention to the fact that it was actually a British ruse to break the Single Market and to allow GMOs to be registered in particular Member States and rejected in other Member States, in the case of feed, that led us to exactly this problem. We have heard from Mr Andriukaitis that this proposal will bring us closer to the citizens, but many speakers have rejected that and have said that, in fact, it is an anti—democratic move and part of an attempt to steamroll us into accepting GMOs when we do not wish to do so. So I would like to ask Mr Ashworth whether his rejection of the Commission proposal is consistent with the position the British Government has taken on GMOs and whether this is driven more by a desire to feed the world’s poor or a by a Eurosceptic approach to European policy—making.

name: Richard Ashworth (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – I repeat comments which I made earlier: that decision-making must be sound, scientific and evidence-based. Contrary to your comments, it has nothing to do with my political views or thoughts of the European Union. My thoughts, particularly as a farmer myself, are the challenge of feeding a growing world. Science, technology and GM have to be part of that solution.

name: Jan Huitema (ALDE).
text: – In the EU, we have a single market with free movement of goods. This includes GMO products. The Commission's new proposal would restrict the free movement of GMO products. This could mean, for example, reintroducing border controls and bypassing some Member States. Far too often we see cases being paralysed for legal or procedural reasons, which are causing problems for businesses and end users. I am thinking here of the new plant breeding techniques, for example cisgenesis. In contrast to GMO techniques, only species's own genes are used. This actually works the same as classic breeding, only many times faster. As a result, beneficial crop characteristics such as disease and drought resistance can be crossed in faster and better. This can significantly reduce the use of plant protection products. In 2012, the European food watchdog EFSA already concluded that cisgenesis is as safe as conventional breeding and that if only species's own genes are used in breeding, there is no GMO. Unfortunately, cisgenesis is still covered by strict GMO legislation, which means that this promising technique still cannot be applied. Back to the proposal on the table. The consequences of the new proposal for the import of GMOs are very damaging. It would be good if both the Commission and the Member States were to take responsibility and make the current system workable. I am convinced that the European Parliament will take its responsibility by rejecting the proposal.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I found it interesting that MEP Ashworth does not think emotion is important in this debate. Well, when it comes to marketing and selling your food around the world, emotion is important, especially when you are trying to sell your products as clean and green and to use the fact that people are concerned about that. That is done. In Ireland, if we cannot live up to that image – if we are using GM food to feed our cattle, etc. – that damages it. An interesting point was made by the UKIP MEP, Mr Agnew:  would we want to stop it, in the morning? Do we want to stop farmers feeding this in Ireland? I would like to see that happen. Obviously it cannot happen overnight, but I think we should have that goal and that target. We talk about democracy in here, but democracy is about listening to the people, and the people of Europe have consistently expressed the opinion that they do not want GM foods. Please do not tell me you want to feed the world: GM companies want to feed their fat bosses with foie gras and champagne. They do not give a damn about feeding the world; they care about feeding their bloody pockets.

name: José Bové (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I will not go back to the reasons for the refusal, because today all groups refuse. It may sound surprising, but that is the way it is today, we are dealing with this reality. So let's look to the future. Tomorrow we have to propose new legislation. This new legislation must be based on three elements.  The first element is the reset of the assessment: scientific assessment, health assessment, environmental risk assessment, socio-economic assessment. It is only this overall assessment that makes sense. The second element is the change in the rules at European level. It takes a simple majority to reject GMOs at European level, and not the complexity of a qualified majority.  Third, mandatory labelling of all animal products, eggs and dairy products from animals that have consumed GMOs.  In the meantime, I solemnly ask you to ban any renewal of old GMOs, as well as any adoption of new authorizations. It is not possible to continue as if nothing had happened, as if this Parliament was not going to vote against the European Community proposal.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, we support the proposal for a revision of current EU regulation on the authorisation system of GMOs in Europe. However, we reject the rapporteur’s view on GMOs as we believe that each Member State should have the power to opt out and decide if it wishes to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed in its own country. We do not agree with the restrictions put in place by the Commission with respect to the right of opting out. In particular, we think that each Member State should have the right to ban a product if its representatives believe that the product could be a danger to human and animal health or to the environment. Similarly, we do not consider that a prior decision in this instance from the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) is sufficient, due to the inexcusable lack of transparency and the impossibility of accessing data for independent research and, to be honest, the dubious test method used both for GM and feed. In short, we believe that the prior risk assessment method used by EFSA is too short and risky. All documents used for the prior evaluation should be available for independent research, and each Member State should be able to take such crucial decisions without interference by unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with its crazy decisions, Europe is taking everything away from us, including the right to choose what to eat and what to put on the plate.  Europe is listening to the large multinationals which dictate the rules of the food market and who think of their interests, certainly not our health, those multinationals that do not want compulsory origin labelling, which is all the more fundamental now that red meat and processed meat are being accused. Initiatives such as this are welcome, but that is not enough, given that Europe with TTIP and trade agreements is opening the door to the invasion of counterfeit and poor quality products. Europe must choose, ladies and gentlemen, whether to be on the side of the consumer, and therefore of quality agri-food, or on the side of major economic interests. I chose: I say 'no' to GMOs. Europe must say 'no' to GMOs clearly and not leave it to the Member States to produce and sell genetically modified products. That is what the citizens of Europe want, as you said, Commissioner, and I will always be on the side of the citizens.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). Mr President, first of all, on the occasion of today's historic national anniversary on 28 October 1940, I would like to wish all Greeks in Greece and throughout the world. Then the Greeks said no to the foreign invader. But then the no was said by a great political man, followed by the Greek people. Today the people say no, but the politicians sell it out, take it as a yes and sign new memoranda that suggest the Greek people to the economic invaders. On the subject of the debate, we have been witnessing for a few months an attempt by the Commission to literally liberalise the rearing and cultivation of genetically modified organisms in the Union. It does not care about the impact on both the environment and the health of European citizens. It also ignores their view, which is firmly opposed to mutated foods. And finally, it does not even care about the right of states to protect their citizens and to ban food that is potentially harmful.  So I wonder what interests the Commission serves and acts in this way? Which large multinational companies benefit from this attitude and, above all, why do these companies take precedence over European citizens? I would very much like all this to be simply due to incompetence or superficiality, but unfortunately I very much doubt it. Moreover, the number of representatives of agricultural companies residing in Brussels is not small. The firm position of our movement is a complete ban on any kind of genetically modified or cloned organism. The future and health of our children are more important than any other economic or non-economic interest. I therefore fully agree with the rejection of the Commission's proposal.

name: Pilar Ayuso (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, you are right in what you said in your speech, but regardless of the feelings raised by GMOs, which are, of course, foreign to sound scientific arguments, it is logical that the Commission's proposal should be rejected simply because it is contrary to the principles of the single market. I would like to highlight the contradictory attitude of many countries which, while prohibiting their farmers from growing GM plants, allow their farmers to feed their livestock with proteins imported and genetically modified from third countries. All this distorts the debate, and it is understandable, in a way, that the Commission intends to delegate its responsibility to the Member States. However, the Commission's solution is not the most appropriate, as it would leave the crop authorisation at the mercy of national policies outside of scientific and food security considerations most of the time. The European Union has already lost the train of biotechnology and has left the vanguard to third countries that sell their production to us for our consumption. The new proposal to renationalise GMO crops could, in addition to breaking down the single market, have the undesired effect of accentuating the scarcity of feed and increasing the high price already paid by our farmers for having to import these products that we cannot grow within the European Union. The authorization of GMOs is not a matter of democracy; it is a matter of food security and science, but of independent science, like that of the European Food Safety Agency.

name: Paolo De Castro (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, today we are going to reject the proposal to leave it to the Member States to use GMOs or not, a proposal that has not convinced a large majority of this Parliament. I will therefore not repeat the many reasons that also lead my political group to this rejection, which focus mainly on the risk of undermining the Single European Market, bringing animal husbandry to its knees in many countries.  This rejection must, however, be an opportunity to open a broader debate and go beyond a simple confrontation between pros and cons of GMOs. Going further means, first and foremost, explaining to our citizens what biotechnology is, especially new generation biotechnology, and it means noting that Europe's great need for vegetable proteins is currently largely met by imports of genetically modified soya, but above all it means not losing Europe the train of innovation. Only with greater commitment to research will we be able to discover how new generation biotechnology allows us to overcome the ethical limits of the current ones, which are of particular concern to European consumers.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR).
text: – Poland is known in Europe and around the world for producing healthy, safe and high-quality food. Polish society, as well as the societies of many other countries of the European Union, does not want GMOs. Speaking here in Parliament on behalf of the citizens of the European Union, we should take decisions in accordance with the will of the citizens of the Union. The proposal submitted by the European Commission needs to be improved, but I do not agree with the European Parliament's rejection of it. Where Member States have already been allowed to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of genetically modified organisms on their territory, this Decision should also result in them being allowed to prohibit the placing on the market of genetically modified food and feed.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE).
text: Mr President, what are we doing now? Because that is the question, and José Bové is right. I am one of the forty Members who have signed Amendment No 2, which asks you, Commissioner, to come back, to come back to us, this time with a strong proposal on the issue of GMO imports. That's what's expected of you. And as rapporteur on the legislation on the possibility of refusing the cultivation of GMOs, which we negotiated with you just ten months ago, I believe we have been misled. To legislate in the same way here on imports as we have done on culture is nonsense. I'm not going to go back to everything that's been said. In all respects, this is nonsense. Commissioner, the case of the six varieties of Syngenta maize authorised without EFSA's approval highlights the failure - there is no other term - of the current authorisation process. The exercise is difficult, as we all know, but it is urgent now to keep the so-called and repeated promise of candidate Juncker, and to review from A to Z a process that ultimately no longer satisfies anyone.

name: Martin Häusling (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I believe that the Commission is simply playing the wrong way at this point. How can one assume that such a bill can convince the majority here? I believe that the Commission simply wanted to get rid of this issue with this bill. It is not acceptable, the bill. One wonders, of course, how a Commission, which in recent years has actually taken a very different line, which allows genetically modified feed after another into the European Union, is suddenly to change its attitude towards genetic engineering. But there is the promise of the President of the Commission. He has told us here that account must be taken of the majority will of the citizens and the majority will of the Member States. And then such a miserable bill. So, you can't get away with it. You have to put a new bill on the table. And we definitely need a new risk assessment at EFSA. EFSA is always suspected of wavening through everything related to genetic engineering without a risk analysis that really meets the challenges. We need a European protein strategy. We can also produce protein in Europe. We don't have to import everything from overseas soya. It is also quite clear that we need labelling of foods produced with genetically engineered feed, meat and milk. This, too, would strengthen consumer confidence. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Do you not think that the Commission proposal is unacceptable, especially considering the non-existence of an impact assessment, the compatibility of Member States’ opt—out measures with the internal market of the World Trade Organisation rules, the failure to ensure legal certainty and the weak chances that this proposal can actually be implemented?

name: Martin Häusling (Verts/ALE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, I would like to thank my colleague for his work I said yes: I just think it's a stupid job. One wonders how the Commission can put such a thing on the table at all, without taking a risk assessment into account, without taking into account the WTO concerns. It's bad work, I can't say more about it. If the Commission had done a solid job here, we could have talked about a bill that really also takes account of what has been said here and the will of the majority. We want fewer imports of genetic engineering.

name: Ivo Belet (PPE).
text: I think that many of us agree that we do need clear rules for GMOs, because, of course, this is primarily about public health. Unfortunately, we cannot support the proposal that is now on the table. This threatens to create a situation in which we will have a patchwork of national opt-outs within the European single market. This will make it impossible to import and export food and, of course, feed containing GMO components. Moreover, and this is my second point, it is not at all clear how this proposal will work in practice. For example, what arguments can the Member States put forward for this opt-out? The rules must not be contrary to the rules of the European single market or those of the World Trade Organisation, and they must also be in line with the findings of the European Food Agency. It is therefore not at all clear what arguments they can then invoke. The lack of an impact assessment is also, in our view, contrary to the European Commission's intentions for better regulation. So we would like to see a new proposal, and I assume that you intend to take care of it.

name: Susanne Melior (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. You pointed out that here in Parliament we have decided on an opt-out for the cultivation of genetically modified organisms and have launched it. Let me tell you that it sounds plausible at first that this should now also be done for the use and use of genetically modified organisms. However, it cannot work at all. Colleagues have already pointed out that the issues of the internal market clearly stand in the way of this. You would have to check not only every border, but every single truck. Nobody can want that. As you have already said, we are talking here in particular about feed, genetically modified feed such as soya and maize, which are used in animal fattening in the EU. The EU is completely dependent on it. We are importing 30 million tonnes of soya fed and we produce only 2 million tonnes in the EU, everything else comes from third countries, some of which grow up to 95% genetically modified soya. I expect a new proposal from you, and I expect – as Mr Häusling has just said – that we will clearly promote protein feed production in Europe: lupins, peas, beans – that is also growing in Europe!

name: Esther Herranz García (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the debate on genetically modified organisms has been a great deal of controversy for years and, personally, I believe that detractors have not yet provided sound scientific reasons to justify any ban, either on the cultivation and marketing of these food products, while, surprisingly, GMOs are fully accepted in the pharmaceutical industry without problem , and for years, for treatments such as diabetes or cancer. Today, there are fifty-eight GMOs that have been authorised by the European Union, having undergone very strict health and quality checks. Behind these fifty-eight GMOs are, of course, years and years of research and progress that allow, for example, to supply food for livestock and thus compensate for the shortage of feed production in the European Union. This European Union, which today needs to import transgenic soybeans from third countries to cover this shortage of livestock feed. And this is a fact that no one can deny, not even those countries that are banning the cultivation of GMOs in their territory, because they are incuring, at the same time, an inconsistency in allowing the entry of GMOs into that same territory. So above all, I believe that today we must forget about value judgments about GMOs and that our goal must be to legislate consistently. If we want a market that favours the free transit of people, goods and capital, and in coherence with that policy, I believe that we should reject this Commission proposal, because it is a breach of the single market. For all this, I would like to express my absolute, full support to the rapporteur, Mr La Via, in favour of rejecting this proposal from the European Commission.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on the very complex and not a new issue of GMOs, I believe that we need a less ideological, more balanced approach and also with more transparency and greater involvement on the part of science and citizens. It is essential to encourage free and responsible research to understand what the real risks and benefits are.  The proposal for a regulation under discussion is to be rejected: it does not intervene on the real issue, which is the contested procedure by which the European Union authorises GMOs, but allows Member States to ban their use on their territory or not, even in the absence of a genuine serious and comprehensive impact assessment, with the consequent risk of creating more problems than solutions. Moreover, the proposal is impracticable, because it would lead to the reintroduction of border controls, to the erasing of the achievements of the single market. It is also important to consider the negative impact that this proposal would have on the EU livestock sector. If the ambition is to make rules that apply to all Europeans, we need a new and very different proposal.

name: Paul Brannen (S&D).
text: – Mr President, regulating GMOs is a question of both reason and responsibility. Reason should dictate whether we decide to use GMOs in the first place. Some GMOs are known for their potential to contribute to tackling the challenge of global food security and can deliver positive agricultural and health impacts. On the other hand, some GMOs can encourage farmers to use even more chemicals that cause considerable damage to biodiversity, the environment and, especially, cause climate change. Responsibility must therefore be our guiding principle with regards to EU GMO policy. The heart of our policy must be an independent, thorough, case-by-case assessment of each new GM trait by the European Food Safety Authority. In this way, incentives for further scientific research are preserved and the centralisation of the process ensures the integrity of the Single Market. The Commission’s proposal, alas, fails on both counts and therefore should be rejected. Let our GMO policy be guided by reason and responsibility within a common European approach.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I say to the Commission: thanks; you are getting a lot of abuse this morning, but you have done justice to this debate by having it. It is important that we hear all these voices on the issue of GMO. It is wrong to say that European citizens are against GM technology. In the medical sector they welcome it with open arms. In the food sector there is scepticism, but not 99% of people are sceptical, despite the tone of this debate and the realities that have been spelled out. The European livestock sector uses GM protein for their livestock feed. One country grows GM.  I welcome the debate because it allows the facts to elevate above some of the emotion. Some of the comments here I would utterly disagree with, because I approve and accept the authorisation procedures that are in place. I am also aware that young scientists, including young Irish scientists, are leaving the European Union because there is not a welcoming environment for research in this area. I would like to compliment the former Chair of the Agriculture Commission, Paolo De Castro, and support his comments. We need a sound debate on this, not a politicised one.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I must state from the outset, because I think it is sincere, that I do not support the cultivation and use of genetically modified organisms. I don't know what you think as a doctor, because it didn't come away from the point of view that you presented here. You can only convince me, as an engineer, if you present us here scientific studies on the impact on health. That is what many European citizens want. What surprises me is that Mr Juncker deftly passes the hot potato when he doesn't like it.  The European Union and the Commission are not just to share some money, there are no accountants here. I hope we have specialists who look at all the important things and treat them responsibly. I believe that health is an important thing and that is why we need a European policy.  In my view, we must not forget and neglect, of course, livestock farmers, the fact that for decades feed has been imported with genetically modified organisms from other countries. What are you doing? Have you not told us what you can do to stop importing into the internal market? We cannot demolish either the European food industry or livestock farmers.  That is why I believe that you must have a responsible analysis and come back to Parliament with concrete proposals that balance the situation in all respects.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, I agree with the rejection of the Commission's proposal and with the comments made by Mr José Bové, who has raised many issues which concern not only consumer health but also environmental protection and the future of agriculture itself. European consumers have expressed their complete opposition to genetically modified foods and organisms. With the Commission's proposal, the common agricultural policy is renationalised, leading to problematic problems. But food is crucial for the health of consumers and this issue cannot be left to the national authorities, because we have experience of food scandals for which specific Member States are responsible.  The Commission essentially refuses to take a firm stand against mutants and throws the ball at the Member States and does so in view of TTIP, which, if implemented, would pose a serious risk to the health of consumers, since it allows the free movement of GMOs.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE).
text: – We have not debated with not so many Members here today. I notice that the broad line is clear. We think it is absolutely not a good idea that the regulations should be nationalised again, because that would simply not be feasible. If we were to reintroduce border controls to control the transport of feed, it would seem to me to be completely contrary to the internal market. Moreover, Commissioner, I would ask you to come up with a balanced proposal. The ALDE colleagues have already called on you to do so. It is absolutely important that we also take into account the liveability of our livestock farming. After all, this sector has already been very affected. So I ask you: make a balanced proposal that is feasible and that takes account of the internal market, so that we do not have 28 different regulations.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, you said that society is resisting GMOs. So why impose them if we don't need them? Second, he also said that farmers depend on imported feed. This is an imposition, an imposition that could be broken, because conventional, GMO-free feed could be imported; or, better yet, Europe could and should break livestock dependence on plant protein imports. We have land, we have non-transgenic seeds and we have knowledge to produce transgenic-free animal feed. So, Commissioner, what is preventing this from going? Third question: Europe is not called to feed the world. By ethics, responsibility and solidarity, Europe should support for each country to exercise the right to feed itself. Let's not waste any more time. Spend your time changing policies, to respond to the real needs of society and not to the lobby of GMOs and animal feed.

name: Claude Turmes (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The President of the Commission, Mr Juncker, promised during the election campaign that democratisation and transparency would be in place for genetic engineering.  Instead of transparency, we have a black box, and instead of democratisation we have renationalisation. This proposal is a gigantic sham. It is not feasible in practice, and the Commission itself knows that it is not WTO-compatible. Probably this fog bomb was very closely linked to the TTIP negotiations in order to keep genetic engineering away from the negotiating table during the TTIP negotiations. Dear Jean-Claude Juncker, enough has been played now! Genetic engineering is an important thing for citizens. Now we need a serious proposal. We Greens have set the line: evaluation in Europe, cultivation of animal feed, and clear labelling also for animal feed.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I support, like most of my colleagues, the position of the rapporteur, Mr La Vii, calling for the European Commission's proposal to restrict or prohibit the use and sale of feed and genetically modified food on its territory. I believe that the adoption of this proposal could undermine the functioning of the internal food and feed market and could lead, as my colleague just said, to the renationalisation of agricultural policy. In addition, enforcing such a restriction would be either impossible to implement or at least extremely costly, which in turn would not have an impact on the global competitiveness of European agriculture. I am aware that the issue of GMOs is a difficult issue on which there is no unanimity on the part of the Member States. However, I believe that the Commission's proposal would not be a solution to this issue, but merely a hindrance to the current well-functioning mechanisms.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D).
text: – Mr. President, today's vote will solve one problem, which is a bad and unenforceable proposal for a GMO food regulation that would cause chaos in the inward market. The primary purpose for Member States to be able to sell GMO food for the harvest would not be met, and therefore it is good that the vast majority in Parliament will be against it.  But the problem of an unfair GMO food approval system remains. Member States clearly cannot agree on this topic and the Commission will therefore continue to have the power to authorize and use sales and use on its own. In conclusion, I would like to tell the European Commission that rejecting this proposal does not reassess them from the obligation to democratise the approval process.  This was one of President Juncker's promises, and that is why we want the Commission to come up with a new, better proposal. It is a topic that is extremely important to our citizens and a promise that is essential for the democratic legitimacy of the European Union.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, of course I have followed very closely this controversial debate and I have taken due note of all the comments and views that the honourable Members, have expressed. I would like to reply to some of these. Regarding the claims that the Commission proposal is not in line with the European Union single market rules, I will simply respond that this is incorrect. According to the European Union Treaties, Member States may derogate from the freedom-of-movement rule on the basis of overriding reasons related to the public interest. That is enshrined in the Treaties. This is not against the Single Market: it is about the right of Member States to see such overriding reasons. We must follow the rule of law; we must follow the Treaties; we cannot act without a legal basis – and the proposal fully respects that principle. I am in favour of supporting the single European market. I am in favour of supporting science-based assessment, because that is the only way. I believe in science – independent science. As regards the accusation that an impact assessment was not carried out, I would say this: it is meaningless for the Commission to carry out an ex-ante impact assessment on a proposal which merely gives the Member States a legal basis on which to act. In relation to cultivation proposals, the same logic applies. The proposal does not have an impact in itself: it will be up to Member States to evaluate the possible impact of their own decisions – about which you have raised many, many questions. It is in the hands of Member States to use the opt-out mechanism if they are ready to do so. They must follow the impact assessment procedure because this is a very serious and complex matter. I fear from the unwilling tone of the discussions that there is a real possibility of Parliament rejecting the proposal. Allow me to repeat my view: it would be preferable to continue to discuss this frankly and openly under the ordinary legislative procedure rather than to seek to close down the dialogue. I would repeat once again Jean-Claude Juncker’s promise: the Commission should be in a position to give the majority view of democratically—elected governments at least the same weight as scientific advice. It is about the Member State governments’ view, not about the scope for Treaty changes to change the voting mechanism, because that is enshrined in the Treaties. Secondly, I would not want the Commission to be able to take a decision when the majority of Member States had not encouraged it to do so. That is our proposal: please, if Member States have reasonable opinions, that is one thing, but you cannot destroy the single market, you cannot destroy our common European agricultural policy, and you cannot act against the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) assessment because we need a centralised EFSA opinion. On the subject of EFSA, this risk assessment of GM food and feed is carried out by EFSA in accordance with the highest and the most up-to-date scientific standards. We have mentioned independence and scientific evidence, and I am ready to discuss all these arguments about EFSA’s transparency. We must create trust in EFSA because otherwise we will have no scientifically based instruments. We must do our job in the best way to preserve trust in EFSA. Commission Implementing Regulation No 503/2013 on applications for authorisation of genetically modified food and feed reinforces the authorisation process by clarifying the studies to be conducted by applicants and defining the protocols to be followed. It was adopted by a qualified majority of Member States. Furthermore, EFSA carries out risk assessment in close cooperation with Member States: with all 28 Member States, with all the scientists involved. Of course, we must debate and see how to improve EFSA’s capacity but we need science. I call on you once again, honourable Members, to reflect on the consequences of this discussion before proceeding to the vote. We need to reinforce the legitimacy of European Union decisions on GMOs. I would like to say that I have heard some excellent proposals: to continue our debates on biotechnologies, on science, on examining ways of supporting European Union researchers, including biotechnologists, more effectively. I cannot imagine the European Union without scientific progress – that would be against logic. I am a cardiac surgeon and I know what a scientific approach to all the issues means. I am ready to continue those debates. Maybe next year it would be good to organise debates together with the European Parliament, inviting representatives of non-governmental organisations and prominent scientists and to challenge some of our understanding of the issues. Lastly, I would like to confirm that the Commission believes this proposal is the right way of addressing the challenges in relation to the decision-making process on GMOs at European Union level. The Commission will not withdraw its proposal.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I just want to record my displeasure at not being called under catch-the-eye. I just want to say that I was in here at 8.25, before any of you arrived. I asked with the white paper to speak under catch-the-eye at the very outset and I was not called. I do not understand why; I do not need an explanation; it has happened before and it will probably happen again. It will not deter me from my work. In fact I will be here tonight around midnight as the last speaker on behalf of my group on financing for SMEs. So thank you for allowing me to make my point.

name: Presidente. –
text: As far as catch-the-eye is concerned, of course, when there are twenty or more requests, I always try to take into account the balance of groups, gender and nationality. So I cannot, in spite of myself, give the floor to all those who request it.  Mr. Kelly, you often got the floor from me when you asked to participate in catch-the-eye, so there's no intention on my part to discriminate against you. It's just a matter of balance within catch-the-eye.

name: Giovanni La Via
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you first of all to all my fellow Members for their contribution to this debate, and to Commissioner Andriukaitis for defending the Commission's position.  You said today: 'It is likely that this Parliament will reject the Commission's proposal today'. Having heard this debate, I think he has a deep conviction that, for different reasons, there is one point that unites almost all the political groups, which is the reject of the Commission's proposal. I said, for different reasons: because, on the one hand, there are reasons for the inconsistency between a proposal for better regulation put forward by the Commission and the lack of an impact assessment, which you explain to us that it would probably not be necessary, because it will be the Member States that will have to opt out. But it is the Commission that must ask the question of how a leopard-spot market can function, with countries choosing one position and countries choosing another.  We have obviously seen, as you have indicated to us, the possibility of a derogation from the single market. Of course, but it seems to me that in this House today we do not want this derogation from the single market. We want something else, and we have also heard some clearly positive proposals in this House, which you have accepted, but which I would like to highlight. We need a great debate, we need a European debate on new technologies, because Europe must be able to reconcile the tradition of its great agri-food production with the urgent need, which can no longer be postponed, to have a production of quality, of quality adequate to satisfy the food consumption of European citizens and those of the world. I therefore call on you to promote this debate on new technologies, because only through knowledge will we be able to dispel some of the shadows that are there on the new technologies and we will then be able to move in the direction that the governments and citizens of this Europe want.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday 28 October at 12.00 p.m. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. – Although, at first sight, the Commission's proposal was as if it were attractive to the Member States, however, a closer examination of the document showed that the conditions for the choice of states were very difficult, it would be almost impossible to exercise the right of choice. And how to ensure border control, what feed or food is transported to the country from a neighbouring country? From April 2015, Member States may be banned from growing GM crops. However, Member States are not yet in a position to prohibit the import and marketing of FOOD and feed. The European Commission's proposal was to extend the possibilities for states, but did not guarantee the right of states to make proper use of the possibility of restricting or prohibiting the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory. The document will have to be improved and taken into account in the position of the European Parliament.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The draft Regulation 2015/0093 proposed by the European Commission was intended to allow Member States to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory. This is a noble idea based on civic freedom, but it remains impossible to achieve in the current European structures. The Commission's proposal does not provide any guidelines for the procedure and does not propose criteria that could systematise the actions taken. This means that each Member State would have a 'free hand' in introducing restrictions on imports and distribution, which, in the absence of border controls within the European Union, would inevitably cause chaos caused by uncontrolled movement of products. The absence of a homogeneous and structured action plan would also create tensions between countries supporting and opposing GMOs.  It should also be borne in mind that GM food is a relatively new topic and so far there is no scientific basis for finding that such products are harmful to human health or life. To sum up, the European Union needs uniform rules on this issue to prevent internal divisions and ensure the security of internal markets.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – The Commission's proposal is not at all clear and thus jeopardises the proper functioning of the internal market. The Commission should submit a new proposal allowing Member States to restrict the use of genetically modified food and feed in their territory.  The current proposal is not only not based on an impact study, but it also does not comply with Mr Juncker's initial commitment to review the existing rules of procedure for authorising GMOs in such a way that the Commission is no longer able to authorise GMOs when a clear majority opposes it. The Commission must propose to revise the rules for authorising GMOs in Europe to reflect the position of EU citizens.  It should no longer be possible to authorise new GMOs for cultivation or import into the Union until this promise is fulfilled.

name: Владимир Уручев (
text: PPE), in writing. – The European Parliament has consistently rejected the EC's proposal for new rules enabling Member States to restrict or prohibit on their territory the use of GM food and feed authorised by the EC. Thus, Parliament protects the public interest of all European citizens, including the Bulgarian interest.  The rules in force allow Member States to prohibit the cultivation on their territory of authorised GMOs. But when using (trading) GMOs, it goes beyond national borders because of the free movement of goods. The introduction of a ban on GMOs in an individual country means the introduction of border controls on imports of food and feed, which is contrary to the rules of the pan-European market. There are therefore no guarantees that the proposal will work in a single Europe that seeks to remove restrictions and barriers to trade. Clearly, the national approach to limiting GMOs does not provide solutions that avoid negative consequences for the single market and for the competitiveness of farmers.
