I take the view that a comprehensive new pan-European approach to managing GMOs from the process of granting marketing authorisations to their end-use is needed, based on an extensive assessment of all impacts and taking into account the restrictive policy that many countries (including Bulgaria) lead towards GMOs.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the report by James Nicholson, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on novel foods (COM(2013)0894 - C7-0487/2013 - 2013/0435(COD)) (A8-0046/2014).

name: James Nicholson
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, let me make very clear what is at stake here today. Rejecting the delegate deal with the Council and Commission would risk extending the shelf life of an old regulation that is no longer fit for purpose and that is slow to respond to market needs and safety concerns. Our agri-food sector is constantly changing, constantly adapting and improving. We must always be prepared for change. We need a legislative framework in place to keep up with the technological developments of the past 20 years. For example, with regard to nanotechnology and cell tissue cultures, the new innovations must have a proper legal framework securing food safety standards. A new, single and centralised procedure for the authorisation of novel foods and more robust data protection will provide applicants with greater legal certainty, reduce the administrative burden for SMEs and therefore encourage further innovation in the agri-food sector across Europe. It will not compromise our safety standards, which are the highest in the world, and we are rightly proud of them. On the contrary, the enhanced role for the European Food Safety Authority and increased transparency in the process can only improve these standards. The Novel Foods Regulation has had a long and arduous history. I want us to make a breakthrough today. During the negotiations on novel foods we have managed to come much further than Parliament had done in the past. I am pleased with the substantial progress that has been made on a number of issues, and I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs, the Commission and all who worked on this to bring it thus far. On nanomaterials, the definition has been moved to this regulation to reflect the safety concerns of this House, and it will be updated, by means of a delegated act, to reflect scientific progress: in other words, Parliament is being given a say on how the definition is updated. The wording on the test methods for nanomaterials has been strengthened, while taking into account environmental and consumer protection.  On the environment, this regulation should take into account a high level of protection and improvement in the quality of the environment. On animal welfare, the regulation has been strengthened in terms of animal-welfare measures, urging that testing on animals should be replaced, reduced or refined. The transparency of the process has been significantly strengthened: by obliging the Commission to publish the summary of every application and through the fact that the list of rejected applications should be publicly available. Food consisting of, isolated from, or produced from cell or tissue cultures derived from animals, plants, micro-organisms, fungi or algae is now explicitly mentioned in the scope of the regulation. The precautionary principle is explicitly mentioned in the articles as a main factor for the Commission in deciding whether to propose to authorise a novel food. A provision has also been added to align time periods with regard to data protection under the Novel Foods and Health Claims Regulations, which will act as a stimulant to innovation. The regulation also makes it easier for traditional food from one or more third countries to be placed on the internal market. This is particularly welcome for developing countries attempting to export their traditional products. Nevertheless, and quite rightly, any food imported from these third countries must meet our high quality standards. Let me also comment on two other issues. Cloning no longer belongs in this proposal. After the collapse of 2011, the Commission rightly separated out the cloning issue to different files. If you disagree with the Commission proposals, then the right place to have the debate is in relation to those files. Insisting on tackling the cloning issue here benefits no one, whatever side of the debate you are on: clearly the Council will not move on novel foods unless it moves on other files. But if the Council moves on other files it is no longer necessary to do anything on novel foods. Some did want novel food to be authorised by delegated acts, but there is a confusion here. If we are a Parliament representing the people of Europe, we have to act as a Parliament: it is up to us to set the legal framework, not to implement it. We are the legislature, not the executive branch of government. The concept of Parliament deciding on authorisations for companies seems to me a very strange one. To sum up, I want the European food sector to continue to lead rather than follow. We need legislation that can keep pace with new technologies, otherwise I greatly fear that we will be left behind.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first let me thank the rapporteur, James Nicholson, and the shadow rapporteurs, Pilar Ayuso, Pavel Poc, Marit Paulsen, Lynn Boylan, Bart Staes and Eleonora Evi, for the compromise text on novel foods we have in front of us today. I very much appreciate their hard work and commitment which has led to a good outcome. The right balance has been reached in ensuring that only safe foods may be placed on the market, while allowing for innovation in the agri-food sector. The current regulation on novel foods dates back to 1997. Over the last 18 years, scientific innovation in the food sector has progressed, giving rise to the creation of new types of food products. In parallel, consumption patterns among citizens have also changed. The Commission considers it necessary to adopt and improve an up-to-date legislative framework on novel foods to ensure food safety and to protect human health, while also facilitating the functioning of the internal market. This approach will ensure that innovation in the food sector can lead to the placing on the market of new scientifically—assessed safe foods. With a view to updating the current rules, the Commission proposes to streamline the authorisation procedure, through a centralised procedure at Commission level, by granting general authorisation and by ensuring a centralised safety assessment by the European Food Safety Authority. To improve efficiency, deadlines would be established for the evaluation and authorisation procedure, thus reducing the overall time spent on approvals. To improve transparency, the Commission would also make available on its website a summary of applications, as well as a list of applications that did not result in authorisation. This is in line with a request from this House. The safety of novel foods remains the main criterion for authorisation. The European Food Safety Authority will be systematically consulted on all questions relating to the safety of novel foods. In conclusion, innovation will be facilitated without compromising on food safety. Over the years, third countries have criticised our current rules, claiming that some foods that are traditional in their diets are considered to be novel foods in the European Union. This agreement will help us to simplify the authorisation procedure of so-called traditional foods from third countries with a history of safe use, and facilitate their placing on the market. At the same time, safety must not be compromised. To this end, if safety concerns are raised, we will ask the opinion of the European Food Safety Authority. The proposed new regulation on novel foods would contribute to innovation and facilitate market access on the agri-food sector by bringing clarity to the authorisation procedure. It would allow support for true innovators through its data protection provisions. Applicants who are able to present safety studies based on their own protected data would benefit from an individual authorisation for five years. Let me finish by again expressing my satisfaction regarding the compromise that Parliament and the Council have reached on this proposal, to which the Commission can offer its full support.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. – Mr President, the EU has a proud track record of protecting consumers’ rights and making sure that the food that ends up on our plates is safe to eat, while keeping pace with innovation. In the Committee on International Trade (INTA) of the European Parliament, we safeguarded the precautionary principle when dealing with foodstuffs that are new to us, but have traditionally been consumed safely in other countries. We called for Parliament to retain the power to veto any decision to update the list of new foods authorised to access the EU market. Without these elements, we risk losing the careful balance that we hold dear in the EU between innovation and safety. I urge colleagues from all political groups to pursue legislation that helps the EU to keep us and our food safe. We need a clear, transparent and secure framework for dealing with the new foodstuffs.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. – Mr President, first of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs on their efforts to reach agreement on novel foods.  I welcome the simplification and improvements made to the current text by generic authorisation, the shortening of the authorisation period and the facilitation of adding to the list of new foods products considered traditional in third countries. But I would also like to reiterate that food innovation must be encouraged, but not to the detriment of safety and health. I am also pleased that this dossier has been dealt with separately from that on cloning, but I hope that, at the same time, the Commission and the Council will find a way to address Parliament's requests for the proper regulation of food from cloned animals. I do not want this agreement on novel foods to lead to delays and even the abandonment of specific regulation of food from cloned animals.

name: Pilar Ayuso
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, the first thing is to thank Mr Nicholson, the shadow rapporteurs and also the Commission and the Council for the exercise of flexibility that we have all done to reach this agreement, after many hours of work. This regulation is necessary, as the Commissioner has said, because since 1997 food technology has come so far that we cannot go on, eighteen years later, without changing outdated legislation. We have already aborted an agreement from this Parliament in 2011. And today the whole agri-food sector is aware that we are responsible and support this agreement, which is good and balanced. It should be made very clear that this is not a regulation on animal cloning or nanotechnology. It is legislation that only dictates standards for classifying, scientifically evaluating and authorizing new foods that strictly meet food safety requirements. That is precisely why EFSA will be responsible for scientifically evaluating them, all with absolute transparency. The amendments tabled — which, by the way, are drawn from agreement with some additions — apparently only seek to boycott an agreement which, I repeat, is very good and balanced. On behalf of my group, and in mine, of course, I ask the House to support what has been agreed in the tripartite dialogues, making a gesture of responsibility and support for so many SMEs that are pending us.

name: Pavel Poc
text: On the part of the S&D Group. Both the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs have prepared a proposal that respects european consumers' food safety requirements, addressing doubts about the use of nanomaterials in food. The proposal, which respected consumers' right to information about what they eat and therefore defined a transitional, transitional measure on the labelling of foods derived from cloned animals or their offspring. This is how simple it is, food safety and consumers' right to information. The reactions of European consumer organisations clearly and unequivocally say that consumers want both. And what happened after that? During the trialogue, the requirement that foods produced using nanotechnologies should not be authorised until methods are available to assess their safety and those methods are not available. And even the threshold for the content of nanosed ingredients proposed by the European Food Safety Agency has disappeared. I do not know whether the European Commission always wants to respect efsa's views in this way. Ergo, the compromise proposal does not guarantee the safety of new foods for consumers. During the trialogue, the proposal to label foods derived from clones or their offspring was also lost. Ergo, this proposal tramples, in my opinion, on the right of consumers to know what they are actually eating. Of course, in no negotiation can anyone achieve everything. Of course, compromises must be reached between the European Council, the Commission and Parliament, but food safety and consumers' right to information simply must not be compromised. If the European Commission and the Council want to make such compromises, the European Parliament should not do them, which is why, in the plenary vote, we are once again proposing eight key amendments to address the shortcomings of the compromise created in the trilogues on the use of nanomaterials and information on the origin of food from cloned animals. Please note that European consumers have the right to safe food, they have the right to information, and we, as Parliament, are obliged to enable them to realise that right.

name: Bolesław G. Piecha
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by This is the second approach of the European Union, the European Parliament to the issue of novel foods. The previous one ended up rejecting the proposal in 2011. Firstly, nanotechnology and nanomaterials. It seems to me that, in mr Nicholson's report, this problem has been solved by appropriate definitions. The second thing – the approach to food from clones, and especially the offspring of animal clones. A compromise has also been reached here, because this issue will be dealt with in another legislative proposal. I call on the Commission to present this proposal as soon as possible. The third point is the question of delegated or implementing acts. We European Conservatives and Reformers are in favour of implementing acts. The most important feature is food safety, and in this case the precautionary principle should apply, but also the transparency of the application of procedures, and this legislative proposal seems to implement these demands.

name: Jasenko Selimovic
text: On the other: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Today's vote is the result of work and negotiations, which have required a lot of time and a great many meetings. I would therefore like to thank Mr Nicholson for his great work, especially given that the issue of novel foods provokes so much fear and emotion. In the course of our work, we could hear what would suffer if we accept new food. We would get a kiloof meat from cloned animals, we would eat live insects, we would be poisoned by nanomaterials, etc. etc. That is why it feels rather nice to be able to say the obvious, namely: no, that is not going to happen. If you press the YES button, very few things will happen, very few unpleasant things. You will not eat cloned animals, you will not eat foods that are not approved and tested, nor will your tongue fall off if you taste any new exotic fruit.  I promise you that the sun will rise tomorrow as well and that tomorrow we will also have people out there who think that politicians know nothing about it – I can guarantee that. What will change is that tomorrow experts will decide uniformly across the EU whether novel foods are authorised and safe. It will be determined by the help of science and not by the help of emotions. We will have a predictable European system that reduces the time and procedure for approval.  One more thing: some of us will even try a new exotic fruit, but it is not compulsory, but it can be dispensed with. I would like to conclude by thanking everyone who will press the YES button. Thank you for mastering the fear, thank you for treating new food in the same way as new medicines and thank you for showing that you are not afraid. We in the ALDE Group would like to see ourselves as such people, and that is why we will support the proposal.

name: Lynn Boylan
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work, and it is regrettable that I will vote against the novel foods legislation. The report that came from the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety Committee was good, but while this legislation is an improvement on the Council’s position, it still fails to address key concerns with the legislating of novel foods. It is imperative that the precautionary principle is front and centre in nanotechnology. We already know that these particles take on different characteristics to their bulk counterparts. There may well be benefits to the technology, but we cannot simply railroad through legislation without developing a fit-for-purpose safety risk assessment. We must have longitudinal studies on the impact of this technology on the environment and human health. I also find it worrying that if EFSA requires or requests more information from industry as part of an application and they fail to provide it, this does not warrant the automatic halting of the procedure. We are sending out a signal to industry that withholding information is OK. Surely if industries are confident in their product they would make all information available. Furthermore, giving industry the responsibility of deciding whether a food is novel is also troubling. Who will police this, and with what resources? Consumer protection must always come first, and I do not believe that this legislation does that.

name: Bart Staes
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. This is a difficult dossier, which has been on our tables for a long time. I was there from 2008 to 2011, when the dossier was on the rocks in the conciliation procedure. I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs and the rapporteur for cooperation, but as a green group we are not entirely happy with what is on the table for us. Together with the S&D, the GUE and the members of the 5-Star Movement, we have tabled some 25 amendments, which mainly revolve around two themes. The first theme concerns food applications in nanotechnology. We believe that these types of food applications should be labelled as new foods. We want rigorous testing before this kind of food is on the market. We need a definition of technically manufactured nanomaterial as well as good testing methods. The second theme concerns meat from cloned animals. In September, we rejected the Commission's proposals on this. There is now a legal void. We would like the regulation on novel foods to fill that legal void in such a way that we can give consumers an informed choice about the purchases they make, and to prevent them from buying meat from cloned animals and their descendants. That is why we have tabled these amendments. I ask members on the right of this House to support the 25 amendments of the four political groups.

name: Eleonora Evi
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the final text, the key elements introduced by the Committee on the Environment have unfortunately disappeared, and these were the elements for which we, as the 5-star Movement, had supported the opening of negotiations with the Council. We have therefore retabled these amendments, as has been said, and therefore clearly our vote will be on the basis of the final outcome of the retabled retabled amendments.  We have a very strong doubt, a very strong concern about the application of the precautionary principle, which has already been mentioned by my fellow Members. In this case, we see that the precautionary principle has been ignored in order, unfortunately, to favour the commercial interests of the large food and food companies. This is an example of which, unfortunately, we are aware and which demonstrates the interpretation given to this precautionary principle, especially with regard to nanomaterials, for which EFTA gives us a position. When we have to follow EFTA, the Commission redacts us on the case of GMOs. In this case we have not followed what we are asked to do by EFTA, and so uncertainty unfortunately remains.

name: Joëlle Mélin
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the plans before us to regulate new foods are diametrically opposed. On the one hand, the position of elected officials, who call for caution and consumer information. And on the other, that of the Council, which seems to have been phagocytated by the greed of certain agri-food and chemical industries.  Technological innovation is one of the engines of European economies. It must now begin a new revolution and be accompanied by consumer safety. Nanomaterials can obviously be very useful in some industries, but there are too many suspicions about their toxicity. With nanomaterials, we risk considerable health scandals. The French Paradox is envied all over the world, this alliance of gastronomy and health should not be attacked by a race to technology. The safety of citizens and the protection of the environment should guide all our decisions.  I therefore propose to ban nanoparticles in the diet or, at a minimum, to inform consumers by proper labelling. Similarly, everything related to children's nutrition should be subject to much stricter regulation with a firm ban on nanomaterials.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, first let me congratulate the rapporteur in this report, my colleague Jim Nicholson. This was indeed a technically difficult and politically sensitive report and it is quite a challenge to get the balance right on this one. It is an important report, reflecting the need to find a resolution which informs and protects consumers across the EU. I believe that the compromise text goes some way to providing this, and I would encourage this House to look carefully at the text before voting later on the report.  In relation to cloning, I believe that this issue should be addressed outside the remit of the report and that ongoing discussions should be based on clear scientific evidence. Products should be clearly labelled and ensure that food safety is of paramount importance. It is also important that the text of this report is reviewed regularly to take into account scientific and technical developments within the industry. This will ensure that the regulation is fit for purpose and delivers for both consumers and processors.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as chairman of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, I led Parliament's delegation to the trialogue. It has been a long, complex journey, which has also seen different positions within Parliament's delegation. And it is to my colleagues in Parliament that I would like to address them today, because the agreement we reached in the trialogue was probably the best possible agreement, and when negotiating we cannot always be sure that we will bring into the final text what are your demands, those of your political side, and your will. Something must be given up in the negotiations, and we have done so in complete openness, with internal debate, and at every step the parliamentary group, the various rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs have been confronted until a text is adopted, which is what is being put to the vote today. I understand that someone wants to return to their positions. Everyone is free to do so, the legislative path allows it. But we must be aware of one thing: we need new legislation on new foods, and since we need it, we need to make every effort to have this legislation. Today we are close to an agreement and I call on all my fellow Members, all those who have been in the trialogues, but also all my fellow Members who indirectly participated in the process, to vote for this agreement, as it came. It won't be the best, but it was the best achievable.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Speaking in the debate on novel foods, I would like to express my satisfaction that the procedure for introducing new legislation in this area – launched by the European Commission back in 2008 and continued in the new proposal of 2013 – is slowly coming to an end. Since the most controversial issues have been removed from the Commission's proposal, and the use of nanomaterials used m.in in food or food derived from cloned animals has been removed and transferred to other legal standards, only the issue of authorisation of new foods remains to be resolved. The ECR Group is in favour of a solution to ensure that they are provided by the Commission through implementing acts rather than delegated acts. Finally, I would like to express my hope that the main principle that the European Commission will follow when authoriseing new foods will be the precautionary principle. Consumer safety should be a priority for all EU institutions.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL).
text: – Europe is making a mess of food policy. This 'novel food' proposal is mainly aimed at bringing the food industry to the European market as quickly and as easily as possible. Clone meat, nanofoods, insect burgers, all things that can make big money. Attempts are still being made to protect animal welfare, food safety and the environment, but these measures are contradictory, fragmented and are often overtaken by reality. Take, for example, clone meat. The majority of European citizens and the European Parliament are opposed to animal cloning. But while a ban is still being worked on, this 'novel food' proposal can be used to authorising it.  Without a clear vision and without clear priorities, you will not get a consistent policy. Animal welfare, the environment and food safety cannot be guaranteed, and these are important European values. Surely we are not going to let the euro be the only European shared value? I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: José Bové (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, we are facing an implausible situation in Europe. More than eighty products contain nanoparticles without consumers knowing. No indication, except the small E 171 logo. That's all. It's a problem!  At the same time, the largest American doughnut company, Dunkin' Donuts, has just removed the nanoparticles from its products because there is a health risk. Will Europe continue in this situation, while EFSA itself recognises that it does not have sufficient analytical resources today to study the real consequences of nanoparticles, which are already known to pass through the cell walls and create a number of problems, especially among young people? And so we have a real problem.  What I am asking you today is that in the face of this public health risk and this environmental risk, the Commission should have the courage to ban the use of nanoparticles. I do not want tomorrow we to have the asbestos scandal and your name to be linked to this health scandal.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, the people of Britain are tired of absurd EU laws and this EU regulation on novel foods is another perfect example of the Commission obstructing the free market system economy in Europe. It is no secret that this new EU regulation on novel foods is complex, expensive and time-consuming. It is a burden for the applicants and disadvantageous to the economies of Member States, and we believe that the extremely complex EU bureaucracy is interfering in decisions that should be made in our national parliament. Why should Britain support this authorisation procedure? This proposal, which authorises the Commission to decide on the entire authorisation procedure in addition to the removal of old food categories, will compromise consumers’ confidence while causing legal uncertainty for operators. In UKIP we give absolute priority to our citizens’ health and safety and believe that Member States alone should make the initial safety assessment.

name: Annie Schreijer-Pierik (PPE).
text: – Today we are talking about the regulation on novel foods. In this context, it is important to keep the door open to new technological developments. We are going to need them if we are to continue to feed the world's population, especially in the future. The European market has become increasingly unified in recent years and I am therefore pleased that the new procedure facilitates the entry of new resources into the market. This makes it easier to market new foods such as nanotechnological products and insects. How do we want to feed our population in a sustainable way if we are not thinking about new ways and how we can achieve them? Developments in technology must, of course, be safe, but we must not rule everything out in advance. We have to give the developments I know from the Netherlands, including the University of Twente and Brabant, a chance and let it prove itself. Just having fear just gets us here. When people are guided by fear, they make the wrong decisions. The discussion must be based on facts and not emotions, and for that we need common sense. I would like to invite the critics to the Netherlands to come and see what the state of nanotechnology is.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the current novel food regulation is cumbersome and makes the approval and marketing of novel foods too slow.  The agri-food sector, on the other hand, is an evolving sector, which needs an up-to-date regulatory framework to keep up with technological developments over the last twenty years, for example with regard to nanotechnology. The text we are about to vote on today is an important step forward in this respect, which should promote innovation in the food industry through a genuine data protection system and at the same time lead to a reduction in the administrative burden and the simplification of procedures.  However, in simplifying the existing procedures for authoring novel foods, it is also necessary to ensure a high level of protection of human health and consumer interests through a systematic centralised risk assessment carried out by EFTA and strict application of the precautionary principle. We therefore need additional specific labelling requirements to safeguard consumers.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: - Madam Chairman, I would first like to thank the Rapporteur and all those who participated in the trilogue, the Council, the Commission and the Committee on Environmental Protection and Food Safety. In any case, after 18 years new rules were needed and this is clear to everyone. Technology has advanced. Today we simply have to introduce new rules.  Of course there are some doubts, but we will never remove doubts, but that's why we've included science. And that's why I'm advocating that the Food Safety Administration be fully involved. I think it's much better that it's centralized to get authorization because every country would probably have its own rules. All the time we've been striving for 28 legislatures to somehow come together, to have the same rules and to have a common market and I'm advocating that this first point. Also, simplification of obtaining evaluation, but also acceleration. It mentions one month from the moment the application for authorisation is submitted and I think that is a good suggestion.  Likewise, the definition of nanomaterials is entered into this proposal, but it is also subject to additional amendments. As science progresses, it needs to be further explained what this is all about. I simply, and being a member of the ENVI Committee where we unanimously supported this proposal, I want to support this proposal in the hope that we will also enable traditional markets, i.e. traditional products, to reach our European market.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D).
text: Madam President! Larvae, insects, fungi and algae. This is all something that we will have to eat much more of in Europe in the future for the sake of Earth's resources. New foods are called. Consumers are entitled to food sold on the EU internal market to be safe and clearly labelled, even if they are new. That is all the thinking behind the new proposal we are voting on today. We are also voting on a simplified authorisation procedure so that, for example, insects can be approved as a new source of protein. All very well. The problem is that we are also operating with new technologies in relation to our food. Unfortunately, we have not fully achieved this objective. The rules for nanotechnology, for example, are not being properly included in this legislation. It is a bit of a pity that we do not finish the job when we are at it. Food safety is our number one priority for us Social Democrats.

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has Food safety is a top priority. When novel foods come onto the market, we really need to be 100% sure that they are by no means a risk. With stricter criteria and comprehensive safety checks, we create a high level of protection for consumers. A national patchwork – And I would really like to stress this once again – makes no sense in future in the case of authorisations, because we live in an internal market and Austrians must also be subject to the same protection as citizens in Bulgaria and the other countries of the European Union. At the same time, however, we also need legal certainty, especially for innovative local businesses. The regulation for the field of process innovations is particularly important. When it comes to saving energy and achieving environmental protection goals, or when it comes to the efficient and careful use of our raw materials, it is also important to think ahead with the entire process. Innovations in food production will also help to ensure food supply in the future. We must always see this in the context of the growing world population.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D).
text: – Madam Chair, new food regulation is an important law that should err in the process of apizing and controlling new food on the European Union market. It should raise the level of consumer safety and ensure the functioning of the internal market. In short, if our citizens want to eat grasshoppers or exotic berries, these products must be health-correct and safe, but also approved according to a uniform procedure.  It can be said that these objectives have been met, but the final document did not include regulations on the carinth of cloned animals and definitions of nano-foods that would close potential legal loopholes. This can still be corrected in the afternoon of the vote, but it remains to be seen how the majority in Parliament will be set. We have the opportunity to pass a good law that will benefit our citizens and entrepreneurs, and that is why it would be a shame to miss this opportunity.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab At the outset, I would like to point out that I was pleased to welcome the resumption of the debate on new food. Innovation in the food market can be a source of growth and new jobs. These objectives are perfectly in place for the Europe 2020 strategy. However, it should be borne in mind that action in this area brings not only opportunities, but also challenges.  I am of the opinion that it is particularly important to improve the authorisation procedure for the placing on the market of novel foods and to ensure that these rules are consistent with other EU policies. It is also worth stressing the importance of reliable information provided by Member States and food business operators. Let's remember that at stake in this game is the health of consumers. Every effort must therefore be made to ensure that the food we place on the market is completely safe and meets the criteria set out in EU regulations.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would first like to congratulate Mr Nicholson, the rapporteur, and the shadow rapporteurs on a great deal of work done. The current legislation is from 1997, as mentioned, almost nineteen years. There have certainly been technological changes that need to be taken into account and therefore adapt our regulations to strengthen our food sectors. Rejecting, ladies and gentlemen, this agreement jeopardizes the establishment of an appropriate legal framework for our agricultural sectors in Europe. It is a regulation, as other colleagues have said before, in high demand. Today we are here in the final stage, after a very controversial start in 2011, and so far; and I want to expressly support these commitments contained in the agreement. I trust in European guarantee systems and believe that the adoption of this more than reasonable agreement should not be jeopardized.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, as I argued in the previous debate, I am strongly opposed to any use of genetically modified organisms. That is why I support a complete ban on genetically modified foods, cloned animals, mutant feed and proteins from genetically modified sources. I therefore support labelling everywhere so that consumers have knowledge of what they are eating. These principles also apply to new foods, which cannot be the backdoor for mutants to enter our lives. The precautionary principle should be strictly applied to both new foods and nanomaterials and nanoparticles and insects. We must also oppose TTIP, because it paves the way for mutants, as the United States has not signed the most important international conventions to ban mutants. Therefore, yes to scientific innovation, to new foods, provided that consumers' health is safeguarded and that mutants are completely banned. And these are not guaranteed by this Regulation.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, the key question of this debate is not whether someone will enjoy insects, algae, whether they will eat products produced by nanotechnology, but whether these products will be safe and secondly, more importantly, will consumers know what they are eating? I personally don't want us eating meat from cloned animals. I am very skeptical of GMO foods and everything that has to do with GMO and animal cloning, but I am not against research, as in this case I am not against research, but I am in for it, and it has to be our obligation, that we tell consumers what they will come across when they buy a product. What product is that? What does this product have in it? What contains the product and what reactions can be for the organism when using such a product? That's the key to this discussion.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I agree that it is essential to modernise the existing regulation on new food in a way that reflects technological and scientific progress with a view to more adequately protecting the health of citizens. However, this proposal for a regulation contains several positive changes, among which I would highlight in particular a centralised authorisation process that will reduce administrative burdens and unnecessary additional costs.  However, as the primary objective of revising this Regulation is to ensure food safety, I cannot support its adoption as a precautionary principle. The inclusion of food consisting of manufactured nanomaterials is unacceptable as current knowledge of them does not allow the risk to human health to be assessed and there is no clear definition at European level. In conclusion, in order to preserve the health of EUROPEAN Union citizens, we need to strongly support traditional food production, but in a sustainable way, not consciously allow products of questionable quality to be consumed with a risk to consumers.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: "Thank you very much to my compatriot for the opportunity. Madam President, I would like to thank you for The summation of this debate, I think, is broadly that Parliament would like to support this whole initiative, although I do feel that there are many reservations in many of us. I would like to mention some of these.  Europe is rich. Europe is 100 years old, looking for the future. Nevertheless, let us not forget that when we think at the level of traditional food, one-five of Europe is starving at the same time. I am not sure that either Parliament or other European institutions will have to devote so much energy to matters that actually only serve the interests of a very narrow strata throughout Europe. I think that at least as much should be addressed to the hungry, not least children, who are perhaps more on the eastern side of Europe.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, you have heard my explanations setting out the Commission’s views on this proposed new regulation on novel food. I have also listened to the views of this House with great interest. I was a little bit surprised to hear comments from some Members on the issues of cloning. I think that two issues are now clearly distinct. The Commission has proposed separate legislation on the specific issue of cloning and Members commented on it last September. This legislation is only about novel foods and does not affect cloning at all. The right of information for consumers, as was mentioned, already exists in the Regulation on food information to consumers. The new nanotechnology definition will be based on science. There will be an obligation to label the presence of nanotechnologies. Therefore, only safe nanotechnologies will be allowed. The EFSA opinion will be labelled in all cases. It is important to reach an agreement on these new rules in order to contribute to innovation in the agri-food sector without compromising on food safety. I believe that the text in front of us fully achieves these goals and I therefore fully support it.

name: James Nicholson
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, can I add my thanks to all those who took part in this debate. It has been very useful and I would again like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs. This was a particularly delicate file to try to move forward and it was not easy at times. We had tremendous difficulties and it was tough, but during that tough time we acted in a very professional way and I pay tribute to them. Can I also pay a special tribute to Mr La Via, the Chair of the Committee, for his sterling work and his role in finding a way forward.  It is time to move forward. We simply cannot risk extending the shelf life of an existing out-of-date regulation, so it is time, in my opinion, to move forward. I know there are many concerns about cloning but that is the responsibility of others; that is the responsibility of another file. Quite clearly, on nanomaterials, the definition has been moved to reflect safety concerns of Parliament and will be updated to reflect a scientific process through a delegated act. That is the reality.  Can I say that I appreciate the concern on labelling but in the regulation, in the relevant article, it is clear. The words used are that it should be ‘appropriately labelled for the final consumer’. What more safety do we want in labelling for the final consumer?  So I think we have brought forward a good report with tremendous difficulty, highly technical, something that Europe needs and requires. To those who say it is over-regulation, I am afraid on this occasion this is good regulation that will allow the industry, the small industry, to move forward. I would say to UKIP, as a parting stance, that as the small and medium-sized enterprises in the UK need this probably more than any other part of Europe, I hope they may change their mind or whatever they may want to do.

name: elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 28 October 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Laurenţiu Rebega (ENF)
text: in writing. – I believe that transparent and clear legislation on novel foods is absolutely necessary. The free movement of new food products that are consumer-safe is an essential aspect of the progress of the European market. I am not against new foods that have the capacity to ensure a high level of protection of the health of the population, especially among children, but I would like to point out the need to implement EU legislation on these foods which, in my opinion, must comply with stricter rules than conventional or traditional foods. I welcome EU legislation on novel foods or foods produced through the use of new technologies and production processes. The EU has a moral and legal obligation to establish clear information rules whereby food producers inform consumers as thoroughly as possible about the technologies used and the provenance of the raw materials used to obtain these new foods.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. – Mr Nicholson's report raises an important question about the legal regulation of the so-called new food, food and other products, which are placed on the market for the first time. The revision of the Council of Europe Regulation is a particularly sensible step in this case and is undoubtedly necessary to maintain a high level of health protection and consumer interests. Technological progress in recent years has shown that current concepts of food ingredients are outdated. This is why it is important that the new provisions take account in particular of the safety aspects of products, so that any new food products do not have harmful effects on the consumer when they are introduced on the market. It should also be borne in mind whether the molecular structure of food is or is not modified in any way. In this way, we will avoid uncertainty about GMO products, which I believe must be eliminated from the European food market. In no case may new laws and new concepts become tools for their legalisation. One more thing that we need to remember: new laws cannot be introduced without prior consultation with local producers, experts and other actors in this area, so that action that would in any way harm the intersceptions of European farmers can be avoided, because we are particularly committed to protecting them.

name: elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Julie Girling on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety on the proposal for emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants (COM(2013)0920 - C7-0004/2014 - 2013/0443(COD)) (A8-0249/2015).

name: Julie Girling
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, Europe needs to take action to clean up its air. That is the key message of the review of the NEC Directive that will be voting on in a couple of hours. We need to set ambitious targets on key pollutants taking us forward to 2030 and beyond. The reason why is obvious, but let me spell it out: air pollution is the number one environmental cause of death in the EU. Over 400 000 of our citizens die prematurely each year and millions more suffer debilitating illness, medication and hospitalisation. This has an enormous human and economic cost: tens of billions of euros in days lost at work, and even more spent on health care bills. Air pollution also hits the natural environment through eutrophication and acid deposition. So, in December 2013, the Commission published its clean air package, which includes the NEC Directive. The central plank of the proposal is the setting of emissions reductions targets in all Member States for 2030, for six pollutants. This proposal was accompanied by a 352-page impact assessment. This file has had a difficult passage through the process. Parliament agreed to commission an additional impact assessment of our own, which was finally published in October 2014, after the European elections. At the same time, the Commission’s Work Programme suggested that they were considering withdrawing the whole proposal, and a lot of time and effort went into ensuring that this did not happen. I still feel strongly, as your rapporteur, that this is a key issue that is best tackled at EU level. Air pollution does not stop at Member State borders. I passionately believe that better regulation and good air quality are not mutually exclusive, and this is why I fought so hard to keep this proposal alive. This is a very important point for me because, having invested so much time and political capital into making sure the proposal stayed on the table, it really is imperative that we vote responsibly today, finding a consensus that garners broad support on all the key issues. That means not supporting the Environment Committee’s position on lower ceilings across all pollutants, and supporting amendments on ammonia. There will be very many people here who will say that this is not ambitious enough, that we need to push further, but I would like them to take another look at the facts. The proposal I am supporting delivers a 52% improvement in health outcomes. It rejects the Commission’s proposed flexibility for shipping, has added mandatory targets for 2025 on all pollutants, offers vastly improved access to justice for citizens affected by poor air quality, as well as improvements on national air pollution control programs and reporting. This will help all levels of government in Member States, including the regional and sub-regional authorities that have engaged so vigorously in the lobbying process.  Frankly, this is the first time that I have ever experienced this so starkly with regional authorities: a real bottom-up demand for action. My report pushes the Commission to ensure that the RDE legislation is agreed as soon as possible. We all agree that NOx must be dealt with urgently. The public are demanding action in this area following the recent revelations from the car industry. What about agriculture? Across Europe farmers are concerned about demands to decrease output of ammonia. If they are going to achieve this, they will need help, both technically and financially. That is why I have proposed an amendment asking for a review of ammonia targets by 2022 in line with scientific evidence and a new article on access to funding, calling on the Commission to support farmers through its mid-term review of CAP  greening. So, to those of you who are thinking of voting for even tougher targets, let me just say: think very carefully. We do not currently have a position from Council on this file. We do know that many Member States, including some of the biggest, have not yet presented their positions. They are waiting for this plenary vote to see where Parliament will go, so let us not signal intransigence. Let us not choose political grandstanding. Let us not play to the gallery. The EP should be ambitious, but also pragmatic. Let us strike the right balance and get this dossier moving quickly towards trialogue. I do not want to be responsible for any more delay – let us give our citizens a rapid route to improved air quality. It is what they demand, and it is what they deserve.  Finally, can I just say a big thank you to all the shadow rapporteurs, thank you for your help, and a special mention for Kateřina Konečná from the GUE/NGL Group who cannot be with us today as she delivered her baby boy a few days ago. I am sure we all wish to send her our congratulations. (Applause)

name: elnök asszony. –
text: Thank you, Congresswoman, and congratulations to the newborn. Welcome to us.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, even though air pollution in the European Union has significantly decreased over the recent decades, we still have a very long way to go. As Julie Girling has already pointed out, more than 400 000 people die prematurely every year because of poor air quality, not to mention the increasing number of chronic respiratory diseases.  The severe air pollution episodes in north-west Europe in the spring once again demonstrated that pure air is as much an environmental as a health concern. We breathe polluted air even if we cannot often see or smell it. The situation is unacceptable. However, it is avoidable. This is why I am so keen for us to make progress in the negotiations on the Directive on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants.  This proposal is a key part of the Commission’s clean air policy package and an important deliverable for the 7th Environment Action Programme. Every month that passes we are delaying the implementation of policies that could save lives, that could reduce respiratory problems and that could reduce the cost of health care and absenteeism from work. That is why I very much hope that we – meaning Parliament, the Council and the Commission – can come to a viable agreement during a possible first reading.  I will take this opportunity to thank and congratulate the rapporteur, Julie Girling, and her colleagues from the Environment Committee for their commitment and for their hard work on the proposal. I would also like to acknowledge the opinions of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy and Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development.  To maintain their chances of first reading agreement, it will be very important that the positions of the co-legislators do not diverge too much. The Commission proposal is a well-balanced package and represents a major reduction in health impacts of 52% by the year 2030. These figures are supported by a solid and a substantial impact assessment, by scientific evidence and by cost-benefit analysis. To give the best prospects of early resolution I would ask Parliament, as I have already asked the Council in June, to support the level of ambition in the Commission’s proposal. To achieve this, efforts are needed from all sectors.  The cost of current legislation falls almost entirely on industry, transport and households. Only 2% of these large costs fall on agriculture. To move forward, sectors that have so far contributed little will need to do more. Agricultural emissions make the largest relative contribution to PM2.5 in Europe through ammonia emissions. For instance, the major air pollution problem in Paris in the spring of 2014 was predominantly caused by agricultural pollution.  It is important to counter some claims being made on the impact of agriculture. There is no need to change to structure of the agriculture sector. No action is needed from small farms, and there is no need to push for intensification or to reduce animal numbers. We focus on applying good practice and existing technology in large industrial farms, while providing support for implementation under the rural development programme.  With regards to methane, where some Members have concerns, this is increasingly driving background concentration of ground-level ozone in the EU, and has a strong climate impact. The proposed reductions will help us argue for similar reductions across the hemisphere. To conclude, the Commission proposal represents a balanced and a cost-effective distribution of effort. The implementation costs are far outweighed by the benefits to society, including reduced healthcare costs, increased productivity and opportunities for new jobs in a developing green economy. Together we can deliver a major improvement to the health of the European Union citizen. So I would like to invite Members to support the proposal before them.

name: Adam Gierek
text: draft opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. "Our goal is: clean, poison-free air, eco-innovation, the protection of natural capital, new green technologies. Extending restrictions to non-perpetuating greenhouse gases is a misunderstanding. Limiting methane emissions will disrupt the functioning of the agricultural sector. The restrictions should apply only to poisonous emissions, e.g. ammonia, but only in compact areas. Poisons emitted into the atmosphere operate locally and their averaging by including overseas territories, i.e. the so-called flexibility in accrual, is a clear scam. It is important to update nitrogen oxide emission limits on the market for used diesel cars, especially in central and eastern European countries. The project omitted emissions that extremely pollute the local atmosphere, i.e. 'low emissions', as well as health-threatening nanoparticles. Gas poison such as hydrogen sulfide was also omitted.

name: Jan Huitema
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. – European air quality is affected by methane emissions in third countries. That is why the European Commission has chosen to include methane in the NEC directive to show the rest of the world that the EU has a clear methane target.  However, I do not believe that this is the right instrument. For me, the following arguments are reason enough to vote methane from the proposal. Number one: methane is primarily a greenhouse gas and is therefore already regulated through the climate targets. Two, methane emissions have already been reduced by almost a third in Europe. Three: through the feed we can reduce methane emissions from ruminants such as cows and sheep, but the only way to actually capture methane is by putting animals back in the barn, even though society is asking for the animals to be left out. Four: biologically kept animals in particular emit more methane because they are rationed differently. Five: it is agriculture that can play a very important role in reducing greenhouse gases, despite methane emissions. Through organic matter, agriculture ensures that CO2 is absorbed into the soil. So we achieve exactly what we want if we give agricultural entrepreneurs the space and flexibility to achieve the realistic objective.

name: Jens Gieseke
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has As shadow rapporteur for the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, I would like to express my sincere thanks to the rapporteur, Julie Girling, and all the shadow rapporteurs for their good cooperation. I think we agree on the fundamental objective: we need to improve air quality in Europe in order to protect the health of our citizens. In the difficult, sometimes very technical negotiations, we have been able to find a whole series of compromises, which are supported by almost all the political groups. However, there are some key points on which there is a need for improvement from the PPE-DE point of view. The tightening of the already ambitious reduction targets resulting from the vote in the Committee on the Environment is unacceptable.  The opinions of the Committee on Agriculture and the Committee on Industry have not been sufficiently taken into account. Both committees are calling for methane to be removed from the scope of the directive, as methane should also be regulated through climate policy. Mr Huitema has just rightly pointed this out.  The very ambitious reduction targets for ammonia remain unacceptable and will lead to significant disadvantages for European agriculture. We therefore call on the Commission to review this and to call for achievable appropriate targets for a balanced approach between better air quality and maintaining the competitiveness of our agriculture.  Not that we are misunderstood by some colleagues: the PPE-DE is not opposed in principle to the inclusion of mercury in the scope of the directive. But our policy should be based on a sound impact assessment, and we are also calling for it to be used for the inclusion of mercury.  Goals must be realistic and achievable. With this in mind, I hope that we will be able to find a balanced approach and then start negotiations with the Council quickly.  (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Peter Jahr (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Gieseke, I would like to thank Mr Gieseke for his work on this I still have a demand for methane reduction. Many letters from the profession have reached us. My question is: can one goal of methane reduction really be reconciled with the other objective of increasing animal welfare? What is your view on this?

name: n/a
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Thank you very much, Mr Jahr. A good question. I think it is very difficult to reduce methane. Stables with exhaust air systems would have to be built. It may be possible to intervene in animal populations and simply reduce the number of animals. I do not think that is in the interests of animal welfare.

name: Seb Dance
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work on this issue, and also the shadow rapporteurs. Although we have not always agreed on everything, the spirit in which we conducted our conversations has been amicable and productive. I would like to thank the S&D secretariat, and Emily Iona in particular for all her work, as well as my fantastic, wonderful office, and Alex Keynes in particular for his superlative work on this issue. This is an issue that has never been higher on the public agenda or in terms of public awareness. It is not 400 000 but closer to 700 000 Europeans who are dying every year from the effects of the poisonous air that we are breathing. If you think about that over a decade, that is some 7 million people. That is the population of Bulgaria. The human cost in terms of lost loved ones and the loss of human life is obvious, but the economic cost is also there. It runs into hundreds of billions of euros. Quite simply, the cost of doing nothing far outweighs the cost of getting to grips with this issue. That is why we are here today, supporting strong, binding and – crucially – linear targets to reduce the harmful emittents; legal tools to hold governments that do not comply to account; extra powers for local authorities; additional standards on vehicle testing; and – here is the vital point – a principle that every contributing sector must play its part in reducing harmful emissions. This is a good directive and it deserves the support of the whole House. We are an amazing, adaptive species. We have conquered diseases, we have extended our life expectancy and we have even landed on the moon. I refuse to believe that it is beyond our wit to grow our economies, travel the world and farm our land without poisoning the air. If we set ourselves this ambition, there is no limit to what we can achieve. Let us do the right thing today and combine comprehensive ambition with comprehensive action.  (Applause)

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I have reservations about the report. The proposed limits are unacceptable. The most important caveat concerns methane. I would remind you that it is covered by the climate package. Additional regulation will place too much burden on the agricultural sector. The reduction of the population of meat, dairy and pig cattle will not only take place in my country – Poland, but also in other EU countries. It is estimated that in Poland the reduction of the beef cattle population can reach up to 42% and dairy cattle up to 24%. In recent years, the decline in cattle breeding in Poland has been significant and the deepening of this phenomenon will be very detrimental to Polish and European farmers. Methane should therefore be excluded from the Directive. I have tabled amendments deleting methane and I ask you very much to support my amendments.

name: Catherine Bearder
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, this is a serious issue so let us all take a deep breath. But the air in here is not what all our citizens have to breathe on a daily basis. When we think about air pollution, we think of the short-term episodes in big cities like Paris and London. The reality, however, is much, much worse.  Air pollution across Europe kills 10 times more people than all road traffic accidents. More people die from poor air quality than from smoking. Poor air circulates around us all and is as likely in the countryside as it is in the cities. In my own country, the UK, it is estimated that 55 000 people are dying from poor air quality every year. Ninety percent of all Europeans living in cities are exposed to levels of air pollution deemed damaging to human health. I supported a high level of ambition during the committee stage and will continue to do so today. This is based on robust evidence commissioned by this House, which showed that we can prevent more people dying prematurely. Governments must step up their efforts to comply with better air pollution measures, and the 2025 targets mean Member States can start planning now. This is not just an issue with the motor trade, but VW has highlighted to the public what is happening to the air we all breathe. So it is important that every part of our economies take action to share the load to make the air cleaner and safer in Europe by 2030. Ammonia emissions must be addressed. Delaying action on this simply causes more pollution.  This is not designed to target any one sector unfairly, and that includes agriculture. We must all play our part. We also need the quick introduction of emissions tests under real driving conditions across the whole of Europe. The Volkswagen scandal has shown that Europeans do care deeply about air quality, and we here must help them all breathe much more easily.

name: Merja Kyllönen
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you all for their good cooperation. Air quality in Europe has not achieved its objectives, although the degrading effects of poor air quality and the state of the environment have been known for a long time. New research results, which are already of concern, are constantly being published. Of course, we still have to remember that the current diesel gate is not helping at all.  Is it not time, ladies and gentlemen, to take concrete emission reduction decisions? The health of European people and our environment now need our help. Set binding emission reduction targets for 2025. In addition to conventional sulphur dioxide and nitrogen oxides, ammonia, methane and mercury are included. But fine particles, which, based on increased research results, are also more harmful than once thought. European citizens deserve better than they are at present. Let's do it for the people.

name: Bas Eickhout
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur, Julie Girling, for the very good cooperation we enjoyed. We might disagree on some issues in relation to air quality policies, but Ms Girling was a fair negotiator and a fair rapporteur, and we were able to reach a good position in the Committee on Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. That is the position we will defend here in the plenary vote. What the Environment Committee has produced is balanced, ambitious and pragmatic, and that is very important. We are here to fight to keep up that stance in order to open negotiations with the Member States.  I would like to mention two issues. The first is the higher ambition level. We have a European Parliament impact assessment available showing that, with the same cost effectiveness, we can reduce our emissions more, and deliver more on public health. That finding has been reached with an impact assessment. People are always complaining that we just come up with numbers and put them where we like: well, this has been done on the basis of research. I think that is a very good thing, and we support the higher ambition level based on research.  On the second point, agriculture, it is fascinating to hear that everyone is talking about air quality and the fact that we need source policies and that all sectors need to contribute, so for the first time we are addressing agriculture – and immediately there is a major lobby out there to get rid of any action in relation to agriculture. I have a major problem with that: every sector needs to contribute, and certainly also agriculture. We are looking forward to the negotiations after this vote.

name: Piernicola Pedicini
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank my colleagues in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy for the improvements that have been made to the text, given that we are deciding whether tens and tens of thousands of European citizens should live or die in the coming years. A formality, in short. Yet, as usual, a myriad of amendments arrive in plenary aimed at watering down the position of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, because governments are demanding unrealistic and unattainable objectives. Look at the lack of will to tackle the problem of air quality decisively and therefore climate change will also weaken a possible ambitious agreement at the next climate conference in Paris.  The European Union must decide whether it wants to continue to favour the affairs of a few, or whether it wants to protect the health of hundreds of millions of citizens. The European Union must decide whether it wants to have worse EU rules than China' s, or not. This is not a struggle between businessmen and environmentalists, between industrialists and farmers. This is a question of civilization that concerns the state of the planet that we will leave to our children.

name: Mireille D'Ornano
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, improving air quality is certainly a very ambitious goal. There are also effective tools to reduce the emission of certain air pollutants, and that is the whole point of this directive. I would therefore like to thank the rapporteur, Julie Girling, for her work and her spirit of conciliation. The implementation evaluation framework is built on the Member States themselves, not just on the whole of the Union, and in a homogeneous manner. I therefore insist that this flexibility be maintained.  Nevertheless, pollution reduction targets must not overwhelm our economic interests. The inclusion of methane in this text seems to me, as such, very questionable. That is why our group has tabled amendments against increasing this regulation with methane, which will weigh on our agricultural sector and add a ball to the feet of our farmers. This issue of methane should be dealt with separately. In general, I think we should be wary of texts that cover too many areas.

name: Peter Liese (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Of course, we have a huge problem with air quality. And when scientific studies tell us that more than 400 000 people die prematurely every year because our air is not clean, then we have to do something. That is why we were proud together that we managed to keep this proposal alive. A year ago, the majority of the Commission was determined to withdraw it, and we managed to keep it on the table. I believe that we should think back on this when we vote at noon today. Because we in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats see the danger that the tightening up of the majority in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Energy will put us back in a situation where, in the end, we will achieve nothing, where the forces that do not want the regulation will prevail because they say that Parliament is exaggerating. And I think that in some places Parliament is even going too far. When I look at the proposal for ammonia: 2025 for my country, which I know best, Germany, 46% reduction. Environmental experts, who are really very green, say that 33% can be achieved realistically. So, the committee is overshooting the mark. I would therefore ask colleagues to be essentially guided by the Commission's proposal. That is also the red line for the PPE-DE. Unfortunately, if there are tightening swells, we will not be able to participate any more, for many reasons. We are prepared to do something about mercury, but only if an impact assessment has been carried out. I hope that we will immediately get a large majority in favour of a text that is close to the Commission's proposal and which rejects the unrealistic demands of the Committee on the Environment. Thank you very much!

name: Matthias Groote (S&D).
text: Thank you very much, Madam President. Air pollution is a huge problem. I just remember that a few days ago everyone said about the emissions scandal: there must be stronger regulations, something needs to be done at this point. Now, before we even enter into negotiations with the Council, some here in Parliament are already on the brake pedal. It has to be said that I am very surprised by this.  Everyone recognises that we have 400 000 premature deaths in the European Union. The difference between the Commission and the European Parliament, that is 43 000 deaths, with what the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy has discussed and then decided. That is why we should maintain this level and fight for it in the negotiations. We must certainly be willing to compromise. I believe that this is every group here. But we should not go into sack and ashes beforehand and throw all levels of ambition overboard. On the subject of mercury, my heartfelt request is that we take a sensible decision today.  The Commission has ten years. The Commission has also taken the time to deal with real driving emissions. In this respect, I have great hope that, in ten years' time, we will be able to implement very clear rules on mercury, as we have already done with industrial emissions. But there must also be control: what are the most useful decisions on paper if there are no checks at the end of the day and that everything is just a paper tiger? Therefore, a heartfelt request: take mercury with you!

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for This House is constantly making the same mistake: it commits itself to objectives that are then not achieved because they cannot be achieved. In the Pargneaux report, the S&D Group has already ensured that the agreed targets for energy efficiency have suddenly been increased from 27% to 40%. Today we are talking about the Girling report. And what happens? The Greens and Sozis have once again raised some limit values to completely unrealistic levels. You consciously accept that there is no agreement, ladies and gentlemen, and an agreement is needed on emissions. Incidentally, this also applies to the meeting now in Paris. Parliament is jeopardising the legislative process, I would like to point this out. Incidentally, ladies and gentlemen, now comes my ceterum censeo, I believe that the single euro in Europe leads to strife and discord and must therefore be abolished. (Laughter)

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, we must be blunt against greenhouse gas emissions. Moreover, if the European Union is to be credible at the Paris summit, it needs to regulate methane emissions as soon as possible, which cause respiratory and cardiovascular diseases and significantly damage farmland in Mediterranean countries. What is at risk is the health of the planet, of the people and, also, do not forget, the bread of many farmers and fishermen. It is not enough for this report to be adopted, either. Compliance must be monitored. I therefore demand that the European Commission fulfil its functions, not as it did with the Volkswagen case. Because it is also useless for governments such as the PP to come here to Brussels to tell him to move olympically from the commitments made so that diesels can pollute 43% more. So, therefore, we're going to stop patting each other on the back. Let us be demanding with accountability and that they pay responsibilities, whoever is and who falls. What is in the future is the health of our planet, which is the only home we have.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, I would like to congratulate Ms Girling for the hard work that she has done on this report. We, in my party, share her concern about SOx and NOx and particulates, because unlike CO2 they are indeed genuine pollutants that damage human health. However, unlike Ms Girling, we take the view that these decisions and these targets should be taken and set by democratically elected parliaments at the national level, and not by unrepresentative, unaccountable bureaucratic institutions in foreign countries. In December we have the UN Climate Conference in Paris. Even the IPCC has recognised the importance of inviting proposals from independent countries rather than imposing them top down. This EU plan has different targets for different pollutants in different countries. What more evidence do we need that this should be done at the national level and should not be done at the European level? We in my country know that we shall not have the right to make those decisions until Britain leaves the European Union.

name: Olaf Stuger (ENF).
text: – I am a calm and optimistic person. But if the European Commission is going to interfere with figures, and in this case with the control and standards of emissions, then I will have the clammy fear sweat. Because it is precisely this Commission that has been messing around and fiddling with numbers for 20 years. After all, how seriously can you take an institution that has not once received approval of its expenditure from its own Court of Auditors in the last 20 years? It's like asking Robert Mugabe to control elephant stocks in Africa. Totally hopeless. And this proposal, too, has no chance.

name: Andrzej Grzyb (PPE).
text: – We will be voting in a moment on this important air protection directive, a directive that aims to set emission ceilings for certain pollutants for Member States. This is one of our objectives, our priorities, but as always, the ambitions that we want to adopt in the new regulations should be able to be met by the economies. They should not be excessive burdens, in particular in terms of costs.
