I myself was the rapporteur for the recently adopted directive from the same clean air package, which concerned medium-sized energy combustion centres. The work on that directive has succeeded in balancing ambitious environmental objectives and economic opportunities. The most controversial provisions in the proposed directive concern restrictions on methane emissions. These reductions, carried out in an ill-thought-out manner, may jeopardise agricultural production. Mr Wiśniewska and Mr Gieseke also spoke about this. Methane is excreted in the atmosphere in animal production. This could hit the livestock sector not only in Poland, but in many Member States. Methane emissions are also covered by climate legislation. My political group has tabled amendments here. I also wanted to draw attention to one aspect: the directive reduces emissions of nitrogen oxides and dust, and an important source of both pollutants is transport, mainly cars, including diesel cars, which we discussed in the previous session. So we need to have a real assessment here of the reality, of the proposed solutions, so that they can be met by the Member States and that the economy can meet.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, despite what I hear, what we are hearing from the extreme right and the extreme right of our Chamber, yes, there is an emergency, seven million people die every year because of air pollution, 600,000 people in Europe die every year because of air pollution. Therefore, this revision is welcome not only for health reasons but also for climatic reasons. It is, I believe, welcome to a few weeks from the COP 21 that we are organising in Paris. Putting limits on our polluting emissions, as well as reducing our CO2 emissions, are the milestones of this new society that we want to build. Changing our society, changing the way we organize our agriculture, the way we reuse our waste to organize a circular economy: that's how we'll get the low-carbon society we want.

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR).
text: – Clean air is literally vital. Air pollution is a truly dangerous assassin and we know that thousands of people in Europe die prematurely every year from particulate matter. It is therefore important that we set stricter standards, especially for particulate matter.  At the same time, we must not fall into the trap of unnecessary regulation. Substances such as methane are already regulated in the climate package and I find double regulation undesirable. Above all, let us enforce existing rules. That's really crucial. At the same time, we still need to puzzle over where the boundaries should be and ask ourselves whether they are really feasible. It must not be the case that Dutch cows will soon no longer be able to stand in the meadow, because Europe has introduced an ill-conceived rule. Cows should be able to stand in the meadow and eat fresh grass instead of being inside the barn and chewing imported soya. Clean air should, but no unnecessary regulation.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE).
text: – Mr President, in the midst of all this debate, it is worth remembering that air quality in Europe has improved significantly over the last few decades. But we still have major problems: in many cities, air quality is heavily polluted and people suffer from fine particulate matter emissions. It is therefore a major problem in Europe.  We can do a great deal, both in the areas of energy, transport, agriculture and urban planning. This is the responsibility of both cities and Member States, but we know that European and international action is also needed, because air pollution knows no borders. However, the measures taken must be as effective and cost-effective as possible. There are four grievances in this motion that I would like to highlight, many of which have already been mentioned here. One of these is methane. There is a risk of overlapping regulation, bureaucracy, because methane is also treated as greenhouse gas emissions. As a result, overlapping regulation should be avoided. The second maladministration is related to ammonia. In this respect, the regulations are far too high and unrealistic in this respect.  Thirdly, I would like to highlight the mercury that Parliament has added to this. Mercury is certainly a problem in terms of air pollution and air quality, but there is no good legislation to add mercury to this proposal without a proper impact assessment. We must be as effective and effective as possible. I would also like to highlight Parliament's addition of the binding target for 2025. It would be realistic to consider 2025 as such a period of time and aim for 2030.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D).
text: – Fil-fatt qabel ma ġejna għal dan id-dibattitu ħafna go analizzaw il-kwalità tal-arja fit-toroq tagħna, u r-riżultati kienu xokkanti immaħertament mhux sorprendenti. L-arja ta' madwarna m'hijiex nadifa, u l-karozzi fit-toroq tagħna jikkontribwixxu bil-kbir għal dan. Imma nistgħu ma nistgħux nagħżlu fejn nieħdu nifs, imma nistgħu nagħmlu l-almu kollu tagħna biex nillimitaw il-ħsara li ssir. It-teknoloġija biex ikollna karozzi aktar nodfa teżisti u tiswa ftit mijiet ta' euro, madwar tliet mitt euro biex inkun pre大iża. Dan ikeertament li huwa prezz baxx ikkumparat mal-kważi disa' mitt biljun euro li jintefqu f'kura għas-saħħa u f'telf ta' produttività madwar l-Unjoni Ewropea. U dan minbarra li rridu testijiet li jikkalkulaw b'mod reali kemm il-karozzi jniġġsu fit-toroq tagħna. I大-大ittadini jixirqilhom u għandhom dritt għal arja nadifa, huma fejn huma, f'liema pajjiż u f'liema belt jgħixu. Imma biex nagħmlu din id-differenza fil-ħajja ta大-ħdini tagħna, irridu nkunu ambizzjużi u naġixxu proprju issa.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: – On the one hand, the European Commission is fighting ammonia, methane, fine, particulate particles and, on the other hand, it supports agriculture, which produces precisely these emissions, with EUR 60 billion a year. The European Commission is fighting against something that it also supports. This is an excellent example of the european Commission's insu conceptuality and non-systemicity. Moreover, the European Union is once again trying to save the whole world. He wants to be a global leader in environmental goals, he wants to save all the migrants who go around, he's been saving Greece for years, he wants the economy to grow and debt to fall. This is incompatible. This is what only Euroromantics can want, torn from reality. Yes, let us protect the environment, but the European Union does not have to come first, as long as it has so many other problems.

name: Karl-Heinz Florenz (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Yes, my dear colleague, it would have been very nice if you had made a few contributions on how we can regulate air quality in Europe.  That is exactly what the Commission has done. Mrs Girling has done this very neatly and I believe that between the two proposals lies the sensible path that we must take in Europe.  Health policy should not always be treated so disly. Many people suffer. In my country, mr ECR, an additional 8 000 cars are registered every day – in addition! It should be quite clear that we have to talk about the air, without being a world savior. I think it is a normal realistic policy to move. Industry is already heavily involved in many other areas. I believe that, in this case, we must come to the principle that we need more shoulders. One of these more shoulders is agriculture, which we should not leave out completely, but must be given a feasible regulation that farms can bear. That is what I would like to do. This must also be covered by structural funds.  95% of the ammonia comes from agriculture. I am a farmer myself and I know that this is not a pleasant task. But we have to work on this: fair and realistic. I would like to agree to this and would like to support the main corridor between the Commission and Mrs Girling.

name: Jytte Guteland (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for This is, as many have pointed out, both a climate reform and a health reform. Ladies and gentlemen, let us not forget that it is precisely a health reform. Every year – as many have scored – hundreds of thousands of people die prematurely in the EU, and in Sweden, five thousand people die prematurely as a result of air pollution. We spend billions in health care to try to save lives when it is sometimes too late. It is therefore important that we work preventively to save lives in the future. This is also a climate reform – many have also mentioned this. Methane is actually one of the most dangerous greenhouse gases. If we are serious about us wanting to be a Union that takes responsibility for climate policy, then we must also regulate methane in a sensible way. Here we have the chance to do so – let us not lose it.

name: Annie Schreijer-Pierik (PPE).
text: – This proposal touches on our productive sectors such as industry, transport and agriculture. The inclusion of methane in the proposal is a serious limitation to reduce greenhouse gases. There is talk of over-regulation and this threatens the end of many farming farms in Europe. Since 1990, ammonia emissions in Europe have decreased by 30% and in the Netherlands by 66%. This is mainly due to heavy efforts by farming companies, which have suffered greatly from the environmental measures. It cannot be the case that the 2005 zero line will be used in no distinction. Future air quality should recognise the efforts of the Member States. This is necessary for a level Playing Field in Europe. Clean air may cost something, but do not always make the same sectors pay. One of the solutions should be manure processing and processing and the use of phosphate as a valuable future scarce resource. Removing manure from the waste law and bringing it to the Fertilizers Act will be the deciding factor for clean water and soil and air, giving the farmer a fair chance. I therefore ask the Commissioner to get to work on this. As a director of politics and agriculture, I have been working on this for 20 years. This way the farmers know where they are and can start investing. And that is a very important point in the clean air in this debate.

name: n/a
text: Madam President, I have heard here several times the colleagues who have mentioned this important issue of air pollution and the various levels of air quality which obviously affect human health and the environment. And I think we all agree to find a clear, comprehensive and swift answer to the various institutional levels, but let me leave a note here on this Commission proposal. I think it falls a little short of what was expected, especially with regard to exception schemes for the outermost regions. That is why I think it is important to recall Article 349 of the Treaty of Lisbon which differentiates the outermost regions of other regions of the Union. It differentiates them by the distinct condition socially and economically, differentiates them by the small dimension, differentiates them by insularity. And the outermost regions must and must be safeguarded through specific measures in the Union's common policies. However, I welcome this proposal because ... (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker)

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, this is a legislative text which embraces one of the greatest challenges of our day. This challenge translates into transforming the paradigm of the start-up of the era of industrialization, which has reached a dimension that does not care for the world as we know it today. This challenge means reassessing our senses of economic progress and growth and integrating criteria such as the urgency of preserving our resources that are not infinite. This legislation is an incentive to technological innovation and should be implemented in harmony and coordination with other policies in the field of research and development, the protection of biodiversity and climate change. This should be done with a view to a parallel volition at all these levels or, otherwise, we will jeopardise the transition to a low-carbon economy, the resilience of our resources and the quality of life of future generations.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, air pollution is a major problem with dimensions relating to health, the environment, society and the economy. Air pollution is also caused by diesel vehicles. In the wake of the Folkswagen scandal, the European Union and the Member States must take action against diesel engines, since the majority of investigations link pollution from diesel engines to premature deaths. So after the 'dieselgate', which was certainly revealed by the United States as part of its competitive effort to shorten Germany's economic and political influence, the landscape in the European Union is completely different and calls for decisive measures to be taken to control nitrogen oxide emissions. It is therefore clear that the European diesel and vehicle industry must be placed under the microscope of the Commission and the Member States, because what is most important is public health, environmental protection and not the super-benefits of Folkswagen, .... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE).
text: – Of course we all want to live longer. Of course we all want cleaner air and a clean environment. But this proposal, which includes methane, is not the right instrument for this. As Mr Huitema has pointed out, this is already regulated in the climate package and there is no way to reduce methane emissions from livestock farming, unless by reducing the herd or putting all the cows back in the barn. That's not the right way for me as a farmer's daughter. We must be careful not to overdo the regulations. Please let's live and be allowed to do business.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, health, impact and environment and socio-social impact should be the main criteria for evaluating the implementation and success of this Directive. The fact that we must not ignore is that health costs in the European Union due to pollution amount to several hundred billion euros a year.  Member States often forget to mention the fact and indirect costs incurred by air pollution in their calculations. Fine particulate matter is a major problem because they are mainly caused by emissions from transport and energy, and it is estimated that tiny particles of ozone concentration are responsible for too many tens of thousands of premature deaths in the European Union.  Member States have sufficient tools to use to reduce emissions provided by European funds, and I support the proposal that the Commission establish a Clean Air Fund to ensure that funding processes are simple, transparent and accessible to different levels of governance, all for the purposes they can use to improve air quality.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – Health protection, environmental protection are two things that have a very strong emphasis in Europe, so I think that Europe can and is an example to other countries around the world in these cases. The steps have already been taken in the past, with the next steps, following, as is the position of the European People's Party, that we must be moderate in these steps, while taking into account both expectations and certainly the need to protect the environment, and, on the other hand, to give those dealing with both industry and farming the opportunity to adapt their techniques to these new requirements. Unjustified and over-set requirements would be counterproductive, because they would either not be accepted or would not be respected. Therefore, in this case, we must be specific and act both in accordance with the requirements for a healthier environment and the environment.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, improved air quality must be a priority objective for the European institutions and the Member States. Today we have the opportunity to play our part by voting for a text that can significantly reduce air pollution, improve air quality and save lives. And I spoke of saving people's lives, because pollution in Europe causes hundreds of thousands of deaths, negatively affecting the GDP of the Member States, with very high costs linked to health.  Following the Volkswagen scandal, with today's vote, the European Parliament has the opportunity to show its willingness to set ambitious environmental targets and its sensitivity to the health of citizens. But Parliament alone cannot change things. Every sector must make its contribution, including agriculture, but it must not be disproportionately affected. That is why I believe that enteric methane alone, to be understood as that from breeding through the digestive processes of ruminants, should be excluded from the scope of the directive with a shared effort on the part of all, both in terms of public health and in economic terms. Cleaner air can lead to greater benefits.

name: Ulrike Müller (ALDE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the way in which Today's vote will decide the continued existence of sustainable agriculture and forestry with animal husbandry in the European Union. Agriculture and forestry with the upstream and downstream sectors is one of the most important economic factors in Europe. It produces the highest quality food and food and secures a great deal of jobs. It makes no sense to endanger all this with excessive reduction measures for ammonia and methane. Of course, we are in favour of achievable objectives with scientific support, and you can rest assured that farmers have nothing more to do with the future of the planet. But, ladies and gentlemen, this vote will be a key vote for agriculture. Animal welfare will be opposed to environmental protection and, with false targets, family farms with livestock farming will be among the big losers. I would ask you to take this into account in your vote.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Cows produce methane – sounds weird, but is so, quite natural and hard to avoid. Unless you slaughter the cow or you pick the animals from the pasture, pack them into a narrow barn, build a filter system over it and it's good. It is actually funny that it is environmentalists and greens who want to impose such nonsense on our farmers, the family farms. Let us not ridicule ourselves! If we remove methane from the scope of the directive, let us stop this European airstrike on the grazing cow! Together with my Polish group colleagues, I have tabled eight amendments that exclude methane and make the limit values for ammonia realistic. Leave the cows in the pasture and take their hands off the methane ban! Please support the amendments, stand alongside our farming and also show yourself to be an animal lover! I do not want such decisions to throw animal welfare efforts of the last twenty years over the top and push the cows back into the stables.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like also to thank the honourable Members for their valid comments and for their valid arguments. We keep reminding each other that we need to be more realistic and that we need to look more at reality, and I could not agree more. That is exactly what we should be doing and the biggest reality is that we have almost half a million European citizens dying every year from poor air quality, plus a bigger number with chronic respiratory diseases. The reality is that we need to stop this.  As several of you have stressed in your statements, our citizens increasingly demand action to address the health impacts of air pollution. Efforts are needed from all sectors, including agri-industry. It is important to keep the level of ambition for ammonia in line with the overall objective and to retain methane in the proposal. This will not have any negative effect on animal welfare and will not require keeping them inside, as some of Members have tried to suggest.  On the overall ambition, I share the rapporteur’s concern that if the position of this House is too far from that of the Council, this will jeopardise the chances of agreement. I would therefore encourage your support for a plenary position close to the original proposal of the Commission for all pollutants. It was also encouraging to note that we all agree on the objectives and it would be a big pity not to agree on how we can achieve these same objectives.  A number of Members referred to the supplementary impact assessment done by the European Parliament’s own services. While this shows that with the climate and energy package we can deliver greater air pollution reduction for broadly the same cost, it also shows that we can deliver the same reduction at a lower cost. Given that the assessment does not fully reflect the latest state of play, I feel the latter message should carry more weight. With regard to a number of other proposed amendments, many improve the original proposal. However, I would make two last comments.  On the interim targets for 2025, it is important to ensure steady progress towards the 2030 reductions. But if the interim targets become binding, this could in some cases lead to disproportionate costs. Hence I would support a solution based around the original Commission proposal. With regard to reduction commitments for mercury, as emissions from all major sources are regulated under the Industrial Emissions Directive, reduction commitments under the NEC directive would not further reduce emissions. Furthermore exposure of EU citizens to mercury is largely due to emissions from third countries. The Commission is preparing the ratification of the Minamata Convention on Mercury which is expected to curb those emissions and thereby reduce exposure of EU citizens to this toxic substance.  As I said earlier on, every month that passes delays the implementation of policies that could alleviate the problems with bad air quality. I call on your support today to pave the way for a viable agreement between the co-legislators during the first reading. Let me conclude by making some final remarks. First, this is not just about a better environment, it is about avoiding and reducing further deaths as a result of our non-action. Polluted air kills; non-action does the same. EU citizens deserve, expect and have a right to action. We all acknowledge that we have a serious, lethal problem, so let us all come together towards a much-needed responsible solution. Finally, let me assure everyone here that we are not after less agriculture, we are not after less economic growth, what we are after is better and healthier agriculture, what we are after is better economic growth that will contribute to better living and not to premature deaths.

name: Julie Girling
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I want to just make the point that what we agree on in this directive is far more significant than what we disagree on. But that does not mean that those areas of disagreement are not significant. They are.  So I would like to ask those in this Chamber who are considering voting for targets which, we have heard, many of us believe are unattainable and will lead to considerable delays in coming to an agreement with the Commission, to please think again before they vote today. There is no disagreement on health impacts. Nobody can lecture me on health impacts. I understand them completely. That is what we want to get to, but we want to get to it quickly. We do not want any more delay. Please do not be responsible for delay.

name: elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 28 October 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Pilar Ayuso (PPE)
text: in writing. – This proposal is another step in reducing polluting emissions and preventing their cross-border dissemination. As in any proposal, we must seek an optimal cost-benefit ratio and seek the best possible result. The exclusion of outermost areas and the safeguards contained in the text for livestock holdings as regards the ammonia of slurry and methane is consistent. We cannot and should not afford to undermine our agriculture. Methane and mercury should be left out until we have an impact assessment. It is necessary to ensure that vehicle testing methods are approved to actual driving conditions, because cars are the largest urban pollutant. Objectives for 2025 are also not needed, as the proposal already envisages them for 2020 and 2030.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. We need ambitious standards for combating air pollution, whose poor quality causes more than 48,000 premature deaths a year in France. This directive is therefore a crucial legislative instrument for monitoring compliance with air quality targets at European level.  But I would like to reiterate the importance of realistic legislation. I therefore call on you, ladies and gentlemen, to vote for the exclusion of methane and ammonia from this directive, whose unrealistic emission limits would unfairly penalise the agricultural sector, first and foremost small farms. I draw your attention to our amendment to exclude enteric methane from the release of animals, since we do not currently have an effective technical or technological means to reduce these natural emissions. We have to ask ourselves about the agricultural model we want: animals parked indoors to reduce enteric emissions or animals raised outdoors? We cannot argue on the one hand for animal welfare in the agricultural sector and on the other hand impose unreasonable constraints on our breeders!

name: Jørn Dohrmann (ECR)
text: Written. – Air pollution is a problem in Europe that needs to be taken seriously. However, I am concerned about how we are going to deal with the problem. The agricultural sector is being hugely challenged by this air package. I own agriculture, which is why I also know how Danish agriculture is constantly being squeezed by new legislation. This is despite the fact that the Danish agricultural sector has been immensely adept at doing its part to protect the environment. Yet the sector is being punished. Competition is distorted if Danish agriculture is obliged to set overambitious targets for ammonia reduction, when, for example, in Germany, which is right next door, they do not have the same obligations. This means that the air is still polluted in Denmark, while at the same time we have to contend with unequal conditions of competition. That's not fair. Everyone has to go in bunches. There is no point in a small country like Denmark taking the heavy tow. Neither environmental nor competitive. At the same time, methane reduction targets also threaten agriculture with double regulation, as such targets already exist and need to be renegotiated again within the framework of climate policy. It is also a distortion, which, to me, damages more than it benefits. We cannot sacrifice the lives and businesses of hard-working people in favour of symbolism.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. - Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. Parliament's draft position amending the Air Quality Directive is of concern in many respects. On the one hand, the proposed methane emission limits would have a devastating impact on Hungarian livestock production. The Hungarian Government is doing its utmost to encourage an increase in the hungarian cattle and pig population, which has fortunately led to an increase in the number of both livestock. The proposed limit, which experts calculate would require a 30% reduction in current emissions! – break the objective of increasing livestock, one of the most important objectives of the Hungarian agricultural government. Moreover, the reduction of methane emissions is already regulated and is subject to the Community commitment to reduce greenhouse gases. There are also serious problems with ammonia emission limits. The 2030 and 2020 limits are already unrealistic, but the proposed 2025 intermediate limit is downright outrageous. Hungary would require a reduction of almost 40%! Furthermore, unnecessary legislation would be taken here, since fertilisation methods are already regulated by the standards of the Cross Compliance system and other environmental rules, in particular the Nitrate Directive. This would complicate the situation of farmers and result in unenforceable standards. I therefore demand that the methane emission reduction limits be removed from the draft and that the ammonia emission limits be reduced to a reasonable level, otherwise I will not be able to support the proposal.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "None of us have any doubt that we should take action to protect the environment. But the negotiated agreement and the goals we set cannot be detached from reality. We must not forget that cattle farmers are facing one of the most serious crises in recent years. As a Member of Polish, I will not support solutions that are harmful to our breeders. I appeal to all my colleagues to support the amendments tabled by the Polish delegation of European Conservatives and Reformists, which remove the methane commitment. I would like to stress that issues relating to emissions of this compound are already covered by climate legislation and there is no need to duplicate them. I also believe that the reduction commitments imposed are too ambitious and costly. I would remind you that Poland is among the countries that meet its emission ceilings, and in 2011-13 the emissions were below the limit resulting from the Polish Accession Treaty. The draft amendments to the Directive need more flexibility so that each country can determine its path to the levels indicated for 2030.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. – Yesterday, we agreed on the urgent need to investigate the issue of car emission manipulation and to introduce a vehicle test based on real driving conditions without delay. We have sent a message to European citizens that it is no longer possible to break the rules designed to protect their health and the environment with impunity. Today, therefore, the only logical next step is to change the legislation restricting emissions of air pollutants, based on a report by the Committee on the Environment. Doing so could save more than 74,000 people from premature death every year across Europe, according to the latest expert calculations (http://www.eeb.org/?LinkServID=9168DFDD-5056-B741-DBA5B64C92B81F9D&showMeta=0&aa). Diseases caused by air pollution have significant economic costs in the health sector and due to reduced working hours. To prevent this, binding targets should also be adopted in Europe for 2020, 2025 and 2030. Mandatory limits for ammonia, methane and mercury are also required in the Directive. Earlier this week, I Budapest air quality measurements in the center of The New York City, in a joint with the Air Task Force. The results supported the need to reduce air pollution rapidly: the amount of pollutants increased 14-times as much as normal when diesel cars passed us.  The Impact Assessment of the Committee on the Environment (Oct 2014) (Oct 2014) http://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/STUD/2014/528802/EPRS_STU%282014%29528802_REV1_EN.pdf showed that achieving more stringent targets than the European Commission's original proposal would not cost more, while saveing tens of thousands of lives.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The European Parliament's proposal to set new national emission ceilings for the main air pollutants is, in principle, to be welcomed. It should be noted, however, that better regulation is urgently needed with regard to emissions and better monitoring at local level through optimised measurement procedures. Similarly, seasonal fluctuations, such as heating periods, must be taken more into account in the regulation. Emissions do not stop at national borders either, which is why overseas countries and maritime and air transport must also be made compulsory. In addition, individual states should not be able to have a flexibility regime in the accounting of their emissions, as most of the Member States will not meet certain targets, especially for NOX emissions, within the specified period. This creates difficulties for Europe as a business location, as certain limit values cannot, in reality, be achieved in the way that the Commission provides. Countries that miss these limits are also threatened with infringement proceedings – which, it seems, will flourish for most Member States.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D)
text: Written. – With our vote on the Commission's proposal for tightening the national pollutant emission ceilings, we are doing a lot of jaded air over Europe. That's what's needed. Air pollution is at the root of at least 400 000 premature deaths in the Union from respiratory infections, heart attacks and cancers. Urban residents are particularly affected. Nevertheless, it is difficult to be entirely satisfied with this result. The stricter objectives proposed by the Social Democrats did not meet in the final vote. If our proposals, which still won a narrow majority in the Committee on the Environment, were also approved in plenary, we could prevent an additional 42 000 premature deaths in Europe each year. Fortunately, the Conservatives failed to pass the emissions limits on ammonia and methane. These polluents emitted by intensive livestock breeding cause a lot of fine dust and ozone pollution. In order to tackle this pollution, the agricultural sector must also suffer. We also welcome the binding emission ceilings for 2025, the additional opportunities for local authorities to tackle air pollution, greater participation for citizens and easier access to justice if governments do not take sufficient measures.

name: Jens Geier (S&D).
text: Thank you, Mr President. I have only one point for my group that there is an error in our voting list on page 15.  This concerns Amendment No 20 by the Greens to paragraph 28 of the political resolution. The amendment is marked with a minus in our list, but we want to vote in favour of it, so there must be a plus.

name: Presidente. –
text: I would like to inform you, ladies and gentlemen, that given the length of the votes, which you know will be very long today, the Conference of Presidents has decided that explanations of vote will not be taken into account today at the end of the votes. Explanations of vote on the items voted on today can be given tomorrow after the votes. I would also remind you that explanations of vote may also be submitted in writing.

name: Danuta Maria Hübner
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like, on behalf of the EPP Group and also in agreement with my colleague and co—rapporteur representing the Socialists and Democrats, Jo Leinen, to request that the vote on the European electoral law be postponed to the November I part-session.

name: Jo Leinen
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, European electoral law is one of the two cases where this Parliament has a right of initiative, so it is very important that we debate this thoroughly. I think it is wise to have two more weeks to reflect in the political groups and delegations about how we handle this very important dossier for our House. So I agree with Ms Hübner that we should postpone it to the part—session in two weeks’ time.

name: Presidente. –
text: Mr Leinen, since there was a problem of interpretation, I would ask you to rephrase your request to the House. I would ask all parliament's services to be as concentrated as possible, because they are very long and also very complicated votes.

name: Jo Leinen
text: Rapporteur. Thank you, Mr President. The reform of European electoral law is one of the two cases in which this Parliament has the right of initiative.  That is why we should be very careful with this dossier, which is very important for the next European elections. I therefore agree with Mrs Hübner that we have another two weeks to reflect on the AFCO Committee's proposal in the political groups and delegations. I am in favour of a two-week postponement.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF).
text: Our group would like to see no European electoral law. We would therefore prefer to postpone it to 2063, which is why I am opposed to Mrs Hübner's proposal, which we believe is too limited.

name: Presidente. –
text: The proposal to postpone the vote on the reform of the EU electoral law is accepted.

name: José Manuel Fernandes
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I am obliged, as I do every year, to make a technical statement. Due to the complexity of the procedure, there are some technical adjustments that need to be put to a vote before the vote on the 2016 budget.  Budget comments, line 04 02 64, "Youth Employment Initiative": Amendment 1,435 will include additional remarks, approved by the Committee on Budgets, on gender equality, education and training.  Figures, line 11 06 62 01, "Scientific Advice and Knowledge," Amendment 478: payments will be adjusted to 14,064,771.  New lines 18 04 01 01, "Europe for citizens": strengthening the memory and strengthening the capacity for civic participation at EU level, and 18 04 01 02, "European Citizens' Initiatives", Amendment 1366: payments will be adjusted to EUR 18,650,000 in the draft budget on the front line and EUR 500,000 on the second line.  Line 19 02 01, "Response to crisis and emerging crisis", Amendment 995: payments will be adjusted to 156,914,703 euros.  Line 21 02 07 04, "Food and Nutrition Security and Sustainable Agriculture," Amendment 1,373: payments will be adjusted to 89,783,000 euros.  Line 21 02 07 05, "Migration and Asylum", Amendment 1,374: payments will be adjusted to 28,114,291 euros.  Line 24 01 07, "European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF)", Amendment 1,389: restores the level of the draft budget and must be adjusted to 53,149,500 euros to take into account the amount set aside.

name: Presidente. –
text: The amendments proposed by the rapporteur are accepted and will be incorporated into the text.

name: James Carver (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, this is a point of order because, after 20 years in this place, the accounts still have not been signed off. So, as we come to vote on this year’s budget, could I make a request, on behalf of all Members of the European Parliament, that maybe the auditors can get their job done properly, and after 20 years we can see proper accounts?

name: Pierre Gramegna
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, I attended the vote to demonstrate the attention with which the Luxembourg Presidency is following the progress of the debate around the European Union budget. Parliament has just adopted a whole series of amendments, and I will of course take them into account and report them to the Council of Ministers. We therefore take note of the differences between the position on the budget as agreed by the Council and the amendments you adopted today. That is why, in accordance with Article 314, paragraph 4, paragraph (c), of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, I agree with the convening of the conciliation committee by the President of the European Parliament. This conciliation committee will meet for the first time on 9 November and the Luxembourg Presidency, together with the Commission and Parliament, will do everything possible so that we can reach a conclusion at the end of the week, namely 13 November this year.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR).
text: – Mr President, so we come to Paragraph 77, which states: ‘Stresses that Parliament and the Council must address the need for a roadmap to a single seat, as requested by a large majority in this Parliament in several resolutions, in order to create long term savings in the Union budget’.  I propose an oral amendment to add the following:  ‘notes the Conference of Presidents’ decision of 11 February 2015 to consider this issue as part of an ongoing report in the Committee on Constitutional Affairs (AFCO); urges the rapporteur Guy Verhofstadt to bring forward his proposals within the next six months’.

name: Gérard Deprez
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Amendment 90 follows a request we made in our July vote calling on the Office to develop new regulations for a better balance between accredited parliamentary assistants and local assistants.  The text we were asking you to vote on deplores the fact that the Bureau has not yet decided on this point; this is not true, since the Bureau made a decision last Monday. I therefore propose to remove the whole last part of the original text submitted to you, and from 'communicating to the Office a proposal to that effect', to delete the text and replace it with: 'takes note of the agreement reached within the Office in that it essentially responds to the request made by the European Parliament , and welcomes the decision to implement the agreement immediately."

name: António Marinho e Pinto
text: Rapporteur. – A short explanation of what is on the ballot right now. In April 2014, the Council, the European Union, the Court of Justice and Parliament agreed to increase the number of judges of the General Court by 12 more judges. In October of that same year, six months later, the Council proposed an increase of 28 more judges because the members of the Council could not agree to appoint 12 judges. The members are 28 and the judges to be appointed were 12.  In my report, I propose returning to the first reading, that is, the 12 judges should be approved again, because that is the number that solves the alleged problems in the court and not 28 judges, which solve a problem of the Council and not of the General Court.  There are, therefore, two questions at a vote: either the Council's position, which was a majority in the JURI Committee, or that of the rapporteur, which I endorsed in my report, which is to return to the initial proposal at first reading and to adopt only 12 judges, which was what the court initially asked for and which was necessary to solve the court's problems.

name: Félix Braz
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Court of Justice plays a fundamental role in the application and interpretation of our rules of law and in doing so in the process of European integration.  The reform of its status will go hand in hand with strengthening the values and principles of law that unite our states and our citizens. Without reform, on the other hand, the backlog of cases before the Tribunal and the average length of proceedings, which are increasing, are gradually, but surely, undermining the effectiveness of our judicial system. This reform will solve, for today and for tomorrow, the problems facing the Tribunal, which our citizens and businesses have every right to expect in a Union based on the rule of law. Ladies and gentlemen, this compromise text also contains important elements, serious efforts to achieve a better balance between men and women in the composition of the Tribunal. At the end of the three phases of the reform, the Court of the Union will be composed of two judges per Member State. This is why, in order to achieve gender equality, which is a european Union objective under Article 3 of the Treaty on European Union, the governments of the Member States should, as far as possible, in the process of appointing candidates for the office of judge at the Court of the Union, in accordance with Article 254 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. , ensure an equal presence of men and women.

name: António Marinho e Pinto
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is just to say that I want to remove my name from this report because it is not the report I made. Whoever made this report that subscribes to it, other than me.

name: n/a
text: Transitional national measures The Commission takes note of the decision of the European Parliament and the Council to allow Member States to keep existing derogations related to red coral harvesting without any time limit, and to provide for new derogations to be granted during a transitional period again without clear cut-off date. The Commission considers that, by their nature, derogations and/or transitional measures can only be temporary and that the unlimited exceptional regimes agreed between the co-legislators may put the Union in a position where it is not able to ensure that its international obligations towards the GFCM are fully respected.  In the event that the above mentioned risks should materialize, the Commission will submit proposals for appropriate measures in accordance with the relevant provisions of the Treaty. In any event, the Commission emphasises that any decision in this case will not prejudice the Commission position in relation to other rules on derogations and/or transitional regimes. Final date for use of ROVs (Remotely Operated underwater Vehicles) With regards to the final date of 31/12/2015, agreed by the European Parliament and the Council for authorised use of ROVs for observation and prospection of red coral, the Commission takes note of the decision of the co-legislators to interpret the words "until 2015" in paragraph 3a) of recommendation GFCM/35/2011/2, as "until 31 December 2015", thus deviating substantially from the Commission's proposal to consider only the time period before 2015, until 31 December 2014.  Having already stressed that, by their nature, derogations can only be temporary, the Commission recalls that also the FAO Legal Service had expressed the view that only the time limit before 2015 should be considered. In the light of this, the Commission will assess if appropriate initiatives need to be taken in order to clarify the Union's position on the issue of ROVs within the GFCM.

name: Giovanni La Via
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, following the plenary's decision to reject the Commission's proposal, we will have to see whether the Commission intends to withdraw the proposal or maintain it, and therefore, of course, to take our decisions.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission regrets the decision of the European Parliament to reject the Commission’s proposal, which is aimed at giving more freedom to Member States to decide on the use of EU—authorised GM food and feed. The Commission maintains its original proposal which, if adopted, would enable Member States to address at national level considerations which are not covered by the EU decision-making process. The Commission believes that the proposal is the right way of addressing the challenges in relation to the decision-making process on GMOs at EU level. The Commission will continue the discussions with the Council.

name: Giovanni La Via
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, in view of the Commission's desire not to withdraw the proposal, given the debate that has taken place this morning in this House with a broad convergence of all the political groups towards rejecting the proposal, given also the large majority that has taken place in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy on this issue, I call on the plenary to express its opinion today with the legislative resolution and therefore to proceed and continue with the votes on the legislative resolution.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D).
text: Mr President, this is the question of the limit on annual methane emissions.  Following the phrase 'Member States must at least limit their annual anthropogenic emissions of methane', I propose to add the sentence: 'except for the enteric methane emissions produced by ruminants', which would allow us, Mr President, to avoid being ridiculous in the eyes of the whole of Europe. For, at the risk of disappointing you, Mr President, the European Parliament does not yet have the power to prevent cows from farting or burping.

name: Stefan Eck (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the There is a great deal against this oral amendment. It is not a question of whether cows emit methane gas or not. Of course, we cannot put an end to this. But it is about sending out a signal that we are serious about a climate change policy. That is why we must also include methane emissions!

name: Julie Girling
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, a short speech: I would like to postpone the final vote, please, to enter negotiations in trilogue.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I notice that Ms Le Pen is not here. I would like you to kindly check what is happening with her vote and her neighbour.

name: Ivan Jakovčić
text: Rapporteur. – Mr. President, (the REPRESENTATIVE started his speech in Italian) paragraph number 58 please just include: "including the southern extension of the Adriatic-Ionian dorsal". This was agreed together with the S&D, the EPP and others.  (President addressed in Italian) Well, then I'll do it again. Please accept this oral amendment to paragraph number 58, which goes for the southern extension on the Adriatic-Ionian dorsal. I'm asking you to accept that.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D).
text: Mr President, I do not want to talk about the Rules of Procedure, but, with more than two hours of voting, I wanted to congratulate you on the way in which you conducted the vote. Thank you, Mr President.

name: Presidente. –
text: That concludes voting time.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Our position on the European Union budget for 2016 has been to increase expenditure on all budget items aimed at improving the functioning of the European Union. We have refused to finance European programmes that have an impact on the interests of the military industry or support institutions such as FRONTEX, assuming little profit for European citizens. We have also proposed and supported aid programmes for the countries under the Troika, occupied territories of Palestine and different programmes aimed at job creation and support for different sectors, and we have tried to avoid cuts in the most important headings for the European economy. We believe that the Union budget should avoid austerity policies in order to boost the economy and we voted in this regard.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Report which contained a number of important provisions.  Specifically, it highlighted that the European Union is currently facing a number of serious emergencies, notably the unprecedented migration and refugee crisis. This report called for financial resources to be deployed in the EU budget, in order to match the political challenges and therefore enable the EU to deliver and effectively respond to these crises, as a matter of utmost urgency and priority. Whilst of course the refugee and migration crisis cannot be solved by financial resources alone, in these extraordinary times, extraordinary measures are required and a strong political commitment is needed to secure fresh appropriations for this purpose. It was for these reasons, amongst others, that I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Together with my colleagues from the National Front, we oppose Brussels' control over the peoples of Europe. We believe in a Europe based on free nations and peoples, we believe in a Europe proud of its Christian values and its ancient Greco-Latin heritage. On the other hand, we deplore the construction of Europe as it has been carried out for forty years. We do not want this European Union, which is destroying identities and graveying sovereignty.  However, this artificial technocratic construction, in order to impose itself on the European peoples, has a colossal budget. Thus, the budget planned for 2016 will amount to more than 150 billion euros. I find it absolutely scandalous to puncture the peoples of Europe even though it has become clear that this Europe has completely failed: mass immigration, mass unemployment, moral and spiritual crisis, etc. That is why I voted against the european Union's draft general budget for 2016.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The priority must always be to ensure value for money, that not a penny of taxpayers’ money is spent for the wrong reasons or wasted. The money does not belong to the European Union, but to citizens. I therefore voted against the budget, and in favour of those amendments which sought to improve the accountability of the EU institutions, which cut the costs for the taxpayer, and which would have shown us taking a lead in reducing our expenditure here in Parliament. Sadly, these good amendments were voted down.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of reading the EP for the draft 2016 budget. Four billion separates the Council's position and that of Parliament. I guarantee that the final result will be removed from the expectations expressed by parliamentarians. A period of conciliation between the two branches of the budgetary authority is now opening. I regret that our budget lacks resources, flexibility and responsiveness when it comes to migration. In this regard, there is an urgent need to revise the multi-year financial framework. I regret that the European Parliament has not been more rigorous in adopting its own budget. The credibility and authority of the EP in discussions with the Council depends on this.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016. The EU budget commitments for 2016 will amount to EUR 157.4 billion. Euro. The promotion of employment is a key priority of next year's budget. A total of around EUR 50 billion is earmarked for achieving this objective. The budget will support transnational exchanges of students, teachers and other staff (Erasmus+) and small and medium-sized enterprises (Cosme), as well as investments in research (Horizon 2020), infrastructure and strategic projects (Connecting Europe Facility, European Fund for Strategic Investments). Another budgetary priority is improving the reception of refugees, including improving infrastructure, faster processing of applications, and organising language courses. I support the proposal to strengthen the EU's external policy in order to combat the causes of the crisis in third countries.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this immigration report, which calls for increasing funding for aid to "migrants" to the tune of 1.1 million euros, a sum that will be in addition to the funding already voted for the 2015 budget and all the aid released in recent months for the result we know: increased migration submersion.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. Once again, parliamentarians were called upon to amend the draft 2016 budget submitted by the European Commission. Admittedly, it must be acknowledged that the evolution of EU spending between 2015 and 2016 is almost nil and that, on the other hand, some amendments even went in the direction of a reduction in the pharaonic expenditure of the EU institutions. However, the report as a whole responds to a logic of increased expenditure through an increase in Member States' contributions: an indecent prospect when one thinks of the role of the policeman of austerity endorsed by Brussels for several years vis-à-vis the Member States! That is why common sense was for me to reject the majority of the amendments to restore the appropriation ceilings that had been lowered in the original draft budget.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that little has been done to reduce the costs of the European institutions to date, while our local administrators are struggling to provide citizens with good services given the very limited resources at their disposal, I voted against it.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The draft budget proposal that came from the committee responsible highlights and acknowledges two key problems: the migrant crisis and the need to increase the EU's competitiveness. As budget rapporteur on the Gender Equality Committee, I support this proposal.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Report which contained a number of important provisions.  Specifically, it highlighted that the European Union is currently facing a number of serious emergencies, notably the unprecedented migration and refugee crisis. This report called for financial resources to be deployed in the EU budget, in order to match the political challenges and therefore enable the EU to deliver and effectively respond to these crises, as a matter of utmost urgency and priority. Whilst of course the refugee and migration crisis cannot be solved by financial resources alone, in these extraordinary times, extraordinary measures are required and a strong political commitment is needed to secure fresh appropriations for this purpose. It was for these reasons, amongst others, that I voted in favour of this report.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The EU's general budget for the 2016 financial year is already indiscriminately taking into account the financing of infrastructure for the reception of illegal migrants. However, the rapporteur recommends increasing this budget by EUR 1.161 billion in order to respond to this unprecedented migration crisis.  Their so-called solidarity is making a mockery at a time when millions of Europeans are suffering from mass unemployment and poverty. Their foreign preference is simply unworthy of politicians whose sole purpose should be to defend the interests of their people. These additional expenditures are being carried out at the expense of the cohesion policy, which nevertheless reduces regional disparities within the European Union and promotes the structural competitiveness of our economies. This budget also does not propose any sustainable solution to ensure that the backlog of unpaid bills is reduced in terms of the implementation of the programmes for the period 2014-2020. That is why I voted against this budget.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU general budget for the 2016 financial year is to propose to reduce the amount of amounts to be redistributed from a number of budget lines under Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility. The result will be an increase of EUR 153 million in commitment appropriations for Horizon 2020 and EUR 150 million in appropriations for the Connecting Europe Facility.  In the current context, account must be taken of a financial effort to address the shortcomings of the European Union's economy, but also of the challenges facing: migration and the refugee crisis, actions to be taken on the farmers' crisis, job growth, the key role played by micro-enterprises and SMEs, but also the commitment to reduce the outstanding payment delays for the period 2007-2013 of cohesion programmes to around EUR 2 billion by the end of 2016. I voted in favour of this proposal because it leads to increased funds on lines such as: Migration and Asylum, Erasmus Plus, increased innovation for SMEs, the EU's external smart borders, programmes that lay the foundations for a prosperous European Union and with the lowest unemployment rate.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the provisions on small and medium-sized enterprises and agriculture alone.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the Council's position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, as many political priorities, such as the effective management of the migration and refugee crisis, the promotion of competitiveness through job creation and the development of businesses and entrepreneurship in the Union , are all supported with an adequate allocation of financial resources. In particular, in the 2016 budget, Parliament focused its attention on migration and refugees, considering these phenomena as the crossroads of internal and external solidarity, mobilising the appropriate funding instruments, as part of an integrated approach, in order to address at the root the causes of the problems facing the Union. The budget also provides for many instruments to stimulate competitiveness, growth and quality employment in the single market, thus helping to effectively address the root causes of the crises currently facing the Union, and that is why I have chosen to vote in favour of the text.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Report which contained a number of important provisions.  Specifically, it highlighted that the European Union is currently facing a number of serious emergencies, notably the unprecedented migration and refugee crisis. This report called for financial resources to be deployed in the EU budget, in order to match the political challenges and therefore enable the EU to deliver and effectively respond to these crises, as a matter of utmost urgency and priority. Whilst of course the refugee and migration crisis cannot be solved by financial resources alone, in these extraordinary times, extraordinary measures are required and a strong political commitment is needed to secure fresh appropriations for this purpose. It was for these reasons, amongst others, that I voted in favour of this report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The budget now looks to be restored to EUR 157.4 billion in commitments and EUR 146.5 billion for payments; this is due to the opposition relating to the proposed cuts.  There is major support for all EU programmes such as strengthening the European Neighbourhood Instrument plus Social and Territorial Cohesion. In addition to this there is added pressure to increase the budget to deal with the on-going refugee and migration crisis relating to the mismanagement of the disaster in the Mediterranean.  A further EUR 1.6 billion is directed to the Asylum Migration and Integration Fund; this includes Global Europe Security & Citizenship.  We cannot support programmes that have already been badly managed and expect the taxpayer to fund initiatives that are not valid or reliable in relation to meeting objectives of the citizens of Europe. These EU programmes do not serve the people of Europe but promote ‘more Europe’ and meet the political agenda of the Commission.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 We voted today on the draft budget for 2016. On all the proposed amendments, I would like to point out that we have decided to allocate EUR 473 million in aid to unemployed young people seeking work and eur 500 million to farmers affected by the embargo on Russia.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the Union draft budget for 2016 as it realistically reflects the EU's current priorities. I am also very glad that the so-called pilot project, which I co-submitted, was also approved within the EU budget. The project will address strengthening the position and education of consumers on product safety and market surveillance within the Digital Single Market and will be funded at EUR 325 000. It aims to contribute to making consumers aware of and avoiding the risks associated with e-commerce to the maximum extent possible.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft because I fully agree with the need for Parliament and the Council, in order to achieve long-term savings in the Union budget, to address the need for a roadmap for the creation of a single seat, as called for by a large majority in Parliament in various resolutions. Furthermore, because of the abolition of milk quotas, I believe that preparatory measures are needed to avoid market imbalances. The sugar sector also deserves as much attention in view of the September 2017 deadline. Finally, I am opposed to EU funding for bullfighting because animals are life and bullfighting is death, while Europe should be more conscientious towards those who, for example, have been out of work and not bullfights.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of the draft EU general budget for the financial year 2016, fully agreeing with the need to proceed as soon as possible with the resolution of the issue of creating a single seat of the European Parliament, in order to save money that could help finance policies for the benefit of European citizens. I also welcome the particular emphasis in the draft budget on the need to give new impetus to employment, growth, investment and the revival of competitiveness.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE)
text: in writing. – I welcome the adoption of the paragraph on a roadmap for a single seat for the European Parliament, and the fact that Parliament has reiterated its call for a single seat. We need to be able to decide when and where to meet. This is an important step towards a more efficient Parliament. I am the chair of the Single Seat Steering Group because I am committed to creating a more effective Parliament. European citizens are asking for this. They do not understand why, or accept that, we waste EUR 114 million and 19 000 tons of CO2 every year on commuting between Brussels and Strasbourg. A majority of this Parliament has repeatedly voted in favour of the savings of a single seat. This is a vote in favour of a more cost-efficient Parliament. We stand ready to pursue a constructive dialogue with all those who want to find viable solutions for all the European institutions’ seats. I therefore encourage Guy Verhofstadt to bring this forward in his ongoing report in the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, in line with the decision of the Conference of Presidents of 11 February 2015. The deadlock must be broken. Now it is time for the Member States to take shared responsibility and to act.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is the resolution on the approval of the EU Budget for the year 2016. In its June proposal, the Commission proposed a global allocation of EUR 153.8 billion in commitments and EUR 143.5 billion in payments; In its July reading, the Council applied, as usual, certain reductions, particularly as regards payments, to EUR 142.1 billion. The European Parliament, through the vote at the end of September in the Committee on Budgets, rejected the Council's cuts in its full and also proposed significant increases compared with the European Commission's initial proposal. The final outcome was therefore an increase to 157.5 billion in commitments and 146.5 billion in payments, with the largest increases concentrated in Rrubrica III (Security and Citizenship), with a particular focus on funds related to the immigration emergency. Although the priorities supported by the Committee on Budgets are largely acceptable, I am voting against it because I am critical of the general approach because, as far as administrative expenditure is concerned, for example, there is not the slightest mention of reducing it and every year there is a continuous increase in administrative expenditure, which is not at all sustainable at a time when it is the EU itself that is calling for restrictions on the Member States.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Our position on the European Union budget for 2016 has been to increase expenditure on all budget items aimed at improving the functioning of the European Union. We have refused to finance European programmes that have an impact on the interests of the military industry or support institutions such as FRONTEX, assuming little profit for European citizens. We have also proposed and supported aid programmes for the countries under the Troika, occupied territories of Palestine and different programmes aimed at job creation and support for different sectors, and we have tried to avoid cuts in the most important headings for the European economy. We believe that the Union budget should avoid austerity policies in order to boost the economy and we voted in this regard.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The adoption of the draft budget was our challenge to the Council's rigidities. Our aim is to safeguard resources for growth and employment. Compared to the Commission's draft 2016 budget, we have introduced increases of 3.6 billion commitments, and 2.9 billion in payments. Among other things, we have focused on economic, social and territorial cohesion, increasing the allocation for youth employment by EUR 473 million and providing extra resources to deal with the flow of immigrants and the challenge of reception. The challenges we face are solved by guessing and proposing courageous and innovative solutions, which, however, must not be frustrated, and that is why, as a Parliament, we will do everything possible to preserve adequate levels of resources that will enable Europe to play its role as a global player to the full.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of next year's EU budget. The 2016 budget also included draft projects for which support from the European Commission could be called up next year. Among the approved projects is our joint project "Diverse Europe" with Kinga Gál.  According to the budget report voted on, EUR 1 million of EU funds will be available to applicants to finance minority programmes to combat discrimination. The proposal is to support multilingual programmes for cultural, educational and training purposes in European regions where the rights of national minorities are still being overshadowed. The programmes are intended to improve the coexistence conditions of different ethnic groups, helping to preserve the cultural and linguistic identity of minority nations. Under the project, representatives of municipalities, civil and youth organisations, schools and the private sector can apply for the organisation of various events and events aimed at maintaining diversity and eliminating discrimination at local and regional level.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the draft general budget of the European Union for 2016. It covers the administrative budgets of the EU institutions including the European Parliament (EP) but excluding the European Commission. I supported Parliament’s approach as, while it protects the interests of Parliament and the Commission as functional bodies, it also safeguards employees while facilitating essential bodies like EEAS especially in the current international political situation.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report was Parliament's position on the 2016 EU budget. It recommends reversing the Council's cuts to the Commission's initial proposal and adding funds to finance migration-related measures inside and outside the European Union, in order to help unemployed young people find jobs. It also aims to restore funding for research and transport programmes, which was cut earlier this year to fund the Juncker plan. Parliament has set the overall level of commitment appropriations (funding available for contracts) at EUR 157.42 billion and payment appropriations (money available to pay bills) at EUR 146.46 billion.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report of Mr Fernandez and Mr Depre on the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016 – all sections. In that report, the European Parliament's budget committee amended the proposed budget from the Council and adopted increases of 4159 billion euro. eur 4.34 billion for payment appropriations. With this decision, the Budget Committee opposed the budget cuts proposed by the Council and that is why I am against the proposal.  Yes, more money needs to be allocated to deal with the flow of illegal immigrants, yes, more investment needs to develop the private sector and create jobs. But there must also be ways to save money, especially from the huge, crowded and inefficient administration of the European institutions and agencies, and not to constantly increase the budget at the expense of Member States' budgets.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the direction of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of parliament's position on the 2016 EU budget. In plenary, the EP defended agricultural resources from the reduction proposed by the Council, in line with Hungarian interests. The EUR 500 million milk rescue package can be provided by the EU budget for 2016, so that all obstacles can be removed from the fact that Hungarian dairy farmers receive the announced EUR 2.9 billion in EU aid on time.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 The EU budget for 2016 must be used in the best possible way. An example of this is to allocate as much as possible, of course within the framework of the multiannual budget ceiling, to the effective reception of refugees and migrants in the Member States. It is a pity that the Council does not share this view. The EU budget must be modern and clearly focused on research, entrepreneurship and important future issues such as climate and the environment, if we are to meet tomorrow's challenges. This is not automatically tantamount to an increase in the budget. On the contrary, there is room for substantial savings and reprioritisation, including within the European Parliament. I have therefore voted in favour of a review of the so-called Members' Statute. However, I do not share the view that we MEPs should decide on our own salaries, fees and allowances.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Over the past few months, we have tabled a total of 128 amendments to the draft budget for 2016 submitted by the European Commission and amended by the Council. Among these, we retableed in plenary 13 amendments, signed each by at least 40 Members: – The creation of a programme to support a negotiated exit from the Euro;  – the establishment of a programme to support the countries intervened by the Troika; – strengthening support for small and medium-sized enterprises; – strengthening the "Youth Employment Initiative", making it conditional on the creation of permanent jobs with rights; – Strengthening fruit distribution schemes (66%) and milk in schools (100%); – The strengthening of the Programme for the Environment and Climate Action LIFE – sub-programme for the environment; – Strengthening spending on translation and interpretation in the EU institutions; – Strengthening the budget of the European Institute for Gender Equality (EIGE); – Strengthening support for the peace process and financial assistance to Palestine. With diverse content and scope, these proposals are based on a firm purpose of defending national interests and on the need to affirm other policies and another direction for Europe.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the fact that the level of the budget’s increase is the same as the level of the estimates approved in spring 2015: reinforcements in the appropriations due to the creation of a new political group (ENL) and those necessary to ensure stable employment of contract staff in all political groups have been fully compensated by decreases in the EP administrative budget. I support the enhanced transparency of the General Expenditure Allowance and the roadmap to a Single Seat, as well as the fact that the Commission’s draft budget has been mostly restored – thus rejecting the cuts by the Council – with some adjustments to take into account the specific needs of the institutions. My congratulations for the efforts made in order to restore the Draft Budget for the European External Action Service.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Union budget convinced of the need for it to serve to consolidate economic recovery in the EU and to support the social and integration policies of Union citizens, through the correct and effective implementation of EU funds in the States, but always taking into account the principle of subsidiarity and the need for European funds to be implemented at regional level. Similarly, the necessary financial resources should be recorded in the Union budget to respond to political challenges and to enable the Union to act and respond to crises as a matter of priority and with the utmost urgency.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I welcome in principle the draft general budget of the European Union for 2016, as I see a serious desire to save. However, I cannot accept the millions of investments planned by the 'wave plan' from next year in the renovation of the dilapidated Brussels Parliament buildings and the wasteful construction of new buildings, which are ultimately 30-50 percent above the average price of Brussels office buildings. Parliament should - as proposed by me and the Groupe Kammerzell - sell the buildings in Brussels and present a roadmap for the complete relocation to Strasbourg.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the general budget for 2016. The budget presented prioritises the management of the refugee crisis and the integration of those seeking protection in Europe. It is also to be welcomed that other sectors in need, such as the dairy industry, are receiving increased support.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I voted against the Draft general budget of the European Union for 2016. Breaking the MFF ceilings is not a fiscally responsible proposition. The focus of spending should be on tackling the major challenges we are faced with today: creating jobs and growth, supporting sustainable development and innovation, and managing the refugee crisis in a responsible and humane way.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In this report I followed my political group line in almost every area, except in such articles referring to the implementation of austerity plans. For in these articles I therefore abstained, as the debate cannot be reduced to a ‘pro’ or ‘contra’ one. Moreover, I did not support any increase in parliamentary assistance allowances, or funding to political parties and foundations, as I believe that the funding today is more than enough, and should not be increased any more. In the case of the free vote on using CAP funding for bull fighting, I voted along my personal conviction, which is in favour, however I accept that it is a divisive and emotive issue for many.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained in the vote on this document which determines Parliament's negotiating position before the Commission and the Council. Firstly, because the budget is slightly better than in previous years (very slight increase), with its lights (growth of humanitarian spending on refugees, improvement of educational aspects, research, Youth Employment Initiative and support for SMEs) and its shadows (diversion of resources to an insufficient and problematic investment model to FEIE ̶ and ̶ significant percentage of additional resources for Europe-strength and greater "competitiveness"). Secondly, and mainly because it is a question of countering the Council's regressive proposal, which would be much worse.
