The Resolution is critical of the Council's approaches and includes several calls for extraordinary measures, the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework for more flexibility or the promotion of quality employment. Since the resulting budgets will presumably contribute to persevering in a neoliberal EU, with a derisory and non-redistributive budget, we will vote against it later.

name: Jytte Guteland Anna Hedh Olle Ludvigsson och Jens Nilsson (S&D)
text: Written. We Swedish Social Democrats chose to abstain in the vote on the package deal for heading 1a (competitiveness for jobs and growth). As far as we are to our part, several items in this part of the budget have a very high priority. There are well-functioning activities with clear European added value. Investment in Horizon 2020 research and infrastructure within the Connecting Europe Facility is one of the best in EU cooperation.  We would like to see the strong investment in these programmes that the Committee on Budgets – and now the whole of Parliament – is advocating. The general focus is that the programmes should suffer as little as possible from the establishment of the EFSI investment fund.  At the same time, we are doubtful about how this issue has been dealt with in the budgetary process. These efforts should have been offset by appropriate savings in low-priority parts of the EU budget. Since this has not really happened – and this is, among other things, helping parliament to fall above the MFF ceilings for the budget as a whole – we cannot fully support the solution for heading 1a.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Hungarian People's Party members voted to ensure that Hungary one of the winners of the 2016 EU budget. In the course of the vote, we defended the cohesion funds due to Hungary, because the plenary confirmed the position that, even in the Committee on Budgets, efforts to reduce the European Regional Development Fund by 20% for countries (including Hungary) that opposed the European Commission's quotas for the relocation of migrants were voted down by a large majority. A priority was to reverse the reduction of the Pre-Accession Fund proposed by the Council. These instruments have a decisive impact on the accession efforts of the candidate countries, such as Serbia and the Hungarians in Vojvodina. Thanks to the proposals of the Hungarian delegation from the People's Party, tens of millions of euros have been raised. The plenary session defended agricultural resources from council cuts in line with Hungarian interests. The EUR 500 million milk rescue package can be provided by the EU budget for 2016, so that Hungarian dairy farmers can receive the announced EU aid of HUF 2.9 billion on time.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was pleased to see in the EU’s draft general budget 2016 measures which prioritise growth and jobs such as restoring the original levels of Horizon 2020 and Connecting Europe Facility before the cuts related to EFSI and crucially the continuation of the Youth Employment Initiative which reverts to the original annual instalment format for 2016 following the frontloading of payments for 2014 and 2015 with a commitment of almost EUR 500 million.  I was also very pleased that a proposal for a pilot project, regarding the reduction of youth unemployment and the setup of co-operatives as a measure to enhance working opportunities in the EU from myself and ALDE colleagues was approved. The main objective is to contribute to reducing youth unemployment by establishing best practice in the area of worker co-operatives for the whole of Europe. Worker co-operatives act as an economically feasible way to start entrepreneurship, and due to their communality as well as shared opportunities and obligations, they are a low risk way for participants to both work and own part of the company simultaneously.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the draft general budget of the European Union for 2016 - all parts of it because the draft is dosed according to the challenges facing the European Union, primarily the refugee and migrant crisis. The year ahead will be particularly challenging due to pressing problems for which the Union needs to find adequate solutions as soon as possible, and in addition to the refugee crisis, I would like to recall that the agricultural crisis is also a major challenge.  Therefore, it is important to ensure budget flexibility in order to address these situations as quickly and efficiently as possible, but also to ensure readiness for those unforeseen. It is important to stress that funding for the Union's main policies and priorities is not suspended and that an adequate framework has been built to drive growth, employment and financing for SMEs, although some programmes and activities have been partly ignored. However, although with some shortcomings and shortcomings, this draft represents a balanced and consistent budget plan that I support.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Together with my colleagues on the National Front, we oppose the excessive control of Brussels over the peoples of Europe. We believe in a Europe based on free nations and peoples, we believe in a Europe proud of its Christian values and its ancient Greco-Latin heritage. On the other hand, we deplore the construction of Europe as it has been carried out for forty years. We do not want this European Union to be graveyly sovereignty and destroying identities. However, this artificial technocratic construction, in order to impose itself on the European peoples, has a colossal budget. Thus, the budget planned for 2016 will amount to more than 150 billion euros. It is scandalous to puncture the peoples of Europe even though it has become clear that this Europe has completely failed: mass immigration, mass unemployment, moral and spiritual crisis, etc. I therefore voted against the European Union's general plan for 2016.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by my colleagues José Manuel Fernandes and Gérard Deprez on the amendments to the general budget of the European Union for the 2016 financial year. These amendments are intended to support the essential policies for European citizens to deal with the current challenges of the European Union and not to reduce the budget as envisaged in the Council's proposal. Parliament thereby puts the priority on employment, competitiveness, the agricultural crisis and the refugee crisis. For example, almost EUR 1.16 billion has been earmarked for the handling of the refugee crisis, EUR 473 million for youth employment programmes, EUR 500 million for farmers affected by the Russian embargo and EUR 1.3 billion for the Horizon 2020 research programme. This position was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This report must be rejected because, in fact, funds are intended to be used for purposes for which the Union has no mandate.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against a number of measures which would have seen the overall EU budget increase and against proposed rises for agricultural subsidies, including bullfighting subsidies, and administration. I voted instead to focus the EU budget more heavily upon investment for growth and jobs and voted for regional funding that goes directly to communities that are best able to determine how to deliver for people locally. I want to see a real budget reform in the EU, with areas that do not bring any real benefits to our constituents cut.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. Parliament has requested commitment appropriations of EUR 157.4 billion and payment appropriations of EUR 146.5 billion for the 2016 EU budget, resulting in a net increase of EUR 4.159 and EUR 4.34 billion respectively. The aim is to repeal almost all Council cuts and to ignore the ceilings agreed between EU Member States in the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework. In addition to sensible budget increases, such as the request for an additional EUR 1.161 billion to deal with the current migration crisis and EUR 473.2 million for the fight against youth unemployment, there are numerous budget lines that the parliamentary majority wants to provide with equal or higher resources largely unaudited. For example, structural and cohesion policy and agriculture/environment alone account for more than two thirds of the EU budget, although the implementation of programmes and activities, especially in cohesion policy, is often deficient. Nevertheless, these areas should remain untouched regardless of the performance achieved. This is offset by cuts in the very important areas of research (Horizon 2020) and infrastructure (Connecting Europe Facility CEF). Our demands for a sustainable, balanced and transparent budget based on an efficient, subsidiary and added-value budget policy at European level have not been taken into account in this draft budget. That is why I voted against Parliament's 2016 draft budget.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I am opposed to the draft 2016 budget because the budget by definition reflects the political choices of the European Commission, and these are disastrous. National Front MPs supported the vast majority of amendments to reduce the budget, but unfortunately they were not accepted.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 A satisfactory overall assessment for the result achieved in committee reflecting the overall agreement for the 2016 budget between S&D, PPE and ALDE, and which has mostly also been followed by the Greens.  The position adopted by the Committee on Budgets: it replenishes all the cuts proposed by the Council with regard to the draft budget submitted by the Commission for 2016 in relation to commitment appropriations; proposes a significant increase over the Commission's draft budget for political priorities, in particular. Thus, the EP proposal currently amounts to EUR 157 427 547 086 in commitment appropriations, i.e. EUR 2 520 million above the draft budget (+ 1.63 %). I would specifically like to highlight my individual vote in favour of the amendment prohibiting the allocation of resources from the European Budget to bullfighting activities, which was adopted. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Our position on the European Union budget for 2016 has been to increase expenditure on all budget items aimed at improving the functioning of the European Union. We have refused to finance European programmes that have an impact on the interests of the military industry or support institutions such as FRONTEX, assuming little profit for European citizens. We have also proposed and supported aid programmes for the countries under the Troika, occupied territories of Palestine and different programmes aimed at job creation and support for different sectors, and we have tried to avoid cuts in the most important headings for the European economy. We believe that the Union budget should avoid austerity policies in order to boost the economy and we voted in this regard.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. Parliament has requested commitment appropriations of EUR 157.4 billion and payment appropriations of EUR 146.5 billion for the 2016 EU budget, resulting in a net increase of EUR 4.159 and EUR 4.34 billion respectively. The aim is to remove almost all Council cuts and to ignore the ceilings agreed between EU Member States in the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework. In addition to sensible budget increases, such as the request for an additional EUR 1.161 billion to deal with the current migration crisis, there are numerous budget lines that the parliamentary majority wants to provide with the same or higher resources largely unaudited. For example, structural and cohesion policy and agriculture/environment alone account for more than two thirds of the EU budget, although the implementation of programmes and activities, especially in cohesion policy, is often deficient. Nevertheless, these areas should remain untouched regardless of the performance achieved. This is offset by cuts in the very important areas of research (Horizon 2020) and infrastructure (Connecting Europe Facility CEF). Our demands for a sustainable, balanced and transparent budget based on an efficient, subsidiary and added-value budget policy at European level have not been taken into account in this draft budget. That is why I voted against Parliament's 2016 draft budget.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The draft European Union budget for 2016 was adopted with the priorities of job creation, economic growth, investment and a new migration policy in mind. It envisions an increase to 157.4 billion euros in commitment appropriations, or 146.4 billion euros in payment appropriations.  I supported Parliament's proposal, as this increase is important to allow for additional financing of development projects in the field of quality employment, fostering entrepreneurship and the development of SMEs, but also to strengthen existing instruments in response to the ongoing migration crisis.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016 because it is not complete and documented.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against an increase in the EU Budget today, which goes beyond the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), the EU’s seven-year framework regulating its annual budget. I have voted to reprioritise the budget towards spending on growth, jobs and innovation – in particular the Youth Employment Initiative, which should be an EU priority. I have also backed increased funding for refugees to help countries cope with the current humanitarian crisis.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016. The Eu ropean Union budget proposal for 2016 focuses on growth, employment and migration. This draft provides for payment appropriations to support the recovery of the European economy. The funds will be used to finance investments to support and promote innovation, create new jobs and promote convergence between Member States and regions.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. It is incomprehensible that more money is to be spent. Often for purposes for which the Union does not even have a mandate. The report must therefore be rejected.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Here is Parliament's first formal opinion on the EU budget for 2016, before the final vote in December. From the outset, it can be seen that none of the recommendations made in July by the same rapporteur Fernandes has been implemented. The rapporteur notes that the Council is increasing the obstacles to the resolution of unpaid debts, even though it called for them to be resolved "without delay" in July. A façade will is still displayed for 2016. And the report expresses a salutary warning against fake announcements such as those of the Juncker investment fund leading to the undressing of existing programmes. While affirming the need to free up an additional billion to deal with the migrant crisis, the report recommends an amount of commitments for 2016 that are almost 4 billion less than the budget for 2015! This report claims that more can be done with less, even though the 2015 budget has already proved insufficient! That's reason enough to vote against.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The MEMBER voted against the European Union's draft budget for 2016. At the National Front, we oppose Brussels' control over the peoples of Europe. We believe in a Europe based on free nations and peoples, we believe in a Europe proud of its values. On the other hand, we deplore the construction of Europe as it has been carried out for forty years. We do not want this European Union, which is destroying identities and graveying sovereignty.  However, this artificial technocratic construction, in order to impose itself on the European peoples, has a colossal budget. Thus, the budget planned for 2016 will amount to more than 150 billion euros. It is scandalous to puncture the peoples of Europe, even though it has become clear that this Europe has completely failed: mass immigration, mass unemployment, moral crisis, etc. That is why she voted against the European Union's general plan for 2016.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support Parliament’s efforts to use the 2016 general budget to increase levels of youth employment across the Union, enhance the EU’s competitiveness and to keep the necessary funds available to tackle the migration crisis.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the General budget of the European Union for 2016 – all sections. I supported the reinforcement of the budgetary lines of some political key priorities for growth, competitiveness and employment, in particular compensations for the cuts on the two important programmes Horizon 2020 and Connecting Europe Facility and the increase in the Youth Employment Initiative. I have also voted in favour of increase for the school fruit scheme and the school milk. Last but not least I voted against the subsidies for the breeding of bulls used for bullfighting.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The 2016 Budget fully reflects political priorities, specifically internal and external solidarity, as well as increased competitiveness through the creation of decent and quality jobs and business development and entrepreneurship across the Union. I endorse the rapporteur's position on the migration and refugee crisis, for which the necessary financial resources should be mobilised in the Union budget to meet the political challenges and enable the Union to achieve results and respond effectively to these crises, with a priority and high urgency. I believe it is essential to make a greater effort to fill the gaps in the Union's economy by increasing competitiveness, growth and quality employment, and I advocate the continuation of the Youth Employment Initiative for the basic role of this programme in the fight against unemployment. I commend the work of Mr José Manuel Fernandes for the complexity, explanation and consensus he has gathered.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This vote concerns the adoption of several amendments to the draft 2016 budget submitted by the European Commission. It should be remembered, however, that for once the Member States have shown measure since the change in the volume of EU expenditure is almost zero between this draft budget 2016 and the year 2015. Several amendments were to be welcomed, notably aimed at reducing the sumptuous spending of the various EU institutions. But the overall dynamic is more spending and therefore more contribution requested from the Member States. Opposing an ever-increasing EU budget when member states are being imposed on unprecedented austerity measures at the same time, I voted against most of the amendments to restore the appropriation ceilings that had been lowered in the original draft budget.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the Fernandes–Deprez report on the draft EU general budget for 2016, as it incorporates many of the amendments proposed by our S&D Group and almost all our financial demands. The draft corresponds to the budget estimates approved in spring 2015. Unfortunately, due to the recent refugee crisis, the European Commission had to propose two letters of amendment to establish a new line of as much as two billion to be removed from some programmes already planned. I also welcome the provision for an action plan to be followed in order to obtain a single seat for Parliament, which would, in fact, guarantee an enormous optimisation of costs for the benefit of taxpayers and the European budget. The budget for the other institutions, which is basically taken up in the draft written by the European Commission, also seems to me to be fair and proportionate to the new institutional needs.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the draft general budget of the European Union for 2016.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the draft EU budget for the 2016 financial year because I believe that it provides, on the one hand, funding for started and ongoing projects, and on the other hand, pays further attention to innovation, young people and women, which is an essential aspect. Of the pilot projects included in the 2015 budget, I would like to highlight three, which I consider very important for Romania: the pilot project on reducing youth unemployment; the one on promoting entrepreneurship by educating and encouraging young people to pursue an entrepreneurial career; and the third, on improving access to risk finance for investment in research and innovation, especially among women. These three topics, among many other projects to be financed and which, in my opinion, will have a big positive impact on citizens, address the main issues in the EU in general and in Romania in particular: lack of jobs for young people, lack of investment of any kind, including private, in research and innovation and poor encouragement of young people and women , especially in entrepreneurship.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this Report which contained a number of important provisions.  Specifically, it highlighted that the European Union is currently facing a number of serious emergencies, notably the unprecedented migration and refugee crisis. This report called for financial resources to be deployed in the EU budget, in order to match the political challenges and therefore enable the EU to deliver and effectively respond to these crises, as a matter of utmost urgency and priority. Whilst of course the refugee and migration crisis cannot be solved by financial resources alone, in these extraordinary times, extraordinary measures are required and a strong political commitment is needed to secure fresh appropriations for this purpose. It was for these reasons, amongst others, that I voted in favour of this report.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report for the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016 calls for more financial resources in many places for which the European Union has no mandate at all. The report also includes further efforts towards the Transfer Union with the aim of investing more in neighbouring countries. I consider it more necessary that the financial resources be used to support our own citizens, and I have therefore voted against the report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. With next year's budget, the EU will have the opportunity to rect onto some of the important omissions to date, which are about the massive refugee crisis. In this way, it is essential to increase the financial allocation for Syrian refugee camps in Turkey, Jordan and Lebanon, as well as to refugee camps in other conflict zones.  Improving living conditions in these centres would allow refugees to avoid the perilous journey to Europe. The contribution to the creation and adequate maintenance of refugee reception centres in Greece and Italy needs to be significantly increased. This would allow the tragic unmanageable movement of refugees across Europe to be placed on the line. There is also a serious need to increase the contribution to support thoughtful development in both the EU's southern and eastern neighbourhoods.  The 2016 budget must make it possible to contribute to real change in ukraine's economic system and to support other countries moving towards a full market economy and upholding the rule of law. In the direction of Ukraine, Moldova and Georgia, the EU can also do more on a budgetary basis.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for this text because we agreed on a crisis budget that restores all the cuts made by the Council. Better yet, all the cuts made under the EFSI agreement - the armed arm of the investment recovery plan - have been removed to maintain research and transport budgets, which are themselves efficient investment budgets. Additional resources have also been set up to combat youth unemployment and to help refugees.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The draft budget for 2016 is the first EU budget prepared in light of Political Guidelines by Commission President Juncker, which presents a new road plan for Europe to develop jobs, development, justice and democratic change, in particular through the European Fund for Strategic Investment (EFSI). The 2016 budget supports solidarity between Member States and others from the region through the European Structural and Investment Fund and helps young people to educate and find work through the YeI.  Furthermore, the funds are also foreseen to de-escalate the crisis adjacent to Europe (Syria and Ukraine). The Commission's draft budget for 2016 reflects the 10 political priorities of the Juncker Plan. The total expenditure in the 2016 draft amounts to EUR 153 529.5 million, corresponding to 1.04 % of GNI, amounting to EUR 8413.3 million, i.e. a decrease of 5.2% in expenditure compared to 2015. The means of payment (including specific instruments) amount to EUR 143 541.5 million, corresponding to 0.98 % of GNI.  This represents a moderate increase of 1.6% compared to the level of payment of funds in the 2015 budget. It should be added that for the fourth year in a row, the Commission will reduce the number of employees by 1% in 2016.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This vote concerns the adoption of several amendments to the draft 2016 budget submitted by the European Commission. It should be remembered, however, that for once the Member States have shown measure since the change in the volume of EU expenditure is almost zero between this draft budget 2016 and the year 2015. Several amendments were to be welcomed, notably aimed at reducing the sumptuous spending of the various EU institutions. But the overall dynamic is more spending and therefore more contribution requested from the Member States. Opposing an ever-increasing EU budget when member states are being imposed on unprecedented austerity measures at the same time, I voted against most of the amendments to restore the appropriation ceilings that had been lowered in the original draft budget.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support this year's balanced budget blueprint for next year that seeks to regulate and equalize the income-to-expenditure ratio, as well as anticipate backlog funds that have not been paid. Since I come from Croatia, one of the countries on the migrant route that actively and responsibly relates to the refugee crisis, I especially welcome the funds allocated exclusively for this purpose, for Greece, the European Fund for Strategic Investments and the financing of the Youth Employment Initiative.  The cooperation between the S&D and EPP groups resulted in a funding allocation of 1326 million for two important programmes: Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility, as well as for a number of other programmes aimed at boosting growth, competitiveness and jobs. In the area of economic, social and territorial cohesion, the adoption of amendments to increase the funding of the Youth Employment Initiative in the amount of EUR 473 million was particularly commendable, and in the sphere of sustainable development and natural resources, an emergency support package for dairy producers was approved. I am proud to point out that the S&D Group has managed to ensure an increase in relation to the draft Commission on Foreign Development Policy, Humanitarian Aid, the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights and other important development programmes.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The anti-corridas may be agitating when they shout at the end of European subsidies for fighting bull breeders, but they are in complete ignorance. Let me be clear, the CAP does not fund bullfighting. The CAP subsidizes beef and calf farms without discrimination. Secondly, if the States, such as Spain and France, want to direct part of the CAP and FEADER budget towards fighting bull breeding, it is their strictest right, nothing forbids them. The European Commission has had a clear position on this issue for many years. These amendments, even if voted, are legally wobbly and ill-prepared. They therefore have no value. Only the European right in its vast majority voted against, and thus respected the principle of subsidiarity and cultural freedoms. The other political families have dispersed, left, centrist, extremist. By not taking a clear position, they have flouted our traditions! The Greens and the anti-corridas lit a straw fire, this year it took, but by definition it will go out of itself. I will give them an appointment at the end of the budget negotiations.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft general budget for the financial year 2016, because I believe that Parliament's position adequately reflects European political priorities, seeking to mobilise the resources needed for the EU to be able to meet the important challenges it faces, in particular with regard to the migration and refugee crisis, job creation and business development and entrepreneurship. In this sense, it is necessary to welcome the comprehensive package of amendments presented with a view to providing a response to the migration crisis, both internally and externally. I would also like to highlight the proposals put forward to strengthen the COSME programme and Horizon 2020 and to ensure the continuity of the Youth Employment Initiative. It should also be stressed the importance of the €500 million emergency support package in aid to milk producers, as well as the relevance of the common payment plan for 2015-2016 agreed between Parliament, the Council and the Commission, in order to reduce the volume of late payments for cohesion programmes for the period 2007-2013.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Union's budget for 2016 voted by Parliament is ambitious and realistic in view of the challenges ahead and the limited resources we have. That is why I voted in favour of this text.  In cancelling the 4 billion euro cuts the Council's aim, MEPs reaffirmed their willingness to respond to the refugee crisis, the solution of which can only be European, but also their determination to support the European Union economy, which is still weakened by the lack of investor confidence, with a particular emphasis on innovation and SMEs as a growth driver.  With regard to transport and long-term investment, I am pleased that additional funds have been allocated to the Interconnection Mechanism in Europe, in order to intensify sustainable investments in energy, telecommunications and transport infrastructure. I also welcome the adoption of five additional posts by the European Railway Agency compared to what the Commission had proposed. As with immigration, let us cease to ask Europe more and more without giving it the corresponding means of action.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report, which provides, among other things, to meet the needs of the Member States managing the largest influx of refugees and migrants, as well as those from non-EU countries that still host more, 1.16 billion euros more for migration management measures that the European Commission originally proposed.  In terms of employment, Parliament has added EUR 473 million for contracts for new programmes to help unemployed young people find jobs. Farmers affected by the Russian embargo on food imports from the EU and low milk prices will also receive an additional EUR 500 million.  Finally, Parliament has added EUR 1.3 billion for the European research programme Horizon 2020 and the mechanism for the interconnection (of infrastructure) of Europe, to return the funds borrowed from them in order to launch the Juncker investment plan. On the other hand, I voted against any increase in the fees and expenses associated with the activity of an MEP.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained in the vote on this document which determines Parliament's negotiating position before the Commission and the Council. Firstly, because the budget is slightly better than in previous years (very slight increase), with its lights (growth of humanitarian spending on refugees, improvement of educational aspects, research, Youth Employment Initiative and support for SMEs) and its shadows (diversion of resources to an insufficient and problematic investment model to FEIE ̶ and ̶ significant percentage of additional resources for Europe-strength and greater "competitiveness"). Secondly, and mainly because it is a question of countering the Council's regressive proposal, which would be much worse. The Resolution is critical of the Council's approaches and includes several calls for extraordinary measures, the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework for more flexibility or the promotion of quality employment. Since the resulting budgets will presumably contribute to persevering in a neoliberal EU, with a derisory and non-redistributive budget, we will vote against it later.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 The EU budget must be modern and clearly focused on research, entrepreneurship and important future issues such as climate and the environment, if we are to meet tomorrow's challenges. This is not automatically tantamount to an increased budget. On the contrary, there is room for substantial savings and reprioritisation, including within the European Parliament. I have therefore voted in favour of a review of the so-called Members' Statute. However, I do not share the view that we MEPs should decide on our own salaries, fees and allowances.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Our position on the European Union budget for 2016 has been to increase expenditure on all budget items aimed at improving the functioning of the European Union. We have refused to finance European programmes that have an impact on the interests of the military industry or support institutions such as FRONTEX, assuming little profit for European citizens. We have also proposed and supported aid programmes for the countries under the Troika, occupied territories of Palestine and different programmes aimed at job creation and support for different sectors, and we have tried to avoid cuts in the most important headings for the European economy. We believe that the Union budget should avoid austerity policies in order to boost the economy and we voted in this regard.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. My opposition to death bull runs and other blood bullfighting is public, having signed a petition on the matter. I abstained in this vote on Amendments 22 and 435 because the proposal in question is incoherent, since there is no European funding for death bull races. As such, I believe that, as a Member of the European Parliament, despite the recognised good intention behind the proposal, this part of a false assumption, in my view, is a non-issue within the EU budget and a diversified one which, being expanded to other animal welfare issues, which I am fully defending, ends up creating serious noise problems with out-of-context matters , short in detail and poorly formalised.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this draft budget due to the huge spending increases. I am against the EU wasting taxpayers’ money in this way.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the Parliament’s negotiating position for the budget of the European Union because I do not believe that breaking the MFF ceilings is a fiscally responsible proposition at this time. As my colleague has said, more of the EU Budget needs to be spent on creating growth and more flexibility is needed to reprioritise the budget and direct it towards priority areas, such as the current humanitarian crisis and greater investment for growth. I could not agree more.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ The EU budget is primarily an investment budget that serves as a catalyst for growth, competitiveness and jobs across the Union. Pooling resources and economies facilitates the implementation of programmes and projects that would otherwise be difficult, or even impossible, to implement and guarantees strategic investments in projects with European added value.  The largest share of investment expenditure of the EU budget is the European Structural and Investment Funds, which are essential for job creation, increasing growth and improving competitiveness and innovation. The proposed investment plan and the EU budget are interconnected through the European Semester and complement each other, together aimed at reviving the economy and boosting job creation.  Nevertheless, in plenary, I declared myself abstention. While I welcome the Investment Plan put forward by the Commission, which can allow €315 billion to be mobilised to invest in infrastructure, education and research, and in SMEs and mid-caps to reduce the deficit of public and private investment caused by the economic and financial crisis, inequalities in the development of different REGIONS of the EU are increasing.  First of all, the justification, fairness and credibility of the budget objectives needs to be shown and the problems created by 2014 should be addressed, so that together, clean accounts can continue to be planned further.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of Parliament's proposal on the General Budget of the European Union for 2016, which will be used as a basis for reaching an agreement with the Council. Our proposal to allocate the Union's financial resources reflects the need to address the priorities for action that have recently emerged. Firstly, the migration and refugee crisis, for which we propose the allocation of adequate funds in line with what the Commission has proposed and against the cuts proposed by the Council, totalling around EUR 1 billion. We also aim to combat youth unemployment, with EUR 473 million for new job-seeking support programmes for unemployed young people, and to promote growth by increasing funding for Horizon 2020, Cosme and Erasmus+, but also by providing compensation for farmers affected by the Russian embargo on imports of European food products (around EUR 500 million). Particular attention has been paid to research and innovation, real drivers of competitiveness, to consolidate efforts in the construction of technologically advanced digital infrastructures through Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Mechanism. It is therefore a forward-looking budget based on an idea of inclusive and sustainable development.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report because I think the budget reflects the political priorities adopted by the majority in previously adopted resolutions. I believe that the priorities are internal and external solidarity, in particular the effective resolution of the migration and refugee crisis, as well as increasing competitiveness by creating decent and quality jobs and developing businesses and entrepreneurship in the Union.  The Union is facing a number of serious crises such as the migration and refugee crisis, and it is necessary to provide for the necessary financial resources to address the ongoing challenges that would allow the Union to urgently find solutions and respond effectively to these crises, which should be its priority. Of course, it is understood that the migration and refugee crisis cannot be solved solely through financial means.  I also support the decision to take action to address the ongoing crisis in the agricultural sector, in particular in the dairy sector, and will already include in its position on the 2016 budget emergency support measures of EUR 500 million announced by the Commission. I also support the decision to transfer the funds earmarked for crisis cases in 2015 to the 2016 budget and that these unused funds will be used to reimburse beneficiaries of direct payments, as provided for in Regulation (EU) No 2020/2016. 1306/2013.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016. A week ago, the Council called on the European Parliament to make realism in adopting the EU budget in 2016. The proposed amendments are a very realistic response to the problems we face in the EU, such as refugees, unemployment and growing disparities between members. In order for countries along the Balkan route to cooperate and protect one of the EU's fundamental acquisitions, Schengen and the free movement of people, they need resources. It is true, however, that there is a great deal of room for manoeuvre in EU spending to make them more efficient and efficient.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 This is the report that will give the mandate to Parliament's negotiating team for the follow-up tripartite dialogue on the 2016 budget.  This procedure is always done for the budget and decisions taken during the tripartite dialogue do not return to Parliament for final approval. That is why most of the time the Council passes all its positions and the budget lines are cut more even than the Commission's proposals. Of course, the whole process and the size of the budget lines is determined by the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020. With this report, Parliament is bringing all the funds back to the levels proposed by the Commission in its own proposal, bringing the commitments back to EUR 157 billion. 427.5 cm and payments to EUR 146 billion. 459.5 cm Compared to the previous year, it made cuts of EUR 3.5 billion. commitments and EUR 2.9 billion in commitments. payments.  We voted against this report, as our position on the budget is settled and there is no doubt that the 2016 budget is also another austerity budget.  Unfortunately, the Multiannual Financial Framework and the dominant neoliberal forces in the Council, the Commission and Parliament are following the same trends.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The 2016 draft budget shifts the European Union's focus to aid to a total of EUR 26 million to dependent organisations with migration-related tasks, with the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) receiving the largest increase of EUR 12 million above the amount of the draft budget, the FUND fund, rather than its own citizens and their needs. There are Member States of the Union that are plagued by the crisis, and yet they are the first countries to qualify as migrant collection countries and must, under EU rules, take care of them throughout their stay there. Countries such as Greece are unable to take care of its own citizens.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the draft EU budget for 2016, in full line with my group's political line, with the exception of the bullfighting line where I refused the amendment.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The report on the draft general budget of the EU for the financial year 2016 sets it at EUR 146 billion in payment appropriations, which is an increase of EUR 4 billion compared with the Council position. The increase in appropriations reflects two key political priorities of the EU – tackling the migration and refugee crisis and boosting competitiveness. Apart from expenditures on asylum and immigration, it will finance for example the COSME program for small and middle size enterprises, the research programme Horizon 2020 and mechanisms for the interconnection of Europe. In my, opinion, these objectives are well justified, and the dedication of more resources is crucial if we want to implement sustainable solutions to the migration crisis. I therefore voted in favour of it.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016 because it provides the necessary financial resources for all the Union's political challenges.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained in the vote on this document which determines Parliament's negotiating position before the Commission and the Council. Firstly, because the budget is slightly better than in previous years (very slight increase), with its lights (growth of humanitarian spending on refugees, improvement of educational aspects, research, Youth Employment Initiative and support for SMEs) and its shadows (diversion of resources to an insufficient and problematic investment model to FEIE ̶ and ̶ significant percentage of additional resources for Europe-strength and greater "competitiveness"). Secondly, and mainly because it is a question of countering the Council's regressive proposal, which would be much worse. The Resolution is critical of the Council's approaches and includes several calls for extraordinary measures, the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework for more flexibility or the promotion of quality employment. Since the resulting budgets will presumably contribute to persevering in a neoliberal EU, with a derisory and non-redistributive budget, we will vote against it later.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Parliament is proposing a budget proposal to confront the Commission's initials and the subsequent Council's initials. The EU budget is not voted on, but Parliament's proposal for the next phase of negotiation. Although the accounts and the Resolution do not fall within our discourse, it is tactically appropriate to abstain at this time. First, because the budget is slightly better than in previous years, obviously with its lights (growth, humanitarian spending on refugees, improvement of educational aspects, research, youth employment initiative and support for SMEs) and its shadows (diversion of resources to an insufficient and problematic investment model to FEIE ̶ and ̶ significant percentage of additional resources for Europe-strength and greater "competitiveness"). Secondly, because it is a question of taking a strong position which counteracts the Council's very regressive proposal. In this regard, the Resolution is critical of the Council's approaches and includes several calls for extraordinary measures and the revision of the multiannual financial framework. Therefore, as the resulting budgets will presumably unacceptable, with a derisory and non-redistributive budget, we will vote against it later.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I abstained because I do not share the general lines of the budget but I understand that Parliament's negotiating position in the trilogue and the conciliation committee meetings should be strengthened.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the general budget of the European Union for 2016. The resolution highlights that the Union is currently facing a number of serious emergencies, notably the unprecedented migration and refugee crisis, on which there is substantial focus in the 2016 budget. The main areas of the budget are: Competitiveness for growth and jobs;  Economic, social and territorial cohesion; Sustainable growth: Natural resources; Security and Citizenship; Global Europe and Administrative and research support expenditure. Parliament’s estimates for 2016 were set at EUR 1 823 648 600, which corresponds to a 1.6% increase over the 2015 budget; in addition, EUR 15 million have been earmarked for urgent investments in security and cyber security, setting the overall level of its 2016 budget at EUR 1 838 648 600.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Our position on the European Union budget for 2016 has been to increase expenditure on all budget items aimed at improving the functioning of the European Union. We have refused to finance European programmes that have an impact on the interests of the military industry or support institutions such as FRONTEX, assuming little profit for European citizens. We have also proposed and supported aid programmes for the countries under the Troika, occupied territories of Palestine and different programmes aimed at job creation and support for different sectors, and we have tried to avoid cuts in the most important headings for the European economy. We believe that the Union budget should avoid austerity policies in order to boost the economy and we voted in this regard.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This budget is a reflection of the current moment of this European Union. A project that is stranded in a sea of uncertainty of lack of mutual trust and that discourages countries from contributing to the budget. This budget, short for so much ambition, will only fuel the disillusionment of those who still believe in this European project. We have made positive efforts to build the best possible budget within the narrow limits determined by the refusal of the main countries to contribute to strengthening the budget, without which social and territorial cohesion policies are not possible. We have no illusions in a project that focuses everything on supply-side measures and believes that investment will fall from the sky through a strategic investment fund without credibility and that will only strengthen public-private partnerships and the concentration of investment in the wealthiest regions. It should also be recalled that many of the hottest issues discussed in this budget, such as support for farmers and refugees, stem from wrong policies taken in recent years and which stem from the neoliberal and neocolonial matrix that characterises this European Union, today in the midst of a crisis of values.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. It is incomprehensible that more money is to be spent. Often for purposes for which the Union does not even have a mandate. The report must therefore be rejected.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Parliament's budget proposal, which will be used as a basis for reaching an agreement with the Council. The European Commission has understood the dramatic nature of the migrant emergency – which is no longer an emergency but a structural issue – by allocating adequate funds while we parliamentarians have worked to compensate for the more meapic cuts proposed by the Council. Also this year we have aimed to save growth and jobs, increasing funding to Horizon 2020, Cosme and Erasmus+. We want a budget that focuss on research and innovation, focused on digital and telematic infrastructures, capable of looking to the future and not perched on an idea of development slightly out of history. We have made a lot of progress on the issue of the sharing economy. One of my pilot projects has been included among those worthy of funding. I will be able to tell you more in the coming months, but I hope that it will help, in its small way, to support those who invest in the most innovative and sustainable economies. In addition, Parliament will redistribute certain items of expenditure saving around EUR 12 million. A serious commitment, not small accounting made of receipts and populism.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am glad that we have approved the EU budget for 2016 in this form. In the vote, I supported an amendment asking the European Commission to start looking at the single seat of the European Parliament and present road maps on this initiative. I believe that moving Parliament 12 times a year is completely meaningless and financially inefficient.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 A number of amendments were tabled under the 2016 general budget proposal calling for austerity measures and, in particular, for not increasing expenditure in the European Parliament on buildings, missions or parliamentary assistants, inter alia. Although I support the idea of these proposals and need to set priorities and eliminate annual expenditure increases in non-priority areas in the current economic situation, I could not support all the proposals. I therefore did not support the proposals made by the political groups, whose political agenda is totally unacceptable to me, despite their content.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the EU's general budget for 2016 because it proposes an increase in the financing of our political priorities, and more specifically to offset the cuts in the agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EIE) to meet the R&D&I and infrastructure objectives that we have set ourselves, to ensure the additional resources needed for the internal and external dimension of the refugee crisis , renew our commitment to youth unemployment by funding one more year of the Youth Employment Initiative and compensating our farmers and ranchers, who are being affected by the Russian veto or the milk crisis. Our proposal amounts to EUR 157 427 547 086 in commitment appropriations, an increase of EUR 3.6 billion for 2016 which actually represents only a 2.34% increase.  In doing so, we want to send a strong political signal on what the EP's priorities are, highlight the lack of funding for key EU programmes, and establish a strong starting position for negotiations with the Council and the Commission during the conciliation procedure.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution on the budget of the European Union because it does not recognise the political importance of this instrument in boosting the economy of the 28 Member States. The Resolution contains positive points; indeed, it is a much better position than that of the Council, for example condemning the cuts caused by the reallocation of funds produced by the establishment of the EIES. However, we do not consider that it meets all the needs of the Union in the budgetary area, which needs an economic policy tool that increases public spending in the absence of any improvement in the international economy. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to amend the Council's draft general budget. This is a deeply harmful report. An additional EUR 900 million is being requested for immigration policy, bringing the total budget for the migration crisis currently affecting the European continent to 2.1 billion euros. These funds are intended to "distribute" refugees among European countries, to modernise reception centres, to pay for language training for asylum seekers or to strengthen rescue operations in the Mediterranean Sea. In no way is it a question of providing the means for a firm policy aimed at strengthening border control and deporting illegal immigrants to their countries of origin.  I naturally voted against this incondic report, which is satisfied with mass immigration despite the high rates of unemployment and poverty in the EU Member States, despite the huge cultural differences between indigenous peoples and the vast majority of immigrants.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The priority must always be to ensure value for money, that not a penny of taxpayers’ money is spent for the wrong reasons or wasted.  The money does not belong to the European Union, but to citizens. I therefore voted against the budget report, and in favour of those amendments which sought to improve the accountability of the EU institutions, which cut the costs for the taxpayer, and which would have shown us taking a lead in reducing our expenditure here in the Parliament. Sadly, these good amendments were voted down.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of reading the EP for the draft Budget 2016. 4 billion separate the position of the Council and that of Parliament, I guarantee that the final result will be far removed from the expectations expressed by parliamentarians. A period of conciliation between the two branches of the budgetary authority is now opening. I regret that our budget lacks resources, flexibility and responsiveness when it comes to migration. In this regard, there is an urgent need to revise the multi-year financial framework. I regret that the European Parliament has not been more rigorous in adopting its own budget. the credibility and authority of the EP in discussions with the Council depend on it.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016. The EU budget commitments for 2016 will amount to EUR 157.4 billion. Euro. The promotion of employment is a key priority of next year's budget. A total of around EUR 50 billion is earmarked for achieving this objective. The budget will support transnational exchanges of students, teachers and other staff (Erasmus+) and small and medium-sized enterprises (Cosme), as well as investments in research (Horizon 2020), infrastructure and strategic projects (Connecting Europe Facility, European Fund for Strategic Investments). Another budgetary priority is improving the reception of refugees, including improving infrastructure, faster processing of applications, and organising language courses. I support the proposal to strengthen the EU's external policy in order to combat the causes of the crisis in third countries.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The budget now looks to be restored to EUR 157.4 billion in commitments and EUR 146.5 billion for payments; this is due to the opposition relating to the proposed cuts.  There is major support for all EU programmes such as strengthening the European Neighbourhood Instrument plus Social and Territorial Cohesion. In addition to this there is added pressure to increase the budget to deal with the on-going refugee and migration crisis relating to the mismanagement of the disaster in the Mediterranean.  A further EUR 1.6 billion is directed to the Asylum Migration and Integration Fund; this includes Global Europe Security & Citizenship.  We cannot support programmes that have already been badly managed and expect the taxpayer to fund initiatives that are not valid or reliable in relation to meeting objectives of the citizens of Europe. These EU programmes do not serve the people of Europe but promote ‘more Europe’ and meet the political agenda of the Commission.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this immigration report, which calls for increasing funding for migrant assistance to the tune of EUR 1.1 million, in addition to the funding already voted for in the 2015 budget.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the draft 2016 budget proposed by Parliament because, unlike the cuts made by the Council, this project provides interesting resources to address the main challenges facing the Union. Economic recovery and job creation, of course, even if it is primarily a matter of political choice and will, but also research and development, the migration crisis for which EUR 800 million is planned, the supervision of banking supervision or the development of cross-border infrastructure.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is further proof of the over-awareness of the institutions of the European Union: not content with imposing ever more asphyxiating austerity on Member States, this report is not afraid to call for an increase to 146.5 billion euros in the commitments for the 2016 budget (which amounts to 4.4 billion euros more than what the Commission itself proposed and even exceeds the ceilings of 144.7 billion euros decided by the EU for the year). Not content with the economic and budgetary use of the citizens of the Member States, this increase is also geared towards the financing of mass immigration, since EUR 1.2 billion is spent on this submersion. But none of this reaches the level of expenditure that the Commission will spend on Eurobeate propaganda: EUR 26 million will be used in the service of the 'EU' mirage. It is in its budget reports that the EU reveals all its cynicism, and I could only vote against such a scandal.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the enormous costs of the Union's institutions, while very few resources are allocated to services to citizens, I have expressed my negative opinion.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted against the budget report. The budget is too large and comprehensive. There should be substantial cuts. Agricultural policy results in overproduction and negative effects on the environment, the climate and animal husbandry. Another example is the incalculable regional and structural funds, where there is widespread fraud. I am opposed to the efforts of Frontex, which means the continued construction of Fortress Europe, which forces people fleeing war and oppression, to risk their lives to get to sanctuary. Initiatives to increase the militarisation of the EU are completely the wrong path for a Union that claims to defend human rights and is a peace project. I am opposed to the European institutions having such high budget accounts. Measures are needed to reduce excessive salaries, allowances and the like. On the other hand, I have voted in favour of draft texts and budget lines which, for example, sharply criticise the EU's macroeconomic austerity policies that deepen the crisis within the Union, as well as proposals aimed at action on gender equality, action against racism and xenophobia, and support for life-saving and humanitarian efforts to help refugees and asylum seekers. In principle, I think it is wrong that the European Parliament has power over the budget. The Member States that pay the EU budget should have full decision-making power over Union expenditure.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the EU's general budget for 2016 because it proposes an increase in the financing of our political priorities, and more specifically to offset the cuts in the agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EIE) to meet the R&D&I and infrastructure objectives that we have set ourselves, to ensure the additional resources needed for the internal and external dimension of the refugee crisis , renew our commitment to youth unemployment by funding one more year of the Youth Employment Initiative and compensating our farmers and ranchers, who are being affected by the Russian veto or the milk crisis. Our proposal amounts to EUR 157 427 547 086 in commitment appropriations, an increase of EUR 3.6 billion for 2016 which actually represents only a 2.34% increase.  In doing so, we want to send a strong political signal on what the EP's priorities are, highlight the lack of funding for key EU programmes, and establish a strong starting position for negotiations with the Council and the Commission during the conciliation procedure.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Cohesion funds for Hungary were confirmed in the vote, as the plenary confirmed the position that efforts to reduce the European Regional Development Fund's framework by 20% for countries (including Hungary) that opposed the European Commission's quotas for the relocation of migrants were already voted down by a large majority in the Committee on Budgets. A priority was to reverse the reduction of the Pre-Accession Fund proposed by the Council. These instruments have a decisive impact on the accession efforts of the candidate countries, such as Serbia and the Hungarians in Vojvodina. Thanks to the proposals of the Fidesz delegation, tens of millions of euros have been raised. The plenary session defended agricultural resources from council cuts in line with Hungarian interests. The EUR 500 million milk rescue package can be provided by the EU budget for 2016, so that Hungarian dairy farmers can receive the announced EU aid of HUF 2.9 billion on time. Hungarian PP members voted to ensure that Hungary winner of the 2016 EU budget. Among the proposals adopted is the joint project "A Diverse Europe". In this context, €1 million of EU funds will be available to applicants to finance minority programmes to combat discrimination.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which contained a number of important provisions.  Specifically, it highlighted that the European Union is currently facing a number of serious emergencies, notably the unprecedented migration and refugee crisis. This report called for financial resources to be deployed in the EU budget, in order to match the political challenges and therefore enable the EU to deliver and effectively respond to these crises, as a matter of utmost urgency and priority. Whilst of course the refugee and migration crisis cannot be solved by financial resources alone, in these extraordinary times, extraordinary measures are required and a strong political commitment is needed to secure fresh appropriations for this purpose. It was for these reasons, amongst others, that I voted in favour of this report.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I broadly agree with the budgetary priorities it identifies for the year 2016. In particular, I am convinced that the increase in resources dedicated to tackling the migration crisis is an important signal.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The EU's general budget for the 2016 financial year is already indiscriminately taking into account the financing of infrastructure for the reception of illegal migrants. However, the rapporteur recommends increasing this budget by EUR 1.161 billion in order to respond to this unprecedented migration crisis. Their so-called solidarity is making a mockery at a time when millions of Europeans are suffering from mass unemployment and poverty. Their foreign preference is simply unworthy of politicians whose sole purpose should be to defend the interests of their people.  These additional expenditures are being carried out at the expense of the cohesion policy, which nevertheless reduces regional disparities within the European Union and promotes the structural competitiveness of our economies. This budget also does not propose any sustainable solution to ensure that the backlog of unpaid bills is reduced in terms of the implementation of the programmes for the period 2014-2020. That is why I voted against this budget.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Final vote clearly against the own-initiative report accompanying the 2016 budget of the European institutions. My motives are primarily political, but I also have fundamental objections. Much more could and should be done to reduce the costs of the EU institutions. We owe this, firstly, to our local administrators who have important responsibilities, but very little resources to use to provide efficient services to citizens.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the EU's general budget for 2016 because it proposes an increase in the financing of our political priorities, and more specifically to offset the cuts in the agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EIE) to meet the R&D&I and infrastructure objectives that we have set ourselves, to ensure the additional resources needed for the internal and external dimension of the refugee crisis , renew our commitment to youth unemployment by funding one more year of the Youth Employment Initiative and compensating our farmers and ranchers, who are being affected by the Russian veto or the milk crisis. Our proposal amounts to EUR 157 427 547 086 in commitment appropriations, an increase of EUR 3.6 billion for 2016 which actually represents only a 2.34% increase.  In doing so, we want to send a strong political signal on what the EP's priorities are, highlight the lack of funding for key EU programmes, and establish a strong starting position for negotiations with the Council and the Commission during the conciliation procedure.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has voted its position on the EU budget for 2016. The priorities are employment, competitiveness, the management of the refugee crisis and the agricultural crisis. It is important to build a strong and effective EU budget to meet the various challenges that lie ahead in 2016. I hope that the European Parliament will make its voice heard in the negotiations with the Council.  The European Parliament's position is both realistic and ambitious. There will be an increase in budgets for youth job search programmes as well as for the COSME, Horizon 2020 and Erasmus programmes. An additional EUR 500 million will also be mobilised for dairy farmers affected by the Russian embargo. Parliament intends to reconcile the EU budget with the political programme that Europe aspires to. I am particularly sensitive to the funding of the pilot project on the creation of European coastguards, which I have proposed and which has been taken up by the European Commission.  I voted in favour of the European Union's draft general budget for 2016.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Regarding both internal and external issues that the EU is facing, I agree with the rapporteur that the Union needs a rise in its budget in order to tackle them. The report aims to alleviate the migration and refugee situation and also improve competitiveness through employment, entrepreneurship and innovation. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The priorities put to the vote today are largely to be welcomed, but I am critical of the general approach to the imbalance between commitments and payments (which is unlikely to be resolved by increasing the gap between the two items each year). I supported the amendments concerning a single seat of the European Parliament, the funding of a pilot project for alternative methods to animal testing and the one aimed at preventing bull farmers from receiving European funding. As far as administrative expenditure is concerned, there is not the slightest mention of a reduction in administrative expenditure, and every year there is an increase in it, which is not at all sustainable at a time when it is the EU itself that is calling for restrictions on the Member States. Together with the M5S Europa delegation, I voted against.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I agree with the increase in commitment and payment appropriations compared to the previous year, which should provide the European Union with the necessary instruments to support and promote its values and interests and contribute to the protection of its citizens in its relations with the rest of the world. In particular, the importance of the considerable increase in payments, which will help to cope with the delay in recent years. I would also like to point out that the number of refugees and internally displaced persons in the world has reached an unprecedented level of 60 million and that, as a result, the need for humanitarian aid has increased. To this must be added new funds to be used for education in refugee camps and in emergency and crisis situations, as this can provide key skills to save lives, help children build a future and protect them from radicalisation. Finally, I would like to point out that a high level of environmental and health protection in the Union is an indispensable condition for economic prosperity and that the safety of food and feed and the mechanisms that contribute to protection against natural and man-made disasters are of fundamental importance to all European citizens and, consequently, to the European Parliament.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The budget now looks to be restored to EUR 157.4 billion in commitments and EUR 146.5 billion for payments; this is due to the opposition relating to the proposed cuts.  There is major support for all EU programmes such as strengthening the European Neighbourhood Instrument plus Social and Territorial Cohesion. In addition to this there is added pressure to increase the budget to deal with the on-going refugee and migration crisis relating to the mismanagement of the disaster in the Mediterranean.  A further EUR 1.6 billion is directed to the Asylum Migration and Integration Fund; this includes Global Europe Security & Citizenship.  We cannot support programmes that have already been badly managed and expect the taxpayer to fund initiatives that are not valid or reliable in relation to meeting objectives of the citizens of Europe. These EU programmes do not serve the people of Europe but promote ‘more Europe’ and meet the political agenda of the Commission.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the Indrek Tarand amendment, as I did last year, because it results from a misunderstanding. 1. If the Community budget had any provision to finance bullfighting, it would make sense to vote against it. It is not for the European Union to intervene in these matters. They fall exclusively in national jurisdiction. 2. The truth is that the Community budget, and specifically the CAP (Common Agricultural Policy), does not finance either bullfighting or bullfighting.  This is clear in law and has been reiterated to the European Parliament by the Director-General for Agriculture and Rural Development. 3. CAP support for several years has been translated into direct aid to farmers who, on their land, have the autonomy to, depending on objective conditions (soil, climate, water, size, etc.) and the market, to develop the most appropriate agricultural activities, and this includes livestock and cattle. 4. The usefulness of this proposal seems to focus on raising the European Parliament's awareness of the fight against bullfighting, but the expedient used is not appropriate and violates the principle of subsidiarity, since it is not community competence.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The budget is an annual battleground for new needs and policy projects, but a fair balance needs to be struck in order to continue to support all those funding programmes that are already functioning and to invest in new instruments, clearly and transparently defining the political priorities and objectives to be achieved. In my opinion, two of the main priorities are certainly employment, especially among young people, as well as the need to adequately support SMEs in terms of access to markets and funding.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution on the budget of the European Union because it does not recognise the political importance of this instrument in boosting the economy of the 28 Member States. The Resolution contains positive points; indeed, it is a much better position than that of the Council, for example condemning the cuts caused by the reallocation of funds produced by the establishment of the EIES. However, we do not consider that it meets all the needs of the Union in the budgetary area, which needs an economic policy tool that increases public spending in the absence of any improvement in the international economy. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the general budget of the European Union for 2016. It covers the administrative budgets of the EU institutions including the European Parliament (EP) but excluding the European Commission. I voted in favour of a roadmap to a single seat. I agree with the S&D’s work to ensure transparency of the General Expenditure allowance. I abstained on the Greens’ Amendment 26 since whilst I agree with further transparency and accountability the amendment was loaded with other issues which required further clarification.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the European Executive's proposal for solutions to the persistent crisis affecting European farmers, in particular in the dairy sector, and, in particular, the proposal to already integrate EUR 500 million in its position on the 2016 budget to support the emergency measures announced by the Commission.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report sets out Parliament's position on the 2016 EU budget. It recommends reversing the cuts made by the Council in the European Commission's proposal and adding funds to finance migration-related measures inside and outside the European Union. I believe that it is also essential to provide answers to the challenges of youth employment in the face of unemployment and the funding of research and transport programmes, which were reduced earlier this year in order to finance the Juncker plan. Considering that migration and youth employment are two priority issues on which the European Union must provide swift and effective responses, I voted in favour of this report.
