name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted in favour of this report because it addresses a number of important problems that we, as the EU, are facing at the moment. The first is certainly the current migration crisis, which requires more resources to be made available. A second is to support the competitiveness of our companies. It is important that we provide sufficient funding for start-ups and companies that are growing. Special attention should be paid to SMEs, as we are doing now by strengthening COSME.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted on the European Parliament's 2016 budget proposal, which nullifies all budget cuts initiated by the Council and focuses on dealing with the refugee crisis, the agricultural crisis, employment, competitiveness and the programmes that are dear to me such as Horizon 2020 and Erasmus. We have thus voted a total of EUR 1.16 billion to deal with the refugee crisis, both internally and externally. The budget aims to continue funding the Youth Employment Initiative in 2016 and adds EUR 473 million for programmes to help young people find jobs. Parliament has also added EUR 1.3 billion to the Horizon 2020 research programme and the Interconnection Mechanism to offset the funds borrowed from these budget lines to finance the Juncker Plan guarantee. The budget also proposes to mobilise an additional EUR 500 million for dairy farmers affected by the Russian embargo. Finally, during the vote, an amendment on the single seat was tabled, which I opposed. I am very attached to the Strasbourg Parliament, a symbol of European integration.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Hungarian People's Party members voted to ensure that Hungary one of the winners of the 2016 EU budget. In the course of the vote, we defended the cohesion funds due to Hungary, because the plenary confirmed the position that, even in the Committee on Budgets, efforts to reduce the European Regional Development Fund by 20% for countries (including Hungary) that opposed the European Commission's quotas for the relocation of migrants were voted down by a large majority. A priority was to reverse the reduction of the Pre-Accession Fund proposed by the Council. These instruments have a decisive impact on the accession efforts of the candidate countries, such as Serbia and the Hungarians in Vojvodina. Thanks to the proposals of the Fidesz delegation, tens of millions of euros have been raised. The plenary session defended agricultural resources from council cuts in line with Hungarian interests. The EUR 500 million milk rescue package can be provided by the EU budget for 2016, so that Hungarian dairy farmers can receive the announced EU aid of HUF 2.9 billion on time. Among the proposals adopted is the joint project "Diverse Europe" by Pál Csáky (MKP) and Kinga Gál (FIDESZ). In this context, €1 million of EU funds will be available to applicants to finance minority programmes to combat discrimination.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerned the general budget of the European Union for 2016. Filled with a demagoguery of the reduction of operating costs inherent in any institution, while at the same time more than one million euros is still allocated for the financing of the migration invasion, this report is contradictory. While the travel and other allowances used by Members are used to properly exercise the mandate entrusted to them by the people, it is believed that they are making substantial savings by tackling this issue, which does not weigh in any way on the Union budget. Let Europe instead stop destroying The identity and the European economy, where the costs are in billions or even priceless costs to our heritage, rather than demagoguery without solving the real problems of its budget. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report and thus against an EU spending increase. If this report were enacted the amendments would exhaust several margins and the expenditure agreed as part of the multinational financial framework (MFF) for years 2014-20. We should not forget our key aims in relation to the creation of jobs, promoting growth and competitiveness in the EU.

name: Linnéa Engström (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. I support the content of the amendment which seeks to reduce members' fees. However, I abstained because it is not possible to change this in the budget, but it must be amended in the Members' Statute, according to which members' salary should be 38.5% of the basic salary of a judge of the Court of Justice.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The 2016 draft budget shifts the European Union's focus to aid to a total of EUR 26 million to dependent organisations with migration-related tasks, with the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) receiving the largest increase of EUR 12 million above the amount of the draft budget, the FUND fund, rather than its own citizens and their needs. There are Member States of the Union that are plagued by the crisis, and yet they are the first countries to qualify as migrant collection countries and must, under EU rules, take care of them throughout their stay there. Countries such as Greece are unable to take care of their own citizens.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the direction of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of parliament's position on the 2016 EU budget.  In plenary, the EP defended agricultural resources from the reduction proposed by the Council, in line with Hungarian interests. The EUR 500 million milk rescue package can be provided by the EU budget for 2016, so that all obstacles can be removed from the fact that Hungarian dairy farmers receive the announced EUR 2.9 billion in EU aid on time.

name: Peter Eriksson (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. 'We support the content of Amendment No 9 on paragraph 97, which seeks to reduce Members' allowances but abstained, because it is not possible to amend this in the budget, but it must be amended in the Members' Court of Justice which states that members' salary should be 38.5 % of the basic salary of a judge of the Court of Justice of the European Union;

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Included in this budgetary resolution I voted to cut EU subsidies for bullfighting in Spain. Many of my constituents in Wales had contacted me about this issue and I believe it was the right thing to do for the sake of animal rights.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. My final vote on the European Union budget for 2016 was against. However, I would like to point out that I voted in favour of a number of important amendments, which called for: making unemployment and the fight against poverty the EU's priorities; a substantial reduction in Members' general allowance costs; an increase in funding for the 'fruit in schools' programme; a 'Single Seat' for a single seat of the European Parliament; the increase in funds to be devoted to the fight against climate change; the funding of a pilot project for alternative methods to animal testing. I also voted in favour of the amendment calling for the cap appropriations not to be used to finance lethal bullfights, listening to the voices of thousands of citizens who, like me, consider this practice unacceptable, as well as a clear violation of the European Convention on the Protection of Animals in Livestock Farming (Council Directive 98/58/EC).

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 The EU budget for 2016 must be used in the best possible way. An example of this is to allocate as much as possible, of course within the framework of the multiannual budget ceiling, to the effective reception of refugees and migrants in the Member States. It is a pity that the Council does not share this view. The EU budget must be modern and clearly focused on research, entrepreneurship and important future issues such as climate and the environment, if we are to meet tomorrow's challenges. This is not automatically tantamount to an increase in the budget. On the contrary, there is room for substantial savings and reprioritisation, including within the European Parliament. I have therefore voted in favour of a review of the so-called Members' Statute. However, I do not share the view that we MEPs should decide on our own salaries, fees and allowances.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This budget proposal is realistic, responsible and credible. The European Union must ensure greater competitiveness and greater economic growth, and it must respond to the refugee crisis. The budget provides for €157.4 billion in commitments and €146.5 billion in payments, of which 94% is for investment, with only 6% for administrative expenditure. Job creation is the central priority of this proposal for the General Budget of the European Union for 2016. Therefore, I propose that the Youth Employment initiative continue and propose measures to support economic development – with a particular focus on strengthening the competitiveness of the economy through what is called 3 E(s) – Employment, Enterprise, Entrepreneurship. We have therefore strengthened the Research and Innovation Programme "Horizon 2020", the Connecting Europe Facility, the Cosme programme, the Erasmus+ programme and the Programme for Employment and Social Innovation. We have also reinforced support for farmers to deal with the milk crisis by EUR 500 million. The issue of refugees must be seen from an internal and external perspective. On the one hand, we have an obligation to welcome and integrate, but at the same time we have to solve the problem at the origin. Our internal and external solidarity is an obligation. To this end, we propose an additional eur 1 200 million.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 With this resolution, the European Parliament adopts its position on the proposed EU budget for 2016. The resolution agrees with the Commission's proposal, subsequently amended by the Council and the amendments introduced by Parliament in the meantime. Our disagreement with the draft budget is a backline disagreement. Of course, for that reason, we can only vote against this report. We do not ignore the "original sin" of this budget: the large financial envelope that determines it – the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework, the lowest in the eu's history – is far from being able to effect any relevant redistributive function that could effect the much-proposed principle of economic and social cohesion. But even in view of this embarrassment, nothing despicable, another budget was possible. The amendments we have tabled show this. Proposals are proposed to reinforce existing programmes aimed at cohesion and social and environmental areas, while cutting back on other areas, such as eu external interventionism, militarism and institutional propaganda. They give a different direction for Europe. A direction of refusal of the Budgetary Treaty, which puts on the agenda the need for debt restructuring, alongside the dissolution of EMU and the recovery of monetary and budgetary sovereignty.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained because I feel the report could have gone further.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The 2016 draft budget shifts the European Union's focus to aid to a total of EUR 26 million for dependent organisations with migration-related tasks, with the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) receiving the largest increase, amounting to EUR 12 million above the amount of the draft budget, the FUND fund, rather than to its own citizens and their needs. Countries such as Greece are unable to take care of their own citizens. For these reasons I am voting against the General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016 for all departments.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the fact that the level of the budget’s increase is the same as the level of the estimates approved in spring 2015: reinforcements in the appropriations due to the creation of a new political group (ENL) and those necessary to ensure stable employment of contract staff in all political groups have been fully compensated by decreases in the EP administrative budget. I support the enhanced transparency of the General Expenditure Allowance and the roadmap to a Single Seat, as well as the fact that the Commission’s draft budget has been mostly restored – thus rejecting the cuts by the Council – with some adjustments to take into account the specific needs of the institutions. My congratulations for the efforts made in order to restore the Draft Budget for the European External Action Service.
