name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the 2016 budget of the European Union. I would particularly like to stress the important allocation, thanks to Parliament's requests and amendments, for programmes for growth and social cohesion. I also think it is very significant that we have solemnly sanctioned, once again, the call for a single seat in the European Parliament, in order to put an end to the waste of resources and to rationalise the political and parliamentary work of us, the representatives of the European citizens.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I welcome in principle the draft general budget of the European Union for 2016, as I see a serious desire to save. However, I cannot accept the millions of investments planned by the 'wave plan' from next year in the renovation of the dilapidated Brussels Parliament buildings and the wasteful construction of new buildings, which are ultimately 30-50 percent above the average price of Brussels office buildings. Parliament should - as proposed by me and the Groupe Kammerzell - sell the buildings in Brussels and present a roadmap for the complete relocation to Strasbourg.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the Report on the Council position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016. Breaking the MFF ceilings is not a fiscally responsible proposition.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The ECR Group has consistently argued for fiscal discipline and a reduced EU budget, one in which the same budgetary rigour applied to national spending is applied to EU spending.  True, the migration and refugee crisis present significant challenges that should not be ignored, however we should not forget our key aims in relation to the creation of jobs, promoting growth and competitiveness in the EU. Each one of these is crucial for the stability and future success of the Union and therefore should not be compromised by inflation-busting EU budget increases. I subsequently support the alternative budget motion presented by the ECR Group which outlines a series of ideas for a less burdensome yet more targeted EU budget. It is for these reasons that I voted against.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained in the vote on this document which determines Parliament's negotiating position before the Commission and the Council. Firstly, because the budget is slightly better than in previous years (very slight increase), with its lights (growth of humanitarian spending on refugees, improvement of educational aspects, research, Youth Employment Initiative and support for SMEs) and its shadows (diversion of resources to an insufficient and problematic investment model to FEIE ̶ and ̶ significant percentage of additional resources for Europe-strength and greater "competitiveness"). Secondly, and mainly because it is a question of countering the Council's regressive proposal, which would be much worse. The Resolution is critical of the Council's approaches and includes several calls for extraordinary measures, the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework for more flexibility or the promotion of quality employment. Since the resulting budgets will presumably contribute to persevering in a neoliberal EU, with a derisory and non-redistributive budget, we will vote against it later.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. The European budget is the cornerstone of our actions and policies. In 2016, more than ever, this budget must enable us to meet many challenges, including the Greek crisis, the youth employment initiative, the reception of migrants and the dairy crisis.  In order for our political choices to be translated in a concrete way, in the daily lives of our citizens, we need stronger budgetary resources, which is why I have supported an increase of EUR 800 million in the European budget. We must now ensure that the Council does not question these amounts, which are primarily aimed at supporting long-term policies, and certainly not just managing the urgency of the crises we are going through.  That is why, together with my colleagues, the Council has strengthened strategic financing for the revival of growth, including Horizon 2020 and Connecting Europe Facility, which funds cross-border infrastructure projects. Negotiations will now begin with the Council. The battle has only just begun between our institutions, in diametrically opposed positions.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the EU's general budget for 2016 because it proposes an increase in the financing of our policy priorities, and more specifically to compensate for the cuts in the agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EIE) to meet the R&D&I and infrastructure objectives we have set ourselves, to ensure the additional resources needed for the internal and external dimension of the refugee crisis , renew our commitment to youth unemployment by funding one more year of the Youth Employment Initiative and compensating our farmers and ranchers, who are being affected by the Russian veto or the milk crisis. Our proposal amounts to EUR 157 427 547 086 in commitment appropriations, an increase of EUR 3.6 billion for 2016 which actually represents only a 2.34% increase.  In doing so, we want to send a strong political signal on what the EP's priorities are, highlight the lack of funding for key EU programmes, and establish a strong starting position for negotiations with the Council and the Commission during the conciliation procedure.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Hungarian People's Party members voted to ensure that Hungary one of the winners of the 2016 EU budget. In the course of the vote, we defended the cohesion funds due to Hungary, because the plenary confirmed the position that, even in the Committee on Budgets, efforts to reduce the European Regional Development Fund by 20% for countries (including Hungary) that opposed the European Commission's quotas for the relocation of migrants were voted down by a large majority. A priority was to reverse the reduction of the Pre-Accession Fund proposed by the Council. These instruments have a decisive impact on the accession efforts of the candidate countries, such as Serbia and the Hungarians in Vojvodina. Thanks to the proposals of the Fidesz delegation, tens of millions of euros have been raised.  The plenary session defended agricultural resources from council cuts in line with Hungarian interests. The EUR 500 million milk rescue package can be provided by the EU budget for 2016, so that Hungarian dairy farmers can receive the announced EU aid of HUF 2.9 billion on time. Among the proposals adopted is a joint project between Pál Csáky (MKP) and Kinga Gál (FIDESZ) entitled "A Diverse Europe", under which EUR 1 million of EU funds will be available to applicants to finance minority programmes to support the elimination of discrimination.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it will put in place a sound package of budgetary measures for 2016.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The budget now looks to be restored to EUR 157.4 billion in commitments and EUR 146.5 billion for payments; this is due to the opposition relating to the proposed cuts.  There is major support for all EU programmes such as strengthening the European Neighbourhood Instrument plus Social and Territorial Cohesion. In addition to this there is added pressure to increase the budget to deal with the on-going refugee and migration crisis relating to the mismanagement of the disaster in the Mediterranean.  A further EUR 1.6 billion is directed to the Asylum Migration and Integration Fund; this includes Global Europe Security & Citizenship.  We cannot support programmes that have already been badly managed and expect the taxpayer to fund initiatives that are not valid or reliable in relation to meeting objectives of the citizens of Europe. These EU programmes do not serve the people of Europe but promote ‘more Europe’ and meet the political agenda of the Commission.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. Parliament has requested commitment appropriations of EUR 157.4 billion and payment appropriations of EUR 146.5 billion for the 2016 EU budget, resulting in a net increase of EUR 4.159 and EUR 4.34 billion respectively. The aim is to repeal almost all Council cuts and to ignore the ceilings agreed between Member States in the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework. In addition to sensible budget increases, such as the request for an additional EUR 1.161 billion to deal with the current migration crisis and EUR 473.2 million for the fight against youth unemployment, there are numerous budget lines that the parliamentary majority wants to provide with equal or higher resources largely unaudited. For example, structural and cohesion policy and agriculture/environment alone account for more than two thirds of the EU budget, although the implementation of programmes and activities, especially in cohesion policy, is often deficient. Nevertheless, these areas should remain untouched regardless of the performance achieved. This is offset by cuts in the very important areas of research (Horizon 2020) and infrastructure (Connecting Europe Facility CEF). Our demands for a sustainable, balanced and transparent budget have not been taken into account in this draft budget. That is why I voted against Parliament's 2016 draft budget. Incidentally , and this is my ceterum censeo – I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. The migration crisis in Europe is leading us to redefine our priorities. This naturally has an impact on the Community budget. I the for example, I welcome the European Parliament's decision to increase funding for migration by EUR 1.16 billion. It is an emergency and a necessity. However, I make it clear that this money is spent on relevant actions and measures that restore control of migration flows.  I also regret the vote of a majority of MePs against the seat of Parliament in Strasbourg. This has been a recurring trend for several years, reflecting the weariness of these monthly transhumances for a majority of MEPs well-established in Brussels.  However, if I understand the relevance of a single seat, I think it must be in Strasbourg. Is it not the heart of European integration, the symbol of Franco-German friendship that remains to this day the real engine of Europe?  By abandoning Strasbourg, we are abandoning the sense of this formidable movement of solidarity and cooperation that our Founding Fathers had wished to establish, we are losing the memory of this tragic history that led them to found a common and unwavering foundation of values.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒I voted for a proposal for a Resolution from the European Parliament on the Council's position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, on the basis that I consider that budget to be in line with the Political Priorities of the Union. One of the key aspects of next year's budget is of course the migration and refugee crisis and therefore I fully agree with the increase in funding for this purpose, as exceptional opportunities require exceptional measures.  Accordingly, I also support urgent support measures that are dedicated to the crisis that has affected European farmers and has a significant impact on the overall EU economy. However, the implementation of existing Union policies and the respected payment plan for 2015-2016 should be ensured. SMEs' financing must take an important place in the budget, as they are the same driver of growth and should be supported in accessing markets.  Furthermore, as the implementation of cohesion policy programmes is likely to be delayed, it is necessary to try to keep the delay to a minimum, as the policies concerned are particularly important for the balanced growth of the Union. Moreover, I believe that the Union budget should be more flexible in order to be able to respond in a timely and efficient manner to external and internal crises that are increasingly present.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. There is talk of amending the Council's draft general budget.  An additional EUR 900 million is being asked of European taxpayers to allocate them to immigration policy, bringing the total budget for the migration crisis currently affecting the European continent to 2.1 billion euros. These funds are intended to "distribute" refugees among European countries, to modernise reception centres, to pay for language training for asylum seekers, or to strengthen rescue operations in the Mediterranean Sea. In no way is it a question of providing the means for a firm policy aimed at strengthening border control and deporting illegal immigrants to their countries of origin.  This report is insy and satisfied with mass immigration despite high rates of unemployment and poverty, despite also the huge cultural differences between indigenous peoples and the vast majority of immigrants.  I voted against this report.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The budget now looks to be restored to EUR 157.4 billion in commitments and EUR 146.5 billion for payments; this is due to the opposition relating to the proposed cuts.  There is major support for all EU programmes such as strengthening the European Neighbourhood Instrument plus Social and Territorial Cohesion. In addition to this there is added pressure to increase the budget to deal with the on-going refugee and migration crisis relating to the mismanagement of the disaster in the Mediterranean.  A further EUR 1.6 billion is directed to the Asylum Migration and Integration Fund; this includes Global Europe Security & Citizenship.  We cannot support programmes that have already been badly managed and expect the taxpayer to fund initiatives that are not valid or reliable in relation to meeting objectives of the citizens of Europe. These EU programmes do not serve the people of Europe but promote ‘more Europe’ and meet the political agenda of the Commission.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is important that the EU budget for next year is sufficient to deal with issues such as the migration crisis. As the ALDE draftsperson on the LIBE opinion to the budget, I pushed for more funding in order to better secure the EU’s borders and to address security concerns. I am pleased that Parliament as a whole backed the increase to the FRONTEX budget as well as for the European Agenda on Security. This is a step towards better managing the current crisis.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by my colleagues José Manuel Fernandes and Gérard Deprez on the political resolution of the General Budget of the European Union for the 2016 financial year. This resolution calls for an increase in the budget of key programmes, such as Erasmus, or aid to small and medium-sized enterprises, necessary to tackle issues such as mass unemployment in the European Union and the refugee crisis. This position, contrary to the Council's proposal, was essential for the Union to carry out its policies. Parliament's resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This report must be rejected because, in fact, funds are intended to be used for purposes for which the Union has no mandate.

name: Rikke Karlsson (ECR)
text: In writing. With the ECR Group, we had been working for several weeks on an alternative resolution to the Fernandez-Deprez proposal on the draft budget for 2016. I voted with my group, particularly considering the efforts we are calling on the Commission to promote youth employment. For the rest, I have been vigilant on specific budget lines. For example, through the Daphne programme, funding for the emergency alert line (116,000) for missing children must be supported. I also voted in favour of a roadmap for a single seat of the European Parliament, which is a source of substantial savings. I have spoken out again against the millions of euros of public money paid for cruel shows in which intentional injuries and killings are inflicted on animals: Europe in crisis certainly has better money to make that taxpayers entrust to it!

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against a number of measures which would have seen the overall EU budget increase and against proposed rises for agricultural subsidies, including bullfighting subsidies, and administration. I voted instead to focus the EU budget more heavily upon investment for growth and jobs and voted for regional funding that goes directly to communities that are best able to determine how to deliver for people locally. I want to see a real budget reform in the EU, with areas that do not bring any real benefits to our constituents cut.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the Council's position on the European Union's draft general budget for the 2016 financial year. Like the other Members of the National Front and the Europe of Nations and Freedoms group, I supported the vast majority of amendments to reduce the budget, but these were not accepted. In addition, paragraph 77 of the report calls into question Strasbourg's position as the seat of the European Parliament, provided for by the Treaty. It is scandalous to find such claims in a budget report.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it increases aid to migrants by more than one million euros, which is already considerable. It yields to good immigrationist sentiments instead of defending the peoples of Europe.

name: Sander Loones (ECR)
text: Written. 'With this resolution, the European Parliament indicates that it wants to increase the EU budget by more than EUR 4 billion in 2016. The N-VA delegation does not share this view. Not only do the Member States have to make savings, but the EU must also make a move. The N-VA supports the additional expenditure in response to the migration crisis or to compensate for the EFSI cuts to Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility, but considers that existing budgets should be shifted in the first place before there can be an increase in the budget. There are still many efficiency gains to be made within the current budget, for example in budget lines with a weak implementation rate or within budgets that do not offer added EU value. The N-VA delegation therefore voted against the joint resolution and instead supports the recommendations made in the alternative ECR resolution.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution on the budget of the European Union because it does not recognise the political importance of this instrument in boosting the economy of the 28 Member States. The Resolution contains positive points; indeed, it is a much better position than that of the Council, for example condemning the cuts caused by the reallocation of funds produced by the establishment of the EIES. However, we do not consider that it meets all the needs of the Union in the budgetary area, which needs an economic policy tool that increases public spending in the absence of any improvement in the international economy. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The draft budget for 2016 was prepared starting from key priorities defined at EU level: job creation, economic growth, investment and new migration policies. In the draft budget for 2016, The Commission is proposing a total of €153.5 billion for commitments and €143.5 billion for payments, representing increases of 2.4 percent for commitments and 1.6 percent for payments compared to 2015.  Parliament has proposed an increase to 157.4 billion euros for commitments, or 146.4 billion euros for payment. I supported Parliament's proposal, as this increase is important to allow for additional financing of development projects in the field of quality employment, fostering entrepreneurship and the development of SMEs, but also to strengthen existing instruments in response to the ongoing migration crisis.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the Council's position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 27/10/2015 and because it is not complete and documented.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ More of the EU Budget needs to be spent on creating growth and more flexibility is needed to reprioritise the budget and direct it towards priority areas like the current humanitarian crisis and greater investment for growth. Over the last year we have seen a major humanitarian crisis unfold on our doorstep and the MFF, as it is structured right now, is not suitably flexible enough to reprioritise the budget. We have also all acknowledged that greater investment is needed with President Junker’s Investment Plan – but the money for this came from budget lines already targeted at growing the economy and creating jobs. The money for this should have come from less productive areas of the EU Budget

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, which represents Europe's priorities and needs. The Eu ropean Union budget is spent in those areas where resources are needed to achieve results for Europe. The aim of the budget is to support employment, growth, help underdeveloped regions of the European Union, improve the competitiveness of European businesses and finance research and innovation programmes in favour of youth employment.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. It is incomprehensible that more money is to be spent. Often for purposes for which the Union does not even have a mandate. The report must therefore be rejected.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the 2016 Budget which sets outs the Parliament’s main priorities for the coming year: more resources to tackle the migration crisis, restoring cuts to the Horizon 2020 programme and Connecting Europe Facility, and continuing the Youth Employment Initiative.  I did not support Amendment 22 as there are no coupled payments for bullfighting within the CAP.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Here is Parliament's first formal opinion on the EU budget for 2016, before the final vote in December. From the outset, it can be seen that none of the recommendations made in July by the same rapporteur Fernandes has been implemented. The rapporteur notes that the Council is increasing the obstacles to the resolution of unpaid debts, even though it called for them to be resolved "without delay" in July. A façade will is still displayed for 2016. And the report expresses a salutary warning against fake announcements such as those of the Juncker investment fund leading to the undressing of existing programmes. While affirming the need to free up an additional billion to deal with the migrant crisis, the report recommends an amount of commitments for 2016 that are almost 4 billion less than the budget for 2015! This report claims that more can be done with less, even though the 2015 budget has already proved insufficient! That's reason enough to vote against.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to amend the Council's draft general budget. This is a deeply harmful report. An additional EUR 900 million is being requested for immigration policy, bringing the total budget for the migration crisis currently affecting the European continent to 2.1 billion euros. These funds are intended to "distribute" refugees among European countries, to modernise reception centres, to pay for language training for asylum seekers, or to strengthen rescue operations in the Mediterranean Sea. In no way is it a question of providing the means for a firm policy aimed at strengthening border control and deporting illegal immigrants to their countries of origin.  The Member voted against this incondic report, which is satisfied with mass immigration despite the high rates of unemployment and poverty, despite also the huge cultural differences between indigenous peoples and the vast majority of immigrants.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I have voted in favour of the report on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016. I congratulate the rapporteur on the work done and the agreements reached: Parliament's proposal will strengthen the Commission's proposal by EUR 2.8 billion. In view of the previous implementation rates, as well as future predictable absorption capacities, these are realistic amounts that will enable the proper implementation of policies and allow the EU to ensure adequate funding of its priority areas. As part of the financing of bullfighting, I would stress that the CAP does not finance activities related to bullfighting.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it proposes additional increases in the 2016 budget for the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) which is essential if the Union is to handle the crisis in a way fitting to our standards and values.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. We have decided to be ambitious by providing additional funds (4.1 billion euros more than the Council's commitment position and 4.3 billion euros more than the Council's position in payment/ordering) in the 2016 EU budget to deal with the various crises facing Europe.  The aim is to meet the needs arising from the unprecedented influx of refugees inside and outside the EU, to finance assistance to create jobs for young people, to improve the competitiveness of the EU, etc. We therefore propose a budget of 157.4 billion euros in commitments and 146.4 billion in payments. The last word is not said. A conciliation procedure with the Council is now under way, which is expected to end with an agreement, which will be approved at the ECOFIN Council on 23 November. In addition, we asked to be able to benefit from all the flexibility instruments to respond to the unforeseen and therefore to use the contingency reserve if necessary.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: writing ‒ The Union is currently facing many serious challenges in many areas at the same time, which needs to be taken into account in the EU general budget for next year, which should remain an investment and pro-growth budget. I am disappointed that it is precisely the area of competitiveness for growth and jobs that has once again been hit by severe cuts by the Council, with a reduction of EUR 140.9 million in commitments and EUR 435.4 million in payments. I also do not agree with the cuts in economic, social and territorial cohesion, because it is the Union's main investment policy aimed at reducing the often significant disparities between European regions. The EU Structural Funds significantly help regions to convergence and create quality jobs. Their sufficient funding must remain a priority for the Union.  Finally, I would like to express my support for Parliament's decision to increase funding of EUR 473.2 million for 2016 for the Youth Employment Initiative, and I stress the need to implement programmes to combat unemployment.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution, which is a political document explaining Parliament’s position on the general budget of the European Union for 2016 – all sections. The resolution needs to be consistent with the vote on the figures. Therefore, as in the budgetary lines, I supported the reinforcement of some political key priorities for growth, competitiveness and employment, in particular compensation for the cuts in the two important programmes Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility, and the increase in the Youth Employment Initiative. I also voted against subsidies for the breeding of bulls for bullfighting. Last but not least, I voted in favour of more transparency for the general expenditure allowance but taking into account that this should happen without creating an extra administrative or financial burden.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 24 June 2015, the Commission adopted a draft general budget for the EU for the financial year 2016. On 4 September 2015, the Council adopted its position on the plan and forwarded it to Parliament on 17 September 2015. The report of Parliament's Committee on Budgets goes far beyond and opposes the Council's position. First of all, it proposes that Parliament propose, as a first response to the migration crisis, to increase the draft budget by EUR 1 161 million in the framework of a comprehensive package of amendments. It proposes new commitments for 2016 to continue the YOUTH Employment Initiative, increasing the 2016 appropriations by EUR 473.2 million. The launch of the Fund for Strategic Investments proposes to fully re pay for the amounts withdrawn from Horizon2020 and the Network Finance Facility (EUR 1326 million) in the 2016 budget. Finally, it proposes to restore all the reductions proposed by the Council in the draft budget (eur 563.6 million commitment appropriation and EUR 1421.8 million payment appropriation). To this end, it proposes that Parliament set the overall level of appropriations for 2016 at EUR 157 427.5 million in commitment appropriations and EUR 146 459.5 million in payment appropriations. I agree with the position of the Committee on Budgets, so I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The 2016 Budget is part of the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020 and can be adjusted according to the priorities set by the Commission, Parliament and the Council for the coming year. I am voting in favour of this report on the 2016 Budget, which has as a priority support for refugees and the strengthening of European competitiveness through the Employment, Business and Entrepreneurship axis. Employment must indeed be the top priority next year, and only strengthening the competitiveness of businesses and a greater allocation of the European Horizon 2020 and Cosme Funds will allow this to be done. I believe that the strengthening of EUR 1.3 billion in Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility, which were used to establish the Juncker plan guarantee, is extremely positive and to add EUR 473 million to allow the continuation of the Youth Employment Initiative.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. Unsurprisingly, this report on the 2016 budget is further proof of the EU's indecent arrogance in cutting down its Member States' budgets.  It is scandalous that this report increases commitment appropriations (to 146.5 billion euros) by 4.4 billion euros above the Commission's proposal and above the ceilings decided by the EU (144.7 billion euros) for the year.  It is focused on financing the migration madness, providing $1.2 billion to spread the migration consequences of its irresponsible and Atlanticist foreign policy.  The European Commission plans to spend 26 million euros in 2016 on advertising campaign to make the EU's after-sales service, believing that it is by making the taxpayer pay for propaganda measures that the people will be convinced of the eu's benefits. Finally, what about the sardanapalesque lifestyle of the President of the Parliament, who needs 35 employees as well as two limousines to meet his obligations, except that it reveals a total disconnection of the European institutions from the peoples.  So I voted against this report.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted against an increase in the EU Budget today, which goes beyond the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), the EU’s seven-year framework regulating its annual budget. Labour MEPs have voted to re-prioritise the budget towards spending on growth, jobs and innovation – in particular the Youth Employment Initiative, which should be an EU priority. They have also backed increased funding for refugees to help countries cope with the current humanitarian crisis.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Union's draft general budget for 2016. This text stresses the strengthening of the response to the refugee crisis, the agricultural crisis and employment and competitiveness issues. In particular, I approved the continuation of funding for the Youth Employment Initiative and the allocation of EUR 473 million for programmes aimed at helping them enter the labour market. Parliament's vote called for the allocation of EUR 1.3 billion to the Horizon 2020 research programme and the Interconnection Mechanism to compensate for the funds that had been withdrawn from them to finance the Juncker Plan guarantee. The text also calls for support for programmes for youth training such as COSME and Erasmus.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the adoption of the resolution on the EU general budget, Parliament outlines the political priorities to be implemented through the implementation of the European Commission's programmes. In the fields of culture and education, the Union's clear support for Erasmus+ is confirmed, certainly the programme best known to our fellow citizens. The hope – and the signs for this are positive – is that this year there will be no shortage of payments that result in financial difficulties for the children in exchange and their families. On the other hand, in the areas of culture and citizenship, it should be noted that the Council is reducing the amount compared to the Commission's proposals for both Creative Europe and Citizens' Europe; and so the scope for pilot projects and preparatory actions has also been reduced. Despite the emergencies with which we are familiar, starting with the refugee crisis, it should not be underestimated how culture builds citizenship and social inclusion. While Euroscepticism and mistrust are rampant in Europe, and populism is growing at the extreme end of the political spectrum, programmes that bring citizens and institutions closer together are being cut back. It is also these real problems, as well as the accumulation of unpaid invoices from the Commission due to lack of funds, that are disintegrating drives of the European project.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report on the general budget of the European Union for 2016, which will increase the commitment and payment appropriations under Heading 4, Global Europe.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report for the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016 calls for more financial resources in many places for which the European Union has no mandate at all. The report also includes further efforts towards the Transfer Union with the aim of investing more in neighbouring countries. I consider it more necessary that the financial resources be used to support our own citizens, and I have therefore voted against the report.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The resolution on the EU's general budget for 2016 confirms the need for Parliament to restore budget lines where the Council, obsessed with widespread austerity, wants to see only cuts. It is thereby proposed, and rightly so, to strengthen budgets allocated to key programmes such as the Youth Initiative, Horizon 2020 or development funds or those allocated to support for refugees.  However, Parliament's proposal is unfortunately far too weak and will not be able to cope with the current emergencies, such as the migrant crisis, or even in the face of the Council, which will seek to cut the European budget for programmes that are more than necessary. Despite the limitations imposed on us by the multi-year financial framework, Parliament should have the audacity of a proposal more ambitious than a semblance of a status quo. For these reasons I abstained on the vote of this resolution.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. With next year's budget, the EU will have the opportunity to rect onto some of the important omissions to date, which are about the massive refugee crisis. In this way, it is essential to increase the financial allocation for Syrian refugee camps in Turkey, Jordan and Lebanon, as well as to refugee camps in other conflict zones.  Improving living conditions in these centres would allow refugees to avoid the perilous journey to Europe. The contribution to the creation and adequate maintenance of refugee reception centres in Greece and Italy needs to be significantly increased. This would allow the tragic unmanageable movement of refugees across Europe to be placed on the line. There is also a serious need to increase the contribution to support thoughtful development in both the EU's southern and eastern neighbourhoods.  The 2016 budget must make it possible to contribute to real change in ukraine's economic system and to support other countries moving towards a full market economy and upholding the rule of law. In the direction of Ukraine, Moldova and Georgia, the EU can also do more on a budgetary basis.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – Further efforts are needed to overcome the union's economic weaknesses. The Union budget should focus on the objective of economic and social cohesion. The budget must help people get out of poverty. It is therefore necessary to provide sufficient funds for the needs of society. The negative effects of the economic and social crisis must be reduced. The Union budget should be used for wage increases and for investments creating jobs. Particular attention must be paid to social progress and the preservation, promotion, and job creation, sustainable use of natural resources and environmental protection of each country' potential. The cuts to funding for Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility need to be compensated. In addition, a plan must be drawn up to move to a single headquarters.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The budget now looks to be restored to EUR 157.4 billion in commitments and EUR 146.5 billion for payments: this is due to opposition to the proposed cuts. There is major support for all EU programmes, such as strengthening the European Neighbourhood Instrument and social and territorial cohesion. In addition to this, there is added pressure to increase the budget to deal with the ongoing refugee and migration crisis as a result of mismanagement of the disaster in the Mediterranean. A further EUR 1.6 billion is being directed to the Asylum Migration and Integration Fund and this includes Global Europe Security and Citizenship. We cannot support programmes that have already been badly managed and expect the taxpayer to fund initiatives that are not valid or reliable in relation to meeting the objectives of Europe’s citizens. These EU programmes do not serve the people of Europe but rather promote ‘more Europe’ and serve the political agenda of the Commission.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 While I appreciate the division of funds between the different budget headings presented, I reiterate here the position of the ENVI Committee, of which I am a member, with particular reference to the request for additional funds and funding for research and innovation projects in the environmental field, in order to achieve the objectives set by Horizon 2020 for a resource-efficient economy and society capable of tackling climate change.  For these reasons, I am in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Taking into account that a key priority for the budget proposal in 2016 in light of the Juncker Plan, a strategy that would provide new jobs, development and investment, the proposed higher budget allocation is justified but also necessary to accelerate the pace of investment. The backbone of this investment plan is the making available €8 billion guarantee fund for commitments and payments to equip the European Fund for Strategic Investments.  The EU budget is a means to foster internal solidarity, as it supports economic, social and territorial cohesion, but also a means of external solidarity that serves to provide emergency assistance during humanitarian and civilian crises. I personally supported amendments concerning the implementation of a pilot project to establish a European Rural Woman's Award, the establishment of a fund to restructure the sugar industry, the establishment of a single session place for Parliament and increased investment in the search for missing children.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. Unsurprisingly, this report on the 2016 budget is further evidence of the EU's indecent arrogance in cutting down its Member States' budgets. It is scandalous that this report increases the appropriations of commitments (to 146.5 billion euros) by 4.4 billion euros above the Commission's proposal and above the ceilings decided by the EU (144.7 billion euros) for the year. It is focused on financing the migration madness, providing $1.2 billion to spread the migration consequences of its irresponsible and Atlanticist foreign policy. The European Commission plans to spend 26 million euros in 2016 on advertising campaign to make the EU's after-sales service, believing that it is by making the taxpayer pay for propaganda measures that the people will be convinced of the eu's benefits. Finally, what about the sardanapalesque lifestyle of the President of the Parliament, who needs 35 employees as well as two limousines to meet his obligations, except that it reveals a total disconnection of the European institutions vis-à-vis the peoples. So I voted against this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒As evidenced by the Budget Committee report, the European Parliament's achievements in opposing the Council's proposals for sharp cuts and insufficient funding to finance key EU programmes are commendable. In doing so, commitments to allocate funds to the refugee crisis, for Greece, the European Fund for Strategic Investments and the financing of the Youth Employment Initiative are particularly important.  Cooperation between S&D and EPP groups has resulted in a funding allocation of 1326 million for two important programmes: Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility, as well as for a number of other programmes aimed at boosting growth, competitiveness and jobs. In the area of economic, social and territorial cohesion, the adoption of amendments to increase the funding of the Youth Employment Initiative of EUR 473 million was particularly commendable, and in the sphere of sustainable development and natural resources, an emergency support package for dairy producers was approved.  A total of 89 pilot projects and preparatory activities have been approved, as well as an increase in the amount of subsidy for the European Globalisation Fund. I am proud to point out that the S&D Group has managed to ensure an increase in relation to the draft Commission on Foreign Development Policy, Humanitarian Aid, the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights and other important development programmes.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Union is currently facing a number of challenges that seek swift and effective solutions. This is particularly true of the refugee and migration crisis, which is why financial resources need to be deployed in a way that will allow for an adequate and flexible response to the crisis. Further efforts should also be made to address shortcomings in the European economy, strengthen competitiveness, and raise the number and quality of jobs, especially for young people.  In this regard, the role of micro, small and medium-sized enterprises is invaluable. The projected €50 billion of investment by public and private investors through the European Fund for Strategic Investments should make a significant contribution as a generator of economic recovery. It is necessary to compensate for savings in the field of research and development - Horizon 2020, encouraging medium-sized entrepreneurship - COSME and student mobility - Erasmus +.  The €157.4 billion budget must be guided by the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy and be aligned with the European Union's multiannual financial framework for 2014-2020. In times of uncertainty, Europe's most important financial instrument must ensure stability and investment in further development.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 An adequate European budget is a condition for European programmes to be implemented correctly and continuously. I therefore voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the Council's position on next year's budget. It is no longer possible for member states' representatives, despite promises they have made to the European Parliament in the past, to jeopardize the smooth implementation of programmes benefiting their own citizens. I therefore supported the increase in funding for Horizon 2020 and the CEF, programmes that have been negatively affected by the creation of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, so that the agreed objectives can be met. Although decisions have been made in the past that seemed rational in the context at the time, the Union can no longer afford to spend unnecessarily resources that could be better invested elsewhere. I therefore supported the proposal to draw up a timetable for the introduction of one seat of Parliament. I voted against the use of the European budget to finance bullfighting, in which animals are killed, as these brutal activities no longer have a place in modern Europe. I supported an increase in funding for health and environment programmes because their importance was once again ignored by the Council. I did not support the call on the Commission to adopt budgetary measures to ensure a more balanced solidarity between member countries in the refugee crisis, because this initiative goes against all democratic principles and the very principle of solidarity.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The vote on the EU budget is one of the European Parliament's most responsible tasks, as Parliament has the final say on the EU budget. The approved proposal will now be the subject of a pending procedure with the European Council, followed by the final approval of the compromise proposal at the November plenary session. I supported all sensible proposals that have led to the avoidance of waste of funds, such as on the single seat of the EP in Brussels, thereby saving millions of euros paid for permanent migration between Brussels and Strasbourg. On the contrary, it is necessary to add where money is needed, currently mainly to the solution to the migration crisis, but also to the promotion of employment in the EU, especially among young people. Parliament has thus channeled EUR 1.16 billion more to support migration management than in the commission's original proposal. EU sanctions against Russia help to meet the EU's strategic objectives, but I consider it important that the EU be able to address the effects of these sanctions on its own most affected sectors. I therefore supported the proposal to increase the budget chapter for farmers whose existence is threatened by a reciprocal ban on the import of food into Russia. Last but not least, as a member of the ITRE Committee, I am pleased with the increase in the Budget for Horizon 2020, because we have waged a tough fight in committee so that this programme does not lose important financial flows because of the financing of the Juncker Investment Plan.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft general budget of the European Union for 2016. The Commission made this public on 24 June 2015. The draft budget sets the overall level of appropriations for 2016 at EUR 157,427.5 million in commitments and EUR 146,459.5 million in payments. I believe that the budget was designed according to correct and comprehensive evaluation criteria and that it effectively intercepts the needs of the European Union and its citizens. In any case, I believe that, in future, the Commission must take account of the economic recovery efforts that the Member States are making at national level to revive their economies. We must avoid placing an excessive burden on the public finances of the Member States with unnecessary obligations and constraints. In this respect, the right balance must be struck between rigour and development in order to achieve an effective distribution of available resources. We must safeguard initiatives for youth employment, business development and entrepreneurship in the Union and not further reduce the commitments proposed under this heading.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The anti-corridas may be agitating when they shout at the end of European subsidies for fighting bull breeders, but they are in complete ignorance. Let me be clear, the CAP does not fund bullfighting. The CAP subsidizes beef and calf farms without discrimination. Secondly, if the States, such as Spain and France, want to direct part of the CAP and FEADER budget towards fighting bull breeding, it is their strictest right, nothing forbids them. The European Commission has had a clear position on this issue for many years. These amendments, even if voted, are legally wobbly and ill-prepared. They therefore have no value. Only the European right in its vast majority voted against, and thus respected the principle of subsidiarity and cultural freedoms. The other political families have dispersed, left, centrist, extremist. By not taking a clear position, they have flouted our traditions! The Greens and the anti-corridas lit a straw fire, this year it took, but by definition it will go out of itself. I will give them an appointment at the end of the budget negotiations.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. Parliament's position on the 2016 budget adequately reflects European political priorities, in particular with regard to the migration and refugee crisis, job creation and business development and entrepreneurship. This is a responsible proposal, which contains important measures, such as: the package of amendments tabled with a view to providing a response to the migration crisis, both internally and externally; strengthening the COSME programme and horizon 2020; the continuation of the Youth Employment Initiative; and the emergency support package of EUR 500 million in aid for milk producers. In order for the EU to be able to respond to the important political challenges it faces and to honour its commitments, in particular as regards the reduction of the volume of overdue payments for cohesion programmes for the period 2007-2013, the necessary financial resources need to be mobilised. In this regard, we cannot agree on a set of cuts proposed by the Council, and there is also a call for an agreement to be reached on the use of all the flexibility mechanisms available in the Multiannual Financial Framework Regulation, including the full mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The budget now looks to be restored to EUR 157.4 billion in commitments and EUR 146.5 billion for payments: this is due to opposition to the proposed cuts. There is major support for all EU programmes, such as strengthening the European Neighbourhood Instrument and social and territorial cohesion. In addition to this, there is added pressure to increase the budget to deal with the ongoing refugee and migration crisis as a result of mismanagement of the disaster in the Mediterranean. A further EUR 1.6 billion is being directed to the Asylum Migration and Integration Fund and this includes Global Europe Security and Citizenship. We cannot support programmes that have already been badly managed and expect the taxpayer to fund initiatives that are not valid or reliable in relation to meeting the objectives of Europe’s citizens. These EU programmes do not serve the people of Europe but rather promote ‘more Europe’ and serve the political agenda of the Commission.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the EU's general budget for 2016 because it proposes an increase in the financing of our political priorities, and more specifically to offset the cuts in the agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EIE) to meet the R&D&I and infrastructure objectives that we have set ourselves, to ensure the additional resources needed for the internal and external dimension of the refugee crisis , renew our commitment to youth unemployment by funding one more year of the Youth Employment Initiative and compensating our farmers and ranchers, who are being affected by the Russian veto or the milk crisis. Our proposal amounts to EUR 157 427 547 086 in commitment appropriations, an increase of EUR 3.6 billion for 2016 which actually represents only a 2.34% increase.  In doing so, we want to send a strong political signal on what the EP's priorities are, highlight the lack of funding for key EU programmes, and establish a strong starting position for negotiations with the Council and the Commission during the conciliation procedure.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report, which provides, among other things, to meet the needs of the Member States managing the largest influx of refugees and migrants, as well as those from non-EU countries that still host more, EUR 1.16 billion more for migration management measures compared to what the European Commission originally proposed.  In terms of employment, Parliament has added EUR 473 million for contracts for new programmes to help unemployed young people find jobs. Farmers affected by the Russian embargo on food imports from the EU and low milk prices will also receive an additional EUR 500 million.  Finally, Parliament has added EUR 1.3 billion for the European research programme Horizon 2020 and the mechanism for the interconnection (of infrastructure) of Europe, to return the funds borrowed from them in order to launch the Juncker investment plan. On the other hand, I voted against any increase in the costs and expenses associated with the activity of an MEP.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the 2016 budget proposal, which nullifies all budget cuts initiated by the Council and provides answers to recent events while maintaining the priorities to be pursued.   In particular, the text we voted on provides EUR 1.16 billion for the treatment of the refugee crisis, both internally and externally. This will give the EU more budgetary capacity to implement the provisions adopted in recent months, such as the creation of hotspots, the refugee relocation mechanism and the European supervision of the coastguard; but also in order to contain the root causes of this crisis with an additional EUR 250 million for the neighbourhood, development cooperation and humanitarian aid.  The text also continues the EU's efforts to promote employment, competitiveness with increased funding for horizon 2020 programmes (an additional $1.3 billion), Erasmus and the Youth Employment Initiative. This budget proposal does not forget to respond to the agricultural crisis and calls for an additional EUR 500 million for dairy farmers affected by the Russian embargo.  This budget responds to the challenges we face and is committed to growth and jobs, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016 as I believe that the report is in line with the new challenges posed first and foremost by the Juncker Plan. There is no need to run the risk of support for Europe also becoming an instrument for draining resources from other instruments that already work, such as the CEF and Horizon 2020. This is the position I have followed as rapporteur for the transport and tourism budget, as well as the position adopted by the European Parliament, in the hope that, in the trialogues, what we have requested will not be distorted.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against as I believe that much more could and should be done to reduce the costs of the EU institutions.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained in the vote on this document which determines Parliament's negotiating position before the Commission and the Council. Firstly, because the budget is slightly better than in previous years (very slight increase), with its lights (growth of humanitarian spending on refugees, improvement of educational aspects, research, Youth Employment Initiative and support for SMEs) and its shadows (diversion of resources to an insufficient and problematic investment model to FEIE ̶ and ̶ significant percentage of additional resources for Europe-strength and greater "competitiveness"). Secondly, and mainly because it is a question of countering the Council's regressive proposal, which would be much worse. The Resolution is critical of the Council's approaches and includes several calls for extraordinary measures, the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework for more flexibility or the promotion of quality employment. Since the resulting budgets will presumably contribute to persevering in a neoliberal EU, with a derisory and non-redistributive budget, we will vote against it later.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution on the budget of the European Union because it does not recognise the political importance of this instrument in boosting the economy of the 28 Member States. The Resolution contains positive points; indeed, it is a much better position than that of the Council, for example condemning the cuts caused by the reallocation of funds produced by the establishment of the EIES. However, we do not consider that it meets all the needs of the Union in the budgetary area, which needs an economic policy tool that increases public spending in the absence of any improvement in the international economy. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. My opposition to death bull runs and other blood bullfighting is public, having signed a petition on the matter. I abstained in this vote on Amendments 22 and 435 because the proposal in question is incoherent, since there is no European funding for death bull races.  As such, I believe that, as a Member of the European Parliament, despite the recognised good intention behind the proposal, this part of a false assumption, in my view, is a non-issue within the EU budget and a diversified one which, being expanded to other animal welfare issues, which I am fully advocating, ends up creating serious noise problems with out-of-context matters , short in detail and poorly formalised.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this budget report due to the fact there is vast support for EU programmes and political aims and objectives.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. – Again, as has been the case so many times before, we are seeing a general downs of budget lines. This year, about 2 billion euros, of which 1.4 billion are on the payment side. In the Council's proposal, I am particularly concerned about the fact that the cuts will significantly affect the Competitiveness for Growth and Jobs section, where the Council is proposing a reduction of more than half a billion euros.  As many as half of these cuts will be severely affected by Horizon 2020. And let me point out, we are talking here about a further reduction, after part of the funds of this programme have already been reallocated to EFSI. The Council states that the proposed amounts reflect the actual implementation rate of the budget in previous years and are in line with a realistic assessment of future absorption capacity.  At the same time, I wonder whether we might not have acted more responsantly if we had improved the absorption volume, rather than adjusting budget lines to this unsatisfactory situation. I very much hope that in the final budget for 2016 we will be able to reconcile the positions of all three institutions involved in the budgetary procedure.  As a driver of the European Union, the Commission, the Council and Parliament have a duty to achieve the objectives to which we have committed ourselves under the Europe 2020 strategy, and budget cuts will certainly not help. Parliament's report rightly removes all the cuts in the Council's proposal, which is why I voted to support it.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. Parliament has requested commitment appropriations of EUR 157.4 billion and payment appropriations of EUR 146.5 billion for the 2016 EU budget, resulting in a net increase of EUR 4.159 and EUR 4.34 billion respectively. The aim is to repeal almost all Council cuts and to ignore the ceilings agreed between EU Member States in the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework. In addition to sensible budget increases, such as the request for an additional EUR 1.161 billion to deal with the current migration crisis and EUR 473.2 million for the fight against youth unemployment, there are numerous budget lines that the parliamentary majority wants to provide with equal or higher resources largely unaudited. For example, structural and cohesion policy and agriculture/environment alone account for more than two thirds of the EU budget, although the implementation of programmes and activities, especially in cohesion policy, is often deficient. Nevertheless, these areas should remain untouched regardless of the performance achieved. This is offset by cuts in the very important areas of research (Horizon 2020) and infrastructure (Connecting Europe Facility CEF). Our demands for a sustainable, balanced and transparent budget based on an efficient, subsidiary and added-value budget policy at European level have not been taken into account in this draft budget. That is why I voted against Parliament's 2016 draft budget.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ the EU budget should reflect the EU's political priorities. It is therefore important to allocate more financial resources to tackle the migration and refugee crisis. However, the EU's priorities should not be forgotten, namely increasing competitiveness and growth through job creation, business development and entrepreneurship across the Union.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report because I think the budget reflects the political priorities adopted by the majority in previously adopted resolutions. I believe that the priorities are internal and external solidarity, in particular the effective resolution of the migration and refugee crisis, as well as increasing competitiveness by creating quality jobs and developing businesses and entrepreneurship in the Union.  I note that the Union is facing a number of crises such as the migration and refugee crisis, and that it is necessary to provide for the necessary financial resources to address the current challenges, which would allow the Union to urgently find solutions and respond effectively to these crises.  It is understood that the migration and refugee crisis cannot be solved solely through financial means. I also support the decision to take action to address the ongoing crisis in the agricultural sector, especially in the dairy sector.  I also support the decision to transfer the funds earmarked for crisis cases in 2015 to the 2016 budget and that these unused funds will be used to reimburse beneficiaries of direct payments, as provided for in Regulation (EU) No 2016/ 2016. 1306/2013.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. The report proposed that EUR 1.3 billion be allocated to competitiveness for growth and jobs, EUR 467 million to economic, social and territorial cohesion and EUR 931 million to security and citizenship, breaking the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) commitment ceilings. I believe that, in the current economic climate, breaking the MFF budget is not fiscally responsible.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Resolutions of 11 March 2015 on general guidelines and from 8 July 2015 on the granting of powers for the trilogue testify to the political priorities of the European Union budget for 2016. Priorities focus on internal and external solidarity, in particular in terms of effectively addressing the refugee and migrant crises, as well as boosting competitiveness through job creation, leading to the development of entrepreneurship across the Union as a whole.  Parliament therefore concludes that in order to adequately finance this type of urgent needs, while taking into account the strict ceilings of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) for 2016, all funds available in the MFF Regulation must be introduced. It therefore sets the total level of appropriations for 2016 at €157 427.5 million for commitment appropriations, i.e. €146 459.5 million for payment appropriations.  I fully support this report, as it takes into account both the well-being of vulnerable individuals outside the borders of the European Union and the well-being of European entrepreneurs, which will contribute to the betterment of the whole Union.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: I did not support the proposal in writing ‒ as I fundamentally disagree with it. In fact, the proposal presented brings about a significant increase in the European Union budget, which, in my opinion, is completely unjustified. On the contrary, the EU budget would be helped by substantial cuts, particularly in the area of EU funds and payments to farmers. As a result, taxpayers could use more money at their discretion, which would ultimately also contribute to sustainable growth and a reduction in unemployment.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016. A week ago, the Council called on the European Parliament to make realism in adopting the EU budget in 2016. The proposed amendments are a very realistic response to the problems we face in the EU, such as refugees, unemployment and growing disparities between members.  In order for countries along the Balkan route to cooperate and protect one of the EU's fundamental acquisitions, Schengen and the free movement of people, they need resources. It is true, however, that there is a great deal of room for manoeuvre in EU spending to make them more efficient and efficient.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The 2016 draft budget shifts the European Union's focus to aid to a total of EUR 26 million for dependent organisations with migration-related tasks, with the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) receiving the largest increase, amounting to EUR 12 million above the amount of the draft budget, the FUND fund, rather than to its own citizens and their needs. There are Member States of the Union that are plagued by the crisis, yet they are the first countries to qualify as migrant collection countries and must, under EU rules, take care of them throughout their stay there. Countries such as Greece are unable to take care of their own citizens.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Hungarian People's Party members voted to ensure that Hungary one of the winners of the 2016 EU budget. In the course of the vote, we defended the cohesion funds due to Hungary, because the plenary confirmed the position that, even in the Committee on Budgets, efforts to reduce the European Regional Development Fund by 20% for countries (including Hungary) that opposed the European Commission's quotas for the relocation of migrants were voted down by a large majority. A priority was to reverse the reduction of the Pre-Accession Fund proposed by the Council. These instruments have a decisive impact on the accession efforts of the candidate countries, such as Serbia and the Hungarians in Vojvodina. Thanks to the proposals of the Fidesz delegation, tens of millions of euros have been raised. The plenary session defended agricultural resources from council cuts in line with Hungarian interests. The EUR 500 million milk rescue package can be provided by the EU budget for 2016, so that Hungarian dairy farmers can receive the announced EU aid of HUF 2.9 billion on time. Among the proposals adopted is the joint project "Diverse Europe" by Pál Csáky (MKP) and Kinga Gál (FIDESZ). In this context, €1 million of EU funds will be available to applicants to finance minority programmes to combat discrimination.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal containing the European Union's budget allocation for 2016, because I consider that the draft as a whole and in most chapters is capable of meeting the challenges and challenges facing it in the coming period. The draft budget provides the necessary resources for effective action by the EU in the management of refugee migration by redeployment of EUR 800 million, with the necessary flexibility. It also foresees adequate amounts for other related international and humanitarian tasks, while not losing sight of the promotion of economic development and modernisation as a primary Community challenge.  Overall, I wished to acknowledge, by my vote, that the draft budget for the financial year 2016 is sufficiently transparent and sufficiently reflects, in proportion and in its objectives, the social and European political priorities represented by my party and my group and is capable of adequately financing the community's activities resulting there from them.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 It is extremely costly and difficult for Europeans to maintain the three seats of the European Parliament, in three different countries and cities, namely Brussels, Strasbourg and Luxembourg, and especially for the citizens of those Member States where the Institutions of the European Union are calling for a reduction in public spending. It therefore seems perfectly reasonable to choose one city as the seat of the European Parliament, most likely Brussels, where other EU institutions are also located.  Of course, I fully understand the symbolic importance of the city of Strasbourg for Franco-German reconciliation after World War II. However, it should not be forgotten that this city is home to other extremely important European institutions, such as the Council of Europe and the European Court of Human Rights. I therefore believe that the issue of a single seat of the European Parliament should once again be raised, which would be more in line with both our needs and our capabilities.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the adoption of the amendment to prevent bull farmers from receiving European funding for Spanish agriculture as well. At last! It is a victory for civilisation to which I am pleased to have contributed with my vote. At the same time, it is a step towards less cruel management of animal husbandry, although the overall goal is unfortunately still a long way off. From a general point of view, however, our assessment of the report accompanying the EU budget is negative, since it does not resolve the imbalance between commitments and payments and does not work towards the closure of certain completely unnecessary expenditure lines: on the contrary, they are further increased. This is shameful, given, moreover, that the EU is forcing Member States to cut back and austerity policies.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Since the 2008 financial crisis, Member State Governments have been forced to impose austerity budgets in order to balance their books and mend their economies. The UK has been foremost among those, and the Government has had to make some very difficult decisions in the past several years. I am pleased to note that the UK is now benefiting from those measures – it remains the fastest growing G7 economy – but austerity packages have been painful for those having to readjust, including many of my own constituents in London. The Council recognises this context and understands that it is unacceptable for Member States to cut their budgets at home, only to increase the budget of the EU. Sadly, the motion before the plenary today suggests, however, that a majority in the European Parliament has yet to comprehend this. Calling for increases of EUR 4.1 billion and committing to a further EUR 4.3 billion in payment appropriations is unacceptable, and for this reason I voted against the motion.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Union budget for the 2016 financial year, in total line with my group's political line, with the exception of the bullfighting line, where I refused the amendment.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the report on the Council position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016 because the proposal provides the Council with the necessary financial resources for all the Union's political challenges – it provides for the necessary financial resources for the migration and refugee crisis, takes action for the current crisis of European farmers, seeks to address the shortcomings in the Union economy, stresses the key role of small, medium and social enterprises , promotes youth employment and maintains funding for existing Union policy programmes.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. Parliament has requested commitment appropriations of EUR 157.4 billion and payment appropriations of EUR 146.5 billion for the 2016 EU budget, resulting in a net increase of EUR 4.159 and EUR 4.34 billion respectively. The aim is to repeal almost all Council cuts and to ignore the ceilings agreed between EU Member States in the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework. In addition to sensible budget increases, such as the request for an additional EUR 1.161 billion to deal with the current migration crisis, there are numerous budget lines that the parliamentary majority wants to provide with the same or higher resources largely unaudited.
