Nevertheless, these areas should remain untouched regardless of the performance achieved. This is offset by cuts in the very important areas of research (Horizon 2020) and infrastructure (Connecting Europe Facility CEF). Our demands for a sustainable, balanced and transparent budget based on an efficient, subsidiary and added-value budget policy at European level have not been taken into account in this draft budget. That is why I voted against Parliament's 2016 draft budget.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of the report of the Committee on Budgets and the opinions of the other committees concerned, and the fact that the parliamentary reading of the 2016 budget fully reflects the political priorities adopted by an overwhelming majority in the resolutions of 11 March 2015 on general guidelines and on the mandate for tripartit conciliation of 8 July 2015, I therefore supported the report.

name: Bodil Valero (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. 'We support the content of Amendment No 9 to paragraph 96, which seeks to reduce Members' allowances, but abstained, because it is not possible to amend this in the budget, but it must be amended in the Members' State which states that members' salary should be 38.5 % of the basic salary of a judge of the Court of Justice of the European Union.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. Although some of the priorities of the Committee on Budgets are acceptable, I did not support the resolution for two main reasons: firstly, the commitments continue to be too far removed from the real budgetary resources that will be made available, creating an ever wider gap between commitments and payments and thus reducing the possibility of maintaining faith in the years following what is promised; secondly, this year too, no significant cut in administrative expenditure is considered, but rather is being increased again.  Our proposals drew attention to the need not to increase any budget items, especially those relating to MEPs' salaries and allowances and those relating to funding for political parties and foundations. We have also proposed reviewing all the unnecessary expenditure of certain bodies, such as the Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions, but our line was rejected both in committee and in plenary. I therefore regret that, at a time of serious economic crisis during which the European Union itself is calling for restrictions on the Member States, I firmly believe that it is necessary to make judicious and shrewd use of existing budgetary resources.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution on the budget of the European Union because it does not recognise the political importance of this instrument in boosting the economy of the 28 Member States. The Resolution contains positive points; indeed, it is a much better position than that of the Council, for example condemning the cuts caused by the reallocation of funds produced by the establishment of the EIES. However, we do not consider that it meets all the needs of the Union in the budgetary area, which needs an economic policy tool that increases public spending in the absence of any improvement in the international economy. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against Parliament’s negotiating position going into the budget negotiations because the current budgetary framework is unsuitable in a world where the EU needs to be able to shift funds rapidly to meet crises, such as the one in the Mediterranean at the moment. Furthermore, I feel that expanding the Multiannual Financial Framework is not the way forward at this time, as citizens are looking to the EU to be a careful guardian of its resources. It was also wrong for the money for Juncker’s investment plan to come from funds already targeted at increasing productivity and growth: it was a self-defeating method of trying to improve growth – giving with one hand while taking with the other.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This budget is a reflection of the current moment of this European Union. A project that is stranded in a sea of uncertainty of lack of mutual trust and that retracts countries from contributing to the budget. This budget, short for so much ambition, will only fuel the disillusionment of those who still believe in this European project. We have made positive efforts to build the best possible budget within the narrow limits determined by the refusal of the main countries to contribute to strengthening the budget without which social and territorial cohesion policies are not possible. We do not feed any illusions in a project that focuses everything on supply-side measures and believes that investment will fall from the sky through a strategic investment fund without credibility and that will only strengthen private public partnerships and the concentration of investment in the wealthiest regions. It should also be recalled that many of the hottest issues discussed in this budget, such as support for farmers and refugees, stem from wrong policies taken in recent years and which stem from the neoliberal and neocolonial matrix that characterises this European Union, today in the midst of a crisis of values.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. It is incomprehensible that more money is to be spent. Often for purposes for which the Union does not even have a mandate. The report must therefore be rejected.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Parliament's budget proposal, which will be used as a basis for reaching an agreement with the Council. The European Commission has understood the dramatic nature of the migrant emergency – which is no longer an emergency but a structural issue – by allocating adequate funds while we parliamentarians have worked to compensate for the more meapic cuts proposed by the Council. Also this year we have aimed to save growth and jobs (we have increased funding to Horizon 2020, Cosme and Erasmus+). The budget must focus on research, innovation, digital and telematic infrastructure and new economies. Finally, thanks to internal cuts, Parliament will redistribute EUR 12 million on other expenditure chapters.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission's draft budget proposed a global allocation of EUR 153.8 billion in commitments and EUR 143.5 billion in payments; The Council has, as usual, applied certain reductions, particularly as regards payments, to EUR 142.1 billion. The European Parliament, through the vote at the end of September in the Committee on Budgets, rejected the Council's cuts in its whole and proposed significant increases in relation to the Commission's initial proposal. The final outcome was therefore an increase to 157.5 billion in commitments and 146.5 billion in payments, with the largest increases concentrated in heading III, with a particular focus on funds for the immigration emergency. The priorities supported by the Committee on Budgets are largely to be welcomed, but I am critical of the general approach to the imbalance between commitments and payments and, moreover, in my opinion, there are some totally useless lines within the budget on which courageous action should be taken. As far as administrative expenditure is concerned, there is not the slightest mention of a reduction in administrative expenditure, and every year there is a continuous increase in it, which is not at all sustainable at a time when it is the EU itself that is calling for restrictions on the Member States.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of reading the European Union budget for 2016. I think it is important for the European Parliament to stand firm against the cuts feared by the Council, and I hope that this vote will give impetus to a more balanced agreement in conciliation. I find the text particularly appropriate where it calls for EUR 800 million to be allocated to the reception of refugees throughout the EU. Ensuring that the resources needed to deal with the refugee crisis are guaranteed is a priority for the S&D Group and I am extremely pleased that this paragraph has been included in the reading.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 In this draft budget for the year 2016 it is clear the intention of strengthening Europe Fortress, now with the argument of rapid response to the refugee crisis. As well as the intention to strengthen the EU's "competitiveness" between large economic groups on the pretext of combating unemployment and strengthening small and medium-sized enterprises to which such financing does not arrive. Once again, we see that the budget does not have sufficient resources to be able to meet the need for a recovery of the economy as well as the objectives of social and territorial cohesion. The budget would play a decisive role in mitigating and even in reassing the continuing dynamics of divergence and widening of inequalities between Member States. But he never fulfilled this role because of his so-of-life. The EU does not need a restrictive budget. It is regrettable that this budget package once again does not serve the development interests of each Member State, revealing the enormous hypocrisy of those who insist on the same old guidelines, refusing any kind of solidarity between Member States. We voted against it.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. This year, too, I have not seen the slightest mention of the reduction in administrative expenditure, but rather that it is gradually increasing, which is why I voted against the report. Nevertheless, I welcome the fact that the plenary has finally espoused the M5S's call against the economic support – through European funds – of bull farming for bullfighting shows. Instead of funding farmers for years, these funds have served to support, even with EUR 129 million a year, farms for unworthy shows based on the martyrdom of innocent beasts. Today, with the adoption of two amendments promoted by the M5S, the European Parliament has asked the Member States and the Commission to stop funding this sector. With the first, we have called for funding under the CAP for combat bull farms to be excluded from next year's budget. In the second, however, we have called on the Commission to exclude this funding forever, because this is a clear violation of the European Convention.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because, despite its limitations, it responds to the urgent need to speed up the functioning of European Justice. Double the number of judges in the General Court was not the first choice of the S&D Group or the Parliament as a whole; however, worse than not reaching our highs program would be to allow the situation to remain as it is. The delays currently in legal proceedings harm citizens and unreasonably make the whole system unreasonable. The economic costs of these measures far exceed the cost of the proposed reform; on the other hand, its costs in trust and legitimacy are incalculable. It is no coincidence that this reform originates from a request from the EU Court of Justice itself. This reform also opens the door to gender parity in the field of European justice, where until now it was painfully absent. It is a conquest that we must not underestimate, because it is the first step in fulfilling a long-awaited commitment to equality in this area.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In 2011, the Court of Justice of the European Union requested a legislative initiative to amend its Statute with the aim of allowing the increase in the number of judges for the General Court, on the basis of an increase in their workload.  Their number has been varying, not so much for that reason but because the Member States have maintained the criterion of appointing their own judge. In 2014 the TJ proposed to double, in three phases, the number of judges (28 more judges), to two judges per Member State in 2019, as well as to abolish the Civil Service Tribunal, a proposal supported by the Council. However, I consider that theJ's request to double the number of judges is not adequate, since the data provided on the accumulation of pending cases and the length of proceedings do not match. Its proposal also does not promote transparency in the appointment of judges. Therefore, since the ECJ requests a drastic increase in its budget without any justification, nor does it adequately justify its request to abolish the TFF, I voted against this proposal for a Regulation at second reading.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which contained a number of important, progressive provisions. The report emerged from the LuxLeaks scandal. The aim is to ensure the mandatory automatic exchange of information between tax administrations regarding advance cross-border rulings and advance pricing arrangements and to strengthen existing EU legislation. The GUE/NGL rapporteur managed to further strengthen the Commission proposal in a number of key areas including strengthening reporting requirements, i.e. the immediate exchange of information. My Group tabled an alternative compromise stating that all rulings should be publicly available and not only stored somewhere in a central Commission database in an aggregated form. The Greens and EFDD supported the GUE/NGL Group on this issue but unfortunately it was rejected in committee.  Nevertheless, given that the report was still an improvement compared to the Commission proposal, and especially compared to the Council position which was adopted even before the vote in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, I voted in favour of it.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This recommendation calls for doubling the number of judges at the Tribunal to 56 judges under the pretext of a more expeditious European justice system.  I am opposed to any increase in the number of judges. My colleagues in the JURI committee have proposed to increase the number of referendums and translators. They also tabled an amendment to prevent, in the name of the separation of powers, a former MEP or EU official from becoming a judge of the European Court of Justice (first amendment to the vote, rejected without debate) to avoid any conflict of interest. I regard this reform as an insult to the European taxpayer because the Union is increasing its expenditure with great levity in the midst of an economic crisis. Also, the procedural legality of the process is flawed since the ECJ's original application does not, until proven otherwise, serve as a legislative proposal.  Our ENL Group has therefore tabled a single amendment rejecting the report for which I logically voted in favour.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ It should come as no surprise to anyone to learn that I do not believe British courts should be subservient to European courts.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. The reform of the Court of Justice is an emergency in the face of the rise of litigation, particularly competition. I deplore the national selfishness that prompted the Council to double the number of judges (28) so that each Member State would have "its judge". The Court proposed a reinforcement of 12 judges, its recommendations were not followed by the Council. To avoid institutional deadlock and business stacking, Parliament has endorsed this maximalist agreement.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Since the establishment of the General Court, the number of cases brought before it has increased over the years, resulting in an increase in the number of cases pending before that court over time. Failure to take the necessary procedural and organisational measures, including an increase in the number of Judges of this Court, may affect the duration of the proceedings. I supported the Council's position to increase the number of judges to 56, which means appointing two judges on a proposal from each Member State.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The resolution as a whole and various amendments call for the number of European Court of Justice judges to be increased from 28 to 40 or 56, to which we are opposed in principle.

name: Joëlle Bergeron (EFDD)
text: In writing. Increasing the number of judges at the European Court of Justice is not a trivial subject when we know that its jurisprudence has done as much for Community integration as the multiple reforms of the European treaties.  Today, the number of cases settled by the Tribunal has for several years been lower than the number of cases brought and in constant growth (more than 65% between 2000 and 2010). All of this, of course, entails costs and longer procedural time frames. Increasing the number of judges is the structural solution that has been adopted by the Council, the Commission and Parliament. I have proposed with my Italian colleague Laura Ferrara amendments to increase the Matter by 12 judges, 7 of whom are the judges of the Public Service Tribunal, which is destined to disappear. A total of 40 judges instead of the current 28 appears to be an appropriate and less costly response than a doubling to 56 judges as envisaged.  The reform of the European Court of Justice has been under discussion for almost five years now. It is high time today to get out of what has become a gas plant.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim is therefore to double the number of judges at the Tribunal to 56 judges when the Court's original request was to appoint 12 judges. The arguments for this reform are the increase in the number of cases while the figures and statements of the judges are contradictory, or the length of judgment too long, which is still a false argument because it is acceptable in the eyes of the ECHR, given the incompressible delay due to translation and the complexity of competition cases in particular. In committee, ENL elected officials proposed to increase the number of referendums and translators, not the number of judges.  This reform increases EU spending with great levity at a time when people are suffering from austerity. Moreover, the procedural legality of the whole process is tainted since, in reality, the subject that is now under consideration is not the appointment of 12 additional judges, but the appointment of 28 additional judges and the removal of a specialized tribunal (TFP). So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although I am opposed to the idea of expanding the staff of the EU institutions, in particular that concerning the judges of the Court of Justice, I support the report in so far as it calls for equal representation of the Member States and limits the number of appointments, subject to verification of the functioning of the Court. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the text we are voting on.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because, despite its limitations, it responds to the urgent need to speed up the functioning of European Justice. Double the number of judges in the General Court was not the first choice of the S&D Group or the Parliament as a whole; however, worse than not reaching our highs program would be to allow the situation to remain as it is. The delays currently in legal proceedings harm citizens and unreasonably make the whole system unreasonable. The economic costs of these measures far exceed the cost of the proposed reform; on the other hand, its costs in trust and legitimacy are incalculable. It is no coincidence that this reform originates from a request from the EU Court of Justice itself. This reform also opens the door to gender parity in the field of European justice, where until now it was painfully absent. It is a conquest that we must not underestimate, because it is the first step in fulfilling a long-awaited commitment to equality in this area.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒Ensuring a functioning judiciary is essential for europe's future. Given that member states could not agree on simple criteria, while protecting their national interests in all respects, the cost to citizens is quite high.  However, the conclusion is that a dysfunctional judiciary would have an even higher cost for citizens of the European Union, so I support this report. What finally needs attention is gender balance, so that finally both sexes should be equally represented in european courts.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. The proposed reform is to double the number of judges at the European Union Tribunal (from 28 to 56) whereas the Court's initial request was for the appointment of 12 additional judges. It should be noted that the two courts directly affected by the proposal (Tribunal and The Public Service Tribunal) and the staff concerned were not even consulted. The reasons given (increased number of cases and longer judgments) are unfounded and contradict available figures, statements by Tribunal judges and ECHR jurisprudence.  Gilles Lebreton and I had proposed an increase in the number of referendums and translators, not the number of judges. At a time when the European Union is imposing austerity measures of unprecedented violence, it is proposing an expensive and unseeded reform. In addition, it is proposed that the Public Service Tribunal be abolished, which is illegal under the treaty. So I voted against this reform.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report called for a doubling of the current number of judges in the EU General Court from 28 now to 56 in 2022. Whilst in principle this appears inoffensive, there are budgetary issues to take into account and the proposal represents an unacceptable increase in the budget at a time when the EU is forcing Member States to apply harsh austerity policies. It was for this reason that I voted against the report.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this reform is to double the number of judges at the Tribunal to 56 judges, whereas the initial request of the Court of Justice of the Union was to appoint 12 additional judges. These appointments should reduce their ever-increasing workload due to a large increase in the number of cases, which is incorrect. In fact, the Council has proposed doubling the number of judges to satisfy the national authorities of the Member States who could not agree on the nationality of the judges to be appointed without worrying about the interests of European taxpayers who are already suffering from the austerity measures imposed on them.  Furthermore, in the name of the separation of powers, the group, Europe of Nations and Freedoms, has tabled an amendment so that no Member of Parliament or EUROPEAN official who has worked in the decision-making or legislative process can become a judge. I therefore voted in favour of the single rejection amendment tabled by our group.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 There is no final vote at second reading. In the absence of a detailed analysis of the functioning of the Court, I am opposed to any possibility of staff expansion, especially that relating to judges; However, I supported the amendments which ensure equal representation of the Member States and limit the number of appointments, which can only be made as a result of analyses of the functioning of the Court.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because, despite its limitations, it responds to the urgent need to speed up the functioning of European Justice. Double the number of judges in the General Court was not the first choice of the S&D Group or the Parliament as a whole; however, worse than not reaching our highs program would be to allow the situation to remain as it is. The delays currently in legal proceedings harm citizens and unreasonably make the whole system unreasonable. The economic costs of these measures far exceed the cost of the proposed reform; on the other hand, its costs in trust and legitimacy are incalculable. It is no coincidence that this reform originates from a request from the EU Court of Justice itself. This reform also opens the door to gender parity in the field of European justice, where until now it was painfully absent. It is a conquest that we must not underestimate, because it is the first step in fulfilling a long-awaited commitment to equality in this area.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have today voted in favour of the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the Council position at first reading with a view to adopting a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Protocol 3 on the Statute of the Court of Justice of the European Union. In October 2014, the Court of Justice proposed doubling the number of judges in the court (twenty-eight more). The Council immediately gave its assent to the new proposals. However, it is not clear how in 2013 nine judges were enough to solve the court's problems while in 2014 more twenty-eight were needed. The report highlighted the lack of good faith in such a change in the number, linking it to the Council's decision, which voted in favour because the proposal entails the possibility of each Member State appointing 'its own' judge. I therefore voted to reject the Council's position because it signals a deep contempt for European taxpayers' money, given that each cabinet of judges costs more than EUR 1 million per year and that everyone's salaries would lead to an increase in EU structural expenditure of over EUR 20 million per year.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report called for a doubling of the current number of judges in the EU General Court from 28 now to 56 in 2022. Whilst in principle this appears inoffensive, there are budgetary issues to take into account and the proposal represents an unacceptable increase in the budget at a time when the EU is forcing Member States to apply harsh austerity policies. It was for this reason that I voted against the report.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which calls for an increase in the number of judges in the European Court of Justice to 56, since there is an increase in the number of cases before the Court. I also support the idea of gender parity rules and the enforcement of a review clause after five years of the provisions’ entry in force, in order to focus on the efficiency of the General Court in implementing the increase in the number of the judges and the establishment of specialised chambers.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Justice of the EU has proposed a legislative review to appoint 12 new judges, due to the increased workload. The EP voted in favour at first reading but the Council failed to appoint any judge, so the Court proposed doubling the number of judges from 28 to 56. In addition to this inconsistency, I believe that the European Union should not appoint judges in the way it appoints political commissioners. Judges are not Commissioners of the Member States and should not be appointed as such. Judges must be chosen for their technical and legal experience and independence. Only in this way can the quality of decision-making, honesty, impartiality and resistance to any pressure to which they may be subjected be guaranteed. I voted against.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of the reform of the European Court of Justice.  Since 2012, the number of cases handled by the Court has increased by 43%. The main reason for this dysfunction: a cruel lack of judgment. Its consequences: an infringement on the right of European citizens to be heard within a reasonable time, and an obstacle to the functioning of the single market.  In this critical context, the European Parliament has taken its responsibilities by requesting the appointment of 12 new judges in 2015 (already planned in the 2015 EU budget), followed by the transfer of the 7 judges of the Public Service Tribunal and its staff, and the appointment of the last 9 judges in 2019. Above all, I welcome the inclusion in this reform of two pre-assessment reports in the second and third phases, which I have called for during the negotiations, and whose aim is to assess the Real Budgetary Needs of the Court throughout the reform. These reports should help the Court in its tasks while respecting the budgetary exemplary to which the European institutions are bound.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 It is recommended that a joint committee of experts be set up by Parliament and the Council to analyse the overall functioning of justice in the EU and to put forward proposals to improve it.  It is also recommended that all EU courts should now be subject to scrutiny by the European Commission for the effectiveness of justice under the same rules as the courts of the Member States of the Council of Europe.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has today decided on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a regulation amending Protocol No 1 to the Treaty on European Union. 3 on the Body of the Court of Justice of the European Union. The Council's proposal includes a doubling of the Judges of the General Court and the abolition of the Civil Service Tribunal.  But the real problem is not the number of judges but the fundamental change in the way they are elected. The election of judges of the European Court of Human Rights set an example for this. The submission by each Member State of three candidates is followed by the evaluation - vote by the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe. The two-stage structure of the procedure (first the national proposal and then the vote of the representatives of the States), combined with the non-re-election of judges, provides greater guarantees of transparency and impartiality in the selection of judges. What the European Union therefore needs is a fundamental change in the way its judges are elected, going far beyond increasing or reducing their numbers and emphasising meritocracy, transparency and a balanced election of men and women to the positions of European judicial officers.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation, as I believe that the European Parliament should reject the Council's position for a number of reasons: firstly, because it signals a deep contempt for European taxpayers' money; secondly, also for reasons relating to the dignity of justice itself, in reality the EU should not appoint judges as political commissioners. I also believe that the Court of Justice's proposal, if implemented, could have serious long-term repercussions for the Eu ropean judicial system. In fact, many elements of the proposal would require serious and impartial analysis and impact assessment. However, no cost-benefit analysis has been carried out or carried out. I also agree with the proposals for further training in order to analyse the overall functioning of the Union's justice system, such as the recruitment of judges through an open competition between teachers of recognised case law and between judges of higher courts in the individual Member States, the appointment of each judge only for a term of nine years, with the exclusion of renewal or extension and absolute respect for gender equality in the recruitment of judges.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The progressive extension of the powers of the Court of Justice of the European Union from its inception to the present day and the growing affirmation of European law in national law has led to a steady increase in the number of legal proceedings to be carried out for the Court of First Instance. The failure to introduce procedural and organisational measures to improve the management of the load of the issues submitted to the Court has had a negative impact on the duration of the proceedings. I therefore welcome the proposal to increase the number of members of the Supreme Court of Europe, so as to facilitate the work of judges by making it faster and more effective, but at the same time accurate and attentive, while also allowing European citizens to receive answers and protections of their rights in a reasonable timeframe.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2011, the Court of Justice of the EU launched a legislative initiative to amend its statutes and allow the appointment of a further 12 judges to the Court justified on the basis of an increase in workload and the consequent need to reduce the burden per judge and the duration. In the previous parliamentary term, the EP adopted a position at first reading confirming the Court's request. However, the Council did not appoint any of these 12 judges because the Member States did not reach agreement on the choice of judges. Therefore, in October 2014, the Court proposed doubling the number of judges from the current 28 to 56 in three stages, including the abolition of the Civil Service Tribunal. The Council immediately accepted these new proposals. The proposal would also double the relevant referendums and assistants by more than 100 and at a time when the EU is imposing strict austerity measures to balance Member States' budgets, this is completely unjustified. For the reasons listed above, vote against.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. – Increasing the number of judges at the Court of Justice of the European Union has been on the agenda for several years in order to better manage the ever-increasing number of cases. The present proposal concerns the judges of the General Court in the Court of Justice. No compromise with the European Council was reached until the 2014 European Parliament elections, and the European Parliament adopted its own position on the issue in 2014. In September 2014, the Italian Presidency-in-Office of the Council requested a new draft proposal from the Court of Justice because the Member States could not agree on a system for the selection of judges, and the proposed 12 judges could not have been fairly appointed on a national basis. As a result of the new proposal, an agreement was reached between The Member States in the Council, which was adopted by Parliament's commission, the Committee on Legal Affairs. According to this, the number of judges will be gradually increased to a total of 56 and the gender balance will be taken into account. This proposal has been presented to plenary. The decision includes a review clause that, after 5 years, an impact assessment should be carried out on whether the proposed solution will live up to its expectations, i.e. the processing of the backlog of cases, in order to ensure balanced, swift and professional legislation. As described, I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In 2011, the Court of Justice of the European Union requested a legislative initiative to amend its Statute with the aim of allowing the increase in the number of judges for the General Court, on the basis of an increase in their workload.  Their number has been varying, not so much for that reason but because the Member States have maintained the criterion of appointing their own judge. In 2014 the TJ proposed to double, in three phases, the number of judges (28 more judges), to two judges per Member State in 2019, as well as to abolish the Civil Service Tribunal, a proposal supported by the Council. However, I consider that theJ's request to double the number of judges is not adequate, since the data provided on the accumulation of pending cases and the length of proceedings do not match. Its proposal also does not promote transparency in the appointment of judges. Therefore, since the ECJ requests a drastic increase in its budget without any justification, nor does it adequately justify its request to abolish the TFF, I voted against this proposal for a Regulation at second reading.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In this report we voted in favour of adding 28 judges to the Court of Justice of the European Union, phased in over the coming years. A particular clause for gender balance was included. I believe that we need to ensure the functioning of the European judiciary as not doing so comes at a higher price for citizens. However, we also insisted on overcoming discrimination: It is also about time that both genders will be equally represented in European Courts.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This legislative report proposes to increase the staffing of the European Court of Justice by twelve new judges, bringing the total number of judges to fifty-six. Following a request from the Court justified by the increase in cases to be dealt with and the length of time it takes to proceed with cases, the report introduces the principle of gender balance in the context of this appointment and proposes a review clause after five years to assess the court's effectiveness to fifty-six judges and the use of resources. Considering that the Court of Justice plays a key role in promoting the stability and legal security that is essential for citizens and the economic sector, I voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The resolution as a whole and various amendments call for the number of European Court of Justice judges to be increased from 28 to 40 or 56, to which we are opposed in principle.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: Written. – This is a very important dossier. It is about ensuring that the European Court of Justice can carry out its duties to the full and that the necessary judges are assigned to do so. That is why this is a considerable increase. However, I regret the increase by 28 judges, whereas the ECJ itself had requested only 12 additional judges. This number is highly arbitrary and not based on a correct workload measurement as it should be.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Since 2012, cases dealt with at the European Court of Justice have increased by 43%. The Court fails to deal with them on time and accumulates a significant delay, which undermines the quality of the judgments rendered. This dysfunction cannot continue. That is why it is essential to improve the functioning of the Court through structural reform. Internal reorganization measures within the institution should ensure the efficient use of existing human resources. Similarly, the Public Service Tribunal will be abolished and its resources and staff transferred to the Court.  The Court must also be given the means to function better. This requires an evolutionary and equal increase in the number of judges.  Progress reports will assess actual budgetary needs and progress in the handling of business as part of the reform.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Increasing the number of judges in the Court of Justice of the European Union has been on the agenda for several years. In 2011, the Court of Justice first came up with a proposal in this respect, as the increased number of cases could not be handled effectively enough. As no compromise was reached with the European Council on the issue until the 2014 European Parliament elections, the European Parliament adopted its position at first reading on 15 April 2014. In September 2014, the Italian Presidency requested a new draft proposal from the Court of Justice because the Member States in the Council could not agree on a system for the selection of judges, since the proposed total of 12 judges could not be fairly appointed on a national basis. As a result of this new proposal, an agreement was finally reached between the Member States in the European Council, which was adopted at second reading by the JURI commission responsible for this dossier. According to this, the number of judges will be gradually increased to a total of 56 and the gender balance will be taken into account. The decision also includes a review clause according to which an impact assessment should be carried out after 5 years, on the basis of which it will be possible to determine whether the proposed solution will live up to its expectations, namely the processing of arrears in order to ensure balanced, swift and professional legislation. That is why I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. At present, the European Court of Justice is composed of 28 judges, one per Member State. However, the increase in the number of cases to be dealt with has resulted in an overload of work for the Court and an inability to respond to cases within a reasonable time. An increase of 28 judges is therefore proposed for better functioning.  I voted in favour of doubling the number of judges in three phases (12 judges in 2015, transfer of the 7 judges of the Public Service Tribunal in 2016, 9 additional judges in 2019) because following the quadrilogue (Parliament, Council, Commission and Court of Justice) our group has won on two essential elements in my opinion, namely, namely an analysis of the Real Needs of the Court prior to the implementation of Phases 2 and 3 of the reform and respect for gender parity in the appointment of new judges.  It goes without saying, however, that this increase in the number of judges must be followed by an increase in the Staff of the Court and in particular in translation services, which are currently understaffed. These measures are necessary for the proper functioning of the Court's judicial activity.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This reform concerned the change in the organisation of the European Court of Justice (ECJ). While the first version had the sole stated objective of appointing twelve additional judges, this second reading reveals a much more important project. By moving from the simple appointment of a few judges to the increase to fifty-six judges and the abolition of the Public Service Tribunal, it is a real Trojan horse that is proving to be today. By including this new legislative proposal along the way, the Commission is breaking the basic formal rules inherent in legislative drafting in Parliament. On the contrary, our group had proposed, in order to reduce the delays, not the appointment of co-opted persons, but rather the increase in the number of translators and referendums; this is where the true origin of the too-important time frame lies. This amendment was rejected without any debate. I objected to that report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I do not think it is necessary to increase the number of judges at the General Court. It is true that the number of cases that the Court has to deal with is increasing, but I believe that appointing more judges is not the solution. Furthermore, to my knowledge, there is also no assessment of the proposal on how the reform would affect and what its consequences would be. Moreover, their appointment would mean a minus in the European budget equivalent to approximately EUR 20 million per year. And in the current difficult situation that the European Union faces, I think these funds would be more useful invested elsewhere.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 As is apparent from the explanatory memorandum, the real problem is not the lack of judges and prosecutors in the general court but the inability of the Council itself to appoint a correct number of judicial officers, because each Member State wishes to appoint its own judge. However, judges and prosecutors are not Commissioners to be appointed on political terms by each Member State. The proposal to double the number of judges in the DG and the proposal to abolish the IGC should therefore be rejected. Finally, a very important reason is the contempt for taxpayers' money from European citizens. For these reasons, we are voting against the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Protocol No 1 to the Treaty on European Union. 3 on the Statute of the Court of Justice of the European Union.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. There are currently 28 judges, one per Member State, at the General Court. There are also 7 judges working for the Civil Service Tribunal. The reality is that the General Court is absolutely saturated. The current time for sentencing in sensitive cases is four to five years and there is a risk of a non-contractual liability claim against the Union for undue delays of a millionaire nature. In June this year, the Council informed Parliament that it had already adopted its position at first reading on this subject, including amendments to the Statute allowing the increase of the 28 judges in three distinct phases: 12 judges in 2015, 7 judges on 1 September 2016 and 9 judges on 1 September 2019. With the approval of this report by Parliament and the negotiating mandate, we support the Council's position to increase one judge per Member State. It's an issue that's been stuck too long. The current situation requires practicality and rapid action to improve the work of the General Court.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The resolution as a whole and various amendments call for the number of European Court of Justice judges to be increased from 28 to 40 or 56, to which we are opposed in principle.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. When, in 2011, the Court of Justice of the EU proposed a legislative revision to appoint twelve new judges, on the basis of increased workload, the EP voted in favour at first reading, thus approving the court's request. However, the Council has not been able to appoint any judge because no agreement has been reached between the Member States. As a result, the Court proposed doubling the number of Judges from 28 to 56 in three stages, a proposal immediately accepted by the Council. Parliament must now ratify this new proposal. For our part, and in line with the rapporteur's position, we have tabled amendments to reiterate the initial position, namely an increase of twelve judges. The increase in expenditure that would involve hiring such a large number of judges would require an increase in expenditure of more than twenty million euros – more than a hundred staff should be hired to support the judges. Finally, I would like to point out that the judges of an independent body such as the Court of Justice must not be chosen as political appointments, but must be assessed for their experience and independence, thereby ensuring an impartial, independent and transparent decision-making process, all of which are lacking in this legislative initiative. I voted against.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 A reform of the Court of Justice of the European Union is a pressing result of the overwork it has been facing. The Court pointed to the need for 12 judges, in addition to those already possessing – 28, one per Member State. However, member states in the Council were unable to understand which countries would be entitled to an additional judge. Thus, they decided to double the number of judges (up to 56), in a number clearly higher than that pointed out by the Court itself, which translates into a pharaonic and unnecessary expenditure for the European public wasteway. I voted in favour of an increase in line with what had been recommended by the court's real operating needs - up to 40 judges - noting the justified increase in the number of judges and avoiding a pointless and megalomanous decision. The European Union must take decisions, not in accordance with the national egocentrisms which prevent an efficient decision, but because of the real administrative needs of the Union.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted in favour of this agreement. However, I am aware that it is far from perfect: 28 new judges are more than is needed, but it proved impossible to get the Member States into the Council for a different solution. For the sake of legal certainty, we must therefore make progress – citizens and businesses suffer when the Court does not deal with cases on time – and I supported the compromise.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it aims to increase the power of judges in the European Union.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe requires Italy to close small courts, but then doubles its judges. This is what emerges from the hypocritical vote by which the European Parliament, bowing to the will of the Council, reformed the EU Court of First Instance from 28 to 56. Each new judge, with his office, will cost taxpayers one million euros a year. The reform, which stems from the Court of Justice's request to increase its staff in order to cope with the excessive workload and the consequent delays, has turned into an opportunity for Member States to increase their seats. Judges should not, however, be 'Commissioners' of the Member States and should not be appointed as such. In order to speed up justice, we need no more judges but a more effective organisation of the courts, alongside, perhaps, the specialised courts already provided for in the Treaties. On the contrary, this reform prelude to the abolition of the Civil Service Tribunal: the Court that had distinguished itself with the first European judgments on bullying and harassment within public offices. There are no more words ... but only the vote against this scandalous reform.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is a second reading of the proposal for a Regulation on the reform of the Statute of the Court of Justice.  The Council proposed two amendments to the organisation of the General Court: (1) that the number of judges of the General Court should be set at 56 at the end of a three-step procedure; (2) that the Civil Service Tribunal, which has the power to decide at first instance in proceedings of the civil services of the European Union, should be closed and judges transferred to the General Court. Parliament did not fully refuse the Council's proposals and only amended the proposal for a timetable for increasing the number of judges by introducing further steps and adding the need for gender balance in the appointment of judges. For our part, we do not agree with the proposal. We consider the closure of the Civil Service Tribunal to be negative, since, under Article 270 TFEU, the Court has jurisdiction to hear disputes between the EU and some 35 000 officials. We also believe that the mere increase in the number of judges will not solve the problem of the burden of cases before the General Court, in addition to the disagreement with the proposed method of choice.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the report because transparency has not been guaranteed.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 As is apparent from the explanatory memorandum, the real problem is not the lack of judges and prosecutors in the general court but the inability of the Council itself to appoint a correct number of judicial officers, because each Member State wishes to appoint its own judge. However, judges and prosecutors are not Commissioners to be appointed on political terms by each Member State. The proposal to double the number of judges in the DG and the proposal to abolish the IGC should therefore be rejected. Finally, a very important reason is the contempt for taxpayers' money from European citizens. For these reasons, I am voting against the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Protocol No 1 to the Treaty on European Union. 3 on the Statute of the Court of Justice of the European Union.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the introduction of the review clause and of gender balance, and the increase in the number of judges in the General Court to 28. It is absolutely necessary to ensure the functioning of the European judiciary. Member States could not agree on criteria as simple as merit: they insisted on their national interests. This comes at a high price for citizens, but the price for a dysfunctional judiciary would even be higher. Therefore we should accept their agreement, but insist on overcoming discrimination: it is about time that both genders were equally represented in European courts.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliament must reject the Council's proposal for a number of reasons. Firstly, because it completely ignores the interests of taxpayers. At a time when the EU is calling for serious austerity measures to balance member states' budgets and calls on these Member States to reduce their public spending, such a frivolous increase in costs is pointless and difficult for Europeans to accept. Doubling the number of judges would also lead to an increase in the number of legal rapporteurs and assistants, thus increasing the number to more than 100. Given that the operation of each office costs more than EUR 1 million per year, total remuneration would increase EU structural expenditure by more than EUR 20 million per year. The other reason why Parliament rejects the EBB's proposal is the dignity of the judiciary itself, that is, the reputation and respect for the judicial office. The Union may not appoint judges in the way it appoints political commissioners. Judges should be selected on the basis of their professional experience and legal expertise in order to guarantee the quality of decision-making, while the right character is also the basis for selection, ensuring fairness, honesty and impartiality. Furthermore, at the appointment stage, particular emphasis should be placed on gender equality. It is incomprehensible that justice in the Eu is primarily in the hands of men. The proportion of male and female judges in EU courts should be strictly the same.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Court of Justice of the European Union in 2011 for a legislative initiative with a view to changing its Statute in order to allow the appointment of twelve additional judges to the General Court, citing the need to reduce, in the General Court, both the number of cases per judge and the duration of each case.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because, despite its limitations, it responds to the urgent need to speed up the functioning of European Justice. Double the number of judges in the General Court was not the first choice of the S&D Group or the Parliament as a whole; however, worse than not reaching our highs program would be to allow the situation to remain as it is. The delays currently in legal proceedings harm citizens and unreasonably make the whole system unreasonable. The economic costs of these measures far exceed the cost of the proposed reform; on the other hand, its costs in trust and legitimacy are incalculable. It is no coincidence that this reform originates from a request from the EU Court of Justice itself. This reform also opens the door to gender parity in the field of European justice, where until now it was painfully absent. It is a conquest that we must not underestimate, because it is the first step in fulfilling a long-awaited commitment to equality in this area.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because, despite its limitations, it responds to the urgent need to speed up the functioning of European Justice. name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the proposal to reject the Council's proposal to adopt the regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Protocol No 3 on the Statute of the Court of Justice of the European Union, as I consider an increase in the number of judges to be an absolute waste of taxpayers' money, which I do not support.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. Due to the delay in resolving trials and the accumulation of pending proceedings, the CJEO requested in 2011 that twelve new judges be incorporated. This is the enlargement that I supported today with my vote. In addition, I have supported those twelve new judges being elected according to their knowledge and experience. What I have not been able to do was vote in favour of the Council's position, which, unable to agree on how to elect these twelve judges — since then there would be forty judges in total and the 28 Member States would not be represented in the Court by the same number of judges — proposes to incorporate more judges than the Court itself asked for , with the consequent charge for European public coffers. Nor have I supported the proposal not to add any additional judges, as the CJEO has an essential role — ensuring homogeneous compliance with European legislation in the Member States — and should be provided with the necessary resources to comply with it without delay or delay.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. We cannot deny that the Court of First Instance has, over the years, seen an exponential increase in the number of cases brought. This workload has lengthened the length of proceedings and the number of pending cases, making it much less efficient than requests and expectations. The increase in the number of judges has now become a necessity, Community competences have increased, we must respond to these numbers.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. Not only because it was adopted in committee under perfectly undemocratic conditions, as my colleague Lebreton pointed out yesterday in the debates. Not only because it violates the treaties. But mostly because it is completely useless, expensively useless. Even the judges of the Court, it seems, agree. Of course, they asked for a little more resources, but not doubling their number! It must be said that the European Union's regulatory bulimia can only lead to an increase in litigation and preliminary claims. For contrary to what the Commission tells us every year, the Europe of Brussels does not legislate better and more clearly: it regulates and constrains all kinds, with bushy and obscure texts, such as the REACH regulation killing the French chemical industry, or like the thousands of pages of banking and financial legislation, to which are added the thousands of pages of related delegated acts.... Before we think about increasing the number of judges, we should think about stemming this tide of legislation that is overwhelming European businesses and citizens.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of much of the articulation on the number of judges. Increasing times in general judicial proceedings on a large scale in the Union requires an increase in the number of judges. The dossier includes a number of important amendments such as gender balance and insistence on transparent opposition systems. We understand that, without these measures, the dossier would be meaningless and the increase in judges would be merely the creation of more spaces of power within a system which is already distant from the citizens of the Union. It is these types of improvements that allow the Court to initiate its approach to European citizenship.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Protocol No 3 on the Statute of the Court of Justice of the European Union, because in recent years there has been a permanent increase in the number of cases pending at the General Court, reflecting the increased number of admissible classes of action, litigation as a result of the 2004 and 2007 accessions, greater European integration, regulatory acts and trademark applications. Because there are not enough judges the duration of proceedings has increased significantly.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because, despite its limitations, it responds to the urgent need to speed up the functioning of European Justice. Double the number of judges in the General Court was not the first choice of the S&D Group or the Parliament as a whole; however, worse than not reaching our highs program would be to allow the situation to remain as it is. It is a conquest that we must not underestimate, because it is the first step in fulfilling a long-awaited commitment to equality in this area.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Increasing the number of judges in the Court of Justice of the European Union has been on the agenda for several years. In 2011, the Court of Justice first came up with a proposal in this respect, as the increased number of cases could not be handled effectively enough. As no compromise was reached with the European Council on the issue until the 2014 European Parliament elections, the European Parliament adopted its position at first reading on 15 April 2014. In September 2014, the Italian Presidency requested a new draft proposal from the Court of Justice because the Member States in the Council could not agree on a system for the selection of judges because the proposed total of 12 judges could not be fairly appointed on a national basis. As a result of this new proposal, an agreement was finally reached between the Member States in the European Council, which was adopted at so-called second reading by the European Parliament's Committee on This Dossier (JURI). According to this, the number of judges will be gradually increased to a total of 56 and the gender balance will be taken into account. The decision also includes a review clause according to which an impact assessment should be carried out after 5 years, on the basis of which it will be possible to determine whether the proposed solution will live up to its expectations, namely the processing of arrears in order to ensure balanced, swift and professional legislation.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I did not support the agreement between the Council and the Parliament to reform the General Court by multiplying by two the current number of judges. I believe that reform of the court is necessary due to its increasingly heavy case burden and the ever-increasing duration of proceedings, as outlined by the General Court in its original request when it sought an increase of just 12 judges. Due to the Member States’ indecision and wrangling over the nationalities of judges we now have an increase of an additional 28 judges (including seven from the merger with the Civil Service Tribunal) without any assessment of whether such a high number can be justified. Making such a decision on the basis of Member State interests rather than the actual requirements of the Court is irresponsible and undermines the credibility of EU institutions in the eyes of citizens.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I decided to support this report as it will increase the number of judges which will help to cope with the increasing number of cases at the court. I am also in agreement that the selection process should be based on merit and there should be no selection system based on nationality.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted AGAINST the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council amending Protocol No 1009/2013. 3 on the Statute of the Court of Justice of the European Union, because I believe that amendments to the Statute of such an important EU institution should be made on the basis of specific and established needs that are in accordance with legal texts and with fundamental treaties.  I therefore support the rejection of the request to increase the number of judges on the grounds that it is necessary for the Court to explain in detail the reason and need for that increase. Furthermore, I also agree with the rejection of the application for the abolition of the Civil Service Tribunal due to a lack of legal basis in the contracts. However, I support the increase in staffing in the secretariat and in language services in order to increase the efficiency and readiness of judges and the Court itself.  In addition, I support the establishment of a joint committee of experts from Parliament and the Council to analyse the justice system in the EU, i.e. to improve it.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This recommendation aims to double the number of judges at the Tribunal to 56 judges on the pretext of a better speed of European justice.  We are opposed to any increase in the number of judges, but we have proposed to increase the number of referendums and translators. We have also tabled an amendment to prevent, in the name of the separation of powers, a former MEP or European civil servant from becoming judges at the European Court of Justice (first amendment to the vote, rejected without debate). This reform shows a profound contempt for the European taxpayer because the Union is increasing its spending with great levity at a time when people are suffering from austerity.  Also, the procedural legality of the entire process is flawed since the ECJ's original application does not, until proven otherwise, serve as a legislative proposal.  Our ENL Group has therefore tabled a single amendment rejecting this reform.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I decided to vote against the Council decision to increase the number of judges in the Court of Justice of the European Union, as this measure would imply more cost to the EU budget than benefit to the efficiency of the court.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D)
text: Written. 'In voting on the extension of the European Court of Justice, we chose to abstain on all amendments relating to the number of judges. It is important that the General Court functions properly, for which enlargement is also necessary. The original bill therefore assumed an extension of 12 additional judges, on top of the existing 28 (1 per Member State). Unfortunately, the negotiations between the Member States have shown that the national interest was considered so important that an extension of 28 additional judges was chosen, i.e. a total of two per Member State. We do support other amendments to the proposal – such as attention to gender equality, an efficient organisation and a revision clause. That is why we did not want to jeopardise the compromise text, as our S&D Group had to negotiate hard to get these points in. However, because of the large number of judges, the additional costs involved and whether this doubling is proportionate, we have therefore chosen to abstain on those specific points.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Ant-nio Marinho i Pinto's report on the status of the EU Court of Justice. The aim of this text is to respond to a request from the Court to increase the number of judges, currently set at 28, to deal with the increase in cases pending before the Court. The number of judges will be doubled and will be accompanied by a gender balance test and a revision clause. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation because the European Court of Justice (ECJ) is facing more and more cases as a result of the expansion of its powers as well as new members who have joined the EU. It was therefore necessary to change the status of the Court by doubling the number of its judges in order to expedite the proceedings pending before the ECJ and to introduce a gender test in the appointment of judges.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This report should be rejected as it is aimed only at increasing the number of judges.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have decided to give my favourable opinion on this proposal. Given the growing importance and incisiveness of the rules of European law within national law, the number of questions referred to the European Court of Justice and its judges has also increased. I believe that an increase in the number of members of the Supreme Court of Europe can help to make their work even faster, more accurate and more efficient, to the benefit of the reasons for justice expressed by European citizens, in order to obtain accurate answers and protections more quickly.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. The Europe of Nations and Freedoms Group has tabled an alternative motion to replace the Recommendation of the Legal Affairs Committee on the number of judges at the European Court of Justice. The aim of the reform supported by the commission is to double the number of judges at the Tribunal to 56 judges, whereas the Court's initial request was to appoint 12 judges. In committee, the group had voted against any increase in the number of judges, but instead proposed to increase the number of referendums and translators. These amendments were not adopted. This is a profound disregard for European taxpayers because the Union is increasing its spending very lightly at a time when people are suffering from austerity. The in-depth analysis (jurisdictional structure, financial impact) of the project, although promised since 2011 by the Court of Justice, has never been carried out. No impact studies have been carried out or alternatives being considered.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it doubles the number of judges of the Court when there was no need to do so. I fought with all my might, with the help of the rapporteur Mr Marinho e Pinto, who dissociated himself from his own majority, against this ignominy dictated by private appetites. This will cost us more than twenty million euros a year to fatten caciques, when they could have been used to alleviate the misery of certain European peoples.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because, despite its limitations, it responds to the urgent need to speed up the functioning of European Justice. Double the number of judges in the General Court was not the first choice of the S&D Group or the Parliament as a whole; however, worse than not reaching our highs program would be to allow the situation to remain as it is. The delays currently in legal proceedings harm citizens and unreasonably make the whole system unreasonable. The economic costs of these measures far exceed the cost of the proposed reform; on the other hand, its costs in trust and legitimacy are incalculable. It is no coincidence that this reform originates from a request from the EU Court of Justice itself. This reform also opens the door to gender parity in the field of European justice, where until now it was painfully absent. It is a conquest that we must not underestimate, because it is the first step in fulfilling a long-awaited commitment to equality in this area.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In 2011, the Court of Justice of the European Union requested a legislative initiative to amend its Statute with the aim of allowing the increase in the number of judges for the General Court, on the basis of an increase in their workload.  Their number has been varying, not so much for that reason but because the Member States have maintained the criterion of appointing their own judge. In 2014 the TJ proposed to double, in three phases, the number of judges (28 more judges), to two judges per Member State in 2019, as well as to abolish the Civil Service Tribunal, a proposal supported by the Council. However, I consider that theJ's request to double the number of judges is not adequate, since the data provided on the accumulation of pending cases and the length of proceedings do not match. Its proposal also does not promote transparency in the appointment of judges. Therefore, since the ECJ requests a drastic increase in its budget without any justification, nor does it adequately justify its request to abolish the TFF, I voted against this proposal for a Regulation at second reading.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against doubling the number of judges at the Court of the European Union because, in reality, this measure is not necessary, seeming to be the wish of some Member States. Do we really want trials to be judged more quickly and efficiently? The solution is to employ several referees and secretaries in the judges' offices, because they are the ones who do research and documentation for judges' decisions. The numbers don't lie. The hiring of several secretaries in 2014 halved the processing period of a case. Why do we have to double the number of judges, then, and not hire more secretaries? Moreover, in December 2014, the President of the General Court asked the Council for more auxiliary staff. I call for a check on the allegations of possible secret correspondence between the President of Parliament and the President of the Court of Justice and the other allegations mentioned in the letter received by all MEPs from a group of university professors.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. In 2011, the Court of Justice of the European Union launched a legislative initiative to change its status to allow the appointment of 12 more judges of the General Court due to the need to reduce the number of cases per judge and their duration. However, the judges were not appointed because no agreement was reached between the Member States. High costs require the proposal to be rejected and proposes the appointment of 19 new secretaries to help resolve cases more quickly.  I supported representative Antóni Marinh e Pinto's recommendation, as each new office costs more than €1 million a year and the total annual fee would be more than €20 million. Additional high expenditure at the time of the economic crisis is inadequate, so I think the correct step is to appoint new secretaries, as the recruitment of only 9 in 2014 proved successful as 100 more cases were resolved.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Court of Justice of the EU points to the increasing average length of proceedings before the General Court.  He argues that the current number of judges - one judge for each country appointed by a government agreement for six years - is not enough. The Council therefore proposed to increase the number of judges to 56, two for each Member State. This request came at a time when the EU institutions have agreed to reduce their staff by 5% and reduce spending by 0.5%. No ordinary legislative proposal was submitted on this matter, no consultative body commented on the proposal, no analyses and impact assessments were carried out. There have been no sufficiently relevant and unquestionable grounds for increasing the number of judges. Between 2013 and 2014, the productivity of the General Court improved, with the number of judges unchanged. It will be necessary to regularly monitor the statistics of this institution and evaluate productivity.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Protocol No 1 to the Treaty on European Union. 3 on the statute of the Court of Justice of the European Union, because it is complete and documented and for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 27/10/2015.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this reform! This process, bordering on legality, is done with the utmost contempt for democracy and citizens: where the Court of Justice requested the appointment of 12 additional judges, 28 new judges should now be appointed, with the suppression of a specialized tribunal. The whole "normal" legislative process has been ignored and results in a decision that will cost European citizens a fortune, without any impact analysis or evaluation being carried out!

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Justice delayed is often justice denied. The Court of Justice must become a more efficient and speedy organisation.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Justice of the European Union has submitted a request (02074/2011) to the European Parliament and the Council amending Protocol 3 to its Statute on the increase of judges at the Same Court. I am voting in favour of this request because circumstances such as the increase in the number of cases before the Court of First Instance, the extension of its powers, the diversification of the legal acts of the institutions, if not accompanied by measures of a procedural and organisational nature, could have a negative impact on the conduct and duration of proceedings.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The liberal delegation is clearly opposed to an increase in the number of judges as well as to a mandatory gender occupation.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the increase in the number of judges by 28 to cope with the increasing number of cases at the court. This increase will be phased in over the next three years.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The EU proposes an increase in the budget of its Court of Justice. Of course, this Court deals with important cases, for example in the area of environmental legislation. But the bottleneck that justifies this reform is mainly the result of EU disputes against state aid and on recent developments in the Banking Union and the Common Security Foreign Policy. I therefore object to any increase in the weight of this court under these conditions. The report proposes to appoint judges with respect for parity. But the issue is also to ensure the transparency of these appointments to avoid the current pitfalls where the judge appointed by France is a former member of the European business cabinet. I am opposed to that.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I have voted in favour of the adoption of the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council with a view to amending the Protocol on the Statute of the Court of Justice of the European Union to increase the number of judges of the General Court. Parliament has recognised that over the years the number of cases initiated has been increasing, which results in a significant increase in pending cases and the undesirable lengthening of the procedure.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support the increase in the number of judges at the General Court from 21 to 56 by 2019 as it will decrease the backlog of cases.
