If the EU is to retain its credentials as a fair and operational single market we need to ensure that the body mandated to deal with competition, state aid and trademark cases brought by companies can function correctly.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Between the euro crisis and the refugee crisis, this issue may seem secondary. It is actually symbolic. Europe is not at its best. The Court of Justice had proposed to create 12 new judicial positions. Faced with the difficulty of The Member States in agreeing, it decided to increase the number of additional judges to 28, while judicial delays had in the meantime decreased and the court concerned did not ask for these judges. This major change was carried out without external consultation, consultation with national parliaments, without an impact assessment. The Member States, which still want to reduce the European budget, have turned a blind eye to this unnecessary expenditure. It is the triumph of "party" technocratic technocracy over democracy. Parliament should have refused this manifestly excessive expenditure. Across Europe, public services, including the judiciary, must reduce their staff. By voting for this reform, bringing the number of judges to 56, parliamentarians who are in favour of it will come as no surprise tomorrow that the Union will appear as a privileged circle. I regret the vote on this reform, which not only abolishes the Public Service Tribunal but also makes the Eurosceptics play a game.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The speed of legal proceedings before the Court of Justice of the EU appears to be decreasing as a result of the gradual extension of powers and the number of cases lodged, and the number of pending cases is increasing. However, before considering raising the very complex issue of increasing the number of judges in court or even doubling their numbers, it is necessary to think about appropriate and effective measures, both procedurally and organisationally. I therefore support the proposal to set up a joint committee of experts to examine the general functioning of the Union's judiciary and make proposals to improve it.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the Court of Justice of the European Union: number of judges at the General Court, because in my opinion Europe needs to ensure the proper functioning of the European judicial system. A dysfunctional judiciary would not be in interests of European citizens. Therefore, I voted in favour of this agreement but only on condition that the amendments relating to gender parity and the review clause feature in the final text of the agreement.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Court of Justice of the European Union (CNB) initiated the appointment of an additional 12 judges to the General Court in 2011. At first reading, Parliament accepted the request for 12 additional judges, but the Council did not appoint any of these 12 judges, as the number of judges that could be appointed was significantly below the number of Member States, and each Member State wanted to appoint its own judge. Therefore, in October 2014, the TSI proposed doubling the number of judges of the judiciary. The Council approved the proposal, but Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs argues in its report in favour of rejecting the proposal.  It points out that this proposal does not reflect the actual needs arising from the overburdening of judges, but rather the Council's inability to reach agreement due to the selfishness of the Member States. On the one hand, the rejection proposal is justified by budgetary aspects (while the other institutions have agreed to a 5% reduction in staff and a budget reduction of around 0.5%, the CBA's budget would increase by more than EUR 20 million per year) and, on the other hand, it justifies it with the dignity of the judiciary, the reputation and respect of the judiciary. In the latter respect, it states that judges should be selected on the basis of their professional experience and legal expertise, not their nationality. I found the legal committee's argument to be well founded and therefore supported the proposal.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The 2016 budget fully reflects political priorities, specifically internal and external solidarity, as well as increased competitiveness through the creation of decent and quality jobs and business development and entrepreneurship across the Union. I endorse the rapporteur's position on the migration and refugee crisis, to which the necessary financial resources should be mobilised in the Union budget to meet the political challenges and enable the Union to achieve results and respond effectively to these crises, with a priority and high urgency. I believe it is essential to make a greater effort to fill the gaps in the Union's economy by increasing competitiveness, growth and quality employment, and I advocate the continuation of the Youth Employment Initiative for the basic role of this programme in the fight against unemployment. I commasked José Manuel Fernandes' work for its complexity, explanation and consensus.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This recommendation aims to double the number of judges in the European Union Tribunal to 56, while the ECJ initially called for the appointment of 12 additional judges on the grounds that the number of cases has increased (while the data and statements of judges are contradictory), but also that the length of time to render a judgment would be too long (while the ECHR has not found an unreasonable delay given the translation and translation complexity of competition cases, in particular). That is why the ENL group had proposed to increase the number of referendums and translators, not the number of judges. In the end, this reform increases the European Union's spending indecently when people are imposed with unbearable austerity. Moreover, the procedure is marred by gross irregularities since, in reality, the subject that is now under consideration is not the appointment of 12 additional judges, but that of 28 additional judges and the abolition of a specialized tribunal (TFP). So I voted against it.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the number of judges at the European Court of Justice (ECJ).  In 2011, an initiative was filed by the Court to increase the number of judges by 12 to deal with the increase in pending court cases. This text proposed to support the Council's position in favour of increasing the number of judges. At the request of the European Parliament, a gender balance criterion was introduced, as well as a clause to review administrative expenditure during the second and third phases of the court's enlargement.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. The report that we have adopted today is due to the progressive extension of the powers of the European Court of Justice: in recent years, in fact, the number of cases brought before the Community court has increased considerably, also involving more pending cases and bureaucratic delays. In the absence of a reform to renew procedural and organisational measures, including an increase in the number of judges at the court itself, the duration of proceedings would only risk increasing. In order to ensure fair and fast judgments, we therefore accept the gradual increase of a further twenty-eight judges, one for each Member State, despite the higher costs that will certainly result from the adoption of this criterion of national representation. We need an efficient legal system, and that is why we can also accept the abolition of the Civil Service Tribunal. Finally, we are pleased with the inclusion of a criterion of fair gender representation and a review clause that will make it possible to assess the impact of this reform on the management of the Court's work, which remains the guardian and beacon of European values and integrity.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In 2011, the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) launched a legislative initiative to change its status to allow the appointment of 12 more judges to the General Court. I voted for this proposal, which will increase the number of judges at the CJEU.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report, even though the coordinator of this dossier is a colleague from the ALDE group and the Committee on Fisheries, because I do not consider it necessary to increase the number of judges in the Court of Justice of the EU. The justification given, that of the increased responsibilities and, therefore, the increased workload for judges, was not a reasonable one in my view, given that each judge has less than 60 cases per year to be tried. In addition, the funds allocated annually to each judge for his activities amount to around EUR 1 million, which means that this increase in the number of judges will involve a substantial increase in the institution's expenditure. In these circumstances, I believe that the number of auxiliary staff should have increased, because they are the ones who will actually have an increased workload.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support an increase of 28 judges of the General Court, i.e. twice, because, on the basis of the available statistics, I believe that such an increase goes well beyond the actual needs of the General Court. I do not question the need for reform of the General Court as such, but I reject the doubling of the number of judges simply because the Member States have not been able to agree on a rotation mechanism when increasing by realistic and increasing the agenda corresponding to 12 judges. In general, I do not support solutions that are wasteful, and unfortunately this is one of them, and it is not even good in terms of citizens' trust in the Union.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report called for a doubling of the current number of judges in the EU General Court from 28 now to 56 in 2022. Whilst in principle this appears inoffensive, there are budgetary issues to take into account and the proposal represents an unacceptable increase in the budget at a time when the EU is forcing Member States to apply harsh austerity policies. It was for this reason that I voted against the report.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report calls for a doubling of the number of judges at the European Court of Justice. This effort arose because in 2011 the judges did not get behind the handling of their cases. In the meantime, the judges have been able to re-open their backlog, which, in my opinion, is no longer a reason to increase the number of judges. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. I agree that it is necessary to increase the number of judges in order to speed up judicial proceedings, but this increase does not have to be doubled. Therefore, the proposals to double the number of judges did not support the proposals. The number of judges already agreed should be used to address the problem of national representation, for example by introducing a rotation system.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. The European Parliament has already voted by a majority two years ago on a proposal to extend to 40 judges, with a view to resolving the cap in European jurisdiction. The Council, however, failed to agree with the Member States, which always look out for their own interests and, despite time pressing, missed this opportunity. Now, two years later, they have made a quick and running proposal of 56 judges, poorly formulated (it does not provide, for example, for the extra recruitment of additional judicial secretaries) and which lengthens over time, while rushing Parliament to approve it. The large groups, as always, have been complicit in this sloppy and voted in favour, forgetting Parliament's above-set position.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that a reform of the Statute of the Court of Justice of the European Union is necessary in view of its current inability to guarantee the conditions for respect for the right to a reasonable duration of proceedings laid down in Article 6 of the ECHR and Article 47 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, which is impossible due to an overload of the cases before the Court, particularly in the field of competition and State aid. That is why I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I consider it necessary to increase the number of judges of the General Court of the European Union. The trend of increasing the number of cases brought before the court is a good and bad indicator. Good in the sense that citizens are slowly becoming aware of the possibility of choice and protection - the option that they can protect their rights, not only in a national, but also in a higher, European instance.  We also indirectly influence the national judiciary of the Member States through our work and decisions, while at the same time enhancing the unification and harmonisation of rights. I support the decision on the number of increases in judges, as this ensures compliance with the fundamental principle, the right to a fair trial within a reasonable timeframe. Increasing the number of judges would greatly contribute to the quality of the trials and allow the parties to best protect all rights belonging to them.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This recommendation aims to double the number of judges in the European Union Tribunal to 56, while the ECJ initially called for the appointment of 12 additional judges on the grounds that the number of judges cases would have increased (while the data and statements of the judges are contradictory), but also that the length of time to render a judgment would be too long (while the ECHR did not find an unreasonable delay in view of the translation and complexity of competition cases, in particular). That is why the ENL group had proposed to increase the number of referendums and translators, not the number of judges. In the end, this reform increases the European Union's spending indecently when, on the other hand, unbearable austerity is imposed on the people. Moreover, the procedure is marred by gross irregularities since, in reality, the subject that is now under consideration is not the appointment of 12 additional judges, but that of 28 additional judges and the abolition of a specialized tribunal (TFP). So I voted against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Due to the gradual expansion of the general court's jurisdiction since its establishment, the number of cases before the General Court has been increasing for years, which has over time led to an increase in the number of pending cases before that court. If appropriate measures of a procedural and organisational nature are not taken, including an increase in the number of judges of that court, it is possible that this will affect the length of proceedings. With a view to streamlining the duration and processing of the procedure, I support the adoption of the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council amending Protocol No 1999/2013. 3 on the Statute of the Court of Justice of the European Union, which provides for an increase in the number of judges of the General Court.

name: Kati Piri (S&D)
text: Written. 'In voting on the extension of the European Court of Justice, we chose to abstain on all amendments relating to the number of judges. It is important that the General Court functions properly, for which enlargement is also necessary. The original bill therefore assumed an extension of 12 additional judges, on top of the existing 28 (1 per Member State). Unfortunately, the negotiations between the Member States have shown that the national interest was considered so important that an extension of 28 additional judges was chosen, i.e. a total of two per Member State. We do support other amendments to the proposal – such as attention to gender equality, an efficient organisation and a revision clause. That is why we did not want to jeopardise the compromise text, as our S&D Group had to negotiate hard to get these points in. However, because of the large number of judges, the additional costs involved and whether this doubling is proportionate, we have therefore chosen to abstain on those specific points.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ In 2011, the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) launched an initiative to change its legislative status to allow more than 12 judges to be appointed to the General Court (GC). In 2013, the Court of Justice of the European Union reduced its application to nine judges, which was agreed by the Council of the European Union, the European Commission (EC) and the European Parliament (EP).  However, in the previous session, the EP approved 12 additional judges at first reading. However, the Council did not appoint these 12 judges, as Member States had not reached an agreement on the selection of judges and each state wanted to appoint 'its' judge. So, in October 2014, the CJEU proposed doubling the number of GC judges (28) in three phases, and this report deals with a new proposal.  The conclusions and recommendations are as follows: The Court of Justice needs to justify the exact number of judges that are truly needed, also judges who have already been appointed should be sworn in immediately, and a committee of experts should be drawn up to analyse the pros and cons of creating a new court specialising in trade marks, patents and intellectual property.  Furthermore, it recommended an increase in secretariat staff and translation services and an analysis of overall justice action in the EU, and proposals to improve aspects regarding the recruitment of judges and the appointment of each judge. For all of the above, I support rapporteur Pinto's report.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of changing the status of the Court of Justice of the European Union. Thanks to this change, each member country will have a second judge. By increasing the number of judges, we will be able to reduce the overhang of cases per judge, thus also reducing the length of the proceedings, which currently exceeds five years. In this way, the European Union will be able to reduce the costs of, for example, paying compensation to the parties for excessively long litigation. The Czech Republic advocates the introduction of the principle of equal representation of countries in the institutions of the European Parliament. Thanks to this amendment, the General Court will be able to better cover the different legal cultures that occur across the Member States of the Union. The increase in the number of judges will make the work of the General Court more effective.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In response to the very high workload faced by judges of the Court of Justice of the Union, an initiative in 2011 proposed adding 12 judges to the current 28 judges. This would have allowed more cases to be handled and wait times shortened. Finally, in the face of the lack of consensus among the Member States, the Council agreed on a doubling of the number of judges.  The European Parliament adopted this recommendation with the aim of amending Protocol 3 on the Statute of the ECJ. The text will then be debated at second reading. I voted in favour of this report. Increasing the number of judges would increase the effectiveness of the ECJ.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report deals with the amendment of Protocol No 3 to the STATUTE of the CJEU. At issue is a legislative initiative triggered by the CJEU in 2011 for the appointment of 12 additional judges to the TG. At first reading, the European Parliament approved such a request, but the procedure was blocked at Council level. In October 2014, the CJEU therefore proposed the appointment, in three stages, of 28 more judges to the TG and the abolition of the Civil Service Tribunal. The Council accepted, at first reading, these proposals, on which parliament now has a second reading. The need and impact of these proposals does not seem to be sufficiently documented. The best would therefore be to reject the Council's position. However, since the amendments tabled for this purpose have not passed, I understood that I should have a constructive position, suffraging the proposed increase of judges. This is without prejudice to the situation being reassessed in the second and third stages of enlargement of the TG and the CJEU must submit, within 5 years, a report on the functioning of the TG, in order to assess in particular the need and effectiveness of increasing the number of judges.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The resolution as a whole and various amendments call for the number of European Court of Justice judges to be increased from 28 to 40 or 56, to which we are opposed in principle.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. By voting for the report on the status of the European Court of Justice, I have spoken out against the Council's proposals to increase the number of judges at the European Court of Justice by 28 and abolish the Civil Service Tribunal. While it is conceivable that the European Court of Justice needs to increase its staffing levels in order to respond to the gradual expansion of its powers, the solution is not disorderly recruitment of judges, but must be part of a rational reorganisation.  I am the then in favour of the initial proposal of the European Court of Justice, namely the recruitment of 12 new judges, as well as the establishment of a report to analyse the real needs of the European Court of Justice. Indeed, the recruitment of registrars or referendum staff would be more appropriate in view of the budgetary requirements faced by this institution. It would then seem unacceptable for the choice of the number of judges to be recruited to be met less by a need of the Court than by an arrangement between Member States.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because, despite its limitations, it responds to the urgent need to speed up the functioning of European Justice. Double the number of judges in the General Court was not the first choice of the S&D Group or the Parliament as a whole; however, worse than not reaching our highs program would be to allow the situation to remain as it is. The delays currently in legal proceedings harm citizens and unreasonably make the whole system unreasonable. The economic costs of these measures far exceed the cost of the proposed reform; on the other hand, its costs in trust and legitimacy are incalculable. It is no coincidence that this reform originates from a request from the EU Court of Justice itself. This reform also opens the door to gender parity in the field of European justice, where until now it was painfully absent. It is a conquest that we must not underestimate, because it is the first step in fulfilling a long-awaited commitment to equality in this area.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Court of Justice (ECJ) launched a legislative initiative in 2011 to amend its status to allow the appointment of 12 additional judges for the Tribunal. She cited the need to reduce both the number of cases per judge and the length of cases at the Tribunal. In 2013, the Court of Justice reduced this request to 9 judges, a figure that was accepted by the Council of the European Union, the European Commission and the European Parliament. However, while in the previous Parliament, at first reading of Parliament, the number of additional 12 judges had been approved, the Council did not appoint any of these 12 judges, as the Member States had not reached an agreement on the choice of judges. In October 2014, the Court of Justice proposed doubling the number of judges of the Tribunal in three stages and abolishing the Public Service Tribunal. The Council immediately accepted these new proposals, which are precisely the subject of this report and have been the subject of a comprehensive compromise between the various political groups.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. This report foresees a doubling of the number of judges in the European Court of Justice (ECJ). Given the steady increase in the number of appeals to the ECJ, more resources need to be given to the ECJ.  This text therefore provides for several measures: to increase the number of judges to 56 (i.e. 2 judges per Member State), the introduction of rules guaranteeing parity, the need to carry out an impact assessment to assess the effectiveness of such a measure, and a revision of this provision in 5 years.  I would like to stress the crucial role of the European court and the need to give it the means to carry out its mission; that is why I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider the request to increase the number of judges of the Court of Justice of the European Union to be appropriate. Increasing the number of staff will help to shorten the time of procedures and make the Court more efficient. These improvements will benefit all European citizens, and that is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of much of the articulation on the number of judges. Increasing times in general judicial proceedings on a large scale in the Union requires an increase in the number of judges. The dossier includes a number of important amendments such as gender balance and insistence on transparent opposition systems. We understand that, without these measures, the dossier would be meaningless and the increase in judges would be merely the creation of more spaces of power within a system which is already distant from the citizens of the Union. It is these types of improvements that allow the Court to initiate its approach to European citizenship.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In 2011, the Court of Justice of the European Union requested a legislative initiative to amend its Statute with the aim of allowing the increase in the number of judges for the General Court, on the basis of an increase in their workload.  Their number has been varying, not so much for that reason but because the Member States have maintained the criterion of appointing their own judge. In 2014 the TJ proposed to double, in three phases, the number of judges (28 more judges), to two judges per Member State in 2019, as well as to abolish the Civil Service Tribunal, a proposal supported by the Council. However, I consider that theJ's request to double the number of judges is not adequate, since the data provided on the accumulation of pending cases and the length of proceedings do not match. Its proposal also does not promote transparency in the appointment of judges. Therefore, since the ECJ requests a drastic increase in its budget without any justification, nor does it adequately justify its request to abolish the TFF, I voted against this proposal for a Regulation at second reading.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as I do not wish to see more ECJ judges or more money spent on the ECJ.

name: Pedro Silva Pereira (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I declare that I voted in favour of the amendments tabled by Mr Marinho and Pinto to the report on the number of judges of the General Court of the Court of Justice of the European Union, because I believe that the need to increase expenditure to twice the current number of judges is not properly substantiated, especially at a time when Parliament and other European institutions are promoting measures to contain expenditure.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. In 2011, the Court of Justice of the European Union launched a legislative initiative to amend its Statute, which would allow the appointment of 12 additional Judges of the General Court. At that time, the Court indicated the need to reduce the number of cases per Judge and the duration of their term of office at the General Court. In 2013, the Court reduced its request to nine judges, but before that the European Parliament had already approved an additional 12 judges. As the number of judges appointed did not correspond to the number of Member States and this led to misunderstandings, the Court of Justice proposed in October 2014 to double the number of Judges of the General Court to the final number of 56. I agree that the reform of the Court of Justice of the European Union is very much necessary, as ensuring legal certainty and trial within a reasonable time is one of the fundamental rights of EU citizens. The General Court is faced with a huge number of applications and appeals, which then take a long time to resolve. Although I consider the number of new judges, i.e. 28, to be somewhat excessive, I very much support the gender equality clause in the appointment of new judges and the provision on the Court's mandatory report on this. As I support the recommendation for second reading with a view to the adoption of the regulation, I supported in plenary amendments reflecting the outcome of the negotiations between the European Parliament and the European Council.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I supported this report because increasing the number of judges to 56 improves the general situation and the court's ability to work. Increasing the number of judges allows for a reduction in the length of court cases and increases the efficiency of the Court itself. The aim of this increase is to implement gender equality and increase the effectiveness and performance of the General Court. Increasing the number to 56 judges will also improve resource efficiency, as well as the aspiration to create more specialised councils.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report on an increase in the number of judges in the General Court. Whilst I recognise the benefits of an increase in judicial staff, an increase in the number of judges means an increase in costs. I do not believe that such action can be objectively justified in the current economic climate.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the proposal to increase the number of judges and amend Protocol No. 3 on the Statute of the Court of Justice of the European Union. Since its establishment, the General Court's jurisdiction has gradually expanded and the number of cases before the General Court has been increasing for years. I support the view that appropriate procedural action must be taken and a better organisation taken, including an increase in the number of judges. We must help in our efforts to shorten the length of proceedings and to make the General Court better and more efficient.  I would like to point out that the appointment of additional judges should be based on their independence, impartiality and expertise, bearing in mind their professional and personal suitability and knowledge of the legal systems of the European Union and the Member States, and should also ensure gender equality in the overall composition of the Court.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the presented increase in the number of judges of the General Court and therefore did not support the proposal. The proposed increase in the number of judges is purely a political matter and has no rational justification and, moreover, increases expenditure by EUR 20 million per year, rather than trying to achieve budgetary neutrality.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation for second reading. The initiative to appoint additional judges started back in 2011, and over the years we have come to a compromise between the European Commission, the Council and the European Parliament. A functioning judiciary is one of the most important pillars of the rule of law. We need a well-functioning European justice system. I support the compromise reached for the appointment of an additional 28 judges. I am convinced that this will significantly reduce the delays that occur. In a few years' time, however, we will use the audit clause to check whether the changes have been as effective as we all expect together.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I could not support the proposal for a regulation amending the Statute of the Court of Justice in relation to the General Court, both for political and legal reasons, which I do not mention here. A slight strengthening of the General Court is needed because there has been some increase in the idea, to the extent of the Council's position at 1st reading, which was also agreed by the European Parliament in 2014, i.e. an increase of 12 judges. 28 judges are too much, 1 judge a year costs European taxpayers a little less than €1 million. The only reason for increasing the number of Judges of the General Court by 28 and not by 12 is that the Member States in the Council have not been able to agree on a rotation mechanism. However, such a rotation mechanism could be found in the 11 Advocates-General of the Court of Justice. This is therefore a failure of the Council to be paid for by the taxpayers. The proposal contains, in point 8a of the preamble, support for the idea of an objective of gender balance between judges, which means that specific candidates will be subject to gender discrimination and therefore I cannot agree with it. Moreover, such an objective will cause difficulties, particularly in the smaller Member States. We need the best possible judges for Europe, regardless of their gender. The purpose of the reform was to ensure the proper functioning of the court under changed circumstances. However, the arguments for increasing the number of judges by a further 16 compared to the court's original request are lacking.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 As is apparent from the explanatory memorandum, the real problem is not the lack of judges and prosecutors in the general court but the inability of the Council itself to appoint a correct number of judicial officers, because each Member State wishes to appoint its own judge. However, judges and prosecutors are not Commissioners to be appointed on political terms by each Member State. The proposal to double the number of judges in the DG and the proposal to abolish the IGC should therefore be rejected. Finally, a very important reason is the contempt for taxpayers' money from European citizens.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Increasing the number of judges in the Court of Justice of the European Union has been on the agenda for several years. In 2011, the Court of Justice first came up with a proposal in this respect, as the increased number of cases could not be handled effectively enough. As no compromise was reached with the European Council on the issue until the 2014 European Parliament elections, the European Parliament adopted its position at first reading on 15 April 2014. In September 2014, the Italian Presidency requested a new draft proposal from the Court of Justice because the Member States in the Council could not agree on a system for the selection of judges, since the proposed total of 12 judges could not be fairly appointed on a national basis. As a result of this new proposal, an agreement was finally reached between the Member States in the European Council, which was adopted at second reading by the JURI commission responsible for this dossier. According to this, the number of judges will be gradually increased to a total of 56 and the gender balance will be taken into account. The decision also includes a review clause according to which an impact assessment should be carried out after 5 years, on the basis of which it will be possible to determine whether the proposed solution will live up to its expectations, namely the processing of arrears in order to ensure balanced, swift and professional legislation. That is why I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I think it is important to underline that I have supported the adoption of amendments in several places in relation to the recommendation discussed at second reading, i.e. that the discussion on this issue should not be closed at this stage.  I would like to highlight only one of my concerns at this time. I believe that the duration of proceedings is not acceptable, in particular from the point of view of litigants, in particular in the light of the requirements laid down in Article 47 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and Article 6 of the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms. Measures of an organisational, structural and procedural nature are needed to remedy this situation, including a duly and adequately edinated increase in the number of judges.  In view of this and my concerns about this and other issues contained in the recommendation presented to us in the context of the second reading procedure, I consider it important that the issue has not been closed by the European Parliament in its present form.

name: Paul Tang (S&D)
text: Written. 'In voting on the extension of the European Court of Justice, we chose to abstain on all amendments relating to the number of judges. It is important that the General Court functions properly, for which enlargement is also necessary. The original bill therefore assumed an extension of 12 additional judges, on top of the existing 28 (1 per Member State). Unfortunately, the negotiations between the Member States have shown that the national interest was considered so important that an extension of 28 additional judges was chosen, i.e. a total of two per Member State. We do support other amendments to the proposal – such as attention to gender equality, an efficient organisation and a revision clause. That is why we did not want to jeopardise the compromise text, as our S&D Group had to negotiate hard to get these points in. However, because of the large number of judges, the additional costs involved and whether this doubling is proportionate, we have therefore chosen to abstain on those specific points.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I have spoken out in favour of returning to the previous proposal of the text and therefore disagree with the one presented today. It is a question of consistency between the two votes on his nominations. However, in this text I voted in favour of the amendments advocating gender equality.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament has approved a reform of the EU General Court, doubling the current number of its judges. Reforming the court, which is part of the European Court of Justice, is necessary in order to respond better to the permanent increase in the number of cases. However, the increase in the number of judges by 28 was motivated by EU Member States’ interests in wishing to have as many judges as other countries. Taking this into consideration, I opposed the increase for budgetary reasons and because the proposal makes no provision for a proper impact assessment.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to adopting a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Protocol (No 3) on the Statute of the Court of Justice of the European Union, as I believe that the European Parliament rejected the Council's position for a reason.  At a time when the EU is imposing harsh austerity measures, it would be disrespectful to European taxpayers to recklessly increase the use of public funds. This is not just about doubling the number of judges, but we should also increase the number of assistants and assistants. The abolition of the Civil Service Tribunal would, however, abandon specialised courts known to constitute a better quality of adjudication.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of much of the articulation on the number of judges. Increasing times in general judicial proceedings on a large scale in the Union requires an increase in the number of judges. The dossier includes a number of important amendments such as gender balance and insistence on transparent opposition systems. We understand that, without these measures, the dossier would be meaningless and the increase in judges would be merely the creation of more spaces of power within a system which is already distant from the citizens of the Union. It is these types of improvements that allow the Court to initiate its approach to European citizenship.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This text shows a profound disregard for European taxpayers' money because the Union is increasing its spending very lightly at a time when people are suffering from austerity.  Moreover, the procedural legality of the entire process is called into question. These include the appointment of 28 additional judges (instead of the 12 requested by the Court) and the abolition of a specialized tribunal.  The in-depth analysis (jurisdictional structure, financial impact) of the project, although promised since 2011 by the Court of Justice, has never been carried out. On the other hand, no impact studies have been carried out or other solutions envisaged.  I therefore vote AGAINST this text.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In 2011, the Court of Justice of the European Union (CBA) launched a legislative initiative to change its statutes with the aim of allowing the appointment of an additional 12 judges to the General Court. It argued that the number of proceedings per judge in the General Court and their duration should be reduced. According to the reporter, Parliament must reject the Council's proposal for a number of reasons. Firstly, because it completely ignores taxpayers' money. Considering the arguments, I supported the proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of much of the articulation on the number of judges. Increasing times in general judicial proceedings on a large scale in the Union requires an increase in the number of judges. The dossier includes a number of important amendments such as gender balance and insistence on transparent opposition systems. We understand that, without these measures, the dossier would be meaningless and the increase in judges would be merely the creation of more spaces of power within a system which is already distant from the citizens of the Union. It is these types of improvements that allow the Court to initiate its approach to European citizenship.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation because I think there is a need for reform in the Court of Justice. The reform involves increasing the number of judges in the General Court to 47 as from 1 September 2016 and to two judges per Member State as from 1 September 2019. As a follow-up to the reform of the General Court, yearly figures on its judicial activity should be presented and, if necessary, appropriate measures suggested.  At the second and third stages of the enlargement of the General Court, an assessment of the situation will take place which, if necessary, could lead to certain adjustments, notably in terms of the court’s administrative expenditure. It is also highly important to ensure gender balance within the General Court. In order to achieve that objective, partial replacements in that court should be organised in such a way that the Governments of Member States gradually begin to nominate two judges for the same partial replacement with the aim of choosing one woman and one man, provided that the conditions and procedures laid down by the Treaty are respected.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. In view of the situation of the Court of Justice of the European Union and the need to provide the Court with a greater number of judges for its proper functioning, I consider it necessary to vote in favour of this case.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In 2011, the Court of Justice of the European Union requested a legislative initiative to amend its Statute with the aim of allowing the increase in the number of judges for the General Court, on the basis of an increase in their workload.  Their number has been varying, not so much for that reason but because the Member States have maintained the criterion of appointing their own judge. In 2014 the TJ proposed to double, in three phases, the number of judges (28 more judges), to two judges per Member State in 2019, as well as to abolish the Civil Service Tribunal, a proposal supported by the Council. However, I consider that theJ's request to double the number of judges is not adequate, since the data provided on the accumulation of pending cases and the length of proceedings do not match. Its proposal also does not promote transparency in the appointment of judges. Therefore, since the ECJ requests a drastic increase in its budget without any justification, nor does it adequately justify its request to abolish the TFF, I voted against this proposal for a Regulation at second reading.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR)
text: Written. In 2011, in order to avoid the backlog of the judicial backlog, the European Court of Justice asked 12 new judges before its Court of Justice, a number that it later reduced to nine. However, the Council of Justice Ministers did not agree on which of the 28 EU Member States would be allowed to deliver an additional court. Therefore, he decided to simply double the number of judges, despite the fact that the said backlog was largely eliminated, mainly by internal reorganisation, to ± 10 %. At a cost to the taxpayer of over EUR 20 million a year, this is the European example of unadulterated waffle iron politics, and truly vindictive in times of rigid austerity. Moreover, the planned abolition of the 7-judge Civil Service Tribunal will only partially offset the costs. Without a serious impact assessment, this proposal was quietly guided by the European Parliament. The N-VA delegation therefore voted decisively against it.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. The Court of Justice had asked for 12 additional judges because of its high workload. As the Member States failed to reach an agreement, the Council decided to increase the number of judges by one per Member State, i.e. 28. The backlog had already been reduced and the workload did not require 28 extra judges. I therefore voted in favour of an increase of only 12 instead of 28 extra judges in order to reduce the workload but not to waste resources and staff. The increase to 56 judges is not a good thing for the European project and will only play into the hands of Eurosceptics.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 What is at stake in this proposal is to fix the number of judges of the General Court at 56 through three-step proceedings: first stage: 40 judges; second, 47, from 1 September and, third stage, two per Member State in 2019. On the other hand, the Civil Service Tribunal, which has the power to decide at first instance in proceedings of the Civil Service of the Union, must be closed and judges transferred to the General Court on the basis of a future legislative request to be lodged by the Court of Justice. It should be noted that the simple increase in the number of judges will not solve the problem of overload of cases - it will be necessary to increase the number of assistants of judges, because they are the ones who perform most of the work.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The liberal delegation is clearly opposed to an increase in the number of judges as well as to a mandatory gender occupation.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the growing number of cases that the Court of Justice of the European Union has faced in recent years, and given the obvious need to increase the number of judges to ensure the proper functioning of the court, I voted in favour. However, it is inevitable that the choice of judges by the Member States was driven by the national interest more than by standards of substance. The Court of Justice is a very important instrument for the protection of European citizens' rights and I believe it is essential to have common selection criteria based on the principle of meritocracy and non-discrimination.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. Together with my group, the ECR, I voted against the report 'Court of Justice of the European Union: number of judges at the court'. The report is contrary to the principle of subsidiarity. The appointment of the judges of the Court of Justice of the European Union is an issue that should be dealt with by the Member States. The report calls for the introduction of many measures, including the introduction of gender quotas, and I categorically reject that. For these reasons, I voted against this report.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D)
text: Writing. The European Court of Justice is the main institution for the legal protection of European citizens. Its decisions are a guide for the development of the whole of the European Union. It is therefore necessary to provide the necessary resources to deal with the large number of cases in order to ensure high-quality decisions. Clearly, more judges are needed. At the same time, however, we must not make unnecessary expenditure scares in times of tight coffers. The proposal to double the number of judges is a compromise. It is therefore necessary and wise to carry out an evaluation after five years and, if necessary, to adjust the number of judges.  As Social Democrats, we are always committed to gender equality. That is why we are also insisting that the new posts filled by the Member States should be done on an equal footing with one woman and one man per country. At the moment, a procedure at the ECJ takes between 2 and 5 years. This is clearly too long. Too often, the ECJ finds itself threatened with claims for damages because of the excessive processing time, which entails enormous costs. Maintaining the status quo therefore means a heavy financial burden, as does the increase in the number of judges. However, the functioning of the European judicial system must be a top priority.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2011, the Court of Justice of the EU launched a legislative initiative to amend its statutes and allow the appointment of a further 12 judges to the Court of First Instance. In the previous parliamentary term, Parliament approved a position confirming the Court's request. However, the Council did not appoint any of these 12 judges, so the Court proposed doubling the number of judges to 56 and the Council immediately accepted. Parliament has today been called upon to ratify this decision, which I personally rejected. Firstly, in view of the important budgetary implications, at a time when the EU is imposing severe austerity measures on Member States.  Indeed, the proposal to double the number of judges would increase the number of judges and assistants by more than EUR 100 million for an increase in structural expenditure of more than EUR 20 million per year. The second reason has to do with the dignity of the judicial arm itself; the EU must not appoint judges in the way it appoints political commissioners, they must be chosen for their technical and legal experience and independence. Only in this way can the quality of decision-making, honesty and impartiality be guaranteed.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not vote in support of increasing the number of Judges of the General Court by 12 as proposed in this report. In fact, I believe that this increase is not necessary, nor would it lead to greater efficiency or faster case handling. The fact that the Member States are unable to agree on a functioning rotation system cannot, after all, justify the General Court having 28 judges.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the report on the European Court of Justice's request to increase the number of judges for the General Court. Although the reasons given by the European Court of Justice for its request, namely the reduction of the burden on individual judges by a number of cases and thus the acceleration of proceedings, are understandable, I do not share the idea of supporting an application, the consequences of which have not yet been examined. No independent study has been carried out evaluating the necessity of the required change. In my opinion, an impact study should be the basis for any objective decision-making on proposals.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is a second reading of the proposal for a Regulation on the reform of the Statute of the Court of Justice. The Council proposed two amendments to the organisation of the General Court: (1) that the number of judges of the General Court should be set at 56 at the end of a three-step procedure; (2) that the Civil Service Tribunal, which has the power to decide at first instance in proceedings of the civil services of the European Union, should be closed and judges transferred to the General Court. Parliament did not fully refuse the Proposals of the European Council, having only amended the proposal for a timetable for increasing the number of judges by introducing more steps and adding the need for gender balance in the appointment of judges. We voted against the report as we are either ominating the European Council's proposal or against the European Parliament's proposal: we consider the closure of the Civil Service Tribunal to be negative, since, under Article 270 TFEU, the Court has jurisdiction to hear disputes between the EU and some 35 000 officials. We also believe that the mere increase in the number of judges will not solve the problem of overloadof cases.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This Recommendation of the European Parliament for the second reading on the Council's position on the amendment of the Regulation on the provisions applicable to fishing in the area of the CGPM Agreement (General Committee on Fisheries of the Mediterranean) has been adopted without a vote by Parliament. However, there are certain modifications that should be highlighted. The Council's position is less ambitious than the initial proposal, especially due to insufficient weighting of resource conservation criteria. It allows the granting of derogations to Member States under the CGPM proposals, provided that they have an appropriate national management framework with a well-defined fishing permit scheme and space-time closure measures suitable for the limited use of some red coral colonies. Such exemptions may be corrected by the Commission if the cases are not confirmed. A minimum catch depth is also established, minimum dimensions are defined for them and the use of remote-controlled vehicles – except in very particular circumstances – and trawling in coastal areas are prohibited, but also allowing derogations from Member States.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The legislative resolution on the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) will give a green light to the Council position at first reading, without making any changes. Some recommendations from the GFCM have been taken over in part by the Council. They concern the environmental protection of red coral, and tackling incidental catches of seabirds, sharks and seals. The restrictions remain in place on paper, but the Council has demanded that Member States themselves can grant derogations to their fishermen. Remotely operated underwater vehicles (ROVs) will be prohibited from harvesting red coral, environmental protection will be stepped up for certain species, and Member States will be at liberty to grant derogations for fishermen. While I support the aforementioned proposals, approval of the Council position had already been given by the Committee on Fisheries, and consequently the plenary did not vote on this matter.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This text aims to put in place technical rules that will both preserve fisheries resources and look after the interests of fishermen.  The first point raised by this project was the request of the Black Sea Coastal Member States to be able to continue using trawls and gillnets. This request has been the subject of a compromise: it is permissible, on an exceptional basis, to use trawls along the Black Sea coast, but this exemption cannot set a legal precedent. The second point was raised by several states, including Spain, which requested exemptions to continue harvesting red coral, a protected species. This was also the subject of a compromise: states that have established or will establish a national management framework in the next three years will be able to continue to exploit red coral, but in the event of a danger to this species, the Commission will intervene. These waivers will expire at the end of 2015. These measures maintain a healthy balance between environmental protection and give Member States the opportunity to obtain exemptions. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Approval of this took place without a vote, but for the usual reasons I would not have supported this.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it is simply intended to transpose relevant provisions of the CGPM to ensure that they are applied uniformly and effectively throughout the European Union.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this proposal on the possibility of derogating from the prohibition on the use of certain gears in coastal waters of the Black Sea. It concerns trawling and gillnets in the Black Sea, as well as the minimum allowable base diameter of red coral colonies, their collection and the tools and instruments used for this purpose. However, it is important to stress that such an option is exceptional in nature.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This text must define technical measures that will preserve fisheries resources in a "difficult" context in the Mediterranean (particularly overfishing and pollution), while at the same time sparing the interest of fishermen. The main concern is therefore that it is permissible, on an exceptional basis, to use these devices in the Black Sea coastal zone, but these exemptions could not set a precedent in any future legal act. The second concern is that some states, including Spain, have requested exemptions to continue harvesting red coral, an endangered species, but the country must submit joint recommendations within three years, accompanied by a national management framework. I voted for this text because the idea being, as often, to find a balance between protecting the marine environment and the interests of fishermen, it goes in the right direction.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Mato report on the provisions for fisheries in the area of application of the GFCM (General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean) agreement is acceptable and does not pose any particular critical issues, so I wanted to support it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. Regulation (EU) No 1343/2011 on certain provisions applicable to fishing in the area of the CGPM Agreement is updated, incorporating into EU law the obligations arising from the conservation and control measures adopted by the General Commission on Mediterranean Fisheries (CGPM) between 2011 and 2014. It should be noted that it has been dealt with with a high degree of consensus since, in establishing its position, the Council took full account of the Commission's proposal and the position of the European Parliament at first reading, reflecting the agreements reached in the compromise amendments in the draft Recommendation which was submitted for consideration in the last Committee on Fisheries of 23 September and has now been submitted for plenary approval.   He has therefore received my favourable vote.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it supports the authorisation of a temporary derogation from the prohibition on the use of certain gear in coastal waters of the Black Sea. In the annex to the resolution annexed to the report, Parliament notes that this provision is of an exceptional nature. They shall take into account the situation prevailing in the region when Member States take measures to allow the use of the necessary tools as set out in the relevant UFM recommendations. For these reasons, Parliament agreed, in the current context, to an agreement allowing the Member States concerned to grant the necessary derogations. However, Parliament has reiterated that these provisions should not be regarded as a precedent or are used as a precedent for future legislation.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposed recommendation as its adoption confirms the position of the EU Council on a regulation on certain fisheries provisions in the Agreement area of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM Agreement).  The proposed amendments transpose several recommendations of that Commission into the European acquis, providing an appropriate framework for multilateral cooperation to promote the development, conservation, sound management and best exploitation of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea.  I am pleased that the co-legislators have reached agreement on the most appropriate mechanisms for granting derogations. Fishing methods in the Black Sea and the Mediterranean vary considerably due to different areas and conditions. Thus, the adopted recommendation allows for certain derogations from the black sea coastal fishing ban, with member states managing derogations and giving the Commission the right to control.  Specifically, this means the approval of a limited number of vessels that will exceptionally be able to use trawls in the Black Sea coastal area. In addition, certain deviations are also provided for in the observation of red coral colonies, such as the continued possibility of using remotely controlled underwater devices for observation and searching for red coral, provided that the devices do not contain cutting and harvesting aids.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 I support this recommendation. At issue is a compromise solution to the Fishing Provision adopted by a large majority, and the Commission has retained the right to act if any risk arises in implementing it. What we must always pay attention to is that, in addition to fishing and making much-needed living earnings, we must also take care of the preservation of flora and fauna for all future generations to come.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which goes in the right direction, since the idea is to strike a balance between protecting the marine environment and the interests of fishermen. However, this report was not voted on in plenary.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The legislative resolution on the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) will give a green light to the Council position at first reading, without making any changes. Some recommendations from the GFCM have been taken over in part by the Council. They concern the environmental protection of red coral, and tackling incidental catches of seabirds, sharks and seals. The restrictions remain in place on paper, but the Council has demanded that Member States themselves can grant derogations to their fishermen. Remotely operated underwater vehicles (ROVs) will be prohibited from harvesting red coral, environmental protection will be stepped up for certain species, and Member States will be at liberty to grant derogations for fishermen. While I support the aforementioned proposals, approval of the Council position had already been given by the Committee on Fisheries, and consequently the plenary did not vote on this matter.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This dossier takes into account the European Union's interest in the development and proper exploitation of the living marine resources of the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. Indeed, the conservation and sustainable exploitation of marine resources lives in the application area as well as the protection of marine ecosystems where these resources are present play an important role in the context of 'blue' growth and sustainable development. That is why I am pleased with the approval of the fisheries provisions in the GFCM area.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to define technical measures that will preserve fisheries resources while sparing the interest of fishermen. For example, an exceptional exemption, at the request of the Member States, has been proposed so that fishermen can continue to use trawls and gillnets in the Black Sea.  In addition, the report introduces another exemption that allows fishermen to harvest red coral, an endangered species. The Member States in question will have to make joint recommendations, accompanied by a national management framework, within three years. Finally, the use of remote-controlled underwater vehicles for the observation of red coral remains permitted only on the condition that these devices are not equipped with arms to cut the coral.  These exemptions, which expire no later than 31 December 2015, constitute a compromise in favour of protecting the environment and safeguarding our fishermen. That is why I voted for these provisions.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With a view to the most comprehensive legislative framework on fisheries, the European Parliament and the Council agreed on the transposition into Union law of a series of recommendations made by the General Committee on Fisheries in the Mediterranean (GFCM Agreement). This agreement envisages an appropriate framework for multilateral cooperation to promote the development, conservation, rational management and optimal use of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and Black Seaats at levels considered sustainable and at a low risk of exhaustion. The GFCM Recommendations provide for a number of measures to improve the existing framework, including measures for the sustainable exploitation of red coral in the Commission's area of competence, measures to reduce by-catches of seabirds, sea turtles, monk seals and cetaceans in the context of fishing activities in the GFCM Agreement area, and measures to protect against fishing activities for sharks and sea cats. I voted in favour of the recommendation to amend Regulation (EU) No 1343/2011 on certain provisions relating to fishing in the area of the GFCM Agreement because these regulations come to ensure a strengthened regulatory framework for all sectors of activity.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Approval without final vote. The European Parliament declares that the provisions of Article 15a to be included in Regulation (EU) No 1343/2011 concerning derogations from the ban on the use of certain gears in black sea coastal waters are of an exceptional nature. They shall take account of the situation in the region, where Member States have put in place measures to allow the use of the gear in question in accordance with the relevant recommendations of the GFCM. Parliament accepts, in this context, the provision authorising the Member States concerned to grant such derogations. It stresses, however, that these provisions are not to be regarded or used as a precedent in any future legislative act.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Gabriel Mato's report transposes measures adopted by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (CGPM) into EU law during its annual sessions in 2011, 2012 and 2013.  The CGPM is a regional fisheries management organisation established in accordance with Article XIV of the FAO Constitution. Its main objectives are to promote the development, conservation, rational management and optimal use of living marine resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean, the Black Sea and intermediate waters. The CGPM has the authority to adopt binding decisions ("recommendations") in its area of competence.  The transposition includes technical measures for the sustainable exploitation of red coral, the reduction of accidental catches of seabirds, sea turtles and cetaceans, and the conservation of monk seals, sharks and rays in the area covered by the CGPM agreement. The report also implements certain measures in EU law concerning the fishing of small pelagic stocks in the Adriatic Sea. I support the agreement reached in a trilogue between Parliament and the Council on 26 March 2015.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to adopting a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1343/2011 on certain provisions for fisheries in the area of application of the GFCM Agreement. In particular, in order to protect the development, conservation, rational management and better use of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea at levels considered sustainable and at low risk of depletion, Member States should be asked to grant derogations for the use of trawls and hoses and a ban on coastal trawling in the Black Sea. Parliament has accepted the differentiated procedure, which provides for management at national level, with the Commission's right of control, which can be justified by the profound diversity with the Mediterranean basin. Furthermore, the Commission will only authorize ships after checking whether the conditions laid down in the GFCM recommendation have been met. The Member States will therefore be able to maintain their national frameworks, if they comply with the conditions laid down in this regulation, and I have therefore voted in favour of the text.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The legislative resolution on the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) will give a green light to the Council position at first reading, without making any changes. Some recommendations from the GFCM have been taken over in part by the Council. They concern the environmental protection of red coral, and tackling incidental catches of seabirds, sharks and seals. The restrictions remain in place on paper, but the Council has demanded that Member States themselves can grant derogations to their fishermen. Remotely operated underwater vehicles (ROVs) will be prohibited from harvesting red coral, environmental protection will be stepped up for certain species, and Member States will be at liberty to grant derogations for fishermen. While I support the aforementioned proposals, approval of the Council position had already been given by the Committee on Fisheries, and consequently the plenary did not vote on this matter.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because I agree that the recommendations of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) should be implemented before any measures are adopted, and the GFCM aims to provide protection to species covered by the Habitats Directive while also improving development in the Mediterranean, the Black Sea and connecting waters.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this agreement on the transposition into UNION law of several recommendations made by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean to which the European Parliament and the Council have arrived. My vote in favour is due to the fact that this agreement provides an adequate framework for multilateral cooperation aimed at promoting the development, conservation, rational management and better use of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea at levels considered sustainable and at low risk of depletion. Measures are also planned for the exploitation of red coral and to limit the accidental catches of certain marine species such as turtles and cetaceans, and a coherent picture of catch data to be reported to the GFCM (General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean) is contained.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 With a view to derogations from the ban on coastal trawling in the Black Sea, the European Parliament accepted that they should be regulated at Member State level with the right of in-depth control by the Commission. This approach is differentiated from that applicable to the Mediterranean, as these are different basins and even in the case of derogations, such as in the Mediterranean, the conditions laid down in the RECOMMENDATION of the GCM for granting derogations to the Black Sea are much less stringent.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation, as the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM), which covers the Mediterranean, the Black Sea and intermediate waters, has taken a number of measures to ensure the sustainable exploitation of red coral, the mitigation of accidental catches of seabirds, sea turtles, monk seals and cetaceans in fishing activities and the sustainable development of small pelagic stocks in the Adriatic Sea. I also agree with the rapporteur, who believes that the GFCM recommendations represent a sufficient level of regulatory protection and that it must be implemented before any new measures are taken. In other words, the agreement takes account of the measures already in place at national level, with the Member States already including many of these recommendations. Finally, I am very optimistic, as a final political agreement was reached during the second trialogue at the end of March. The european Parliament's objectives have been achieved, so the voice of the citizens has been respected.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The GFCM agreement ensures an adequate framework for multilateral cooperation aimed at promoting the development, conservation, rational management and better use of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea at levels considered sustainable and at low risk of depletion. I fully agree with the management at national level of the derogations relating to the ban on trawling or the collection of red coral, while always bearing in mind the Commission's right of control.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The GFCM agreement ensures cooperation aimed at promoting the development, conservation, rational management of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea, but aims to take measures for the exploitation of red coral and limit the catches of certain species such as sea turtles and cetaceans. In view of the continuing exploitation of marine resources and poor control of the Mediterranean coasts, I can only vote in favour of the adoption of this agreement.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This Recommendation of the European Parliament for the second reading on the Council's position on the amendment of the Regulation on the provisions applicable to fishing in the area of the CGPM Agreement (General Committee on Fisheries of the Mediterranean) has been adopted without a vote by Parliament. However, there are certain modifications that should be highlighted. The Council's position is less ambitious than the initial proposal, especially due to insufficient weighting of resource conservation criteria. It allows the granting of derogations to Member States under the CGPM proposals, provided that they have an appropriate national management framework with a well-defined fishing permit scheme and space-time closure measures suitable for the limited use of some red coral colonies. Such exemptions may be corrected by the Commission if the cases are not confirmed. A minimum catch depth is also established, minimum dimensions are defined for them and the use of remote-controlled vehicles – except in very particular circumstances – and trawling in coastal areas are prohibited, but also allowing derogations from Member States.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with the measures adopted by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) in its Annual Sessions in 2011 and 2012. I voted in favour of the inclusion of measures that deal with the sustainable exploitation of red coral and for the mitigation of incidental captures of seabirds, sea turtles, monk seals and cetaceans, for the protection of sharks and rays amongst others.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This legislative report aims to incorporate the recommendations of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (CGPM) into EU fisheries legislation. Established in 1949, the CGPM covers the Mediterranean, the Black Sea and adjacent waters and includes countries of the European Union as well as countries in Eastern Europe and the Mediterranean. Its main missions are to promote the development, conservation and rational management of live aquatic resource stocks and to promote cooperative training projects. The CGPM has adopted a series of measures to ensure sustainable exploitation of fisheries resources, including red coral, seabirds, sea turtles and sharks. Considering that these objectives are already provided for by European legislation, I have supported this report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report wanted to define technical measures to preserve fisheries resources in the Mediterranean. The problem lay in the necessary reconciliation between the problems of overfishing, pollution and the economic interest of fishermen. Here there is a coherent dialogue between the different interests involved. That is, by limiting pollution, paying attention to overfishing and the renewal of marine resources and finally granting exemptions to fishermen.  Noting a balanced compromise in an environment of economic difficulties for fishermen in Europe, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
