text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report, as the protection of marine fauna requires the application of European provisions, in particular for the collection of red corals by the necessary means and in certain areas.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the direction of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of an amendment to the legislation that would have introduced the recommendations of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean. It is also clear from the recommendations that, in order to maintain marine fish stocks, the European Union is being forced to impose appropriate restrictions on sea fishing. 30% of the earth's seas are overfished and marine fish stocks are at risk. As a result of reasonable steps taken to maintain them, the amount of seafish fish fished will be continuously and significantly reduced. Therefore, the common fisheries policy should pay much more attention to sustainable fish farming, i.e. aquaculture, and in particular freshwater fish farming. A significant number of fish ponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 sites. These farms do not pose any threat to the natural assets of these areas. Moreover, in many cases it is precisely because of our closed-system fish ponds that they have created or preserved individual wetland associations. Consequently, freshwater aquaculture should be prioritised and given as much EU support as possible. Furthermore, this area should be freed from unduly stringent and unnecessary sustainability standards, which are justified only for sea fishing.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament and the Council have agreed to transposition into Union law several recommendations made by the General Committee on Mediterranean Fisheries which provides for an appropriate framework for multilateral cooperation in order to promote the development, conservation, rational management and better use of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea, at levels considered sustainable and at low risk of rupture. As far as derogations from the ban on trawling in black sea coastal waters, Parliament accepted that they should be managed at Member State level, with the Commission having the right of supervision. This is a question of authorising a limited number of vessels to use exceptionally trawls in the Black Sea coastal area.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it has a certain balance between environmental protection and the interests of fishermen.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We rejected the report at first reading, a vote in which it fundamentally weighed insufficient consideration of the conservation criteria for resources. As we said then, the Council's proposal goes back to the GFCM proposal. It is worth noting that the proposal allows derogations from Member States, within the scope of gfcm proposals, provided that they have an appropriate national management framework, with a well-defined fishing authorisation scheme and space-time-based measures suitable for the limited operation of some red coral colonies. These derogations may be corrected by the Commission if the premises are not. A minimum depth for capture is defined, the capture is allowed only with hammer in scuba diving (which at 50 meters depth conditions a lot), minimum capture dimensions are defined, the use of "rovs" is forbidden except in very particular circumstances, namely investigation. Trawling in the coastal vicinity is banned, but derogations are allowed to Member States in the same logic as the previous one. The impacts on birds, cetaceans, turtles, seals and sharks are reasonably addressed, with seemingly appropriate measures.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament and the Council have agreed to transpose into European Union law a number of recommendations of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean setting out an appropriate framework for multilateral cooperation to promote the development, conservation, rational management and best exploitation of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea at levels considered sustainable and at low risk of depletion. As regards the question of how to grant derogations concerning the collection and minimum lower diameter of red coral colonies, the European Parliament has succeeded in proposing a compromise text which states that Member States will submit joint recommendations within 3 years, accompanied by detailed information on the national governance framework.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this recommendation with the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999. 1343/2011 on certain provisions on fisheries in the area of the GIAM Agreement (General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean), because the protection of marine fauna requires the application of European provisions, in particular for the collection of red corals by the necessary means and in certain areas.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Regulation (EU) No 1343/2011 had to be amended to incorporate conservation and control measures adopted by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM). Measures include provisions for the sustainable exploitation of red coral, the mitigation of incidental captures of seabirds, sea turtles, monk seals and cetaceans, the protection of sharks and rays, and the extension of some technical measures to the Black Sea as well as management measures for fisheries exploiting small pelagic stocks in the Adriatic Sea.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the agreement between the European Parliament and the Council to transpose into EU law the recommendation of the Agreement establishing a General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean, which provides an appropriate framework for multilateral cooperation to promote sustainable development, protection, rational management and best possible use of the living marine resources of the Mediterranean and the Black Sea with a low risk of collapse. I consider it important to point out that, on the subject of fishing gear and fishing gear used for the collection of red noble coral, the co-legislators agree that the use of underwater remotely controlled vehicles for the monitoring and tracing of red coral should continue to be permitted in waters under the jurisdiction of the Member States, provided that such vehicles should not be equipped with movable arms or any other accessories suitable for the slaughter and collection of red coral.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour considering that the European Parliament and the Council agreed on the transposition into EU law of a number of recommendations made by the General Committee on Fisheries of the Mediterranean ('the CGPM Agreement'), which establishes an appropriate framework for multilateral cooperation in order to promote the development, conservation, rational management and better use of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea , at levels considered sustainable and at low risk of depletion.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position with a view to adopting a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on certain provisions for fisheries in the area of application of the GFCM Agreement because I consider it important that the recommendations and suggestions of the GFCM be incorporated into Community law. The General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean has an important role to play in cooperation between countries in the development, conservation and sustainable use of Mediterranean and Black Sea marine resources. These recommendations cover important issues, such as sustainable red coral fishing, the incidental capture of turtles, seabirds, seals and cetaceans, and the exploitation of small pelagic stocks. I agree with the approach taken by the rapporteur during the negotiations with the other institutions with regard to the exceptional nature of the derogations granted, which do not constitute a legislative precedent and may be modified in the event of certain risks. These derogations, if granted by individual States, will in fact be closely monitored by the European Commission and Parliament.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I welcome the adoption of the report 'Rules for fisheries in the GfCM Convention Area (General Commission for Fisheries in the Mediterranean),' as it provides an important basis for parts of the blue economy in this region.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. In the context of new rules for fisheries, it is also important for the future to ensure the careful and sustainable management of our seas. Only in this way can future generations live and benefit from the richness of the seas. An important element in achieving this objective is the use of proper fishing nets. At the same time, the competitiveness of our local fishermen must be maintained.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report given Regulation (EU) No 1343/2011 is to be amended to incorporate conservation and control measures adopted by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean. Measures include provisions for the sustainable exploitation of red coral, the mitigation of incidental captures of seabirds, sea turtles, monk seals and cetaceans, the protection of sharks and rays, as well as the extension of some technical measures to the Black Sea and management measures for fisheries exploiting small pelagic stocks in the Adriatic Sea.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The aim of this regulation is to transfer into EU law a number of recommendations adopted by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean Agreement area. These measures include the sustainable exploitation of red coral, the reduction of incidental catches (seabirds, sea turtles and seals), encouragement of a high level of protection from fishing activities for sharks and rays. These measures can only be viewed as a positive step and therefore I welcome this agreement.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the fisheries provisions in the gfcm agreement area. These provisions ensure an appropriate framework for multilateral cooperation to promote the development, conservation, management and better use of marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. Derogations must be granted, which I would like to stress are exceptional in nature, for the use of trawls and sulk nets in the Black Sea. I hope that Those Member States which do not have a national framework will be able to initiate one in accordance with the conditions of the regulation under consideration.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this project is to identify technical measures that will preserve fisheries resources while safeguarding the legitimate interests of fishermen. The first problem raised by this project was the request of the Member States bordering the Black Sea to be able to continue using trawls and gillnets. This request has been the subject of a compromise: it will therefore be allowed, on an exceptional basis, to use these devices in the coastal area of the Black Sea.  The second problem was raised by some states, including Spain, which requested exemptions to continue harvesting red coral, an endangered species. Again, a compromise has been reached since the States that have established or will establish a national management framework in the next three years will be able to continue to exploit the red coral. In the event of a danger to this species, the Commission will intervene to request changes to these national management frameworks. Similarly, the use of remotely controlled underwater vehicles (ROVs) for red coral observation and prospecting may continue, provided they are not used to cut or harvest it. These waivers will expire on December 31, 2015.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report because we do not agree to introduce exceptions to the CGPM Agreement, aimed at allowing trawling in the Black Sea. Despite express limitations in the Agreement for the Whole Mediterranean, this concession to the Member States on the Black Sea coast is a serious detriment to the ecosystems of the seabed and we believe that, from the European institutions, we should strive to protect them rather than provide third parties with their deterioration.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, alongside my colleagues in the S&D Group, voted in favour of this report. Although the UK is not directly affected by this proposal the agreement contains a number of good conservation measures for the Mediterranean particularly aimed at reducing unintended catches, as well as the extension of some technical measures to the Black Sea and management measures for fisheries exploiting stocks in the Adriatic Sea, thus reducing overfishing.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for these provisions for fishing in the GFCM (General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean) Agreement area because the provisions in Article 15a, to be inserted in Regulation (EU) No 1343/2011, regarding derogations from the prohibition on the use of certain gear in the coastal waters of the Black Sea, are of an exceptional nature. We have to take into account the prevailing situation in the region, where Member States have put in place measures to allow for the use of the gear concerned in accordance with relevant recommendations from the GFCM.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report as it promotes responsible conservation measures in regard to the seas and its inhabitants. The report aims to ensure the mitigation of incidental catches of seabirds, sea turtles, monk seals and cetaceans in fishing activities and also ensures a high level of protection from fishing activities with regard to sharks and rays, and in particular to the shark and ray species listed as endangered or threatened. It also helps assist in the sustainable exploitation of red coral and the sustainable development of small pelagic stocks in the Adriatic Sea.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading in order to adopt a regulation by Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 2013/2013; 1343/2011 on certain provisions for fishing in the area of the GFCM Agreement, on the grounds that I consider that exceptions to the rules are necessary and acceptable in some and limited cases for technical and natural reasons, such as in the case of coastal trading in the Black Sea and coral harvesting.  I therefore support that exceptions to the prohibition of traising in the Black Sea are the responsibility of the Member States under the supervision of the Commission. However, any exception, like all other activities, must comply with the principles of promoting development, conservation, rational management and protection of marine resources and ecosystems.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The draft of this text is the definition of technical measures that will both preserve fisheries resources and look after the interests of fishermen.  The first point raised by this project was the request of the Black Sea Coastal Member States to be able to continue using trawls and gillnets. This request is the subject of a compromise: it will therefore be allowed, on an exceptional basis, to use these trawls along the coast of the Black Sea. The second point was raised by several states, including Spain, which requested exemptions to continue harvesting red coral, a protected species. This request is also the subject of a compromise: States that have established or will establish a national management framework in the next three years will be able to continue to exploit red coral. In the event of a danger to this species, the Commission will then intervene to request changes to these national management frameworks. Also, the use of remote-controlled underwater vehicles for red coral exploration may continue, provided they are not used to cut and harvest it. These waivers will expire at the end of 2015.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Gabriel Mato's report, which aims to transpose into European law the measures adopted since 2011 by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean. The aim of this regional organisation is to promote the rational management of marine resources and it has adopted binding measures, hithert covered by European law, to reduce accidental catches and protect certain species. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the agreement, as it contains a number of preferable conservation measures for the Mediterranean, particularly aimed at reducing unintended catches, and thus reducing overfishing.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I have decided to give a favourable opinion to this draft resolution. The granting of derogations on fishing methods to countries bordering the Black Sea is justified by the diversity of its basin in relation to the Mediterranean, which discourages fishing techniques other than towing in coastal areas. In particular, the draft resolution in question aims to authorise a limited number of vessels to exceptionally use trawls within the Black Sea coastal zone. I think it is appropriate here to point out the efforts of this Parliament to protect red coral in the coastal areas of the Black Sea, which have been included in this measure by compromise.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. Like the other Members of the National Front, I am, like the other Members of the National Front, generally in favour of the fisheries provisions in the area covered by the agreement of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean. These technical measures are the result of a compromise between the European institutions and the Member States. The idea is as often to find a balance between the protection of the marine environment and the interest of fishermen.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. Regulation (EU) No 1343/2011 on certain provisions applicable to fishing in the area of the CGPM Agreement is updated, incorporating into EU law the obligations arising from the conservation and control measures adopted by the General Commission on Mediterranean Fisheries (CGPM) between 2011 and 2014. It is therefore a legislative dossier of ordinary procedure, of which it should be noted that it has been dealt with with a high degree of consensus since, in establishing its position, the Council took full account of the Commission's proposal and the Position of the European Parliament at first reading, reflecting the agreements reached in the compromise amendments in the draft Recommendation which was submitted for consideration in the last Committee on Fisheries of 23 September and has now been submitted for plenary approval.   For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This Recommendation of the European Parliament for the second reading on the Council's position on the amendment of the Regulation on the provisions applicable to fishing in the area of the CGPM Agreement (General Committee on Fisheries of the Mediterranean) has been adopted without a vote by Parliament. However, there are certain modifications that should be highlighted. The Council's position is less ambitious than the initial proposal, especially due to insufficient weighting of resource conservation criteria. It allows the granting of derogations to Member States under the CGPM proposals, provided that they have an appropriate national management framework with a well-defined fishing permit scheme and space-time closure measures suitable for the limited use of some red coral colonies. Such exemptions may be corrected by the Commission if the cases are not confirmed. A minimum catch depth is also established, minimum dimensions are defined for them and the use of remote-controlled vehicles – except in very particular circumstances – and trawling in coastal areas are prohibited, but also allowing derogations from Member States.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. This report aims to reach agreement between the EP, the Council and the General Committee on Mediterranean Fisheries on the matters discussed below.  As regards the prohibition of coastal trawling in the Black Sea, Parliament accepted that this matter should be managed at Member State level, while maintaining the Commission's right of control.  The aim is to authorise a limited number of vessels to exceptionally use trawls in the coastal waters of the Black Sea. On the other hand, from 31 December 2015 the authorisations granted to Member States to use remote-controlled underwater vehicles for the purpose of observation and prospecting of red coral shall expire, unless Member States demonstrate through scientific studies that the use of such vehicles will not have negative consequences for the sustainable exploitation of red coral. I consider this report to be very useful in generating multilateral cooperation that promotes the development, conservation, rational management and better use of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The Parliament and the Council agreed measures to ensure an appropriate framework for multilateral cooperation in promoting development, conservation, rational governance and making the best use of natural flora and fauna in the Mediterranean and Black Seas. The main obstacle arises when choosing legal mechanisms that would allow certain derogations to Member States, in particular on the issue of red coral.  I supported Representative Gabriel Mato's recommendation because, among other things, it highlights the need for additional control and regulation due to the risk of endangering precious coral, which is extracted annually from the Mediterranean Sea by up to 20 tonnes, but also by other endangered riches. In Croatia, the extraction of red coral requires a permit, i.e. a concession that is no longer issued by the Ministry of Environmental Protection.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Fishing and related activities are one of the oldest and most traditional activities both in Europe and worldwide, wherever there is or has been a way out to the world's ocean. Given that several species of marine animals are under threat today, including in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea, while an absolute majority of Europeans regularly consume wealth collected from the seas in one way or another, it is quite clear and logical that a clearly designed legislative system must exist and effectively operate, taking into account the historical, cultural and other characteristics of individual Member States, to regulate the use of marine resources. In order to guarantee citizens' access to marine resources, various types of derogations may be granted periodically to Member States, where this is, of course, economically and morally permissible. The main thing is that it is also fully possible to guarantee in parallel the effective protection of endangered marine species, in accordance with the principles contained in these derogations in the framework of their implementation. I would also like to express my positive attitude to the point made in this draft legislative resolution that 'the provisions set out therein must not be considered or used as a precedent in future legislation'. Given the rather specific and often fragile situation of marine resources in the various regions of Europe, it would not be quite reasonable to use these rules as a precedent: in this area, similar specificities in the extraction of marine resources would need to be looked at on a case-by-case basis. The reason is quite simple: if we do not take care of nature ourselves, who will do it for us?

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstain from voting on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999. It is therefore necessary to amend Regulation (EC) No 1343/2011 on certain provisions on fisheries in the area of the AGREEMENT of the GEM (General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean) because it is not complete and substantiated.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As Council’s first reading position is in conformity with the agreement reached in the trilogues, I voted to accept it without further amendments.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text. This text, which is the result of negotiations between the European institutions, which wish to protect the environment, and the Member States, which wish to defend the interests of their fishermen, sets out technical measures that will preserve fisheries resources in the Mediterranean.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The FPÖ is committed to promoting the development, conservation, rational management and optimal use of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and Black Seas to a scale that is considered sustainable and where there is a low risk of stock collapse.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. At first reading, Parliament adopted an ambitious text aimed at tightening the conditions for red coral fishing and small pelagic fishing for their preservation. And also to prevent the accidental capture of seabirds, sea turtles, seals, cetaceans and protected rays and sharks. But, following the trilogue, the Council has severely weakened the text. For example, the harvesting of red coral at a depth of more than 50 metres, which is theoretically prohibited, is now permitted by numerous exemptions. I am voting against this text, which dutifully de-escalates any ecological progress.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Parliament's recommendation for the adoption of a Regulation amending Regulation (EU) No 1343/2001 on certain provisions applicable to fisheries in the area of the Agreement of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean. This is an appropriate framework for cooperation between the parties in order to promote the conservation and rational management of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and Black Sea. As the rapporteur points out, certain Member States which have a defined national framework may maintain them, but where the Commission considers that a particular national framework does not comply with the conditions laid down in the Regulation, it may request the amendment of the regulation.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean recommendations offer increased levels of regulatory protection without burdening the fishing industries of the countries involved – many of the measures already being in place at national level.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of  amending Regulation (EU) No 1343/2011 to incorporate conservation and control measures adopted by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM). Measures include provisions for the sustainable exploitation of red coral, the mitigation of incidental captures of seabirds, sea turtles, monk seals and cetaceans, the protection of sharks and rays, and the extension of some technical measures to the Black Sea, as well as management measures for fisheries exploiting small pelagic stocks in the Adriatic Sea.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The General Committee on Mediterranean Fisheries (GFCM) aims to promote the development, conservation and best use of living marine resources in the Mediterranean Sea and the Black Sea, agreeing the European Parliament and the Council with the transposition of the various recommendations made by the GFCM. Having already adopted the motion for a resolution, the European Parliament has achieved its proposed objectives in that the GFCM Agreement respects its prerogatives, corresponding to sufficient protection regulation applicable to fishing in the corresponding area.  I am in favour of the recommendation for second reading, because the adoption of such measures implies the adoption of sufficient levels of sustainability to protect it from marine resources and takes into account the measures that are already being implemented at national level by Member States.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this recommendation is to define technical provisions to preserve fisheries resources in the context of overfishing and pollution in the Mediterranean, while at the same time sparing the interest of fishermen. The primary concern is therefore the exceptional authorisation to use these devices in the Black Sea coastal zone, but these exemptions could not set a precedent in any future legal act. The second concern is that some States, including Spain, have requested exemptions to continue harvesting red coral, an endangered species, but they must submit joint recommendations within three years, accompanied by a national management framework. I voted for this text because I believe that I am trying to find an acceptable balance between protecting the marine environment and the interests of fishermen.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the UK is not directly affected by this proposal, the agreement contains a number of preferable conservation measures for the Mediterranean – particularly aimed at reducing unintended catches, thus reducing overfishing.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on fisheries provisions in the area covered by the agreement of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (CGPM). The aim is to transpose into EU law the decisions adopted by this Commission which aim to promote the development, conservation, rational management and optimal use of living marine resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean, the Black Sea and intermediate waters. I have therefore supported the technical measures planned by this Commission to ensure the sustainable exploitation of red coral, the reduction of accidental catches of seabirds, sea turtles and cetaceans, and the conservation of monk seals, sharks and rays in the area covered by this agreement.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report, which will provide an appropriate framework for multilateral cooperation to promote the development, conservation, rational management and best utilisation of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea at levels which are considered sustainable and at low risk of collapse.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported my colleague's report in the Committee on Fisheries in my vote today, because this is a good report that has been negotiated with the Council representatives for a long period of time, thus having the opportunity to support my amendments during the procedure. The final form of these negotiations, the document voted on today, is one that meets the needs of the General Commission for Fisheries in the Mediterranean for the purpose of carrying out the work. It is also very important that this document also contains an exceptional derogation for Romania in the use of trawls and gilles in fishing activities in the Black Sea, a regulation that would have had a major negative impact on the Romanian industry. This derogation was possible because the main reasons for which the use of trawls and gilles should be restricted, although it applies to the Mediterranean Sea, do not apply to the Black Sea.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The legislative resolution on the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) will give a green light to the Council position at first reading, without making any changes. Some recommendations from the GFCM have been taken over in part by the Council. They concern the environmental protection of red coral, and tackling incidental catches of seabirds, sharks and seals. The restrictions remain in place on paper, but the Council has demanded that Member States themselves can grant derogations to their fishermen. Remotely operated underwater vehicles (ROVs) will be prohibited from harvesting red coral, environmental protection will be stepped up for certain species, and Member States will be at liberty to grant derogations for fishermen. While I support the aforementioned proposals, approval of the Council position had already been given by the Committee on Fisheries, and consequently the plenary did not vote on this matter.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report on the Council's position with regard to the adoption of the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1343/2011 on the rules for fisheries in the Convention Area of the GFCM (General Commission for Fisheries in the Mediterranean) refers to the granting of exemptions for the use of trawls and actnets in the Black Sea. A derogation goes against the principle of sustainable fishing. That is why I would have voted against the report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. In order to make any exceptions in the Black Sea region, it is important to ensure that it does not degrade the marine environment.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I approved the recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to adopting a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1343/2011 on certain provisions for fisheries in the area of application of the GFCM (General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean) Agreement. I welcome the agreement reached by the European Parliament and the Council on the transposition into Union law of numerous recommendations made by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean, which guarantees an appropriate framework for multilateral cooperation aimed at promoting the development, conservation, rational management and better use of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea at levels considered sustainable and at low risk of exhaustion. In the meantime, it should be remembered that Member States that already have national frameworks can maintain them and Member States wishing to set up national frameworks can do so provisionally, provided that there is already an adequate national management framework.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Over recent years, the fishing sector has been much debated that directly affects the lives of many people and families. I believe that this report will benefit small fishermen engaged in bluefish farming and will greatly contribute to the protection of the overall marine and coastal ecosystem, and that is why I support it. The fisheries sector is a significant exporter, food producer and sector that employs workers 12 months of the year.  It is no coincidence that the European Union has a special fisheries fund, as it is a food-producing branch, without which people's lives would not be possible. Croatia is also a maritime country with many fishermen for whom fishing, which has its long tradition in Croatia, is much more than just work and employment, so fishing deserves special care and care from the EU in order to prevent the adoption of measures that would be at the expense of the fishing sector. I am committed to implementing these measures that are important, not only for fisheries, but also contain some protective ecological lines that are essential for the protection of the Mediterranean and Adriatic Seas that we must preserve.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This recommendation aims to define technical provisions to preserve fisheries resources in the context of overfishing and pollution in the Mediterranean, while at the same time sparing the interest of fishermen. The first concern is therefore that it is permissible, on an exceptional basis, to use these devices in the Black Sea coastal zone, but these exemptions could not set a precedent in any future legal act. The second concern is that some States, including Spain, have requested exemptions to continue harvesting red coral, an endangered species, but they must submit joint recommendations within three years, accompanied by a national management framework. I voted for this text because I believe that it is trying to strike an acceptable balance between protecting the marine environment and the interests of fishermen.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. In line with the recommendations of the General Fisheries Commission of the Mediterranean (GFCM), the Council and the European Parliament approved the introduction of certain amendments to existing EU law, in order to improve the framework of multilateral cooperation to promote sustainable development, conservation, rational governance and optimal use of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. For example, the harvesting of red corals is prohibited at a depth of less than 50 meters, and the use of remotely operated underwater vehicles for coral harvesting is prohibited, but not for observing and exploring corals.  In its additional statement, Parliament expressed its agreement with the agreement exempting certain Member States from the provision prohibiting the use of certain equipment in the coastal waters of the Black Sea, as they use the equipment concerned in accordance with the recommendations of the General Commission, according to predetermined and approved national frameworks. In doing so, the Commission reserves the right to control the national frameworks regulated by the Member States themselves.  Since the Republic of Croatia is one of the ten Member States that are contracting parties to the GFCM Agreement, I consider the transposition of the relevant provisions and recommendations of the GFCM to be of utmost importance in order to ensure their unique and effective application throughout the European Union, while allowing Croatia some autonomy in the management of marine goods in the Adriatic Sea.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Parliament has introduced provisions concerning the derogation from the prohibition on the use of certain equipment in the coastal waters of the Black Sea. They take into account the current situation in the region where Member States have put in place measures to allow the use of the equipment concerned in accordance with the relevant GFCM recommendations.  The European Parliament and the Council have agreed several recommendations from the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (the 'GFCM Agreement') which provides an appropriate framework for multilateral cooperation to promote development, conservation, rational governance and make the best use of the living richness of the seas in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea at levels considered sustainable and at low risk of collapse.  The main problem faced by legislators is the choice of legal mechanisms used in requirements for Member States, in particular as regards the use of traxa in the Black Sea and the harvesting of red coral.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The recommendation provides for derogations from the ban on inshore trawling in the Black Sea, in particular as regards the use of trawls and sulk nets, the minimum base diameter of colonies, tools and red coral harvesting devices. I voted in favour of this recommendation because I believe that the provisions of Article 15a to be included in Regulation (EU) No 1343/2011, concerning derogations from the ban on the use of certain gears in black sea coastal waters, are of a completely exceptional nature. They shall take account of the situation in the region, where Member States have already put in place measures to allow the use of the gear in question in accordance with the relevant recommendations of the GFCM (General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean).

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has approved the text on fisheries provisions in the area covered by the agreement of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (CGPM). I have spoken in favour of this text. It transposes the measures adopted by the CGPM into EU law and strengthens cooperation between the European Commission and the CGPM.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. Established in 1949, the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) provides an appropriate framework for multilateral cooperation in order to promote the development, conservation, rational management and better use of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea, at levels considered sustainable and at low risk of rupture. In its annual sessions in 2011, 2012 and 2013, the GFCM adopted a set of recommendations for the sustainable exploitation of red coral, the reduction of occasional catches of seabirds, sea turtles and cetaceans, the conservation of monk seals, sharks and rays in the GFCM Agreement area, as well as the sustainable development of small pelagics in the Adriatic Sea. Following the adoption of Parliament's position at first reading on 13 January 2015, formal negotiations began with a view to rapidly obtaining a second reading agreement for the incorporation of those measures into Regulation (EU) No 1343/2011. After two rounds of trilogue, an agreement has been reached between Parliament and the Council, and it is now important, following the recommendation of the PECH committee to adopt the Council's position at first reading, without amendments. I voted in favour.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. Regulation (EU) No 1343/2011 on certain provisions applicable to fishing in the area of the CGPM Agreement is updated, incorporating into EU law the obligations arising from the conservation and control measures adopted by the General Commission on Mediterranean Fisheries (CGPM) between 2011 and 2014. It should be noted that it has been dealt with with a high degree of consensus since, in establishing its position, the Council took full account of the Commission's proposal and the position of the European Parliament at first reading, reflecting the agreements reached in the compromise amendments in the draft Recommendation which was submitted for consideration in the last Committee on Fisheries of 23 September and has now been submitted for plenary approval.   He has therefore received my favourable vote.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Following the adoption of the European Parliament's (EP) first reading position in plenary session on 13 January 2015, informal negotiations began with the Latvian Presidency with a view to reaching an early agreement at second reading. After two rounds of trilogue, the EP and the Council reached an agreement on this issue in March 2015. The text of the agreement was presented to the EP Fisheries Committee for a vote of approval in May 2015 and was approved by a very large majority. Today's plenary session of the European Parliament definitively approved the Council's position at first reading without any amendments.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which transposes into EU law measures adopted by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (CGPM) during the 2011, 2012 and 2013 sessions.  The CGPM was established in 1949. It is a regional fisheries management organisation whose main objectives are the promotion of fisheries, conservation, rational management and optimal use of living marine resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean, the Black Sea and intermediate waters. In 2011, 2012 and 2013, the CGPM adopted a series of measures to ensure the sustainable exploitation of red coral, the reduction of accidental catches of seabirds, sea turtles, monk seals and cetaceans during fishing activities, a high level of protection of sharks and rays from fishing activities and the sustainable development of small pelagics in the Adriatic Sea.  EU Regulation 343/2011 provides for certain fishing provisions in the area covered by the CGPM agreement and the aim here is to amend this regulation to include these recommendations of the CGPM.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report because we do not agree to introduce exceptions to the CGPM Agreement, aimed at allowing trawling in the Black Sea. Despite express limitations in the Agreement for the Whole Mediterranean, this concession to the Member States on the Black Sea coast is a serious detriment to the ecosystems of the seabed and we believe that, from the European institutions, we should strive to protect them rather than provide third parties with their deterioration.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This Recommendation of the European Parliament for the second reading on the Council's position on the amendment of the Regulation on the provisions applicable to fishing in the area of the CGPM Agreement (General Committee on Fisheries of the Mediterranean) has been adopted without a vote by Parliament. However, there are certain modifications that should be highlighted. The Council's position is less ambitious than the initial proposal, especially due to insufficient weighting of resource conservation criteria. It allows the granting of derogations to Member States under the CGPM proposals, provided that they have an appropriate national management framework with a well-defined fishing permit scheme and space-time closure measures suitable for the limited use of some red coral colonies. Such exemptions may be corrected by the Commission if the cases are not confirmed. A minimum catch depth is also established, minimum dimensions are defined for them and the use of remote-controlled vehicles – except in very particular circumstances – and trawling in coastal areas are prohibited, but also allowing derogations from Member States.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal aims to transpose into Union law a series of recommendations made by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM), which ensures an appropriate framework for multilateral cooperation aimed at promoting the development, conservation and sustainable management of fishery resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. I voted in favour of the agreement reached because I believe that some of the issues that exist at first reading were resolved during the negotiations.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. In the case of Parliament's negotiating position, in which only details are changed on the operation of net fishing in the Black Sea, I have decided to contribute to the continuation of negotiations with the Council and the Commission at trilogue level.  Since it is not the close of negotiations, but the negotiating mandate for second reading, there was no formal vote.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ There was no vote on this recommendation, which shows the contempt this political project has for democracy.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this legislation because, although the UK is not directly affected by this legislative proposal, the agreement introduces several measures aimed at reducing unintended catches and overfishing in the Mediterranean, and such issues do not have national boundaries and have knock—on effects all over the world. This represents a great move towards a sustainable fisheries policy in the European Union.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the establishment of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM), the European Union has acceded to the agreement concluded there which provides a framework for multilateral cooperation aimed at promoting the development, conservation, rational management and better use of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea at sustainable levels. Parliament has now discussed the amendment of Regulation 1343/2011 amending certain provisions for fisheries in the area of application by the GFCM agreement previously adopted by virtue of accession to the GFCM. The amendments are intended to incorporate into European legislation the recent conservation and control measures adopted by the GFCM, including measures for the sustainable exploitation of red coral and for the accidental capture of seabirds, turtles, seals and cetaceans, but also some exceptional derogations for trawling in the Black Sea. On this point, we have obtained that the derogation on the ban on trawling cannot set a precedent in future legislative acts. In addition, the Commission will ensure that the risks arising from the derogations do not materialise. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the report and proposals by the General Fisheries Commission in the Mediterranean, as it provides an appropriate framework for multilateral cooperation to promote development, conservation, rational governance and make the best use of the living richness of the sea in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. I also agree with the decision to compromise on how to approve harvest deviations and the minimum basal diameter of the red coral colony, for all Member States to submit their proposals within 3 years.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. Although the UK is not directly affected by this proposal, the agreement contains a number of preferable conservation measures for the Mediterranean – particularly aimed at reducing unintended catches, and thus reducing overfishing.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The General Fisheries Commission of the Mediterranean (GFCM) was established in 1949 and its main objectives are to promote development, conservation, rational management and best exploitation of living marine resources and the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean, the Black Sea and neighbouring seas.  Over the last five years, the GFCM has adopted a number of technical measures to sustainably exploit red coral, reduce accidental catches of seabirds, sea turtles and whales, and preserve bears, sharks and stingrays in the GFCM Agreement area. Such measures go beyond the protection already provided at EU level for these species by the Habitats directive and other Union acts, and include certain recording and reporting obligations for economic operators and Member States.  I support the Council's position at first reading in order to adopt the Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 2020/2013. 1343/2011 on certain provisions for fishing in the area of the GFCM Agreement (General Fisheries Commission of the Mediterranean), as I consider that the adoption of this Regulation will ensure that the relevant GFCM measures are transposed into Union law without exceeding what is necessary to achieve the objective desired.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal as it mainly brings about changes of a technical nature.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation for second reading on certain fisheries provisions in the Agreement area of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean. It is a vote on the Council's position, which was also drawn up by the Latvian Presidency and coordinated in the trialogue.  Despite the fact that we are working through a number of measures for economic and technological development, jobs and economic growth, this growth must be sustainable. In addition to resource efficiency and carbon reduction, we must also strive for our marine ecosystem.  I therefore voted in favour of the recommendation, as by transposing the GFCM recommendations in the Mediterranean into the EU acquis, we will provide an appropriate framework for multilateral cooperation to promote the development, conservation, sound management and best exploitation of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The protection of marine fauna requires the application of European provisions, in particular for the collection of red corals by the necessary means and in certain areas.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Fishing in the Mediterranean is one of the significant economic activities of the European Union. The regulation of this activity is the main task of the General Commission for Fisheries in the Mediterranean, in accordance with the Agreement adopted in 2011. These regulations should now be amended to incorporate a number of conservation and control measures on marine habitat, including the protection of certain species of birds, turtles, seals, cetaceans, sharks. In particular, the use of trawls and gilles in Fishing activities in the Black Sea, which is included in the tasks of the General Commission, the minimum basal diameter of colonies, fishing gear and devices, and the harvesting of red coral, are concerned. However, a number of derogations on trawling for a limited number of vessels and the use of remote-controlled underwater vehicles in the coastal areas of the Black Sea, unlike in the Mediterranean Sea, where this is not permitted, were also accepted in the text adopted by the Commission. However, these derogations will not act as a precedent for other situations, being closely monitored by the General Commission. The current amendment is a necessary measure to bring regulations in this area up to date.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported the fisheries provisions in the area covered by the agreement of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (CGPM), which provides an appropriate framework for multilateral cooperation to promote the development, conservation, rational management and optimal use of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and Black Sea at levels considered sustainable and at low risk of depletion. We accept that derogations from the ban on trawling in the Black Sea should be managed by the Member States with the Commission's say, but they do not set a precedent in any future legal act.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the approval of this resolution which seeks to amend Regulation (EU) No 1343/2011 on certain provisions for fishing in the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) Agreement area. In adopting it, Parliament and the Council agreed on the transposition into EU law of several recommendations made by the GFCM Agreement. This will provide an appropriate framework for multilateral cooperation, focused on promoting the development, conservation, rational management and best utilisation of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea at sustainable levels and at low risk of collapse. The resolution also includes a statement on granting derogations to Member States for the use of trawl nets and gill-net fisheries in the Black Sea.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. Recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010 of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of the european community and the european union I supported it as I believe that by transposing the GFCM recommendations into the Union acquis, we will provide an appropriate framework for multilateral cooperation to promote the development, conservation, efficient management and best exploitation of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea to the extent that it is considered sustainable and does not pose a risk to their depletion.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report because we do not agree to introduce exceptions to the CGPM Agreement, aimed at allowing trawling in the Black Sea. Despite express limitations in the Agreement for the Whole Mediterranean, this concession to the Member States on the Black Sea coast is a serious detriment to the ecosystems of the seabed and we believe that, from the European institutions, we should strive to protect them rather than provide third parties with their deterioration.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The technical measures presented in this text are the result of a simple compromise between the European institutions and the Member States, the idea being - as often - to find a balance between protecting the marine environment and the interests of fishermen.  I vote for this text.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Since the Council's position at first reading is the same as that reached in the trialireated consultation, the rapporteur for the report convinced the Committee to adopt it without further amendments.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report because we do not agree to introduce exceptions to the CGPM Agreement, aimed at allowing trawling in the Black Sea. Despite express limitations in the Agreement for the Whole Mediterranean, this concession to the Member States on the Black Sea coast is a serious detriment to the ecosystems of the seabed and we believe that, from the European institutions, we should strive to protect them rather than provide third parties with their deterioration.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on provisions for fishing in the GFCM (General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean) Agreement area. The text outlines the agreement on the transposition into the Union law of several recommendations made by the GFCM, which provide an appropriate framework for multilateral cooperation to promote the development, conservation, rational management and best utilisation of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea at levels which are considered sustainable and at low risk of collapse. A good step forward was the compromise, accepted by all the EU institutions, in relation to the issue of how to grant derogations on the harvesting and the minimum basal diameter of colonies of red coral. The agreement also provides that, in the meantime, Member States which already have national frameworks in place can maintain them, and those who wish to set up national frameworks they can do so provisionally, provided that an appropriate national management framework is in place.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. After the agreement reached in the tripartite dialogues, the rapporteur believes that the additional provisions applicable to fisheries in the CGPM area have a sufficient level of protection. Taking into account further that the agreement deals with measures which have already been transposed by the Member States, I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This Recommendation of the European Parliament for the second reading on the Council's position on the amendment of the Regulation on the provisions applicable to fishing in the area of the CGPM Agreement (General Committee on Fisheries of the Mediterranean) has been adopted without a vote by Parliament. However, there are certain modifications that should be highlighted. The Council's position is less ambitious than the initial proposal, especially due to insufficient weighting of resource conservation criteria. It allows the granting of derogations to Member States under the CGPM proposals, provided that they have an appropriate national management framework with a well-defined fishing permit scheme and space-time closure measures suitable for the limited use of some red coral colonies. Such exemptions may be corrected by the Commission if the cases are not confirmed. A minimum catch depth is also established, minimum dimensions are defined for them and the use of remote-controlled vehicles – except in very particular circumstances – and trawling in coastal areas are prohibited, but also allowing derogations from Member States.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal allows derogations from member states within the scope of gfcm proposals, provided that they have an appropriate national management framework with a well-defined fishing authorisation scheme and waste time-space measures suitable for the limited exploitation of some red coral colonies. These derogations may be corrected by the committee if the premises do not take the case. Sets a minimum depth for capture. The capture is allowed only with hammer in scuba diving. It also sets minimum catch dimensions and prohibits the use of rovs except in very particular circumstances, including investigation. It prohibits trawling in the vicinity of the coastal areas but allows derogations from Member States in the same logic as the previous one.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I am committed to promoting the development, conservation, rational management and optimal use of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and The Black Sea to a scale that is considered sustainable and where there is a low risk of stock collapse.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this Recommendation of the European Parliament because I am convinced that it is necessary to protect the marine ecosystem through various measures concerning, among other things, the sustainable exploitation of red coral, the reduction of accidental catches of birds and sea turtles and the protection of other species that inhabit our seas. I hope that the regulation on fisheries in the areas implementing the GFCM (General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean) agreement will be amended as soon as possible, taking these recommendations into account.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the Council's position with a view to the adoption of the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1343/2011 on rules for fisheries in the Convention Area of the GFCM (General Commission for Fisheries in the Mediterranean). The proposal includes technical measures for the sustainable use of red corals, the reduction of unintentionally caught red corals, the unintentional capture of seabirds, sea turtles, whales and the conservation of monk seals, sharks and rays in the area of the GFCM agreement. The report also implements measures for fisheries of small oceanic stocks in the Adriatic Sea. We accept that the Member States concerned grant the derogations in the event of danger, on condition that this agreement does not serve as a model for any future actions.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal allows derogations from Member States, within the scope of the proposals of the GFCM Agreement, provided that they have an appropriate national management framework with a well-defined fishing authorisation scheme and time-centred measures suitable for the limited exploitation of some red coral colonies. These derogations may be corrected by the European Commission if the premises do not occur. A minimum depth is set for capture - the capture is allowed only with hammer in scuba diving and minimum capture dimensions are defined. On the other hand, trawling in the vicinity of the coastal is prohibited, but derogations are allowed from Member States, in the same logic as the previous one. They are generally positive measures.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. Today, the European Parliament voted on a report on the use of genetically modified food and feed (GMOs). The Commission's proposal to allow individual Member States to ban GMOs was rejected by a broadly unanimous Committee on the Environment, Transport and Rural Development, Common Relations and Rural Development ( Firstly, the proposal was feared to lead to a relaxation of the internal market and to cause trade-related problems vis-à-vis the outside world. Secondly, the proposal was seen as a way of integrating GMOs into the internal market by the back door. Guided by the precautionary principle and the expectation of clear impact assessments from the Commission, I therefore chose to vote in favour of the committee's decision to reject the proposal.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The marketing of genetically modified food or feed is an issue which naturally concerns and concerns all European citizens. The Commission cannot impose such an important choice on the Member States, each country must be free to introduce or not to introduce food or feed containing or based on GMOs into its territory. To this end, a proposal to amend Regulation 1829/2003 was presented with the introduction of Article 34a, which would have given states the opportunity to ban food or feed containing or based on GMOs without, however, invoking environmental or health reasons which are the subject of exclusive assessment by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). Such a path would, however, have exposed the Member States to legal disputes over obstacles to the free movement of goods. We have tabled amendments aimed at committing the Commission not to authorise new gmo-based food or feed and not to renew the expiring permits until agreement is reached on a new proposal but has, of course, been rejected. For these reasons, I have chosen to abstain in the vote.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. With this vote, the Socialists send a clear signal to the European Commission: the rejection of the proposed legislation, as this would have a negative impact on the EU agricultural sector.  We Socialists miss the European Commission's proposal for greater attention to key aspects such as traceability and legislative coherence between the human and animal feed sectors, as well as a memory of the socio-economic impact of the proposals.  We also have reservations about the actual possibility of implementing this legislation in the single market and on legal aspects; all this without obviousing that, apart from these legal issues, there is a problem of public perception and political order.  That is why we Socialists are voting in favour of the European Commission withdrawing the proposal in the current terms and developing an improved one that echoes the shortcomings identified.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The text submitted by the European Commission under which, in theory, Member States are given the possibility of restricting or prohibiting the use of genetically modified food and feed in their territory is in fact an ambiguous document in which such a prohibition or restriction would be carried out under conditions which, in fact, make its application impossible. For example, a Member State wishing to restrict or prohibit the use of GMOs in its territory would have to put forward grounds other than those linked to risks to human, animal or environmental health; nor could it allege scientific motives, nor grounds which are not 'properly substantiated' and based on 'imperious' reasons and which, in turn, involve proportionate and non-discriminatory measures. For more inri, the Commission's proposal presents other implementation problems, for example the ambiguity of the concept of 'use'. That is why I voted in favour of Parliament's proposal to ask the Commission to withdraw its proposal and submit a new one.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. The Commission's legislative proposal to give Member States the ability to restrict or ban the use of genetically modified food or feed on their territory is unassy.  It amounts to renationalising the market and is therefore at odds with the internal market. This decision would inevitably be challenged by the EU Court of Justice, but also likely by WTO bodies. Moreover, this would probably not prevent commercial diversions and therefore the presence of GMO-derived raw materials in human and animal feed among countries that refuse to import it. It should be remembered that 19 out of 28 states have rejected the cultivation of GMOs on their soil and 59% of citizens consider GMOs to be dangerous. The Commission is flouting democracy and the rights of citizens who are overwhelmingly opposed to GMOs. While it refuses to ban them on European territory, it continually and too easily discards the Member States and takes too much cause for the multinationals holding GMOs.   This game of dupe can no longer be tolerated. That is why I will vote resolutely in the amendment which proposes the rejection of the Commission's proposal.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The use of genetically modified food and feed is a sufficiently sensitive issue, which concerns the health of European citizens.  We are talking about food and feed for which we do not know the long-term effects it can have on our environment and our bodies.  That is why you promised us a comprehensive reform of the way genetically modified organisms are licensed. Unfortunately, however, the proposal before us today not only does not fulfil this objective, but rather creates greater ambiguity and legal uncertainty, especially for countries such as Greece, which has traditionally opposed the use of genetically modified organisms.  You have presented us with a proposal which: •is not accompanied by an impact report • does not protect countries that want to ban genetically modified food and feed from their territory • it is ineffective as it allows Member States to restrict the use, but not the import and trade of these organisms.  That is why we, as the Group of the Party of Socialists and Democrats, have decided to vote against the Commission's proposal. Protecting the health of European citizens is a non-negotiable value for our group.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Together with my colleagues, we believe that the so-called freedom of the Member States is a decoy, with the laws of the internal market and the dynamics of integration still priorities for the Commission. Thus, the conditions imposed for the suspension of the use of such products are drastic and ne limit the possibilities for Member States to protect themselves. The ENL Group has tabled amendments to replace the term "use" with "marketing," which is proving to be broader and more appropriate.  The rapporteur, for his part, proposes to reject the Commission's proposal and calls for a new proposal unconditionally, that is, without framework or requirements previously suggested by the European Parliament, which our group is opposed to. Between these two alternatives to which I am opposed, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ My vote here reflected the uncertainty of the situation surrounding the Commission proposal and to what extent they might be prepared to change it in an amended version. The proposal would make matters better than they are at the moment, but subject to tough criteria which would be very difficult to meet. Unusually, it recognises that some matters should be for member states to determine. Do I, then, vote the proposal down in the hope that the Commission will come up with a better one? Or do I support is because it is less bad than the current situation? Overall, I decided to abstain.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I objected to the provision to allow Member States to choose whether to restrict or ban the sale and use of EU-approved foodstuffs or feeds containing GMOs on their territory. I fear that this legislation will prove unworkable and lead to the reintroduction of border controls between pro- and anti-GMO countries.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the rejection of the Commission document. At first sight, the Commission's proposal was attractive to the Member States. The Commission has proposed to allow Member States to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory, even if these products have been or will be authorised. However, a closer examination of the document has shown that the conditions for the choice of states are very difficult, and that the right to choose would be almost impossible to exercise. And how to ensure border control, what feed or food is transported to the country from a neighbouring country? From April 2015, Member States may be banned from growing GM crops. However, Member States are not yet in a position to prohibit the import and marketing of FOOD and feed. The European Commission's proposal was to expand the opportunities for states. Unfortunately, the test was not successful, the document was rejected because it did not guarantee the right of states to make proper use of the possibility of restricting or prohibiting the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory. The document will have to be improved and taken into account in the position of the European Parliament.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted in favour of the proposal for a revision of the current regulation on the authorisation system for GM food and feed. We believe that each Member State should have the power to opt out and to decide whether to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on its own territory.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I rejected the European Commission's proposal to give Member States the option of banning the use of imported GMOs for human or animal feed. This would lead to a fragmentation of the internal market, and the lack of an impact assessment remains extremely worrying with regard to the consequences of an a la carte authorisation/ban for all of our agriculture and food.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. With this report, the European Commission unanimously brought together political groups against its own proposal. I believe, as do my colleagues in the Committee, that the so-called freedom of the Member States is a decoy, the laws of the internal market and the dynamics of integration are always a priority in the eyes of the Commission. This semi-freedom is clear in the conditions imposed for the suspension of the use of such products: - the period during which Member States must refrain from acting and for the Commission to consider the Member State's request; - the Risk Assessment carried out by the European level; - the "imperative" grounds which must justify the Member State's decision on a fairly limited legal basis.  The rapporteur's proposal was that of a rejection with a request for a new proposal without conditions, and I am therefore opposed to it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not intend to support this report with my vote because I believe that our first duty is to protect the quality productions of our entrepreneurs and the right of our citizens who want to know what ends up in their dishes. I am in favour of compulsory origin labelling that is contrary to GMOs, which are exclusively in the interests of multinationals.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted in favour of the report. Genetically modified organisms (GMOs) are controversial and face strong opposition both in Sweden and in the EU. The Left Party is critical of GMOs and believes that the precautionary principle should be safeguarded in the first place. This was the second time the Commission has put forward a proposal on GMOs, and although the Commission has improved them considerably and given the Member States greater opportunities to say 'no' to GMOs, both the Left Group, the Greens and the Socialist Group agreed that sharper proposals had been needed, as more loopholes remained. That is why I voted in favour of withdrawing the proposal, but also in favour of the resolution at the end.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. On 22 April 2015, the Commission submitted a proposal for a Regulation with a view to amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, in which it suggested allowing Member States to restrict or prohibit, under certain conditions, the use of genetically modified food and feed (GMOs) in their territory after these products had been authorised.  However, the Commission's proposal has not been preceded by an impact assessment of the consequences for the functioning of the internal market and competition from the agricultural sector. In addition, there are reasonable doubts as to their implementation and how Member States using the opt-out clause will, in practice, ensure compliance with such measures in their territory. We therefore consider that the proposal does not guarantee the necessary legal certainty or appropriate instruments for Member States wishing to restrict or legally prohibit the use of GMOs in their territory. That is why I rejected the Commission's proposal and voted in favour of asking the Commission for a new legislative proposal.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposed decision rejecting the proposed regulation, as it is an extremely bad proposal from the Commission which does not take into account reality. The Regulation should be based on a clear analysis of the health, environmental and social consequences of the proposed regulation.  These effects were not presented by the Commission, nor did it have any consequences for European agriculture. The shortage of protein feed without GMO in EU livestock farming is huge. We do not have before us the social effects of potential farm collapses in the EU, nor do we have an assessment of the food market, which would certainly go up if the proposed regulation were adopted in such a handi way. The European agricultural model requires a clear plan for such a twist, cap measures must be drawn up and there must be enough time to transform agriculture. Food security consists of noxious food and a sufficient amount of food at an affordable price.
