The wrong and speedy decisions – without clear preliminary analyses of the profession – would at least make many people not have access to food, as it would become too costly. A hungry man is not nutritionally safe either. Moreover, it would be virtually impossible to implement the regulation, as it would first be very difficult for food and feed to establish a traceability system. The regulation would also not be in line with the EU's free market, as border controls would have to be introduced if its provisions were consistently implemented.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote in plenary confirms what was approved in the ENVI Committee and the AGRI Committee and therefore the rejecting of the Commission's proposal. While it is true that the existing legislation on the marketing authorisation of products containing GMOs needs to be reviewed and that this process needs to be more democratic, the solution to this problem cannot be found in proposals that are likely to be difficult to apply, contradicting principles guaranteed by the Union, such as free movement within the internal market. For these reasons, and given the impracticality of this proposal, we expect the Commission to commit itself to formulating a new proposal that is compatible with the internal market and the EU's international trade obligations, and able to consider the needs of European productions together with the possible consequences for the environment and human health.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Today's vote solves one problem, which is a bad proposal for a GMO food regulation that would be unenforceable and bring chaos to the common market.  Its primary purpose, if Member States had the option of prohibiting the sale of GMO food, would not be fulfilled and therefore I will vote to withdraw it. But the problem of an unfair GMO food approval system remains. Member States will never be able to reach an agreement on this topic and the Commission will therefore continue to have the power to grant sales and use authorisations on its own.  In conclusion, I would like to tell the European Commission that rejecting this proposal for a GMO directive does not reassess them from the obligation to democratise the approval process. This was one of President Juncker's promises, and that is why we want the Commission to come up with a new, better proposal for regulation. It is a topic that matters to our citizens and a promise that is essential to the democratic legitimacy of the European Union.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. The Commission, for whom internal market laws and dynamics are always a priority, has been unanimously agreed by political groups against its own proposal. Member States are placed on day parole, which is attested in particular by the assessment of risk at European level and the compelling reasons that must justify the Member State's decision. The rapporteur proposed rejection with a request for a new proposal without conditions, and therefore I objected.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the Commission's proposal on the use of genetically modified food and feed has several shortcomings that affect its effectiveness. For example, it is difficult to understand how the states that have decided to take advantage of the opt-out for this regulation will be able to enforce it without reintroducing a whole series of controls that would interfere with the functioning of the Union's greatest achievement, the single market.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The rejection in plenary of the Commission's proposal is based on the lack of an impact assessment and the difficulty of implementing it as there are no longer border controls for agricultural products within the EU. However, the issue of genetically modified food cannot fall into oblivion: the drafting of a new text focusing on the process of risk assessment and authorisation of new transgenic varieties at Community level will be useful for debate and preparatory to the refinement of legislation in this area. The risk of the Commission's proposal being inapplicable in practice and the consequent danger of the reintroduction of controls at the Union's internal borders between pro- and anti-GMO countries, seriously damaging the European internal market, highlights the need to further deepen the parliamentary debate and integrated studies on this important issue.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report which amends the regulation governing the possibility for Member States to temporarily restrict or ban the use of food for genetically modified animals. We regret that this freedom of action is too limited. Member States must wait for the Commission's approval before implementing these restrictions. In addition, the grounds for allowing national authorities to initiate this procedure are limited. We are aware that, in the Eyes of the Commission, the laws of the internal market are a priority. MEP Mireille d'Ornano, a member of the Europe of Nations and Freedoms group, tabled an amendment to replace the term "use" with "marketing".

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against because of Parliament's reject of the Commission proposal with which I was in principle in agreement, because: – a Member State, being able to prohibit the use of a GMO feed, must be left free to assume its responsibilities sovereignly to its citizens (breeders in this case); - the present case demonstrates the fallacy of one of the pillars founding the EU: the free movement 'at all costs' of everything and everyone.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission presented on 22 April 2015, together with the Communication on 'Review of the decision-making process on genetically modified organisms', a proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. 1829/2003 as regards the possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed in their territory after these products have been authorised - the option of non-application - opt-out ( COM(2015)0177).  In view of the absence of an impact study, the feasibility of the proposal and the fact that it is contrary to the commitments of 'transparency' and 'better regulation' made by the new Commission and taking into account the long-term consequences of the proposal with regard to the functioning of the internal market in food and feed, as well as the competitiveness of the Union agricultural sector, support the rejection of the Commission's proposal.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. Beyond whether or not GMOs should be authorised in the EU — which is not the subject of debate on this proposal — I reject the Commission's proposal because it is not preceded by an impact assessment of its implications for the functioning of the internal market. The proposal does not guarantee the necessary legal certainty or appropriate instruments for Member States wishing to restrict or legally prohibit the use of GMOs in their territories.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to reject the Commission’s proposal on genetically modified food and feed. I also voted in favour of asking the Commission to submit a new proposal. I felt that the proposal produced by the Commission this time around did not legitimately address the concerns surrounding this topic, not least its impact on and implications for food sovereignty. Such a sensitive proposal, seeking to combine GM food and feed, requires a full impact assessment. Any approval system within the EU would need to be based on an assessment of the impact on conventional and organic farmers, animal and human health as well as the environment. Provision for such an assessment was lacking in this case. For these reasons I felt it necessary to ask the Commission to come up with another proposal.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted in favour of the proposal for a revision of the current regulation on the authorisation system for GM food and feed. We believe that each Member State should have the power to opt out and to decide whether to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on its own territory.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with the rapporteur that the Commission’s proposal should be rejected because it is unclear in terms of the requirements imposed on the Member States that wish to lawfully restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory. I am also concerned that it would most likely have a negative impact on the internal market for food and feed.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I would remind you that 19 out of 28 Member States rejected the culture of GMOs. We have therefore tabled an amendment committing the Commission not to authorise new gmo-based food or feed and not to renew the expiring permits until agreement is reached on a new proposal. Unfortunately, our amendment did not pass, so I abstained in the final vote in order to point out the distance both from the Commission's original proposal and from the solution chosen to send it back to the sender, since I am sure that in this way there will no longer be (at least not immediately) the possibility of handing over the sovereignty of food choices to the Member States.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Giovanni La Via's report, which proposes to reject the Commission's proposal.  The proposal was intended to allow Member States to restrict or ban, under certain conditions, the use of genetically modified foodstuffs on their territory, even after these products have been authorised.  Such a proposal went against the maintenance of a strong internal market and tended to re-create barriers between the 28 Member States. Above all, I regret that this proposal was not based on an assessment of the potential impacts of these measures on the agricultural sector, which depends mainly on the supply of protein from genetically modified sources. For these reasons, this proposal seemed irresponsible to me.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this proposal. While I believe it should be for each Member State to decide if it wishes to allow GMOs to be grown on its soil, I cannot support a measure that would damage the functioning of the single market and which could set the precedent of allowing for the reintroduction of non-tariff barriers within the Union itself. The Commission should withdraw this proposal.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today, I was joined by an overwhelming majority of fellow MEPs in rejecting a proposal from the Commission to reform this GMO authorisation process. The systems currently in place to open or close the door to genetically modified food and feed in EU markets are not appropriate and need tightening. The Commission was tempting us with what could be termed a dubious legal offer to allow Member States to ban EU-approved GMOs, while ignoring serious flaws with the approval system in the first place. Almost 60% of EU consumers have serious concerns about the safety and the long-term implications of genetically modified organisms. We must take these concerns very seriously and it makes sense to allow EU countries to ban GM feed imports. I do not think we should sacrifice this freedom to the integrity of the single market. However, we must make sure that this possibility is solid enough to withstand a legal challenge invoking breaches of EU or World Trade Organisation rules. I am firmly of the view that we should have a moratorium and halt all GMO approval procedures until we have a serious review of the authorisation system itself.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 It was proposed to reject the Commission's proposal because it is considered that the proposal for a regulation is almost impossible to implement, because there are no longer border controls in the EU agricultural sector. The reintroduction of these controls between Member States will reverse the economic achievements of the European Customs Union and the single market.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I am concerned about the lack of an impact assessment and compatibility of the measures taken by Member States with the internal market, WTO rules and the practicability of the proposal. In particular, since the adoption of the proposal was not preceded by an assessment of all the possible consequences and choices available, the rapporteur considers that the proposal conflicts with the commitments made by the new Commission to 'better regulation' and 'transparency', and I agree. I also agree with the rapporteur on the far-reaching consequences that the proposal could have for the functioning of the internal market in food and feed and for the competitiveness of the EU's agricultural sector, since the EU is still heavily dependent on the supply of protein from genetically modified sources, and whereas the proposal is likely to have an indirect negative effect on imports , I am of the opinion that the proposal could seriously damage livestock production and also adversely affect agriculture in the EU. Finally, since border controls no longer exist in the EU's agricultural sector, the reintroduction of such controls between Member States would be tantamount to erasing the economic achievements of the European Customs Union and the single market.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted in favour of the proposal for a revision of the current regulation on the authorisation system for GM food and feed. We believe that each Member State should have the power to opt out and to decide whether to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on its own territory.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I support the referral of the proposal back to the Commission. This is not about the question of 'yes or no' to genetic engineering, but about the fact that the proposal does not provide a solution in accordance with the current WTO rules and our internal market rules. The Commission is now called upon to identify ways that are enforceable and do not lead to border controls on agricultural products between Member States that have opted for or against the cultivation of genetically modified food.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Today UKIP voted in favour of the proposal for a revision of the current regulation on the authorisation system for GM food and feed. We believe that each Member State should have the power to opt out and to decide whether to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on its own territory.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With regard to the proposal for a regulation on the possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory, I am clearly in line with the thinking expressed by the rapporteur, who is in favour of rejecting the Commission's proposal. I believe that this proposal may have an indirect negative effect on imports and that it could have a negative impact on agriculture in the EU. To date, there is no evidence to show that the consumption of GMO foods can have consequences for human health, and the Commission's proposal does not guarantee the necessary legal certainty and appropriate instruments for Member States that legitimately wish to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE)
text: Written. I voted to reject the proposal in its entirety, as it does not take into account existing research and science. The proposal would also pose a direct obstacle to the single internal market in the EU. If the proposal were to become a reality, it would also severely restrict trade with the outside world without any objective basis. Against this background, I welcome the rejection of the proposal.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 To date, no qualified majority has ever been reached in the Technical Evaluation Committee, in which representatives of the Member States participate, for or against proposals for authorisation for trade in food and feed containing or resulting from GMOs. The Commission has therefore always applied the legislative prerogatives which enable it to give its own positive opinion. The Commission has recently tabled an amendment to Regulation 1829/2003 on the marketing of GMO-based feed, with the aim of introducing another article (31b) which ultimately aims to give Member States the possibility of banning food or feed containing or based on GMOs without, however, invoking environmental or health reasons. Following the rejection of our amendment committing the Commission not to authorise new GMO-based food or feed and not to renew the expiring permits until agreement is reached on a new proposal, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The text submitted by the European Commission under which, in theory, Member States are given the possibility of restricting or prohibiting the use of genetically modified food and feed in their territory is in fact an ambiguous document in which such a prohibition or restriction would be carried out under conditions which, in fact, make its application impossible. For example, a Member State wishing to restrict or prohibit the use of GMOs in its territory would have to put forward grounds other than those linked to risks to human, animal or environmental health; nor could it allege scientific motives, nor grounds which are not 'properly substantiated' and based on 'imperious' reasons and which, in turn, involve proportionate and non-discriminatory measures. For more inri, the Commission's proposal presents other implementation problems, for example the ambiguity of the concept of 'use'. That is why I voted in favour of Parliament's proposal to ask the Commission to withdraw its proposal and submit a new one.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution rejects the Commission's proposal for a number of reasons, including the lack of an impact assessment of the possible consequences for the functioning of the internal market in food and feed and for the competitiveness of the Union's agricultural sector; and for the practicability of the proposal, since the reintroduction of controls between Member States would be tantamount to erasing the economic achievements of the European Customs Union and the single market. I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution because I believe that these concerns are justified.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The european Commission's new proposal to Parliament on the use of genetically modified food and feed follows a GMO-free policy, a possibility for Member States to prohibit the use of GM food and feed in their territory.  Despite the shortcomings of the existing proposal, the European Commission's proposal should not be rejected, but negotiations should continue in a constructive spirit. The cooperative approach was also the basis for the drafting of legislation banning public cultivation. If we do not give the substantive debate on this proposal a chance, we may be missed a chance that will not be followed by another one. I did not support the report by Member La Via to reject the Commission proposal.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to reject the Commission proposal. However, considering the Commission’s proposal in stating that it would still go on to negotiate the proposal with the Council, I voted in favour of a new proposal which has to be submitted by the Commission and also in favour of asking the commission not to authorise the placing on the market of any new product containing, consisting of, or produced from GMOs and not to renew old ones until the new proposal is agreed upon.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is known that the use of genetically modified organisms has always been controversial, with the European Union having very strict rules and complex authorisation procedures for their cultivation and marketing. I consider it auspicious that, from April 2015, Member States can decide whether to allow the cultivation of GMOs on their territory.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This legislative report proposes to reject the European Commission's proposal to allow Member States to restrict or ban, under certain conditions, the use of genetically modified organisms (GMOs) on their territory, after they have been authorised on the European market. With broad support in the European Parliament, the rapporteur justifies this rejection on two main grounds. On the one hand, the European Commission has not carried out any impact assessment to assess the consequences of this measure on the functioning of the internal market. On the other hand, this decision is inconsistent with World Trade Organization (WTO) rules, which state that any such restriction must be proportionate, non-discriminatory and motivated by compelling reasons. Considering moreover that in practice such a measure would be unenforceable knowing that border control no longer exists in the agricultural sector, I voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted in favour of the proposal for a revision of the current regulation on the authorisation system for GM food and feed. We believe that each Member State should have the power to opt out and to decide whether to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on its own territory.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: Written. I fully support the report as it was before the plenary session. It rejects the Commission's proposal to nationalise imports. This would constitute a major infringement of the free movement of goods within the European Union. It is also a measure which has absolutely no scientific grounds, but merely wants to address political concerns about GMOs in some Member States. After all, there is no difference (even at cell level) between a piece of meat from, for example, a cow that is and a cow that is not fed with genetically modified food.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the La Via report on the marketing and use of GMOs. This was a request to reject the European Commission's proposal. Indeed, through its proposal, the Commission wanted to renationalise the marketing authorisation procedure for GMO products and thus weaken the role and joint scientific assessment of the European Food Safety Authority. This proposal would have dealt a blow to the single market, which we are seeking to preserve and consolidate.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The general Hungarian position on GMOs is known to all. Hungary the country's GMO exemption in its Basic Law and, accordingly, played an active role in negotiating the proposal to restrict public cultivation. The commission's new proposal before us is in line with Hungary's GMO-free policy, as it would give Member States the possibility to prohibit the use of foods and feedingstuffs containing GMOs on their territory. Therefore, despite the obvious errors and shortcomings, the European Commission's proposal should not be rejected, but negotiations must be continued in a constructive spirit. The cooperative approach was also the basis for the drafting of legislation banning public cultivation, an attitude that has helped the party through difficult stages of the 5-year legislative process. If we do not give the substantive debate on this proposal a chance, we may be missed a chance that will not be followed by another one. Against this basis, I did not support Mr La Via's report to reject the proposal in the vote.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 The N-VA delegation voted against the European Commission's proposal to allow Member States to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on their own territory. The N-VA considers the new Commission proposal problematic and incompatible with the agenda for better regulation. It is unclear how the proposal can be implemented, monitored and enforced in practical use. Moreover, the proposal threatens to fragment the European single market and may also have serious consequences for international trade. Also problematic is the lack of an impact assessment. For example, the possible financial consequences for the agricultural sector are by no means clear, but in any case the agricultural sector is facing significant additional costs. For high-protein feed (such as soya), Europe is particularly dependent on imports from third countries where GMO crops are widespread. Finally, the N-VA is not convinced that this proposal provides a structural solution to the political blocking of the approval procedure for GMOs at European level.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The general Hungarian position on GMOs is well known to all. Hungary the country's GMO exemption in its Basic Law and, accordingly, played an active role in negotiating the proposal to restrict public cultivation. The commission's new proposal before us is in line with Hungary's GMO-free policy, as it would give Member States the opportunity to prohibit the use of GM food and feed on their territory.  Therefore, despite the obvious errors and shortcomings, the European Commission's proposal should not be rejected, but negotiations must be continued in a constructive spirit. The cooperative approach was also the basis for the drafting of legislation banning public cultivation, an attitude that has helped the party through difficult stages of the 5-year legislative process. If we do not give the substantive debate on this proposal a chance, we may be missed a chance that will not be followed by another one. Against this basis, I did not support Mr La Via's report to reject the proposal in the vote.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 The Commission should not authorise new GMOs intended for cultivation or import into Europe, I am adamant. In its desire to enable Member States to decide on the authorisation of GMO products themselves, the College of the Commission has come up with this proposal.  One of my main battles here in the European Parliament is to protect the sovereignty of the Member States and to closely monitor the application of the subsidiarity rules. In many areas, the EU cannot interfere with state law and the idea that Member States decide for themselves whether to ban the import and use of GM food or feed could seem attractive.  However, it is important to note that in practice the idea is not applicable in the existence of a common market. That's why I turned down the offer.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this amendment because it is a proposal to reject the Commission's proposal on the use of genetically modified food and feed. We are opposed to Directive 2001/18/EC as regards GMOs intended for cultivation and categorically against the opt-out clause. The proposal for a regulation cannot be implemented, as there are no longer any border controls in the agricultural sector. We support rejection because, even if there are restrictions and certain prohibitions on the use of modified food and feed, they will seriously jeopardise vital production and adversely affect agriculture in the EU and the functioning of the internal market.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am dissatisfied with the European Commission's approach to the current GMO case. The Panel put on the table a proposal which is unacceptable in all respects, such as internal market, feed supply and international trade. That is why I could not support this proposal, even though the subject is very topical. More than 70% of the European Union now needs to be imported from feed, with 30 million tonnes of GM feed arriving in the EU each year, according to a data last year. This raises serious public safety and public health concerns. However, the answer should not be an unenforceable and unlawful proposal for legislation.  However, it is a great success that, thanks to the intervention of the Hungarian delegation from Fidesz, the EP rejection contains at least one condition calling on the Commission to come up with a new legally acceptable proposal. In the meantime, we must work hard to alleviate the EU's feed dependency. A good example is the national soy programme launched by the Hungarian Government, which has been successfully launched.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Today UKIP voted in favour of the proposal for a revision of the current regulation on the authorisation system for GM food and feed. We believe that each Member State should have the power to opt out and to decide whether to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on its own territory.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to reject the Commission’s proposal on GMOs because it would have facilitated EU GMO authorisations by allowing Member States to opt out without legal certainty for doing so. It also failed to address the flawed risk assessment process, which is at the heart of the problem. The Commission must now come forward with a real reform that addresses these problems, as President Juncker committed to doing.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal did not contain sufficiently credible solutions to unblock the ongoing impasse that exists in the committees of experts of the Member States responsible for granting the authorisation of this type of GMO. The decision, in the event of a deadlock (as always happened), is then the responsibility of the Commission. Because it is legal for Parliament to introduce amendments that radically alter this proposal (guiding it in the appropriate direction to the demands that European citizens have made to Members, that is to say, for greater control of these authorisations by democratically elected bodies such as Parliament or governments), I voted against this proposal, requiring the Commission to present its recast.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. I think it is important that there is a good scientific basis for decisions and that authorities with expertise, such as EFSA, should be allowed to play an important role. That is why I voted against the proposal.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 22 April 2015, the Commission presented a proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 on the possibility for Member States to limit or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory (COM(2015)0177).  The Commission proposes that Member States may limit or prohibit, under certain conditions, the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory after such products have been authorised ('opt-out').  This proposal was not preceded by an assessment of all possible impacts and available alternatives. There are serious concerns about the far-reaching consequences of the proposal for the functioning of the Internal Market for food and feed and for the competitiveness of the Union's agricultural sector.  I voted in favour of rejecting the committee's proposal.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The legal framework for genetically modified food and feed still does not allow Member States to express all their concerns in an area of great interest to the public and which covers several aspects: health, the environment, the economy, the democratic nature of authorisation procedures, scientific research, food sovereignty. The proposal for a regulation under discussion was not preceded by an assessment of all possible impacts and alternative options available. In this context, the Commission's attempt to adapt the legal framework to allow national governments to better express their views on the use of GMOs risks creating more problems than solutions. I hope that a wide-ranging debate will be launched with a view to arriving at a proposal that is as democratic as possible and informed of the principle of legal certainty with regard to the decision-making power of The Member States on the use or prohibition of GMOs on their territory.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission confirms itself as a proxy for the interests of agri-business multinationals. In view of the growing reserves of citizens regarding the consumption of Genetically Modified Organisms (GMOs); in the face of the discredit of the European Union's GMO authorisation mechanism, such as its proximity and the network of relations with industry, the Commission is moving forward with a proposal which is nothing other than a huge deception. The conditions imposed on Member States to limit or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory after such products have been authorised (the so-called "opt-out") are in fact impractical. We have therefore voted in favour of this report, which rejects the Commission's proposal. Even if the background reasons that converged in the rejection of this report may be diverse.  Recognising the fairness and necessity of the principle (that the use of genetically modified food and feed should be limited or prohibited), the Commission should submit a new proposal and should, for the sake of elementary seriousness and responsibility, not issue new authorisations and not renew existing ones until this new process is completed.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against as the Commission proposals are unrealistic and unworkable.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Genetically modified food and feed may be marketed to consumers only if additional authorisation has been granted. The roles of the European Commission and the Member States are clearly defined in existing law within the European Union. Member States have been allowed to restrict or prohibit, under certain conditions, the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory after those products have been authorised. Such measures must be compatible with the internal market and the international obligations of the European Union. In particular, national measures must be justified and based on compelling reasons which must not conflict with the risk assessment. Member States must submit compelling reasons justifying their derogation from application, while respecting internal market and WTO trade rules, in order to ensure the necessary legal certainty and appropriate instruments for Member States wishing to lawfully restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament was right to reject the proposal on the marketing of products containing GMOs to the sender. I regard this as an inconsistent and inadequate proposal on authorisations to be managed on a case-by-case basis, state by state, because it does not propose any regulation to protect citizens. The Commission thus disregards the commitments made by Juncker himself, proposes ambiguous solutions, citing only food for human consumption and fodder/animal feed, while it has not been clear about seed imports and the necessary restrictions. Parliament in January 2014 was very explicit in demanding clear rules starting from its opposition to transgenic ma corn; The Commission should have interpreted this disagreement with coherent and harmonisation proposals and not handed the matter back to the Far West of multinationals and GMO lobbies. Our position is totally opposed to the marketing of GMOs.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this amendment because it is a proposal to reject the Commission's proposal on the use of genetically modified food and feed. I am opposed to Directive 2001/18/EC as regards GMOs intended for cultivation and categorically against the opt-out clause. The proposal for a regulation cannot be implemented, as there are no longer any border controls in the agricultural sector. I support the rejection, because even if there are restrictions and certain prohibitions on the use of modified food and feed, they will seriously jeopardise vital production and adversely affect agriculture in the EU and the functioning of the internal market.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ We must ensure that clear and unambiguous rules are set to provide legal certainty for Member States which want to restrict the use of GM food and feed in order to respond to the concerns raised by citizens. The Commission proposal is not acceptable, especially considering the non-existence of an impact assessment, the incompatibility of Member State opt-out measures with internal market and WTO rules, the failure to ensure legal certainty, and the weak prospects for the proposal actually being implemented. Citizens’ concerns about GMOs have to be taken into account today, as our main priority in this matter is the health and safety of European citizens. It must be up to the citizens to choose Europe’s future food and agricultural model and to refuse GMOs if they do not wish to have them on their table.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider it important to address the concerns raised in the report that Member States should be allowed to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed in their territory after the authorisation of these products. In my opinion, such measures should always be compatible with both the internal market and the international commitments entered into by the Union.  In this context, together with the rapporteur, I am deeply concerned about the far-reaching implications of the proposal for the functioning of the internal market in food and feed and for the competitiveness of eu agriculture. Moreover, I believe that it is almost impossible to implement the proposal, as there is no longer border control within the EU agricultural sector. Reintroducing this type of control between Member States would reverse the economic results achieved by the European Customs Union and the internal market. Furthermore, it is also unclear how Member States with opt-outs would in practice ensure compliance with such measures on their territory.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the European Commission's view that the European Commission proposes to allow Member States to restrict or prohibit, under certain conditions, the use of genetically modified food and feed in their territory after these products have been authorised. The proposal contravies the new Commission's commitments to 'better legislate' and to provide greater 'transparency'. I am concerned about the far-reaching consequences of the proposal on the functioning of the internal food and feed market and the competitiveness of the Union's agricultural sector.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. – With this vote, the Socialists send a clear signal to the European Commission: the rejection of the proposed legislation, as it would have a negative impact on the EU agricultural sector.  We Socialists miss the European Commission's proposal for greater attention to key aspects such as traceability and legislative coherence between the human and animal feed sectors, as well as a memory of the socio-economic impact of the proposals.  We also have reservations about the actual possibility of implementing this legislation in the single market and on legal aspects; all this without obviousing that, apart from these legal issues, there is a problem of public perception and political order.  That is why we Socialists are voting in favour of the European Commission withdrawing the proposal in the current terms and developing an improved one that echoes the shortcomings identified.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. With this vote, the Socialists send a clear signal to the European Commission: the rejection of the proposed legislation, as this would have a negative impact on the EU agricultural sector.  We Socialists miss the European Commission's proposal for greater attention to key aspects such as traceability and legislative coherence between the human and animal feed sectors, as well as a memory of the socio-economic impact of the proposals.  We also have reservations about the actual possibility of implementing this legislation in the single market and on legal aspects; all this without obviousing that, apart from these legal issues, there is a problem of public perception and political order.  That is why we Socialists are voting in favour of the European Commission withdrawing the proposal in the current terms and developing an improved one that echoes the shortcomings identified.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With this vote as a Parliament we rejected a commission proposal that was decidedly inadmissible, which would have been an obstacle to the internal market and a significant step backwards compared to the current situation, throwing consumers and farmers into chaos. From a technical point of view, too, we must condemn in this case the work of the Commission, which has not presented any impact assessment or alternative possibilities. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report 'Use of genetically modified food and feed', as I support the approach of rejecting the Commission proposal.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The use of genetically modified foods is an area that affects people. However, national solutions would be contrary to the principles of the free internal market. In principle, it is important that we find a common European solution for genetically modified food and feed.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, given that the Commission proposal on the use of genetically modified food and feed raises serious questions with regard to the integrity of the single market and therefore has to be rejected. I grasp this opportunity to call on the Commission to live up to its commitment with regard to a comprehensive revision of the authorisation framework for GMOs in the EU and to put forward a new legislative proposal.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. At present, there is a European authorisation procedure aimed at ensuring that the marketing of GMOs does not pose a risk to human and animal health or the environment. The legislation entrusts responsibility for scientific risk assessments to the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), in collaboration with the scientific bodies of the Member States. In addition, the current regulation already contains provisions that allow Member States to take emergency measures to prevent the marketing and use of an authorised GMO, where it is common ground that the product may present a serious risk to health or the environment. I therefore believe that existing legislation is sufficiently guaranteed. Giving Member States greater chances of ignoring European authorisation means opening the door to creating barriers to free trade in the internal market.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Firstly, the Commission proposal disingenuously ignores the reality that the EU is reliant on imports of GM feed to sustain its livestock sector. The proposal could lead to farmers in some countries being denied access to affordable feed, which could in turn threaten their viability. Secondly, the proposal undermines the fundamental principle of free movement of goods. With different rules across different Member States, how can we speak of a single market? The proposal fails to give any indications or reassurances of how opt-outs would be individually assessed and ultimately sanctioned if found to be contrary to free movement rules. Thirdly, by allowing different national approaches, the proposal risks giving the impression that GMOs deemed safe by EFSA are in fact dangerous. This undermines science-based policymaking and exposes European citizens to scaremongering and irresponsible risk communication. For these reasons, I voted to reject the Commission proposal. I did not support calls from colleagues for the Commission to draft a new proposal, or to refrain from authorising new GMO applications until a new proposal is adopted. Rather, I would prefer to see better implementation of the current rules which allow for authorisations on the basis of science-based, case-by-case assessment.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Commission has proposed to Parliament that Member States should be able to ban the use of a duly authorised GMO on their territory.  This proposal was at first glance interesting and nevertheless looks very much like the trap already set by the Commission in January regarding the ban on the cultivation of GMOs.  Thus, on the basis of this new proposal, the Member States are clearly not sovereign. They would simply be allowed to apply for a ban on the use of a GMO, for reasons that would be "imperative" and not for health or environmental reasons. The restriction of these grounds has been denounced and amended by our political group ENL. Moreover, the term "use" is legally imprecise and should have been clarified, in accordance with the amendments tabled by our group.  The EPP rapporteur, who is also chairman of the ENVI committee, simply proposed rejecting the Commission's proposal. Unconditionally rejecting was, of course, unsatisfactory and unacceptable.  I have therefore voted against the draft submitted by Mr La Via and against the Commission's proposal, and I, like many citizens, expect the Commission to submit a serious proposal to protect our health and our environment.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report to ask the Commission to withdraw its proposal, as it is vague. Our group defends the sovereignty of the peoples and, of way, also as a result, we defend our food sovereignty. But the inconsistencies in this report empty such a concept from content. We share that it cannot be the market or the interests of agribusiness that dictate the rules on an issue as crucial as food security. We believe that, in view of the division of public opinion and the scientific community into such a sensitive subject, it would be best to give each country freedom to self-regulate, but by defining in advance what is considered 'use', to give an example, as well as other specifications which are not detailed in the Commission's report. From this group, we will therefore bet that there should be no halanche on the freedom of the Member States to maintain their different legislations — some more permissive, some more restrictive — on GMO foods, but from a more democratic legislative process in which the European Parliament has a greater share than it has so far been granted in that report.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 as regards the possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory. I believe that it is not enough to reject the Commission's proposal. The regulation as it stands is not ideal and requires greater precision, particularly in terms of definition, in order to ensure its effective implementation and legal certainty. However, rejecting this proposal is not a good solution, because on an issue so important for public health, action must be taken as soon as possible. The current legal order allows the European Commission to authorise the product after obtaining a favourable opinion from the European Food Safety Authority, as Member States on the Standing Committee are unable to take a qualified majority position.  As a Member of Polish, where a majority of citizens oppose the placing on the market of genetically modified organisms, I believe that the current rules are not satisfactory and need to be amended.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament on Wednesday (October 28th) rejected a legislative proposal by the European Commission to allow EU states to restrict (or not) the sale and use of GMO-containing foodstuffs on their territory. I welcome this strong rejection on the part of the European Parliament: parliament has been firmly telling the Commission that we are against GMOs and against an 'a la carte system' that would allow states to authorise GMOs on their territory or not. This is a strong and recurrent position of this House, which clearly says NO to GMOs until they are proven to be safe. We have therefore referred this matter to the European Commission for "reviewing its copy".

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with my fellow Labour MEPs, voted in favour of this report. The current proposal from the Commission raises serious questions with regards to the integrity of the single market. For this reason the EPLP supports this motion to reject the Commission proposal. We also argue for the Commission to live up to a promise made by President Juncker to comprehensively revise the authorisation framework for the GMOs in the EU and to put forward a new legislative proposal.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report, which rejects the European Commission's proposal. After the introduction of a two-tiered system for GMO cultivation permits, which threatens to create a real distortion of competition between our farmers, the Commission is now re-offending with marketing authorisations. The renationalisation of authorisation procedures would undermine the cohesion of the single market. To avoid a difficult debate, we would have put in place a completely illegible system. Whether we are for or against GMOs, I find it regrettable that the debate is totally ideologized, to the detriment of science and a real risk assessment.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. The proposal to reform the European Commission's GMO import authorisation procedure was not acceptable. It is therefore normal that it was rejected by Parliament. This draft law would have allowed any EU Member State to restrict or ban the sale and use of food or feed containing GMOs on its territory. He was at once incoherent, impractical and inconsistent. Incoherent, because it went against the idea of the free movement of products and turned its back on all of our policies aimed at achieving a unified market. Impractical, because a return to border controls would certainly have been very difficult to put in place concretely and probably challenged by the European Court of Justice and the WTO bodies. Inconsequent, because we have to make strong choices on the issue of GMOs. For my part, together with the elected representatives of my group, I am a resolute campaigner against the cultivation and use of GMOs. GMOs symbolize both productive agriculture and non-compliance with the precautionary principle. Our agriculture, our food, our economic development must take a very different direction.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 as regards the possibility for the Member States to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory because this legislative act sets out an authorisation procedures to ensure, via a scientific risk assessment, that the placing on the market of the products concerned will not pose a risk to human or animal health or to the environment. Every authorisation for placing a product on the market must be duly justified, and the main ground on which such justification can rely is scientific assessment.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. – With this vote, the Socialists send a clear signal to the European Commission: the rejection of the proposed legislation, as it would have a negative impact on the EU agricultural sector.  We Socialists miss the European Commission's proposal for greater attention to key aspects such as traceability and legislative coherence between the human and animal feed sectors, as well as a memory of the socio-economic impact of the proposals.  We also have reservations about the actual possibility of implementing this legislation in the single market and on legal aspects; all this without obviousing that, apart from these legal issues, there is a problem of public perception and political order.  That is why we Socialists are voting in favour of the European Commission withdrawing the proposal in the current terms and developing an improved one that echoes the shortcomings identified.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The general Hungarian position on GMOs is known to all. Hungary the country's GMO exemption in its Basic Law and, accordingly, played an active role in negotiating the proposal to restrict public cultivation. The commission's new proposal before us is in line with Hungary's GMO-free policy, as it would give Member States the opportunity to prohibit the use of GM food and feed on their territory. Therefore, despite the obvious errors and shortcomings, the European Commission's proposal should not be rejected, but negotiations must be continued in a constructive spirit. The cooperative approach was also the basis for the drafting of the public crop ban legislation, which helped the party through difficult stages of the 5-year legislative process. If we do not give the substantive debate on this proposal a chance, we may be wastre down an opportunity that is not followed by another one. Against this basis, I did not support Mr La Via's report in the vote.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose not to support this report on the practical grounds that the proposal would be almost impossible to implement because border controls no longer exist within the EU agricultural sector and would therefore reverse the economic achievements of the European Customs Union and the Single Market. Today the EU remains highly dependent on GM imports to feed livestock, where 75% of its animal feed and over 90% of compound feed imports contains GMO materials. To ban such imports would severely endanger livestock production within the EU.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted in favour of the proposal for a revision of the current regulation on the authorisation system for GM food and feed. We believe that each Member State should have the power to opt out and to decide whether to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on its own territory.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The general Hungarian position on GMOs is known to all. Hungary the country's GMO exemption in its Basic Law and, accordingly, played an active role in negotiating the proposal to restrict public cultivation. The commission's new proposal before us is in line with Hungary's GMO-free policy, as it would give Member States the opportunity to prohibit the use of GM food and feed on their territory.  Therefore, despite the obvious errors and shortcomings, the European Commission's proposal should not be rejected, but negotiations must be continued in a constructive spirit. The cooperative approach was also the basis for the drafting of legislation banning public cultivation. This approach has helped the party through difficult stages of the 5-year legislative process. If we do not give the substantive debate on this proposal a chance, we may be missed a chance that will not be followed by another one. Against this basis, I did not support Mr La Via's report to reject the proposal in the vote.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 2012/2013; 1829/2003 as regards the possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit the use of GM food and feed on their territory, as this rejects the Proposal of the European Commission. In my view, the proposal does not address problems under the current authorisation system and leads to potential fragmentation of the internal market.  Moreover, it is difficult to implement this proposal, as border controls no longer exist in the European agricultural sector. I therefore support calling on the Commission to propose a new and improved legislative proposal. Given the controversy of GM foods and the importance of the agricultural sector, it is essential that the Commission's proposal is better developed, in line with EU legal texts, and fully respects the principles of the single market.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Our position on this issue remains the same: the so-called freedom of the Member States is a decoy, the laws of the internal market and the dynamics of integration are always priorities for the Commission.  For example, the conditions imposed for the suspension of the use of such products are drastic and ne limit the possibilities for Member States to protect themselves. Mireille d'Ornano has tabled amendments on behalf of the ENL Group to replace the term "use" with "marketing", which is proving to be broader and more suitable.  I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Today my colleagues and I voted in favour of the proposal for a revision of the current regulation on the authorisation system for GM food and feed. We believe that each Member State should have the power to opt out and to decide whether to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on its own territory.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the motion of rejection proposed by my colleague Giovanni La Via on the Commission's proposal on the use of genetically modified food and feed. The Commission's proposal aimed to renationalise the marketing authorisation procedure for GMO products, weakening the role and joint scientific assessment of the European Food Safety Authority.  The motion to reject it was passed by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ In the proposal by the Commission, Member States are allowed to restrict/prohibit (under certain conditions) the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory after these products have been authorised; but such measures need to be compatible with the internal-market and the EU’s international obligations (WTO).  All groups in the Chamber decided to reject this proposal based on the following reasons:   1. Lack of an Impact Assessment; 2. Non-real democratisation of the authorisation procedure; 3. Problematic implementation due to the ban in ‘use’ instead of ban in ‘placing on the market’; 4. Compatibility of measures taken by Member States with the Internal Market and WTO, (legal uncertainty & risk for the competitiveness of the EU agricultural sector). EH Bildu is politically against GMOs, but in our opinion a more important reason needs to be underlined: MS can only restrict/prohibit GMOs and GM food and feed on the basis of compelling grounds compatible with Union law, not related to risks to human and animal health, and to the environment. And this is key.  Hence EH Bildu has voted against the Commission proposal; but in favour of the legislative resolution.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I objected to the Commission's proposal to take away Europe's right to legislate on genetically modified organisms (GMOs). This led to a de facto transfer of these EU authorisation rights to the Member States and thus a damage to the cohesion of the single market.

name: Sandra Kalniete (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the rejection of the European Commission’s proposal for national bans on genetically-modified foodstuff and feedstuff due to the serious concerns about the far-reaching consequences for the functioning of the internal market for GM food and feed and for the competitiveness of the agricultural sector. In practical terms this proposal would be close to impossible to implement because it fails to ensure the necessary legal certainty and adequate tools for Member States and border controls no longer exist within the EU agricultural sector. For food and feed import we cannot apply the same logic as for the new legislation to opt-out of authorisations for cultivating GMOs.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. Member States should be allowed to decide for themselves whether they want to place genetically modified food on the market. This is a proposal put forward by the ENF, which is reflected in this report. The introduction of genetically modified foods must not be decided in Brussels, but must remain a prerogable of the individual Member States. Only in this way can the respective governments ensure that the rights of their citizens remain protected. The diversity of the peoples of Europe and their individual wishes in terms of.B, for example, consumer protection, food quality, food processing, etc., is not a matter that should be regulated across borders. I am therefore voting in favour of this report.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 At the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg, I voted against the proposal from the European Commission (EC) amending the regulation as regards the possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed in their territory. I believe that the introduction of genetically modified food is a premature step, as the impact of these products on human health and the environment is still not entirely clear. I support the subsidiarity of each Member State on this issue, namely that we can choose what we produce and what processes we use in the course of production, but the current EC proposal is not satisfactory, because it does not shed any light on how each Member State would be able to provide bans in practice, thereby undermining the fundamental values of the European Union: the free movement of people, goods and services within the EU and a single internal market, which is one of the European Union's main objectives and cornerstones. Supporting such a proposal could even lead to border controls, which would not only be a step, but a whole marathon back. I therefore believe that the EC should do its job more thoroughly in analysing the consequences of the proposals, in the end offering what would really be an adequate solution to the issue in question.

name: Rikke Karlsson (ECR)
text: In writing. The President of the Commission, Mr Juncker, pledged to reform the GMO assessment process so that it is finally serious and effective. He did not. In any event, the management of health risk must be the responsibility of states and of them alone. The European Commission and EFSA are inherently too permeable to the influence of the world's rich agrochemical industry, including producers of genetically modified organisms and other poisoners around the world. I fight against the right to produce and sell everything, without limit and without precaution. Like pesticide disasters, the harmfulness of GMOs has been proven time and time again by courageous independent researchers around the world. Yes, we must demand a ban on the trade and cultivation of GMOs in the field, otherwise they will be scattered throughout our environment and the food chain. Under pressure from citizens, national governments can and must prevent this scandalous control of patent owners and other "producers" living on nature and our health.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. We have today rejected the European Commission's proposal on the use of genetically modified food and feed, giving a strong signal on an issue that has provoked heated public debate, mainly on the possible consequences for human health. Against this proposal from the European Commission, the ENVI Committee had already spoken out loud. Over the past few months, I have repeatedly expressed serious concerns about the lack of an impact assessment, the compatibility of the measures taken by the Member States with the internal market, and the practicability of the proposal. I believe, in fact, that the proposal could have a negative impact on agriculture in the EU, given that the EU is still heavily dependent on the supply of protein from genetically modified sources, and given that the proposal is likely to have an indirect negative effect on imports. Finally, we cannot expect to have an internal market in a leopard patch, after all the efforts that have allowed us over the years to remove barriers within the EU to ensure a single market.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. With a first success in GMO cultivation, which now allows states to choose whether or not to grow them in their territories, whereas previously they had to seek authorisation from the majority of States, the Commission wanted to repeat this manoeuvre to encourage the importation of GMO-based foods into the Union. The text it submits to us was therefore intended to allow States to decide on their own whether to allow these imports without the consent of the majority of them. Thus, with the aim of facilitating the ongoing trade negotiations with the United States, which is one of its priorities, the Commission has once again attempted to scuttle the European front against genetically modified organisms by allowing them to enter Europe. I have, of course, voted against this text in order to refuse any facilitation of the importation of GMOs and continue to oppose their production on European territory.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the legislative resolution on the use of genetically modified food and feed. The Europe of Nations and Freedoms Group had tabled nine amendments to replace the term 'use' with 'marketing', to improve the use of the precautionary principle and to give real freedom to Member States. I can only regret that the rapporteur's proposal, Mr La Via, to reject the Commission's proposal has been adopted.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The text submitted by the European Commission under which, in theory, Member States are given the possibility of restricting or prohibiting the use of genetically modified food and feed in their territory is in fact an ambiguous document in which such a prohibition or restriction would be carried out under conditions which, in fact, make its application impossible. For example, a Member State wishing to restrict or prohibit the use of GMOs in its territory would have to put forward grounds other than those linked to risks to human, animal or environmental health; nor could it allege scientific motives, nor grounds which are not 'properly substantiated' and based on 'imperious' reasons and which, in turn, involve proportionate and non-discriminatory measures. For more inri, the Commission's proposal presents other implementation problems, for example the ambiguity of the concept of 'use'. That is why I voted in favour of Parliament's proposal to ask the Commission to withdraw its proposal and submit a new one.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 One of the most important problems facing the European Community after the end of the Second World War was the problem of hunger. The production of food and feed resistant to pests, which do not deteriorate rapidly and have the expected colour, was a priority task.  It should be made clear what effects genetically modified food and feed have on human health and life. There are no reliable studies to answer the question of whether food and genetically modified feed have a positive impact on human health and life, or on the contrary. Some opponents point out that they can cause bees to become extinc, develop more difficult-to-eliminate weeds, increase allergy rates, and finally increase diseases primarily in the digestive system. The will of those who do not want to eat genetically modified food must be taken into account. For this reason, such food should be properly labelled so that the consumer makes informed decisions. In my opinion, the EU institutions should be more concerned with promoting organic food. At this stage of knowledge, the subject of genetically modified food and feed should rather be approached with caution. Almost half of food is wasted in the European Union, mostly in households, so think about an information campaign to raise consumer awareness in this respect. I therefore voted against the Commission's proposal.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Objective of Directive 2001/18/EC and Regulation (EC) No 2001/18/EC 1829/2003 is the development of a comprehensive legal framework for the marketing of GENETICALLY modified organisms (GMOs) and genetically modified food. The purpose is the safety of Union citizens and the safety and quality of food for humans and animals. It is important to establish a centralised procedure for universal rules to apply and to authorize the Commission to take decisions rejecting or approving applications.  Where GMOs or GM foods comply with that Directive and Regulation, a Member State may prohibit, restrict or prevent their free flow only with convincingly reasoned arguments. Human health and environmental risk assessments are also set out in the Regulation.  I supported Representative Giovanni La Via's report because we need a uniform and detailed legal system that will protect our citizens, food quality and Union standards. There are no GMO seed producers in Croatia yet, and food has been regularly controlled for the presence of GMO since 2007.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposed regulation appears confusing due to the already existing regulation, which also includes the necessary measures by the Member States and the Commission in the field of GMOs, and could give rise to legal uncertainty. The original Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 introduced a system in this area. It regulates the use and authorisation of GMOs on member states' markets so that this does not pose a risk to human health, animal health or the environment. It takes into account the EU's position as the largest importer of agricultural products. However, the location of GMOs is preceded by a scientific risk assessment, the responsibility for this scientific risk assessment being with the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) in cooperation with member states' scientific bodies. This Regulation also provides for measures that Member States or the Commission may take against the location or use of GMOs where the product is likely to pose a risk to health and life. Also in March 2015, a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council (EU) was adopted allowing Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of GMOs on their territory.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. This Regulation should therefore be amended as regards the possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory, because it is complete and documented and for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 28/10/2015.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against it. Our position remains the same, as with all previous votes on GMOs: we formally oppose it. As we keep saying, the so-called freedom of the Member States is a decoy, the laws of the internal market and the dynamics of integration are always priorities for the Commission. We oppose it.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this proposal. By stating that Member States must provide ‘compelling reasons’ to justify their opt-out while respecting the Internal Market and WTO trade rules, the proposal fails to ensure the necessary legal certainty and adequate tools for Member States that wish to lawfully restrict or prohibit the use of GM food and feed on their territory. Likewise, the Commission has, to the detriment of legal certainty, not provided any definition of the term ‘use’ in its proposal.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 22 April 2015, the Commission adopted a proposal for a revision of the Regulation on GENETICALLY MODIFIED ORGANISMS concerning the possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory. Considering that the European Union depends on the supply of protein from genetically modified sources, considering that the proposal is likely to have an indirect negative effect on imports, considering that border controls no longer exist in the EU agricultural sector and their reintroduction would be tantamount to erasing the economic achievements of the European Customs Union and the single market, and also considering that the proposal does not guarantee the necessary legal certainty and appropriate instruments for Member States that legitimately wish to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory, I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 22 April 2015, the Commission presented a proposal amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 on the possibility for Member States to adopt measures restricting or prohibiting, under certain conditions, the use on their territory of GMOs and genetically modified food or feed ("opt-out"). This proposal does not seem to be preceded by a careful assessment of all the possible consequences for the competitiveness of the Union's agricultural sector. Given that the EU is still dependent on the supply of protein from GENETICALLY MODIFIED sources, this proposal could adversely affect imports and agriculture in the EU. I am therefore voting in favour of Mr La Via's report, which rejects the Commission's proposal.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. Whether a Member State allows genetically modified food and feed must be decided for itself. I am opposed to the use of genetically modified food and feed, so I do not support this report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I rejected the Commission proposal, as it could have negatively impacted on the EU livestock sector which requires the importation of GM protein for feed. The ban provided for in this proposal would also have the potential to break up the single market and result in distortion of competition between Member States.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. In its proposal, the Commission suggests allowing Member States to restrict or ban, under strict conditions, the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory after these products have been authorised ("opt-out option"). The Commission could have gone further and simply banned these products, especially when we know that GMOs put on the European market are fraudulent and do not correspond to the declarations. In any case, this decision will be difficult for member states to implement because of a lack of control.  The rapporteur opposes this proposal because "the Union remains highly dependent on the supply of genetically modified proteins". In France, 80% of farm animals are fed GMOs, they account for 80% of the food used in livestock: more reason to ban them! On the contrary to the rapporteur, who argues that "the proposal could have a negative impact on agriculture in the Union", I say that the future of European agriculture rests on 100% GMO-free livestock.  I am voting for this report, which has the sole merit of pointing out the nullity of the Commission's proposal.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a Regulation on the use of genetically modified food and feed appears to be of paramount importance as it is at issue with food safety. I voted in favour of rejecting the Commission's proposal. I share the rapporteur's position on the concerns expressed about the inevitable consequences for the functioning of the internal market for both food and animal products. I call for an in-depth debate on the matter, on the consequences and associated risks.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this resolution rejecting the Commission’s proposal regarding an ‘opt-out mechanism’ in respect of the use of genetically modified food and feed, as it would ultimately threaten the coherence of the single market.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the European Parliament's rejection of the Commission's proposal that Member States should restrict or ban the use of genetically modified food and feed after they have been authorised. Because of serious doubts about, among other things, the practicality of the measure and its compatibility with the rules of the internal market and those of the WTO, I agree with the large majority of Members who preferred to reject the text. The Commission's proposal would have risked leading to fragmentation between Member States, therefore undermining the functioning of the internal market.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although caution should be exercised when using genetically modified food and feed, mainly because to this day we cannot say with precision whether this will only benefit humanity. It must be said that the European Union has the strictest regulation of genetically modified food in the world. It is therefore an unnecessary step to introduce regulations on the possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory. All the more so because even the conditions currently in force on the possibilities for granting an exemption have never been met. The safety clause has been invoked by states in nine cases so far, but in all of these cases eu scientific committees have found that there were no grounds to amend the original authorisation decision. Moreover, it is almost impossible to implement the regulation tabled, as there are no longer border controls within the EU agricultural sector. The reintroduction of such controls between Member States would reverse the economic achievements of the European Customs Union and the single market. In addition, the dependence of Union livestock production on genetically modified feed needs to be realised.
