The adoption of the regulation could result in a reduction in EU production and therefore a necessity for imports from countries with lower animal production standards than the Union.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I expressed strong concerns with regard to the Commission approach on an opt-out option for the use of genetically modified food and feed. In my opinion the practical implementation of such a process and its administrative burden are still not clear due to the non-existence of an impact assessment, the incompatibility of Member State opt-out measures with internal market and WTO rules, the failure to ensure legal certainty and the question of the proposal’s ‘implementability’ in general. Last but not least, this option could be misleading for both the consumer and the relevant industries. Therefore, I supported the rapporteur’s approach in rejecting the Commission proposal.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ A clear vote upholding the European Single Market and the principles of rules-based international trade.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 22 April 2015, the European Commission proposed a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 as regards the possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed in their territory. According to the Belgian Chamber of Deputies, the Spanish Parliament, the Dutch Lower House and the Austrian Federal Council, the draft is incompatible with the principle of subsidiarity. Parliament's Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety points out in its report that the proposal could seriously endanger livestock production and adversely affect EU agriculture. Moreover, it explains that the proposal is almost unenforceable as there is no longer border control within the EU agricultural sector. In view of all this, it recommended that Parliament reject the Commission proposal. I voted in accordance with the proposal of the parliamentary commission.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal submitted by the Commission concerns the possibility for Member States to limit or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory, in certain circumstances, after such products are authorised ("opt-out").  The adoption of this proposal would have a negative impact in a number of areas, notably on the European agricultural sector, where there is free movement and no border control, and the sector's economy is also affected within the internal market and the WTO's own rules on trade. The competitiveness of the agricultural sector is at stake, and the European Union is dependent on the supply of genetically modified proteins and is a regression in the economic progress made to date. In this sequence, I am o-going against the adoption of this proposal, as it will affect economic regulation and affect the legal certainty of the European agricultural sector, and also have implications for economic relations with third countries.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This La Via report concerns the use of genetically modified food and feed. The Commission's proposal succeeded in winning the unanimity of all political groups against it. Indeed, the so-called freedom of the Member States on the issue is a decoy, since the principles of the internal market and European integration are put on a pedestal.  The period during which Member States must refrain from acting for the Commission to consider the application, the risk assessment by the European level, and the compelling reasons for the Member States' decision are indicative of a very limited freedom regime for Member States on this crucial issue.  I voted against this text, since the rapporteur's proposal was that of a rejection with a request for a new proposal without conditions.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the marketing and use of GMO food for animals. A few months after the adoption of new rules on the cultivation of GMOs, the aim was to reject the Commission's proposal, which would have resulted in the nationalisation of the authorisation procedure in this area and to weaken the role of the European Food Safety Authority in the field of common scientific assessment. This vote supports the single market, whose consolidation is needed more than ever.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome this report because of my serious concerns about the European Commission's proposal. The new regulation, by increasing member states' discretion over the agricultural and commercial use of GMOs, raises serious doubts as to its actual applicability and its compliance with the rules governing the single market. The introduction of different regulations diverges from the need for greater integration and would put at risk the interconnection between the different food production chains. Similarly, the measure could deny one of the founding principles of the single market: the free movement of goods. The lack of borders also raises serious doubts about the controls that would rule the introduction of GMO products into the various markets. The division of the single market would also threaten competitive balances. The different access to GMO feed, to which the European agricultural sector is heavily dependent, could, in fact, change the competitiveness of one Member State in relation to another. The inhomogeneity of the various markets could cause damage to the ec's joint international trade negotiations. In the agricultural field, the negotiators should, at the same time, represent the different interests of countries geared to the use and marketing of GMOs and those opposed to them.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am fundamentally in support of the aim of a member state to have the right to decide whether they want to see food and feed containing GMOs within their borders. In this case, however, I voted against the European Commission's proposal. Serious shortcomings have arisen, the acceptance of which can only lead to chaos or arbitrary political decisions. For example, there is no impact assessment of the consequences of member states' decisions, and in this form it is a practically impractical proposal, as it is extremely difficult to prevent the entry into the market of GMO-containing crops in a Europe of today's air borders when they are already on the market in a Member State. I expect the European Commission to put a much more precise proposal on the table.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report which rejects the Commission’s proposal that Member States wishing lawfully to restrict or prohibit the use of GM food and feed on their territory must provide ‘compelling reasons’.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of rejecting the proposal allowing Member States to unilaterally restrict or prohibit the use at EU level of authorised GM food or feed on their territory. I had several reasons for this attitude. Firstly, it would be the introduction of an obstacle that could lead to a threat to the internal market, secondly, it would be de facto unenerable, because the principle of free movement of goods in the EU means the absence of internal borders and therefore border controls, thirdly, it would be a threat to the development of agriculture, which is largely dependent on imports of genetically modified feed such as soy. Last but not least, the legal ambiguity of the concept of 'use' would result in legal uncertainty for the parties concerned. Nor is the protection of consumer health a valid argument for me, because GM foods do not occur on the European market.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report on the use of genetically modified foods has not been supplemented by important points such as Member States' self-determination on imports of modified foods. As a result, member states will be further curtailed in their ability to decide on the import of genetically modified food themselves. I voted against the report.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report which proposes to reject the Commission's decision allowing Member States to remove genetically modified food and animal nutrition products from their market. Through its measures, this decision calls for the renationalisation of trade and public health policies, calling into question the European competence in the movement of goods. In addition, the "opt-out option" and the blocking of products at the borders are technically unfeasible.  With this rejection, the European Parliament calls on the Commission to make a better-constructed proposal by assessing the impact of the measures on the European market and by enabling the establishment of a permanent situation to resolve once and for all the issue of GMOs arriving or circulating in the Union.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the rejection of the European Commission's proposal. The implementation of the proposal is essentially unfillable by the lack of customs and border controls at the EU's internal borders. However, restoring control would undo the economic and political achievements of the European customs union and the single market. It also makes it very difficult to conclude free trade agreements with third countries.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I consider it appropriate to reject the proposal put forward by the Commission.  In particular, the proposal tabled does not meet the requirements for better regulation and transparency. Before the proposal was submitted, no impact assessment was carried out and the aspects of the practical implementation of the proposal were properly assessed and, in particular, its compliance with the rules on the functioning of the EU internal market and the World Trade Organisation principles on free trade.  It should be noted that the proposal does not contain clear provisions enabling Member States to prohibit or restrict food and feed from GMOs within their territory. In this context, it must be concluded that the proposal would be very difficult to implement. It would also have a negative impact on the single internal market. It should be noted that no new products containing, consisting of, or produced from genetically modified organisms shall be placed on the market and old authorisations must not be renewed until a new proposal has been fully agreed.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 as regards the possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit the use of GMOs on their territory. Firstly, I fear that, as trade in GMOs goes beyond national borders, the regulation proposed by the Commission may prove impossible to enforce, since the reintroduction of border controls between countries in favour of and those opposed to GMOs would be incompatible with the single market and the customs union. Furthermore, since the adoption of the proposal was not preceded by an assessment of all the possible consequences and alternatives available, I believe that the proposal conflicts with the commitments made by the new Commission to 'better regulation' and 'transparency'. Finally, I have serious concerns about the far-reaching consequences that this proposal could have for the functioning of the internal market in food and feed and for the competitiveness of the agricultural sector. As the EU is heavily dependent on protein supplies from GMO sources, the proposal could also have indirect negative effects on imports.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The JRC voted in favour of rejecting the European Commission's proposal for a regulation on Genetically Modified Organisms, because the proposed regulation effectively excludes the right of Member States to prohibit the use of GMOs on their territory. Within the EU, of course, protecting health and the environment from mutants is impossible. This is because the freedom of movement of capital guaranteed by the EU Treaties freely allows the import and marketing of mutants in all EU Member States. The rejection of the Commission's proposal should not reassure the public, because it is certain that the EU institutions will come back with new measures to promote GMOs, since this imposes the interests of monopolies on the sector concerned, especially in view of the EU-US negotiations on the conclusion of the TTIC. The JRC calls for a complete ban on the import, marketing and all use (including agricultural) of GMOs, which cannot be guaranteed under the regime of monopoly sovereignty. It requires the people in power and owner of concentrated means of production and land, so that they can be released from the EU and with central nationwide planning and labour-people control to create agricultural productive cooperatives, to ensure nutritional adequacy, cheap, healthy and safe food for the people.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. A system as proposed would not have prevented the presence of raw materials from GMOs in countries that would refuse to import them: nothing would have been controllable with regard to the use of GMOs. Given my strong opposition to GMOs, like the citizens of Europe, it was impossible for me to vote in favour of such a text.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted in favour of the proposal for a revision of the current regulation on the authorisation system for GM food and feed. We believe that each Member State should have the power to opt out and to decide whether to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on its own territory.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Fearing that the possibility for Member States to decide whether to ban or restrict food and feed containing genetically modified organisms could make imports difficult and, consequently, harm the feed industry, as well as Eu ropean agriculture, I felt it necessary to vote in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of the report calling on the Commission to present a new, improved proposal for a regulation. Due to the failure to carry out an impact assessment, to ensure that Member States' actions comply with internal market rules and, in general, to the (non)feasibility of the proposal in practice, I rejected the commission's existing proposal. I expected the Commission to review the current authorisation procedure for GMOs and to come up with an appropriate proposal, rather than simply copying the concept from the recently amended GNM Cultivation Directive, which is the basis for the exemption or exclusion of territory for the cultivation of GMOs, as the situation here is fundamentally different. Unfortunately, the Commission's proposal would not contribute to greater transparency, nor would it provide the necessary legal certainty and adequate tools for Member States wishing to restrict or prohibit the use of GM food and feed on their territory.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report La Via concerns the use of genetically modified food and feed. The Commission's proposal succeeded in winning the unanimity of all political groups against it. Indeed, the so-called freedom of the Member States on the issue is a decoy, since the principles of the internal market and European integration are put on a pedestal. The period during which Member States must refrain from acting for the Commission to consider the application, the risk assessment by the European level, and the compelling reasons for the Member States' decision are indicative of a very limited regime of freedom for Member States on this crucial issue. I voted against this text, since the rapporteur's proposal was that of a rejection with a request for a new proposal without conditions.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I strongly support the clear and unequivocal rejection of the Commission's proposal. Member States must reserve the right to decide independently on the presence of genetically modified organisms on their territory. This applies especially to Croatia, where all counties have declared themselves GMO-free zones. We should say no to the pressures of the GMO industry and strongly advocate for the production of food products as it is done today in Croatia – in a natural, safe way and in a clean environment.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The aim of the report proposal is to maintain the same level of safety regarding the use of GMO foods throughout the EU. Under the proposed regulation, Member States may adopt restrictive or prohibition measures on the use of GMO or GMO feed and feed, provided that such measures are reasoned on compelling grounds, comply with Union law and are proportionate and non-discriminatory in accordance with.  Where a Member State intends to adopt measures to limit or prohibit the use of products, it will first submit draft measures to the Commission and an appropriate justification. The Commission will immediately inform other Member States of such draft measures, together with the appropriate justification. However, Member States must be able to demonstrate that the product in question poses a risk to health and the environment. Therefore, provisions are in place to protect the rights of economic operators legally placed on the market of GMO or GMO feed and feed before Member States in order to adopt measures in compliance with the proposal.  Furthermore, sufficient time should be given to operators to allow products to be eliminated from the market. I support the report, as it is intended to amend existing legislation, in order to give Member States the opportunity to restrict or prohibit the use of GMO food and feed on their territory for the safety of citizens in the EU.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the European Social Democratic Faction, I do not, of course, want to extend the cultivation or distribution of GM food to the EU, where 60% of the population thinks GMOs are harmful and dangerous for the future. However, the relevant legislation must be precisely drafted. On the contrary, the current proposal was overall poorly conceived and must be remade. States already have the right to prohibit or restrict GMOs when these crops are grown, but this is necessarily limited to the territory of one state or another. On the other hand, a sales ban could lead to the introduction of additional border controls or an overall restriction on cross-border trade. In the present document, the Commission has not put forth any plan to preserve states' right to sovereign access to the issue without consequences in the form of an adverse impact on imports and the internal market. The Commission's planned procedure of agreeing on the current proposal directly with the Member States should not then be accepted by them. A new proposal must be put forward to ensure safe and efficient functioning within the single internal market.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Last April, the European Commission adopted a proposal to revise the GMO regulation which, among other things, would allow Member States to restrict or prohibit the use of GMOs that have already been authorised on their territory.  I voted in favour of rejecting the proposal presented by the Commission amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003. I believe, in line with what the rapporteur has said, that the proposal was not preceded by a proper impact assessment.  Furthermore, I believe that the implementation of this proposal could have negative consequences for the functioning of the internal market and the competitiveness of the Union's agricultural sector.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal by the European Parliament and the Council on the possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory. In my opinion, it should be the responsibility of the State to decide on the use of such prepared feed or food in its territory. It is therefore appropriate for the European Parliament to support this proposal in order to give space in this area to the Member States of the Union. However, these measures must also be compatible with the internal market and international obligations, for example towards the World Trade Organisation. Member States' actions must be justified and based on relevant reasons and, of course, must be proportionate and non-discriminatory. I believe that this proposal will lead to greater satisfaction for the Member States, as they will be able to regulate the use of genetically modified food and feed on their own territory.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament rejected the report on the use of genetically modified food and feed. I voted against this text because I believe it called into question the role of the European Food Safety Authority in authorising GMOs in the Union. In addition, it encouraged the nationalisation of marketing authorisations for GMO products, undermining the European approach and the achievements of the single market, when we just need to strengthen it.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a Regulation submitted by the European Commission on 22 April provides that Member States may limit or prohibit, under certain conditions, the use of GMOs for human (food) or animal (feed) consumption after such products have been authorised by the EU (opt-out).  ENVI members expressed serious concerns about this proposal, first of all because it was not preceded by an impact assessment, but also because they considered that this proposal would have negative consequences for the functioning of the internal market for food and feed and the competitiveness of the EU agricultural sector, and is also virtually impossible to implement , as border controls no longer exist in the EU agricultural sector and their reintroduction would be a step backwards.  In these terms and if these concerns were fully justified, I voted in favour of rejecting the Commission's proposal.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted in favour of the proposal for a revision of the current regulation on the authorisation system for GM food and feed. We believe that each Member State should have the power to opt out and to decide whether to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on its own territory.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. This is a clear message that the European Parliament sent to the Commission on Wednesday by opposing its proposal on GMOs. In its text, the Commission wanted to allow any Member State to restrict or ban on its territory the sale and use of food or feed containing EU-approved GMOs.  The idea may be interesting, but it goes against the free trade rules so dear to Europe. This would mean that Member States should regain control at their borders of imported products, a practice contrary to the treaties. Having been rapporteur on the legislation on national bans on GMO cultivation negotiated earlier this year, I believe that to legislate identically on imports and on the cultivation of GMOs is nonsense. Especially when we know that Europe is dependent on imports of GMO soybeans to feed its livestock, which cover more than 60% of Europe's food needs.  I welcome the decision by the vast majority of Parliament, which calls on the Commission to present another proposal that is more coherent, courageous and meets the needs of European citizens.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. The Commission intended to renationalise and speed up the authorisation process for GMOs imported into Europe for food and feed, but the European Parliament decided otherwise by voting in favour of THE report by MP La Via. The European Parliament has acted in the public interest by rejecting the Commission's proposal which would have led to the renationalisation of the procedure for authorising GMOs within the European Union and to an acceleration of their marketing. Rejecting the Commission's proposal, however, is not enough. The Greens therefore welcome MEPs' support for our amendment to force the Commission to table a new proposal despite its opposition.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted, like the overwhelming majority of my colleagues, for the motion to reject the Commission's proposal to allow Member States, individually and under certain conditions, to restrict or ban the use of food or animal feed containing GMOs previously approved at European level.  We are opposed to this "à la carte" legislation for many reasons: risk of fragmentation of the internal market, lack of impact analysis, impractical or illusory character, lack of legal rigour, threat to the competitiveness of the agricultural sector, etc. For all these reasons, we call on the European Commission to withdraw its proposal and present a new one.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. On 22 April 2015, the Commission submitted a proposal for a Regulation with a view to amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, in which it suggested allowing Member States to restrict or prohibit, under certain conditions, the use of genetically modified food and feed (GMOs) in their territory after these products had been authorised.  However, the Commission's proposal has not been preceded by an impact assessment of the consequences for the functioning of the internal market and competition from the agricultural sector. In addition, there are reasonable doubts as to their implementation and how Member States using the opt-out clause will, in practice, ensure compliance with such measures in their territory. We therefore consider that the proposal does not guarantee the necessary legal certainty or appropriate instruments for Member States wishing to restrict or legally prohibit the use of GMOs in their territory. That is why I rejected the Commission's proposal and voted in favour of asking the Commission for a new legislative proposal.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of rejecting this Commission proposal (like a large majority of MEPs: 577 against, 75 in favour and 38 abstentions) which was based on legislation in force since April and intended to leave it up to Member States to refuse the cultivation of 8 GMO seeds approved by the EU or in the process of being approved. Parliament therefore opposed any nationalisation of decisions on GMOs and found the Commission's proposal unenforceable in a single market without internal borders. For example, for the "simple" case of Belgium: Flanders traditionally tolerates GMOs, unlike Wallonia and Brussels. However, the Commission's proposal makes it possible for a Member State to decide on the use of GMOs in part of its territory; therefore, in Belgium, internal border controls would become necessary. In fact, at present, 19 Member States have expressed their intention to ban genetically modified cultivation on part or all of their territory. Personally, I deplore the fact that the Commission does not dare to refuse GMOs on European territory, when a large majority of Member States and citizens are against the exploitation of GMOs.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for the rejection of the European Commission's proposal. The Commission proposed giving Member States more freedom to import and market genetically modified food and feed. A few months after the adoption of common legislation on the cultivation of GMOs, it is crucial that the European territory does not become a patchwork of national legislation on the use of GMOs. The Union must maintain a common policy that leaves no room for an "a la carte" approach; Indeed, the Commission's proposal suggests a renationalisation of the GMO marketing authorisation procedure. In addition to the risk of jeopardising the single market, this reversal also poses a threat to agricultural competitiveness; that is why I voted in favour of rejecting the Commission's proposal.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report rejecting the proposal adopted by the European Commission for the revision of the GMO regulation, because it was not preceded by an impact assessment that took into account all the possible negative consequences that could fall in the agricultural field. Such a proposal would allow each individual Member State of the European Union to decide to restrict or prohibit the use of already authorised GMOs on its territory, which could have an indirect negative effect on imports. Furthermore, I am not in favour of the reintroduction of border controls for EU agricultural products, because this would hinder the free movement of goods and make it difficult to maintain the single market at European level.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report to ask the Commission to withdraw its proposal, as it is vague. Our group defends the sovereignty of the peoples and, of way, also as a result, we defend our food sovereignty. But the inconsistencies in this report empty such a concept from content. We share that it cannot be the market or the interests of agribusiness that dictate the rules on an issue as crucial as food security. We believe that, in view of the division of public opinion and the scientific community into such a sensitive subject, it would be best to give each country freedom to self-regulate, but by defining in advance what is considered 'use', to give an example, as well as other specifications which are not detailed in the Commission's report. From this group, we will therefore bet that there should be no halanche on the freedom of the Member States to maintain their different legislations — some more permissive, some more restrictive — on GMO foods, but from a more democratic legislative process in which the European Parliament has a greater share than it has so far been granted in that report.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to reject the Commission proposal because it does not review or improve the GMO authorisation process, in fact it leaves it completely unchanged. The entire GMO system in the EU needs a thorough review. The existing system is not transparent and does not reflect the concerns that many citizens have in relation to GM products and their potential effects on human health and the environment. The Commission must honour its commitment to look again, in depth, at the GMO regime at EU level and propose changes which reflect citizens’ concerns.

name: Jordi Sebastià (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of rejecting the European Commission's proposal because I believe that there must be European coherence with regard to GMO food and feed, and it is not a good thing to let each State decide on its own. Our position is also contrary to the import, production and use of these products.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The text submitted by the European Commission under which, in theory, Member States are given the possibility of restricting or prohibiting the use of genetically modified food and feed in their territory is in fact an ambiguous document in which such a prohibition or restriction would be carried out under conditions which, in fact, make its application impossible. For example, a Member State wishing to restrict or prohibit the use of GMOs in its territory would have to put forward grounds other than those linked to risks to human, animal or environmental health; nor could it allege scientific motives, nor grounds which are not 'properly substantiated' and based on 'imperious' reasons and which, in turn, involve proportionate and non-discriminatory measures. For more inri, the Commission's proposal presents other implementation problems, for example the ambiguity of the concept of 'use'. That is why I voted in favour of Parliament's proposal to ask the Commission to withdraw its proposal and submit a new one.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal rejected today by the European Parliament does not defend the interests of a more competitive agricultural sector open to scientific innovation. Scientific innovation must be framed without taboos of any kind to inform and serve as best as possible the political decision, in defense of the common good, the future of citizens and, for this, the resilience of our resources.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution, because I am against the creation of new EU legislation and new EU Regulatory frameworks.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Parliament’s motion to reject the Commission proposal because the current proposal raises serious questions about the integrity of the single market. I would also add that the Commission should live up to the promise made by its President Jean-Claude Juncker to comprehensively revise the authorisation framework for GMOs at EU level and to put forward a new legislative proposal.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider genetically modified food and feed to be experimentation and I am against their cultivation in Slovakia. In the EU dimension, I consider it important that every state in the EU should be able to decide this area on its own. However, I did not consider the content of the proposal on the possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory to be satisfactory enough, which is why I abstained from voting.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Union has a comprehensive legal framework for issuing authorisations and labelling of genetically modified organisms (GMOs) and genetically modified (GM) foods.  The authorisation process for such food should be verified by the European Food Safety Agency (EFSA) under strict risk assessment guidelines. Unfortunately, in frequent cases of GM foods, this assessment is not sufficiently detailed.  GmOs alone remain fully informed and improved analyses of the ecological aspects of GM plants and GENETICALLY modified food and feed should be introduced in the marketing authorisation process. Also, in its 2015 work programme, the Commission announced a review of these procedures to address the concerns of citizens and Member States, as GMO authorisations are issued even in cases where a qualified majority of Member States oppose it.  That is why I supported the proposed legal framework which provides that GMOs or GM foods must not be placed on the market without prior authorisation issued in accordance with the relevant legal regulations. A review of authorisation procedures for GM food and feed is essential and such food should not be released on the market before a risk assessment is made.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. In April 2012, the Commission published a proposal proposing to allow Member States, with regard to genetically modified food and feed, to restrict or prohibit them under certain conditions. Those national measures should be reasonable and justified on valid grounds, which should not conflict with the risk assessment carried out by the European Food Safety Authority and those measures should be proportionate and non-discriminatory.  I share the concerns expressed in the report on the failure to carry out the impact assessment as regards the compatibility of the measures taken by the Member States with internal market rules and WTO rules and the practical feasibility of the proposal. As the EU is still heavily dependent on the supply of protein from gm sources and because the proposal could have an indirect negative impact on imports, I believe that it could seriously jeopardise livestock production and have a negative impact on agriculture in the EU.  The proposal also does not provide the necessary legal certainty and adequate tools for Member States wishing to legally restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory. The possibility of such a restriction or prohibition would reintroduce a kind of border controls between Member States, thereby reverseing the economic achievements of the European Customs Union and the single market. For the sake of the above, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Renate Sommer (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of Giovanni La Via's report, which calls on the Commission to withdraw its proposal on Member States' national import bans on GMO feed. The Commission proposal would be the beginning of the end of our common internal market. Border controls would have to be reintroduced between Member States in order to prevent genetically modified feed from entering a country that has imposed a ban on imports. There would be massive distortions of competition in EU agriculture and unmanageable chaos. The possibility of import bans is also completely unrealistic because European agriculture is dependent on the import of protein feed. Only 5% of our soya needs, which are used as feed in animal production, are produced in the EU. The rest comes from countries such as the USA, Canada and Brazil, where genetically modified plants are mainly grown. In any case, animal products would be much more expensive for the consumer and meat production, which is also one of the EU's largest export transactions, would migrate to third countries. The proposal is therefore dangerous nonsense. The import of GMO food and feed is strictly regulated by law in the EU. These rules guarantee the safe handling of GMOs, and they should continue to do so.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the use of genetically modified food and feed, in which Parliament rejected the European Commission's proposal that would allow individual Member States to restrict or prohibit the sale and use on their territory of GMO food or feed already approved at EU level. We believe that this decision should be taken at European level and not by individual Member States, in order to prevent the renationalisation of limits and prohibitions in this area leading to a risky fragmentation of the internal market and the customs union. The Commission's proposal could, in fact, prove unfeasible or lead to the reintroduction of border controls between countries in favour of and those opposed to GMOs, given the divisions that exist on this issue. With the resolution adopted today, we therefore call on the Commission to present a new draft legislation that takes these concerns into account and provides an assessment of the potential consequences or other viable options.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Genetically modified foods are highly controversial and there is no unity among scientists on this subject either. Member States must therefore have the right to decide whether or not to allow their cultivation and marketing in their territory.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report because I believe that amending Regulation (EC) No 2012 will allow the 1829/2003 introduce new options to allow Member States in their territory to restrict or prohibit the use of GMOs and genetically modified food and feed.  Furthermore, I support the additional powers that this proposal will grant to Member States to restrict or prohibit the use of GMOs and genetically modified food and feed, but I note that these powers must comply with the Legislative Framework of the European Union. I believe that this proposal is in line with EU legal frameworks and the principle of subsidiarity, and will contribute to the regulation of the restriction of GMOs and genetically modified food and feed.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support the rapporteur's position, as I find the Commission's proposal very difficult to implement, although Member States should be able to restrict or prohibit the use of GM food and feed on their territory. Under certain conditions, the Commission proposes to allow Member States to restrict or prohibit the use of GM foods on their territory.  If such a proposal is implemented, this could leave major consequences and there are concerns about the functioning of the internal market for food and for the competitiveness of the Union's agricultural sector. In addition, the proposal will be very difficult to implement, as in practice there are no longer border controls in the European Union agriculture sector.  If such controls are reintroduced, this could be a setback in the Union's economic achievements and the achievements of the single market. Likewise, the Commission did not clarify the term 'use' in its proposal. For all of the above, I support the rapporteur's position.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal. I fully agree that it is up to the Member States themselves to decide whether or not to use GMOs. At the same time, however, I share the rapporteur's view that the current Commission proposal contains fundamental problems and should therefore be recast.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory, rejecting the European Commission's proposal. This proposal was also rejected by a large majority in the committees responsible in the European Parliament.  The European Commission's proposal is not realistic, as it is not feasible. In the European Union, we have spent a long time establishing the internal market and abolishing customs duties. If we wanted to implement this Commission proposal, we would have to reintroduce customs duties, which, of course, would have a very negative impact on the internal market. The Commission's proposal misses the impact assessment and alternatives.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of this report, as it proposes to reject the Commission's proposal, which provides for a series of measures limiting the possibility for Member States to prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory. Directive 2001/18/EC enables Member States to do so and the Commission is coming through amendments to limit it and to ask States to answer to the Commission for not choosing to import GMOs into their country. Our long-term position is that the sovereignty of the Member States and the ability to decide on key issues that concern them are non-negotiable, especially those concerning the health and well-being of their citizens.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Directive 2001/18/EC as regards GMOs intended for cultivation and the opt-out clause are incorrect. The proposal for a regulation cannot be implemented, as there are no longer any border controls in the agricultural sector. Even if there are restrictions and certain prohibitions on the use of modified food and feed, they will seriously jeopardise vital production and adversely affect agriculture in the EU and the functioning of the internal market.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The issue of genetically modified (GM) food and feed divides European Union decision-makers and the majority of the population rejects these products outright. Parliament, the Council and the Commission have long tried to find a solution to treat these products with common EU legislation, while not hindering scientific progress. However, this proposal from the Commission did not adequately manage the issue, which is why I voted in favour of the Commission withdrawing the proposal and developing a new one.  I believe that, in the short term, a solution could be for Member States to decide whether to authorise or prohibit the marketing of GM products. In addition, a debate should be launched involving society, based on analyses, in order to find a solution. We must take into account global population growth, changes in consumption patterns, our dependence on import protein, the effects of GM feed and the fact that free movement of products within the EU single market cannot be restricted. If it is introduced later, I also consider a strict labelling system to be one possible solution.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 We are very much in favour of states having the opportunity to ban GMOs. The European Commission's proposal seems to be heading in this direction. It only seems: in fact, it does not give the real possibility of such a ban being implemented in practice. We in the M5S tabled amendments to the legislative proposal in committee to make it applicable. The ENVI Committee, on the other hand, has submitted to plenary a simple resolution rejecting the European Commission's proposal. We abstained in order to point out our distance both from the unworkable possibility of prohibition originally proposed by the European Commission (we want a workable ban!) and from its simple rejection. This rejection excludes the possibility of Member States banning GMOs, particularly in view of the fact that the Commission has already indicated that it does not wish to present a new legislative proposal on the subject. new proposal to make national bans possible.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The use of genetically modified organisms in the diet of the population has been a very intense and controversial topic of debate from the outset. Beyond the arguments of the supporters and opponents of this type of food, the decisions we take, as representatives of European citizens, must take into account their interests. The Commission's proposal to amend the 2003 Regulation in this area concerns the possibility for Member States to restrict or even prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory, while maintaining an EU-wide authorisation system. The application of these amendments, however, would create legal uncertainty as to the practical application of the measures proposed by the Commission, would fragment the internal market and distort competition, would contravene the principles of good regulation and transparency and could limit the freedom of movement of goods within the EU. In this context, it is clear that we need an impact assessment of these measures, but in particular a number of scientific opinions of the European Food Safety Authority, which assess the risks to human health, animal health and environmental protection. I believe that the position of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety is well founded and I support the adoption of the report, in the sense of rejecting the Commission's proposal.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has rejected the Commission's proposal to give Member States the opportunity to ban the use of GMOs on their territory, whether they have the opportunity to accept or not. This proposal, made without an impact assessment, runs counter to the single market, favours multinationals but above all reflects the cowardice of the Commission, which does not dare to refuse GMOs on European territory when a large majority of Member States and citizens are against the exploitation of genetically modified organisms. When is a simple majority to reject GMOs, as 19 of the 28 Member States and 60% of the population want?

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Today, all genetically modified organisms need authorisation before they can be placed on the EU market. However, a qualified majority among the Member States has never been reached either in favour of or against any authorisation proposal put forward by the Commission. The Commission has therefore concluded that the legal framework for decision making on genetically modified (GM) food and feed needs to be adapted. The Member States would thus be allowed to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory, despite it being authorised at EU level. I voted in favour of Amendment 1 calling for the rejection of the Commission’s proposal. By this vote I expressed my serious concerns about the proposal. The Commission proposed more flexibility for the Member States to limit or ban the use of GM food and feed on their territory. Under this regulation, Member States could block the free circulation of feed, which would have a negative impact on the internal market (in violation of Article 34 TFEU).

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I share the concerns expressed in Mr La Via's report on the use of GMOs on EU territory and for this reason I believe that the Commission's proposal should be rejected. The institutions can and must make every effort to protect the health of citizens: effective measures must be taken, the result of a careful assessment of all the possible consequences of the use of GMOs and the alternative options available. Rejecting this proposal means not allowing Member States to adopt different and incongruous rules, with countries choosing one position and countries choosing another. We need a common commitment to promote an open debate on new technologies, which will make it possible to protect the tradition of European agri-food production and to respond to the growing needs to meet the food consumption of European citizens and beyond. Only through an in-depth debate on new technologies and the impact they have on the lives of each of us will we be able to make progress in the interests of all.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The la Via report raises very important issues for European farmers, so I supported it with my voice. The reason for this is obvious and should be important for food producers. The Commission proposed to take into account developments in genetically modified food and feed in the GMO Directive, which entered into force in early 2015. Proposals have emerged to allow Member States to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed in their territory even after they have been authorised. The protection of European farmers, the protection of local crops and natural genetic material are paramount, as it ensures the preservation of natural and organic crops, which in turn has a significant impact on consumer health.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. Report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1049/2001 of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of the general public I supported it because Member States should have the right and freedom to restrict and prohibit genetically modified food and feed in their territory, provided that they have evidence that genetically modified food and feed have a negative impact on human health or the environment.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report to ask the Commission to withdraw its proposal, as it is vague. Our group defends the sovereignty of the peoples and, of way, also as a result, we defend our food sovereignty. But the inconsistencies in this report empty such a concept from content. We share that it cannot be the market or the interests of agribusiness that dictate the rules on an issue as crucial as food security. We believe that, in view of the division of public opinion and the scientific community into such a sensitive subject, it would be best to give each country freedom to self-regulate, but by defining in advance what is considered 'use', to give an example, as well as other specifications which are not detailed in the Commission's report. From this group, we will therefore bet that there should be no halanche on the freedom of the Member States to maintain their different legislations — some more permissive, some more restrictive — on GMO foods, but from a more democratic legislative process in which the European Parliament has a greater share than it has so far been granted in that report.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Commission has unanimously rounded up political groups against its own proposal for very different reasons: the integrity of the internal market, lack of legal certainty, the risk of shortages for livestock feed in the sectors affected by imports, insufficient national room for manoeuvre, etc.  The position of National Front MEPs remains the same as in the previous GMO dossier: the so-called freedom of the Member States is a decoy, the laws of the internal market and the dynamics of integration are always a priority in the eyes of the Commission. I am opposed to this text because the ENL amendments tabled have been rejected.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The La Via report is built against the European Commission's proposal on whether Member States can restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed in their territory. This Commission proposal follows the model of a recent amendment allowing States to prohibit the cultivation of genetically modified organisms approved by the EU on their territory, but not their marketing. Thus, Member States could restrict or prohibit, under certain conditions, the use in their territory of genetically modified food and feed after those products have been authorised.  This Commission proposal is, above all, a lacor, as there is no preventive study showing the true implications for the functioning of the internal market, in which controls have been eliminated, and on the competitiveness of the agricultural sector within the EU, which is heavily dependent on protein supplements from sources of genetically modified organisms. In this respect, we could be in the presence of a setback within the Single Market by reintroducing controls between accepting Member States and those that do not accept the marketing of such products. I therefore voted in favour of the La Via Report, which recommends rejecting the proposal for national bans on GMOs.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 22 April 2015, the Commission, together with a communication on the review of decision-making procedures for genetically modified organisms, presented a proposal for a regulation amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 as regards the possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed in their territory. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report to ask the Commission to withdraw its proposal, as it is vague. Our group defends the sovereignty of the peoples and, of way, also as a result, we defend our food sovereignty. But the inconsistencies in this report empty such a concept from content. We share that it cannot be the market or the interests of agribusiness that dictate the rules on an issue as crucial as food security. We believe that, in view of the division of public opinion and the scientific community into such a sensitive subject, it would be best to give each country freedom to self-regulate, but by defining in advance what is considered 'use', to give an example, as well as other specifications which are not detailed in the Commission's report. From this group, we will therefore bet that there should be no halanche on the freedom of the Member States to maintain their different legislations — some more permissive, some more restrictive — on GMO foods, but from a more democratic legislative process in which the European Parliament has a greater share than it has so far been granted in that report.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. In view of the repeated breaches of its promises in the field of GMOs by the Juncker Commission and a more than deficient legal proposal, I voted in favour of Member States being able to restrict or prohibit the use of GMOs in their own legislation.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The text submitted by the European Commission under which, in theory, Member States are given the possibility of restricting or prohibiting the use of genetically modified food and feed in their territory is in fact an ambiguous document in which such a prohibition or restriction would be carried out under conditions which, in fact, make its application impossible. For example, a Member State wishing to restrict or prohibit the use of GMOs in its territory would have to put forward grounds other than those linked to risks to human, animal or environmental health; nor could it allege scientific motives, nor grounds which are not 'properly substantiated' and based on 'imperious' reasons and which, in turn, involve proportionate and non-discriminatory measures. For more inri, the Commission's proposal presents other implementation problems, for example the ambiguity of the concept of 'use'. That is why I voted in favour of Parliament's proposal to ask the Commission to withdraw its proposal and submit a new one.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'Whether we are for or against the authorisation of genetically modified organisms, I do not think it is possible for Europe to organise this authorisation per Member State. This would not only entail unfair competition, but would also require us to reintroduce controls at Europe's internal borders to check whether or not some food or feed contained GMOs. I therefore voted against the European Commission's proposal.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal to give Member States the possibility to limit or prohibit the use of genetically modified organisms authorised by the European Union in food or feed on their territory constitutes legal nonsense given the practical impossibility of delimiting territorial borders in a framework where there is free movement of persons and goods. To that extent, it can only be interpreted as another disguise of the Commission's obvious commitment to the GMO lobby. Instead of refusing to introduce GMOs into the Community in the face of scientific evidence, it pretends to empower national states knowing in advance of their practical impossibility.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Whether a Member State allows genetically modified food and feed must be decided for itself. I am opposed to the use of genetically modified food and feed, so I do not support this report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the Commission's proposal for a regulation on the possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory. Parliament rejected the proposal because it did not bring anything new to the level of protection that already exists. On the contrary, any national bans on the use of genetically modified food and feed would be impossible to implement because of the rules of the internal market and the WTO. I have heard the concerns of citizens and consumer associations about the risks arising from the consumption of GMOs. I hope that Mr Juncker will stick to his agenda and that the Commission will present a new proposal on this matter. The revision of the rules for authorising GMOs in Europe is necessary, but it must better reflect the opinion of the majority of citizens. Until then, the Commission cannot use its powers to authorise new GMOs.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. Unlike my group, the ECR, I voted against this report. In principle, I am opposed to the use of genetically modified food or feed. This is not only a moral issue, but also another example of the violation of the EU's subsidiarity principle. That is why I voted against the report.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against the Commission's proposal for a Regulation amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 in regards to the possibility for the Member States to restrict or prohibit use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory.  The reasons explaining my decision in that matter, consider both practical level of implementation of this proposal, as well as the possible consequences on EU agricultural sector.  The implementation of this proposal is basically nearly impossible to achieve. This is due to the fact that the border control has been already abolished and the only way of monitoring the exports and imports of GMO food is to introduce the border control again. This measure is absolutely pointless, since it would actually constitute the regress of economic achievements of European Customs Union and the Single Market.  In terms of the consequences on EU agricultural sector, the proposal will have a direct negative impact on it. The research shows that, nowadays, EU is highly dependent on GM imports to feed the livestock and banning such imports would highly reduce the livestock production within the EU, and therefore, in the long-term scenario our economy would suffer severely.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against the Commission's proposal to bring the restriction or ban on GMO marketing back to national level, as this would have been a major step backwards in this area. In addition to the divergences it would have created between Member States, such a proposal would have had a catastrophic consequence: the weakening of the single market.  The Commission will therefore have to come back with a new proposal, which is more in line with the expectations of European citizens and which does not undermine one of the foundations of the European Union.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. I believe that a clear distinction needs to be made between the cultivation and marketing of genetically modified organisms (GMOs). While control over the cultivation of GMOs can be managed efficiently at domestic level, allowing Member States to have the final say regarding their marketing can bring serious inconsistencies in the EU internal market. As the AGRI Commission has indicated, this proposal would mean the reintegration of border controls between pro-GMO and anti-GMO countries, something that would go against the European spirit and which, in practice, would be extremely complex to implement.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The JRC voted in favour of rejecting the European Commission's proposal for a regulation on Genetically Modified Organisms, because the proposed regulation effectively excludes the right of Member States to prohibit the use of GMOs on their territory. Within the EU, of course, protecting health and the environment from mutants is impossible. This is because the freedom of movement of capital guaranteed by the EU Treaties freely allows the import and marketing of mutants in all EU Member States. The rejection of the Commission's proposal should not reassure the public, because it is certain that the EU institutions will come back with new measures to promote GMOs, since this imposes the interests of monopolies on the sector concerned, especially in view of the EU-US negotiations on the conclusion of the TTIC. The JRC calls for a complete ban on the import, marketing and all use (including agricultural) of GMOs, which cannot be guaranteed under the regime of monopoly sovereignty. It requires the people in power and owner of concentrated means of production and land, so that they can be released from the EU and with central nationwide planning and labour-popular control to create agricultural productive cooperatives, in order to ensure nutritional adequacy, cheap, healthy and safe food for the people.

name: Roberts Zīle (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The european Commission's aim is to enable Member States to decide whether to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food on their territory. While the arguments of the committee responsible can be largely accepted, it is not clear how the mechanisms proposed in this draft regulation would be implemented in the EU's single market and whether they would lead to the reintroduction of border controls, I could not support the complete rejection of the proposal for a regulation in the vote, as I believe that work on this proposed regulation should be continued: such regulation is necessary and Member States should be given the opportunity to restrict or prohibit the use of GMO food authorised at EU level in their territory , similar to the community ban on gMO plant cultivation, which has already been introduced by Latvia. If countries are not given this opportunity, in view of the interests of large food producers and importers, at EU level, countries have failed to agree on a gMO food ban so far and will not succeed in the future, no matter how critical and cautious consumers are. Work on the Regulation should therefore be continued by providing for harmonised control measures to monitor restricted or banned FOOD from GMOs in the EU internal market and by finding specific, common criteria which do not conflict with the principles of the internal market and the EU's international obligations on the basis of which Member States could ban or restrict food from GMOs on their territory.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained in the vote on this report. The Commission's proposal itself was complicated and, in my opinion, members' position on genetically modified food could not be unequivocally expressed in the vote. At the beginning of this year, we voted that Member States should be able to prohibit the cultivation of GM crops on their territory. I agree with this position and, in view of the divergent views on this topic under discussion and controversy and the fact that the consequences of GMOs on human health and the environment are not yet sufficiently examined, Member States should not be denied the possibility to decide whether or not to place genetically modified food on the market as they consider it necessary. or at risk for their inhabitants.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report rejecting the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003. The Commission proposal considers that Member States should be able to limit or prohibit, under certain conditions, the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory after such products have been authorised. However, serious concerns remain as regards, inter alia, the lack of an impact assessment, the compatibility of the measures adopted by member states with the internal market and world trade organisation rules, as well as the feasibility of the proposal. As regards the Union's agricultural sector, there are major concerns about the consequences of the proposal for the functioning of the Internal Market for food and feed and on the competitiveness of the sector, as the European Union remains highly dependent on the supply of genetically modified proteins and the proposal is likely to have negative indirect effects on imports. Moreover, the proposal is virtually impossible to implement, as border controls no longer exist in the Union's agricultural sector and its introduction would be a regression from the progress already made.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. Since the beginning of my term of office, I have fought to make Europe a GMO-free territory. Gm food and feed should not enter European territory. On the other hand, the EU imports 32 million tonnes of soya for feed from its farms every year and 90% of it is genetically modified. The Commission's proposal would give individual Member States a false freedom of choice because it would expose to denunciation by multinationals the individual country that chooses not to trade GMO food and feed on its territory. According to this approach, millions of tonnes of gm feed would continue to reach Europe, feeding our animals and, indirectly, us too.  Rejecting it is therefore necessary but not sufficient: we need to introduce a moratorium on genetically modified feed and we regret the fact that the majority of the European Parliament did not want to support this approach, leaving the situation unchanged. A behavior that could only see me not satisfied with the simple rejection and, for this reason, I chose to abstain.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. The European Parliament today voted on a report on 'novel foods'. The aim is to make it easier for foods with a different molecular structure, consisting of micro-organisms, fungi or algae .m. I voted in favour of the compromise voted in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, as I want to see new legislation in place as soon as possible. I also welcome the fact that this compromise contains transitional provisions for food from cloned animals.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Proposals to facilitate and facilitate the opening up of the European market to the marketing of food obtained from so-called innovative technologies and foods from defined traditional third countries is an issue that has animated heated debates within the European Parliament. The novel food market raises many well-founded concerns about protecting consumer health. In fact, the economic potential dictated by the expansion of this market must not sacrifice the necessary guarantees of protection for citizens, established according to well-defined scientific standards and, above all, oriented towards compliance with the precautionary principle. On the other hand, the picture outlined by the political orientation of the European Commission and the Council seems quite different. The problem of the vague classification of what should or can be called a food of 'traditional origin', which also includes the marketing of insects, adds to the real risk of seeing food in our supermarkets with additives obtained from GMOs, products containing nanoparticles in high percentages, foods with nutritional substitutes of synthetic origin, while failing to comply with the appropriate information requirements. I voted against because this danger absolutely must be curbed, in the interests of both the health of European citizens and the environment itself.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. With our vote in favour, the Spanish Socialists are committed to simplifying the procedures for the authorization of new foods. The European Regulation currently in force dates back to 1997, the date from which there has been a great evolution in the new food sector and its ingredients. The revision of this regulation is therefore necessary to keep up with scientific and technological advances.  The new legislation includes the following proposals: it centralizes the authorisation procedure and eliminates the previous national assessment, which implies a reduction of the administrative burden for both food business operators and national authorities; implies a reduction in the time and costs for obtaining an authorisation for a new food; makes individual authorisations generic and thus facilitates market access for SMEs; establishes a simplified procedure for traditional third-country foods that improves the access of third-country operators to the European market; and ensures a high level of public health through a centralised and systematic risk assessment by EFSA, followed by a Union authorisation decision.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The one which was not used for human consumption to a significant extent in the Union before 15 May 1997 is considered 'new food', and also includes traditional third-country food which, for at least 25 years, has been part of the usual diet of a significant number of its population. There are many aspects to this report that we do not agree with and which have not been improved by the proposed amendments, since they were rejected, in particular the permissiveness in relation to nanomaterials and clones and their descendants, the use of implementing acts rather than delegated acts, and the limitation of Member States to ban new food. To top it all off, there is no background analysis of the non-need for these new foods, the interests of large multinationals and industry to bring them to market, the linkage with regulatory convergences for international treaties (the TTIP, for example) and the need to promote local, seasonal consumption that is sustainable and not these "new foods". That is why I voted against this report.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I abstained from the final vote, as many of the issues that Parliament wanted to include in the legislation on 'New Foods' were not accepted by the Council. In particular, we wanted stricter legislation on cloned animals, as we want the consumer to know whether what he is eating comes from a cloned or a descendant of a cloned animal.  Although we have tabled amendments to this in plenary, unfortunately we have not gathered the necessary majority for them to be accepted.  But by accepting that this legislation offers even less protection to consumers, we have decided to abstain from the final vote.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report regulates the marketing of new foods, i.e. foods that did not exist in the European Union before 1997 (e.g. insect-based food or nanomaterials). All of these new foods would pose a potential danger to consumers as these nanoparticles are likely to penetrate human cells. There is a need for better regulation, labelling and even outright bans. Unfortunately, all these precautionary measures have not been adopted: neither by the Commission, nor by the Council, nor by Parliament. I therefore objected to this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This is highly complex, highly technical and very difficult to understand the impact. The definition of ‘novel foods’ is problematic. I therefore followed the advice of colleagues in voting, who have more expertise on this matter than I do, and voted against the resolution. I am advised that this will create a great financial burden for applicants and could challenge foods which are already legally on the market. Member States could even be deprived of the ability to make an initial safety assessment.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to ensure food safety, protect public health and ensure the proper functioning of the internal market in the food sector, while promoting innovation in this sector.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 A high level of protection of human health and consumer interests and the effective functioning of the internal market must be ensured in the implementation of the Union's food policy and transparency. A high level of environmental protection and improvement of its quality are among the objectives of the Union as set out in the Treaty on European Union. It is important that all relevant Union legislation, including this Regulation, takes those objectives into account. The categories of novel foods should be reviewed, revised and updated to take account of scientific and technological progress since 1997. The categories of foods for which the molecular structure has been changed new or deliberately altered, as well as food products derived from animal, plant, micro-organisms, cultures or cultures of algae cells or tissue cultures, categories of micro-organisms, fungi or algae and foodstuffs derived from mineral substances should be provided. In addition, a category should be provided for which foodstuffs produced from plants obtained by non-traditional propaceration methods, where such methods lead to a substantial change in the composition or structure of foodstuffs, affecting their nutritional value, metabolism or concentration of undesirable substances.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP opposes the Commission legislative proposal for a regulation on novel foods. The new proposal, with the removal of the former novel food categories, would put at risk foods already legally on the market which could be challenged under the new regulation. We are concerned that this would cause legal uncertainty for operators, and if products already on sale were to be withdrawn for further assessment this would compromise consumer confidence. We also oppose the new authorisation system proposal that would introduce a centralised authorisation process.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted against the revision of the procedure for authorising new foods because I do not believe that it does not have sufficient requirements under the precautionary principle and food safety, knowing that this new regulation will cover, for example, nanomaterials or foodstuffs derived from cloned animals.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report should help define and regulate the introduction of new food products called new foods. In this text, the Council has removed all security measures adopted by Parliament. As a reminder, new foods are all foods that did not exist in the European Union before 1997. For example, they cover foods based on insects, nanomaterials or other products. It is therefore necessary that these products so defined can only be put on the market in accordance with the precautionary principle, accompanied by a particular labelling, and once their safety is proven in relation to health and the environment.  I regret in this text mainly the fact that nanomaterials are not simply banned in food. We are going towards too little consumer protection, only remedies are provided through objections.  I abstained on this vague text because, even if the report is intended to be more protective, there is a risk to nanomaterials and a legitimate distrust of the Commission and EFSA.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not support the Nicholson report with my vote because I am opposed to the so-called 'new foods' – insects, algae, nanomaterials, laboratory-built foods and new dyes – that will arrive on our tables, while some foods that have always been linked to our territorial traditions find no protection, on the contrary, they are opposed by the regulations of European bureaucrats, with considerable damage both to our productive fabric and to our peoples.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted against the report. New types of food are positive in themselves, but there are too many shortcomings in this regulation. The report covers both new types of food, cloned animals and nanomaterials and its use in the food sector. The final proposal lacks sufficient guarantees of the precautionary principle, and thus does not put consumers and food safety first. Our sharper amendments were voted down. Finally, it is important to invoke the principle of subsidiarity. Those Member States that do not want this type of product should have the right to regulate their own market.
