However, it is doubtful how this can be followed when the EU now votes on a regulation that places the main power at EU level. In view of this, I have chosen to vote against the report.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. This proposal for a Regulation on new foods aims to ensure food security, protect public health and ensure the functioning of the internal market, while supporting innovation in the food sector. The proposal updates current legislation by creating a 'streamline' authorisation procedure, clarifies the definition of 'new food', introduces a faster and proportionate safety assessment for third-country 'traditional foods' which have a safe history of food and simplifies procedures for public authorities and private actors.  The final outcome of the negotiations with the Council includes many aspects claimed by this Parliament, such as the provisional inclusion of cloned animal feed within the scope of the Regulation until specific legislation enters into force or the reintroduction of old food categories and the introduction of new ones, with a view to including food from micro-organisms, fungi and insects.  Although the final text has some gaps with regard to the development of the list of categories of new foods or for foods containing nanotechnology, in order to adapt the rules on new foods to technological and scientific progress, I have decided to vote in favour of this reform.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The New Food Regulation is an important law that should edit and centralise the process of approval and control of new food on the EU market. It should raise the level of consumer health protection and improve the functioning of the internal market.  In short, if our citizens want to eat grasshoppers and exotic berries, these products must be healthy and safe, but also approved according to a uniform procedure. It can be said that these objectives have been met, but the final document did not include regulations on the care of cloned animals and definitions of nanofoane that would close potential legal loopholes.  That's why I abstained in this vote.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. Given the Council's removal of all the safety measures adopted by Parliament and our fears about: - the possible penetration of cells by nanomaterials - the absence of a real study on health impacts - the particular risk to pregnant women and babies - the lack of legislation on this subject for animal feed It is clear that we are calling for an outright ban on nanoparticles in food. I cannot therefore support this text and vote against it.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I am convinced that the introduction of new food products into the single market must be subject to controls aimed at ensuring the non-harmfulness of these foods, protecting the health of European citizens

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of the report is to regulate the introduction of new foods, i.e. all food products that did not exist in the European Union before 1997, such as insect-based food or nanomaterials. These would pose a potential danger to consumers because these nanoparticles could penetrate our cells. Hence the need for increased regulation ranging from labelling to prohibition, in accordance with the precautionary principle. However, all these safety measures have not been adopted by the Council to the detriment of the Europeans who will suffer the harmfulness of these particles. The parliamentary group of which I am a member has called for a simple ban on the use of these foodstuffs. As this request goes against the philosophy of the text, I voted against this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The food sector is one of the most productive in the European Union. This productivity must first take into account consumer safety and profitability. In this respect, by amending the report on novel foods, it is intended to provide consumer safety, with new foods subject to safe assessment and authorisation, before being placed on the EU market. Innovation is also attractive, but the consumer requires that food be safe for consumption, asks to be informed of how it was produced, but also of its benefits. Innovation is only accepted if it gives confidence to the consumer. I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on novel foods, as a robust legislative framework is needed for the approval of new foods to ensure compatibility with regard to safety, benefits for the consumer, as well as environmental, social and ethical issues.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. They are for traditional products, we leave grasshoppers, larvae and ants elsewhere....

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 THE EU rules on novel foods were established by the entry into force of Regulation (EC) No 258/1997 of the EUROPEAN Parliament and of the Council and of Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. Commission Regulation (EC) No 1852/2001. In view of the scientific and technological progress made in the food industry in recent years, it is natural that legislation reflects the new realities of this sector in the EU internal market. The definition of a new food, the rationalisation of the authorisation procedure and the data protection provisions are the main concerns. I support the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on novel foods (2013/0435(COD), because I believe that stakeholders need an effective procedure that provides adequate product certainty and protection.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. The European Regulation currently in force dates back to 1997, the date from which there has been a great evolution in the new food sector and its ingredients. The revision of this regulation is therefore necessary to keep up with scientific and technological advances, while at the same time guaranteeing the right of consumers to know everything about food, especially in food innovations. That is why I voted against it, because of the absence of a moratorium on foods containing nanotechnology until EFSA adopts a specific strategy on risk assessment for these nanofoods, and for the lack of transitional measures with respect to food derived from the descendants of cloned animals. It should be recalled that the European Parliament has spoken out against the cloning of animals for food use and that these products now come from importation.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The new foods consist of any food whose human consumption was negligible in the Union before 15 May 1997. It is very important to regulate these new foods which are now more consumed on the European market. This report clarifies the definition of new foods in order to adapt European legislation to the realities of the current European market. Procedures for authorising new food into the EU will be streamlined and simplified, leading to a much more transparent system. This text aims to improve the single market. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on novel foods. The agri-food sector is an evolving sector that needs an updated regulatory framework to keep up with technological developments. At present, human consumption of certain species of insects, classified as new food products, is already permitted in several Member States, including Belgium, the Netherlands, Denmark and the United Kingdom. With the report we have adopted, we have updated the legislation in this area. While simplifying the current authorisation procedures for novel foods, the text ensures a high level of protection of human health and consumer interests through a systematic centralised risk assessment carried out by EFSA and the application of the precautionary principle. At the same time, additional specific labelling requirements are laid down with the aim of informing final consumers about any specific food features or properties of these new products. The text voted on guarantees consumer protection and maintains legislation in step with scientific and technological advances in the sector. That is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report which deals with novel food (food not consumed in the EU before 1997) and cloning. I was not happy with the outcome of the negotiations on these issues. The issue of cloning was not adequately addressed as descendants of cloned animals were not covered. On food safety, the rules were also not clear enough, in that, on nanomaterials, controls by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) were limited to requests by the Commission. Furthermore, responsibility for judging whether a substance is a novel food or not, and thereby subject to this regulation, is left in the hands of operators: this does not provide sufficient consumer protection.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP opposes the Commission legislative proposal for a regulation on novel foods. The new proposal, with the removal of the former novel food categories, would put at risk foods already legally on the market which could be challenged under the new regulation. We are concerned that this would cause legal uncertainty for operators, and if products already on sale were to be withdrawn for further assessment this would compromise consumer confidence. We also oppose the new authorisation system proposal that would introduce a centralised authorisation process.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I agree that detailed study of the so-called novel foods and subsequent legislation are vital to ensure the highest quality of products on the European market. The current Novel Foods Regulation therefore needs to be updated in line with the latest developments and information at hand. Also, the rapporteur rightly points out the need to include more provisions on different types of novel foods in order to avoid a legal vacuum.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report provides for the possibility of authorising new traditional foods or foods provided that they are not disadvantageous and not necessarily beneficial, from a nutritional point of view compared to existing ones. In the event that EFSA or the Commission has requested additional documents from applicants and they do not provide them, the assessment is not suspended but the available documentation is carried out. The meaning of the term "significant number of people" who should have consumed food for at least 25 years so that it can be recognized as traditional food, remains undefined. Coverage is guaranteed for animal clones but not for descendants.  Finally, the application of the precautionary principle in the event of scientific uncertainty about the safety of a given food stuff is referred to only in recital 17, whereas in the enacting times the precautionary principle is indicated as one of the parameters on which the Commission will base its opinion. What is the real consideration of this indication can already be deduced from how nanoparticles were treated which, by applying the recital's indications and EFSA's conclusions, should have been reduced to a maximum of 10%, and prohibited in the event that the lack of sufficiently sensitive instruments prevents the achievement of the indicated objective. I therefore voted against.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of James Nicholson's report on new foods, which led to very constructive negotiations at first reading between the European Parliament and the Council.  This report responds to the need to revise eu-market authorisation regulations for new foods. Dating back to 1997, this regulation is somewhat obsolete given the evolution of food production methods, scientific advances, and the opening of markets to products from third countries.  As such, James Nicholson's report is a vehicle for beneficial developments. It provides for the reassessment of the definition of new foods and the delineation of different food categories within the scope of new foods. Similarly, some of the provisions of this report will make it easier for traditional foods from third countries to enter the Union.  In the end, in my view, this report facilitates innovation while ensuring consumer food security.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The report stresses that the free movement of safe and healthy food is a fundamental aspect of the internal market and makes an important contribution to the health and well-being of citizens and to safeguarding their social and economic interests. Differences between national laws on safety assessment and the authorisation of new foodstuffs may hinder the free movement of such foodstuffs, causing a lack of legal certainty and conditions of unfair competition.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the current authorisation procedure, prior to placing on the market, has been criticised, as it is too expensive and too long. Indeed, one of the objectives set out by the Commission in the new proposal is to simplify and streamline the regulatory process, thereby reducing the administrative burden on applicants, the authorities of the Member States and the Commission itself. Furthermore, the Commission has rightly recognised that long delays in the procedure, as well as the costs of submitting applications, have created an obstacle to innovation and the participation of SMEs. Therefore, although a simplified authorisation procedure will undoubtedly reduce the costs borne by applicants, it will inevitably be an effort that can entail considerable burdens, while encouraging the competitiveness and innovation of food business operators should remain the main objective and therefore achieve the appropriate degree of protection. With regard to the controversy over insects, it is a question of regulating a sector that until now has been the subject of a regulatory vacuum. No authorization has been given, contrary to what the newspapers say.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP opposes the Commission legislative proposal for a regulation on novel foods. The new proposal, with the removal of the former novel food categories, would put at risk foods already legally on the market which could be challenged under the new regulation. We are concerned that this would cause legal uncertainty for operators, and if products already on sale were to be withdrawn for further assessment this would compromise consumer confidence. We also oppose the new authorisation system proposal that would introduce a centralised authorisation process.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Union rules on food were laid down by Regulation (EC) No 258/97 of the European Parliament and the Council and by Commission Regulation (EC) No 1852/2001, which recognises that any new food or food ingredient requires prior authorisation to place on the market in order to preserve a high level of protection of human health and consumer interests. In view of the rapid scientific and technological progress in the food sector there are a number of new foods and food ingredients, such as containing foods, consisting of or produced from micro—organisms, fungi and algae, or foods with an intentionally modified primary molecular structure that do not fall within the scope of the definition of "new foods" of the legislation force. I am voting in favour of this report which will close this gap and adapt the definition of new foods to these realities while reducing administrative burdens for applicants by simplifying and streamlining the regulatory authorisation process.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because the current authorisation procedures for this type of novel food are too complicated, lengthy and expensive. We need a centralised and shortened procedure in the internal market, whereby authorisation applies not only to a single food, but to the whole product category of similar foods. However, I would also like to point out the important role of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), which must ensure, through inspections, that a product has no impact on human health.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP opposes the Commission legislative proposal for a regulation on novel foods. The new proposal, with the removal of the former novel food categories, would put at risk foods already legally on the market which could be challenged under the new regulation. We are concerned that this would cause legal uncertainty for operators, and if products already on sale were to be withdrawn for further assessment this would compromise consumer confidence. We also oppose the new authorisation system proposal that would introduce a centralised authorisation process.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that authorisation for a new food stuff is a barrier to trade and prevents access to the EU market for products with safe and historically proven food use in their country of origin, I fully agree with the implementation of the new regulation, which, in addition to ensuring food safety, aims to streamline and simplify the authorisation procedure for new nutrients through a list of new foods authorised in the Union. This new regulation will bring benefits on many fronts: it will, in fact, reduce the administrative burden, the duration and cost of the authorisation process and increase the competitiveness of the European food industry, especially SMEs.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 We have voted in favour of the agreement with the Council. The legislation means that we will be able to approve novel foods more quickly. This is positive, especially since the existing legislation today constitutes an obstacle to the production of food. The law requires the labelling and therefore traceability of cloning that may conflict with WTO agreements and create other trade-related problems. To demand that all our trading partners put in place traceability systems for cloned animals is unrealistic. Despite this objection, we voted in favour of the proposal because it is important to have a new system for faster authorisation of novel foods in place.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of the review is to facilitate procedures for authorising the placing on the market of new food and traditional food from third countries. It should be remembered that this proposal stems from the one previously rejected in March 2011 for failing to reach agreement on the use of animal clones for food purposes. Although the market for new foods could expand mainly due to the influence of traditional foods from third countries, between 2004 and 2014 the number of authorisations issued by the Commission or individual national authorities was around 100 and 3 cases of rejection officially reported. Furthermore, in addition to food or food preparations for immediate consumption, all food additives, including those from GMOs , play an important role in the new food market (despite the fact that GMOs are excluded from the scope of new foods as they are already covered by Regulation 1829/2013), microorganisms such as yeasts, or individual compounds with particular properties. Following the rejection of our amendment which would have prohibited the use of nanotechnology in the light of current toxicological uncertainties and the impossibility of being able to assess their presence in concentrations of less than 50% of the total, I decided to vote against it.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The one which was not used for human consumption to a significant extent in the Union before 15 May 1997 is considered 'new food', and also includes traditional third-country food which, for at least 25 years, has been part of the usual diet of a significant number of its population. There are many aspects to this report that we do not agree with and which have not been improved by the proposed amendments, since they were rejected, in particular the permissiveness in relation to nanomaterials and clones and their descendants, the use of implementing acts rather than delegated acts, and the limitation of Member States to ban new food. To top it all off, there is no background analysis of the non-need for these new foods, the interests of large multinationals and industry to bring them to market, the linkage with regulatory convergences for international treaties (the TTIP, for example) and the need to promote local, seasonal consumption that is sustainable and not these "new foods". That is why I voted against this report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on the Commission proposal and the legislative resolution on novel foods because given the regulation is outdated and the rules on novel foods have to be adjusted to the technological and scientific progress, there are clearly missing elements which are of extreme importance.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the new rules will subject food to safety assessment and authorisation through a fully harmonised procedure at European Union level. The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) should carry out an assessment in all cases where a food may affect human health.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This legislative report aims to speed up the process of authorising "new foods" as too complex, costly and time-consuming, and to better take into account recent scientific and technological developments in the food sector. "New foods" are foods not covered by the current legislation dating back to 1997. They can be innovative and produced through new technologies, or are products traditionally consumed in third countries outside the European Union. The report expands the definition of new foods to include, among others, food with a modified molecular structure, microorganisms, fungi, algae, foods obtained from cell or tissue cultures, and insects. Considering that the European Parliament has obtained satisfactory guarantees from the Council on food from cloned animals, the precautionary principle, measures to keep nanomaterials under surveillance and restrictions on animal testing, I voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP opposes the Commission legislative proposal for a regulation on novel foods. The new proposal, with the removal of the former novel food categories, would put at risk foods already legally on the market which could be challenged under the new regulation. We are concerned that this would cause legal uncertainty for operators, and if products already on sale were to be withdrawn for further assessment this would compromise consumer confidence. We also oppose the new authorisation system proposal that would introduce a centralised authorisation process.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: Written. – This dossier contains a number of important elements. For example, it provides a centralised application procedure at EU level (and no longer at Member State level) for so-called 'novel foods'. Cloned food is now also included, whereas previously there was an unclear arrangement around it that led to legal uncertainty. Processing applications will now also be possible in a shorter, more streamlined procedure.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. This regulation simplifies marketing authorisation procedures for new foods, i.e. foods or food ingredients not consumed in the European Union before 1997. For example, Goji berries, native to Latin America that were not at all consumed in Europe 20 years ago, are now widely available commercially and highly valued for their energizing properties.  Globalization and technological innovations have helped to diversify our diet. The European Union must therefore adapt and support innovation in the food sector without questioning the principle of precaution and protection of European consumers. That is why the authorisation procedure at European level must be properly supervised and the scope of the regulation specified.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for the Nicholson report on new foods. I welcome the adoption of this report because the European regulation on new foods needed to be revised in order to simplify procedures and, above all, to comply with changes in markets and new technologies. This report covers a significant number of topics because it covers new technologies, such as nanomaterials, as well as imports of products from third countries. This report will streamline and simplify the authorisation process and improve its efficiency and transparency. It will also introduce a safety assessment method that will be both faster and better adapted to traditional foods from third countries.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: Written. The N-VA delegation today gave the green light to the revision of the legislation on new types of food. This review is both important and urgent. The current legislation dates back to 1997 and is no longer adapted to technological and scientific progress. An earlier attempt to update the legislation failed in 2011. After almost 20 years of stagnation, it is now really time for progress, which benefits both our citizens and our businesses. The N-VA strongly believes that the new legislation will encourage innovation. The approval procedure for new food species today lasts on average three years and is expensive. A single authorisation procedure that reduces administrative burdens should ensure that new foods can enter the market faster and cheaper. This progress is important for Flanders, where many companies (especially SMEs) are strong in the development of innovative food types. Of course, the new rules do not affect consumer protection. The safety of the products remains paramount. The N-VA also welcomes the legislation's emphasis on discouraging testing on animals through the application of the 3V principle (replacement, reduction, refinement).

name: Ангел Джамбазки (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 For those for whom it is incomprehensible what exactly "new foods" mean – those that were not consumed en masse in the European Union before 1997, when the first regulation on the subject came into force. This proposal simplifies Union-wide rules and adapts to technical and scientific progress.  The new rules will subject novel foods to safety assessment and authorisation at EU level. If new food is likely to affect human health, the European Food Safety Authority will have to carry out an assessment.  Where decision-making at EU level can make it easier for traders and increase consumer security so that everyone wins, I can only support such a proposal.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the proposal for an EP and Council regulation on new foodstuffs. The reason is that no one can guarantee in an absolute and unequivocal way the suitability and safety of this new type of food and the impact it will surely have on the health of consumers. Our fixed position is the exclusive production and consumption of food whose primary molecular structure is not in any way modified or altered as for example in cloned animals.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP opposes the Commission legislative proposal for a regulation on novel foods. The new proposal, with the removal of the former novel food categories, would put at risk foods already legally on the market which could be challenged under the new regulation. We are concerned that this would cause legal uncertainty for operators, and if products already on sale were to be withdrawn for further assessment this would compromise consumer confidence. We also oppose the new authorisation system proposal that would introduce a centralised authorisation process.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 A prerequisite for the development of Europe's food sector is the existence of a regulatory framework in place to allow for the approval and launch of new innovative products in the common market. The proposal provides for a fully harmonised EU-wide procedure for the safety evaluation and authorisation of innovative food products. In addition, the European Food Authority (EFSA) shall carry out an evaluation in all cases where food may have an effect on human health. The proposal provides the conditions for development and security for consumers. I have therefore voted in favour of this proposal.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The new legislation provides for a new authorisation procedure at EU level for new foods, rules on the placing on the market of food from cloned animals, control of nanomaterials and restrictions on animal testing. "New foods" are considered those that were not used significantly for human consumption before 1997, for example, those consisting of or are produced from microorganisms, fungi and algae. According to the report, the new procedure for the authorisation of new foods at EU level should be more effective and faster. The long delays in the process, as well as the costs of submitting an application, have created an obstacle to innovation and the participation of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The new legislation also regulates the placing on the market of food from cloned animals, defines what nanomaterials are and imposes restrictions on animal testing.

name: Édouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this resolution because it does not highlight the dangers of nanomaterials.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 New foods are foods that were not included in the human diet of a significant number of people within the EU before 1997. In 2008, the European Commission adopted a proposal for a regulation on new foods. The legislative discussion focused primarily on the provisions applicable to nanomaterials, cloning of animals for food production, traditional foods from third countries, the criteria to be examined for studies and risk management and the procedures for the authorisation of new foods. This new proposal has several problematic points, including the definition and clarification of the designation of food, the role of national agencies in the authorisation process and with regard to delegated acts. Another controversial issue is the need for long-term monitoring of the market introduction of these foods and their impact. Unfortunately, the result of the trilogue does not reflect all these concerns, and is better than the European Commission's proposal, as it includes concerns about animal welfare and the labelling of these foods. There are other points that should have been included and were not.  Moreover, the precautionary principle is not guaranteed in this legislative proposal. Reasons for our vote against.

name: Santiago Fisas Ayxelà (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the adoption of the New Food Regulation, because I believe that the previous regulation of 1997 does not allow for legal coverage of new food practices. In addition, the new legislation allows, through the centralization of the procedure, to expedite and simplify the granting of authorizations. As shadow rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on International Trade on New Food, I welcome the that this new legislation will help ensure food security and public health.

name: Christofer Fjellner (PPE)
text: Written. We have voted in favour of a council agreement for so-called novel foods. The legislation means that we will be able to approve novel foods more quickly. This is positive, especially since the existing legislation today constitutes an obstacle to the production of food. The law requires the labelling and therefore traceability of cloning that may conflict with WTO agreements and create other trade-related problems. To demand that all our trading partners put in place traceability systems for cloned animals is unrealistic. Despite this objection, we voted in favour of the proposal because it is important to have a new system for faster authorisation of novel foods in place.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the proposal as I believe consumers are not protected by the precautionary principle.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of the European Commission's proposal in question is to ensure safe food and thus protect consumers in the European Union, but at the same time to ensure the functioning of the internal market in food and to promote innovation in the food sector. The proposal seeks a clear definition of the concept of new foods, including new technologies that have an impact on food production. However, this proposal also has significant shortcomings, to which the Socialists and Democrats group has referred. As it stands, the regulation is obsolete and the rules for new foods must be adapted to technological and scientific progress.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the proposal for a regulation of the EP and of the Council on new foodstuffs. The reason is that no one can guarantee in an absolute and unequivocal way the suitability and safety of this new type of food and the impact it will surely have on the health of consumers. My fixed position is the exclusive production and consumption of food whose primary molecular structure is not in any way modified or altered as for example in cloned animals.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly believe that we must ensure food safety, protect public health and secure the functioning of the internal market for food, while supporting innovation in the food sector. Streamlining the authorisation procedure, improving its efficiency and transparency must be our priority. I support the clarification of the definition of a novel food and of new technologies which have an impact on food production, as well as the introduction of a faster and more proportionate safety assessment for traditional foods from third countries having a history of safe food use. However, implementing acts for the authorisation procedure for a novel food give Parliament absolutely no political control over what kind of novel food is being authorised; the list of categories of novel foods is non-exhaustive and can cover any new food that falls under the scope; and no transitional measures regarding the food derived from the descendants of cloned animal are included – thus leaving a legal gap until new legislation is in place. I am therefore not fully satisfied with the final text of the regulation.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the proposed definitions are not at all satisfactory, do not create legal certainty and ultimately do not clarify the scope and definition of 'new food', which was one of the main objectives of the Commission's new proposal.  While I welcome the Commission's intention to develop an enlarged concept for the definition of new foods, involving all types of innovation in the food industry, the elimination of these categories has caused serious concerns. Although all relevant actors in the food sector agreed that the new definition was not workable, there were already differences of opinion on what should be replaced. Since scientific and technical progress in the food industry needs to be recognised and legal certainty improved, I believe that the most reasonable step would be to introduce new categories of novel foods in a modern way in order to make the provision on novel foods 'future-proof' in the face of unexpected industrial developments. I also consider it important that the regulation be adapted to technical progress and to the new types of products entering the EU market.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the need to update the legislation in this area in accordance with the enormous scientific and technological advances that the food sector has made, always ensuring the food security of European citizens.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. – With our vote in favour, the Spanish Socialists are committed to simplifying the procedures for the authorisation of new foods. The European Regulation currently in force dates back to 1997, the date from which there has been a great evolution in the new food sector and its ingredients. The revision of this regulation is therefore necessary to keep up with scientific and technological advances.  The new legislation includes the following proposals: it centralizes the authorisation procedure and eliminates the previous national assessment, which implies a reduction of the administrative burden for both food business operators and national authorities; implies a reduction in the time and costs for obtaining an authorisation for a new food; makes individual authorisations generic and thus facilitates market access for SMEs; establishes a simplified procedure for traditional third-country foods that improves the access of third-country operators to the European market; and ensures a high level of public health through a centralised and systematic risk assessment by EFSA, followed by a Union authorisation decision.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. With our vote in favour, the Spanish Socialists are committed to simplifying the procedures for the authorization of new foods. The European Regulation currently in force dates back to 1997, the date from which there has been a great evolution in the new food sector and its ingredients. The revision of this regulation is therefore necessary to keep up with scientific and technological advances.  The new legislation includes the following proposals: it centralizes the authorisation procedure and eliminates the previous national assessment, which implies a reduction of the administrative burden for both food business operators and national authorities; implies a reduction in the time and costs for obtaining an authorisation for a new food; makes individual authorisations generic and thus facilitates market access for SMEs; establishes a simplified procedure for traditional third-country foods that improves the access of third-country operators to the European market; and ensures a high level of public health through a centralised and systematic risk assessment by EFSA, followed by a Union authorisation decision.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I fully support the proposal for legislation that will control and guarantee trade in new foods. The Union must reaffirm its role as guarantor of the health and well-being of its citizens and consumers, and as such, protect, by means of appropriate checks, that new foods arriving on our tables are safe for human and environmental health.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to abstain in the vote on the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on new food products because I am not entirely satisfied with the compromise reached with the Council. The issue of new foods is a very sensitive issue. On the one hand, we find the fundamental values of protecting human health, defending healthy food and the characteristics of European products and protecting consumer rights; on the other hand, the legal need to adapt an outdated regulation, to support the European food industry in global competition and job creation and to support scientific innovation. I believe that legislation is necessary because of the technological advances that have taken place over almost 20 years compared with the 1997 regulation, knowing that these new products would still reach our tables due to globalisation. However, its content must take account of the principles of precaution, environmental protection and health. I therefore supported the amendments aimed at providing for greater control power for Parliament, a regulation that pending specific regulations requires, an indication of the origin of the product from cloned animals and a call for a moratorium on foods produced by nanotechnology, which were unfortunately rejected by this House.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on novel foods, as I welcome clear legislation and improved consumer protection. I very much support the report prepared by my group colleague Jom Nicholson.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I have advocated a revision of the current food assessment legislation. Against the background of a highly technological food industry, it is important that legislation can keep pace with current developments in the production and processing of food. At the same time, it must also be possible for companies to be able to go through authorisation procedures for new foods as efficiently as possible.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained in the final vote on this report, as it fails to ensure sufficiently strong provisions for protection of public health and consumer interest. Playing down the importance of the precautionary principle, especially with regards to the application of new technologies used in food production, is not an option. Furthermore, it is a matter of concern that the draft regulation opens the door for food derived from cloned animals or their offspring, despite the strong opposition from Parliament evident in the vote during the September plenary. The current wording, moreover, allows the Commission to update the list of novel foods by means of implementing acts, which precludes scrutiny by Parliament.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. The authorisation and use of new foodst foods and food ingredients has been harmonised in the European Union since 1997. The procedure has so far consisted of pre-marketing applications for authorisation being assessed first by a Member State, the Commission circulating the initial assessment report for observations and objections from all Member States and, if no informed safety objections were raised, the new food could be placed on the market. The Regulation we adopted today replaces this procedure with a centralised one at European level by the European Food Safety Agency. This change is positive because it implies, inter alia, that applications for authorisation of the same food can no longer be submitted in several countries and that the time limit for deciding whether or not to authorise a new food in the EU will be shorter.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. The Nicholson report was designed to regulate the introduction of new foods.  These new foods include foods containing nanomaterials. These nanomaterials are very small particles that can give food the properties desired by industrialists (color, sparkling, melting...). They are suspected by the scientific community to be dangerous to health because their size allows them to pass through cell membranes. There is therefore a risk that tomorrow a health scandal will arise because of these new molecules. I had proposed a ban on foods containing nanomaterials. This proposal was rejected by the majority of the assembly.  Similarly, these MEPs rejected the labelling of meat from cloned animals and their offspring.  From the transparency of authorisations to compliance with the precautionary principle, all the proposals that the ENVI Committee had made to protect the consumer were rejected. So I voted against it.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against the Nicholson report on new foods. This term covers a wide variety of realities, from traditional products from third countries to foods containing nanomaterials and insects. I am not hostile to the consumption of insects, although my brain and my stomach of French, yet accustomed to snails, are a little reluctant to consume it personally. And these exotic products must be controlled with the same rigour as more traditional foods in our latitudes. On the other hand, I am concerned about the potential health risks posed by nanomaterials. They are ignored in the final text, which authorizes their use in food products. I am also concerned about the role of the European Food Safety Agency. It has demonstrated in the past its unreliability, on GMOs for example. And the European Commission does not hesitate to ignore its most cautious opinions. I am touched by the European Union's interest in the contents of my plate, but I would prefer that it favour the presence of local products from farms that would make our farmers live with dignity.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report, which seeks to determine what are considered 'new foods', since, although the Commission understands that this report is the result of consensus, the negotiation in the tripartite dialogue did not address issues of paramount importance, such as the definition of the concept of 'new food' itself. It does not include post-marketing monitoring or monitoring of such foods, nor does it emphasize the importance of proper labelling on the product so that the consumer can make a sufficiently informed decision regarding their use.  As far as food security is responsible, we understand that the precautionary principle should prevail and consider this report insufficient for the proper treatment of foods comprising nanomaterials, clones (or their descendants) and other genetic engineering applied to food.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, alongside my fellow Labour MEPs, voted in favour of three S&D amendments to this report but abstained on the motion as a whole. Whilst the report is not so bad as to warrant voting against, the Ulster Unionist rapporteur failed to ensure that the final text of the draft regulation includes sufficiently strong provisions for protection of public health and consumer interest. As a Labour MEP I do not agree with playing down the importance of the precautionary principle, especially with regards to the application of new technologies used in food production. Furthermore, the draft regulation opens the door for food derived from cloned animals or their offspring, despite strong opposition from the Parliament in the September plenary. Finally, the current wording allows the Commission to update the list of novel foods by means of implementing acts which excludes Parliament’s scrutiny.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. On Wednesday 28 October, I voted in favour of the report on the European Parliament and Council's proposed regulation on 'new foods'. The concept of new food generally refers to foodstuffs whose consumption in the European Union was negligible before May 1997, that is, before the current regulation came into force. The European regulations on new foods needed to be revised in order to simplify procedures and, above all, to comply with changes in markets and new technologies. Therefore, this compromise adopted in the plenary session seems to me to be balanced. It will ensure strict control of new foods and good consumer information, while ensuring faster marketing of safe and innovative foods in the European Union. I therefore welcome the adoption of the European Parliament's position, and hope that the agreement between the Council and the European Parliament on this text can be quickly endorsed.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. I approved the draft text to encourage food innovation through a new simplified authorisation procedure for new foods. This proposal was intended to replace an old regulation that is now inadequate. The agri-food sector is evolving, adapting and constantly improving. A legislative framework to respond to the progress of recent years, for example with regard to nanotechnology and cell and tissue cultures, is needed. A new procedure for the authorisation of new foods will allow for greater legal certainty and reduce the administrative burdens of SMEs. When deciding whether to allow a new food, the European Commission will have to apply the precautionary principle if the safety of that food cannot be assessed or in the event of scientific uncertainty. The text stipulates that the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) should carry out an assessment whenever a food is likely to have an impact on human health. The text states that animal testing should be replaced, reduced or improved. In addition, the repetition of animal experiments should, if possible, be avoided. The European Commission would be required to publish a summary of each application.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on novel foods because I support this review of an outdated and cumbersome 1997 law, with a view to streamlining the procedure for novel food applications and making the authorisation of novel foods easier and faster for businesses and more transparent for consumers, while maintaining a high standard of food safety.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. – With our vote in favour, the Spanish Socialists are committed to simplifying the procedures for the authorisation of new foods. The European Regulation currently in force dates back to 1997, the date from which there has been a great evolution in the new food sector and its ingredients. The revision of this regulation is therefore necessary to keep up with scientific and technological advances.  The new legislation includes the following proposals: it centralizes the authorisation procedure and eliminates the previous national assessment, which implies a reduction of the administrative burden for both food business operators and national authorities; implies a reduction in the time and costs for obtaining an authorisation for a new food; makes individual authorisations generic and thus facilitates market access for SMEs; establishes a simplified procedure for traditional third-country foods that improves the access of third-country operators to the European market; and ensures a high level of public health through a centralised and systematic risk assessment by EFSA, followed by a Union authorisation decision.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this new regulation that updates an outdated procedure for novel food applications which became law in 1997. The proposal ensures food safety, protects public health and secures the functioning of the internal market for food, while supporting innovation in the food sector. It will streamline the authorisation procedure through centralisation at Union level, while improving efficiency and transparency. The proposal also makes it easier for traditional foods from countries outside the European Union to enter the EU market.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was in favour of this report in order to help protect public health. New foods or food ingredients (‘novel foods’) require safety assessment and authorisation before they can be placed on the EU market. The current authorisation process covering novel foods is seen by the food industry as complex, expensive and time- consuming. In addition, stakeholders agree that updating the current Novel Foods Regulation is urgently needed to reflect scientific and technological advances. Products should obviously not pose a risk to human health but in addition they should also not pose a risk to animal welfare or to the environment.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP opposes the Commission legislative proposal for a regulation on novel foods. The new proposal, with the removal of the former novel food categories, would put at risk foods already legally on the market which could be challenged under the new regulation. We are concerned that this would cause legal uncertainty for operators, and if products already on sale were to be withdrawn for further assessment this would compromise consumer confidence. We also oppose the new authorisation system proposal that would introduce a centralised authorisation process.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. This is a great initiative that the European Parliament has just taken. New foods are foods with negligible consumption such as insects that have been the new culinary trend of recent years. That says negligible does not say harmless.  That is why I welcome the balance we have achieved, which is to ensure strict control of these products, good consumer information and support for European companies that dare to venture into the production of new foods.

name: Jan Huitema (ALDE)
text: Written. 'The VVD delegation considers that the Regulation on Novel Foods is an improvement for food producers by simplifying, accelerating and centralising the procedure for the marketing of novel foods. Producers will also have the opportunity to market their product directly to the European single market. However, the VVD delegation expresses its concerns about the possible cost of such an authorisation procedure for producers of insects intended for human consumption already on the market in the Netherlands. The European Commission should therefore ensure a smooth and rapid transition with a minimum of administrative burdens for the entrepreneurs concerned. The VVD continues to monitor this situation very closely and is in contact with the producers concerned. Legal ambiguity has led to this undesirable situation. However, because the VVD delegation considers that this new legislation creates legal clarity and benefits for producers, the VVD delegation votes in favour.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ Voted with the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council on new food, as it revises the outdated 1997 law and simplifies the application procedure for new food and speeds up and facilitates its authorisation, while increasing transparency for the benefit of consumers.  Scientific and technological advances in the food sector require an updated definition of new foods, and it is necessary accordingly to ensure a high level of protection of human health. The obsolescence of the existing definition has been confirmed by producers, experts and stakeholders of the food industry, as it lacks legal certainty and a clear meaning of what the new food actually entails. For the above reasons, I support this report.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to regulate the marketing of new foods, foods that did not exist in the European Union before 1997, such as insect-based food or nanomaterials. All of these new foods would pose a potential danger to consumers as these nanoparticles are likely to penetrate human cells. There is a need for better regulation, labelling and even outright bans. Unfortunately, not all of these precautionary measures have been adopted by the Council.  Our group has called for a ban on the use of these foodstuffs. I voted against this report.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP opposes the Commission legislative proposal for a regulation on novel foods. The new proposal, with the removal of the former novel food categories, would put at risk foods already legally on the market which could be challenged under the new regulation. We are concerned that this would cause legal uncertainty for operators, and if products already on sale were to be withdrawn for further assessment this would compromise consumer confidence. We also oppose the new authorisation system proposal that would introduce a centralised authorisation process.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague James Nicholson's report on new foods. New legislation was needed in light of technological developments in this sector. Definitions of new foods have been clarified and clarified to include the impact of new technologies and simplified procedures to promote innovation and the proper functioning of the single market. This report strengthens consumer health protection by introducing a faster method of assessing food safety and transparency in authorisation procedures. The report has been adopted, which I welcome.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ In December 2013, the EC presented a proposal to clarify the definition of novel foods and to take into account new technologies in food making, and streamline and speed up the authorisation process; as until then it was considered as food that was not used for human consumption to a significant degree within the Union before the 15 May 1997. The report of the ENVI Committee on the matter was good; managing to include engineered nanomaterial food and food derived from cloned animals in the scope of it; however, the outcome of the trilogues does not satisfy us. Of course it is better than the original EC proposal; it includes animal welfare concerns and labelling but still there some important points that should have been included. First, the responsibility of whether a food is considered novel falls into the food operators, only when they are unsure, they shall consult the MS. Moreover, everything (establishing list of novel foods, adding, removing specifications, etc.) will be done by implementing acts; and also, the EFSA MAY give its opinion on a novel food upon request of the EC. Hence, following the precautionary principle, and since 1AM block AMs (trilogue) have been carried to the detriment of block 2AMs (ENVI Committee AMs), EH Bildu has voted against both the Commission proposal and legislative resolution.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which concerns foodstuffs that were very little consumed before 1997 by humans. The aim of this report is to adapt EU legislation to these new products to ensure a high level of health protection, while ensuring the proper functioning of the internal market.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Novel Foods refers to the type of new food products that have not previously been consumed in the European Union or are produced by previously unknown methods. This includes non-EU regional products, newly produced nutrients and extracts from well-known foods. The first entry on these products appeared in European legislation in 1997 and has not been amended since. The proposed amendments aim to update and harmonise existing standards in order to eliminate legal uncertainties and increase consumer safety. Technological developments should be taken into account and rules simplified in order to exclude products covered by other regulations from their scope. It is necessary to introduce criteria so that Member States can clearly determine which products belong to the relevant novel foods category. A transparent and easily accessible list of products is needed, which will be regularly supplemented and thus sensitive to market developments. Amendments to improve regulation are necessary in the face of rapidly changing production technologies and increasing access to non-EU goods. However, it should be borne in mind that the proposed amendments are intended to ensure consumer safety and this must remain an essential condition for any changes.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I do not agree with this report, as cloning is also expected to come within the scope of this regulation.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Legislation is often not accompanied by scientific and technological developments in the European Union, so is the case with the Novel Food Regulation, which was adopted in 1997, and the food sector has also changed considerably since then. That is why I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the EP and the Council on novel food at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg. This regulation provides for new and uniform EU rules that will facilitate and simplify the procedure for the registration of new food. These rules will significantly reduce the costs and duration of the procedure required for the food safety assessment procedure and for obtaining authorisation in the EU. The Regulation also provides that, in certain cases, in the absence of clarity on product safety, the European Food Safety Authority will have to assess the impact of this food and products on human health. I believe that harmonising the rules and reducing red tape in these rules is also a step towards a single EU market.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on the final vote on this report. The rapporteur failed to ensure that the final text of the draft regulation includes sufficiently strong provisions for protection of public health and consumer interest. I do not agree with playing down the importance of the precautionary principle, especially with regard to the application of new technologies used in food production. Furthermore, the draft regulation opens the door for food derived from cloned animals or their offspring, despite the strong opposition from Parliament evident in its vote at the September plenary.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Novel food is a food for human consumption considered innovative or a food produced using new technologies and production processes, including cloning. The first problem is that the labelling of novel food will be done through implementing acts. Secondly, the definition of novel food is still unclear. Consumers should be enabled to make informed choices regarding the use of novel foods and not be misled about their purchases. I voted against this report because there are still many changes to implement.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour of Mr Nicholson's report. After lengthy negotiations, we managed to find a good compromise, necessary to replace the old regulation, which dates back to 1997. New products are now part of the common food supply. Furthermore, both in Italy and in Europe, we have a large community of foreigners and we must therefore adapt the consumables on our continent, also bringing them into line with the needs and tastes of the citizens of other countries who have had access to the European continent. The overall picture of the standard will give our industries the opportunity to be more competitive by innovating and placing new products on the market. Finally, I would like to remind consumers that the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) will monitor everything that is placed on the market, guaranteeing European citizens the highest levels of safety.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against Mr Nicholson's report on new foods. Unfortunately, the text from the trilogue was adopted. All of this will therefore be governed by acts of enforcement that are beyond the control of Parliament. Products from cloned animals and products with nanomaterials will not be labelled. The consumer is deprived of any information that allows him to choose. The principle of the internal market is preferred over consumer safety. Permission may be issued despite partial information, etc.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it allows "new foods" (nanomaterials) to be put on the market without sufficient precautions, even though they are suspected of being toxic. Lobbies once again trump health safety.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The one which was not used for human consumption to a significant extent in the Union before 15 May 1997 is considered 'new food', and also includes traditional third-country food which, for at least 25 years, has been part of the usual diet of a significant number of its population. There are many aspects to this report that we do not agree with and which have not been improved by the proposed amendments, since they were rejected, in particular the permissiveness in relation to nanomaterials and clones and their descendants, the use of implementing acts rather than delegated acts, and the limitation of Member States to ban new food. To top it all off, there is no background analysis of the non-need for these new foods, the interests of large multinationals and industry to bring them to market, the linkage with regulatory convergences for international treaties (the TTIP, for example) and the need to promote local, seasonal consumption that is sustainable and not these "new foods". That is why I voted against this report.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The rapid development of the food market, linked to the introduction of innovation in its field over the last 20 years, has forced us, as co-rapporteur of the European Union, to take appropriate decisions that will ensure consumer safety. I would like to point out that I am very pleased with the agreed tripartite agreement on this issue. The emergence of so-called novel foods in Europe requires the adoption of legislation at the level of Community law, which is why I voted in favour of it. It is worth noting that the planned regulation will also cover traditional food from non-EU countries, which have been considered safe and harmless to health for years. I would like to stress that this will avoid excessive, numerous checks by the Member States, which will speed up the introduction of these products into the European market. I believe that this will be a good solution for smaller entrepreneurs, as the whole procedure will be less costly, more transparent and simplified and uniform. We must not forget that products from this sector are currently treated differently in different Member States.  At the same time, by voting in favour of the project, I want entrepreneurs to have a level playing field in accessing and selling them. The standards developed in the tripartite compromise will not only increase the competitiveness and attractiveness of new food, but also protect the lives of EU citizens at an appropriate level, which, in my opinion, is one of the most important elements of this regulation.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it updates legislation which has been in place since 1997. The report aims to improve access for novel foods to the EU market, while maintaining a high level of consumer protection. It updates the categories of food which constitute novel foods and also provides for the introduction of a centralised EU authorisation system in order to enable safe, innovative foods to reach the EU market faster.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Regulation (EC) No. 258/97 of the European Parliament and the Council and Commission Regulation (EC) No 258/97. 1852/2001 it was established that any new food or ingredient should be approved before being placed on the market in order to maintain a high level of protection of human health and consumer interests.  The list of foods and ingredients has expanded significantly, including foods containing microorganisms, fungi, algae or food with a deliberately modified primary molecular structure, therefore the existing definition of new foods does not cover new species and ingredients. The scope and definition of new food is a contentious issue, but also the need for a simpler approval process. The aim of the Regulation is to introduce a more practical safety assessment without the negative impact on human health, not to be against the interest of consumers and not to adversely affect the functioning of the internal market. I supported MP James Nicholson's report taking into account progress in the food industry which requires the refurbishment of legislation to protect intellectual property and harmonise the authorisation process without reducing the level of consumer protection. In Croatia, in the case of new food being placed on the market, the entity must inform the Ministry of Health and is obliged to do the same if new scientific knowledge occurs as to whether new food is dangerous for human health.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on new foods, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 28/10/2015.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against it. All foods that did not exist in the European Union before 1997 are referred to as "new foods", which include, for example, foods based on insects, nanomaterials or other products. As a reminder, it should be mentioned that nanomaterials are suspected to be toxic. It is because of the risk posed by these nanomaterials that we cannot support this text.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on new foodstuffs. In 2013, the Commission adopted a proposal to revise the New Food Regulation, which aims to ensure food safety, protect public health and ensure the functioning of the internal food market, while promoting innovation in the food sector. The ultimate aim of this proposal is to update the categories of new foods, taking into account the impact of new technologies on food, to review the authorisation process, in order to improve its efficiency and transparency, and to simplify procedures for food imported from third countries with historically proven safe food use.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The rules on new foodstuffs date back to Regulation No 258 of the European Parliament and Of Council No 258 of 1997, which to date are totally inadequate in relation to scientific and technological advances affecting the food sector. This progress has seen the development of a number of new food products or ingredients with intentionally modified primary molecular structure not covered by the 1997 Regulation. This therefore requires a change. Mr Nicholson's report, which I support by voting in favour of, aims to encourage a new harmonised EU-wide procedure of the Food Safety Authority (EFSA) which should carry out an assessment in cases where a food has an effect on human health, including new genetically modified food, present on the EU internal market.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The adoption of amendments has led to food from cloned animals also falling within the scope of this Regulation. It is strictly to be rejected that Member States should be forced to allow food and feed from cloned animals on their territory. I therefore do not support this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. A new food is a food that has not yet been used for human consumption to a significant degree in the EU. The text proposes some ways to ensure the safety of consumers in these cases. But the account is not there! The responsibility for defining what a new food is rests with food operators and it is only when they are unsure that they consult the Member State in which they intend to market it. EFSA (European Food Safety Agency) can, at the commission's request, give its opinion on a new food but only on the basis of the elements provided without the possibility of asking for more details. Finally, all power is left to the Commission to act by act of execution to establish the list of new foods. I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The authorisation to place food on the Union market shall be granted provided that food security is fully complied with. According to legislation adopted by the European Parliament, authorisation procedures for the introduction of new foods will be centralised at European level through the European Food Safety Authority. It shall be the entity responsible for the assessment and certification of the admission of these foods. Greater and better regulation is essential to ensure compliance with a high and demanding degree of food security in the European Union.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this resolution as it will promote innovation in the food industry and in the realm of novel foods in particular. The new regulation seeks to update the current definitions and requirements for placing novel foods on the market. These food items would also have to be evaluated and authorised via a fully harmonised procedure before entering the market and deemed safe for consumption.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. After the blocking of the dossier for several years, I am pleased that the European Parliament has finally voted on the report on new foods. It was essential that eu legislation dating back to 1997 be updated to take account of the many new foods and changing eating habits. I therefore welcome the fact that the procedure for authorising new foods, now centralised at European level, is thus simplified in order, in particular, to encourage innovation without compromising food security. The introduction of traditional third-country foods deemed safe to the European market should also be easier. More transparency is also planned to reassure consumers. Finally, animal testing in the food field should also be reduced as duplication of tests will be avoided as soon as possible.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Since the food sector is one of the most ininerable sectors in the Union's internal market, I welcome the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on novel foods, as it is important that new facts are reflected in the legislation. According to some scientific forecasts, it is difficult to conceive in the future that it will be possible to feed gmo-free humanity if, at the same time, we want to increase the spread of organic farming. It is thus likely that, just as new forms of breeding have been promoted, genetically modified crops will also be promoted as raw materials for food production. I therefore consider it important to give clear rules to this trend. In this context, however, I reject the path of animal cloning, even given that a survey by the International Food Information Council showed that more than half of consumers would not buy meat from a cloned animal and even label cloning as immoral. Moreover, the reproduction of animals in this way is no more advantageous than reproduction by natural means, and in addition, there are still many question marks regarding the impact on human health.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained in the final vote on the report on novel foods, as I am not fully satisfied with the text of the regulation. In my opinion, the report has been watered down and is outdated. The rules on novel foods have to be adjusted to reflect technological and scientific progress while at the same time taking into consideration the need to ensure food safety, to protect public health and to secure the functioning of the internal market for food, while supporting innovation in the food sector.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The rules on new foods were laid down in Regulation (EC) No 258/97 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 5 May 1997 and Commission Regulation (EC) No 1852/2001 of 20 September 2001. The protection of human health and consumer interests requires the pre-marketing authorisation of new foods or food ingredients. At the same time, fundamental scientific and technical developments in the food industry have made the definition of new foods in Regulation (EC) No 258/97 obsolete and should therefore be reviewed.  As early as 2008, the European Commission proposed to modernise the Regulation, but the Conciliation Committee agreement was thwarted by the issue of the placing on the market of food from cloned animals. The Commission therefore made a new proposal in December 2013, which included issues on which there had previously been agreement but did not address the issue of cloning, for which the Commission made specific proposals. Parliament's Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety tabled more than 100 amendments to the proposal in its report, but it recommended that parliament adopt it. I voted accordingly on the proposal.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal submitted by the Commission concerns the possibility for Member States to limit or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory, in certain circumstances, after such products are authorised ("opt-out").  The adoption of this proposal would have a negative impact in a number of areas, notably on the European agricultural sector, where there is free movement and no border control, and the sector's economy is also affected within the internal market and the WTO's own rules on trade. The competitiveness of the agricultural sector is at stake, and the European Union is dependent on the supply of genetically modified proteins and is a regression in the economic progress made to date. In this sequence, I am o-going against the adoption of this proposal, as it will affect economic regulation and affect the legal certainty of the European agricultural sector, and also have implications for economic relations with third countries.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this Nicholson report is to define and regulate the introduction of new food products known as new foods. In this text, the Council has removed all security measures adopted by Parliament. As a reminder, new foods are made up of any food that did not exist in the European Union before 1997. For example, they cover foods based on insects, nanomaterials or other products. It is therefore necessary that these products so defined can only be put on the market in accordance with the precautionary principle, with a particular labelling, and their proven safety with regard to health and the environment. I regret, however, that this text does not propose the ban on nanomaterials in food. This reduces the protection of consumers in advance and promotes remedies after the fact through objections. I abstained on this vague text because even if the report is intended to be more protective, there is a risk generated by nanomaterials and a legitimate distrust of the Commission and EFSA.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The draft regulation opens the door for food derived from cloned animals or their offspring, despite strong opposition from the Parliament as voted in September plenary. Finally, the current wording allows the Commission to update the list of novel foods by means of implementing acts which excludes Parliament’s scrutiny. At the same time, the rapporteur failed to ensure that the final text of the draft regulation includes sufficiently strong provisions for protection of public health and consumer interest.
