The EPLP cannot agree with playing down the importance of the precautionary principle, especially with regards to the application of new technologies used in food production.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the european Parliament and council's proposed regulation on new foods. The aim is to authorise the revision of the regulations on foodstuffs whose human consumption was negligible in the Union before 1997. The aim of this text is to facilitate innovation and protect consumer food security by proposing to clarify and clarify the definition of new foods that may contain elements that may have an impact on food, such as nanomaterials or tissues and culture cells. It improves the effectiveness of the authorisation process for these new foods by centralising their assessment at the level of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). It also introduces a faster and better-suited method of safety assessment for traditional foods from third countries. Finally, generic authorisations will be shared among all stakeholders and not just granted to petitioners, which should benefit SMEs in particular.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the draft report, as it has established clear deadlines and definitions for the whole process of placing new food on the market, taking into account the precautionary, environmental and food safety principle, and also providing safeguards against a negative impact on human health. The proposal, which has become necessary to ensure food safety, aims to protect public health and ensure the functioning of the internal market for food products, while supporting innovation in the food sector. Its purpose is to streamline the authorisation procedure so as to improve its efficiency and transparency. It also clarifies the definition of a new food product, taking into account new technologies that have an impact on food production. Finally, a faster and more appropriate safety assessment is introduced for traditional foods from third countries that have a reliable history of food production.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. The compromise on new foods is balanced. It will ensure strict control of these and good consumer information, while ensuring the support of our companies and the proper functioning of the internal market.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained in the vote on the proposal for a regulation on novel foods.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report because I believe that this, like the Commission's proposal, is, while it wants to simplify the certification procedures for new foods to be marketed on the EU market, could endanger the health of citizens.  The Commission has correctly identified since 2008 the need for new EU regulation for the authorisation of new foods and the need to facilitate procedures in this case, but I believe that the centralisation of this decision and the abolition of individual authorisations in favour of a generic authorisation system essentially means that in certain cases there will be products that will be authorised without individual evaluation.  This, in my view, poses a real danger to the health of EU citizens because certain products affecting human health could be authorised. However, when we are also talking about centralised authorisation, it means that there will no longer be any subsequent filters to identify these products, but they will be directly part of the citizens' diet.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the EP-Council agreement at 1st reading because, in my opinion, this is the right response to technological progress, which has created and created many innovative new foods that are not regulated by the current regulation. I see it as beneficial to introduce a centralised authorisation procedure for new foods in the EU, which should lead to a reduction in the cost of authorisation procedures. The widespread practice of double assessment to date energising an average cost of BETWEEN EUR 20 000 and EUR 45 000, which is, in particular, a very burdensome and unnecessarily high sum for SMEs in particular.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report for a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on novel foods also includes cloned meat in its scope. Although the report also opposes the placing on the market of nanomaterials in food and feed, it also makes it possible to import cloned meat. I reject this and have therefore also spoken out against the report.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I objected to this report which proposes insufficient regulation for consumer protection with regard to new foods (foods not consumed in Europe before 1997). The identification and definition of a new food is always entrusted to farmers who are not obliged to consult either the Member State or EFSA (European Food Safety Agency) to establish the presence of a new food, the latter of which must be seized by the Commission. In the face of the dangers posed by the presence of nanomaterials, among others, in new foods, it is important to generalize and objectify their controls by an independent authority to ensure that there are no hidden irregularities that could harm the health of the consumer.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. A review of the Novel Foods Regulation is necessary in so far as a number of scientific and technological developments have taken place in the food industry in recent decades and it is appropriate that legislation takes account of this new reality.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – A high level of protection of human health, consumer interests and the environment is essential for the effective functioning of the internal market. All novel foods must be based on scientific studies demonstrating that they are safe to consume. In order to protect human health across the EU, a ban on the placing on the market of nanomaterials for human and animal consumption and the use of nanotechnologies in food production must be applied until the testing methods for nanomaterials suitable for use are approved. People's health must not be put at risk and you will allow food that has not been studied to be placed on the market. Food licensing is a very sensitive issue for each country and particular caution is needed. The authorisation process for new and scientifically researched foods should become faster and cheaper. It should be noted that States should have the right to temporarily restrict or suspend the marketing and use of the food or food ingredient concerned in their territory because of a potential risk to human health or the environment.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The New Food Regulation is 'cut and sewn' to the requirements of business groups already active in the sector concerned or intending to expand into it, seeing profitable prospects. The creation of an exclusively centralised Eu-Union mechanism excludes the possibility for Member States and their competent authorities to control and prohibit the marketing and use of new foodstuffs on their territory. At the same time, the Regulation leaves out food derived from cloned animals and their offspring, while excluding the prohibition or even stricter scientific controls of foodstuffs derived from nanomaterials and nanotechnologies, leaving consumers' health exposed to risks. Once again the EU institutions do not hesitate to leave workers' health and lives at the mercy of monopolistic gains and interests, demonstrating the EU's hostile nature to the people.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP opposes the Commission legislative proposal for a regulation on novel foods. The new proposal, with the removal of the former novel food categories, would put at risk foods already legally on the market which could be challenged under the new regulation. We are concerned that this would cause legal uncertainty for operators, and if products already on sale were to be withdrawn for further assessment this would compromise consumer confidence. We also oppose the new authorisation system proposal that would introduce a centralised authorisation process.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. – I supported the report because of the need to recast European legislation in the field of food or novel foods, which aims to protect human health and allows innovation and access for food consumed outside Europe.  Under the new Regulation, the procedures for assessing the safety of new food and licensing it will be harmonised at EU level. For any novel food that could have consequences for human health, the evaluation will be made by the European Food Safety Authority.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I supported this proposal because I think it is necessary to adapt the existing legislative framework to today and to the development of new technologies and types of food that are occurring on the market. The issue of nanotechnology with the advancement of technology development is becoming an important issue of food safety. That is why I supported the amendments tabled by the Environment, Health and Food Safety Committee and requested that special care be taken precisely on nanotechnology in the food industry.  I need to establish a rigorous research and oversight process of the European Food Safety Agency, as well as appropriate labelling of such food. I also expect that "new food", especially one that has certainly been used for a long time in third countries and comes to europeans' tables, will become the subject of a clearer and more efficient approval process.  Citizens of Europe, consumers need to know what they are eating and must be informed about the composition of the end product they are buying for consumption. This EU act allows safe and innovative food to be placed on the EU market after the necessary tests, without compromising the existing high level of health security.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This Nicholson report aims to define and regulate the introduction of new food products known as new foods. In this text, the Council has removed all security measures adopted by Parliament. As a reminder, new foods are made up of any food that did not exist in the European Union before 1997. For example, they cover foods based on insects, nanomaterials or other products. It is therefore necessary that these products so defined can only be put on the market in accordance with the precautionary principle, with a particular labelling, and a proven safety with regard to health and the environment. I regret, however, that this text does not propose the ban on nanomaterials in food. This reduces the protection of consumers in advance and promotes remedies after the fact through objections. I abstained on this vague text because, even if the report is intended to be more protective, there is a risk generated by nanomaterials and a legitimate distrust of the Commission and EFSA.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Opening up space for innovation in the food sector is not possible without increasing the efficiency and transparency of the new food authorisation procedure, and the work on speeding up the assessment of traditional food from third countries with a history of safe use is particularly commendable.  At the same time, I support the efforts of the Council and Parliament to ensure high standards of public health and food safety through this Regulation and to define precisely the concept of new food and new technologies affecting food production.  Particularly important are the amendments in relation to an earlier proposal that gives Parliament greater control over the authorisation of new food, and stricter regulation and more precise definitions in the field of food produced by nanotechnology and food derived from cloned animals or their descendants. In particular, it is a requirement that these foods be properly labelled for final consumers, and in the case of nanomaterials, that new testing methods be developed and the precautionary principle applied to reduce potential human exposure to nanomaterials.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support rapporteur James Nicholson's report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on new food, which is already the Commission's second attempt to reform the regime on new food in the EU, dating back to 1997. The current regulatory framework has been criticised as particularly difficult, time-consuming and expensive for new food approval. As a consequence, many food companies in the EU, and SMEs, did not want to develop and market new foods or food ingredients, which will fall under the scope of new food.  The proposal introduces a faster and proportionate safety assessment for traditional food from third countries. In addition to the overall objective of ensuring food safety, the new regulation aims to simplify the authorisation process for new food by establishing a list of authorised new foods. The proposal is aimed at clarifying the definition of new food and thereby increasing legal certainty. The revision of the new food regulation is highly sensitive and indeed necessary given the scientific and technological advances in the food industry.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission adopted in December 2013 a proposal to revise the New Food Regulation with the aim of updating the categories of new foods, reviewing the authorisation process and simplifying procedures for food imported from third countries. Since Regulation (EC) No 258/97 came into force, a wide range of new food products and ingredients have been developed, including foods containing, consisting of or produced, from microorganisms, fungi and algae, or foods with an intentionally modified primary molecular structure. This type of food has called into question the adequacy of the current definition of 'new food products'. I therefore believe that an amendment to the regulation is absolutely necessary in the light of the scientific and technological progress made in the food sector. I voted in favour of this report in order to achieve greater clarity as soon as possible on the definition of 'new food products' and with the aim of providing for stricter provisions on consumer protection. My vote does not involve any judgment of substance with regard to the use of foods based on algae and insects which, personally, I find against.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In order to ensure an ever higher level of food safety and to ensure the public health of European citizens, the EU has proposed to amend and adapt the EU's new food regulations. The European Parliament has adopted this text to clarify European legislation in this area. I have spoken in favour of this text and I stress the importance of updating legislation affecting the daily lives of citizens.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The rules on so-called new foods (i.e. foods which were not used significantly for human consumption in the EU before May 1997) are currently in place in Regulation (EC) No 258/97 and Regulation (EC) No 1852/2001. In view of the scientific and technological progress made since the entry into force of these regulations, the Commission presented in December 2013 a proposal to review and adapt existing regulations, which was approved by ENVI with amendments in November 2014. Following interinstitutional negotiations between December 2014 and June 2015, an agreement was reached.  Under the compromise reached, the new rules aim to address the main concerns expressed in the broad consultation with operators in the sector, namely: clarification of the definition of new food; the subjection of new foods to a harmonised evaluation and authorisation process; simplification and rationalisation of the authorisation process; and the provision for a robust data protection regime. The new legislation also regulates, on a transitional basis, the placing on the market of food from cloned animals and defines what nanomaterials are. I voted in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP opposes the Commission legislative proposal for a regulation on novel foods. The new proposal, with the removal of the former novel food categories, would put at risk foods already legally on the market which could be challenged under the new regulation. We are concerned that this would cause legal uncertainty for operators, and if products already on sale were to be withdrawn for further assessment this would compromise consumer confidence. We also oppose the new authorisation system proposal that would introduce a centralised authorisation process.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. It is a path fraught with pitfalls that the proposal for a "new food" regulation has travelled before arriving in plenary. After the failure of the negotiations in 2008, there was an urgent need to legislate to adapt the legal framework to the realities of today's food market. That is why I voted for the Nicholson report without any additional amendments which risked bringing down the fragile compromise reached in June 2015 with the Council.  The European Union is based on a comprehensive and strict regulatory framework for food safety. It must continue to promote its local products, but at the same time it must make room for new food trends and alternative sources of protein: mushrooms, seaweed, or grilled insects, even if they still represent a niche market for human consumption. This variety of offer is an undeniable plus for the European consumer. The new European legislation regulates these new foods and provides safeguards in terms of food ethics, which suits me perfectly. I am thinking of the inclusion of foods derived from cloned animals in the legislative field and the necessary limitation of animal testing.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. Parliament has adopted a new procedure for authorising new foods (foods that were not on the market before 1997, including those containing nanomaterials or from animal cloning) which is not acceptable to environmentalists. Parliament has not lived up to Europeans' concerns about new foods. By refusing, on the one hand, to support the environmental amendment calling for a moratorium on the presence of nanoparticles in food until an adequate European health and environmental assessment procedure has been developed. And, on the other hand, by rejecting our amendment to label foods derived from cloning that require new legislation. Finally, we asked for a veto for Parliament on the authorisation of any new food in the single market. Environmentalists cannot therefore support a text far too far removed from the health concerns of our fellow citizens.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on new foods (e.g. insects, seaweed-based foods or new dyes). European legislation needed to be updated to take account of technological, scientific and legal developments in this area. This is how we have provided for a harmonised authorisation and assessment procedure for the safety of these foods in the European Union. A new food can only be accepted on the European market if it is safe and does not mislead the consumer.  With this text, we ensure the proper functioning of the internal market, we simplify procedures, we promote innovation while protecting public health, which is why I supported it.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. This proposal for a Regulation on new foods aims to ensure food security, protect public health and ensure the functioning of the internal market, while supporting innovation in the food sector. The proposal updates current legislation by creating a 'streamline' authorisation procedure, clarifies the definition of 'new food', introduces a faster and proportionate safety assessment for third-country 'traditional foods' which have a safe history of food and simplifies procedures for public authorities and private actors.  The final outcome of the negotiations with the Council includes many aspects claimed by this Parliament, such as the provisional inclusion of cloned animal feed within the scope of the Regulation until specific legislation enters into force or the reintroduction of old food categories and the introduction of new ones, with a view to including food from micro-organisms, fungi and insects.  Although the final text has some gaps with regard to the development of the list of categories of new foods or for foods containing nanotechnology, in order to adapt the rules on new foods to technological and scientific progress, I have decided to vote in favour of this reform.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. On the occasion of this report, I have supported several amendments calling for the following information to be accompanied by the following information to the consumer's attention when it is marketed and marketed within the Union, including when it comes to imports, until specific legislation on foods derived from cloned animals comes into force.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Commission Regulation (EC) No 258/97 and Commission Regulation (EC) No 1852/2001 are the legislative instruments establishing Union rules on food.  It is commonly accepted by consumers, food operators and policy makers that any new food or food ingredient requires prior authorisation to place it on the market in order to preserve a high level of protection of human health, its traceability and obviously the interests of consumers. However, the scientific and technological progress in the food sector has demonstrated the need to review the definition of "new foods" contained in Regulation (EC) No 258/97, so that new foods produced from micro-organisms, fungi and algae can be contemplated in particular. That is why I support Mr Nicholson's report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and the Council to close this gap by adapting the definition to new foods on the market and at the same time reducing unnecessary administrative burdens on the regulatory authorisation process in order to promote innovation and competitiveness in the European food sector.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which facilitates the marketing of new foods in the European Union. New foods define any food that was consumed by men negligible in the EU before 15 May 1997 (this date corresponds to the entry into force of the current regulation). It was therefore necessary to revise the existing regulations and modernise them in order to adapt them to the current market situation and to the new technologies that need to be taken into account, while simplifying procedures.  The adopted text is balanced: it guarantees strict control of new foods, ensures the transmission of correct information to consumers and also supports European companies by ensuring faster marketing.  In the end, the new text modernises, simplifies, streamlines and makes the European procedure for authorising new food more efficient and transparent.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as I support the European Commission's decision to update the regulation on categories of new foods and to simplify and improve authorisation procedures for food imported from third countries.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report, which seeks to determine what are considered 'new foods', since, although the Commission understands that this report is the result of consensus, the negotiation in the tripartite dialogue did not address issues of paramount importance, such as the definition of the concept of 'new food' itself. It does not include post-marketing monitoring or monitoring of such foods, nor does it emphasize the importance of proper labelling on the product so that the consumer can make a sufficiently informed decision regarding their use.  As far as food security is responsible, we understand that the precautionary principle should prevail and consider this report insufficient for the proper treatment of foods comprising nanomaterials, clones (or their descendants) and other genetic engineering applied to food.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The one which was not used for human consumption to a significant extent in the Union before 15 May 1997 is considered 'new food', and also includes traditional third-country food which, for at least 25 years, has been part of the usual diet of a significant number of its population. There are many aspects to this report that we do not agree with and which have not been improved by the proposed amendments, since they were rejected, in particular the permissiveness in relation to nanomaterials and clones and their descendants, the use of implementing acts rather than delegated acts, and the limitation of Member States to ban new food. To top it all off, there is no background analysis of the non-need for these new foods, the interests of large multinationals and industry to bring them to market, the linkage with regulatory convergences for international treaties (the TTIP, for example) and the need to promote local, seasonal consumption that is sustainable and not these "new foods". That is why I voted against this report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal voted on today aims to encourage innovation in the food sector, through a new and simplified procedure for new products and ingredients that are on the market. That is why I voted in favour. The previous legislation dates back to 1997, so it was necessary to update the rules in order to keep up with technological developments over the last 20 years. One of the most notable variations concerns the inclusion in the definition of "new food products" of foods with altered molecular structure, fungi, algae, insects and food obtained from cell cultures and tissues. Transparency will be increased through the new legislation, as the Commission will have to publish a summary of all new applications for authorisation and a list of rejected applications. The EU list of new authorised foods will therefore be available to the public.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained in the final vote of this report because the ECR rapporteur failed to ensure that the final text of the draft regulation includes sufficiently strong provisions for the protection of public health and consumer interest. The EPLP cannot agree with playing down the importance of the precautionary principle. The wording, as it stands, would allow the Commission to update the list of novel foods by means of implementing acts, excluding the scrutiny of Parliament. However, I would argue that the result of the trilogues weren't so bad as to make a vote against make sense, but the abstention will send a strong message to the UK food and drink industry, which is a leader in terms of technological innovation in this sector.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 All health standards should be maintained when new foods are approved at an accelerated rate. We cannot make the population of the EU experimental rabbits. I think it would be better for us to return to traditional Slovak foods such as chickpeas, wheat or barley groats, and also to breed rabbits, chickens and pigs at home.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ EU rules on new food were established on 15 May 1997 by Regulation No 1997. 158/97 of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission. Food retailers, shareholders and policymakers in the Union institutions agreed that any 'new food' or food product should undergo authorisation before being exposed to the market in order to maintain a high level of protection of human health and consumer interests.  In order to make rapid and major scientific and technological developments in the food sector, the suitability of the current definition of 'new food' has been questioned. The current definition does not cover the new type of food produced (or consists of) microorganisms, fungi and algae, therefore a revision of the definition enshrined in the Provision is highly necessary. I did not support this resolution, because I think it is essential to clarify the definitions and clarify the unknowns so that new foods do not have negative consequences on our health, consumer interest or the functioning of the internal market itself. If there is a significant change in the food production process, the same substance should be considered as new food. It should also be assessed in accordance with the relevant specific rules, so as not to call into question food safety.

name: Renate Sommer (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the compromise agreed with the Council on the revision of the Novel Foods Regulation. The food sector is one of the largest and most innovative in the EU. In order to compete fiercely, manufacturers are constantly developing new products, additives and manufacturing methods. We must take these developments into account. I therefore welcome the fact that the new regulation finally regulates the use of nanoparticles in food. These tiny particles can increase the stability of products, change the appearance, taste or consistency, or also improve the absorption of certain ingredients, such as .B vitamins. Centralisation of the authorisation procedure is also important. It makes applications simpler, cheaper and speeds up the procedure. The fact that the authorisation should no longer apply only to individual foods, but to the entire product category, also contributes to the reduction of bureaucracy. The simplified authorisation procedure also makes it easier for food that has so far only been consumed in other regions of the world,.B such as dried insects, to be exported to the EU. This also takes account of culinary globalisation.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The introduction of new types of food on the European market is only permissible if their safety is unconditionally ensured and the consumer is sufficiently informed about their exact origin and composition.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report because the safe movement of safe and healthy food significantly contributes to the health and well-being of citizens. It also has a significant impact on social and economic opportunities. I believe that the import of traditional food from third countries into the Union market should be facilitated, and it should be clarified that such food should be considered as traditional food only if it is obtained by primary production as set out in Article 1 (EC) No 100/2013. 178/2002, whether processed or unprocessed.  Attention should be paid to the setting of safety assessment criteria arising from new food. In order to stimulate R&D within the agri-food industry and thus to innovate, investment needs to be protected. As for the technology involved in the emergence of new food, it can have an impact on food and its safety.  It should therefore also be clarified that food should be considered as new food if it is subject to a production process that has not previously been applied in production, or if the food contains or consists of manufactured nanomaterials, as set out in Article 2(2) (t) of Regulation (EU) No 1999/2013. 1169/2011 of the European Parliament and the Council.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained from voting on this report because I do not believe that the final text of the draft regulation includes sufficiently strong provisions for the protection of public health and consumer interest. Furthermore, the draft regulation opens the door for food derived from cloned animals and their offspring, despite the strong opposition from Parliament expressed in the September plenary. That said, I do not believe that the outcome of the trilogues is sufficiently serious to justify voting against the report. Voting against would send a negative signal to the UK food and drink industry, which is a European forerunner in technological innovation.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ New foods represent food and food ingredients that were not used in the diet of people in the European Union to a significant extent before 1997. New foods are considered to be food derived from the use of new technologies, innovative foods or foods traditionally used in other countries but not in the European Union.  The current process of authorization of this type of food has proven to be complex, expensive and time-consuming. Consumer protection, food safety and effective authorisation must be priorities, but procedures need to be reformed and regulations updated for regulation to follow scientific and technological developments in this area. I think it is important to point out that in addition to the safety of human health, we must also take care of animal welfare and the environment.  Labels of such products must inform consumers in good quality and the origin must be clearly indicated. The most important areas updated by this proposal are the centralized procedure for authorization, simplification of the authorization process, better data protection and the introduction of the definition of nanomaterials, which will have to be improved in the future according to future knowledge. I support this proposal because I believe it contributes to better regulation of food safety in the European Union.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal. Although I fundamentally disagree with the functioning or very existence of today's system for approving new foods in the EU. However, the proposal makes this system more effective, thus bringing a little more freedom and a little less administrative burden in the summary.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on novel foods. Any legislation must be updated at all times. In recent years, the food industry has changed greatly, has made great strides, and technology has developed greatly, so we cannot wait any longer with a change in the law.  We need solutions that respond to the needs of the market and modern challenges. This regulation is good and balanced. We must reduce the administrative burden for SMEs and encourage progress and innovation in the food sector across Europe. We must not give up our highest standards in the world.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The revision of Regulation No 136/66/EEC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 22 December 200 In the case of new foodstuffs, it is necessary to take into question the scientific and technological developments in the food sector since 1997.  For us, the aim is to ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and the interests of consumers. It must be made clear that the priority is the consumer and the provision of security to the consumer, not the functioning of the internal market and competitiveness. The European Parliament's report is also moving in this direction, which is why we voted in favour of the text.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 No one can guarantee in an absolute and unequivocal way the suitability and safety of this new type of food and the impact it will surely have on the health of consumers. Our fixed position is the exclusive production and consumption of food whose primary molecular structure is not in any way modified or altered.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the field of new food to be an important area of innovation. This includes, inter alia, chia seeds, flavonoids from licorice, rapeseed, but also products containing insects, nanomaterials, algae or certain colouring matter. The proposal aims to protect public health, food safety and strengthen the functioning of the internal food market in relation to new products, while supporting the innovative food sector. I believe that only products which do not have a moral, environmental or health risk may be authorised for human or animal consumption. We therefore need regulation at EU level, plus tools such as labelling, consumer information or the introduction of an information campaign. The report takes steps towards the development of EU-wide rules on safety control and authorisation of new foods. While I supported most of the amendments, I abstained in the final vote because cornerstones that were important to me were not included in the final material, such as cloning and nanomaterials.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 New foods are a special category within the food industry at the level of EU Member States. It arose as a result of the need to regulate the technological processing of food with a view to marketing on the consumer market. Advances in processing technology over the time frame since the first regulation, dating back to 1997, make it necessary to revise European legislation in this area.  The new regulation proposed by the Council provides a number of advantages, such as the establishment of a single centralised and harmonised procedure at European level for the authorisation of new foods, data protection and legal certainty for companies submitting authorisation dossiers, reducing the administrative burden for small and medium-sized enterprises, adapting to new techniques and creating a favourable framework for innovation in the agri-food sector. At the same time, the new regulation excludes cloning issues, which are the subject of other legislative proposals, and provides for a simplified separate procedure for the placing on the market of traditional foods from third countries.  In order to ensure the protection of public health, the opinion of the European Food Safety Authority becomes essential, which is an important step forward. However, it may be useful to include the European Parliament institutionally in this decision-making process.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted against the new food report. It is not that I have anything against new foods, far from it, but I cannot understand that in this text it is proposed that Parliament no longer have a say or any power over the acceptance of future products. It is in this sense that my decision is motivated and results in a negative vote.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ To keep up with technological development and innovation, the EU considered it necessary to update the rules on novel foods. The current legislation dates back to 1997, therefore food and food ingredients which were not consumed in the EU to a significant degree before the entry into force of the current regulation are considered to be ‘novel’. The Commission’s proposal from December 2013 brought several changes compared to the 1997 regulation (e.g. a centralised authorisation process and the removal of specific categories of food from the scope of the regulation). The agreement with Council brought, for instance, improved transparency in the applications system, the re-introduction of the food categories in updated form and some new categories as well as safety assessment using the most up-to-date test methods. Given the length and complexity of the examination of the draft regulation on novel foods, I support the agreement reached with Council as an acceptable compromise and I hope for the swift implementation of the new rules.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i supported the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on novel foods because, by taking this regulation into account, no novel food to be put on the market will have a negative impact on human health, the interests of consumers or the functioning of the internal market.  However, the content of the new Regulation on novel foods is sensible and necessary in the light of the scientific and technological progress of the food industry since 1997 – the food sector has become one of the most competitive and innovative sectors in the Union's internal market and it is appropriate for the legislation to reflect the new situation.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report, which seeks to determine what are considered 'new foods', since, although the Commission understands that this report is the result of consensus, the negotiation in the tripartite dialogue did not address issues of paramount importance, such as the definition of the concept of 'new food' itself. It does not include post-marketing monitoring or monitoring of such foods, nor does it emphasize the importance of proper labelling on the product so that the consumer can make a sufficiently informed decision regarding their use.  As far as food security is responsible, we understand that the precautionary principle should prevail and consider this report insufficient for the proper treatment of foods comprising nanomaterials, clones (or their descendants) and other genetic engineering applied to food.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The risk posed by nanomaterials, coupled with a legitimate distrust of the Commission and EFSA, does not allow us to support a text that does not ban nanoparticles. I cannot condone a major health risk in 10 or 20 years.  I vote AGAINST this text.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 New foods are foods that were not commonly used in human nutrition in the European Union before 15 May 1997, such as: foods with a new or intentionally modified primary molecular structure, foods containing, consisting of or being plant products, foods containing, consisting of or produced from micro-organisms, fungi or algae, etc. They were introduced by a 1997 regulation.  The Nicholson report proposes to revise this regulation, as several new food products and ingredients have since been developed due to scientific and technological advances. Furthermore, it proposes new rules on safety assessment and authorisation of new foods through a fully harmonised eu procedure and, in this respect, the European Food Safety Authority should carry out an assessment of foods that may affect human health. In addition to the establishment of a single centralised and harmonised procedure at EU level for the authorisation of new foods, this report introduces certain measures to reduce the administrative burden on small and medium-sized enterprises and at the same time creates a favourable framework for innovation in the agri-food sector. I therefore support the Nicholson Report on novel foods.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report, which seeks to determine what are considered 'new foods', since, although the Commission understands that this report is the result of consensus, the negotiation in the tripartite dialogue did not address issues of paramount importance, such as the definition of the concept of 'new food' itself. It does not include post-marketing monitoring or monitoring of such foods, nor does it emphasize the importance of proper labelling on the product so that the consumer can make a sufficiently informed decision regarding their use.  As far as food security is responsible, we understand that the precautionary principle should prevail and consider this report insufficient for the proper treatment of foods comprising nanomaterials, clones (or their descendants) and other genetic engineering applied to food.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report, because it does not include some key elements, for example: the need to observe the precautionary principle when deciding about authorisations; transparency requirements (both the list of novel foods and applications and rejected applications should be made public); the need for an opinion by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) in every case; detailed requirements in respect of the EFSA risk assessment (e.g. to consider potential cumulative/synergistic effects, and to exclude risks not only for food safety, but also for animal welfare and the environment); mandatory post-market monitoring requirements; and requirements regarding food packaging.

name: Inese Vaidere (PPE)
text: Writing. – Like any other sector, food has also been affected by innovations in the market for novel foods, both from engineering techniques and those that have been used in other parts of the world for a long time.  I therefore welcome the establishment of a single european union general procedure for the assessment of novel foods and the issue of authorisation. The single system will make authorisations faster and more efficient, while maintaining a high level of public health protection. The establishment of a centralised system is expected to significantly reduce the time required for the evaluation and authorisation of this food, as well as the total costs for operators in this process.  At the same time, I believe that food evaluation standards should be very high so that products that are not fully safe or still at the experimental stage are not placed on the market. All novel foods or elements must be thoroughly scientifically tested or have a safe history of use in other countries.  I also believe that, in addition to supporting innovation, it is necessary to protect traditional products whose production methods have been passed down from generation to generation or which are typical of a specific geographical region.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on novel foods because I agree that the free movement of safe and wholesome food is an essential aspect of the internal market and contributes significantly to the health and wellbeing of citizens, and to their social and economic interests. Differences between national laws concerning the safety assessment and authorisation of novel foods may hinder the free movement of such food, thereby creating legal uncertainty and unfair conditions of competition. On the basis of scientific and technological developments, it is appropriate to review, clarify and update the categories of food which constitute novel foods.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The one which was not used for human consumption to a significant extent in the Union before 15 May 1997 is considered 'new food', and also includes traditional third-country food which, for at least 25 years, has been part of the usual diet of a significant number of its population. There are many aspects to this report that we do not agree with and which have not been improved by the proposed amendments, since they were rejected, in particular the permissiveness in relation to nanomaterials and clones and their descendants, the use of implementing acts rather than delegated acts, and the limitation of Member States to ban new food. To top it all off, there is no background analysis of the non-need for these new foods, the interests of large multinationals and industry to bring them to market, the linkage with regulatory convergences for international treaties (the TTIP, for example) and the need to promote local, seasonal consumption that is sustainable and not these "new foods". That is why I voted against this report.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. After a long road, a delicate balance/compromise has been reached with the Council to adapt the legal framework to the realities of the current food market. The European Union should continue to promote local products, safeguard food safety and allow new foods to appear on the market. This balance carries away my approval.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This new proposal has several problematic points, including the definition and clarification of the designation of food, the role of national agencies in the authorisation process and with regard to implementing acts versus delegated acts. Another controversial issue is the need for long-term monitoring of the introduction to the market of these foods and their impact, the implementation of a transparent procedure for the introduction of food with no history of safe use in the EU to be applied, without limiting safety and information control to consumers (maximum amount of consumption, adverse effects), leading to informed choices and consumption stifures regarding the use of new foods not being deceived by the properties Announced. Moreover, the precautionary principle in this legislative proposal is not guaranteed.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The adoption of amendments has led to food from cloned animals also falling within the scope of this Regulation. It is strictly to be rejected that Member States should be forced to allow food and feed from cloned animals on their territory. I therefore do not support this report.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. Together with my group, the ECR, I voted in favour of this report on 'Novel Foods'. Within the EU legal framework, novel foods are defined as foods that were not consumed to a significant extent in the EU before 1997. The report defines an appropriate framework for dealing with novel foods.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report was put to the vote following a legislative procedure aimed at updating the legal framework governing the authorisation procedure for new foods. The current Regulation was adopted in 1997 and does not provide for solutions to support entrepreneurs in the market introduction of innovative products. In view of the change in market realities over almost 20 years, there is a need to amend the procedures for the authorisation of novel foods on the EU market – the draft regulation provides for m.in. simplification of the procedure for traditional foods from third countries by allowing only notifications to be stopped, maintaining the precautionary principle of the Commission's action in the field of novel foods and introducing a principle of transparency of uses, under which information obligations will be imposed on the Commission on restrictions imposed by third countries. In my opinion, the text presented represents a reasonable compromise on these issues – that is why I decided to support the resolution.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The New Food Regulation is 'cut and sewn' to the requirements of business groups already active in the sector concerned or intending to expand into it, seeing profitable prospects. The creation of an exclusively centralised Eu-Union mechanism excludes the possibility for Member States and their competent authorities to control and prohibit the marketing and use of new foodstuffs on their territory. At the same time, the Regulation leaves out food derived from cloned animals and their offspring, while excluding the prohibition or even stricter scientific controls of foodstuffs derived from nanomaterials and nanotechnologies, leaving consumers' health exposed to risks. Once again the EU institutions do not hesitate to leave workers' health and lives at the mercy of monopolistic gains and interests, demonstrating the EU's hostile nature to the people.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on new foods. Since the current legislation dates back to 1997, it is certainly necessary to update the legislation in the light of innovation. Moreover, this report simplifies existing procedures on the one hand and, on the other hand, contributes to greater transparency, thereby clearly facilitating trade in new foods while at the same time contributing to consumer protection.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on new foods, as the proposed legislation no longer covers food from cloned animals, as this is covered by another package area. As such, I agree that the new proposal on new foods only seeks to revise current legislation on this matter to update and simplify existing authorisation procedures and take account of recent developments in Eu law, thereby creating a centralised authorisation system, which should provide more certainty for applicants for authorisations for new foods and simplify and speed up the authorisation process. However, despite the need to simplify the current authorisation process, the European Union must also give priority to safeguarding food safety and consumer health at all stages of the food authorisation process, and it should offer its citizens a full range of safeguards relating to food safety placed on the internal market, as well as food from third countries should also be required to comply with standards equivalent to those required for food European Union.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. New foods are foods that were not included in the human diet of a significant number of people within the European Union before 15 May 1997, and include traditional food from a third country provided that for at least 25 years it is part of the diet and customs of a significant number of its population. This new proposal has several problematic points, in particular in defining and clarifying the designation of a food or in the role of national agencies in the authorisation process. Other controversial issues are the need for long-term monitoring of the introduction to the market of these foods and their impact, the implementation of a transparent procedure for the introduction of food with no history of safe use in the EU to be applied, without limiting safety and information control to consumers Unfortunately the outcome of the trilogue does not reflect all these concerns. Being better than the European Commission's proposal, as it includes concerns about animal welfare and the labelling of these foods, other points should have been included.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. The aim of the report is to facilitate the marketing authorisation procedures for all foods produced with technologies developed after 1997 and defined as innovative, as well as traditional foods from third countries. I voted against this regulation because there are serious concerns about foods containing nanoparticles. Since a tolerance threshold of 50% has been established, it has been decided to allow percentages in food 2.5 times higher than deemed advisable and not to take into account the migration of nanoparticles that may be contained in food-contact packaging. EFSA itself had suggested a limit of no more than 10% in compliance with the precautionary principle, given the lack of scientific evidence on the behaviour that these particles would have on the metabolism of humans. In addition, food additives, including those from GMOs, microorganisms such as yeasts, individual compounds with special properties (methylcellulose in gluten-free products) play too important a role among new foods. Once again, it is chosen to bypass in principle a precautionary measure that protects European consumers in the name of profit.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. "When the European Parliament today voted on the so-called ceiling directive on national emission ceilings for sulphur, nitrogen and other combustible gases, I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal. This proposal represents a 70% reduction in emissions of what is technically possible by 2030. This will mean better air quality, which will have a positive impact on human health as well as for the environment. I voted against those requests which wished to go further than the Commission because, unlike the Commission's proposal, they do not have an impact assessment.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. The Socialists support the European Commission's plans to impose stricter and more binding limits on emissions of air pollutants, which will have to be reached between 2020 and 2030. Air pollution has enormous human, environmental and economic costs; thus, around 400,000 people die prematurely in the EU each year for this cause.  Around 62% of Community territory is subject to eutrophication, including 71% of Natura 2000 ecosystems. Total costs are between EUR 330 billion and EUR 940 billion per year, including direct economic damage of 15 billion days of work lost, EUR 4 billion in health services, 3 billion for crop losses and 1 billion days of building damage, according to European Commission data.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The revised proposal for an NEC Directive replaces the current Union regime in the annual leveling of national emissions of air pollutants, as defined in Directive 2001/81/EC, for four air pollutants, namely sulphur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), volatile organic compounds other than methane (RNA) and ammonia (NH3), until 2020. The revised NEC Directive lays down controls on the different types of air pollution in each Member State. It aims to halve the number of premature deaths – an estimated 400,000 per year in the EU – caused by air pollution by half by 2030. The proposed revision sets out new national emission reduction commitments applicable from 2020 to 2030 for the four pollutants mentioned and also for fine particulate matter (PM2.5) and methane (CH4). Although there are important points that were not adopted (it eliminates binding targets for methane), I voted in favour of this report as I think it is more demanding than the Commission's proposal and therefore improved.

name: Éric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. The Commission proposes to include methane in national pollutant emission caps and air quality legislation. For agriculture, this means the integration of methane resulting from the ingestion of grass by ruminants consumed especially in traditional and extensive farming areas located very often in un prospering territories. I am opposed to this idea because these farms have very little potential for emission mitigation, partly because of the lack of an effective technical solution to prevent cows from releasing so-called enteric methane. It is difficult to go against nature. To want to incorporate this methane into the obligations of the directive would lead to a reduction in herds or even an abandonment of grass-breeding systems. This would be tantamount to favouring intensive farming models that are less favourable to the environment and fragile territories. I am pleased that our Assembly has taken into account the reality of agriculture without neglecting public health and environmental issues. It will raise many concerns in the livestock world currently shaken by crises.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the Commission's proposal. Indeed, the directive it wants to put in place includes methane and ammonia among the pollutants that need to be regulated. To this end, the Commission proposes the introduction of thresholds until 2030. These regulations are likely to be very restrictive for French farmers and herders.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The implementation costs of this resolution are estimated to be in the order of EUR 3 billion per year. I oppose the inclusion of methane in this directive, although I note that various deletion amendments were passed.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. With a few weeks to go until COP21 in Paris, the European Parliament is expressing its desire to stem the damage done to the ozone layer. I share this vital objective for the planet, but I felt it necessary to oppose the measure to introduce emission caps for methane, in particular the so-called "enteric" methane that is produced by cattle. In a difficult economic context, this new standard would have harmed cattle producers, particularly milk producers, who chose an extensive method of cultivation. I trust farmers who have already implemented new practices that meet the need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The CAP is being "greened." "Double punishment" should be avoided as a result of new standards. I therefore supported and voted on an amendment to exclude enteric methane emissions from this directive. I welcome its adoption and hope that this decision will be supported by the European Council in the forthcoming negotiations. In a context of globalisation, we must be aware that the air ignores borders and that the enactment of standards in Europe should not have the effect of pushing producers to relocate.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this proposal for certain atmospheric pollutants. Air pollutants are an important cross-border problem for human health and the environment, which has a huge impact on all EU citizens and requires immediate action. Poor air quality contributes to premature deaths, sick leave and high health care costs. In Europe, the total external costs of air pollution to society cost between EUR 330 billion and EUR 940 billion per year. In addition, there is growing evidence that atmospheric nitrogen deposits are changing the natural environment, such as eutrophication and acidification reduces the diversity of the earth's surface vegetation, slows down plant growth and leads to unbalanced nutrition. Efforts are being made across the Union to reduce air pollution, but most Member States do not meet the agreed standards. The Commission proposal repeals and replaces the existing National Emission Ceilings (INR) Directive by introducing new emission limits for sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, ammonia and non-metane volatile organic compounds in 2020 and 2030.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the creation of a new EU legislative framework on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants. We are particularly concerned that the proposal to include methane in this directive would duplicate international and domestic climate-change legislation, creating an additional regulatory burden for industry and government, without any corresponding benefit for the environment.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Knowing that 90% of Europeans living in cities are exposed to pollution levels harmful to human health, I supported this resolution which supports strict and binding targets for limiting toxic emissions by 2025 and 2030. Proposals include the limitation of 6 toxic pollutants, with the agricultural sector also affected.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This Commission directive proposed to the European Parliament continues the work of the 2001 PEN Directive on emission caps for certain air pollutants for sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxide, ammonia and non-methane volatile organic compounds (NMVOC) until 2020. The new directive proposes new thresholds until 2030 by adding methane (polluting gas from largely agricultural and livestock activities) and fine particulate matter.  The rapporteur proposed a more binding deadline in 2025 but rejected the inclusion of methane (see agriculture). The elected FN in the Commission supported the position against the inclusion of methane and against the mention of ammonia in order to limit the regulatory weight on agriculture and certain industries. So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider the Girling report to be uneth objective and balanced in the assessment of the emission thresholds for certain pollutants, in particular those relating to methane, which would have negative repercussions in relation to the agricultural sector already hard hit by the crisis, for these reasons I did not intend to support it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 Air pollution is responsible for the premature death of more than 400,000 people each year and its economic cost to the health system is estimated at between EUR 300 000 and EUR 900 billion annually. Approximately 90% of Europeans living in cities are exposed to a level of air pollution detrimental to human health. In addition, vulnerable sociodemographic groups, in particular pregnant women, children and the elderly, as well as low-income groups, are particularly affected.   The proposal for a Directive on national emission ceilings replaces the current national emission limit regime for certain air pollutants, in particular sulfide (SO2), nitrogen (NOx), volatile organic compounds (NMVOC) and ammonia (NH3) until 2020. It includes the establishment of new national emission reduction commitments applicable for 2020 and 2030 for the above-mentioned air pollutants, as well as for fine particulate matter (PM2.5) and methane (CH4). In addition, Member States shall draft national air pollution control programmes.  For these reasons, I voted in favour of this essential legislative proposal to improve air quality in Europe. In addition, with the aim of assisting the agricultural sector, I supported the exclusion of methane from the scope of the Directive.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has given Parliament its position on a directive on the reduction of emissions in certain Member States. Air pollution has recently emerged as a major public health issue on the political agenda. Poor air quality contributes to premature deaths, sick leave, high health costs, lost productivity, crop loss and damage to buildings. In Europe, the total external costs of air pollution to society cost between EUR 330 billion and EUR 940 billion per year. In addition, there is growing evidence that atmospheric nitrogen deposits are changing the natural environment, such as eutrophication and acidification reduces the diversity of the earth's surface vegetation, slows down plant growth and leads to unbalanced nutrition. Efforts are being made across the Union to reduce air pollution, but most Member States do not meet the agreed standards. The most complex part of the proposal is the 2030 targets, as different restrictions are imposed for each Member State and for each pollutant. The Commission has imposed restrictions on individual Member States on the basis of where it considers that the most economically advantageous measures can be taken.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. -u2012 I supported the proposed directive with sensible compromise amendments adopted, as I support the EU's transition to a low-carbon society. On reasonable and realistic terms, of course. The transition must not be to the detriment of agriculture and industry as the two biggest emitters. I am pleased that the envi proposals, which set unrealistically high targets, have been rejected. For example, their implementation would cost Slovenia the most among all EU Member States. I am also pleased that methane is excluded from the proposal for a directive, and an adaptation scheme is proposed for amonjak. This, in my view, is guaranteed the competitiveness of industry and agriculture.

name: David Borrelli (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Girling report on the emission of certain air pollutants because, although the conditions were in place to do more, overall the assessment is positive. The limits on pollutants have been lowered than the ENVI Committee's proposal, but ammonia and methane (excluding enteric emissions) have been maintained within the scope of the directive. Mercury has unfortunately been excluded, but at least the request to the European Commission for an impact study has been passed on and will be followed by a legislative proposal. The situation of air pollution is serious, the air we breathe every day is increasingly polluted and it is, in my view, essential to have a strong NEC directive that can be the driving force behind ambitious air quality policies in all sectors.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ 400,000 Europeans die prematurely every year due to air pollution. Poor air quality causes the most diverse diseases, reduces quality of life and leads to excessive use of medicines, increased hospital care and millions of working days lost.  Air pollution also affects Europe's nature and biodiversity, agricultural yield and vegetation. Losses in agricultural yields are estimated at around 3 billion euros in 2010. This is why I support the ambitious targets proposed by the European Commission, but along the fence, how it was necessary to add exemptions for small farmers.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. The rapporteur refused to include methane, which had been supported by FN elected officials in committee in order to limit the regulatory burden on agriculture and certain industries. The directive, on the other hand, adds methane, so I voted against it.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU Commission's proposal to set higher national emission limits for major pollutants is right. Air pollution causes around 400,000 premature deaths in the EU every year. The new rules could save up to EUR 40 billion to combat environmental pollution by 2030. Europe wants to set itself ambitious targets, not even in view of COP21 in Paris. The new national emission limits (NECs) cover: sulphur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), non-metanic organic compounds (VOCNM), methane (CH4), ammonia (NH3) and particulate matter (up to PM 2.5 micrometers). In addition, the new rules will also help to reduce mercury (HG) emissions. It is right to exclude naturally produced methane from cows from the directive. However, it is now necessary to continue the fight against food waste, not least in order to reduce pollution and land consumption. In fact, about a third of the world's production of food for human consumption is lost or wasted along the food chain. This amount corresponds to a waste of some 1.6 billion tonnes of food. And we must not forget that in many countries around the world too much meat is consumed compared to the real need in our diet.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. Revision of the Air Quality Directive, which sets the new National Emission Ceilings (NEC) from 2020 to 2030. Compared to the Commission's proposal, ENVI: - makes the intermediate thresholds compulsory by 2025; - extends the field of application to other gases (CH4 methane, NH3 ammonia, HG mercury). We are all aware of the extreme difficulties that local authorities have in complying with current limits, especially in certain unfavourable geographical areas such as Padania. Therefore, we consider it unnecessarily burdensome to set mandatory reduction thresholds even at the intermediate stage, to 2025. The addition of methane and ammonia, which has a significant impact on the agricultural sector (livestock farming), is particularly controversial. But it's the addition of methane that's discriminating for our final grade. As a greenhouse gas, we interpret its inclusion in this directive as (yet another) attempt to mix anti-pollution legislation with climate policy legislation (as they say: pears with apples).

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. The Socialists support the European Commission's plans to impose stricter and more binding limits on emissions of air pollutants, which will have to be reached between 2020 and 2030. Air pollution has enormous human, environmental and economic costs; thus, around 400,000 people die prematurely in the EU each year for this cause.  Around 62% of Community territory is subject to eutrophication, including 71% of Natura 2000 ecosystems. Total costs are between EUR 330 billion and EUR 940 billion per year, including direct economic damage of 15 billion days of work lost, EUR 4 billion in health services, 3 billion for crop losses and 1 billion days of building damage, according to European Commission data.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The Directive on reducing national emissions of certain air pollutants is part of the legislative package proposed by the Commission on Air Quality. This text proposes the implementation of very ambitious targets for reducing certain polluting gases. It is very important to increase air quality as pollution is responsible for many deaths each year. However, we must try to remain realistic and put in place binding targets that do not jeopardise the economic competitiveness of the European Union. The example of the methane reduction target is particularly telling. Methane emissions come mainly from the agricultural sector, as ruminants are the main culprits. The agricultural sector is currently experiencing particularly difficult times. Imposing this on our farmers would only make their situation worse. I therefore voted in favour of this text on the condition that enteric methane emissions be excluded from the scope of the legislation.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of national emissions of certain air pollutants and amending Directive 2003/35/EC. I believe that better air quality within the Community must be a priority objective for the European institutions. With today's vote, Parliament has played its part by adopting a text that will significantly reduce air pollution and improve air quality and save people's lives, as pollution in Europe causes hundreds of thousands of deaths and adversely affects the GDP of Member States with very high health-related costs.  But Parliament alone cannot change things, we need a shared effort by the Commission, the Member States and the productive sectors to achieve the enormous benefits, both in terms of public health and in economic terms, that cleaner air can bring.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which sets the emission targets for certain atmospheric pollutants, including sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and ammonia, until 2030. The revised Directive on the reduction of national emissions puts controls on different types of air pollution in each Member State. Its goal is to cut the number of premature deaths caused by air pollution – estimated as 400 000 a year in the EU – by half by 2030. When voting on the proposed amendments, I bore in mind targets that could be realistically achieved by Ireland.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the creation of a new EU legislative framework on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants. We are particularly concerned that the proposal to include methane in this directive would duplicate international and domestic climate-change legislation, creating an additional regulatory burden for industry and government, without any corresponding benefit for the environment.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as I believe it is necessary to decrease emission levels in order to protect human health, animal welfare and the environment.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 As you know, air pollution is a serious environmental health problem in the European Union. It is estimated that poor air quality is responsible for more than 400,000 premature deaths each year and causes illness, hospitalization and millions of days of lost work, as well as damage to biodiversity, crops and buildings. I could therefore only vote in favour of a text aimed at limiting emissions, providing for access to up-to-date information on the progress of national reduction commitments, taking specific measures to protect the health of vulnerable groups, supporting the transition to investment in clean and efficient technologies with tax incentives, organising regular and routine environmental inspections and ensuring public consultation.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the outcome of today’s vote to set stricter air pollutant emissions rules and ceilings, which Member State governments are bound to meet by 2030, with interim targets for 2025. We want to control a suite of toxic pollutants that accounts for over half a million premature deaths throughout Europe. In Ireland alone, there are over three thousand premature deaths annually, by An Taisce’s estimates. Beyond the human cost, this represents a great loss to the Union in healthcare and social expenditure and productivity, and more than justifies restrictions that will spur innovation and cleaner industrial solutions. Some calculate the loss to be just short of a trillion euro, EU-wide. Although cattle got off the hook for their belching, we have included under the rules ammonia and methane, mostly arising from agricultural use, given the vast emissions coming from this sector. Ammonia from agricultural sources is a surprisingly significant killer. It is quite regrettable; however, that Fine Gael’s parliamentary party in Europe chose to kill off the inclusion of mercury – which is churned out in dozens of tons every year – calling for a lengthy impact assessment instead. Coal pollution seems to have blinded many policymakers to the incontrovertible scientific evidence about this dangerous neurotoxin.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The report stressed that Member States should be fully informed of their performance with regard to their specific emission reduction commitments.  Where Member States are at risk of not fulfilling their obligations, measures should be provided to identify the problem in a timely way to enable countries to take corrective action.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it deals with an important and cross-border issue for both human health and the environment, which affects all citizens of the Union and is now one of the strategic priorities. In addition, poor air quality causes premature deaths, sick leave, high health care costs, lost productivity, reduced crops and damage to buildings. It is estimated that in Europe the total external health costs borne by society and resulting from air pollution are between EUR 330 billion and EUR 940 billion per year. I therefore agree with the rapporteur that it is essential to give the competent authorities the power to take the necessary measures to comply with the relevant legislation and to respect the limits for 2030. An excellent example of a measure would be the introduction of low-emission zones and a system of penalties based on pollution due to the movement of vehicles, with the aim of reducing emissions from diesel vehicles in urban areas most affected by emissions of nitrogen oxides and particulates.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the creation of a new EU legislative framework on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants. We are particularly concerned that the proposal to include methane in this directive would duplicate international and domestic climate-change legislation, creating an additional regulatory burden for industry and government, without any corresponding benefit for the environment.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
