text: in writing. – Today UKIP voted against the creation of a new EU legislative framework on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants. We are particularly concerned that the proposal to include methane in this directive would duplicate international and domestic climate-change legislation, creating an additional regulatory burden for industry and government, without any corresponding benefit for the environment.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Noting that transport contributes to worsening air quality, I believe that manufacturers should use clean technologies in order to reduce emissions of nitrogen oxide (NOx), particulate matter and other pollutants. In this regard, I believe that a significant strengthening of the current EU vehicle type-approval system is necessary, including greater control by the European Union itself, in particular with regard to market surveillance, coordination and a follow-up system for vehicles sold in the Union. I am also in favour of a review of the Car Labelling Directive (1999/94/EC) in order to improve the accuracy of the information provided to consumers. It is important for European citizens to regain full confidence in the EU's automotive sector, as the Eu ropean Union has a duty to safeguard public health and ensure respect for consumer rights.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Air pollution is a serious environmental health problem in the European Union. Poor air quality is responsible for more than 400,000 premature deaths each year and causes disease, hospitalization and millions of days of lost work, as well as damage to biodiversity, crops and buildings. The proposal provides, among other things, for access to up-to-date information on the progress of national reduction commitments; cost-effectiveness of emission reduction measures; specific measures to protect the health of vulnerable groups; have air quality levels recommended by the World Health Organisation (WHO); support the transition to investment in clean and efficient technologies with tax incentives; regular and routine environmental inspections and market surveillance; public consultation; 'Clean Air' Fund and European Forum in order to facilitate the coordinated implementation of the Clean Air Programme. For the ambitious objectives described above, I can only vote in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The revised proposal for an NEC Directive replaces the current Union regime in the annual leveling of national emissions of air pollutants, as defined in Directive 2001/81/EC, for four air pollutants, namely sulphur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), volatile organic compounds other than methane (RNA) and ammonia (NH3), until 2020. The revised NEC Directive lays down controls on the different types of air pollution in each Member State. It aims to halve the number of premature deaths – an estimated 400,000 per year in the EU – caused by air pollution by half by 2030. The proposed revision sets out new national emission reduction commitments applicable from 2020 to 2030 for the four pollutants mentioned and also for fine particulate matter (PM2.5) and methane (CH4). Although there are important points that were not adopted (it eliminates binding targets for methane), I voted in favour of this report as I think it is more demanding than the Commission's proposal and therefore improved.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliament's report supports the Commission's proposal for member states' emission limit values for the six most important air pollutants, including nitrogen oxides, ammonia and methane. Economic savings of EUR 40 billion can be achieved by respecting emission limits in the Member States, and it is also important from a health point of view that the decision can save thousands of lives by following the new emission limits in a disciplined way.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal for this revised National Emission Ceilings Directive replaces the current Union regime on the annual capping of national emissions of air pollutants for SO2, NOx, NMVOCs and ammonia until 2020. This is very timely measure as the air quality in Europe is still far from achieving levels that do not result in acceptable risks to humans and the environment. Certain pollutants combine to create PM and ground-level ozone, which in turn adversely affect human health, the environment and the climate. Air pollutants are emitted from a variety of sources, including transport, electricity production, industry, heating, households, agriculture and waste. I am strongly in favour of ambitious, realistic measures to address dangerous pollutants because we must go for strong, realistic targets in order to achieve real results.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the new air pollution legislation, which causes around 400 000 premature deaths in the EU annually, could lead to savings of up to EUR 40 billion in pollution costs by 2030.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This legislative report reviews national emission caps for certain pollutants to improve air quality and human health. The text introduces new limit values (e.g. sulphur dioxide, ultrafine particles or methane), from 2020 and 2030. It also proposes a binding intermediate target in 2025 for all pollutants except ammonia. Other measures include access to air quality improvement funding and emissions control programs. There has been many oppositions, both on the level of ambition of the reduction targets for 2020, 2025 and 2030, and on the addition of new pollutants. Considering that we do not currently have an effective technical or technological means to reduce emissions of enteric methane (rejection of livestock), I have co-signed an amendment, the content of which was taken up by the plenary to exclude these emissions from the directive, so as not to penalise the agricultural sector. I regret, however, that my amendments to protect small farms and exclude ammonia have not been adopted. Nevertheless, supporting the main objectives of this report, I voted in favour of opening negotiations between the European Parliament and the Council.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the creation of a new EU legislative framework on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants. We are particularly concerned that the proposal to include methane in this directive would duplicate international and domestic climate-change legislation, creating an additional regulatory burden for industry and government, without any corresponding benefit for the environment.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: Written. I supported the agreement in this dossier. In view of the damage to the environment and public health from pollutant emissions, I think it is important that this problem is addressed. We have opted for an ambitious yet realistic approach, including by providing an exception for cows grazing outside.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The 2001 EU NEC Directive sets national emission limits for certain air pollutants: sulphur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and ammonia (NH3). In a new revised proposal, the Commission introduces two new pollutants, fine particulate matter (PM2.5) and methane (CH4), and sets new, more stringent national caps for the other four pollutants.  Air pollution is responsible for the deaths of 400,000 Eu-citizens every year, which is why the European Union needs to have stricter emission caps and binding 2025 targets for all pollutants targeted.  It is wise to provide an exception for enteric methane, that is, from the rearing produced by the belated and farts of cows. The European ecological revolution that we call for is synonymous with the preservation of a sustainable agricultural model that respects the welfare of animals.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the GIRLING report, or NEC directive, which aims to set Member States' emission caps for the main pollutants. However, I have been mobilised to exclude enteric methane from the scope of the directive. Reducing methane emissions is certainly an important public health issue, but we need to be pragmatic. That is why we have fought throughout the committee discussions to reject the inclusion of enteric methane in the calculation of national emission caps. This inclusion could have undermined the competitiveness of our agriculture at a time when the European livestock sector is going through an unprecedented crisis. On the one hand, we cannot argue in favour of animal welfare in the agricultural sector and, on the other hand, impose unreasonable constraints on our farmers. This directive is therefore a crucial legislative instrument for monitoring compliance with air quality targets at European level. But if we want effective legislation, it must first and foremost be realistic!

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Directive governing the emission of certain atmospheric pollutants is an important step on the road to reducing the harmful effects of air pollution on human health and improving air quality in Europe. Achieving the objectives set requires realistic emission limits that can be realistically met, taking into account national strategies. Not only Hungary, but agriculture as a whole would be extremely bad affected by the adoption of legislation that ignores this principle.  An unrealistic limit on methane emissions would break down one of the Hungarian government's main objectives: a significant increase in livestock. Methane is a greenhouse gas and therefore already has a climate reduction obligation. The same is the case for ammonia, where fertilisation methods are already regulated by the requirements of the cross-compliance system, in particular the Nitrate Directive. This would complicate the situation of farmers and result in unenforceable standards. By 2030, it is not possible to set a specific reduction target now, as air pollution is influenced by a number of variable factors and there is no linear reduction path. Finally, it should be noted that the European Commission did not plan to tighten the limit values until after 2020, given that many Member States are still struggling to meet previous targets. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of all the plenary amendments tabled to the report adopted by the Committee on the Environment aimed at erasing methane and fundamentally changing ammonia standards.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: Written. 'Air pollution remains a huge problem and calls for a cross-border approach. Dirty air is detrimental to health and the environment and, consequently, to society and the economy. The impact of air pollution on vulnerable groups, especially children, requires our absolute priority. Updating and extending the NEC Directive is an opportunity to address this challenge. The N-VA delegation shares the analysis of the rapporteur and the European Commission that we must show ambition, mainly by improving standards per Member State for six of the most pollutants by 2030, by setting binding interim targets by 2025 and by tackling pollution at source. The rapid introduction of emission tests based on actual driving conditions in the automotive sector is also fundamental in this regard. We don't have time to waste. In order to enable rapid and effective progress, our proposals must also be realistic, figure-based and technologically feasible. Clean air is not achieved by air cycling or by building air castles. The N-VA is satisfied that a majority of Parliament today is opting for responsible policies that offer the best guarantees in the interests of all of us health, well-being and prosperity.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which sets new virtuous thresholds in the policy of reducing emissions for several air pollutants. However, I have made a reservation about enteric methane (which results from the ingestion of the herb by ruminants) through a specific amendment. The integration of this methane into national emission ceilings is problematic because it would in fact lead to a reduction in livestock or even a conversion to intensive farms consuming more flour with multiple consequences. On the environment, with the abandonment of permanent grasslands. On the employment and vitality of traditional and extensive livestock areas where incomes are lowest and where generational renewal is no longer assured. On our food autonomy, finally, which could be reduced. We must fight against the greenhouse effect but without sacrificing traditional agriculture because it also allows to capture a certain number of gases through its soils (real carbon sinks very useful especially in the fight against global warming). Attentive to this reality, I also want to help to remove the legitimate concerns felt by many breeders already affected by a deep crisis and a severe drought this year.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Commission's proposals to set new emission limits for six key air pollutants, including NOx, particulate emissions and sulphur dioxide. On the other hand, I voted on an amendment to remove from this list the enteric methane produced by ruminant farming. It seemed to me justified not to force the agriculture sector, which has already made considerable progress in this area and is going through a very difficult period, to meet objectives which, in the opinion of many experts, were neither realistic nor achievable. I have supported the vast majority of the Commission's other proposals because air pollution has enormous human and economic costs. In 2010, it caused more than 400,000 premature deaths in the European Union. Air pollution also causes damage to the environment and knows no borders. The total costs incurred are in the order of 330-940 billion euros per year, of which 4 billion euros are in the health care sector.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The Directive regulating the emission of certain atmospheric pollutants is an important step on the road to reducing the harmful effects of air pollution on human health and improving air quality in Europe. Achieving the objectives set requires realistic emission limits that can be realistically met, taking into account national strategies. Not only Hungary, but agriculture as a whole would be extremely bad affected by the adoption of legislation that ignores this principle.  An unrealistic limit on methane emissions would break down one of the Hungarian government's main objectives: a significant increase in livestock. Methane is a greenhouse gas and therefore already has a climate reduction obligation. The same is the case for ammonia, where fertilisation methods are already regulated by the requirements of the cross-compliance system, in particular the Nitrate Directive. This would complicate the situation of farmers and result in unenforceable standards. By 2030, it is not possible to set a specific reduction target now, as air pollution is influenced by a number of variable factors and there is no linear reduction path. Finally, it should be noted that the European Commission did not plan to tighten the limit values until after 2020, given that many Member States are still struggling to meet previous targets. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of all the plenary amendments tabled to the report adopted by the Committee on the Environment aimed at erasing methane and fundamentally changing ammonia standards.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This Girling report on the emission of certain air pollutants appears to be heading in a more encouraging direction. Indeed, it has been amended several times in the right direction, especially by excluding methane from the text. As a result, our agriculture will not suffer undue from this regulation, being the first emitter of methane. Satisfied with the text as amended, thus protecting our rural economy, I voted for this report.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This is a Commission proposal which repeals the old directive and replaces it with a new one. It provides for a new legislative act aimed at improving air quality by adopting stricter standards. It is imperative that the competent authorities are empowered to ensure compliance with all legislative provisions relating to the 2030 limits. In particular, the introduction of low-emission zones and a system for charging charges for road pollution with the objective of reducing emissions of pollutants from diesel vehicles, particularly in urban areas. For all the above reasons we are voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on reducing national emissions of certain air pollutants.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In accordance with the guidelines of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of parliament's position amending the Air Quality Directive. This proposal initially carried enormous risks. As regards methane emission limit values, a proposal has emerged that would have had a devastating impact on the livestock Hungary eu and its member states. The current growing hungarian cattle and pig population would have been decimated by an excessively strict methane emission limit, thus achieving the objective of increasing livestock, one of the most important objectives of the Hungarian agricultural government. It is a serious Hungarian achievement that we have managed to pull methane out of the parliamentary report. On the other hand, the original proposal set out conditions too strict for ammonia: not only the ammonia emission limits for 2030 but also for 2020 were unrealistic. Here, too, a reduction has been achieved, so that final ammonia emission limits will only be decided in the future.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Today UKIP voted against the creation of a new EU legislative framework on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants. We are particularly concerned that the proposal to include methane in this directive would duplicate international and domestic climate-change legislation, creating an additional regulatory burden for industry and government, without any corresponding benefit for the environment.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. Air pollution is responsible for more than 400,000 deaths each year in the European Union. The WHO and the OECD have estimated that the total health costs attributable to air pollution amount to more than € 1.4 trillion, or about one tenth of the GDP of the entire European Union. The revision of the directive establishing maximum concentrations of pollutants is necessary in order to update levels to health protection requirements. Parliament was called upon to vote on the text voted on in the ENVI Committee, which contained substantial improvements, including the inclusion of mercury limits and the obligation to take account of methane from cattle farms.  Although the rapporteur has succeeded in watering down the text produced by the ENVI Committee, we have nevertheless managed to maintain certain qualifying points such as ammonia levels and levels for anthropogenic methane. In the case of mercury, on the other hand, the Commission has been in a position to study the possibility of extending the scope of the directive to this toxic metal as well. I voted in favour of the amended text, which is convinced of the urgency of the measure and of the improvement made to the initial text to be defended in the negotiations with the Council.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of limiting atmospheric emissions of eutrofizent acidifying polluting substances, among others, in order to contribute to achieving the Union's air quality objectives, thereby minimising negative impacts on human health and the environment. The biodiversity of ecosystems will also benefit greatly from the control of these substances as their deposition at the bottom of lakes and soil will be reduced.  This directive is all the more important as it will align these emissions with the Union's 2030 climate and energy targets and send a positive signal on the eve of the climate summit in Paris, where an international agreement is expected to effectively combat man-made climate change.  I also voted positively in the key votes related to the introduction of target values for methane and ammonia emissions, since a large share of air pollution comes from emissions of these gases at the agricultural level. The establishment of mandatory targets for reducing these emissions by Member States by 2025 has also received my positive vote.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. I have voted in favour of an ambitious air protection policy, and I am pleased that that line gained support in the European Parliament. The strict limit values adopted by 2030 are estimated to halve the number of premature deaths caused by air pollution each year, which currently stands at around 400 000 in the EU. Air pollution causes ten times more deaths than road accidents, and it is about time the EU Member States did more to tackle the problem.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This legislative proposal establishes new national emission limit values for certain air pollutants with the aim of reducing threats to human health, the environment and climate. Poor air quality contributes to premature death, disease-motivated job absenteeism, significant health costs, lost productivity, loss of crop yield, and damage to buildings. In Europe, total external costs to society related to health and air pollution are estimated at between EUR 330 billion and EUR 940 billion per year. According to the report, Member States should at least limit their emissions of sulphur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), non-methane volatile organic compounds (NMVOC), ammonia (NH3), particulate matter (PM2.5) and mercury (Hg). The containment of non-methane volatile organic compounds (NMVOC) and methane (CH4) should be inserted into the wider context of reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. For environmental and public health reasons, air quality concerns everyone. It is, by its nature, a cross-border issue, which calls for immediate action after years of political negligence.  This proposal reviews the Directive (2001) on national emission limit values for certain air pollutants. It is an integral part of the Clean Air Package. It is proposed to change the emission limits of air pollutants, particularly sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, ammonia and non-metanic volatile organic compounds, for 2020 and 2030. Mercury has also been added to this list, and the limits for this element will only be introduced from 2020. In addition, the scope of the Directive is extended to cover particulatematter (PM2.5) from 2020 and, with a view to convergence with climate legislation, methane from 2030 on.  The new targets of the proposal for 2030 are the most complex element, with different limits for each Member State and for each pollutant, based on the fulfillment of 70% of the technically possible maximum reductions in health impacts, as defined by the WHO. Despite the existence of some contradictory elements, we supported this report. We reiterate that the normative approach must prevail in the face of market approaches.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal repeals and replaces the current Union regime on the annual capping of national emissions of air pollutants, as defined in Directive 2001/81/EC. It ensures that the national emission ceilings (NECs) set in Directive 2001/81/EC for 2010 onwards, for SO2, NOx, NMVOC and NH3, shall apply until 2020, and it establishes new NEC reduction commitments applicable from 2020 and 2030 for SO2, NOx, NMVOC, NH3, fine particulate matter and methane, as well as intermediate emission levels for 2025 applicable to the same pollutants. While we have to face up to our responsibilities in this area, as an agriculture-based economy, this could entail disproportionate costs for the sector. Research work on mitigating methane emissions through changes in the diet of animals is in its early stages: this approach could offer solutions as a part of a wider strategy which must be in place to assist the agricultural sector meet necessary targets in advance of ceilings being set.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Poor air quality is responsible for more than 400 000 premature deaths each year, and the economic value for health systems in each Member State is in the range of 300-900 billion every year. More than 90% of the population who live in cities on the territory of the Member States of the European Union are exposed to air pollution that harms their health. Moreover, the most vulnerable sections of the population, such as pregnant women, children and the elderly, as well as low-income population groups, are also exposed to these negative effects.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This is a Commission proposal which repeals the old directive and replaces it with a new one. It provides for a new legislative act aimed at improving air quality by adopting stricter standards. It is imperative that the competent authorities be empowered to ensure compliance with all legislative provisions relating to the 2030 limits; For all the above reasons I am voting in favour of the report with the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on reducing national emissions of certain air pollutants.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to stress the importance for Romania of the proposal for a revised National Emission Reduction Commitments Directive, in terms of its impact on many industrial sectors: energy, industry, transport, residential and agriculture. As a general position, I agree that measures to address dangerous pollutants covering all sectors are urgently needed but we need to ensure that the proposed measures will not lead, in the end, to increased costs in economic terms and will not impose undue administrative burden for the government and private sector. The proposal for new national emission reduction commitments applicable for 2020 and 2030 specifically implies for Romania the following reduction compared to emissions in 2005: 93% for sulphur dioxide, 67% for nitrogen oxides, 64% for volatile organic compounds, 24% for ammonia, 65% for particulate matter PM2.5; and 26% for methane. These reductions will require additional efforts and costs, to prevent and control emissions, which could affect economic competitiveness. I consider that the objectives for 2030 should better reflect national emission projections, or alternatively that they should be proposed as indicative targets.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. Evidence-based policy-making should be a cornerstone of EU legislation. Although work is being done to reduce air pollution across the EU, many Member States are not complying with the agreed standards. In addition, the Union is also far from meeting its long-term objective of meeting the proposed limit values for pollutants in the WHO Air Quality Guidelines 2005.  Poor air quality contributes to premature death, absence from work, significant health costs, loss of productivity, loss of yields and deterioration of buildings.  In line with the rapporteur, I support the Commission's recent commitment to smarter, more sensible regulation and to reducing the administrative burden on businesses and Member States. It should also be stressed that the ceilings for the target dates set out in the report should be set in such a way as to be realistic, proportionate and feasible, based on facts and without disproportionately affecting any sector.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report to help reduce polluting emissions which represent a major cross-border problem. Action is needed at Union level with the aim of establishing a coherent and ambitious framework to address the problem of emissions from largely incomplete combustion of fuels in heating, transport and energy production.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. – The Socialists support the European Commission's plans to impose stricter and more binding limits on emissions of air pollutants, which will have to be reached between 2020 and 2030. Air pollution has enormous human, environmental and economic costs; thus, around 400,000 people die prematurely in the EU each year for this cause.  Around 62% of Community territory is subject to eutrophication, including 71% of Natura 2000 ecosystems. Total costs are between EUR 330 billion and EUR 940 billion per year, including direct economic damage of 15 billion days of work lost, EUR 4 billion in health services, 3 billion for crop losses and 1 billion days of building damage, according to European Commission data.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. The Socialists support the European Commission's plans to impose stricter and more binding limits on emissions of air pollutants, which will have to be reached between 2020 and 2030. Air pollution has enormous human, environmental and economic costs; thus, around 400,000 people die prematurely in the EU each year for this cause.  Around 62% of Community territory is subject to eutrophication, including 71% of Natura 2000 ecosystems. Total costs are between EUR 330 billion and EUR 940 billion per year, including direct economic damage of 15 billion days of work lost, EUR 4 billion in health services, 3 billion for crop losses and 1 billion days of building damage, according to European Commission data.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the agreement reached between the EP and the Council on the directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of national emissions of certain air pollutants because I believe it is right for the EU to have robust legislation to protect air quality. The quality of the air we breathe is not just an environmental issue, but a serious European problem: the data tell us that 90% of citizens in the EU live in polluted places and that there are around 400 000 related premature deaths per year, at a cost to our health systems of hundreds of billions per year. Strong action is therefore needed. I welcome the provision of limits and thresholds for emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, ammonia, fine particulatematter, methane and VOCNM: ambitious targets, to which states will have to commit themselves with appropriate plans, but which follow up the EU's commitment to combating climate change. Finally, I agree with the decision to provide for fair doses of flexibility on specific points in the light of the situation of our farms, and in particular the exclusion of methane emissions from ruminants: air quality can and must be combined with the characteristics and traditions of our quality agriculture.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I welcome the fact that, on the basis of the amendments jointly tabled by myself and my Polish group colleagues, we have succeeded in removing methane from the directive. This would have had devastating consequences for our agriculture and is simply alien to the world. I now expect the rapporteur to have a committed debate with the Council and to defend the positions we have adopted in the trialogue.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. As rapporteur for the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, I have advocated a balanced report, with ambitious but realistic emission reduction targets. With our proposals, we have been able to prevail on key voting points. Our legislation must be based on sound impact assessments. That is what we are constantly asking for, and that is what we have been trying to do this time too.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Air pollution causes 50 000 premature deaths across the UK and 700 000 across the EU in total every year. Its economic cost for health is estimated at between EUR 300 billion and EUR 900 billion on an annual basis. That is why I voted to set ambitious measures to cut toxic emissions that contribute to air pollution. Proper results can only be achieved if the agriculture sector plays its part, just as the car industry, following the emissions test scandal. Thousands of deaths are attributable to ammonia from farms, and the setting of limits on agricultural emissions is both necessary and fair.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. U2012 Air pollution is a public health problem. The EU is far from achieving the long-term goal of reaching levels that do not have a significant negative impact on health. I therefore supported the setting of emission limits on all pollutants, including methane and ammonia, in today's vote, and voted in favour of ambitious and binding targets not only by 2030, but also by 2025.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted today in favour of improved air quality standards across the EU. The new directive on national emissions reduction commitments will reduce harmful emissions and lessen the health and environmental impact on our population. It is estimated that around 400 000 people a year die prematurely across the EU from air pollution. This is a crucial issue and action must be taken, based on robust scientific evidence, to improve life expectancy and reduce associated costs to society. Billions of pounds per year are being lost, and the public is now acutely aware of the issue. Policymakers have been concentrating on climate change to the detriment of air quality for the past decade, and it is clear there is a need for more cohesive and streamlined policymaking, with binding targets for 2025, improved reporting, and provisions on driving emissions and on access to funding to help people adapt to the new measures. I see today’s vote as an important step on the path to better air quality.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. The Girling report is a directive that aims to set a maximum emissions of certain polluting fumes.  Instead, it was intended to focus on industrial products and also intended to rule on methane and ammonia, gases produced by agriculture. Under ecological cover, the objective of reducing methane was an attack in good standing against our breeding with only one possible outcome: the industrialization of livestock and the confinement of animals.  These kinds of standards, which aim to pollute ever less in Europe, are in fact just a Trojan horse. Imports of industrial or agricultural products are not subject to the same binding provisions. They then become balls at the feet of our economy. The effect is quite counterproductive: the death of our companies and our farms for lack of competitiveness in favour of non-European actors whose environmental concerns are nevertheless inferior to ours. Other measures could be taken to address the roots of pollution, in particular stop negotiating free trade agreements.  Endangering both our agriculture and our industry, this text did not deserve my voice and I voted against it.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report in order to regulate certain air pollutants, such as methane emissions. 40% of greenhouse gas emissions come from agriculture. It is also an important precursor to another air pollutant, tropospheric ozone, which causes respiratory and cardiovascular diseases and, by the way, also significant damage to agricultural crops, especially in Mediterranean countries.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of national emissions of certain types of atmospheric pollution and the revision of Directive 2003/35/EC, as it imposes excessive methane obligations. As a Member of Polish, I could not support solutions that harm Polish cattle and pig farmers. I regret that not all the amendments tabled by the Polish delegation of European Conservatives and Reformists on the removal of methane commitments have been accepted.

name: Γιώργος Γραμματικάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 According to valid data, air pollution is responsible for hundreds of thousands of deaths per year in the EU as a whole. At the same time, the financial burden on health systems is therefore several hundred billion. The new directive sets realistic but ambitious national targets for reducing certain pollutants that place a significant burden on human health. In this context, the European Parliament proposes reasonable exemptions for pollutants in the livestock sector, ensuring that the burden of the reduction is mainly on waste and waste water management but also on the energy sector. In these areas, especially in Greece, the greatest possibilities of restrictions are presented for the sake of the health of citizens.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE)
text: In writing. Air pollution is believed to be responsible for 400,000 premature deaths a year in the European Union! On the eve of COP 21 in Paris in December, Parliament has just adopted an ambitious report to reduce emissions of air pollutants in the European Union. I welcome the adoption of this ambitious but also balanced and realistic draft directive, since it takes into account the particular situation of the agriculture and livestock sector by excluding enteric methane emissions.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a central legislative instrument for the control of air pollution at European level. The aim of this text is to set Member States' emission caps for the main pollutants. It is also an important public health tool, as it is estimated that poor air quality causes more than 48,000 premature deaths in France. But if we want effective legislation, it must first and foremost be realistic! That is why I particularly welcome the exclusion of methane from the scope of the directive. Its inclusion could have undermined the competitiveness of our agriculture at a time when the European livestock sector is going through an unprecedented crisis.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported the report to reduce emissions of air pollutants, adopted in plenary on 28 October. Several political groups, including the Socialists and Democrats, have agreed to set higher targets for reducing pollutants. These include nitrogen oxide, particulate and sulphur dioxide, ammonia, and methane, with the exception of enteric methane, which is emitted by ruminants. I voted in favour of this text because air pollution causes 400,000 premature deaths in the EU every year, and is very expensive for our planet and our societies. It is estimated, for example, that up to 40 billion euros in savings could be achieved through this text by 2030. In the run-up to COP21, as MEPs begin negotiations with the Council to reach an agreement on air pollutants, it must be reaffirmed that it is high time to act.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report in order to support the setting of a level playing field, ensuring that installations in all Member States make a fair effort to reduce pollution. Air pollution currently causes more than 400 000 premature deaths in the EU each year.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. – The Socialists support the European Commission's plans to impose stricter and more binding limits on emissions of air pollutants, which will have to be reached between 2020 and 2030. Air pollution has enormous human, environmental and economic costs; thus, around 400,000 people die prematurely in the EU each year for this cause.  Around 62% of Community territory is subject to eutrophication, including 71% of Natura 2000 ecosystems. Total costs are between EUR 330 billion and EUR 940 billion per year, including direct economic damage of 15 billion days of work lost, EUR 4 billion in health services, 3 billion for crop losses and 1 billion days of building damage, according to European Commission data.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the rapporteur’s proposal to take this file to trilogue negotiations because I believe that Parliament has come up with a good position with realistic targets that will reduce air pollution.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the creation of a new EU legislative framework on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants. We are particularly concerned that the proposal to include methane in this directive would duplicate international and domestic climate-change legislation, creating an additional regulatory burden for industry and government, without any corresponding benefit for the environment.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The proposal for revised national emission ceilings (NEC Directive) is part of the European Commission's Clean Air Package and replaces current rules on the annual capping of national emissions of air pollutants, such as.B sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides or ammonia. The new directive aims to introduce new emission reduction commitments for Member States from 2020 to 2030, namely PM 2.5 and methane. Parliament always erases the same mistake by increasing the targets agreed by the Council from .B 27% to 40%. The limit values for some pollutants have once again been arbitrarily increased. We need ceilings on pollutants to incentivise emission reductions, but they should be realistic, proportionate and evidence-based and should not disproportionately affect certain sectors. However, it will be difficult for some Member States, especially those with large agricultural sectors. That is why we need flexibility. Parliament's practices jeopardise the legislative process. It should be guided by the decisions of the Council, as they are negotiated by the Member States. That is why I voted against this report because it has taken on a completely different form through numerous amendments. Incidentally , and this is my ceterum censeo – I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Directive governing the emission of certain atmospheric pollutants is an important step on the road to reducing the harmful effects of air pollution on human health and improving air quality in Europe. Achieving the objectives set requires realistic emission limits that can be realistically met, taking into account national strategies. Not only Hungary, but agriculture as a whole would be extremely bad affected by the adoption of legislation that ignores this principle. Finally, it should be noted that the European Commission did not plan to tighten the limit values until after 2020, given that many Member States are still struggling to meet previous targets. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of all the plenary amendments tabled to the report adopted by the Committee on the Environment aimed at erasing methane and fundamentally changing ammonia standards.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I was very proud to support these measures, along with my Labour Party and Socialist and Democrat Group colleagues. Poor air quality is responsible for over 400 000 deaths per year and its estimated cost to the economy is hundreds of billions of euros. In my own region, London, the number of premature deaths is estimated to be around 10 000 people per year. This of course affects vulnerable people the most: pregnant women, children, the elderly and those on the lowest incomes. This is why we urgently need measures to address dangerous pollutants across all sectors.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Thousands continue to die in my East of England constituency from respiratory diseases such as asthma, COPD and lung cancer, in the last year alone: more than 200 in Cambridgeshire, 300 in Suffolk, 400 in Norfolk, 500 in Hertfordshire, and 700 in Essex. Yet the British Conservative rapporteur voted against her own report at committee due to successful amendments which Labour MEPs submitted to raise the level of ambition in terms of the targets with which EU Member States have to comply. Labour backs and the Conservatives oppose: binding EU emission targets for 2025, specific measures to protect vulnerable people, enhanced monitoring by the European Commission, and access to justice if governments fail to deliver. This would save an additional 140 000 life years each year across Europe. British Conservatives should explain why these lives are not worth saving. More than a third of the UK’s air pollution is blown over the Channel. It is yet another example where Conservatives are doing the wrong thing in Europe and would be doing the wrong thing if they took us out of Europe.

name: Jan Huitema (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 The VVD delegation considers that methane emission ceilings do not belong in the Directive on national emissions of air pollutants. Methane is a greenhouse gas and is already regulated in agreements on climate targets, including the decision on the distribution of efforts. It provides Member States with the flexibility to reduce greenhouse gas emissions based on CO2 equivalents. The inclusion of methane in the Directive on national emission ceilings limits this flexibility and the VVD delegation is opposed to this. The VVD delegation welcomes the exclusion of methane emissions from ruminants, but would have preferred that methane was not included in the European Parliament's position at all.

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki (ALDE)
text: Written. "Improving air quality is at the heart of EU regulation. Air pollution transcends national borders and causes global problems. My reservation about the proposal for a directive concerns the regulation of methane emissions. Finnish agricultural production based on relatively small numbers of animals faces major challenges if methane emissions are strictly and quickly regulated.  Imposing new obligations on a sector struggling with profitability problems is not reasonable without proper research-based planning and adequate financial support. Agriculture must play its part in reducing emissions, but the regulation of the sector must recognise the facts: there is no single magical means. There are many sources of emissions and biological processes inevitably release greenhouse gases. In livestock farming, the emission reduction package consists of numeroage small improvements in, for example, the composition of feed and manure treatment. Biogas production, which is known to be an effective methane emission reducer, also requires investments of at least hundreds of thousands of euros, which few individual countries can afford under the current circumstances. Decisive action is needed in addition to requirements.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Today my fellow MEPs and I voted against the creation of a new EU legislative framework on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants. We are particularly concerned that the proposal to include methane in this directive would duplicate international and domestic climate-change legislation, creating an additional regulatory burden for industry and government, without any corresponding benefit for the environment.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Julie Girling's report on national caps on emissions of certain air pollutants. This instrument is important to combat the aggravated air pollution experienced by large urban areas. Thousands of deaths can be prevented (nearly 48,000 in France). Nevertheless, in the interests of realism and in order not to stifle the agricultural sector, which is already suffering enormously from the Russian embargo, enteric methane has been excluded from the scope of this directive.  The report has been adopted, which I welcome.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ In December 2013, the EC adopted a proposal-package to improve air-quality in Europe, called ‘Air quality package’, whose main piece was a proposal to revise the National Emission Ceilings Directive (NECD). The new EC considered withdrawing the directive in November 2014, but because of strong resistance from the EP and civil society the proposal was kept.  The key points of the ENVI committee NECD proposal are: - Introduction of national ceilings for six pollutants (sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, ammonia, methane, particulate matter and non-methane volatile organic compounds) by 2030 - Mercury (Hg) added to the list of pollutants as caps were introduced on mercury from 2020 - Midpoint targets for 2025 fully binding for all pollutants, with the exception of methane - Methane targets delayed until 2030 to give the agriculture sector adaptation time  - Removal of CE proposal for flexibility allowing Member States to offset reductions in emissions from nitrogen oxides, sulphur dioxides and particulate matter from international shipping  - Public participation, transparency, access to justice and information This EP report is stronger than the EC-proposal, at the same time that the big aim of the directive is to put controls on different types of air-pollution with the goal to cut the number of premature deaths (about 400 000/year, caused by air pollution) by half by 2030. Hence, EH Bildu has voted in favour.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to strengthen air pollution control at European level by setting ceilings for the main pollutants. However, I rejected the inclusion of certain products in the list of controlled pollutants that would have resulted in a loss of competitiveness of our agriculture already heavily affected.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 A few months ago, EU environment ministers agreed that the level of air pollution on our continent is too high (according to EC data, around 400 000 Europeans die prematurely each year due to diseases caused by the inhalation of harmful compounds). It was therefore decided to reduce emissions of hazardous compounds from industry, road traffic or power plants by 2030.  However, in addition to the introduction of limits for sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and particulate matter, it was also decided to reduce emissions of e.g. methane, i.e. gas produced by animals, mainly cattle, and such a reduction could cause serious disturbances in the livestock sector. Together with members of the European People's Party group and colleagues from other groups, we strongly oppose the introduction of provisions to reduce methane emissions, as this could damage European agricultural production in the long term.  I hope that, despite the unfavourable outcome of the VOTE in the EP, the negotiations in the Council will take into account the voice of reason and that the revision of the directive on national pollution ceilings will not harm our farmers.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This report should be rejected. Measures to reduce greenhouse gas and air pollutant emissions from agriculture could lead to a reduction in EU production and thus jeopardise food security in view of the increase in global demand for food. Setting reduction targets for methane is "not effective." This greenhouse gas is already effectively regulated by the burden-sharing decision. In addition, the IMPACT assessment study carried out by the European Commission clearly shows that implementation entails high costs.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as measures to address dangerous pollutants covering all sectors are urgently needed. Poor air quality is responsible for over 400 000 premature deaths each year and its annual economic cost to health is estimated at EUR 300-900 billion. Around 90% of Europeans living in cities are exposed to levels of air pollution deemed damaging to human health. In addition, vulnerable socio-demographic groups, such as pregnant women, children and the elderly, and those from low-income groups are particularly affected.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The proposal for revised national emission ceilings (NEC Directive) is part of the European Commission's Clean Air Package and replaces current rules on the annual capping of national emissions of air pollutants, such as.B. sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides or ammonia. The new directive aims to introduce new emission reduction commitments for Member States from 2020 to 2030, namely PM 2.5 and methane. Parliament is increasing the targets agreed by the Council from .B 27% to 40%. The limit values for some pollutants have once again been arbitrarily increased. We need ceilings on pollutants to incentivise emission reductions, but they should be realistic, proportionate and evidence-based and should not disproportionately affect certain sectors. However, it will be difficult for some Member States, especially those with large agricultural sectors. That is why we need flexibility. Parliament's practices jeopardise the legislative process. It should be guided by the decisions of the Council, as they are negotiated by the Member States. That is why I voted against this report because it has taken on a completely different form through numerous amendments.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. The National Front delegation maintains its position against the inclusion of methane and against the mention of ammonia in the directive on reducing national emissions of certain air pollutants, in order to limit the regulatory burden on agriculture and certain industries. I was therefore ready to vote for the legislative resolution, since Mr Andrieu's oral amendment proposing an exception for enteric methane emitted by ruminant farms was adopted. However, the text was referred to committee. The National Front delegation will remain vigilant.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The revised proposal for an NEC Directive replaces the current Union regime in the annual leveling of national emissions of air pollutants, as defined in Directive 2001/81/EC, for four air pollutants, namely sulphur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), volatile organic compounds other than methane (RNA) and ammonia (NH3), until 2020. The revised NEC Directive lays down controls on the different types of air pollution in each Member State. It aims to halve the number of premature deaths – an estimated 400,000 per year in the EU – caused by air pollution by half by 2030. The proposed revision sets out new national emission reduction commitments applicable from 2020 to 2030 for the four pollutants mentioned and also for fine particulate matter (PM2.5) and methane (CH4). Although there are important points that were not adopted (it eliminates binding targets for methane), I voted in favour of this report as I think it is more demanding than the Commission's proposal and therefore improved.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The proposal for revised national emission ceilings (NEC Directive) is part of the European Commission's Clean Air Package and replaces current rules on the annual capping of national emissions of air pollutants, such as.B. sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides or ammonia. The new directive aims to introduce new emission reduction commitments for Member States from 2020 to 2030, namely PM 2.5 and methane. Parliament wanted to arbitrarily increase the targets proposed by the Council, which would have been a particularly heavy burden on German dairy farmers, particularly in the case of methane, which should have led to mass slaughter. To do so, Germany would have had to deliver much greater reductions than other states. That is why I voted against this report because it has taken on a completely different form through numerous amendments. We need ceilings on pollutants to incentivise emission reductions, but they should be realistic, proportionate and evidence-based and should not disproportionately affect certain sectors. Excessive requirements will be difficult and require flexibility, especially for those Member States with large agricultural sectors. Parliament's practices jeopardise the legislative process. It should be guided by the Decisions of the Council, as they are negotiated by the Member States.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Air quality is an important element for human health and the environment, concerns all citizens and requires urgent action. Because of years of ignorance, air pollution has become the biggest public health problem, and poorer air quality has contributed to the development of various diseases, increased health care costs, work absences and declining productivity. The total health costs caused by air pollution in Europe are estimated to be between €330 billion and €940 billion per year. On 18 December 2013, the Commission adopted a clean air package for the period up to 2030.  The proposal contains different restrictions for each Member State and each pollutant and requires member states to adopt national air pollution control programmes. It is important that the Commission continuously carries out comprehensive monitoring and provides timely assistance to Member States in delivering on the programme set out. A key step towards the target will be the introduction of low emission zones, designed to reduce diesel car emissions in urban areas hardest hit by pollution.  I supported MP Julie Girling's report to protect human health and ecosystems from the harmful effects of air pollution. Croatia has a second and third category of air quality in some urban areas, which is moderately and excessively polluted air. This is more than reason enough to give this topic more space because the price we pay is too high.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Directive provides a framework for action and regulation in EU country regimes to achieve climate change mitigation, improved air quality, population health and the environment, which are among the Union's long-term objectives. Many Member States do not comply with the standards and commitments adopted so far, thus delaying the achievement of the targets. This results in a deterioration in the health of the population and an increase in health protection expenditure. The Directive repeals and replaces the existing Directive on national emission ceilings, lays down sector-specific and economic life measures and sets new emission ceilings for sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, ammonia and non-methane volatile organic compounds for 2020 and 2030. From 2020, it also applies to particulates. In order not to increase the costs of adopting the targets set, it will be necessary to focus on new and innovative ways of financing emission reductions.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of postponing the vote on the report on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on reducing national emissions of certain air pollutants and amending Directive 2003/35/EC.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report concerns the directive used to tackle cross-border pollution. As agreed with Member States, national governments commit to ceilings for the emission of certain pollutants. I supported the raising of these ceilings to more appropriate levels and the call for binding targets for 2025. Committing to binding targets is the only way we will effectively reduce pollution, and this is crucially important, as we see that 90% of people living in cities in Europe are now exposed to levels of pollutants classified as damaging to human health.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. Setting methane reduction targets is "not effective". This greenhouse gas is already effectively regulated by the burden-sharing decision. Too strict measures to reduce greenhouse gas and air pollutant emissions from agriculture could lead to a reduction in EU production and thus jeopardise food security in view of the increase in global demand for food. That is why I abstained from voting.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The legislative proposal aims to revise the 2001 Directive on National Emission Limits (ERPs). The report sets national ceilings to be reached by 2030 for six pollutants (sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, ammonia and non-methane volatile organic compounds, fine particulate matter (PM2.5) and mercury). Compelling targets were also set mid-term. To achieve these goals, the report stresses the need to reduce road transport emissions. Some attention is also paid to pollution from agriculture. I vote for this text.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. The emission permit for certain air pollutants should be the target of binding reduction commitments. Air pollution is a serious public health problem that causes around 430 000 premature deaths in the EU each year, and it is essential that risks or threats to health and the environment are controlled. To this end, the report establishing new limit values for the emission of certain air pollutants, different from those proposed by the European Commission, is adopted. I share the rapporteur's position that it is ensured that the measures necessary to comply with the legislation allow for action within the limits set for 2030.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report as it calls for measures to strengthen the monitoring mechanisms to ensure timely progress in emission reductions, including transparency in drawing up and updating the national air-pollution control programmes. The final vote on the legislative resolution was postponed to another sitting.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption by the European Parliament of the report on emissions of certain air pollutants to revise the 2003 directive. The Union intends to tackle the problem of air pollution. The text provides emission caps for 6 major air pollutants, including sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, ammonia and methane. With regard to enteric methane (produced by ruminants), I have expressed my support for its removal from the scope of the text in order to avoid imposing an additional burden on farmers and to take into account the specificities and rules relating to the sector as well as the progress already made.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 European air protection policy has a long history and has achieved significant successes in that time, but the EU is still far from its long-term objective of complying with the recommended pollutant limits set out in the WHO Air Quality Guidelines of 2005. I therefore welcome the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on reducing national emissions of certain air pollutants. Our aim must be to achieve a level of air quality that does not have unacceptable effects and risks with regard to human health and the environment. Today, poor air quality contributes to premature deaths, absences from work due to illness, significant health care costs and productivity losses, with the total external health costs incurred by companies due to air pollution estimated at between EUR 330 and 940 billion per year. Moreover, according to the OECD, by 2050, urban air pollution may become the leading environmental cause of mortality worldwide.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission has proposed the adoption of a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants and amending Directive 2003/35/EC. The Commission proposal repeals and replaces the current Directive on national emission limit values, And for 2020 and 2030, it sets new limits for emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, ammonia and volatile organic compounds other than methane, and extends the scope of the Directive to particulate matter (PM2,5) from 2020 and methane from 2030. Parliament's Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety tabled 118 amendments to the proposal in its report, but recommended the proposal to Parliament for adoption. I voted accordingly on the proposal.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This Girling report on emissions of certain air pollutants concerns the directive that continues the work of the 2001 PEN Directive on emission caps for certain air pollutants including sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxide, ammonia and non-methane volatile organic compounds (NMVOC) until 2020. The new directive proposes new thresholds until 2030 by adding methane (polluting gas from largely agricultural and livestock activities) and fine particulate matter. The rapporteur proposed a more binding deadline in 2025, but rejected the inclusion of methane (see agriculture). The elected FN in the Commission supported the position against the inclusion of methane and against the mention of ammonia in order to limit the regulatory weight on agriculture and certain industries. So I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Poor air quality is responsible for over 400 000 premature deaths each year and its economic cost for health is estimated at between EUR 300bn-900bn every year. Around 90% of Europeans living in cities are exposed to levels of air pollution deemed damaging to human health. In addition, vulnerable socio-demographic groups such as pregnant women, children, the elderly, as well as those from low income groups, are particularly affected. Measures to address dangerous pollutants covering all sectors are urgently needed.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the NEC Directive, which is a crucial legislative instrument for monitoring compliance with air quality targets at European level. Ambitious standards are needed to combat air pollution, which is believed to be responsible for many premature deaths. However, to be effective, legislation in this area must be realistic and take into account the economic role played by businesses. For example, I am in favour of setting national ceilings for environmental protection and air quality, but I have opposed the integration of enteric methane (gas from fermentation that takes place in the ruminant belly) into the calculation of these ceilings. This would have been an unreasonable constraint for European breeders whose animals are raised outdoors.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of revising the NEC Directive for the proposed ambitious new targets. In fact, despite the progress made, low air quality causes more than four hundred thousand victims every year and weighs on the health sector with an annual figure of between three hundred and nine hundred billion euros. In addition, the most vulnerable to health risk are the most fragile: pregnant women, the elderly and low-income families. It is clear that, in order to address these concerns and to ensure that the EU's international commitments are fulfilled, a reform setting new binding targets for 2025 and 2030 is needed. We also welcome the introduction of limits, particularly on ammonia, on emissions from the agricultural sector, which is responsible for forty% of air pollution. The cost of non-action is, in fact, too high and agriculture, like all other sectors, must, by limiting its emissions, contribute. The proposal is also part of the wider framework of the EU's long-term objectives, with particular reference to the fight against climate change. The review is, in fact, consistent with the European Union's position on the international stage and, in particular, strengthens its role at the next Conference in Paris.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. We need ambitious standards to combat air pollution. This directive is therefore a crucial legislative instrument for monitoring compliance with air quality targets at European level. But if we want effective legislation, it must above all be realistic and take into account the negative impact that overly restrictive standards could have on industry and agriculture and, ultimately, on employment.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report that will led to the introduction of new ceilings on emissions for sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, ammonia and non-methane volatile organic compounds for 2020 and 2030.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I decided to vote against this report because I believe that it started from a Commission proposal on reducing air pollutants in the EU, which is a topic that needs to be debated and for which viable solutions must be found in order to achieve the objectives, but, with the additions to this initial proposal, it has also involved small and medium agriculture.  By adding provisions on harmful gas emissions from livestock farming, with the express appointment of small and medium-sized agriculture, costs and obligations are involved for farmers who are at the limit or below the limit of profitability. Such a provision for farmers and livestock farmers in Romania, however large or small, would mean additional costs that are intractable and would involve the bankruptcy of many.  In these circumstances, I felt obliged to the citizens of Romania to vote against this report.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of national emissions of certain air pollutants and on the amendment of Directive 2003/35/EC aims to tackle the cross-border problems of air pollution. In general, I welcome a more sustainable approach to our nature, including a reduction in air pollutants. However, further requirements restrict the competitiveness of our companies, which is why I would have abstained.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported and hopefully the trilogue will give a good result for the final vote. Air quality is an area that very clearly affects both human health and our wider environment. Air pollution causes the premature death of hundreds of thousands of people in the EU every year. It is therefore necessary to act immediately to reduce air pollution.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. The Emissions Reduction Directive comes at a turning point. The growing concern of citizens about public health issues is linked to the Volkswagen scandal and the incalculable and irreversible negative effects on health and the environment.  Despite efforts to reduce air pollution, the European Union is still far from meeting the targets. Polluted air kills more than three million people worldwide every year prematurely and external health costs to society in Europe are estimated to range from EUR 330 billion to EUR 940 billion per year, not counting environmental damage. The proposal we are voting on today is ambitious, setting new emission ceilings and mandatory targets for 2025 in a clear commitment to the health of Europeans. That's why I can only vote for it.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – Air pollution is harmful to human health and the environment. It is necessary to reduce emissions into the atmosphere, especially in the industrial and energy sectors. However, the new regulation cannot create an unreasonably high financial or bureaucratic burden. I do not believe that methane and mercury should be included in the scope of this directive. The introduction of new national emission limits for the most important types of atmospheric pollutants requires an assessment of the efforts already made by The Member States. Research on the extent and environmental impact of pollution needs to be carried out. In addition, the introduction of more environmentally friendly technologies and cleaner production methods and the application of more efficient environmental protection measures must be promoted.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for this text. This directive will help to redefine the targets for reducing air pollutants that are very dangerous to human health. Air quality in Europe will be greatly improved after the adoption of this text in trilogue. The european Parliament's position is firm and balanced and will allow for a good negotiation with the Council, hence my support.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the creation of a new EU legislative framework on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants. We are particularly concerned that the proposal to include methane in this directive would duplicate international and domestic climate-change legislation, creating an additional regulatory burden for industry and government, without any corresponding benefit for the environment.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 While I understand the rapporteur's difficulties, I do not agree with the final result. I therefore reserve the right to vote in favour only if the amendments proposed by my group are taken into account. As you know, I am concerned about the problem of air pollution and I believe that we must continue to work together to resolve this problem, which is of enormous importance to the European and international community.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. – I supported the report because the European Union needs legislation that will restrict more emissions of major air pollutants, including ammonia. Emissions have an impact on poorer human health and, with Parliament's proposals adopted, citizens will be able to enjoy a better, cleaner air.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Air pollution is a problem encountered by many major cities in Europe and the world, and sources of pollution are due to the development of civilization and the way of life of modern man. This directive aims to set frameworks for reducing air pollution to pollution levels that would not cause significant negative effects for human health and the environment, in line with air quality guidelines published by the World Health Organisation. The appropriate measures and objectives must take into account the possibility of their implementation and the impact of those measures on individual sectors. This is why, when preparing the report, there was a heated debate about the inclusion of methane and mercury on the list of air pollutants whose emissions should be limited, and on better monitoring of anmonia emissions whose emissions should be further reduced in the environment.  Including methane on the pollutant list can have serious consequences for EU agriculture, especially meat-producing sectors. Animal welfare could be jeopardised by limiting methane emissions from the agriculture sector, as animals would have to spend more time indoors.  I believe that methane emissions from agricultural production must be addressed in a package of regulations related to European climate action, a joint effort of all sectors emitting methane bearing in mind the real capabilities of each sector.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This Girling report on emissions of certain air pollutants relates to the directive that continues the work of the 2001 PEN Directive on emission caps for certain air pollutants including sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxide, ammonia and non-methane volatile organic compounds (NMVOC) until 2020. The new directive proposes new thresholds until 2030 by adding methane (polluting gas largely from agricultural activities and livestock) and fine particulate matter. The rapporteur proposed a more binding deadline in 2025 but rejected the inclusion of methane (see agriculture). The elected FN in the Commission supported the position against the inclusion of methane and against the mention of ammonia in order to limit the regulatory weight on agriculture and certain industries. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ As poor air quality remains the cause of hundreds of thousands of premature deaths per year and a major environmental and economic problem, stronger EU integrated action is needed to mitigate the impact of climate change and improve the synergy of Union legislation with its climate and energy policies.  The proposal for this directive establishes new obligations to reduce national emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, atmonia and non-methane volatile organic compounds for 2020, 2025 and 2030, on the basis of a detailed cost-benefit study for each Member State separately.  Methane, fine particulate matter (PM2.5) and mercury were also added to the scope of the Directive. The implementation of this directive should, in addition to the expected gains in environmental and health terms, lead to the creation of 40 000 new jobs and the strengthening of green technology. National air pollution control programmes provide for measures applicable to the agricultural sector, industry, road transport, and for Member States to regularly update their national emission reduction programmes under the supervision of authorised authorities.  Under the new proposal, Croatia should reduce SO2 emissions by 87%, nitrogen oxides by 70% and ammonia by 29% under the new proposal, and in addition such provisions would contribute to encouraging more responsible agri-organic farming, while opening access to additional subsidies from EU funds to support SMEs.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support my colleague Julie Girling's report on the proposal for a directive from the European Parliament and the Council on reducing national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants and amending Directive 2003/35/EC. The Directive aims to limit emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants, contributing to the European Union's long-term objective of achieving better air quality that would not cause negative impacts on human health and the environment, as well as mitigating the impact of climate change.  The Directive should be in line with European and international actions on climate change and a comprehensive binding global agreement on climate change. Even more ambitious targets to be met by 2030 are proposed, with Member States needing to meet the emission reduction requirements of certain polluters and providing progress reports to the Commission. National air pollution control programmes should consider the cost-effectiveness of emission reduction measures and set out concrete policy measures aimed at reducing health-negative risks.  Member States should establish a routine and non-routine environmental inspection system and ensure that members of the interested public are consulted at an early stage of drafting. The Commission should facilitate access to finance to ensure that appropriate measures can be taken in line with the objectives of this Directive, and a European Clean Air Forum is also planned.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Environmental pollution causes around 400,000 premature deaths in the EU each year.
