The new rules contained in the Commission's proposal could save up to EUR 40 billion in costs to combat environmental pollution by 2030. The Commission's proposal repeals and replaces the current NEC Directive, setting new limits for emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, ammonia and non-metanic volatile organic compounds by 2020 and 2030. This proposal also aims to extend the scope of the directive to fine particulate matter (PM2.5) from 2020, and to methane from 2030. The 2020 targets reflect the commitments that have been made internationally under the Gothenburg Protocol 2012. In view of the serious health risks and the considerable impacts still arising from air pollution on the environment, I hope that, even through my vote in favour, we will be able to achieve a gradual reduction in harmful emissions into the atmosphere as soon as possible, for the sake of the health of European citizens.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In order to effectively combat global warming and to encourage a gradual reduction in air pollutant emissions, the Commission has introduced the PEN Directive on National Emissions Caps. This instrument aims to regulate emissions of pollutants into the air by setting emission limits for Member States for the main pollutants. In this context, the Commission has proposed to adapt the current PEN directive and set new ceilings.  The European Parliament has adopted the Commission's proposal, but has not yet agreed on the ENVI committee's proposal. The vote was postponed because the ENVI resolution set far too ambitious or even unrealistic ceilings. I support this position and encourage a realistic text that is adapted to the environmental, social and economic needs of our States.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the creation of a new EU legislative framework on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants. We are particularly concerned that the proposal to include methane in this directive would duplicate international and domestic climate-change legislation, creating an additional regulatory burden for industry and government, without any corresponding benefit for the environment.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted this afternoon in favour of ambitious air quality legislation. Not because the Paris climate summit is on the horizon, but because air pollution is responsible for 400,000 premature deaths in the EU every year. More exactly, I supported binding targets for 6 gases that are particularly harmful to the environment and/or human health: ammonia, fine particulate matter, NOx, SO2, VOCs and methane. For the latter gas, which is bad for the ozone layer, I have taken into account the difficulty for the agricultural sector to comply with the most ambitious standards. That is why I strongly and convincingly supported Amendment 33, which provides for the exclusion of enteric methane from the scope of this directive. As a result, herds of cows will be able to continue to graze quietly in the meadow. The reverse would have been damaging for cattle farming, which is in tune with the new rules set by the CAP: the application of the third pillar known as "greening". Nevertheless, it is essential to do more against this invisible killer, air pollution, which causes ten times more deaths each year than traffic accidents.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. Air pollution from human activities, from industry to agriculture, is believed to be responsible for the deaths of 400,000 European citizens each year. This number is ten times higher than that of road deaths. Thus, it is essential to tackle the problems of polluting emissions, through a comprehensive and European solution, since pollution knows no borders.  So, on Wednesday, October 28, I voted in favour of the report on reducing national emissions of certain air pollutants, which specifically sets an emissions ceiling by 2030. Emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and fine particulate matter are included here. However, the European Parliament has decided, and I welcome this, not to introduce an emissions cap on enteric methane, thus avoiding imposing a double penalty on cattle producers. By reducing tolerated emission limits, this legislation could improve the living conditions of European citizens and reduce the number of deaths due to poor air quality. It is also a signal sent to our partners in the run-up to COP 21.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. Parliament has clearly spoken out to strengthen the European Commission's proposal for new rules from 2020 to 2030 on emissions of certain pollutants that are dangerous to health. A few weeks before COP 21, Parliament sent a strong signal to reduce emissions of harmful pollutants. Today's vote reinforces the European Commission's proposal, which includes sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxide, fine particulate matter and ammonia, which seriously attack the respiratory system. Environmentalists regret, however, that on mercury, a powerful neurotoxic, a source of neurological impairments, Parliament has followed the Commission by excluding it from regulation. The Commission's proposal aimed to reduce emissions of these pollutants from 2020 to 2030 and Parliament has added binding targets from 2025. Air pollution is responsible for nearly 480,000 premature deaths on the European continent, the time for procrastination is now over.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution setting new, more ambitious national caps on emissions of major air pollutants harmful to human health and the environment: nitrogen oxides, sulphur dioxide, non-methane volatile organic compounds, ammonia, methane and particulate particles. Air pollution is responsible for around 400,000 premature deaths each year in the European Union and causes between 300 and 900 billion euros in health costs per year. There is therefore an urgent need to address these serious air quality problems that persist in the Union. The fixed reductions apply from 2020 and 2030, with intermediate emission levels for 2025. We have decided to keep methane and ammonia in the directive, two pollutants mainly from agriculture, while excluding the naturally produced enteric methane emissions from ruminants. Negotiations will now be open with the Council with a view to reaching a first reading agreement.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 Air pollution is responsible for the premature death of more than 400,000 people each year and its economic cost to the health system is estimated at between EUR 300 000 and EUR 900 billion annually. Approximately 90% of Europeans living in cities are exposed to a level of air pollution detrimental to human health. In addition, vulnerable sociodemographic groups, in particular pregnant women, children and the elderly, as well as low-income groups, are particularly affected.   The proposal for a Directive on national emission ceilings replaces the current national emission limit regime for certain air pollutants, in particular sulfide (SO2), nitrogen (NOx), volatile organic compounds (NMVOC) and ammonia (NH3) until 2020. It includes the establishment of new national emission reduction commitments applicable for 2020 and 2030 for the above-mentioned air pollutants, as well as for fine particulate matter (PM2.5) and methane (CH4). In addition, Member States shall draft national air pollution control programmes.  For these reasons, I voted in favour of this essential legislative proposal to improve air quality in Europe. In addition, with the aim of assisting the agricultural sector, I supported the exclusion of methane from the scope of the Directive.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I welcome the vote in this report, in which the European Parliament voted in favour of caps on emissions of pollutants that need to be much stricter to combat air pollution. The adopted report strengthens the emission limits for certain pollutants that are dangerous to health by 2020-2030.  As a reminder, air pollution causes some 400,000 premature deaths in the EU annually. While Member States are well committed to dealing with this situation, they are not keeping their commitments. It is therefore a good thing that Parliament has chosen to strengthen the European Commission's proposal by tightening standards for six pollutants.  At the base, ceilings must continue to fall by 2030 for sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxide, ammonia, methane, volatile organic compounds other than methane, fine particulate matter or ammonia. The European Parliament has introduced binding intermediate targets to be met by 2025 and will have to negotiate with Member States to reach an agreement in the coming months.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Having a high air quality is a design that takes on a cross-border dimension in the field of public health and preservation of the environment. As such, this draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament and the Council aims to revise Directive 2003/35/EC on national emission limit values for certain air pollutants, setting new emission limit values for 2020 and 2030 for sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, ammonia and non-metic volatile organic compounds. This proposal also extends the scope of the Directive to cover particles from 2020 and methane from 2030 on. I would like to point out, like the rapporteur, that the targets of the proposal for 2030 set different limits for each Member State (MS) and for each pollutant, which is probably the most complex element. However, it is essential to comply with it, taking into account the negative impacts these emissions have on health and on increasing air pollution. It should also be added that this proposal is smarter and simplified, reducing administrative costs for businesses and Member States, and is consistent with other pillars of European policy, and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report which sets new national caps on certain pollutants and will allow for control of the level of air pollution in the European Union. Indeed, we must provide solutions to the serious phenomenon of air pollution, which causes more than 400,000 premature deaths in the European Union every year, including more than 48,000 in France! In voting for this report, we are pursuing the objective of improving air quality and I want to make it clear that we have supported realistic objectives, including calling for the exclusion of methane from the scope of the directive; indeed, without this exclusion, this text could have been a real threat to the agricultural sector.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the improvements achieved in recent years, air pollution in Europe remains a major problem, but at the same time we must ensure the right balance between the environment and industrial policies in view of the technological and economic capabilities of European industry and the possible loss of jobs. The European Parliament approved the rapporteur's proposal to postpone the vote on the draft legislative resolution. The matter is therefore deemed to have been referred back to the committee responsible for review.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report in order to regulate certain air pollutants, such as methane emissions. 40% of greenhouse gas emissions come from agriculture. It is also an important precursor to another air pollutant, tropospheric ozone, which causes respiratory and cardiovascular diseases and, by the way, also significant damage to agricultural crops, especially in Mediterranean countries.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report which sets new national ceilings on certain pollutants and will allow for control of the level of air pollution in the European Union. Indeed, we must provide solutions to the serious phenomenon of air pollution, which causes more than 400,000 premature deaths in the European Union every year, including more than 48,000 in France! In voting for this report, we are pursuing the objective of improving air quality and I want to make it clear that we have supported realistic objectives, including calling for the exclusion of methane from the scope of the directive; indeed, without this exclusion, this text could have been a real threat to the agricultural sector.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This directive on the reduction of national emissions aims to improve air quality, and that will undoubtedly have a positive impact on health. However, headline targets mean nothing if they cannot be implemented or if doing so leads to extensive job losses and increased inequality. Ambitious targets must be achievable for all Member States and should not represent a disproportionate burden for countries with fewer resources. We must strive to adopt legislation which brings environmental, health, societal and economic benefits.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The revised proposal for an NEC Directive replaces the current Union regime in the annual leveling of national emissions of air pollutants, as defined in Directive 2001/81/EC, for four air pollutants, namely sulphur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), volatile organic compounds other than methane (RNA) and ammonia (NH3), until 2020. The revised NEC Directive lays down controls on the different types of air pollution in each Member State. It aims to halve the number of premature deaths – an estimated 400,000 per year in the EU – caused by air pollution by half by 2030. The proposed revision sets out new national emission reduction commitments applicable from 2020 to 2030 for the four pollutants mentioned and also for fine particulate matter (PM2.5) and methane (CH4). Although there are important points that were not adopted (it eliminates binding targets for methane), I voted in favour of this report as I think it is more demanding than the Commission's proposal and therefore improved.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We are faced with a legislative text that embraces one of the greatest challenges of our day. This challenge translates into transforming the paradigm of the start-up of the era of industrialization that has reached a dimension that does not care for the world as we know it today. This challenge means reassessing our senses of economic progress and growth and integrating criteria such as the urgency to preserve our resources, which are not infinite.  This legislation is an incentive for technological innovation and should be implemented in harmony and coordination with other policies in the field of research and development, the protection of biodiversity and climate change. This should be done with a view to evolving parallel to all these levels, or otherwise we will jeopardise the transition to a low-carbon economy, the resilience of our resources and the quality of life of future generations.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this proposal because I do not wish to see EU regulation in this field. However, I recognise the importance of improving air quality and reducing pollutants in the air. I wish for this type of legislation to be made in our own national parliament, not the EU.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As other MEPs have highlighted, poor air quality is responsible for a shockingly high number of premature deaths each year, and its economic cost for health is also worryingly pronounced. Vulnerable socio-economic groups are particularly at risk from poor air quality, in particular the elderly, low-income groups, children and pregnant women. Measures are needed desperately to address these issues, and that is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. \u2012 Today we are at risk of major pollution caused by gases such as sulphur dioxide, nitric oxide, non-methane volatile organic compounds, ammonia, fine particles and methane. It is essential to reduce air pollution and its detrimental impact on public health and the environment across the Union.  As the objectives of the report are ambitious and in line with the Objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy for Smart, Inclusive and Sustainable Development, I supported this initiative. It should stimulate innovation to support green growth and maintain the competitiveness of the European economy, while helping to transition to a low-carbon economy while protecting Europe's natural capital and taking advantage of Europe's leadership in developing new technologies.  In addition, reduction commitments for 2030 will reduce the total external cost of air pollution by €40 billion, compared to €212 billion in baselines, which is all the more reason why this initiative needs to be implemented.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Report on the proposal for a directive on the reduction of national emissions for certain air pollutants sets binding national emission reduction commitments by 2020, 2025 and 2030. The aim is to limit emissions of air pollutants and to contribute effectively to the EU's objective of achieving better air quality.  The aim is to reduce the negative effects on human health caused by air pollution. The desire is to improve the quality of life of EU citizens and to promote the transition to a green economy. In order to actually reduce emissions of the largest air pollutants, measures applicable to all relevant sectors, including agriculture, industry, road transport, inland navigation and domestic maritime transport, domestic heating and solvents, should be included in national air pollution control programmes.  Taking into account specific national circumstances, Member States should be able to implement measures which are not provided for in this Directive but which are equally environmentally effective. I myself abstained in the vote on the Commission's proposal, as amended by the amendments, mainly because the ambitious emission reduction requirements were not supported by the majority of the European Parliament.  However, I supported the proposal to postpone the legislative resolution with a view to allowing negotiations on the position of the first position to be negotiated between the European Parliament and the European Council.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Air pollution is responsible for the premature death of more than 400,000 people each year, with estimated annual global costs of between €300 billion and €900 billion, according to data provided by the European Commission. In addition to the high human and economic costs, poor air quality is a serious damage to the natural environment, through phenomena such as eutrophication and acid rain. That is why I voted in favour of the report approving the European Commission's proposal to set higher national emission limits for the six main pollutants, including sulphur dioxide, particulate matter and nitrogen oxides. These measures are necessary to combat pollution from these substances in all sectors and to limit their effects on people and the environment; action in this regard was particularly necessary with regard to urban areas, where European citizens are exposed to air pollution levels considered harmful to human health.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The proposal for revised national emission ceilings (NEC Directive) is part of the European Commission's Clean Air Package and replaces current rules on the annual capping of national emissions of air pollutants, such as.B. sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides or ammonia. The new directive aims to introduce new emission reduction commitments for Member States from 2020 to 2030, namely PM 2.5 and methane. Parliament always erases the same mistake by increasing the targets agreed by the Council from .B 27% to 40%. With this report, too, we have seen that the Greens and Sozis would rather have no agreement on emissions than reach an agreement. The limit values for some pollutants have once again been arbitrarily increased. We need ceilings on pollutants to incentivise emission reductions, but they should be realistic, proportionate and evidence-based and should not disproportionately affect certain sectors. However, it will be difficult for some Member States, especially those with large agricultural sectors. That is why we need flexibility. Parliament's practices jeopardise the legislative process. It should be guided by the decisions of the Council, as they are negotiated by the Member States. That is why I voted against this report because it has taken on a completely different form through numerous amendments.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The right to quality air should be a matter of course. However, we must seek an appropriate balance between environmental protection and the objective of restoring industrial production, increasing economic growth and increasing employment.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report, as progress has been made in the Union over the past 20 years in the area of anthropogenic air emissions and air quality thanks to a specific Union policy, including the Commission Communication 'Thematic Strategy on Air Pollution'. The Union's long-term objective for air quality policy should be to achieve air quality that does not have negative impacts on and risks to human health and the environment.  Intensified efforts are needed in areas where residents and ecosystems are exposed to high levels of air pollutants and enhanced synergies between air quality legislation and policy objectives set by the Union to change the climate and biodiversity in particular.  Member States should contribute to achieving the Union's long-term air quality target in line with World Health Organisation guidelines and Union biodiversity and ecosystem objectives by reducing the level and deposition of acidifying, eutrophication-causing air pollutants and those relating to ozone below critical loads and levels.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ This proposal for a directive from the European Parliament and the Council to reduce the national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants, although there are very high-quality provisions, is not precise enough and I do not support such a proposal. Much progress has been made in the European Union over the past 20 years in the area of air quality thanks to the Union's specific policy.  The setting of ceilings on total annual emissions in application since 2010 for sulphur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), amonia (NH3) and non-methane volatile organic compounds (NMHOS) has led to a reduction in a number of harmful emissions. However, significant negative impacts for the environment and human health persist. This proposed directive would replace the current European Union regulation on the caps on annual national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants and would establish new commitments to linear reductions in national emissions between 2020 and 2030.  This proposal certainly contributes to the quality of human health and the environment, but the European People's Party's request is that by 2017 the Commission adopts a new proposal for burden sharing within the European Union with a revised mandatory reduction inmonia emissions by 2030. In addition, the EPP requires methane deletion. I supported the return of this report to the home committee in order to continue the dialogue with the Council.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report aims to ensure that the national emission ceilings set out in Directive 2001/81/EC for 2010 apply by 2020 and also establishes new national emission reduction commitments. It obliges Member States to regularly update their national air pollution control programmes and lays down the provisions on penalties applicable to infringements of national provisions adopted in accordance with the proposal.  Particularly important is the exception we have achieved with regard to the agricultural sector with regard to the directive on greater reduction of methane and ammonia. The agricultural sector, particularly in Cyprus as in other EU countries, is already facing a number of problems and it would not be the most appropriate time to burden it more with targets for further reduction of ammonia and methane. For the time being, the current limits are satisfactory. That is why we have decided to vote in favour of the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is imperative to empower the competent authorities to ensure compliance with all legislative provisions relating to the 2030 limits. In particular, the introduction of low-emission zones and a system for charging charges for road pollution with the objective of reducing emissions of pollutants from diesel vehicles, particularly in urban areas.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that air pollution is a real problem and the draft proposes real solutions to create cleaner air.  High levels of air are estimated to be responsible for around 400 000 premature deaths in the EU each year, while their indirect adverse effects are unpredictable. I believe that the level of emissions of pollutants should be radically limited. For this reason, the draft proposes an ambitious immediate reduction for all sectors with this so-called national emission reduction ceiling directive. Setting up the 2020 and 2030 SO2, NOx, NMVOC and ammonia (NH 3) as well as fine powder (PM2,5) and methane (CH4) for the new Member States' commitments is a serious responsibility, but it also gives us the opportunity, in my opinion. Member States should set up a national air pollution control programme and monitor it every two years, but this could save hundreds of thousands of lives. This will also save them money, which they can safely spend on developing renewable, environmentally friendly technologies.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the limits of pollutants have been weakened compared to the ENVI committee's proposal, it has been possible to keep ammonia and methane among the substances covered by the directive. I regret that mercury has been left out, but we have managed to get the Commission to approve an impact study followed by a legislative proposal on mercury. Air pollution is a serious environmental health problem in the European Union. The Commission must ensure that all policies on air pollution of European origin are suitable for achieving air quality objectives in the Union. To this end, the Commission must also implement without delay the new proposal for a Euro 6 regulation on emissions under real driving conditions. The proposal also aims at binding emission reduction targets by 2025 and not just 2030. Overall, however, my opinion is not unfavourable.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Economic development, with ramifications in increasing transport, industrial activity and urbanisation, brings with it a number of negative effects on the health of European citizens.  The European Commission has dedicated a policy to the objective of improving the poor quality of breathed air in Europe, the instrument of which involves capping Member States' total annual emissions for sulphur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), ammonia (NH3) and non-methane volatile organic compounds (COVnm). In the Member States of Central and Eastern Europe, where indigenous solid fuel is used in the energy mix, reducing pollutants such as sulphur dioxide and particulate matter is proving to be much more difficult than in other cases. Despite this, the States concerned are signatories to the Gothenburg Protocol, which governs measures to control and protect air quality. However, the application of the measures proposed in this report by reducing certain air pollutants leads to excessive costs and creates a disproportionate administrative burden on key sectors such as industrial, energy, transport and residential sectors. While the European Commission's proposal sets out a set of limits on pollutants that can be imposed, the European Parliament's report is very ambitious, based on some theoretical assumptions and projections.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. Europe must be at the forefront of the fight against climate change.  We want a fair transition to a sustainable, low-carbon economy. Today we spend the equivalent of one and a half planets a year on resources. The future of our planet is in danger.  The text voted today goes in this direction and sets limits on the release of pollutants into the air for the Member States of Europe. We are talking about thousands of tons of fine particulate matter, ammonia, nitrogen dioxide, sulphur, etc. I recall that poor air quality is responsible for more than 400,000 premature deaths each year and its economic cost to health is estimated at between 300 and 900 billion euros each year. 90% of Europeans living in cities are exposed to pollution levels considered dangerous. A real change of course is essential! One more important point, I spoke in favour of the exclusion of enteric methane. Indeed, it is in the minority, and, without its exclusion, the agricultural sector should bear an additional obstacle in its food mission.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In December 2013 the Commission presented a proposal on the directive on national emissions reduction commitments. Despite improvements in air quality in the EU in recent decades, we are still far from achieving the quality levels we need. The Commission proposed a number of annual reduction objectives for several pollutants (including the transposition of the Gothenburg Protocol, 2025 indicative targets and 2030 binding targets, aimed at achieving 70% of the ‘maximum technically feasible reduction’ identified in an impact assessment) as well as the addition of PM2,5 and methane to the list of pollutants. While I am very much in favour of limiting air pollution, in order to protect the health of EU citizens and the environment, I am opposed to strengthening the reduction targets and making the intermediate 2025 targets binding. I voted in favour of the deletion of methane and mercury from the scope of the directive and I voted against higher reduction targets proposed by the Committee on Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, as these could have a significant impact on EU industry. The higher targets for 2030 were voted down; the inclusion of methane and ammonia and the binding 2025 targets were approved. Therefore I decided to abstain in the final vote.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. Poor air quality is responsible for more than 400,000 deaths each year and costs our health systems between 300 and 900 million euros. 90% of European city dwellers are exposed to levels of pollution that pose a health risk. It was therefore necessary that we legislate to reduce these risks and limit polluting emissions.  The report presented by Mrs Girling is ambitious, aiming to limit emissions of the main pollutants, particularly in the sectors of transport, industry, energy, residential heating, services and agriculture. This revision of the Emission Caps Directive includes methane and ammonia, which is a substantial step forward for air quality. Although I welcome the ambition of the text, I have chosen to vote on the amendment that excludes enteric methane, i.e. the farts of cows. Farmers already in great difficulty cannot be penalized for an unavoidable natural phenomenon, while they sustain our territories and preserve the grasslands, which are also essential for air quality.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The air pollution situation in Europe is serious. Every year, air pollution causes more than 400 000 premature deaths in the countries of the European Union. Strokes, respiratory infections, lung cancers are also on the increase due to the presence in the atmosphere of pollutants that are very harmful to health. Air pollution also has a serious and often devastating impact on nature and biodiversity, crops and, not least, our artistic and cultural heritage. A reduction in emissions is therefore necessary, which is why I voted in favour of the proposal. Only through greater commitment and ambitious targets will we be able to guarantee a healthier environment for future generations.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of national emissions for certain air pollutants and on the amendment of Directive 2003/35/EC, because I believe that air quality is important for human health and the environment, and the current state of pollutants in the air requires immediate, global and responsible action.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report in order to regulate certain air pollutants, such as methane emissions. 40% of greenhouse gas emissions come from agriculture. It is also an important precursor to another air pollutant, tropospheric ozone, which causes respiratory and cardiovascular diseases and, by the way, also significant damage to agricultural crops, especially in Mediterranean countries.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. The proposal for revised national emission ceilings (NEC Directive) is part of the European Commission's Clean Air Package and replaces current rules on the annual capping of national emissions of air pollutants, such as.B. sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides or ammonia. The new directive aims to introduce new emission reduction commitments for Member States from 2020 to 2030, namely PM 2.5 and methane. Parliament wanted to arbitrarily increase the targets proposed by the Council. We need ceilings on pollutants to incentivise emission reductions, but they should be realistic, proportionate and evidence-based and should not disproportionately affect certain sectors. Excessive requirements will be difficult and require flexibility, especially for those Member States with large agricultural sectors. Parliament's practices jeopardise the legislative process. It should be guided by the Decisions of the Council, as they are negotiated by the Member States. That is why I voted against this report because it has taken on a completely different form through numerous amendments.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report in order to regulate certain air pollutants, such as methane emissions. 40% of greenhouse gas emissions come from agriculture. It is also an important precursor to another air pollutant, tropospheric ozone, which causes respiratory and cardiovascular diseases and, by the way, also significant damage to agricultural crops, especially in Mediterranean countries.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Dear Colleagues, I supported My Colleague Gurling's report on the introduction of national emission ceilings for six main pollutants – sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, non-methane volatile organic compounds, ammonia, methane, and particulate matter (less than 2.5 micrometres) to be achieved between 2020 and 2030. , protecting the interests of farmers who have recently been exposed to too many risks. In the end, however, the European Parliament was able to exclude restrictions on enteric methane, which is caused by degestimation processes in farm animals. But essentially methane is a greenhouse gas, and there are already limits to climate legislation, and any duplication of norms causes chaos and new difficulties for affected people and businesses. My support for the new legislation is also due to the fact that the European Parliament has not accepted an increase in member states' obligations over the European Commission proposal, which would make it more difficult to meet the targets and cost many billions of euros in additional costs. Despite the conscious need to limit harmful emissions, from which hundreds of thousands of people die each year, the legislation must take into account the real possibilities and the necessary costs for its implementation.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The revised proposal for an NEC Directive replaces the current Union regime in the annual leveling of national emissions of air pollutants, As defined in Directive 2001/81/EC, for four air pollutants: sulphur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), volatile organic compounds other than methane (RNA) and ammonia (NH3), up to 2020. The revised NEC Directive lays down controls on the different types of air pollution in each Member State. It aims to halve the number of premature deaths – an estimated 400,000 per year in the EU – caused by air pollution by half by 2030. The proposed revision sets out new national emission reduction commitments applicable from 2020 to 2030 for the four pollutants mentioned and also for fine particulate matter (PM2.5) and methane (CH4). Although there are important points that were not adopted (it eliminates binding targets for methane), I voted in favour of this report as I think it is more demanding than the Commission's proposal and therefore improved.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Amending Directive 2003/35/EC could be an important step towards reducing national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants. There were, however, some issues with the aspects of the proposed approach that we in the S&D Group attempted to address. However, that should not detract from the fact that, while overall the progress in tackling air pollution has been good, there is still a lot of work to be done to ensure that air quality in Europe improves. This is crucial, as our levels of air pollution are central to our long-term ecological wellbeing, and low levels of air pollution are also vital to our day-to-day health. We would not tolerate contamination of our water: it makes no more sense to tolerate the contamination of our air.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'We must not forget that our own farmers supply top quality food in a highly regulated framework. If we were to tighten the emissions standards for methane and ammonia without scientific research into how this might be possible, we would force our agriculture to operate from outside the EU's borders or go bankrupt. I voted for the survival of agriculture in Europe and for cleaner air.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Air quality represents a cross-border issue that profoundly affects all citizens by demanding immediate action after years of political neglect. On 18 December 2013 the Commission published its long-awaited Clean Air Package.  The proposal to repeal and replace this Directive amends the union regime with regard to national emission limits for air pollutants for 4 new pollutants, in particular sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, ammonia and non-metic volatile organic compounds for 2020 and 2030. Mercury has also been added to this list, and the limits for this element will only be introduced from 2020. Finally, it should be noted that these new emission targets contained in the air quality standards will be redundant if we do not observe a clear political will that is reflected in a reduction in pollution from the main sources.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. A setting of binding reduction targets for methane is "not effective". This greenhouse gas is already effectively regulated by the burden-sharing decision. Too strict measures to reduce greenhouse gas and air pollutant emissions from agriculture could lead to a reduction in EU production and thus jeopardise food security in view of the increase in global demand for food. That is why, unfortunately, I had to abstain.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal because I consider air pollution to be an important problem, which goes beyond national borders and affects all citizens. Health protection is an absolute value and its protection obliges us to make every effort. The issue of air pollution has been totally ignored by the political class and this neglect has led to the issue re- emerge stronger and more worrying than ever before. Poor air quality is considered to cause about 400,000 premature deaths per year resulting in higher health care costs. Air pollution is estimated to have an economic impact of between EUR 330 billion and EUR 940 billion per year.  For these reasons, I believe it is essential to proceed quickly and to implement an immediate action plan.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The draft revision of Directive 2001/81/EC on national emission limits (NEC Directive) is part of the Clean Air Programme for Europe strategy. Since 2010, the current legislation provides for national emission limits for certain substances: sulphur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), non-methane volatile organic compounds (NMVOCs) and ammonia (NH3). The proposal for a directive envisages the continuation of this mechanism for the 2020-2030 period and reporting obligations, and extends the existing catalogue of restrictions to include new substances: the smallest particulate matter particles (PM2.5) and methane (CH4). According to the calculations carried out at the Commission's request, the consequence of the entry into force of this regulation may be a reduction in the number of meat cattle in Poland by up to 42%, dairy cattle by 24% and pigs by 12%. In view of the restrictions that could be applied so far as my country could have, I tabled amendments with Janusz Wojciechowski aimed at leaving methane outside the scope of the directive. As proposed by the rapporteur, the proposal is unacceptable to me.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the resolution proposing a revision of the National Emissions Ceiling (NECD) Directive in order to reduce toxic emissions that contribute to air pollution. I think it is appropriate to provide for binding limits for six toxic pollutants, which are estimated to cause 690 000 premature deaths every year in the European Union alone, with an estimated economic cost to health of between EUR 300 billion and EUR 900 billion each year. I find the report particularly timely because it specifies that the level of local government must play a role in defining best practices for dealing with air pollution and I am at the same time pleased that an appropriate formula has been found with regard to methane so as not to harm our farmers.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 This scandal pointed to a fundamental error in the implementation of any new measures. In this particular case of emission measurements in the automotive sector, the question of whether it is realistic for these values to be achieved and how they can possibly be enforced should be examined from the outset. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the European Commission should do more to address this scandal and, above all, to revise the current measures.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Parliament has today voted on a very important report which aims to reduce harmful emissions from various pollutants in the coming years by proposing to limit the impact of these substances on human health and the environment. The price to be paid due to poor air quality is higher in terms of human lives than that due to road accidents, thus making it the main environmental cause of premature deaths in the EU. Poor air quality also has an impact on the quality of life, as it causes asthma and respiratory problems, as well as having a major impact on the health costs of the various Member States. In the light of these figures, therefore, we can only welcome the important result achieved today. I also welcome the fact that it has been possible to exclude enteric methane from the scope of the directive, thus meeting the strong concerns expressed by small and medium-sized farms. I hope that in the coming months the text voted on by Parliament will not be undermined in its essential content, because firstly our citizens are calling for highly protective rules for their health and, on the other hand, it is important that the EU also send out a strong signal in the run-up to the Paris 2015 Conference on Climate Change (COP21).

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and the Council on the reduction of national emissions of certain air pollutants and amending Directive 2003/35/EC, considering that air quality is a cross-border issue with significant repercussions on human health and the environment, which profoundly affects all citizens of the European Union and requires immediate action. After years of political neglect, air pollution now appears on the political agenda as a serious environmental and public health problem, mainly due to the Volkswagen case. Moreover, while work has been done to reduce air pollution in the Union, many Member States have not yet met the agreed standards and the European Union itself remains far from its long-term objective. In this sense, the commission's current proposal is of great importance in replacing the existing Directive, setting new emission limit values for 2020 and 2030 and requiring Member States to take national air pollution control programmes. However, while the limit values set out in the report should encourage emission reduction, they should also be set at a realistic level, based on concrete data, and which does not have a disproportionate impact on any sector.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Air quality is a cross-border issue that affects all citizens. On 18 December 2013, the Commission published its long-awaited Clean Air Package consisting of four elements: a Clean Air Programme for Europe; a proposal for a decision to ratify the 2012 amendment to the Gothenburg Protocol on the UNECE Convention on Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution on behalf of the EU; a proposal for a new Directive on the reduction of pollution of medium-sized combustion plants, such as power plants for large buildings, and small industrial installations and, finally, the legislative proposal on this report, which reviews the 2001 Directive on national emission limit values for certain air pollutants. The proposal to repeal and replace this Directive amends the EU regime with regard to national air pollutant emission limits for 4 new pollutants, in particular sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, ammonia and non-metic volatile organic compounds for 2020 and 2030. Mercury has also been added to this list, and the limits for this element will only be introduced from 2020. We voted for it.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Citizens' Initiative is the only instrument of direct democracy in existence at present, allowing citizens to participate actively in the work of the European Union. As representatives of the Five Star Movement, which is fighting to increase direct democracy at all levels of government, I can only be pleased. This report is a good starting point. However, more can and must be done: for example, we are introducing the possibility of amending the Treaties through the people's initiative. In this way, the request for amendment would have much more force, as well as being more democratic. Again, we should think about a repeal referendum with a European scope. We simplify and reduce the bureaucratic steps of the procedure and make it as easy as possible to use IT and electronic tools. Finally, ladies and gentlemen, let us reduce the Commission's discretion in following up citizens' demands. The voice from one million or more Europeans cannot remain unheeded. This is in order to encourage participation and prevent participation from being frustrated. Let us bring the European Union closer to its citizens! For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report refers to the forthcoming revision of Regulation (EU) No 211/2011 on the European citizens' initiative and to the conclusions drawn by the European Commission in a recently published document. Our position is that the implementation of the European citizen initiative has been an absolute failure; in fact, of fifty-one registered proposals, only three have been able to meet the requirements, often because of the numerous administrative locks during the signature collection process, which sometimes lead to the Commission's own complaint to the courts.  As if that were not the case, the European Commission is not obliged to initiate any proposal for legislative amendments, so their effectiveness is minimal. In the face of this situation, the final report is not at all critical of the procedures regulated for this participatory tool; it also proposes limiting the content of the European citizens' initiative if it does not suit the competences of the Union and, above all, that the Commission should make a legislative proposal only if it has a positive opinion published by it. For these reasons, and given the low prospositivo content of the report to consolidate European citizen initiatives politically and legally, I voted against it.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF)
text: Written. 'Even if the European Citizens' Initiative were to function perfectly, it cannot be expected to solve the democratic deficit that characterises this European Union. I support the principle of the European Citizens' Initiative, not because of the so-called European integration idea, but because it can be a means of drawing the attention of the European Commission and the European elected representatives to certain issues and social problems, large or small. The Schöpflin report notes that the success of the European Citizens' Initiative is waning because of a variety of practical barriers. The finger is placed on the wound. That is why our group is not only calling for these obstacles to be cleared or for the use-friendly use of the instrument of initiative, but also for an obligation for the Commission to follow an appropriate legislative proposal on a successful European citizens' initiative. In this sense, we amended the report, but at the same time we support it.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The report on the European Citizens' Initiative (ECI) contains good ideas. It aims to reform the ICE process, which allows citizens of the Member States to refer the matter to the Commission on a subject close to their hearts and to be heard.  Since this scheme has been in existence, only three petitions have resulted in the fifty-one petitions that have been launched. Among the three that were deemed admissible was the "One of Us" initiative, which called for the european Union to stop all funding for "research activities that destroy human embryos".  The Commission, which has a veto over the admissibility of these initiatives, finally rejected this initiative in May 2014. This ICE had obtained more than 1.7 million signatures! Thus, the Commission is both a judge and a party, and is entitled to give political opinions when its role should be limited to issuing a purely technical and formal opinion. Considering that it is therefore useful to reform the ICE, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained overall as it proposes replacing a failing system with a system which still does not have sufficient democratic input.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation, which aims to remove obstacles that are problematic for the organizers and promoters of an ICE, such as legal protection for the abuse of personal data for which they are now personally responsible.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which aims to improve the functioning of EU citizens' initiatives, to make them more user-friendly, to remove some of the obstacles that are causing difficulties for eu citizens' proactive organisers. The EU Citizens' Initiative, which has its origins in the Convention, was designed as a tool to enable European citizens to take up a legislative initiative. The fundamental idea of this instrument is therefore to ensure that, once launched, this instrument helps to bring society socially and civically together and strengthen citizenship in Europe, including at cross-border level. In view of the numerous feedback received from civil society and the Commission's report on the first three years of application of this instrument, it is clear that no good results have been achieved, however defined, since no initiative has yet become a legal act. It is imperable that in 2016 The Commission would review the EU citizens' initiative in detail.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The resolution as a whole contains numerous calls for legislation and expenditure by the EU and makes a series of bogus claims that the European Citizens’ Initiative is a significant and effective means of participation by the citizens of Member States in democracy and the legislative processes of the EU.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The group played a leading role in the launch of the European Citizens' Initiative, which enables European citizens to directly influence the democratic process. This initiative is a step forward for direct democracy, public participation and involvement in the European debate. Three years after the new instrument came into force, it seems appropriate to evaluate its implementation in order to detect possible deficiencies. I supported the Committee on Constitutional Affairs' initiative report calling on the European Commission and member states to improve the ICE to ensure its effectiveness and attractiveness to citizens.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report mentions the fact that the European Citizens' Initiative, if it could be a good thing, has done little. Of the 31 initiatives launched, only 3 were successful and had no consequences. The process is considered too complicated and the European Commission is a judge and a party in this arbitrary process. In addition, the deadline for collecting signatures is imposed by the Commission's timetable.  This report therefore calls for serious reform by ensuring transparency and security of personal data, and MEPs want to be more involved in the process. This report is a step in the right direction for a more democratic process, so I voted for it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Schöpflin report is balanced and I support it, so I supported it with my vote. The European citizens' initiative is an instrument of formidable democracy, but the rules must change, it is not acceptable that of the 51 initiatives presented only 3 have been successful, let us give our citizens a voice!

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The European citizens' initiative is a fundamental tool that seeks social mobilisation and strengthens the relationship between citizens and European institutions. We need to propose to the Commission improvements in its functioning and eliminate certain difficulties that arise when organising and carrying out such initiatives. It is important to make certain legal advice and technical support available to the organisers, to provide technical facilities when collecting signatures in the different Member States, to assess the possibility of registering only part of the initiative if it does not fully fall within the competences of the Commission, etc. It is vital for European democracy that the citizen initiative mechanism works properly and that it is not seen by citizens as an inadequate element that produces no result. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it expresses Parliament's assessment of the European citizens' initiatives that have been in place for three years. Parliament's assessment is the first instrument for cross-border participation in democratic processes, enabling citizens to communicate directly with the EU institutions and to play an active role in shaping European policies and legislation. Š̌i measure complemented the rights previously provided for for citizens to petition Parliament and to contact the European Ombudsman. In view of the numerous feedback received from civil society and the Commission's report on the first three years of application of this instrument, it is clear that no good results have been achieved, however defined, since no initiative has yet become a legal act. It is likely that in 2016 The Commission will review the EU citizens' initiative in detail and Parliament's opinion on this instrument will be of great importance.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the three years since the European Citizens' Initiative was established as a new institution under the Treaty of Lisbon, it has had no breakthrough success: a total of three out of 51 initiatives have met expectations – 1 million signatures from 7 Member States. The Schöpflin report explores and proposes the causes of this procedural failure, including better communication of the instrument, the creation of more user-friendly interfaces, simpler data requests, budget support, direct advice and the promotion of digital citizenship participation, facilitating the participation of millions of citizens in an EU-wide initiative by establishing an EU digital citizenship. The rapporteur underlines the wider awareness of the initiative, which aims to directly connect citizens to European institutional decision-making. The report wants to confirm this connection. In agreement with the report, I called on the Commission to review the rules of procedure so far.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This report calls for a serious reform of the European Citizens' Initiative, a mechanism which has been achieved little because of an overly complicated process and the role of the European Commission, which is both a judge and a party. I therefore voted in favour of this report, which is in the direction of a more democratic process.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I firmly believe that the European Citizens' Initiative is a fundamental instrument of participatory democracy that allows europe's more than 500 million citizens to have a direct impact on the European Union's legislative process. This instrument must be strengthened in order to enable citizens to participate even more actively in the decisions of the institutions.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report attempts to provide answers to the many shortcomings of the European citizens' initiative process. As a reminder, of the thirty-one citizen initiatives, only three have been successful, but none have had a real legal impact. The rapporteur emphasizes the complexity of the procedures to be followed. He is also a legitimate critic of the Commission's role in the process. Judge and party, it has the responsibility to determine whether the applications are admissible. The deadline for organisers to collect signatures is also imposed by the Commission.  I generally agree with the rapporteur, who questions the current functioning of the European Citizens' Initiative process, especially since his proposals ensure that the transparency of the procedure and the security of the signatories' personal data are maintained. That is why I voted for this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The opportunity for citizens to express themselves through legislative initiatives is an important step in ensuring the legitimacy and strengthening of participatory democracy at European Union level. This is an indisputable truth and it is necessary for the responsible institutions to contribute to the smooth running of the proceedings so that this democratic instrument works.  Given that since 2012 to date only three of the 51 applications for an initiative have been admissible, this instrument needs to be simple, clear, easy to use and widely known.  I voted in favour of the report on the European Citizens' Initiative because I believe that it is essential that European citizens can contribute to the exercise of the Union's legislative powers and are directly involved in the initiation of legislative proposals.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. Report which, net of hyperbolic over-the-bottom action on the role of the ECI, highlights its shortcomings on time, first of all the almost zero follow-up given so far by the Commission to only three (out of fifty-one!) ICE that have been successful.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Citizens' Initiative was set up in 2009 with the Lisbon Treaty with the aim of allowing European citizens, according to numerical criteria, to ask the Commission to legislate on a certain subject. This measure responds to a need for democratic legitimacy of the European Union. We need to involve citizens in the European project. They too often feel left out of the European institutions, which have a considerable impact on their daily lives. Getting closer to the citizens is a necessity if we do not want the populist movements promoting withdrawal to gain ground. I am in for more Europe but with more citizen participation.  The citizens' initiative is a very good measure. However, there are some flaws in its application. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to improve the European Citizens' Initiative so that it truly lives up to its ambitions. In the long run, a citizens' initiative will have to be really the subject of European legislation to prove its effectiveness.

name: Enrique Calvet Chambon (ALDE)
text: In writing. With regard to the SCHOPFLIN deferral on the European Citizens' Initiative, I abstained in conscience because I have huge doubts about the satisfaction of my constituents. My doubts are twofold. First, there is a good chance that giving ICE the prerogative to enter primary law is contrary to the current wording of the treaties. Secondly, if ICE is to be able to access primary law or force Parliament to act on its behalf, I think it would have to be revised the level of representativeness, the number of citizens and states that support ice. One million is very little for such ambitions, and we must not forget that we too represent European citizens, and more of them.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After debate in plenary and careful reflection, I voted in favour of the report on the European Citizens' Initiative. The analysis of supporting documentation and the report emphasise that priority should be given to different aspects: balancing responsibility for the retention and retention of personal data; streamlining the procedure; the harmonisation of requirements in all Member States; the problem of the potential conflict of interest, since the Commission itself has sole responsibility for initial legal control. In any case, it is clear that much remains to be done to ensure that ECI realises its full potential, given the excessive requirements and difficulties of the procedure. In any case, emphasis should be made on the use of European consciousness in young people, including the most effective fight against anti-Europeanism. I therefore voted in favour.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am concerned that the European Citizens’ Initiative is failing to meet the goals it was set to achieve. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the Citizens’ Initiative is a great step towards the further expansion of civil society in the European Union and it should be constantly improved in order to maximise its effectiveness.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Citizens' Initiative is the first instrument of direct democracy conceived at Eu ropean Union level. As I argued during my speech in plenary, however, the mechanism that the rule currently has many shortcomings (including delays and bureaucratic impediments in the first place, but also lack of information and support, differences between the rules for data collection in the Member States). My colleague's report addresses many of the most important issues, outlining a marked improvement in the functioning of the instrument and also raises the question of the potential conflict of interests of the Commission; I therefore voted strongly in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The European Citizens' Initiative is rooted in the Convention and was designed as a means of giving European citizens the opportunity to participate in the launch of legislative initiatives. The underlying idea was that this instrument would be put in place to increase the mobilisation of citizens and to strengthen the awareness of the European family at transnational level in particular. The European Parliament considers that, in order to ensure the proper use of this participatory democracy tool by citizens and to avoid its possible abuse by private interests, it is important and crucial to increase the transparency and quality of controls on the financing and sponsorship of the European Citizens' Initiative.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, as the European Citizens' Initiative (ECI) is a new political right, as well as a unique and innovative instrument for setting the agenda for participatory democracy in the European Union, the potential of which must undoubtedly be exploited to the full and fully exploited in order to achieve the best results and to encourage as many EU citizens as possible to participate in the further development of the European integration process. I would also like to stress that there are shortcomings that should be addressed and resolved in order to make the ECI more effective. I remain firmly convinced that the use of one's mother tongue is a civic right and I call on the Commission and the Member States to review the choices, in order to offer the possibility of using it in all activities related to the ECI. Finally, civic engagement among young people is fundamental to the future of all democracies and I encourage the Commission to learn lessons from the fully successful national experiences of ECI: children represent our future and this issue cannot be overlooked, but expanded to the full.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Citizens' Initiative, introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon, is a new political right of European citizens, allowing the institutions of the European Union to be closer and therefore essential for the deepening of European democracy. Since 2012, when it came into force, 51 applications for registration have been made, involved in 6 million citizens but only 3 Initiatives have reached the final stage of the procedure. Furthermore, the European Ombudsman and the European Court of Justice were also called upon to resolve disputes during this period. It seems clear to me, of course, that there is ample room for improvement The Commission has presented an evaluation report this year, which echoes the problems of operation. This implementation report, which I vote in favour of, contributes to this diagnosis and offers suggestions for improvements, thus anticipating the proposal to revise this instrument.  Among the various measures proposed, I stress the need for further harmonisation of the procedure, an improvement of the technologies and online platforms used or a single point of contact in each Member State.  I believe it is essential to stimulate participatory democracy and bring citizens closer to the European Union. To this end, the European Citizens' Initiative is essential and its improvement in these first years of natural and desired operation.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of the European Citizens' Initiative (ECI) is to mobilise civil society, involving it in the launch of relevant legislative initiatives and offering the opportunity to play an active role on the European political agenda. Although ECI is a valuable tool of participatory democracy, its use presents many obstacles, as the system is excessively complex and the requirements for submitting an initiative are disproportionate and unclear. Consequently, it is very difficult for an initiative to be followed by a European legislative act, and this failure is one of the causes of a loss of public confidence in the European institutions. I agree with the need to make changes to facilitate the use of this instrument, for example by strengthening electronic signature collection systems, simplifying the procedures for filling out and submitting forms online, and finally encouraging interinstitutional cooperation at all levels.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the future revision of the European Citizens’ Initiative (ECI). We need to address the challenges that citizens have encountered since the adoption of the regulation in 2011. Cutting red tape and increasing citizens’ access to information about the ECI are crucial in terms of raising awareness and encouraging more citizens to get involved. EU offices in the Member States should be used more to inform citizens about this great opportunity for them. The reasons supplied by the Commission for refusing citizens’ initiatives should be detailed and clear. Organisers should be better informed about their rights after a refusal and about which parts of their initiatives they may correct. Citizens should be encouraged, not demotivated. I am glad that, as representatives of European citizens, we showed a strong commitment to review the Citizens’ Initiative Regulation so as to ensure that citizens will fully enjoy this new right.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report introduces a proposal to revise Regulation 211/2011 which rules for the European Citizens' Initiative. This is the main instrument of direct democracy, introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon. The report produced by the Commission at the end of the first three years of the mechanism's existence and several civil society bodies have highlighted significant shortcomings in the design of the instrument, so it is very likely that the Commission itself will launch a review of the ECI in 2016. Parliament's report is therefore intended to provide useful input for ECI to become a truly useful and effective tool. The text of the report is very good and the work in committee has been based on cooperation and inclusion. The main elements of improvement in the report are: the call for more detailed information on the existence and rules for the use of the instrument; the request to use Europe Direct (or special offices) to offer support and guidance to promoters, especially with regard to guidelines and indications for the identification of the legal basis. Following the above explanation of vote in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report refers to the forthcoming revision of Regulation (EU) No 211/2011 on the European citizens' initiative and to the conclusions drawn by the European Commission in a recently published document. Our position is that the implementation of the European citizen initiative has been an absolute failure; in fact, of fifty-one registered proposals, only three have been able to meet the requirements, often because of the numerous administrative locks during the signature collection process, which sometimes lead to the Commission's own complaint to the courts.  As if that were not the case, the European Commission is not obliged to initiate any proposal for legislative amendments, so their effectiveness is minimal. In the face of this situation, the final report is not at all critical of the procedures regulated for this participatory tool; it also proposes limiting the content of the European citizens' initiative if it does not suit the competences of the Union and, above all, that the Commission should make a legislative proposal only if it has a positive opinion published by it. For these reasons, and given the low prospositivo content of the report to consolidate European citizen initiatives politically and legally, I voted against it.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Citizens' Initiative (EPK) is the first instrument of eu direct participatory democracy, encomperes the Treaty of Lisbon. The FUNCTIONING of the EPK, better known by its English name ECI, is governed by a regulation which, taking into account the lessons of the first three years since its entry into force, has produced a report by Parliament. For the parliamentary report, as the people's party responsible for the opinion in the Committee on Petitions, I have prepared proposals to address the limitations in practice. The instrument exists, but it must be acknowledged that, for the time being, it has brought more disillusionment than results to EU citizens actively participating in the Union's activities. Simplification is needed, inter alia, to simplify the technical and data request parts of the Regulation and, in order to ensure a balance between the institutions, parliament's continued information on the Commission's citizens' initiatives received may also improve the effective functioning of the instrument. One of the most important things and a call for the European Commission to prepare a revision of the Regulation is to make it as easy as possible for EU citizens to access information on the citizens' initiative in as easily as possible, but in more places and in several languages, preferably in their own language.  The creation of the European Citizens' Initiative was a political decision and, likewise, a strong political will is needed to bring it to life and function in real life, which is why I voted in favour of the Schöpflin report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which focuses on the European Citizen’s initiative (ECI) and on ways how to improve the ECI. The ECI is a tool that has been of major interest to the European Parliament as it gives an opportunity for European citizens to collect signatures and propose an action or law to be taken on by the EU. However, there were only three successful initiatives so far and there is a steady decline in the use of the ECI. I strongly believe in a closer relationship between the EU and its citizens, hence I voted in favour of this report.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Citizens' Initiative is an essential means of linking the citizens of Europe and the Union institutions and an effective instrument of democratic participation, because it contributes to the formulation of citizens' aspirations to demand action from the EU.  In order for citizens to contribute to the exercise of the Union's legislative powers and to be directly involved in the initiation of legislative proposals, it is necessary for them to be aware of this instrument. It is also why I support the rapporteur's proposal for information and promotion campaigns.  I also consider it essential to support the media and to use all public communication channels to raise public awareness of citizens' initiatives, to take the necessary measures to ensure their transparency and to facilitate communication on current initiatives, for example by creating applications that provide information, send notifications and make the possibility of online signature.  It must also not be forgotten that the civic commitment of youth is fundamental to the future of all democracies, and we must use the national experiences of citizens' initiatives that are true models of success.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report assesses the implementation of EU legislation on the European Citizens' Initiative. The European Citizens' Initiative is a tool for participatory democracy in the European Union, allowing one million European citizens residing in at least a quarter of the EU Member States to invite the Commission to submit a proposal for legislation they deem necessary and within the competence of the European Union. Since the legislation came into force in 2011 that sets out the applicable procedures and conditions, many complaints have been made by citizens. In order to facilitate the use of this instrument, the European Parliament calls for a simplification of the rules for collecting signatures and to offer assistance to citizens who raise a subject outside the competence of the citizens' initiative. Parliament is also asking the European Commission to formulate a legislative proposal within 12 months. Considering that this report aims to strengthen the link between citizens and the institutions of the Union, I voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The resolution as a whole contains numerous calls for legislation and expenditure by the EU and makes a series of bogus claims that the European Citizens’ Initiative is a significant and effective means of participation by the citizens of Member States in democracy and the legislative processes of the EU.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: Written. – The Citizens' Initiative is a good tool for involving citizens more in European policy making. This resolution recognises this and proposes a number of amendments to improve this instrument. In this way, the collection of signatures can be simplified, the initiative can be given more visibility, and the provision of information to the organisers needs to be improved.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Created three years ago, the European Citizens' Initiative (ECI) allows European citizens to tackle major European issues and ask the European Commission to legislate. To be eligible, the initiative must be supported by at least one million Europeans from at least a quarter of the Member States, or from seven different countries.  It was a good idea to take stock of the operation of the initiative and to propose several avenues for improvement. So far, of the 51 applications for registration of an initiative submitted, only three have been found to be admissible ("Water, a human right", "One of us" and "Stop vivisection").  European citizens should be able to propose initiatives more easily on all subjects covered by the European Union treaties. This is why the European Commission must improve the multilingual ICE website and provide a one-stop shop, in all official EU languages, on the rights and obligations of ICE organisers and on the administrative procedures applicable under the ICE procedure.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Citizens' Initiative (ECI) is the first tool for participatory democracy allowing EU citizens the right, if they gather at least one million signatures representing at least a quarter of the EU states, to invite the Commission to present a legislative proposal on the subject of their choice.
