This is a significant step forward for citizens' political rights and I welcome this. That is why I voted for the SCH-PFLIN report on the European Citizens' Initiative. Through this vote we are increasing communication around ICE, strengthening the transmission and collection of information to the organizers.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the three years since the European Citizens' Initiative was established as a new institution under the Treaty of Lisbon, it has had no breakthrough success: a total of three out of 51 initiatives have met expectations – 1 million signatures from 7 Member States. The Schöpflin report explores and proposes the causes of this procedural failure, including better communication of the instrument, the creation of more user-friendly interfaces, simpler data requests, budget support, direct advice and the promotion of digital citizenship participation, facilitating the participation of millions of citizens in an EU-wide initiative by establishing an EU digital citizenship. The rapporteur underlines the wider awareness of the initiative, which aims to directly connect citizens to European institutional decision-making. The report wants to confirm this connection. In agreement with the report, I called on the Commission to review the rules of procedure so far.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – In the three years since the European Citizens' Initiative was established as a new institution under the Treaty of Lisbon, it has had no breakthrough success: a total of three out of 51 initiatives have met expectations – 1 million signatures from 7 Member States. The Schöpflin report explores and proposes the causes of this procedural failure, including better communication of the instrument, the creation of more user-friendly interfaces, simpler data requests, budget support, direct advice and the promotion of digital citizenship participation, facilitating the participation of millions of citizens in an EU-wide initiative by establishing an EU digital citizenship. The rapporteur underlines the wider awareness of the initiative, which aims to directly connect citizens to European institutional decision-making. The report wants to confirm this connection. In agreement with the report, I called on the Commission to review the rules of procedure so far.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerned the process of citizen initiative, in this case on the protection of personal data. By recommending greater seriousness in the area of data protection, while calling for better involvement of MEPs in citizens' initiatives, this report is moving in the right direction. It is indeed essential to enable citizens' initiatives to have a real impact on the legislative decisions of the European Union. Attached to freedom of expression and the need for it to have a concrete influence, I voted for this report.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 This report concerns the creation of an instrument of transnational participatory democracy that allows citizens to participate directly in the EU institutions.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the three years since the European Citizens' Initiative was established as a new institution under the Treaty of Lisbon, it has had no breakthrough success: a total of three out of 51 initiatives have met expectations – 1 million signatures from 7 Member States. The Schöpflin report explores and proposes the causes of this procedural failure, including better communication of the instrument, the creation of more user-friendly interfaces, simpler data requests, budget support, direct advice and the promotion of digital citizenship participation, facilitating the participation of millions of citizens in an EU-wide initiative by establishing an EU digital citizenship. The rapporteur underlines the wider awareness of the initiative, which aims to directly connect citizens to European institutional decision-making. The report wants to confirm this connection. In agreement with the report, I called on the Commission to review the rules of procedure so far.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The resolution as a whole contains numerous calls for legislation and expenditure by the EU and makes a series of bogus claims that the European Citizens’ Initiative is a significant and effective means of participation by the citizens of Member States in democracy and the legislative processes of the EU.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. A proposal for a revision of Regulation 211/2011 is introduced by this report defining the ECI, the European Citizens' Initiative. Ice is the only real instrument of direct democracy that was introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon; It consists of drawing up a legislative proposal which, if supported by a million signatures, can become a legislative initiative of the Commission. The various problems of the ECI have become apparent over the years, so much so that the number of initiatives has seen a constant decline in the face of the only three successful initiatives (Stop vivisection, Right2Water and One of us) but which have unfortunately received an absolutely unacceptable response from the Commission - just think that some promoters of the ECI have sued the Commission, at the European Court of Justice, for their disappointing answers. But let us not despair, Parliament's report aims precisely to contribute to the revision of the ECI, so that it can become what it is not now: an effective instrument of direct democracy. We are therefore aiming, through this report, for a reform of the ECI that aim to remove obstacles, be they technical/bureaucratic or political. I voted in favour.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Citizens' Initiative was conceived as an instrument to give European citizens the opportunity to participate in the launch of legislative initiatives. It is clear that whatever the success criteria, so far this has not yet arisen, since there has not yet been a single initiative that has given rise to legislation. The Commission's report notes 51 initiatives. The aim of this report is to seek to improve the functioning of the European citizens' initiative in order to make it more user-friendly by removing some of the obstacles that have proved to be difficult for organisers of European citizens' initiatives.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe often has a tendency to close in palaces. This reveals a certain contempt for the instruments of democratic debate and debate, on the fundamental issues for its citizens. The European Union has an instrument, the European Citizens' Initiative (ECI), but it has proved costly, bureaucratic and frustrating both for the promoters of the initiative and for those who subscribe to it. The European Parliament resolution on the European Citizens' Initiative (ECI) aims to call for a revision of Regulation 211/2011, which regulates, precisely, the main instrument of direct democracy, introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon. Ice needs to become a really useful and effective tool. That is why we should simplify the bureaucratic procedures, eliminate any possible situation of conflict of interest of the Commission which, in addition to carrying out the legal eligibility check of the ECI, also decides whether or not to follow them up, and finally we need to standardise the system for collecting signatures in the different Member States. In the final analysis, however, this is a small step towards strengthening an instrument for the direct participation of citizens in the process of law-making, which we cannot fail to appreciate.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Six years after its formal establishment in the Treaty of Lisbon, it is clear the discredit in which this instrument, called participatory democracy, fell. The purpose of this report is to contribute to rehabilitating the "European Citizens' Initiative". This is a goal we repudiate. Life has given reason to what we said when the Treaty of Lisbon was approved. From the outset, this initiative aimed to give the Treaty the appearance of what is not and never has been: something in line with democracy, with the will and participation of peoples.  The so-called European Citizens' Initiative was an (evidently unsuccessful) attempt to legitimise an entire structurally undemocratic building. Let us not forget that the Treaty establishing this initiative has ostensibly escaped the scrutiny of peoples through referendums. It has been approved and ratified on the backs of citizens whose participation it says it wants to welcome. The report – which we obviously reject – still contains some interesting elements, because it is enlightening. In more than half a hundred attempts, only three have been able to meet the strict parameters defined to make this "citizen participation" acceptable. And even in these cases, after the effort and resources spent, the initiatives had no sequence – the case of the initiative in defense of public water.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Citizens' Initiative is an instrument addressed by the European Parliament at an early stage of its development. It is a great pity that the use of this institute is decreasing year on year by the people of the European Union, given that 16 such initiatives were registered in 2012, only one so far in 2015. Citizens and organisers of citizens' initiatives are most often faced with obstacles and a lack of support and awareness of society. Different conditions and forms for signing initiatives in the various Member States of the European Union also remain a serious problem.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report is about creating an instrument of transnational participatory democracy that allows citizens to participate directly in the EU institutions, which is why my vote is in favour of the European Citizens' Initiative.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this initiative as I have concerns that this is a duplication of resources. I believe that the individual EU offices in Member States are able to function in the same manner as the proposed ‘Citizens’ Initiative Offices’ Whilst welcoming citizens’ participation in the democratic process, I am concerned that this will only extend the EU budget further.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Citizens’ Initiative (ECI) is a unique and innovative agenda-setting tool for participatory democracy in the European Union, allowing citizens to play an active part in projects and processes that affect them. Citizens should be able to participate actively in the further development of the European integration process. I therefore strongly support the implementation of the ECI, which will make it possible to ask the Commission to submit a proposal on matters on which citizens consider that a legislative act is necessary to implement the treaties – one of EU’s priority objectives being to strengthen the democratic legitimacy of its institutions. Action of this kind should be encouraged and supported by all available means, and deficits in this respect need to be tackled in order to make the ECI as effective as possible.

name: ldikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The main objective of the report is to improve the functioning of the ECI in order to become more user-friendly and to eliminate some of the obstacles that have already been shown to cause difficulties for ECI organisers. It must be acknowledged that some of these problems were not foreseeable, but the experience of the last three years offers an opportunity for innovation. In 2016, the Commission is likely to start a full review of the ECI, and Parliament's position on the instrument will be decisive primarily by forwarding the views of those who wanted to take advantage of the ECI from the bottom up. I welcome ensuring consistent, fair and equal treatment during hearings of the various European citizens' initiatives.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour in order to improve the functioning of the initiative to make it easier to use and remove some of the obstacles that have posed difficulties for its organizers.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Schöpflin's report on the European Citizens' Initiative because I see the ECI as the first real instrument of participatory democracy, which allows our citizens to take the political initiative by moving closer to Europe and its institutions. The fall in the number of ECi presented in recent years should make us reflect on the actions necessary for the relaunch of this institute, which must be better communicated to the citizens and considerably simplified. I therefore agree with the request to the Commission to promote knowledge of this right as much as possible at EU and national level and to simplify the procedures for collecting signatures so as not to hinder their exercise, with common requirements in the various Member States and greater assistance from the Commission to promoters. Given the importance of the involvement of young people in European democracy, I agree with lowering the age of participation in an ICE to 16 years and I agree with the call to improve the software used by the Commission for collecting signatures. Finally, I believe it is essential for the future of this instrument that, if successful, the ECI should be followed by a legal act, and I therefore agree with the Commission's proposal for a 12-month period of action.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the European Citizens' Initiative today because I believe that elements of direct citizen participation are very important in a modern, better Europe. We must boldly develop the European Citizens' Initiative, preferably into a genuine European referendum.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Citizens' Initiative (ECI) was designed to enable Union citizens to participate in legislative initiatives and to influence Union policies and legislation. The ECI's intention was to increase social mobilisation and strengthen the sense of European citizenship. During the first three years of operation of the Instrument, 51 proposals for initiatives were received, with the support of more than six million EU citizens.  Only three applications were considered admissible. None have so far resulted in the introduction of new legislation. The initiative has not met citizens' expectations and much remains to be done to make full use of its potential. The main objective of this report is to improve the functioning of the ECI, to make it more user-friendly and to eliminate obstacles to organisers. It is worth drawing conclusions from the fact that six ECI organisers, responsible for 30% of all rejected proposals, brought a case against the EC before the European Court of Justice. In addition, the number of applications currently coming in is declining.   The initiative should aim at involving the public and promoting dialogue between citizens and institutions. This instrument should encourage as many Community citizens as possible to participate in the further development of the European integration process.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The current barriers to access to successful European citizens' initiatives are still too high. There is also no sufficient, user-friendly design. It is up to politicians to remove these hurdles in a meaningful way. That is what we are going to do with this report and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It is vital that we foster involvement of European citizens in European decision—making to the largest extent possible. Therefore it is important that the implementation of the European Citizens’ Initiative is improved and associated logistical and practical problems are addressed. We need to ensure that the ECI is a user-friendly tool that is easily accessible to all citizens who want to increase their engagement with the EU.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Citizens’ Initiative is a concrete example of participatory democracy in the European Union. It allows citizens closer proximity to the EU by enabling them to invite the Commission to submit a proposal for a legal act which they believe is necessary in order to implement the EU Treaties. However, we need to ensure that this initiative is used correctly and that citizens have the proper means of using it. Overall, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. The report concludes to convince me that the European Citizens' Initiative (ECI) is a pure demagogic communication operation. ICE is not just suffering from organizational problems. It has a design flaw, as we denounced from the campaign on the European Constitution, which became the Lisbon Treaty. It only allows the Commission to act, not to act. For example, it cannot be validly petitioned for the Commission to stop Turkey's accession negotiations or the transatlantic treaty negotiations, nor can it be asked to end the liberalisation of public services, which is still less in the service of the public. It gives the Commission no obligation to follow up, or even an obligation to justify its fate for these initiatives. And what a fate! Of THE 51 ICE applications, only three were found to be admissible. One third of the refusals are appealed by their organizers to the Court of Justice. The three survivors will not receive any follow-up worthy of the name. Last month, the Boyle report expressed concern about the Commission's contempt for this area. Normal: ICE is not intended to be operational. It is just powder in the eyes.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained in the vote on this report. We understand that European citizen initiatives are the closest mechanism for citizens when considering projects to the Union; we also understand that there is a need to improve the mechanisms by which these initiatives can be carried out; we also understand that, without an improvement in European citizen initiatives, the Union will continue to be perceived as a strange and distant entity. Therefore, the functioning of them must be improved, in the spirit and in the letter; we understand that, having adopted certain amendments, this report loses the strength we would want for it, and that is why we abstained.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, alongside my colleagues in the S&D group, voted in favour of this report. The report seeks to address the problems of the poor implementation of the European Citizens’ Initiative and the logistical and practical problems associated. The ECI could be a great tool to get citizens more involved in the democratic process, yet it has fallen short of this promise so far. With only three ECIs reaching the target for consideration by the Commission, it is clear that the ECI needs to be more user-friendly and that many of the obstacles need to be eliminated before it can become a useful instrument.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Citizens' Initiative theoretically allows one million citizens from at least seven Member States to ask the European Commission to act on a particular issue. It is a democratic tool giving citizens the opportunity to influence the European strategy on concrete issues. It therefore introduces a new form of citizen action and emulation in Europe. However, although ICE is an innovative instrument, it faces many limitations that Mr Schupflin's report had the ambition to rectify in order to exploit its full potential. As proof: ICE has never been transformed into legislation. Parliament adopted a resolution in early September urging the Commission to respond to the demands of the first ICE regarding the right to quality water.  I have therefore supported this report, which aims to improve the functioning of ICEs and thus encourage them. The Commission must respond to citizens' demands in a more flexible and transparent manner. Finally, this text will also, I hope, help to fight against the idea of a Europe too far removed from its citizens, even when it offers them tools to get involved.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ My vote was decided by the fact that there are significant deficits which need to be tackled and resolved in order to make the European Citizens’ Initiative more effective. The Citizens’ Initiative is an exceptional opportunity for citizens to identify and articulate their aspirations and to ask for EU action, and it must be encouraged and supported by all available means.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the three years since the European Citizens' Initiative was established as a new institution under the Treaty of Lisbon, it has had no breakthrough success: a total of three out of 51 initiatives have met expectations – 1 million signatures from 7 Member States. The Schöpflin report explores the causes of this procedural failure and makes new proposals, such as better communication, the creation of more user-friendly interfaces, simpler data requests, budget support, direct advice, and the promotion of digital citizenship participation. These instruments will facilitate the participation of millions of citizens in the EU-wide initiative. The rapporteur underlines the wider awareness of the initiative, as the European Citizens' Initiative aims to directly connect citizens to European institutional decision-making. The report wants to confirm this connection. In agreement with the report, I called on the Commission to review the rules of procedure so far.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was in favour of this report because the ECI is an important instrument of participatory democracy in the European Union. As a result of this measure, one million EU citizens residing in at least one quarter of the Member States can invite the Commission to submit a proposal for a legal act which they consider to be required in order to implement the EU treaties. This is a vital tool which encourages civic participation within the European Union.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. Since the launch of the European Citizens' Initiative in April 2012, only three of the fifty-one initiatives launched have reached the necessary number of signatures. However, none of them has led to legally binding measures. The project, in its current form, poses numerous obstacles for citizens. Therefore, the report proposes several steps to make citizens aware of the initiative and make the process more user-friendly. It also calls on the European Commission to respond more quickly. In order to increase the benefits of this initiative, it is important that this process is as transparent and user-friendly as possible. ALFA has always supported direct democracy. Citizens must have a say and have the opportunity to influence EU legislation. That is why I voted in favour of this report. Incidentally , and this is my ceterum censeo – I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the last three years since the European Citizens' Initiative was established as a new institution under the Treaty of Lisbon, it has not had a great deal of success. A total of three out of 51 initiatives met expectations – 1 million signatures of support from 7 Member States. The Schöpflin report explores and proposes the reasons for this procedural failure. This includes better communication of the instrument, the creation of more user-friendly interfaces, simpler data requests, budget support, direct advice and the promotion of digital citizenship participation, facilitating the participation of millions of citizens in an EU-wide initiative by establishing a so-called EU digital citizenship. The rapporteur underlines the wider awareness of the initiative, which aims to directly connect citizens to European institutional decision-making. The document wants to confirm this connection. In agreement with the report, I called on the Commission to review the rules of procedure so far.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the REPORT on the EUROPEAN Citizens' Initiative, as I consider such an instrument of participatory democracy to be extremely important for actively communicating and connecting citizens with the EU institutions and participating in policy-making and legislation. As this is the first such transnational instrument, there are still many shortcomings, as citizens do not know the tool, which is why the EU should certainly work harder to promote it and visit through the media and other public communication channels.  Awareness-raising of the citizens' initiative should also take place at national and local level in such a way that the Commission encourages and supports elected representatives who would better familiarize citizens with this tool, in particular young people, whose engagement is both desirable and desirable. I think this tool is excellent, but it needs to be approached and clarified to users, and certainly build citizens' trust in this instrument and therefore I support this report.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The report on the European Citizens' Initiative (ECI) aims to reform its procedure. Since its inception, ice has allowed citizens of the Member States to refer the matter to the Commission on a subject close to their hearts and to be heard. To date, only three petitions have resulted in the fifty-one petitions that have been launched.  Among the three that were deemed admissible was the "One of Us" initiative, which called for the european Union to stop all funding for "research activities that destroy human embryos". The Commission, which has a veto over the admissibility of these initiatives, finally rejected this initiative in May 2014. This ICE had obtained more than 1.7 million signatures!  Thus, the Commission is both a judge and a party, and is entitled to give political opinions when its role should be limited to issuing a purely technical and formal opinion.  I voted for it.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Gyorgy Schopflin's report on the European Citizens' Initiative (ECI). This initiative introduced by the Lisbon Treaty allows citizens to bring to the European parliament matters that are dear to them and to get the European Commission to vote on the subject, provided it is within its competence. With the first ICEs coming to an end, this report aims to learn from these early experiences by evaluating its practice and proposing solutions to the difficulties encountered in the implementation of this system. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Up until now, 29 initiatives out of 49 submissions have gone through the process of registration and only three of them have reached the one million signature threshold. Only the ECI Right2Water received a positive – although vague – communication from the European Commission. None of the successful ECIs has led to legislative follow-up.   Upfront the participation crisis of the EU, the Schopflin report aiming to modify the ECIs obtained a large consensus in the AFCO Committee, including some innovative proposals that went beyond the existing Regulation 211/2011 on ECI. Indeed, the report very well underlined the deceptive results of a number of the admitted initiatives and the limits of the overwhelming powers of the EC in assessing the eligibility of such initiative. Moreover, it noted that the ECI should be more user—friendly, transparent and procedures less complex, and recommended to extend the age of submitters from 18 to 16 irrespective to the right to vote in national or European elections.  However, AM4 (which transforms the ECI into a bow without arrows and urges the EC to start preparing a legal act on successful ECIs only after issuing a positive opinion) passed today before the final vote (EH Bildu has voted against), and hence our final vote is been abstention.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. The report on the European initiative aims to improve this tool of participatory democracy which has mobilized more than six million citizens since 2012. Unfortunately, the European Initiative is a complex tool, hampered by many practical difficulties. It was therefore necessary to make some improvements.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this report as the proposals it contains represent a significant improvement in the current legal situation for the European Citizens' Initiative. The ECI is an instrument introduced for the first time by the Treaty of Lisbon to enable citizens to participate directly in politics. This allows national affairs and concerns to be dealt with at European level, as citizens can have the effect of addressing a particular issue for the European Commission.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The European Citizens’ Initiative is to become an efficient tool for millions of EU citizens to participate in shaping EU politics. From an enthusiastic start, it had a bumpy road towards practical implementation. A multitude of initiators and signatories of different initiatives have complained about bureaucratic burdens and non-friendly user procedures. This is what this report aims to improve.  Firstly, the citizens’ initiative procedure has to provide timely and continuous information so that possible hurdles and non-compliance can be prevented. The Europe Direct Contact Centre has to be prepared and ready to answer questions at every stage of preparing for a launch of an initiative. The one-stop online shop should also be providing support for preparation of citizens initiatives and help in guiding activists through the initiation process; it should assist with translation, technical, legal and other information and aid. Data collection must be harmonized, so that it becomes easier to actually collect signatures. Secondly, the online signatory system is not working properly. Signing online should become simple and yet safe; it should be possible to link the signing page with social media and web campaigns.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report, as it seeks to address the poor implementation of the European Citizens’ Initiative (ECI) and the associated logistical and practical problems. The ECI could be a great tool to get citizens more involved in the democratic process, yet it has hitherto fallen short of its promise. With only three citizens’ initiatives reaching the target for consideration by the Commission, it is clear that the ECI needs to be more user-friendly and many obstacles need to be eliminated before it can become a useful instrument.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. Since the launch of the European Citizens' Initiative in April 2012, only three of the fifty-one initiatives launched have reached the necessary number of signatures. However, none of these initiatives has so far led to legally binding measures. The project, in its current form, poses numerous obstacles for citizens. Therefore, the report proposes several steps to make citizens aware of the initiative and make the process more user-friendly. It also calls on the European Commission to respond more quickly. In order to increase the benefits of this initiative, it is important that this process is as transparent and user-friendly as possible. ALFA has always supported direct democracy. Citizens must have a say and have the opportunity to influence EU legislation. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution. The European Citizens' Initiative (ECI) is a measure that allows one million European citizens, residing in at least a quarter of the Member States, to exercise a real right of initiative and thus to invite the European Commission to present a proposal for a legal act. This report is designed to improve the functioning of the ECI, simplify its use and remove some of the obstacles that are having difficulties for ICE organisers.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: in writing. – The European Citizens’ Initiative (ECI) is the first transnational participatory democracy tool that enables citizens to be directly involved in the decision-making processes of the EU, particularly by promoting dialogue between citizens and the EU institutions and contributing to agenda-setting and the framing of issues. However, the ECI is far from perfect, as only three of 51 initiatives submitted have received follow-up, and the first successful initiative – Right2Water – a received response from the Commission in March 2014, almost two years after the ECI entered into force on 1 April 2012. I strongly welcome the report, which seeks to improve the transparency, public awareness, accessibility and efficiency of this instrument that offers a unique possibility for EU citizens to identify with EU action that has been directly translated from citizens’ aspirations and demands.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the European Citizens' Initiative, as it highlights the many flaws in the current process for organising such an initiative. Of the 31 initiatives launched, only 3 have been successful. None had any real consequences. The process is far too complicated. At the same time, the Commission is a judge and a party. The deadline for collecting signatures is imposed by the Commission's timetable. Serious reform is therefore needed, as proposed by the report by Mr Schupflin, while ensuring transparency and the security of personal data.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it highlights the shortcomings of the "European Citizens' Initiative" (i.e. petition) process, none of which has resulted in a concrete result. It confirms to me that "European democracy" is a decoy. Democracy can only exist within the framework of a nation, yet there is no "European nation" in the singular.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report refers to the forthcoming revision of Regulation (EU) No 211/2011 on the European citizens' initiative and to the conclusions drawn by the European Commission in a recently published document. Our position is that the implementation of the European citizen initiative has been an absolute failure; in fact, of fifty-one registered proposals, only three have been able to meet the requirements, often because of the numerous administrative locks during the signature collection process, which sometimes lead to the Commission's own complaint to the courts.  As if that were not the case, the European Commission is not obliged to initiate any proposal for legislative amendments, so their effectiveness is minimal. In the face of this situation, the final report is not at all critical of the procedures regulated for this participatory tool; it also proposes limiting the content of the European citizens' initiative if it does not suit the competences of the Union and, above all, that the Commission should make a legislative proposal only if it has a positive opinion published by it. For these reasons, and given the low prospositivo content of the report to consolidate European citizen initiatives politically and legally, I voted against it.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. Since the launch of the European Citizens' Initiative in April 2012, only three of the fifty-one initiatives launched have reached the necessary number of signatures. None of them has led to legally binding measures because the number of administrative and legal obstacles was too great. The current report proposes several steps to make citizens aware of the initiative and make the process more user-friendly. It also calls on the European Commission to respond more quickly. In order to increase the benefits of this initiative, it is important that this process is as transparent and user-friendly as possible. ALFA has always supported direct democracy. Citizens must have a say and have the opportunity to influence EU legislation. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I supported the report on the European Citizens' Initiative. The European Citizens' Initiative is one of the best instruments for creating EU law. The European Citizens' Initiative allows citizens to be actively involved in the development of EU legislation, so that citizens also have a better opportunity to know how the EU institutions work. I fully agree with the report that, despite the unquestionable added value of a European citizens' initiative, its functioning needs to be improved and facilitated. The first issue is the need to promote this initiative more to citizens so that citizens are fully informed about their rights under EU citizenship, including their right to participate in a citizens' initiative. In turn, the practical aspects of the functioning of the initiative should be looked at in order to help the organisers of initiatives to implement them effectively and effectively. In this respect, I support the creation of an information unit in each Member State, for example with the representation of the European Commission, which would provide legal information and advice on European citizens' initiatives. Furthermore, in the context of the creation of a Digital Union, consideration should also be given to facilitating and increasing access m.in. for persons with disabilities to online signature-collecting software.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Citizens' Initiative is a tool for mobilising at European level and exemplifying transnational participatory democracy. Citizens of the Member States have the right of legislative initiative for projects and processes that directly concern them. Of all the calls for a European citizens' initiative, only three have been considered admissible, which shows that there is still much to improve. Here are some of them: - organisers should receive as comprehensive information as possible on legal admissibility criteria, deadlines and procedures; - The Commission must state the reasons for rejecting a citizens' legislative initiative in detail and the relevant legal considerations, in the name of transparency, must be made public in full; - simplifying the use of the online signature collection application; - the IT tools used for ECI should also be made available to the regions for greater involvement of citizens in public affairs;  This tool must be simple, clear, easy to use and widely promoted, precisely because it allows people to seek action from the EU to achieve their aspirations.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The ECI represents a new political right of citizens that enables active participation in Union projects and processes. The potential of the initiative must be used to achieve the best possible results, as strengthening the democratic legitimacy of the institutions is one of the EU's priorities. Experience shows that most organisers of EUROPEAN citizens' initiatives have encountered a number of difficulties related to practicality and legal aspects.  The ECI enables direct cooperation with the EU institutions and active participation in the design of European policies and legislation and complements the right to petition parliament and appeal to the European Ombudsman. It is necessary to inform citizens about the initiative and raise awareness of its possibilities. So far, more than 6 million Europeans have participated in one of the initiatives with 51 requests - only 3 of which have reached Parliament. It calls on the Commission to explain in detail the reasons for rejecting the ECI proposal and to provide the organisers with relevant legal advice.  I supported MP György Schöpflin's report, as citizens' initiatives represent a major step in participatory democracy. In Croatia, the minimum number of signatories applied to initiatives registered until 1.7.2014. is 9 thousand, and as of 1.7.2014 it is just over 8 thousand.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The European Citizens' Initiative is the first instrument in the hands of EU citizens, enabling them to directly address the European Commission asking it to submit a proposal for European legislation. The condition for this is the collection of at least one million signatures in support from at least seven Member States. Since then, only three initiatives: Right2Water, One of Us and Stop Vivisection have been deemed admissible, managed to collect the required number of signatures and received an official response from the European Commission.  Although declared successful initiatives, the citizens behind them were disappointed that they ultimately did not achieve the impact they wanted on European legislation. As a result, European citizens have lost their initial interest and faith, and now, unfortunately, we are seeing a tendency to reduce the number of new initiatives. I support the European Parliament's resolution to comprehensively assess shortcomings and find solutions. The goal is a simple, clear and user-friendly mechanism. Let us not discourage this form of active democratic participation in the political life of the European Union. I find it a commitment of every MEP to work for the maximum effectiveness of the European citizens' initiative.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Citizens' Initiative has not met the objective of increasing civil society activity and strengthening European citizenship, especially at transnational level. None of its 51 activities have adopted legislation. In carrying out the activities of the European Citizens' Initiative, it was necessary to deal with a number of obstacles, which, however, were removable with appropriate administrative support.  I therefore support the proposal for the Commission, on the basis of current practice and knowledge, to revise the ECI Regulation in order to remove obstacles and ensure transparency and institutional balance in the decision-making process, so as to provide more support and assistance to this activity.

name: Ernest Maragall (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Today the European Parliament has failed to strengthen and consolidate the European Citizen’s Initiative (ECI). The ECI provides an exceptional opportunity for EU citizens to get involved directly in EU politics and to participate in shaping EU policy. However, by not urging the Commission to start preparing a legal act on successful ECIs within 12 months of their submission, we have failed to allow citizens to effectively shape European policies and legislation. Therefore I have voted abstention.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from voting on the report on the European Citizens' Initiative, not including because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report! It highlights that the Citizens' Initiative process is too complicated and ineffective, with no legal impact. The European Commission, both judge and party, allows itself to accept or not, somewhat arbitrarily, the admissibility of initiatives! This report proposes a major reform to ensure greater transparency and efficiency.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Citizens' Initiative – ICE – is a new political right of citizens, which allows them to play an active role in the projects that concern them, thus guaranteeing them the opportunity to participate in the launch of legislative initiatives. The aim of the report is, in fact, to encourage more citizens of the European Union to participate further in the development of the process of European integration.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report makes recommendations on the European Citizens’ Initiative (ECI). The ECI could be an important tool in civic engagement but it has so far fallen short, with very few initiatives being accepted. It is clear that the Commission needs to look again at the rules in order to make them more user-friendly and accessible.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Citizens' Initiative (ECI) is a tool aimed at increasing opportunities for European citizens to participate in the launch of legislative initiatives. This instrument is aimed at strengthening European citizenship and, at the same time, represents a strong impetus for civil mobilisation. In view of the political and social importance of ice, I think it is important to support Mr Schöpflin's position. The report is based on the assumption that, in order to strengthen these instruments of cooperation, the functioning of the ECI must first be improved, its use simplified and some of the obstacles that may prevent the tasks of the organisers must be removed.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The proposals are a significant improvement on the current legal situation with the ECIs. Obstacles that have hitherto been problematic for European citizens' initiatives will be removed. The functioning of the European Citizens' Initiative will be more user-friendly. I therefore supported the report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The European Citizens' Initiative is a farce! Following the mobilization of citizens, through a complex administrative process, it is supposed to lead the Commission to review its legislation on the basis of the application filed. Of the 51 filed, only 3 were found to be admissible, but none were subject to a legislative change. The report proposes many simplifications, but it does not force the Commission to accept more initiatives and act accordingly. It spares the Irresponsibility of the Commission, for example by proposing to be able to re-register initiatives with the relevant national authorities. It does not meet the needs. Thus the TAFTA initiative, which has collected more than three million signatures, was rejected by the Commission as being outside its jurisdiction. Whereas trade negotiation is an exclusive competence of the Commission! But who is competent on the issues that matter? I am voting against this text, which merely validates the lack of citizenship in the life of the EU institutions.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The report on the European Citizens' Initiative (ECI) contains good ideas. It aims to reform the ICE process. Indeed, since this mechanism has been in place, which allows the citizens of the Member States to refer the matter to the Commission on a subject close to their hearts and to be heard, only three petitions have resulted in the fifty-one-one that have been launched.  Among the three that were deemed admissible was the "One of Us" initiative, which called for the european Union to stop all funding for "research activities that destroy human embryos". The Commission, which has a veto over the admissibility of these initiatives, finally rejected this initiative in May 2014. This ICE had obtained more than 1.7 million signatures! Thus, the Commission is both a judge and a party, and is entitled to give political opinions when its role should be limited to issuing a purely technical and formal opinion.  Considering that it is therefore useful to reform the ICE, the Member voted in favour of this text.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. The European citizens' initiative is an important vehicle for participatory democracy. Introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon, it allows the direct possibility of participation in the process of European construction. This report takes some paths to remove obstacles that have proved to be difficult for organisers of European citizenship initiatives. It is important that the experience of recent years serves to introduce improvements in the mechanism in order to bring citizens closer to the European institutions.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this resolution as it highlights the need to raise awareness of the European Citizens’ Initiative in order to make it successful. Greater efforts are need to make the success criteria more widely known, as so far not a single initiative has led to legislation.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Citizens' Initiative was intended to be an instrument for Europeans' participation in governance and to strengthen their European citizenship, unfortunately this instrument has not yet achieved its objectives. I therefore consider it important to adopt a resolution on the European Citizens' Initiative, which will change this situation, so that citizens' opinion is never again ignored, as happened with the One of Us initiative demanding that Brussels no longer finance any practices that destroy human life before birth. In fact, the former Commission of Manuel Barroso vetoed it, despite being supported by two million people in Europe and becoming the largest petition in European history. The Commission has made the ECI mechanism a farce, while MePs, unlike it, wanted it to become a genuine instrument of participatory democracy. This Commission decision was contrary to ethical and democratic requirements, so I welcome the fact that the European Parliament is aware that the EU institutions and the Member States must take all necessary steps to support the ECI and to increase citizens' confidence in this instrument, and regrets the lack of legislative impact and the Commission's deterrent measures, which follow on from successful initiatives.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Citizens’ Initiative (ECI) is the first ever instrument empowering citizens with the right to take a new and active role in EU policymaking. It is crucial in providing European citizens with an opportunity to shape the political future in Europe directly. Unfortunately the instrument has proven to be dysfunctional and very bureaucratic. Therefore, I voted in favour of the report, which offers good recommendations on how the Commission urgently needs to modify the ECI to make it as citizen-friendly as possible and to ensure it lives up to its full potential. Otherwise we risk turning this tool into an obsolete instrument at its very inception.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The ECI was created as a tool to give European citizens the opportunity to participate in launching legislative initiatives. The Commission's report on the first three years of the institution reports on 51 such initiatives, but none have resulted in legislation. The main objective of Parliament's Committee on Constitutional Affairs report is to improve the functioning of the EUROPEAN citizens' initiative and to eliminate some obstacles that have already been shown to cause difficulties for the organisers of the ECI. I supported the motion.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Citizens' Initiative plays an important role in the democratic participation of European citizens, enabling them to communicate directly with the institutions of the European Union and actively participate in the framework of European policy making and legislation. This report aims to improve the regulatory conditions of the European Citizens' Initiative by closing current gaps and becoming a political right, an essential instrument of European democracy, leading to greater effective participation of citizens in the European context. The development and progress of the European Union must be related to the ideals and claims of European citizens, and it is relevant to facilitate their access to the Initiative and to allow it to be known to all through various means. I am in favour of this report, as it plays an essential role in promoting the democratic participation of European citizens by bringing them directly closer within the European Union.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report criticises the effectiveness of the European Citizens' Initiative, as it has done little. Of the 31 initiatives launched, only 3 were successful and had no consequences. The process is considered too complicated and the European Commission is a judge and a party in this arbitrary process. In addition, the deadline for collecting signatures is imposed by the Commission's timetable. This report therefore calls for serious reform by ensuring transparency and security of personal data and MEPs want to be more involved in the process. This report is a step in the right direction for a more democratic process, so I voted for it.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the European Citizens' Initiative (ECI). The ICE is an important tool for participatory democracy in the European Union, which allows one million European citizens residing in at least a quarter of the EU Member States to invite the Commission to submit a proposal for legislation which they deem necessary to implement the EU treaties.  Due to numerous complaints from citizens, the European Commission has committed to initiate a review of the ICE regulation. This report assesses the implementation of this regulation and makes proposals to improve its operation. In particular, it calls on the Commission to present to Parliament a regular report on the progress of the current ICEs, so that it can verify, as part of its commitment to European citizens, that the instrument works as efficiently as possible.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Strengthening participatory democracy is, I believe, the key to Europe's future, the key to development. If we look at the development of democracy, from the ancient Greek example for the privileged only to the opportunity to participate in public life, which is now supposed to be for everyone, I think there is a clear path forward. It's not enough to drag citizens to the polls. They must be given much more power to make their voices heard, and if this does not happen, disillusionment will lead to demotivation, resulting in fewer and fewer people going to vote. This participatory democracy is strengthened by the institutions of the petition and the citizens' initiative. I think the intention of the legislator was clear when regulating the latter. The system isn't working. The European Commission seems alarmed that its convenient bureaucratic system may have a say from the outside, and that one-off citizens may be taking the right of initiative out of their hands. He doesn't like it even when there are almost two million people lining up for an initiative like right to water. This situation is untenable and the solution to the problem will not be delayed. The delay is increasing disillusionment and mistrust of Brussels. I trust that with this report we will take concrete steps in the right direction.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Citizens’ Initiative (ECI) has its origins in the Constitutional Convention on the Future of Europe and was designed as an instrument giving European citizens the opportunity to participate in launching legislative initiatives. I voted for this report, which will improve the functioning of the ECI, make it more user-friendly and eliminate some of the obstacles that have proved a source of difficulty for ECI organisers.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the European Citizens' Initiative because I share the rapporteur's view of its importance in the EU democratic process. This initiative allows EU citizens to ask the Brussels institutions for action on the issues they identify.  Very often there has been talk, quite rightly, of the lack of democracy and transparency in the decision-making process in the EU institutions. I believe that this instrument will improve the democratic process in the EU institutions and bring to the table these problems which citizens face, but which the Commission or Parliament do not know.  I also hope that future evaluations and possible changes to this initiative are only aimed at improving the process and getting access to it as easily as possible, because European citizens need a quick and easy way to make their voices heard in the EU institutions.  I encourage the citizens of Romania to use this initiative and to be actively involved in the process of identifying problems in the EU.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the ECI, which I consider to be an important instrument for citizens' participation in the EU decision-making process. In this context, the Commission should review the wording of Article 10 of the Basic Regulation. Regulation No 211/2011 to ensure proper follow-up to a successful European Citizens' Initiative, which would include a debate on the ECI in Parliament's plenary session and a subsequent vote. It would also contribute to improving the functioning of this instrument if the Commission started preparing a legal act on successful European citizens' initiatives within 12 months of their receipt. These changes could contribute to increasing citizens' confidence in the EU and its decision-making processes.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report on the European Citizens' Initiative aims to improve the possibilities for the procedure of citizens' initiatives. Although the report sometimes contains good approaches to improving this procedure, unfortunately it does not go far enough. Efforts to make the process of citizens' initiatives simpler and more transparent are a good approach, but this will no longer make citizens' initiatives heard. That is why I abstained.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. In 2016, the Commission will have to revise the legislation on the European Citizens' Initiative. This report proposes measures to improve this system by simplifying the procedures and creating national relays competent in this area. But the real problem is that this initiative, which remains the main democratic tool for influencing the Commission's action, is systematically countered by the institution. Of the 51 ICEs filed only 3 have been accepted and none have yet resulted in legislation. The report calls on the Commission to be more transparent in the positive or negative treatment of these initiatives and calls for better informing European citizens, which I welcome. However, it does not ask the Commission to stop the systematic rejection of ICEs even though some deal with highly controversial topics such as TTIP. That is why I abstain.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The purpose of the ECI is to enable citizens to participate in EU policies and the legislative process. However, to do so, this system must be user-friendly and feasible. The ECI Regulation needs to be reviewed, identified and supplemented and amended accordingly. It is also important to introduce citizens more widely so that more and more people use it. In addition, it is important that citizens' initiatives finally reach real outputs.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. The European citizens' initiative needs many changes. It is a tool of direct participation of citizens that, however, has not given the expected result. Few initiatives have succeeded, notably because we have not given citizens and organizers the facilities to effectively implement this instrument. This report puts some remedies on these problems. However, I have identified some problems: for example, I voted against being able to subsidise with public money, considering that there may be cases of fraud or private financing with public funds, or against initiatives being able to change primary law, since it is necessary to provide the Treaties with some extra protection because of the importance they have , and the stipulated channels must be followed through their representatives. However, it is a good report and we hope that the initiatives will succeed in the after-changes.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – The European Citizens' Initiative is an exceptional and innovative European citizens' initiative as a tool for setting the Union's agenda for democratic processes, enabling citizens to participate actively in projects and processes affecting them. It should be noted that none of the initiatives has succeeded in achieving significant legislative changes. It is therefore necessary to ensure the better functioning of this mechanism. In particular, it is necessary to remove existing obstacles. Various measures need to promote the EU citizens' initiative and promote citizens' trust in this instrument. In addition, young people need to be encouraged to play a more active role in the development of the European project. In the event of a successful citizens' initiative, the Commission should be obliged to submit an appropriate legislative proposal. It is also necessary to reduce the cost of the initiative proposal. I believe that the possibility of providing European citizens' initiatives relating to european union primary law should be considered.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The practical implementation of the so-called "citizens' initiative" fully confirms the criticism made in a timely and well-documented manner by the JRC, namely that it is an unpopular firework of EU embellishment and manipulation of consciences, when urban and opportunist parties and the media presented it as a form of so-called "participatory democracy" in the EU. The experience of the only two such initiatives that have gone ahead to date has shown that they are directly dependent on the approval and authorisation of the European Commission, are necessarily in the unpopular framework set by the reactionary EU Treaties and ultimately end up in the wastebasket if they do not serve the unpopular objectives of the EU and civil governments. The KKE's complaints that the 'citizens' initiative' will also serve as a vehicle for presenting unpopular aims of monopolies as a so-called 'popular demand' came to confirm the airline 'Ryanair', known for the savage exploitation of its workers, which launched its own 'citizens' initiative' under the slogan 'Keep European Skies Open', calling on the 'EU institutions' to ban the right to strike air traffic controllers! That is why workers must condemn these reactionary EU tools, step up their fight against the EU, throughout its unpopular structure and the monopolies it serves.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Reiterating my conviction on the need to increasingly guarantee access for European citizens to the activities of the Union and with a view to greater transparency of the institutions, I have decided to vote positively on the motion for a resolution on the European Citizens' Initiative.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The ECI is the first instrument of participatory democracy to enable EU citizens to actively participate in decisions concerning them and directly affect their lives. The European Citizens' Initiative Right to Water has gathered 1.86 million signatures and recently received strong support from the European Parliament.  Equally, the "One of Us" initiative, which was a historic step forward in protecting life in Europe, gathered 1.89 million signatures and in this sense became the most supported European initiative by citizens, but not from politicians. I believe that Europe has failed with this initiative without listening to the voice of 1.89 million of its citizens. Both of these initiatives clearly show that our citizens care about the decisions that are being made, that they concern them and that they also want to influence their adoption.  Therefore, I think it is of utmost importance to constantly think about improving the way citizens participate directly democratically in decision-making processes and, above all, to sufficiently inform citizens about the opportunities at their disposal. It is crucial to involve young people to make their voices heard as well, to open up space for them to fight for the protection of their rights and to actively participate in the civil and political life of the European Union.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report criticises the effectiveness of the European Citizens' Initiative, as it has done little. Of the 31 initiatives launched, only 3 were successful and had no consequences. The process is considered too complicated and the European Commission is a judge and a party in this arbitrary process. In addition, the deadline for collecting signatures is imposed by the Commission's timetable.  This report therefore calls for serious reform by ensuring transparency and security of personal data, and MEPs want to be more involved in the process. This report is a step in the right direction for a more democratic process, so I voted for it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The ECI is an exceptional opportunity for citizens to determine and express their aspirations and to ask the EU to act, which is why the ECI should be encouraged and supported by all available means. At the same time, it is necessary to acknowledge that there are significant shortcomings to be addressed and addressed in order to make ECIs more effective. Any further evaluation of the instrument should aim at maximally achieving accessibility for beneficiaries, as it is the primary means of connecting European citizens with the EU.  The unrealized potential of citizens' initiatives is best indicated by the fact that more than six million EU citizens participated in one of the ECIs, that 51 applications were submitted to launch the initiative, of which only three initiatives were deemed admissible, namely 'Right2Water', 'One of Us' and 'Stop Vivisection', and that six organisers of the European Citizens' Initiative , corresponding to 30% of all rejected applications, questioned the Commission's rejection decision before the Court of Justice of the EU.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I agree with colleague György Schöpflin's report on the EUROPEAN Citizens' Initiative, which is an innovative tool for participatory democracy in the European Union and provides an opportunity for citizens to express their aspirations, as well as to seek action from the Union. Nevertheless, research and extensive contacts with civil society have shown that most organisers of EUROPEAN citizens' initiatives have encountered a number of difficulties in relation to practical and legal aspects.  Therefore, ECIs do not have to be fully under the Commission's remit. The Commission should also consider establishing a special office for ECIs in each Member State, and if it refuses to register the proposed citizens' initiative, the Commission will inform organisers of the reasons for refusal and any remedies at their disposal. Due to complications stemming from the fact that different personal data is required in the 28 Member States to establish European citizens' initiatives, it is proposed to establish EU digital citizenship.  Public hearings should be structured in such a way as to allow organisers to engage in dialogue with MEMBERS of the European Parliament and should be organised by a neutral committee. Opportunities to finance ECIs should be explored, taking into account the need for financial support to the ECI organisation.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Citizens' Initiative is the first instrument to enable citizens to participate directly in shaping European policies and legislation by inviting the European Commission to prepare a specific legislative proposal (the initiative must be supported by at least 1 million people from at least 7 EU Member States). It complements the right of citizens to submit petitions to Parliament and to appeal to the European Ombudsman. As a Social Democrat, I am in favour of strengthening elements of direct democracy, which is why I very much welcome the existence of this possibility, just as I feel that much needs to be improved in this field. Proof is that, since the start of this option in 2012, only 3 citizens' initiatives have reached the last stage. In September, the European Parliament adopted a resolution on the first ever successful Right2Water initiative. At the October plenary session, I supported this report, which proposes a number of concrete improvements, for example on the online signature collection system and the whole simplification of the system (language support, contact points, etc.). I am very glad that the report also includes an appeal to lower the age of signatories to 16. I believe that young people should be involved in public affairs as soon as possible, and during my regular meetings with secondary school students I regularly make sure that they are watching closely in the European Union.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Citizens' Initiative (ECI) enables Europeans to play an active role in decision-making processes that affect them. One million European citizens, residing in at least a quarter of the Member States of the Union, can invite the Commission to submit a legislative proposal which they consider necessary to implement the Treaties of the European Union. Ice therefore confers on citizens of the Union a right of initiative similar to that exercised by the European Parliament and the Council. This is an exceptional opportunity which must be encouraged and supported. However, since Regulation (EU) No 211/2001 entered into force in April 2012, a number of practical difficulties have been reported. Only 3 of the 31 ICE recorded reached the final stage. I voted in favour of this report so that we can improve the functioning of the ECI, simplify its process and remove some of the obstacles that are having the greatest difficulties for the ICE organisers.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal on the EcI tabled by my colleague from the Committee on Petitions. This proposal will be an instrument for all citizens of the European Union who wish to participate in the launch of legislative initiatives. It is desirable that the citizens themselves should participate in the operation of the Union. I therefore welcome this proposal and expect it will help proactive people to enter democratic debates. It is the first instrument of participatory democracy in the European Union, where an initiative can be launched on the basis of one million signatures from at least one quarter of the Member States. It is clear that active people want to express their opinion. In my opinion, they should therefore be able to participate in the initiation of legislative proposals. I believe that this change will have a positive impact on the area of the citizens' initiative.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 So far, 51 citizens' initiatives have been submitted. Three of them have earned the required threshold of 1 million citizens' signatures (including the One Of Us initiative, which has collected nearly 1.8 million signatures). Nevertheless, none of these initiatives have continued, as the European Commission has refused to initiate a legislative procedure. The shape of Regulation 211/2011 means that the European Commission is in fact taking decisions on the fate of a citizens' initiative, regardless of the fact that the initiative has fulfilled all the legal conditions required by law. The procedure in this form makes citizens' right to initiatives unrealistic and fictitious, and this is mainly due to the arbitrary power of the European Commission. Moreover, the regulation as it stands creates a whole range of requirements which are in fact an unjustified obstacle for citizens to create citizens' initiatives. This m.in, for example, the need to provide different personal data in support of citizens' initiatives in the 28 Member States on the basis of different national laws. However, the European Union must not allow the creation of de facto dead and 'internally blocked' institutions. The direction of this report is clear, aimed at correcting existing errors, as well as strengthening and improving the institutions of the citizens' initiative, better communicating it and making it a more viable instrument. That is why I supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Citizens' Initiative, set up by the Lisbon Treaty, gives European citizens the power to directly invite the European Commission to act on a specific issue. This procedure is still recent and still needs to be improved. In this context, the European Parliament has adopted a text proposing some improvements to the functioning of this procedure. I voted for this text and I encourage the use of this instrument by European citizens.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Citizens' Initiative (ECI) is an important instrument of participatory democracy, the potential of which must be fully exploited. To this extent, three years after the entry into force of Regulation (EU) No 211/2012, it must be recognised that the results of its implementation reveal some shortcomings and shortcomings that need to be addressed in order to make the ECI more accessible to citizens and organisers. In fact, since 2012, none of the initiatives have given rise to new legislation, so the Commission must submit a proposal for a revision of Regulation (EU) No 211/2011 and the Commission's Implementing Regulation (EU) No 1179/2011 as soon as possible. The aim of this report is precisely to present a set of suggestions and recommendations which can contribute to improving the functioning of the ECI and to remove the obstacles and difficulties that currently prevent its full implementation. I voted in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The resolution as a whole contains numerous calls for legislation and expenditure by the EU and makes a series of bogus claims that the European Citizens’ Initiative is a significant and effective means of participation by the citizens of Member States in democracy and the legislative processes of the EU.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. The Lisbon Treaty, in establishing the European Citizens' Initiative, wanted to bring Europe closer to the citizens by allowing them to influence political decisions. Six years later, the observation is clear: the failure is total. In six years, only three ICEs have reached one million signatories without leading to a legislative proposal. No longer seeing any interest in this tool, citizens turn away from it and the number of ICEs deposited declines. For this reason, the Greens/FTA group had proposed that the Commission be systematically required, after each ICE that has collected 1 million signatures, to prepare a legislative act. But the Grand Coalition, decidedly reluctant to make democracy a reality, opposed this proposal to maintain the status quo: the Commission will do what it wants. A majority of MEPs even objected to Parliament - and the MEPs themselves - automatically monitoring THE ICEs. At a time when the European project tragically needs to re-create a link with citizens, it is lamentable that the majority of MEPs decide not to take into account citizens' demands.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Citizens' Initiative is a useful instrument of participatory democracy for the Union. It came into force in April 2012 and allows one million citizens from at least seven EU countries to invite the Commission to present a legislative proposal in an area in which the EU has the power to legislate.  Yet, on review, its terms and conditions remain imperfect. Of the 51 applications submitted, only 3 were found to be admissible: "Water, a human right," "One of us" and "Stop vivisection." In addition, there are six challenges to the European Court of Justice due to refusals to take into account. These are all evidence that this instrument needs to be improved. I have therefore supported this resolution, which presents a plurality of proposals for improvement, both in terms of accessibility, awareness and information, transparency, support and the admissibility of the various initiatives. The European Citizens' Initiative offers a great opportunity to unite citizens with this unique project that is the European Union. The European Parliament, a symbol of European democracy, has a duty to ensure that this instrument is fully used.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The European citizens' initiative is a fundamental tool that seeks social mobilisation and strengthens the relationship between citizens and European institutions. That is why I think it is important that this report is adopted. We need to propose to the Commission improvements in its functioning and eliminate certain difficulties that arise when organising and carrying out such initiatives. It is important to make certain legal advice and technical support available to the organisers, to provide technical facilities when collecting signatures in the different Member States, to assess the possibility of registering only part of the initiative if it does not fully fall within the competences of the Commission, etc. It is vital for European democracy that the citizen initiative mechanism works properly and that it is not seen by citizens as a clumsy element that produces no result. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which underlines that the European Citizens' Initiative (ECI) is the first instrument of transnational participatory democracy that gives citizens the opportunity to engage directly with the European institutions and to be actively involved in the development of European policies. The voted text also stresses that an OFFICE dedicated to ICEs could also raise public awareness of these initiatives. Indeed, knowing that since 2012, only three of the 31 ICE registered have reached the final phase. This includes the consequences of the disproportionate requirements and the unnecessary complexity of the system that this adopted report intends to revise.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. The main objective of the European citizens' initiative is to provide European citizens with the opportunity to participate in the launch of legislative initiatives. However, after the first three years of this instrument, it is verified that the results initially desired when the launch of this measure were not yet achieved. As such, this report comes with the intention of alerting to the possibility of a general improvement of this instrument- mainly in the way it works, making it more simplified and accessible to citizens.
