Since I support the position expressed by this report that a full review of the European citizens' initiative is necessary over the next year, as well as the fundamental role of the European Parliament as a transmitter of the interests of European citizens seeking to use this mechanism, I voted in favour.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which takes stock of the implementation of the European Citizens' Initiative (ECI), a tool for citizens to actively engage in the development of European policies and legislation.  Ice has helped to develop participatory democracy within the European Union and to involve European citizens more. Indeed, it allows one million European citizens residing in at least a quarter of the Eu Member States to ask the European Commission to submit a legislative act (directive or regulation) when these citizens consider that this act is necessary for the application of the treaties. Since the ICE Regulations came into force, 51 applications for registration of an initiative have been submitted and more than 6 million EU citizens have taken part in an ICE.  Nevertheless, ICE has some of the dysfunctions that citizens have repeatedly complained about and improvements need to be made, including raising public awareness, providing more information to citizens and improving access to an ICE. An evaluation report will be presented by the Commission next spring.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I consider the European Citizens' Initiative to be an important instrument of direct democracy, because I believe it is of fundamental importance to promote and guarantee citizens' access to European policies. One of the European Union's objectives must be to restore a relationship of trust between citizens and political institutions.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because the report specifically highlights the shortcomings of the ECI, first of all by highlighting the almost nil follow-up given so far by the Commission to the only three successful ECi.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained in the vote on this report. We understand that European citizen initiatives are the closest mechanism for citizens when considering projects to the Union; we also understand that there is a need to improve the mechanisms by which these initiatives can be carried out; we also understand that, without an improvement in European citizen initiatives, the Union will continue to be perceived as a strange and distant entity. Therefore, the functioning of them must be improved, in the spirit and in the letter; we understand that, having adopted certain amendments, this report loses the strength we would want for it, and that is why we abstained.

name: Jordi Sebastià (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. We abstained because, despite including improvements, this regulation of the European Citizens' Initiative continues without forcing the Commission and Parliament to initiate a process derived from the initiative; without this obligation, the effort that citizens make to participate and engage in European political life and which can end in nothing is very frustrating.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Citizens' Initiative is an instrument to give European citizens the opportunity to participate in the launch of legislative initiatives. It has the potential to strengthen civil society activities and the concept of European citizenship, especially on a transnational scale. Since this possibility, European citizens have already launched 51 such initiatives. None of them led to new legislation. I therefore supported the report, which details the experience gained so far in the functioning of the ECI.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report refers to the forthcoming revision of Regulation (EU) No 211/2011 on the European citizens' initiative and to the conclusions drawn by the European Commission in a recently published document. Our position is that the implementation of the European citizen initiative has been an absolute failure; in fact, of fifty-one registered proposals, only three have been able to meet the requirements, often because of the numerous administrative locks during the signature collection process, which sometimes lead to the Commission's own complaint to the courts.  As if that were not the case, the European Commission is not obliged to initiate any proposal for legislative amendments, so their effectiveness is minimal. In the face of this situation, the final report is not at all critical of the procedures regulated for this participatory tool; it also proposes limiting the content of the European citizens' initiative if it does not suit the competences of the Union and, above all, that the Commission should make a legislative proposal only if it has a positive opinion published by it. For these reasons, and given the low prospositivo content of the report to consolidate European citizen initiatives politically and legally, I voted against it.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Citizens' Initiative (ECI) was born as a tool to give European citizens the opportunity to participate in the launch of legislative initiatives, in order to increase the mobilisation of civil society and to strengthen European citizenship, especially at transnational level. Through the report voted on today, an attempt has been made not only to improve the functioning of the ECI, but above all to identify the critical issues of the system itself, given that so far 51 requests have been made to launch an initiative, but only 3 initiatives have been declared admissible. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution because it is essentially creating an economic blueprint for the area in a region that does contain EU Member States. This report also calls for quicker accession to the Union for non-EU member states.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Citizens' Initiative (ECI) has been in operation since 2012 and its main objective is to enable Union citizens to participate in legislative initiatives. Unfortunately, on the basis of the views of civil society and the Commission's reports, it is concluded that this instrument does not fulfil its essential functions. Since 2012, 51 initiatives have been submitted, not a single one of which has resulted in the introduction of the proposed legislation. In addition, the organisers of many rejected initiatives challenged the Commission's decision not to register these initiatives with the Court of Justice and the European Ombudsman. The fact that the number of new initiatives has also been widely highlighted is also widely highlighted. The reasons for this are disproportionately stringent requirements and an unnecessarily complex system. This mainly mentions: insufficient communication activities with regard to the ECI at European and national level, a very different system for providing personal data in order to support the ECI in individual Member States, citizens' distrust of the personal data required in support of the ECI and the personal responsibility of the organisers for the protection of personal data, the failure to provide detailed and exhaustive reasons for the Commission's rejection of the proposed ECI, too short a period of time for organisers to collect statements of support.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report seeks to address the problems of the poor implementation of the European Citizens’ Initiative and the logistical and practical problems associated. The ECI could be a great tool to get citizens more involved in the democratic process, yet it has hitherto fallen short of this promise. With only three ECI reaching the target for consideration by the Commission, it is clear that the ECI needs to be more user-friendly and many of the obstacles need to be eliminated before it can become a useful instrument. In particular, I voted in favour of amendments 4 and 5 because they ensure that successful ECIs will get a real chance of having legal action made about them, whilst having satisfactory safeguards to protect European Citizens from abuse of the democratic instrument.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I have decided to abstain from this report, and this reasoning for voting comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 When the Treaty of Lisbon came into force, when European citizens had the opportunity to apply to the European Commission for a legislative initiative, many of us felt that we had brought Europe one step closer to its citizens once again. That is why I find it outrageous and a mockery of the six million citizens who have taken part in the initiatives so far, that only three of the 51 applications have so far been declared admissible and 20 have already been rejected.  This sends a message to citizens not to interfere in the Commission's affairs, and citizens are taking the message, as the number of initiatives is clearly on a downward trend. It cannot be constantly argued that citizens misunderstand European law and the role of the Commission when seeking solutions to the most important issues affecting their lives. Doing so will only reinforce the perception that the European institutions are unable to find answers to citizens' problems. I consider it extremely damaging from the point of view of participatory democracy and to the image of the European Union, the way in which the Commission has so far handled european citizens' initiatives, and I therefore support my fellow Member Schöpflin's report, which can contribute to improving regulation.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The European Citizens' Initiative is a unique and innovative tool for designing a programme in the context of participatory democracy in the European Union. This enables citizens to participate actively in the projects and procedures that affect them.  This ensures that every citizen has the opportunity to participate in the democratic life of the EU through direct access to the European Commission by calling for a legislative proposal for an EU legal act. The European Citizens' Initiative represents an extraordinary opportunity for EU citizens to express their wishes and to demand appropriate action from the EU institutions.  However, it does not currently constitute an effective instrument for ensuring participatory democracy, as there are many systemic shortcomings. Further assessment of this tool should aim to ensure that the user is as user-friendly as possible, as it is the main means of connecting European citizens with the EU.  Among other things, the report proposes concrete measures to make citizens' initiatives more effective, such as improving citizens' information through 'online one-stop-shop' and specifying the reasons for rejecting the initiative.  On the other hand, the report lacks the rights of the European Citizens' Initiative. Furthermore, the report does not meet all the requirements for effective and effective regulation of the European Citizens' Initiative, which is why I abstained in the vote on the report.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Faced with the need to provide European citizens with an instrument enabling them to make their proposals to the European institutions, the Treaty of Lisbon introduced the European Citizens' Initiative (ECI), which allows citizens the right to apply for EU action on a given subject, if one million signatures are collected. However, only three ECi have so far met all the requirements to be considered by the European Commission, but no initiative has become a legislative proposal, while registrations of new proposals are gradually decreasing. In order to prevent this instrument of citizen participation in the European decision-making process from loseing of interest and usefulness to the public, Parliament adopted a resolution containing a series of proposals on how to improve the process, with a view to improving the discipline of the ECI. As the S&D Group, we have, in particular, achieved a uniform procedure in the Member States, greater flexibility in the time taken to collect signatures, better accessibility for disabled people and young people from the age of 16, and the possibility of signing in the current country of residence. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the text adopted today.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. 'This report strengthens the European Citizens' Initiative (ECI) as an instrument for citizens' political participation. Since the Treaty of Lisbon, there has been a legal framework for the European Citizens' Initiative, but various reactions from citizens' movements point to its malfunction. The aim of this report is therefore to improve the ECI mechanism so that it becomes more user-friendly and removes certain obstacles for organisers and promoters. As greens, we would like the European Commission and the European Parliament to give more action to successful citizens' initiatives. That is why we tabled three amendments to ensure this. Firstly, there is so far no clear obligation for the Commission to respond to a successful citizens' initiative with a legislative proposal. The first amendment therefore proposes that the Commission should respond within a period of 12 months. Secondly, Parliament must come up with a legislative initiative report if the Commission fails in the above proposal. Thirdly, citizens' initiatives that address the European Union's primary legislation must also be allowed, which has hitherto been difficult. Unfortunately, these amendments were all rejected, hence our abstention from the final vote.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. Since the launch of the European Citizens' Initiative in April 2012, only three of the fifty-one initiatives launched have reached the necessary number of signatures. However, none of these initiatives has led to legally binding measures. The project, in its current form, poses numerous obstacles for citizens. Therefore, the report proposes several steps to make citizens aware of the initiative and make the process more user-friendly. It also calls on the European Commission to respond more quickly. In order to increase the benefits of this initiative, it is important that this process is as transparent and user-friendly as possible. ALFA has always supported direct democracy. Citizens must have a say and have the opportunity to influence EU legislation. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Citizens' Initiative is a unique and innovative tool for participatory democracy in the EU. It enables citizens to become an active part of the processes that affect them. I believe that, in this way, we can also engage our citizens more in matters of public affairs. It is important to simplify the way European citizens' initiatives work and also to raise awareness.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report because I believe that the ECI is a new political right for citizens and a unique and innovative tool for shaping democracy programmes in the European Union that enables citizens to actively participate in projects and processes affecting them, and whose potential must undeniably be fully exploited and significantly improved in order to achieve the best results and encourage as many EU citizens as possible to participate in the further development of the European integration process.  Given that strengthening the democratic legitimacy of institutions must be one of the EU's priorities, I believe it is necessary to assess the implementation of Regulation (EU) No 1009/2013. 211/2011 in order to identify all its shortcomings and to propose solutions for them. Experience so far shows that most organisers of EUROPEAN citizens' initiatives have encountered a number of difficulties in organising the ECI on practical and legal aspects, and since the organisers of several rejected ECIs have subsequently lodged complaints with the Court of Justice of the EU and the European Ombudsman about the Commission's decision not to register their ECIs.  I believe that the civilian engagement of young people in the European Union is fundamental to the future of the union and the betterment of all its citizens, and therefore I supported the report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report seeks to address the poor implementation of the European Citizens’ Initiative (ECI) and the associated logistical and practical problems. The ECI could be a great tool to get citizens more involved in the democratic process, yet it has hitherto fallen short of its promise. With only three citizens’ initiatives reaching the target for consideration by the Commission, it is clear that the ECI needs to be more user-friendly and many obstacles need to be eliminated before it can become a useful instrument.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The ECI is designed as an instrument to enable European citizens to participate in the launch of legislative initiatives. This instrument therefore includes the idea that once it enters into force it will strengthen civil social mobility and strengthen European citizenship.  It is clear, both from the numerous responses from civil society and from the Commission's report on the first three years of the instrument, that whatever the criteria for success are, no initiative has so far followed the legislative process. Furthermore, of the 33 initiatives registered so far, only 15 have been launched. I support this report because it aims to achieve a better functioning of the ECI, as well as the elimination of certain obstacles that have got in the way of the organisers of the initiative itself.  While it has been recognised that some of these difficulties could not have been foreseen, the last three years of experience offer an opportunity to innovate and that the Commission is likely to launch a comprehensive review of the initiative in 2016. In this situation, Parliament's attitude towards the instrument will play a major role, as Parliament represents the very beneficiaries of the initiative.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal. I agree with the measures presented, which can make the current possibility of the European Citizens' Initiative more effective, as well as give them more weight. This is also one way of increasing the possibilities for democratic decision-making by citizens in the EU.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the European Citizens' Initiative. Today, we are facing a great lack of citizens' trust in the European Union, its institutions and policies. Despite the fact that citizens vote for their representatives in the European Parliament, they feel cut off from decision-making. That is why we are all responsible and called to change that. With the European Citizens' Initiative, we make an enormous contribution to strengthening participatory democracy, as citizens can actively participate in the projects and procedures that concern them. I agree that this potential needs to be fully exploited and substantially strengthened.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the European Citizens' Initiative (ECI), as I consider this instrument of participation of European citizens in the EU public space to be very important and beneficial. It is an instrument designed for all EU citizens who can launch their initiative in different Member States at the same time, thus drawing attention to areas or problems that require new legislative action. As soon as the ECI regulation entered into force, it became clear that it was an instrument that the public wanted to use. Unfortunately, over time, the whole process has also proved unnecessarily complex, places unnecessary demands on the initiators of the initiative, and a number of rules governing the whole process are not clearly defined. It is now the intention of the European Parliament to draw attention to these problems and to call for redress. Breaking the Exclusivity of the European Commission with regard to the legislative initiative seems too revolutionary at the moment, but I believe that the ECI can still be a meaningful and useful tool if existing shortcomings are remedied and the ECI becomes more user-friendly. The EP's role in this process is irreplaceable because it is the only EU institution that represents directly the citizens of the Member States.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 This report concerns the creation of an instrument of transnational participatory democracy that allows citizens to participate directly in the EU institutions.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of this report because it points to the operational deficiencies of the ECI's legal institution to date with a well-founded criticism of experience, as well as proposals on a number of points for more substantive amendments to the system that give the European citizen a truly direct democratic experience, while at the same time resulting in concrete European legislation. For my part, I consider the EUROPEAN Citizens' Initiative to be a potentially very important institution of European direct democracy, but its results so far have been disappointing, partly because of shortcomings in regulation, partly because of the lack of cooperation between the Member States and partly because of the Commission's restrictive approach to the inclusion of initiatives.  In agreement with this report, I believe that the possible direction for improvement is not to change the Treaty, but to apply the current legislation more flexibly, citizenly and user-friendlyly, as well as better communication between the Commission and the governments of the Member States. In order to achieve this, the report provides a number of useful aspects that the European Parliament must continue to monitor. In considering the importance of this issue, as a Hungarian Member, it was also important for me that the government in my country is currently pursuing a policy aimed at direct democracy and the impediment of the institution of the referendum; I hope that the better functioning of the European citizens' initiative will lead to a positive European example that will help to prevent this effort.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The source of the power of democracy is civil society. In order not only to function well, but also to develop, it must be able to influence the results of governance not only once every few years in the electoral act, but also on an ongoing basis, which, in the case of the European Union, is served by the European Citizens' Initiative. I am in favour of its functioning and of taking measures that can serve to contribute more effectively to the participation of citizens in solving issues that are important to all of us. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of Parliament's report, which includes a number of proposals aimed at simplifying the formal and procedural requirements for submitting a European citizens' initiative.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The ECI is one of the most powerful tools for direct democracy that the Lisbon Treaty provided our citizens. Since the entry into force of the ECI, 51 initiatives have been submitted, resulting in the participation of more than 6 million people. While this is encouraging, in reality, of the 51 initiatives submitted in the past three years only three were deemed admissible. Yet not a single initiative was followed up by legislation. The low success rates are linked to a number of problems regarding 1) the information provided to ECI organisers, 2) the software offered by the EC for collecting signatures online, and 3) problems related to the public awareness of the ECI.  The current report, which I voted in favour of, provides us with the opportunity to address ongoing issues. It calls on the Commission to increase transparency to the ECI, on both the national and the European levels. It further asks the Commission to provide appropriate guidelines, and legal guidance, to ECI organizers. Lastly, as a young MEP I welcome the report’s recommendation to lower the age of participation in Member States from 18 to 16. This recommendation will surely help us to draw young people’s interest and participation in this democratic exercise.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Citizens' Initiative (ECI) has its origins in the Convention and was designed to give European citizens the opportunity to participate in the launch of legislative initiatives. The original idea was therefore that, once in place, this instrument would further mobilise civil society and strengthen European citizenship, particularly at the transnational level. In view of the multiple responses received from civil society and the Commission's report on the first three years of ICE's operation, it is clear that regardless of the criteria for success, the project has not yet achieved its objectives, as no initiative has so far been followed by legislation. The Commission's report mentions 51 initiatives (COM(2015)145). This report seeks to improve the functioning of ICE in order to make it more user-friendly and to remove some of the obstacles that have proven to be a source of difficulty for ICE organizers.  The Commission is expected to undertake a thorough review of the ICE in 2016 and Parliament's opinion on this instrument will have its weight because it will reflect, above all, the point of view of the grassroots, that of the citizens who have tried to use the ICE.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I share the view that the functioning of the European Citizens’ Initiative (ECI) needs improving. The report aims to make it more user-friendly and to eliminate some of the obstacles that complicate organising an initiative. The ECI has been in place since 1 April 2012, and throughout those three years the Commission has noted 51 initiatives, only three of which were deemed admissible. None of them has yet been followed by legislation – a situation that points to weaknesses in the instrument in its current form. The purpose of the ECI is to give European citizens the opportunity to participate in launching legislative initiatives. Amending it should enhance the mobilisation of civil society and facilitate the process of organising initiatives.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome this own-initiative report, because I believe that ECI is one of the greatest innovations in terms of participatory democracy, introduced into the Treaties. Thanks to this instrument, citizens have an exceptional opportunity to identify and define the Union's legislative priorities and to play an active part in the definition of new objectives. As stated in the report, it is necessary to make citizens, especially the youngest, aware of the use of this participatory instrument. The Commission and national authorities must use all public communication channels and take the necessary measures to ensure their transparency, as well as facilitate comprehensive responses that allow European citizens to play a leading role in the legislative initiative process. In order to publicise this type of initiative in the best possible way, technology plays a key role, and the Commission must therefore improve the collection of signatures electronically.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 It has not been a breakthrough institution under the Treaty: a total of three out of 51 initiatives have met expectations – 1 million signatures from 7 Member States. The Schöpflin report explores and proposes the causes of this procedural failure, including better communication of the instrument, the creation of more user-friendly interfaces, simpler data requests, budget support, direct advice and the promotion of digital citizenship participation, facilitating the participation of millions of citizens in an EU-wide initiative by establishing an EU digital citizenship. The rapporteur underlines the wider awareness of the initiative, which aims to directly connect citizens to European institutional decision-making. The report wants to confirm this connection. In agreement with the report, I called on the Commission to review the rules of procedure so far.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I strongly supported the report on strengthening the European Citizens' Initiative, which aims to transform its form into more citizen-friendly and remove the obstacles that make it more difficult. The European initiative is one of the most important instruments of democracy, which allows citizens to communicate directly with the Institutions of the European Union. However, it also enables every European citizen to actively participate and influence EU legislation. For this reason, the Commission should use all possible public communication channels to increase the popularity of the European Citizens' Initiative. The EU institutions should publish this issue on a much larger scale in the Member States. This will contribute to increased awareness and exercise of citizens' rights.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on the European Citizens' Initiative because I believe that this will improve the functioning of the European Citizens' Initiative and make it more user-friendly. The voice of the people is very important. We also want to remove some of the barriers that have been shown to be a source of problems for the organisers of the initiatives.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained in the vote on this report. We understand that European citizen initiatives are the closest mechanism for citizens when considering projects to the Union; we also understand that there is a need to improve the mechanisms by which these initiatives can be carried out; we also understand that, without an improvement in European citizen initiatives, the Union will continue to be perceived as a strange and distant entity. Therefore, the functioning of them must be improved, in the spirit and in the letter; we understand that, having adopted certain amendments, this report loses the strength we would want for it, and that is why we abstained.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. Since the launch of the European Citizens' Initiative in April 2012, only three of the fifty-one initiatives launched have reached the necessary number of signatures. None of them has led to legally binding measures because the number of administrative and legal obstacles was too great. The current report proposes several steps to make citizens aware of the initiative and make the process more user-friendly. It also calls on the European Commission to respond more quickly. In order to increase the benefits of this initiative, it is important that this process is as transparent and user-friendly as possible. ALFA has always supported direct democracy. Citizens must have a say and have the opportunity to influence EU legislation. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Citizens' Initiative is an innovation of the Treaty of Lisbon, which entitles citizens to political initiative, as subject to certain conditions. In this way, citizens can invite the Commission to submit new proposals for legal acts in areas of EU competence, thus directly participating in the development of European policies. However, despite this reforming right it introduces, the European Citizens' Initiative has been facing a number of technical and organisational problems since its introduction on 1 April 2012. Thus, in 3 years of existence, 51 initiatives have been submitted to the Commission, only one of which has been accepted.  In addition to the need for at least one million supporters from at least a quarter of the Member States, the organisers of a European Citizens' Initiative face complex procedures that discourage them and the Commission can reject this request without any particular reason. This requires a reform of this provision of participatory democracy in order to meet its ultimate objective, namely that citizens are placed on an equal footing with the European Parliament and the Council of the EU before the Commission.  I therefore voted in favour of the Schöpflin Report on the European Citizens' Initiative.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EUROPEAN Citizens' Initiative has its roots in the Convention and has been established as a tool to give European citizens the opportunity to participate in legislative initiatives. This instrument is therefore based on the idea that civil society will be mobilised more mobilised and European citizenship strengthened, especially transnationally, once it enters into force. The main objective of the report was to improve the functioning of the European Citizens' Initiative and to make it more user-friendly, which is why I supported it.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained in the vote on this report. We understand that European citizen initiatives are the closest mechanism for citizens when considering projects to the Union; we also understand that there is a need to improve the mechanisms by which these initiatives can be carried out; we also understand that, without an improvement in European citizen initiatives, the Union will continue to be perceived as a strange and distant entity. Therefore, the functioning of them must be improved, in the spirit and in the letter; we understand that, having adopted certain amendments, this report loses the strength we would want for it, and that is why we abstained.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I abstained in this report because, on the one hand, it involves strengthening the European citizens' initiative, but on the other hand it still does not establish the need for the Commission to make a legislative proposal when a European citizen initiative succeeds, nor does it play an appropriate role for Parliament in its functions of representing the sovereignty of the EU as a whole.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the European Citizens’ Initiative (ECI). The aim of the text is to improve the functioning of the ECI, to make it more user-friendly, to raise awareness about it and to eliminate some of the obstacles that have proved a source of difficulty for ECI organisers. The European Citizens’ Initiative is one of the most important tools for citizens’ participation in democratic decisions at European level, hence it should be more citizen-friendly. In this resolution we also call on the Commission to recommend to Member States that they lower the age for supporting and participating in a citizens’ initiative from 18 to 16 – a step which could increase democracy and participation, including among young people.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a report which carries out an evaluation of the implementation of the Regulation on this initiative, and which conveys certain ideas and proposals for a future revision of this Regulation, to be carried out soon by the European Commission. I therefore consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report refers to the forthcoming revision of Regulation (EU) No 211/2011 on the European citizens' initiative and to the conclusions drawn by the European Commission in a recently published document. Our position is that the implementation of the European citizen initiative has been an absolute failure; in fact, of fifty-one registered proposals, only three have been able to meet the requirements, often because of the numerous administrative locks during the signature collection process, which sometimes lead to the Commission's own complaint to the courts.  As if that were not the case, the European Commission is not obliged to initiate any proposal for legislative amendments, so their effectiveness is minimal. In the face of this situation, the final report is not at all critical of the procedures regulated for this participatory tool; it also proposes limiting the content of the European citizens' initiative if it does not suit the competences of the Union and, above all, that the Commission should make a legislative proposal only if it has a positive opinion published by it. For these reasons, and given the low prospositivo content of the report to consolidate European citizen initiatives politically and legally, I voted against it.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to vote in favour of this report, which addresses important problems that have arisen with the European Citizens’ Initiative (ECI). The report seeks to address the poor implementation of the Citizens’ Initiative and the associated logistical and practical problems. The ECI could be a great tool to get citizens more involved in the democratic process, yet it has hitherto fallen short of its promise. With only three citizens’ initiatives reaching the target for consideration by the Commission, it is clear that the ECI needs to be more user-friendly and that many obstacles need to be eliminated before it can become a useful instrument.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The so-called European Citizens' Initiative was, from the outset, a puerile, but also perverse, attempt to legitimize an entire structurally undemocratic building. Let us not forget that the Treaty establishing this initiative has ostensibly escaped the scrutiny of peoples through referendums. It has been approved and ratified on the backs of citizens whose participation it says it wants to welcome. Six years have elapsed, it is clear that this instrument, called participatory democracy, has fallen. In more than half a hundred attempts, only three have been able to meet the strict parameters defined to make this "citizen participation" acceptable.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The proposals are a significant improvement on the current legal situation with the ECIs. Obstacles that have hitherto been problematic for European citizens' initiatives will be removed. The functioning of the European Citizens' Initiative will be more user-friendly. I therefore supported the report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the European Citizens' Initiative (ECI) because I see it as an instrument of guarantee and democratic participation that allows European citizens greater active participation in the legislative initiative. The basic idea was to develop an instrument that, once in force, could increase the mobilisation of civil society and strengthen European citizenship, especially at transnational level. ICE is a relatively young tool (it has been around for three years) and like all instruments it needs to be refined, improved and tested. The goal we have set ourselves is to implement the functioning of ice, through the simplification of procedures and the elimination of obstacles that create difficulties for ice organizers.  At a time when Europe is accused of major democratic shortcomings, support for an instrument that encourages bottom-up initiative becomes essential.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on European Citizens Initiative. ECI is a new political right introduced for our citizens, which allows them to play an active role in the creation of EU law. The initiative was introduced in April 2012, and from that time, we have received a number of complaints suggesting that ECI is not working as well as intended.  First of all, the report focuses mainly on increasing the public awareness of ECI. In order for the initiative to be effective, it is crucial to raise the awareness amongst both our citizens and that appropriate media, and also to ensure its transparency. Moreover, the provisions of that report point out several difficulties that organisers have encountered since the regulation entered into force in spring 2012, and it suggests the measures that should be undertaken in order to eliminate those problems. Hence, the idea of establishing a dedicated ECI office is very promising and it may, in fact, prove to be a sufficient way to ensure that the ECI is working well enough.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As a Member of the CULT Committee, citizenship is a central part of my portfolio. The European Citizens’ Initiative has the potential to strengthen European democracy, empower citizens to participate, and make the EU more responsive to their needs and demands. A European Union of vibrant grassroots citizen engagement is what we would like to see. I voted for this report in order to address the problems of the poor implementation of the European Citizens’ Initiative and the logistical and practical problems associated. The ECI has hitherto fallen short of its promise. With only three initiatives reaching the target for consideration by the Commission, it is clear that the ECI needs to be more user-friendly and that many of the obstacles need to be eliminated before it can become a useful instrument.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D)
text: Writing. The European Union is based on its citizens. It should act in its interests and for its interests. An instrument that allows direct participation was therefore a very good and important step. However, the figures presented by the Commission show that the citizens' initiative's resources have been being used less and less since its introduction. Initiators must be supported in bringing in citizens' initiatives. This means, on the one hand, the reduction of bureaucratic hurdles and, on the other hand, support in the promotion of the respective initiative. It is also necessary to raise awareness that there is the possibility of a European citizens' initiative. I therefore support efforts to improve the citizens' initiative instrument and make it a successful means of participation.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – ICE was considered a triumph of the Treaty of Lisbon because it opened up the chance for European citizens to become legislative initiators and active participants in the development of European policies. 3 years after its entry into force, this tool causes disappointment. The EC's bureaucratic, legal approach risks having the opposite effect to what is desired, helping to remove citizens from Europe.  The EP has played an important role in promoting ICE legislation, and now, once again, the EP is taking the initiative to amend the regulation. The EU must become a political construct and therefore be open to the ideas and proposals of its citizens. This imperative must be understood by EU bureaucrats, but also by Member States who must facilitate the entire ECI procedure, instead of putting additional administrative obstacles.  I voted for the Schöpflin Report, which contains clear proposals to improve the ICE Regulation. The proposed amendment to the EC and the Council must prove that the EU is at a crossroads. Either we learn to listen to the voice of our citizens and then we will be successful, or we continue to move away from European citizens, thus being destined for failure.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. The report on the Citizens' Initiative Regulation was more than necessary.  This possibility was already envisaged in the Lisbon Treaty, but it was not until 2012 that it was able to get going. From the outing point of view it presented major deficiencies, both from a regulatory and communication and logistical point of view. This system has not satisfied citizens, who face a bureaucratic challenge that is difficult to navigate. Citizens need to be aware of the procedure for processing and adopting citizen initiatives, as they are often frustrated to discover that the initiative will not succeed and request explanations from the European Parliament. It is time to take stock and improve the deficiencies of this system.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The practical implementation of the so-called "citizens' initiative" fully confirms the criticism made in a timely and well-documented manner by the JRC, namely that it is an unpopular firework of EU embellishment and manipulation of consciences, when urban and opportunist parties and the media presented it as a form of so-called "participatory democracy" in the EU. The experience of the only two such initiatives that have been taken so far has shown that they are directly dependent on the approval and authorisation of the European Commission, are necessarily in the unpopular framework set by the reactionary EU Treaties and ultimately end up in the wastebasket if they do not serve the unpopular objectives of the EU and civil governments. The KKE's complaints that the 'citizens' initiative' will also serve as a vehicle for presenting unpopular aims of monopolies as a so-called 'popular demand' came to confirm the airline 'Ryanair', known for the savage exploitation of its workers, which launched its own 'citizens' initiative' under the slogan 'Keep European Skies Open', calling on the 'EU institutions' to ban the right to strike air traffic controllers! That is why workers must condemn these reactionary EU tools, step up their fight against the EU, throughout its unpopular structure and the monopolies it serves.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the European Citizens' Initiative is the legal instrument for direct democracy in the European Union, which is intended to enable the citizens of the European Union to be directly involved in the drafting of new legislation on topics they consider important, the fate of the citizens' initiatives to date says otherwise. Of the 51 initiatives launched, only 3 were able to meet the requirements, and unfortunately none of them led to the legislative proposal put forward by the European Commission. In such a situation, I think it is worth asking what the failure of so many citizens' initiatives is. Whether it is a lack of awareness of this possibility, too complex or incomprehensible requirements or other causes. The report deals with possible causes and also looks at how to make this legal instrument more serious so as to return the citizens of the European Union's confidence in its effectiveness. I consider the opinion of at least one million European citizens on a particular subject to be so important that it cannot be ignored simply and without cause, possibly by reference to the failure to meet overly burdensome administrative requirements. I therefore supported the report.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The so-called European Citizens' Initiative was, from the outset, a puerile, but also perverse, attempt to legitimize an entire structurally undemocratic building. Let us not forget that the Treaty establishing this initiative has ostensibly escaped the scrutiny of peoples through referendums. It has been approved and ratified on the backs of citizens whose participation it says it wants to welcome. Six years have elapsed, it is clear that this instrument, called participatory democracy, has fallen. In more than half a hundred attempts, only three have been able to meet the strict parameters defined to make this "citizen participation" acceptable. Unable to accept the illusion of democraticity that this farce creates, we voted against the report.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on an EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region mainly concerns the opportunities of the maritime economy, thus covering all aspects related to it. It calls for recognition of the high potential of renewable energy sources, calling for the exploitation of all available sources, and also highlights the risks related to the exploration and exploitation of oil and gas offshore and on land. It also calls for the capacity of the existing infrastructure network to be optimised, with particular reference to road and rail links in the macro-region, and for the development of a genuine inter-mode of transport, airports, railways and motorways, which will bring undoubted benefits to Italy, which does not shine in these respects. However, there is no shortage of critical issues, since it is planned to exploit the European Fund for Strategic Investments and in Italy it is unfortunately a double-edged sword, since among the projects presented in the EFSI there is the restructuring of the Ilva of Taranto. Then, while looking at clean energy, the importance of joint investment planning for the development of liquefied natural gas (LNG) terminals and gas pipelines is stressed. A great opportunity ruined by the usual economic interests, so I decided to abstain in the vote.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I believe that this report mixes positive and negative elements in the EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region. On the one hand, there is a commitment to support the economic development of these regions, with an impact on aspects such as sustainability or support for SMEs and traditional sectors such as tourism or fisheries.  On the other hand, the EU is endowed with a leading role in a region in which not even all States are members, imposing the adoption of the European acquis and favouring private investment in sectors as sensitive as energy or transport. As a result, I abstained.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report to give the European Parliament's position on the Union's strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Sea region (EUSAIR). This text provides for measures involving strengthening the regionalisation of Member States while weakening the power of national governments. It also promotes an enlargement of the European Union by repeatedly stressing an integration dimension of the EUSAIR strategy.  Opposed to any loss of national sovereignty and to a further enlargement of the Union, I have spoken out against this report.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report proposes an EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region. In doing so, it describes the special characteristics of the Adriatic-Ionian macro-region and the difficulties and opportunities that it faces, and calls for specific action to be taken. However, the strategy put forward is based on the ‘three NOs’ principle – no new legislation, no new institutions, no new funding. The strategy can therefore use only the already existing EU financial resources and tools, and funding in this report is placed in the context of the Europe 2020 strategy with the strict conditions that entails. There are a number of other concerns with the report, such as support for contentious major projects, and a call to non-EU states to accelerate the implementation of sectoral acquis, such as the Water Framework Directive, as a condition of accession to the EU. Therefore, while there are positive aspects to the report, I abstained on this motion.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, as I believe it is necessary to bridge the gap and strengthen cooperation between EU countries in the region and third countries. Issues such as plant shortages, insufficient connection of electrical nodes and destruction of ecosystems by the human factor are just some of the issues that this report seeks to address.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This strategy for the Adriatic and the Ionian Sea covers eight countries, four of which are members of the European Union - Croatia, Greece, Italy and Slovenia - and four non-members - Albania, Montenegro, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina. This report once again illustrates the EU's desire to create cross-border macro-regions in order to circumvent the sovereignty of Member States. It is a question of weakening the central powers in favour of local authorities which are more malleable to the European institutions. In fact, the States concerned could quite deal with these issues in a multilateral manner. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This is, in essence, the EU creating an economic blueprint for an area which does not contain any EU Member States.  Furthermore, it proposes quicker accession for current non-EU countries. I therefore voted against.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, as the committee recommended on its merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on the EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region. EUSAIR is the EU's third macro-regional strategy and has benefited from the lessons and experience of eu strategies for the Baltic Sea Region and the Danube region. EUSAIR is an excellent opportunity, under the leadership of the countries of the region, the Commission working together to achieve prosperity and sustainable development and to leave economic and political problems in the past. EUSAIR enables investment to be channelled in such a way as to achieve results that are beneficial to the region as a whole. The potential of the Adriatic and Ionian region is considerable and can only be exploited through joint and coordinated efforts by all countries in the region with the active involvement of local and regional authorities. The Commission will have a special role to play with the EIB in providing guidance and support for the implementation of the strategy.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has always championed national democracy and state cooperation, but we have always argued against EU overarching policies on any region, especially a region that includes non-EU members. In order to have an effective economic strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region, Member States should decide the best action for themselves through intergovernmental cooperation. Therefore we voted against this report.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on an EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Sea region presented by the Commission consists of a macro-regional strategy covering eight Member States (Croatia, Greece, Italy and Slovenia in particular). Other third countries either have the status of candidate or potential candidate for EU membership. Unfortunately, this strategy directly targets local authorities by ignoring states. Moreover, it shows a hegemonic dimension of the EU that creates a specific policy for a few states when the problem should be dealt with bilaterally. Finally, the text wants the enlargement of the EU and I have therefore naturally decided to vote against this text which kills the nations.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The resolution I approved supports the development of a macro-regional strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region, as this new multi-level governance model, to which the regions are increasingly interested, is a source of considerable benefits.  Parliament takes stock of the potential benefits of this region, including the protection of its marine, coastal and terrestrial ecosystems and blue growth, highlighting the immense potential of the region in terms of creating blue jobs and sustainable and innovative economic development and growth, due to its exceptional geographical position and specific coastal structure. It also notes the positive impact of this strategy on the development of sustainable and competitive tourism, which is of crucial importance to the European economy and the development of social cohesion within the Union.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of macro-regional strategies, as they can ensure effective regional and transnational development in Europe. With this strategy, the Adriatic-Ionian region will benefit from growth in the transport sector, the sea-related economy and environmental protection, which together will bring benefits for tourism. I voted in favour.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. In July, the European Commission presented the EU Strategy on the Adriatic and Ionian Region (EUSAIR), which establishes a third macroregion in the EU – after those of the Baltic Sea and the Danube – providing a coherent framework for regional macro-stress and a cooperation action plan between the EU and three other countries (eight in total). The Adriatic-Ionian region faces a number of common challenges, both because of the historical events of the past and by the large socio-economic disparities between different countries and regions. There are significant infrastructure deficits. Marine and coastal ecosystems are threatened by human exploitation. Administrative and institutional capacities at the national, regional and local levels should be strengthened, etc. The rapporteur seeks to find solutions to all these problems, contributing to the four pillars of the strategy (blue growth, connecting the region, quality of the environment and sustainable and competitive tourism).  That is why I voted in favour of this report, which finally incorporates the socialist claim to finish the Baltic-Adriatic corridor, including the extension of the Ionian-Adriatic ridge as a whole.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has expressed Parliament's position on the EU Strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Seas proposed by the Commission. Macro-regional strategies are a new model of multi-level governance and, in order to ensure its successful implementation and achievement of objectives, the involvement of stakeholders at EU, national, regional and local level is essential. Previous strategies in the Baltic Sea region and the Danube region have brought tangible benefits to these regions and have proven that the EU's cooperation mechanisms are successful. There are significant socio-economic disparities between the countries involved in the implementation of this strategy, in particular between EU Member States and non-EU countries, but their interest in cooperation and joint action in the fight against the potential of the region as a whole and through continuous efforts to create synergies has been increased. Parliament welcomed the Commission communication on the European Union Strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Seas region and the accompanying action plan.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In December 2012, the European Council invited the Commission to present its vision for a new Adriatic and Ionian Strategy (EUSAIR) before the end of 2014 and, accordingly, on 17 June 2014 the Commission presented a draft strategy. EUSAIR is the third EU macro-regional strategy that can build on the experience of strategies for the Baltic Sea and Danube regions. The Adriatic and Yin Sea region is home to more than 70 million people and covers eight countries, four of which are EU Member States (Croatia, Greece, Italy, Slovenia), three candidate countries (Albania, Montenegro, Serbia) and Bosnia and Herzegovina as potential candidate countries. I voted in favour of this draft report in the plenary vote, as EUSAIR provides a good opportunity for the countries of the region to stimulate sustainable development. The Pillars of the Strategy ('blue growth', development of infrastructure links in the region, environment, sustainable, competitive tourism) and other priorities (EU integration of the Western Balkan countries, ensuring coherence between the three EU macro-regional strategies and national strategic projects) will promote economic development and job creation. However, I think it is important to stress that for all macro-regional strategies, a comprehensive evaluation of the results is needed. It is necessary to ensure that the strategies have genuine European added value and that they have real, tangible positive effects in the region concerned.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. The proposed report on the EU Strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Region – i also worked intensively as shadow rapporteur for the EPP Political Group – was, of course, supported by offering a number of recommendations and incentives to the Commission and the macro-region Member States involved.  It encourages them to integrate more actively with a view to better economic cooperation and job creation in areas that are underdeveloped in terms of potential (so-called blue growth), joint planning of transport and energy policies and a coordinated approach to environmental protection.  The Action Plan for this part of Europe thus foresees the improvement and integration of tourism supply with a focus on sustainable tourism and expects the improvement of transport and energy infrastructure. All European policy instruments are thus available to countries, and the strategy enables them to integrate more effectively and to benefit more effectively from the resources already available – from the newly created European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) to regular funding from the European Cohesion Policy as well as Horizon 2020, LIFE, Erasmus plus and the like. The current migrant crisis shows the weak cooperation of these countries, so I hope that this strategy will provide the right basis for cooperation, especially for the leading politicians in the region. This is, above all, a guarantee for further economic development.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 More than ten years have passed since the birth of the Adriatic region that gathered 26 regions of this area. The Italian Presidency expanded this project by launching in 2014 the European Strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Region (EUSAIR) involving four member countries (Croatia, Greece, Italy and Slovenia), three candidate countries (Albania, Montenegro, Serbia), and a potential candidate (Bosnia and Herzegovina). The report, which I support, highlights the four pillars on which EUSAIR insists: innovative growth in the maritime sector (Blue Growth), strengthening infrastructure and links (Connecting the region), better protection of the environment through greater cooperation (Environmental Quality) and development of the region's tourism potential (Sustainable Tourism). This plan aims to realise the opportunities of the region's maritime economy through better energy connectivity, but also to stimulate research and innovation for the benefit of small and medium-sized enterprises, improving European connections, such as the Baltic-Adriatic corridor and the Scandinavian-Mediterranean corridor.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The Adriatic-Ionian Strategy is an important non-existent document describing the EU's objectives and priorities in the areas of blue growth, connecting Europe programmes, environmental protection and sustainable tourism.  This document, following the Danube and Baltic, establishes the third macro-region in the EU. I support the report and the work of rapporteur Jakovčić, who took into account the protection of the interests of the Republic of Croatia, without the strategy being turned into a narrow national document. This ensures the broad support of MEPs.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report proposes an EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region. In doing so, it describes the special characteristics of the Adriatic-Ionian macro-region and the difficulties and opportunities that it faces, and calls for specific action to be taken. However, the strategy put forward is based on the ‘three NOs’ principle – no new legislation, no new institutions, no new funding. The strategy can therefore use only the already existing EU financial resources and tools, and funding in this report is placed in the context of the Europe 2020 strategy with the strict conditions that entails. There are a number of other concerns with the report, such as support for contentious major projects, and a call to non-EU states to accelerate the implementation of sectoral acquis, such as the Water Framework Directive, as a condition of accession to the EU. Therefore, while there are positive aspects to the report, I abstained on this motion.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region and the related action plan represent an essential stage in the development of this region, which is of considerable strategic importance, especially a possible future enlargement of the Union to the Balkan peninsula.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the PECH Committee, we drafted an opinion, for which I was rapporteur for the Group of the Progressive Democrats in the European Parliament, for this macro-regional strategy, which is of great interest to most European countries bordering the Mediterranean. Last month, this Parliament adopted an own-initiative report on research and innovation in the blue economy to create jobs and growth. I am pleased that this report defends the blue economy as a solution to the economic crisis, as a driver of new jobs and economic development, with particular regard to women and young people. I believe that the strategy should be an opportunity to intensify the exchange of good practices, such as projects developed by coastal action groups, which are often a virtuous example of sustainability. Finally, I would like to point out that the Mediterranean is a closed sea characterised by a high rate of depletion of fish stocks, not even as a result of excessive and not always legal fishing practices. At the same time, fisheries are a key economy of the coastal and island areas bordering the macro-region.  I would also draw attention to the urgent need to take action to bring third-country fisheries legislation into line with EU legislation, with data sharing, monitoring platforms and common fisheries management plans. Finally, why not regard the Mediterranean as a macro-region?

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to give the European Parliament's opinion on the EU's strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Sea region (EUSAIR), which covers eight countries. By making local authorities the target of European policy, this report strengthens the regionalisation of Member States and weakens the power of national governments. The report also promotes the enlargement of the European Union. The text stresses that this strategy must help candidate countries on the road to EU membership. We are staunchly opposed to any loss of national sovereignty, to any strengthening of the power of local authorities and to any enlargement of the European Union. We therefore strongly disagree with the philosophy of the text, which is diverted from the original objective of cohesion policy, namely to reduce regional disparities. So I voted against this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Adriatic and Ionian Sea stakes an area with considerable socio-economic differences between the Member States of the European Union and the other third countries. The EU strategy for this region, EUSAIR, is thus a way to create a balance in terms of prosperity and sustainable development between the countries of this region, be they EU Member States, candidate country or 'potential candidate country'. An evaluation by the European Commission in 2013 on previous strategies, namely the EU Baltic Sea Strategy (EUSBSR) and the EU Strategy for the Danube Region (EUSDR) showed that they have led to increased cooperation and thus hundreds of new projects, as well as networks, in the Danube and Baltic Sea region. These examples provide a strong argument for supporting a similar strategy in the Adriatic and Ionian regions. I voted in favour of the report on the EU Strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Seas because this area has vast potential, which can only be unlocked through joint and coordinated efforts by all the countries in the region.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. Whereas: whereas macro-regional strategies can be seen as an instrument for European integration and greater territorial cohesion, which relies on voluntary cooperation between Member States and neighbouring countries to respond to common challenges; that EUSAIR (EU Strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Region) is a new form of regional cooperation that can assist candidate and potential candidate countries on their journey to the EU, and is an important component of the EU's wider Mediterranean policy, expressed within the framework of the Union for the Mediterranean; that EUSAIR, as part of EU regional policy, is an instrument dedicated to promoting economic and social cohesion, the main objectives of which are to reduce disparities between regions, promote real convergence and encourage growth and employment; I voted in favour.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has always championed national democracy and state cooperation, but we have always argued against EU overarching policies on any region, especially a region that includes non-EU members. In order to have an effective economic strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region, Member States should decide the best action for themselves through intergovernmental cooperation. Therefore we voted against this report.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it supports the EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region, which I believe is a crucial part of social and economic cohesion strategy for this region. It stresses the importance of transparency and cooperation at regional level, which result in economic and social development. I agree with the recommendations made in the report for exploiting the enormous potential of the region, which would in turn result in endless benefits for the local people.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In June 2014, the European Commission launched a new EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region, which mainly concerns the so-called 'blue economy'. This is the EU's first macro-regional strategy involving such a high proportion of non-EU countries. The report deals with many important elements, but there are two particularly critical paragraphs. One encourages the full exploitation of the possibilities offered by the new European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) with a view to financing projects in the region. Among the projects submitted by Italy is the one concerning the general restructuring of Ilva. Secondly, the importance of joint investment planning for the development of liquefied natural gas (LNG) terminals and missing gas pipeline networks in the macro-region is stressed. The subtly reference is to tap (Trans-Adriatic Pipeline). Because of these latter critical elements, I voted against.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian macro-region is the first to involve such a large number of non-EU countries (Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro and Serbia). The cooperation that will be carried out with the cooperation of four EU Member States (Croatia, Greece, Italy and Slovenia) will facilitate the alignment of the policies of neighbouring countries with those of the European Union in order to face together common challenges (such as maritime or environmental challenges) that transcend national borders and that must necessarily count on the contribution and commitment of several countries.  The concentration on a limited number of objectives (blue growth, connecting the region, environment and sustainable tourism) traces the way to start concrete projects in search of solutions to problems that affect multiple territories and will certainly provide opportunities for development. As we learn from the resolution, the potential for economic growth for all EU and non-EU countries involved in the strategy is significant, but the important political importance of the strategy should not be overlooked as it will contribute to the stabilisation of the Western Balkans area, which has been the scene of conflict and war in the recent past.  For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The report rightly supports the creation of a quality label for high-quality seafood products bearing the Adriatic-Ionian label, in order to increase the competitiveness of the sector and to provide consumers with certification guaranteeing the quality of fishery and fish farming products. It is stressed that the development of aquaculture and marine farming can play an important role not only in the recovery of species diversity but also in the growth of the economy in the Adriatic and Ionian region.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region. The countries of the Adriatic and Ionian regions have been particularly affected by the economic crisis, resulting in an increase in unemployment and indebtedness, and have experienced a sharp decline in investment, both public and private.  The EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region represents a great opportunity as it allows investment, which has been particularly lacking in recent years, to be directed towards specific sectors and allows certain countries in the region, which are candidates for EU membership (Albania, Montenegro, Serbia) or potential candidates (Bosnia and Herzegovina), to move closer to the European Union by aligning their policies and working closely with EU Member States.  The strategy is based on 4 pillars: blue growth, connecting the region, environmental quality and sustainable and competitive tourism. Among the main priorities identified by the strategy: the development of the fisheries and aquaculture sector, the improvement of links with European corridors, the protection of the marine environment and biodiversity of the ecosystem, diversification of tourism provision and sustainable tourism management, the integration of the Western Balkans into the EU and coherence between the EU's macro-regional strategies.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the EUSAIR strategy offers the countries of the region an exceptional opportunity, namely to turn a page on the economic and political problems of the past, working together, under the leadership of the Commission, to pursue prosperity and sustainable development. I also fully agree with the rapporteur on the pillars adopted for the new strategy: blue growth (sea fishing, aquaculture, blue technologies, governance and maritime and marine services), the connection of the region (maritime transport, intermodal connections with the hinterland, energy networks), the quality of the environment (marine environment, transnational land habitats and biodiversity) and sustainable and competitive tourism (diversified tourism offer, sustainable and responsible tourism management). Finally, the overall objective of the programme is to act as a driving force for governance policies and innovation, by promoting European integration between the Member States and non-EU Member States, by using the rich natural, cultural and human resources of the Adriatic and the Ionian Sea and by strengthening economic, social and territorial cohesion in the programme area, a perfect strategy, in my view, for the European aims of cohesion and union. Of course, for territorial reasons I am more interested in the Alpine macro-region (EUSALP) but these attempts to agglomerate the regions to make policies more efficient are welcome.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has always championed national democracy and state cooperation, but we have always argued against EU overarching policies on any region, especially a region that includes non-EU members. In order to have an effective economic strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region, Member States should decide the best action for themselves through intergovernmental cooperation. Therefore we voted against this report.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP has always championed national democracy and state cooperation, but we have always argued against EU overarching policies on any region, especially a region that includes non-EU members. In order to have an effective economic strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region, Member States should decide the best action for themselves through intergovernmental cooperation. Therefore we voted against this report.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this important own-initiative report by Parliament, which aims to analyse the problem of the EU strategy for the 'Adriatic Ionian Region'. This initiative was launched in 2000 and established in 2006 and includes regional and local authorities from eight countries (Croatia, Greece, Italy, Slovenia, Albania, Montenegro, Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina), with 70 million people. The Ionian Adriatic Region and the Adriatic-Ionian Cooperation Programme 2014-2020 represent a great opportunity to promote integration and act as a driving force for the best use of natural, cultural and human resources, strengthening economic, social and territorial cohesion. The Juncker Commission has stated that there will be no further enlargement at this time. Therefore, the role that the Ionian Adriatic Region will play is even more important in preparing the best bases and conditions for making the countries of the Western Balkans ever closer to those of Europe.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In June 2014, the European Commission launched a new EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region. The strategy mainly concerns the opportunities of the maritime economy: "blue growth", land-sea transport, energy connectivity, protection of the marine environment and sustainable tourism. These sectors are set to play a crucial role in job creation and economic recovery in the region.  This is the EU's first macro-regional strategy involving such a high proportion of non-EU countries (Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro and Serbia) called upon to cooperate with EU member countries (Croatia, Greece, Italy and Slovenia).  However, important issues can be seen in two paragraphs (10 and 64). In the first, the Commission, the EIB and the participating countries are encouraged to make full use of the opportunities offered by EFSI with a view to financing projects in the region.
