In the second, it stresses the importance of joint investment planning for the development of liquefied natural gas (LNG) terminals and missing gas pipeline networks in the macro-region, so as to contribute to greater independence and energy security.  For these critical issues I have decided to abstain.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I believe that this report mixes positive and negative elements in the EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region. On the one hand, there is a commitment to support the economic development of these regions, with an impact on aspects such as sustainability or support for SMEs and traditional sectors such as tourism or fisheries.  On the other hand, the EU is endowed with a leading role in a region in which not even all States are members, imposing the adoption of the European acquis and favouring private investment in sectors as sensitive as energy or transport. As a result, I abstained.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Strategy for the Adriatic-Ionian Macroregion covers eight countries equally represented by EU Member States (Greece, Greece, Italy and Slovenia) and non-EU countries (Albania, Montenegro, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina). The region is home to more than 70 million people and plays a key role in strengthening Europe's geographical continuity. The Italian Government has played an essential role in promoting the strategy, which was approved during our six-month term. It is divided into four interdependent pillars of strategic importance, all equally functional to the objectives of sustainable growth: Blue Growth, Connecting the Region (Transport and Energy Networks), Environmental Quality and Sustainable Tourism. The "Connecting the Region" pillar was the one that created the most conflict. In committee, in the final compromise text, we included the completion of the Baltic-Adriatic corridor as one of the objectives. In plenary we managed to get one of our amendments through to add a specific mention to its completion 'along the entire Adriatic-Ionian ridge'. This is an important and, in many ways, unse hoped for result. It is now up to the governments to turn our initiative into concrete action, giving substance to a strategy which, we believe, has important potential that is still largely unexpressed.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Adriatic and Yin Sea region is home to more than 70 million people and covers eight countries, four of which are EU Member States, three candidate countries and Bosnia and Herzegovina as potential candidate countries. I voted in favour of this draft report in the plenary vote, as EUSAIR provides a good opportunity for the countries of the region to stimulate sustainable development. The pillars and other priorities of the strategy promote economic development and job creation, which contributes to the stability of the region.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The recent economic crisis has had a significant impact on the countries of the Adriatic-Ionian region, in particular the high unemployment rate, debt levels, insufficiency and inhibition of economic development and the decline in investment. The countries of the region have great potential, which is currently not being exploited. I voted in favour of the resolution because it creates legal instruments enabling the countries of the region to develop a common strategy and to act in a coordinated manner under the direction of the Commission and thus, in my opinion, gives them a unique opportunity for rapid and sustainable development and for the countries of the Western Balkans to move closer to the EU.  I believe that the implementation of the resolution's development strategy will benefit both EU Member States and third countries. The demands for skilful water management, harmonisation of rules in this area, cross-border cooperation, a common environmental policy, the construction of road and transmission infrastructure, the promotion of public-private partnerships should contribute to increased competitiveness, job creation and investment, including from foreign actors. The resolution stresses the importance of tourism for the countries of the region and encourages them to promote a diverse and competitive tourist offer. The implementation of this demand would also benefit Poles, including voters in my constituency, who often choose Italy and the Balkans as a place of their holiday.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report establishing an EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region which as a region faces a set of common challenges including socio-economic disparities between different countries and regions. I voted in favour of amendments that address the infrastructure deficits that exist and also the inadequate interconnection of electricity grids.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Representing the EU's third macro-regional strategy, EUSAIR includes 8 countries, Member States and non-eu members and totals more than 70 million inhabitants. The region has been affected over time by events with a major negative impact on the region.  We hope that such macro-regions will be models of good practice and success at European level, because they can benefit all their citizens and contribute to economic recovery and sustainable development by harmonising policies and reorienting investment. On the other hand, local and regional authorities are the main players in the area and only through effective collaboration and joint efforts can the strategy of the Adriatic and Ionian Sea stresses be a success.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The approval of the EU Strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Region (EUSAIR), in favour of which Italy played an essential role during the EU Presidency, is an important stage in the development of the countries in the region. More than 70 million citizens living in the Adriatic-Ionian area will have new opportunities for work, mobility, education and growth through political and administrative coordination, under the leadership of the Commission, which will also serve to turn the page on the economic and political problems faced in the past. The four pillars of the strategy concern the restructuring and extension of energy and transport infrastructure, with new interconnections with the TEN-T corridors; the development of a tourist and cultural offer which will serve to deseasonalise tourism; sustainable growth through the blue economy to overcome the economic crisis and to better protect the marine and coastal environment and, finally, greater cooperation between the countries of the macro-region that will allow common responses to emergencies such as immigration.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report proposes the European Parliament's support for the Eudria and Ionian region's (EUSAIR) strategy. It underlines the added value of this strategy, while recalling the importance of the "three no" principle (no new legislation, no new institution, no new funding) and draws attention to the added value of the multi-level governance model. The report also identifies several development priorities, namely blue growth, strengthening the region's interconnection, environmental quality, or sustainable and competitive tourism. The implementation of a macro-regional strategy is an interesting approach that needs to be supported. There is a need for effective governance and targeted priorities. The next macro-regional strategy to be implemented will be in place for the Alpine region. I fully support this initiative and have voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has always championed national democracy and state cooperation, but we have always argued against EU overarching policies on any region, especially a region that includes non-EU members. In order to have an effective economic strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region, Member States should decide the best action for themselves through intergovernmental cooperation. Therefore we voted against this report.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In December 2012, the European Council invited the Commission to present its vision for a new Adriatic and Ionian Strategy (EUSAIR) before the end of 2014 and, accordingly, on 17 June 2014 the Commission presented a draft strategy. EUSAIR is the third EU macro-regional strategy that can build on the experience of strategies for the Baltic Sea and Danube regions. The Adriatic and Yin Sea region is home to more than 70 million people and covers eight countries, four of which are EU Member States (Croatia, Greece, Italy, Slovenia), three candidate countries (Albania, Montenegro, Serbia) and Bosnia and Herzegovina as potential candidate countries. I voted in favour of this draft report in the plenary vote, as EUSAIR provides a good opportunity for the countries of the region to stimulate sustainable development. The pillars of the strategy ("blue growth", the development of infrastructure links in the region, environmental protection, sustainable, competitive tourism) and other priorities (EU integration of the Western Balkan countries, ensuring coherence between the three EU macro-regional strategies and national strategic projects) promote economic development and job creation. However, I think it is important to stress that for all macro-regional strategies, a comprehensive evaluation of the results is needed. It is necessary to ensure that the strategies have genuine European added value and that they have real, tangible positive effects in the region concerned.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – In December 2012, the European Council invited the Commission to present its vision for a new Adriatic and Ionian Strategy (EUSAIR) before the end of 2014 and, accordingly, on 17 June 2014 the Commission presented its draft strategy. EUSAIR is the third EU macro-regional strategy that can build on the experience of strategies for the Baltic Sea and Danube regions. The Adriatic and Yin Sea region is home to more than 70 million people and covers eight countries, four of which are EU Member States (Croatia, Greece, Italy, Slovenia), three candidate countries (Albania, Montenegro, Serbia) and Bosnia and Herzegovina as potential candidate countries. I voted in favour of this draft report in the plenary vote, as EUSAIR provides a good opportunity for the countries of the region to stimulate sustainable development. The pillars of the Strategy ("blue growth", the development of infrastructure links in the region, environmental protection, sustainable, competitive tourism) and other priorities (EU integration of the Western Balkan countries, ensuring coherence between the three EU macro-regional strategies and national strategic projects) promote economic development and job creation. However, I think it is important to stress that for all macro-regional strategies, a comprehensive evaluation of the results is needed. It is necessary to ensure that the strategies have genuine European added value and that they have real, tangible positive effects in the region concerned.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report was to take stock of the EU's strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Sea region (EUSAIR). It contained two main thrusts with regard to the strategy proposed by the European Union. By fostering interaction with local authorities in the countries concerned (both EU and third parties), it bypasses national governments and their sovereignty and gives too much power to communities. This is in line with the so-called macro-regional logic, which tends to go beyond The Member States to apply European policies to unclear geographical areas. By promoting the integration of third countries, which are involved and explicitly mentioned in this strategy, the European Union is going against the statements of the European Commission, which had repeatedly promised its opposition to further enlargements of the Union. Resolutely opposed to the loss of national sovereignty of the Member States and the enlargement of the European Union, I voted against this report.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. Despite the positive elements of the report, we are voting against it in its entirety because it contains generalities and ambiguities on serious issues. Strategies based on wishful meals and diversions are doomed to fail.  In order to develop the Adriatic and Ionian region, it is primarily necessary to define the EEZs of the countries concerned and to define targeted, funded and implementable actions to upgrade and improve the economic activity and social life of citizens.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In December 2012, the European Council invited the Commission to present its vision for a new Adriatic and Ionian Strategy (EUSAIR) before the end of 2014 and, accordingly, on 17 June 2014 the Commission presented a draft strategy. EUSAIR is the third EU macro-regional strategy that can build on the experience of strategies for the Baltic Sea and Danube regions. The Adriatic and Yin Sea region is home to more than 70 million people and covers eight countries, four of which are EU Member States (Croatia, Greece, Italy, Slovenia), three candidate countries (Albania, Montenegro, Serbia) and Bosnia and Herzegovina as potential candidate countries. I voted in favour of this draft report in the plenary vote, as EUSAIR provides a good opportunity for the countries of the region to stimulate sustainable development. The pillars of the strategy ("blue growth", the development of infrastructure links in the region, environmental protection, sustainable, competitive tourism) and other priorities (EU integration of the Western Balkan countries, ensuring coherence between the three EU macro-regional strategies and national strategic projects) promote economic development and job creation. However, I think it is important to stress that for all macro-regional strategies, a comprehensive evaluation of the results is needed. It is necessary to ensure that the strategies have genuine European added value and that they have real, tangible positive effects in the region concerned.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP has always championed national democracy and state cooperation, but we have always argued against EU overarching policies on any region, especially a region that includes non-EU members. In order to have an effective economic strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region, Member States should decide the best action for themselves through intergovernmental cooperation. Therefore we voted against this report.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. EUSAIR is the EU's third macro-regional strategy and is well placed to take advantage of the lessons and experiences of the EU Strategy for the Baltic Sea Region and the EU Strategy for the Danube Region. This strategy is based on existing cooperation in the region, notably the Adriatic-Ionian Initiative and the Adriatic-Ionian Eurorregion, whose members are made up of 26 regional and local authorities from seven countries.  EUSAIR covers eight countries also represented by EU Member States (Croatia, Greece, Italy and Slovenia) and third countries, all of which have candidate status (Albania, Montenegro and Serbia) or potential candidates (Bosnia and Herzegovina). The region has more than 70 million inhabitants and plays a key role in strengthening geographical continuity in Europe. EUSAIR is a unique opportunity for the countries of the region to turn a new page and leave behind economic and political problems, working together, guided by the Commission, towards prosperity and sustainable development.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because it includes plans to abandon national sovereignty.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report proposes the development of a macro-regional strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Region, in line with previous ones dedicated to other major regions or basins. References to the EU's macroeconomic policy framework are sparse, which in this case is positive, essentially proposing the enhancement of development factors in the region in an integrated and sustainable manner. The principles of the Blue Economy are valued, along with the promotion of sustainable fishing that values traditional segments; the protection of environmental quality and biodiversity is defended; sustainable and less seasonal tourism is advocated. The notion of macro-regions, involving EU countries and others outside this context, contributes to the acquisition of scale, which may benefit some development strategies. This framework and the scope of this territory, however, concern that strategic and cohesion investments, being absorbed by the macro-region, cannot be lacking, resulting in a lack of strategic and cohesion funding for the Member States concerned, i.e. to the detriment of the specific needs of each Member State.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour, as wording on immigration was added to the text.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the Adriatic and Ionian region faces a number of common challenges, from complex political and economic circumstances due to historical events to large social and economic differences between countries and regions located in the area. There is also the problem of completing the necessary infrastructure as well as connections for electrical cables. The ecosystem in this area is threatened and damaged by human intervention.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I vote against the report on the EU strategy for the Adriatic Sea and Ionian Sea region, as it includes call for a solution to migration in a way that favours the influx of more migrants.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Adriatic-Ionian region faces a common set of challenges, ranging from difficult political and economic circumstances, due to past historical events, to big socio-economic disparities between different countries and regions. Significant infrastructure deficits exist, and there is inadequate interconnection of electricity grids. Ecosystems are threatened by increased human exploitation of marine and coastal ecosystems. Natural and man-made hazards are apparent. Furthermore, administrative and institutional capacities at national, regional and local level need to be reinforced. I support the implementation of the EU strategy on Adriatic and Ionian region, as it is fundamental for blue growth, for connecting Europe, for environmental quality and sustainable and competitive tourism. We should focus on the weak pillars of this strategy and make sure that it provides a comprehensive framework for a coherent macro-regional strategy, as well as an action plan for cooperation between the participating EU and third countries.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report because there is huge potential in the Adriatic and Yin Sea regions, which can only be exploited through joint and coordinated efforts by all countries in the region, with the significant participation of local and regional authorities. The Commission should play a specific role by means of guidelines and support in the implementation of the strategy.  I welcome the priorities of prioritising adaptation to resource-efficient fishing and boosting the production and consumption of fishery products. Furthermore, the number of applied innovations in research and development and the maritime sector, as well as the strengthening of blue research, innovation and skills, require increased attention, together with investment, in human resources development.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the EU's third macro-regional strategy, bearing in mind that the region's past is marked by events that have had devastating and lasting effects on development and cooperation between the countries of this area. EUSAIR offers an exceptional opportunity for countries in the region to come to the page of their past economic and political problems working together, under the direction of the Commission. It is also important that the EU encourages the creation of a macroregion in the Western Mediterranean.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted strongly in favour of the EP resolution on the implementation of the EU Strategy for the Adriatic-Ionian Region (EUSAIR), because the strategy, although still in its infanic phase, is an instrument at the same time to promote development in the Adriatic-Ionian region, but also the integration of the countries of the Western Balkans. The strategy is not new, as it was prepared by the Commission in 2012 on the mandate of the European Council, and subsequently accompanied by an action plan and finally approved last December, nor does it provide for additional Community resources, since it will have to be based solely on those already available and provided for under cohesion policy. Nevertheless, at this stage, it is a very important instrument to help promote projects at Community and national level which are not currently among the priorities of the European and national intervention programmes. As the newly created management bodies are opening the debate on identifying the first projects that the participating States should actually commit themselves to financing by mobilising available resources. For Italy, this may mean the extension of the TEN corridors along the Adriatic ridge and therefore the extension of high-speed trains to Bari, giving concrete support to the development of the Mezzogiorno.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the European Union strategy for the Adriatic-Ionian region, as I welcome the EU's approach to this and believe that a strong, joint commitment is important.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Today I have worked to strengthen the Adriatic-Ionian region. This clear sign of European solidarity offers an opportunity to strengthen and develop this region in the long term.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Adriatic-Ionian region faces a set of common challenges which need to be addressed. This includes difficult political and economic circumstances due to past historical events and socio-economic disparities between different countries and regions. Ecosystems are threatened due to increased human exploitation of marine and coastal ecosystems. Furthermore, administrative and institutional capacities at national regional and local level must be reinforced. That is why I voted in favour of this report, which provides the platform for common actions and facilitates an exchange of information, best practice and experience. Importantly, it allows participating countries to learn from each other and to focus on a few key priorities that will bring real results and benefits to the everyday lives of the macro-regions’ citizens.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region, which represents an opportunity to make regions and countries work more closely together and to develop synergies in the fields of tourism, fisheries, environment and maritime transport. The implementation of such a strategy will also allow the implementation of joint projects within this macro-region funded by the EU and the European Investment Bank.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on a Eu-100 strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Sea region. This strategy for the Adriatic and the Ionian Sea covers eight countries, four of which are members of the Union (Croatia, Greece, Italy and Slovenia) and four are third countries (Albania, Montenegro, Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina). This report is a perfect example of the European Union's desire to create cross-border macro-regions in order to circumvent Member States. It is a question of weakening the power of central governments in favour of local authorities which are more malleable to the European institutions. In fact, the States concerned could quite deal with these issues in a multilateral manner.  Moreover, as one legislative train may hide another, it is clear that this type of strategy is also aimed at promoting future enlargements of the European Union. The report thus stresses, in several paragraphs, that it is part of a dimension of integration of candidate or potential candidate countries. However, any further enlargement would only strengthen the power of the European institutions at the expense of European states and peoples.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour as we did in committee, bearing in mind that much of our proposals were made as commitments. We understand that an EU strategy in the Adriatic and Ionian region is expressed in multi-level coordinates that sometimes forget specific spaces for action and green and blue policies for the region; that's not the case. We still understand that some of the parts of the dossier need to be more concrete; above all, those that serve sectors such as tourism, which have to be guaranteed in a sustainable way and which, we understand, require dossiers to the side.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with my fellow Labour MEPs, voted in favour of this report. Even though this report does not have an effect on the UK and macro-regional approach. The report is not about creating new institutions or new legislation; it provides the platform for common actions and facilitates, an exchange of information, best practice and experience. Importantly, it allows participating countries to learn from each other and to focus on a few key priorities that will bring real results and benefits to the everyday lives of the macro-regions’ citizens.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the report on an EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region, and I believe that the EU strategy for the region launched by the Commission in June 2014 is an opportunity for this macro-region to make regions and countries work more closely together and to develop synergies and joint projects financed by EU funds and the European Investment Bank.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In December 2012, the European Council invited the Commission to present its new vision for the Adriatic and Ionian Strategy (EUSAIR) before the end of 2014. Accordingly, on 17 June 2014, the Commission presented a draft strategy. EUSAIR is the third EU macro-regional strategy that can build on the experience of strategies for the Baltic Sea and Danube regions. The Adriatic and Yin Sea region is home to more than 70 million people and covers eight countries, four of which are already EU Member States (Croatia, Greece, Italy, Slovenia), three candidate countries (Albania, Montenegro, Serbia) and a potential candidate country (Bosnia and Herzegovina). I voted in favour of this draft report in the plenary vote, as EUSAIR provides a good opportunity for the countries of the region to stimulate sustainable development. The pillars of the strategy ("blue growth", the development of infrastructure links in the region, environmental protection, sustainable and competitive tourism) and other priorities (EU integration of the Western Balkan countries, ensuring coherence between the three EU macro-regional strategies and national strategic projects) promote economic development and job creation. However, I think it is important to stress that for all macro-regional strategies, a comprehensive evaluation of the results is needed. It is necessary to ensure that the strategies have a genuine European value and that they have real, tangible positive effects in the region concerned.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report because the region plays a key role in strengthening geographical continuity in Europe. The region’s turbulent past is marked by events which had devastating and long-lasting effects on development and cooperation between the countries. More recently, the economic crisis has had a major impact on the region. Unemployment and indebtedness are reaching unprecedented heights. The economic recovery and growth in the ailing economies are hampered by falling investments, both public and private.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has always championed national democracy and state cooperation but we have always argued against EU overarching policies on any region, especially a region that includes non-EU members. In order to have an effective economic strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region, Member States should decide the best action for themselves through intergovernmental cooperation. Therefore we voted against this report.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's report on the EU Strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region, as as chief rapporteur of the REGI Committee, together with other shadow rapporteurs, I am the summary of this very important document for me. As president of the Adriatic-Ionian Euroregion, I have actively worked on economic strengthening and stronger mutual integration and faster rapprochement of the entire region towards the EU.  Among other things, at the Adriatic-Ionian Euroregion assembly we reached a conclusion on the need to launch such an EU strategy back in 2009, while in 2010 our initiative was presented in the Committee of the Regions. It is therefore particularly important to me that our efforts last year were achieved by adopting the European Council decision to launch an EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region.  This document represents the uniform positions of most political groups in the European Parliament and represents a useful contribution primarily to the European Commission, but also to other European bodies towards the quality implementation of the Strategy.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This strategy for the Adriatic and the Ionian Sea covers eight countries, including four MEMBERS of the Union (Croatia, Greece, Italy, Slovenia) and four non-members (Albania, Montenegro, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina). This report is a perfect example of the European Union's desire to create cross-border macro-regions in order to circumvent the sovereignty of the Member States. The aim is to weaken the central powers in favour of local authorities, which are more malleable to the European institutions. In fact, the States concerned could quite deal with these issues multilaterally. Moreover, it is clear that this type of strategy also foreshadows the future enlargements of the Union. The report states, in several paragraphs, that it is part of a dimension of integration of candidate or potential candidate countries. However, any further enlargement would only strengthen the power of the European institutions at the expense of European states and peoples. I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP has always championed national democracy and state cooperation, but we have always argued against EU overarching policies on any region, especially a region that includes non-EU members. In order to have an effective economic strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region, Member States should decide the best action for themselves through intergovernmental cooperation. Therefore my fellow MEPs and I voted against this report.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Ivan JAKOV-I's report on the European Union's strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Sea region. The report highlights the added value of the strategy, while recalling the importance of the "three no" principle (no new legislation, no new institution, no new funding), since macro-regions are frameworks that must build on the synergies created by existing policies and funds. The report identifies with relevance several development priorities for the four pillars of the strategy, namely blue growth, interconnections, the environment and tourism.  The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report which supports the Commission's Communication on the new EU strategy for the Adriatic and the Ionian Sea, with blue growth, the environment and sustainable and competitive tourism in the area as priorities.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This report can be supported because it makes mostly sensible proposals for the development of the regions, particularly in environmental terms.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report, as the strategy will allow participating countries to learn from each other and to focus on a few key priorities that will bring real results and benefits to the everyday lives of the macro-region’s citizens.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the vote on this resolution we have helped to mark a new stage for the development of the Adriatic and Ionian region. Macro-regional strategies are an important instrument of integration and territorial cooperation; in this specific case, EUSAIR can also contribute and assist participating and potential candidate countries on their way to the European Union and constitute an important component of the EU's wider Mediterranean policy, expressed within the framework of the Union for the Mediterranean. As the whole region faces major migration challenges, we have called for the future redefinition of EUSAIR's priorities to focus on social and humanitarian issues affecting the whole region and to promote an exchange of good practice in the area of migrant reception.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The new strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region (EUSAIR) is part of the broader Juncker Commission project, which has decided to move towards reviving the European economy through the Investment Plan and the European Fund for Strategic Investments. I would like to point out that the European Parliament has approved the amendment concerning the completion of the Baltic-Adriatic corridor, which will allow the extension to the entire Adriatic-Ionian ridge from Ravenna to the south, linking maritime transport routes and ports with other parts of Europe.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. This Jakovcic report concerns the EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Sea region (EUSAIR) presented by the Commission in June 2014. It is a macro-regional strategy covering eight Member States (Croatia, Greece, Italy and Slovenia). Other third countries either have the status of candidate or potential candidate for EU membership. The problem with this strategy is that it directly targets local authorities by ignoring states. Moreover, it shows a hegemonic dimension of the EU that creates a specific policy for a few states when the problem should be dealt with bilaterally. Finally, the text promotes EU enlargement. I have therefore decided to vote against this text, which is yet another blow against the sovereignty of States.

name: Andrew Lewer (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ EU macro-regional strategies, based on deeper political and economic cooperation between a specific group of EU Member States and third countries, can provide real added value. British Conservatives felt able to support the Jakovčić report’s positive view of the EU’s third macro-regional strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region (EUSAIR) today, as a case in point. It provides an overall framework for greater intergovernmental policy coordination and a more effective business environment for companies and investors, and addresses gaps and practical difficulties that currently affect the single market. The EUSAIR will be implemented using the region’s existing EU and national funding and it therefore fits our guiding principles of no new EU funds, no additional EU-level structures and no new EU legislation. Where isolated paragraphs did give cause for concern, our Members made their objections clear through split, roll-called votes: notably on paragraph 23, relating to an integrated European approach to migration and a shift in national asylum policies; paragraph 68, in relation to alarmist language on onshore and offshore oil and gas exploration; and paragraph 84, which contained a proposal to establish a new regional centre for disaster preparedness, the added value of which was not clearly defined.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I believe that this report mixes positive and negative elements in the EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region. On the one hand, there is a commitment to support the economic development of these regions, with an impact on aspects such as sustainability or support for SMEs and traditional sectors such as tourism or fisheries.  On the other hand, the EU is endowed with a leading role in a region in which not even all States are members, imposing the adoption of the European acquis and favouring private investment in sectors as sensitive as energy or transport. As a result, I abstained.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The EU Strategy for the Adriatic-Ionian Region aims to ensure sustainable economic growth and development, environmental and energy sustainability and social and territorial cohesion. It is also important because of its impact on non-EU countries, which are part of the enlargement strategy and includes cooperation of all levels – European, national, regional and local.  The refugee crisis has shown shortcomings in the development of this region and the need for greater cohesion. The lack of communication between countries in the region and underdevelopment have certainly contributed to the chaotic situation we are currently in. The preconditions for implementing the strategy are strengthening the institutional capacity and efficiency of public administration, setting legislative frameworks and providing resources and qualified administrative staff dedicated to the implementation of EUSAIR. I supported the report on the EU Strategy for the Adriatic-Ionian Region and as a substitute member of the REGI Committee, and since I come from the region, I consider it important to highlight the need for the implementation of the Strategy and the development of this part of Europe since its potentials are untapped. In particular, I emphasise that the success of macro-regional strategies such as this depends on the will of countries in the region, timely project preparation and strong regional cooperation and coherence across all policies at all levels.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the strategy aims to harness the potential of the Adriatic-Ionian region, which has a population of 70 million. It builds on the four basic pillars under which development activities are proposed. The Objectives of European Territorial Cooperation establish a Adriatic-Ionian cooperation programme for 2014-2020, which includes cooperation between EU Member States (Croatia, Slovenia, Greece and Italy) and non-EU members (Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro and Serbia).  The strategy represents an important step in the integration of the Balkan countries and their accession to the EU.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on an EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Sea regions, because it is complete and documented and for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 27/10/2015.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against it. This report gives the European Parliament's opinion on the EU's strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Sea regions. This region covers eight countries, half of which are members of the EU (Croatia, Greece, Italy and Slovenia), three have the status of "candidate for accession" (Albania, Montenegro and Serbia) and one has the status of "potential candidate" (Bosnia and Herzegovina). We opposed this report for two reasons: first, because it promotes the enlargement of the Union, which we formally oppose. Secondly, because it addresses the Union's macro-regional strategy and involves cases that concern only a small group of EU countries: a European approach is therefore useless, mere bilateral agreements would suffice.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Through this report Parliament has responded to recent updates on the implementation of the Adriatic and Ionian region strategy. Although not directly affecting the UK, the report draws conclusions about best practice in regional development. I supported the report as the exchange of information at EU level is beneficial to all areas of regional development.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In favour of the report on an EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian regions. The Adriatic-Ionian Cooperation Programme 2014-2020 is a programme under the second objective of cohesion policy – European territorial cooperation comprising four EU Member States (Croatia, Greece, Italy and Slovenia) and four IPA countries (Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro and Serbia). The potential of the Adriatic and Ionian region is vast and can only be exploited through joint and coordinated efforts by all countries in the region, with the high participation of local and regional authorities. The overall objective of the programme is to act as a driving force for governance policies and innovation, encouraging European integration between Member States and non-EU Member States, using all natural, cultural and human resources of the Adriatic and Ionian, so that economic, social and territorial cohesion in the programme area can be strengthened.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Adriatic and Ionian region has been characterised by events that have had devastating effects on development and cooperation between countries. These are problems linked to the economic crisis, unemployment and indebtedness, with very high and unprecedented incidence rates. This has led to a sharp fall in investment, both public and private, which is hindering economic recovery. These circumstances explain my support for the proposal of the rapporteur, Mr Jakovcic, who trusts in the EUSAIR strategy presented by the Commission at the request of the European Council. The EUSAIR strategy aims to exploit the real economic potential of the Adriatic-Ionian region through the cooperation of the countries concerned and therefore not only local, but also national and international players.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. Both an early warning system, which is being set up to prevent natural or industrial, transport or other activities, such as floods, fires and raw material extraction activities in the Adriatic, and the improvement of transport infrastructure are important changes. The report makes mostly sensible environmental policy proposals for the development of the region. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. In 2014, the Committee proposed a third EU strategy for a macro-region: the Adriatic and Ionian region (EUSAIR). The proposal is based on existing cooperation in the region, mainly the Adriatic-Ionian Initiative, which began in 2000 with the signing of the Declaration of Ancona and the Adriatic-Ionian Euroregion created in 2006. EUSAIR covers 8 countries: 4 EU member states (Croatia, Greece, Italy, Slovenia) and 4 non-member countries (Albania Montenegro Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina). The report describes the characteristics of the macro region, the challenges and opportunities it faces, and calls for specific actions on blue growth, regional connection, environmental quality, sustainable and competitive tourism. But he argues for implementation through public-private partnerships. Artificial carving of such "macro-regions" in Europe also poses a democratic problem. That's why I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union's third macro-regional strategy is the European Union Strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Region. This region plays a crucial role in the European Union's geostrategic position, the potential of which can only be harnessed on the basis of the region's joint development efforts and participation. This is the definition of a set of priorities in order to achieve results that can benefit the whole region. I have, in this regard, voted in agreement with the strategy defined by the EU.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it stresses the need further to develop transport and energy connections among the participating countries as well as between them and their other neighbours. It is crucial that the network infrastructure gap in the Adriatic-Ionian area is addressed in order to increase the region’s socioeconomic development. The Union’s strategy and the funding allocated to the region should address these issues.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – The events following the break-up of Yugoslavia have left a devastating and long-lasting mortgage on economic development and cooperation between the countries in the Adriatic and Ionian regions. In recent years, this region has also been hit hard by the economic crisis. With its third macro-regional strategy, the EU has adopted a plan of action to ensure that these countries can leave their political and economic problems behind once and for all through targeted cooperation. As the area plays an important role in strengthening geographical continuity in Europe, strategic and smart investment is necessary for the whole region. At the same time, this region has enormous potential, which can only be exploited if all the countries in the region work together. The EU's strategic investment funds enable necessary investments to be made in energy networks between countries, the elimination of "missing links" in infrastructure, innovations in shipping and fishing and the development of the region's tourism assets. The Eusair also enables non-EU countries to cooperate with EU Member States.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Adriatic-Ionian region faces a common set of challenges, ranging from difficult political and economic circumstances, due to past historical events, to big socio-economic disparities between different countries and regions. The report in my opinion tries to find solutions to all these challenges and therefore contributes to all four pillars of the strategy (blue growth; connecting Europe; environmental quality and sustainable and competitive tourism).

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In December 2012, the European Council invited the Commission to present the European Union Strategy for the New Adriatic and Ionian Region (EUSAIR) by the end of 2014. The Commission presented EUSAIR on 17 June 2014. EUSAIR is the third EU macro-regional policy after EU strategies for the Baltic Sea region and the Danube Basin region. The strategy is based on cooperation within the region, in particular the Adriatic and Ionian Initiative launched in 2000 with the signing of the Ancona Declaration and the establishment in 2006 of the Adriatic and Ionian Euroregion, comprising 26 regional and local authorities from the seven member countries. EUSAIR covers eight countries and is home to more than 70 million people.  According to parliament's motion for a resolution tabled by Parliament's Committee on Regional Development, EUSAIR offers the region a unique opportunity to work together, under the Commission's guidance, to address past economic and political problems, seeking prosperity and sustainable development. It points out that there is huge potential in the region, which can only be exploited through joint and coordinated efforts by all the countries of the region, with the significant participation of local and regional authorities. It considers that EUSAIR will prove to be of historic importance for both the participating countries and the Union as a whole.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The creation of a European Union Strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Region has given rise to EUSAIR, a european union macro-regional strategy that plays a key role in the development of this region, representing a new model of multi-level governance.  Through cooperation between Member States and third countries in achieving common objectives, economic and social cohesion is promoted, reducing disparities between regions, stimulating employment and economic growth.  The establishment of several priorities for EUSAIR is based on important areas that will be developed in the future, which will contribute to economic and social growth in the region, namely blue growth, environmental quality and sustainable and competitive tourism. I am voting in favour of this report which will provide benefits for the entire Adriatic and Ionian Region, including for participating third countries which will be in political, social and economic harmony with the Member States.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This Jakovcic report concerns the EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Sea region (EUSAIR) presented by the Commission in June 2014. It is a macro-regional strategy covering eight Member States (Croatia, Greece, Italy and Slovenia). Other third countries have either candidate or potential candidate status for EU membership.  The problem with this strategy is that it directly targets local authorities, ignoring states. Moreover, it shows a hegemonic dimension of the Union, which creates a specific policy for a few States when the problem should be dealt with bilaterally. Finally, the text promotes the enlargement of the Union. I have therefore decided to vote against this text, which is yet another blow against the sovereignty of States.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which provides the platform for common actions and facilitates an exchange of information, best practice and experience. Importantly, it allows participating countries to learn from each other and to focus on a few key priorities that will bring real results and benefits to the everyday lives of the macro-regions’ citizens.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the European Union's strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region. This text recalls that the existing macro-regional strategy for the eight Baltic Sea border countries has been successful and has enabled Denmark, Germany, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Finland and Sweden to respond to several common challenges in the area (creating a sustainable environment , strengthening prosperity, improving accessibility and attractiveness and ensuring continued security). It underlines the success of these framework structures, which improve the articulation of the Union's various policies without resorting to new legislation, institutions or additional funding. This report identifies blue growth, interconnection of the region, environmental quality and sustainable tourism as development priorities for the Adriatic and Ionian region.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this report, which aims to emphasise the strategic importance of promoting the process of integration and enlargement, regional cooperation and good neighbourly relations at European level through the instruments and means of the EU Strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Region (EUSAIR).  We need to give new impetus to strengthening peace, social cohesion, economic development, environmental sustainability and security in south-eastern Europe. To this end, greater involvement of all stakeholders, including civil society, is essential.  EUSAIR should contribute to the process of accession to the European Union of the countries of the Western Balkans, providing them with the opportunity to cooperate closely with EU Member States and addressing common regional challenges. We therefore call on the countries of the Western Balkans to be fully and effectively involved in all stages of implementation, improving connectivity between them and with the rest of the European Union, including the Adriatic-Ionian corridor.  Finally, we call on the Commission to pursue maximum efficiency in the use of all available financing instruments, in order to maximise the impact, achieve better results and encourage sustainable economic growth in the region.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 One of the european Union's core ideas is to promote and support cross-border cooperation and cooperation. Macro regional cooperation is one of the most convincing forms of this. After two successful strategies for the Baltic Sea and Danube regions, it seems clear that this project will be expanded and further macro-regions will be created. The Adriatic and Ionian macro-regions, like the previous two, cover a single geographical region, which can clearly benefit from a single treatment. Countries that are involved in this cooperation can also have many positives, such as improving international relations, closer political cooperation and the specialisation of certain political and economic sectors. In the case of EUSAIR, this macro-regional cooperation can make a major contribution to the multilateral development of non-EU countries and to closer cooperation with the EU.  All four pillars of the strategy are essentially elaborated in detail and clearly cover areas specific to the region and necessary for development. However, in order to ensure that the whole project does not lose its meaning, it is necessary to prevent the emergence of an unnecessary bureaucratic system and, at the same time, to insist on the establishment and maintenance of multi-level governance based on the principle of subsidiarity in the macro-region, since local and regional actors can act most effectively on issues affecting the region and their cooperation with other higher institutions can be the basis for the effective functioning of the region.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Council of December 2012 invited the Commission to present a new EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region (EUSAIR) before the end of 2014. I voted for this report, which will implement EUSAIR, following the model of the EU strategy for the Baltic Sea region.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian regions because I believe it is a report which makes important additions to the Commission's proposal.  I have had the opportunity to be the rapporteur on this dossier in the Committee on Fisheries and I am familiar with the report written by colleagues in the Committee on Regional Development. I am pleased to note that the final report of the Committee on Regional Development also contains the suggestions made by me and my colleagues in the opinion report of the Committee on Fisheries, because the Adriatic and Ionian regions are a special case in terms of pollution and available marine resources. It is a complex strategy for many reasons, but I think the main reason is that it concerns both EU and non-Member States, which do not always have the same legislation or standards as ours.  I believe that this report complements the strategy proposed by the Commission in the key points, and I look forward to seeing the results it will produce.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This report proposes an EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region. In doing so, it describes the special characteristics of the Adriatic-Ionian macro-region and the difficulties and opportunities that it faces, and calls for specific action to be taken. However, the strategy put forward is based on the ‘three NOs’ principle – no new legislation, no new institutions, no new funding. The strategy can therefore use only the already existing EU financial resources and tools, and funding in this report is placed in the context of the Europe 2020 strategy with the strict conditions that entails. There are a number of other concerns with the report, such as support for contentious major projects, and a call to non-EU states to accelerate the implementation of sectoral acquis, such as the Water Framework Directive, as a condition of accession to the EU. Therefore, while there are positive aspects to the report, I abstained on this motion.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report on an EU strategy for the Adriatic Ionian Region calls for a sustainable use of marine resources in the region. These are the right approaches to promoting the region, especially from an environmental point of view and for economic recovery. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. I consider it important that all European countries have a perspective on EU membership. It is also important that these countries continue to work on the fight against corruption, the development of the rule of law and the guarantee of human rights.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D)
text: in writing. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of the report on the EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian regions because I believe that macro-regional strategies, based on cooperation, integration and coordination, are an important tool for achieving tangible results. Responding together with common challenges is key to overcoming socio-economic imbalances between neighbouring countries and strengthening territorial cohesion. The strategy could also bring important benefits to the candidate and potential candidate countries in the region. The Adriatic and Ionian macro-region needs a common and careful management because, by its very particular geographical conformation, it is more vulnerable to pollution and over-exploitation of fish stocks. The Commission communication stresses that this strategy does not require additional rules, institutions or funds that are in fact already provided by the Adriatic-Ionian Transnational Cooperation Programme 2014-2020 (ADRION).

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has always championed national democracy and state cooperation, but we have always argued against EU overarching policies on any region, especially a region that includes non-EU members. In order to have an effective economic strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region, Member States should decide the best action for themselves through intergovernmental cooperation. Therefore we voted against this report.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe it is essential to stress the geostrategic and geopolitical importance of the EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region. Following my personal and proven interest in this issue, However, I would like to highlight the lack of provision in the strategy for the completion of the Baltic-Adriatic corridor from Ravenna to Ancona-Pescara-Termoli-Foggia-Bari-Brindisi. For the full implementation of the strategy, to help the development of regions in crisis such as those in southern Italy and to fully exploit the potential of the area, I therefore hope that such a forecast can finally materialize. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. I support the EU Strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian regions, as I believe it will enable better cooperation between countries in the region in promoting the maritime sector, marine conservation, developing transport and energy networks and boosting tourism, thereby directly affecting the lives of the region's 70 million inhabitants.  The support and investment programme adopted by the Strategy can contribute to the development of the economy and thus the creation of new jobs in the countries of the region, and this is one of the biggest challenges for most of them. I welcome the idea of sustainable use and promotion of all natural beauties and riches that countries of that region have that are not recognized and/or whose capacities have not been fully exploited.  As far as Croatia is concerned, investing in achieving sustainable and quality tourism is certainly something positive and can guarantee a better future for Croatia. Also, since it is an integral part of the Mediterranean corridor and the route Rijeka-Zagreb-Budapest, and between these two parallel routes there is a link Zagreb-Slovenia, it is of utmost importance for the Republic of Croatia. It is a road and rail corridor through which Croatia will also be connected to the Baltic-Adriatic Corridor, which runs from the Baltic Sea through Poland, through Vienna and Bratislava to northern Italy.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This Jakovcic report concerns the EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Sea region (EUSAIR) presented by the Commission in June 2014. It is a macro-regional strategy covering eight Member States (Croatia, Greece, Italy and Slovenia). Other third countries either have the status of candidate or potential candidate for EU membership. The problem with this strategy is that it directly targets local authorities by ignoring states. Moreover, it shows a hegemonic dimension of the EU that creates a specific policy for a few states when the problem should be dealt with bilaterally. Finally, the text promotes EU enlargement. I have therefore decided to vote against this text, which is yet another blow against the sovereignty of States.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I strongly welcome and support the creation of a third European macro-regulation. For now, the Adriatic-Ionian strategy includes four Member States and four aspirant countries for full EU membership, where participation in such a project can and should certainly be assisted on their Euro-integration path. The current differences between countries are much larger than whether they are part of the EU or not.   Differences in economic development and macro-financial indicators are large. Transport infrastructure within some countries and among them is extremely poorly developed. For now, the project of building the Adriatic-Ionian motorway has encouraged Croatia, but we hope that soon the EU will also encourage this project, because Europe can not only connect politically, but also needs to develop transport routes, energy corridors and other relations. Due to its exceptional energy dependence, joint energy projects such as the Adriatic-Ionian pipeline should also be one of the priorities. I hope that the implementation of the strategy will include all interested stakeholders in a transparent and comprehensive way to foster social cohesion, economic development and environmental sustainability. If successful, the Adriatic-Ionian Strategy is of interest to all EU member states and has the capacity to contribute to further integration of the internal market and the stability of this area.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ This strategy is an important part of EU regional policy and will prove to be a quality mechanism of economic and social cohesion and boosting growth and jobs. Since the founding of the Adriatic-Ionian Initiative in Ancona in 2000, I have been intensively monitoring cooperation in the JJI Basin and the emergence of the Strategy adopted last year. As a result of the refugee-migration crisis, the Strategy should be placed in the broader context of Mediterranean cooperation.  In the current format with 4 EU member states and 4 aspirant countries on membership, the focus should be on jointly preparing projects financed by the European Structural and Investment Funds, in the areas of maritime affairs, culture, education, tourism, culture and environmental protection. These are the priority interests of all countries involved, and I believe kosovo and Macedonia will soon join this framework. It is important that there is constant communication and better cooperation between all actors at management, implementation and coordination level so that projects are prepared more quickly.  Local units and SMEs should be involved in the process of selecting and implementing projects. Croatia, as the only Danube and Adriatic country, has a great opportunity to upgrade its foreign policy, trade and development activities. The priority is better transport connectivity on the Adriatic-Ionian route, which refers to the construction of the road and rail network to the south, connections with the islands and completion of the construction of the Pelješac Bridge.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Macro-regional strategies can be seen as an instrument dedicated to promoting economic and social cohesion, the main objectives of which are to reduce disparities between regions, promote real convergence and encourage growth and employment. The adoption of an EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region (EUSAIR) is the result of the interest shown by the countries involved. The strategy covers four EU Member States (Croatia, Greece, Italy and Slovenia) and four IPA countries (Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro and Serbia). For the period 2014-2020, the total budget amounts to EUR 118,154,690, including the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) (EUR 83,467,729), the Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance (IPA II) (EUR 15,688,887 million) and national contributions (EUR 18,998,074). This is the EU's third macro-regional strategy and therefore can benefit from the experience and lessons learned from the Eu ropean Union Strategy for the Baltic Sea Region and the European Union Strategy for the Danube Region. I voted in favour of this report so that the strategy for the Ionian Adriatic region can represent a great opportunity for development.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "I am very pleased that the next region can take advantage of the opportunities offered by this innovative form of cooperation, which is the macro-regional strategy. This is the fourth strategy adopted by the Union in the last few years, the last of which covers the Mountain Region of the Alps. In this context, I would once again like to recall and call for priority to be given to mountainous regions in the European Union and, following in the footsteps of the Alpine region, to develop a macro-regional strategy for the Carpathians region, which requires intervention and increased involvement by the Union. The Carpathian regions have repeatedly demonstrated grassroots initiative and mobilisation in the interests of the entire macro-region. Now the ball is on the side of the Council and the Commission. I would like to remind you that macro-regional strategies of the Baltic and Danube are in contact on the Polish-Slovak border. Both treat the issue of mountain areas in a marginal way – and certainly do not treat the problems of the Carpathians in a comprehensive way. In this spirit, I support the efforts of other regions to establish macro-regional strategies.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has adopted a text on the implementation of an EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region. It is important to promote regional cooperation within the Union and to promote synergies, particularly in the areas of blue growth, transport, the environment and tourism. I voted in favour of this resolution. The text aims to promote existing cooperation frameworks and encourages macro-regions to frame and grow this strategy.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has always championed national democracy and state cooperation, but we have always argued against EU overarching policies on any region, especially a region that includes non-EU members. In order to have an effective economic strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region, Member States should decide the best action for themselves through intergovernmental cooperation. Therefore we voted against this report.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. In July, the European Commission presented the EU Strategy on the Adriatic and Ionian Region (EUSAIR), which establishes a third macroregion in the EU – after those of the Baltic Sea and the Danube – providing a coherent framework for regional macro-stress and a cooperation action plan between the EU and three other countries (eight in total). The Adriatic-Ionian region faces a number of common challenges, both because of the historical events of the past and by the large socio-economic disparities between different countries and regions. There are significant infrastructure deficits. Marine and coastal ecosystems are threatened by human exploitation. Administrative and institutional capacities at the national, regional and local levels should be strengthened, etc. The rapporteur seeks to find solutions to all these problems, contributing to the four pillars of the strategy (blue growth, connecting the region, quality of the environment and sustainable and competitive tourism).  That is why I voted in favour of this report, which finally incorporates the socialist claim to finish the Baltic-Adriatic corridor, including the extension of the Ionian-Adriatic ridge as a whole.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Today I voted in favour of the Jakovcic report on a Union strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Sea region. This vote is a way of welcoming the Commission's communication on the European Union's strategy for the aforementioned region.  First of all, it is important that this region focus on blue growth. It has a remarkable geographical position and a very rich marine biodiversity. These two factors have enormous potential for the creation of "blue" jobs. Secondly, there is a need to improve transport networks and the flow of energy between the countries participating in this macro-regional strategy but also between them and their other neighbours.  Finally, it is also important to preserve the quality of the environment in this region knowing that the Adriatic Sea is home to almost half of all marine species listed in the Mediterranean.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the request of the European Council in December 2012, the European Commission presented in June 2014 the "European Union (EU) Strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Region (EUSAIR)", on which this motion for a resolution is addressed. As the EU's third macro-regional strategy, following the adoption of the Baltic Sea Strategies (2009) and the Danube Region (2011), it seems to us that this new Macro-regional Strategy could draw valuable lessons from these two strategic platforms already in operation, specifically on their governance structures, implementation on the ground and even actions or events undertaken. Because these Strategies involving various regions (and Member States) do not aim to bring new levels of complexity to European policy or add administrative burdens to the current European framework, but rather to foster synergies, more efficient use of resources and more appropriate strategic planning, I draw attention to the need for strict compliance with the principle of the three nos: "not the new legislation , not to new institutions and not to more funding." Because this report is in line with my main ideas on this subject, I voted in favour.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Union's new strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Sea region was presented by the European Commission on 17 June 2014 and follows the European Council's December 2012 request to present a new strategy by the end of 2014.  I voted in favour of this report, which reminds us that macro-regions are frameworks for cooperation initiatives based on synergies that result from the articulation of the Union's various policies. In this sense, the "three no" principle must be respected, namely no new legislation, no new institution and no new funding.  At the same time, the report identifies several development priorities for the four pillars of the strategy: blue growth, interconnection of the region, environmental quality and sustainable and competitive tourism.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Union strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region as it aims to promote the economic recovery of this region. In order to create new jobs, the European Union strategy promotes the development of blue growth, energy networks and transport links, environmental quality and sustainable and competitive tourism.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour as I share the view that a new form of regional cooperation can benefit the areas concerned.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour as we did in committee, bearing in mind that much of our proposals were made as commitments. We understand that an EU strategy in the Adriatic and Ionian region is expressed in multi-level coordinates that sometimes forget specific spaces for action and green and blue policies for the region; that's not the case. We still understand that some of the parts of the dossier need to be more concrete; above all, those that serve sectors such as tourism, which have to be guaranteed in a sustainable way and which, we understand, require dossiers to the side.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I believe that this report mixes positive and negative elements in the EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region. On the one hand, there is a commitment to support the economic development of these regions, with an impact on aspects such as sustainability or support for SMEs and traditional sectors such as tourism or fisheries.  On the other hand, the EU is endowed with a leading role in a region in which not even all States are members, imposing the adoption of the European acquis and favouring private investment in sectors as sensitive as energy or transport. As a result, I abstained.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Adriatic-Ionian region faces a set of common challenges, starting with difficult political and economic circumstances due to past historical events. There is a great deficiency in the infrastructure of this region – including inter alia inadequate interconnection of electricity grids. Although there is some work to be done by the plenary in relation to repetitions and omissions, I am generally in favour in this report and I voted accordingly.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that the European Union strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region is important because of its strategic nature and for promoting sustainable economic growth, reducing social disparities in the region, improving transport connectivity, speeding up the integration of the Western Balkans into the EU and i could list.  However, at this time, as a Green MEP, I would focus in particular on the Environmental Quality Pillar, which is one of the four main pillars of this strategy. The Adriatic-Yland region is increasingly important for the EU's energy security. I would like to express my concern about the construction of energy infrastructure, oil and gas exploration, because the Adriatic and Ionian Seas are very sensitive.  For this reason, I believe that it is essential to respect EU law, especially at the environmental impact assessment stages. This is where a coordinated performance is needed in the protection of the sea and also in the protection of biodiversity. Despite the importance of joint energy policy planning and the achievement of the objective of meeting energy and gas needs, we must be careful not to put too much strain on the Adriatic and the Ionian Sea in the event of all these changes.  As this strategy is important for the development, better integration and progress of the region, I supported this report.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the EU Strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Regions (EUSAIR). This strategy is also based on the experience of the EU Strategy for the Danube Region. I support the combination of tourism and fishing in the regions concerned, the more efficient use of EU funds, the diversification of tourism products and offers that bridge seasonality.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. The EU Strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Region (EUSAIR), as part of EU regional policy, is a tool to foster economic and social cohesion, with its main objectives being to reduce disparities between regions, promote real convergence and boost growth and jobs. In this context, EUSAIR provides an exceptional opportunity for countries in the region to turn the page on past economic and political problems, together seeking progress and sustainable development. I supported the implementation of EUSAIR, primarily as I express my concern at the encouragement of offshore and offshore oil and gas exploration and exploitation, which could put the macro-regulation at risk of disasters with very serious consequences for the environment, the economy, including the fisheries sector and human health.  The Adriatic Sea, because it is semi-sealed, is subject to pollution, so I call for joint efforts to take all possible measures to preserve the biodiversity of the marine environment and transnational terrestrial habitats and to prevent and reduce pollution of the sea and other threats to coastal and marine biodiversity.  By acting together by Member States, not just those in the Adriatic and Ionian regions, we would create development benefits for the area, align inland areas, coastal areas and islands, and achieve synergies between clean energy projects and healthy food production.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Given the current security situation in Europe, it is more important than ever for the EU to work closely with the states in its immediate neighbourhood to address the EU's regional problems. In this respect, the European Union strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian regions will be very useful, which is why I supported this strategy with my vote. From the point of view of the security situation, this strategy is a key aspect of promoting the diversification of THE EU's energy resources. Russia's aggression against Europe's other sovereign states means that the EU cannot afford to rely on Russia as its main gas supplier. Russia regularly abuses the EU's dependence on its resources, blackmailing eastern EU states by raising prices and suspending supplies. It is therefore important, as part of the EUSAIR strategy, to support projects such as the Ionian-Adriatic gas pipeline, which will bring gas from sites in the Caucasus region through Turkey. This will not only reduce our dependence on Russia, but also increase cooperation with the Caucasus states, which are unprotected by NATO against Russia and thus need our support. EUSAIR can also serve as inspiration in the future for similar regional cooperation projects in risky areas such as the Caucasus and bring its countries closer to EU membership.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
