text: Written. ‒I supported this report because I think this strategy highlights in the truest sense the specific location of the region, the specific structure of the coastline as well as the rich marine diversity. I believe there is great potential to create "blue" jobs, boost economic development and growth, including fisheries, aquaculture and blue technologies.  Furthermore, I believe it encourages cluster grouping and cooperation between private and public companies, as well as universities and institutes. I also believe that it encourages shipbuilding and its modernization and specialization. For shipbuilding, this would mean job creation, and this field would also achieve sustainable and competitive growth in blue technologies. Furthermore, this strategy also focuses on connecting the region. He stresses that transport and energy links between the participating countries and their neighbours are essential in the macro-regional.  These networks would be the basis for the economic and social development of the region. This strategy also focuses on the conservation and quality of the environment, recalls the richness of marine, coastal and terrestrial ecosystems, and calls for the exchange of practices between participating countries with a view to managing natural and cultural heritage.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report concerning the EU Strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Region and the accompanying action plan. I believe that the strategy allows participating countries to learn from each other and to focus on a few key priorities which will bring real results and benefits to the lives of the macro-region’s citizens.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. The European Parliament adopted the European Union Strategy on the Adriatic-Ionian Region today. Special emphasis was placed in the document on the transport connectivity of states involved in road and rail infrastructure projects including the Adriatic-Ionian Corridor, and the document explicitly emphasises the importance of building the Pelješac bridge and connecting the EU territory, and thus the severed Croatian south. The strategy also covers the issue of migration, as migration is a new moment in this part of Europe, and this issue has not been addressed due to national egotism and a common European solution is being sought. Recall, the EU Strategy for the Adriatic-Ionian Macro-Region aims to enable the 70 million inhabitants of this macro-region (Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Croatia, Greece, Italy, Serbia, and Slovenia) to reap the benefits of closer cooperation in areas such as promoting the maritime economy, preserving the marine environment, completing transport and energy networks and fostering sustainable tourism.  I support this report and expect that the Strategy will come to life as soon as possible so that residents and these macro-regions enjoy the same treatment with other EU citizens when it comes to transport, energy, environmental protection and the stability and security of Southeast Europe.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the proposal as it does not bring any new administrative or budgetary burden, but uses only existing powers and budgetary resources to make their use more efficient.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region. The initiative brings together eight countries along the Adriatic and Yedician coasts. In addition to Slovenia, where I come from, they are Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Greece, Croatia, Italy and Serbia.  In 2012, Slovenia also chaired the aforementioned initiative for one year. I support the report, which welcomes the Commission's communication, which considers the initiative to be an important step in the development of this part of Europe. The basic idea of a macro-regional strategy is that better cooperation and coordination than individual initiatives are more useful in order to meet more effectively and effectively the specific challenges common to a particular cross-border area.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 This report concerns the third in a series of EU macro-regional strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian regions (EUSAIR). The report includes elements that further promote synergies for cooperation between participants and the economic empowerment of the countries of the region.  It is good that the report emphasises the principle of multi-level governance, calling on the Commission to strengthen the involvement and initiative of local authorities and communities, while urgently raising the issue of asylum policy for the regions directly affected. It is also good that it mentions the need for a single European asylum strategy. We voted in favour of the report because it supports a number of measures which are important for the social and economic development of the region, which is currently facing enormous territorial, economic and social problems.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Strategies based on wishful thoughts and diversions are doomed to fail. In order to develop the Adriatic and Ionian region, it is primarily necessary to define the EEZs of the countries concerned and to define targeted, funded and implementable actions to upgrade and improve the economic activity and social life of citizens.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In December 2012, the European Council invited the Commission to present its vision for a new Adriatic and Ionian Strategy (EUSAIR) before the end of 2014 and, accordingly, on 17 June 2014 the Commission presented a draft strategy. EUSAIR is the third EU macro-regional strategy that can build on the experience of strategies for the Baltic Sea and Danube regions. The Adriatic and Yin Sea region is home to more than 70 million people and covers eight countries, four of which are EU Member States (Croatia, Greece, Italy, Slovenia), three candidate countries (Albania, Montenegro, Serbia) and Bosnia and Herzegovina as potential candidate countries. I voted in favour of this draft report in the plenary vote, as EUSAIR provides a good opportunity for the countries of the region to stimulate sustainable development. The pillars of the strategy ("blue growth", the development of infrastructure links in the region, environmental protection, sustainable, competitive tourism) and other priorities (EU integration of the Western Balkan countries, ensuring coherence between the three EU macro-regional strategies and national strategic projects) promote economic development and job creation. However, I think it is important to stress that for all macro-regional strategies, a comprehensive evaluation of the results is needed. It is necessary to ensure that the strategies have genuine European added value and that they have real, tangible positive effects in the region concerned.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is a project in which Member States have put all their hopes when they have chosen to become part of this continental entity governed by rules and principles.  For the Member States of central and eastern Europe, the acquisition of this status has been synonymous with achieving a huge opportunity to develop and reach the socio-economic level existing in the west of the continent. EU cohesion policy is the guarantee of Community assistance to reduce development gaps between regions. This also applies to candidate countries in the Western Balkans. Croatia's accession in 2013 is clear proof that the EU is interested in this region.  However, in order to properly manage the development gaps with the other regions of the Union, a special strategy is needed for that area, embodied by the EU Strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Seas. That strategy will contribute to progress in identified priority areas, such as the interconnection of electricity networks, the protection of marine ecosystems, the increase of local administrative capacity or the development of sustainable tourism.  I think it would be useful to develop a similar strategy for the Black Sea region to take account of the development of the regions in this EU border area.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. Indeed, the strategy is timely for two reasons, which are due to the political changes that have taken place in the Union. First, the Juncker Commission decided to focus its policy on investments, through the investment plan and the resulting European Fund for Strategic Investments. The countries of the Adriatic and Ionian region therefore have a great opportunity to fill the investment gap they have experienced in recent years. The strategy opens up opportunities to guide these investments in order to achieve results for the benefit of the entire region.  Secondly, the Commission has repeatedly said that there will be no further enlargement in the near future. Although this is bad news for the countries of the Western Balkans, the strategy will enable them to move closer to the Union by aligning their policies and working closely with the Member States.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report that scrutinises the EU Strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Region (EUSAIR), introduced by the Commission on 17 June 2014. It is a third macro-regional EU strategy, together with the one for the Baltic Sea Region and for the Danube Region. The EUSAIR covers EU Member States (Croatia, Greece, Italy and Slovenia) and non-EU countries, all of which have either ‘candidate’ (Albania, Montenegro and Serbia) or ‘potential candidate’ membership status (Bosnia and Herzegovina). The aim of the strategy is to foster mutual cooperation among the countries and pursue their prosperity and sustainable development. The report sets out priorities in the fields of blue growth focusing on marine governance; regional interconnectedness, mainly in terms of transport and energy; quality of environment; and tourism.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome this report, because thanks to the strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian regions, development can be promoted in the Adriatic region and the integration of the countries of the Western Balkans can be promoted. The experience of existing macro-regional strategies shows that the quality and stability of governance mechanisms are crucial for the effective implementation of all programmes and initiatives. Better governance does not depend on new funds, but on how joint actions are initiated and financed. Governance must therefore have both a political and an operational dimension, with the full involvement of the ministries responsible and the implementing bodies responsible for defining strategic objectives and ensuring that the work is carried out efficiently and rigorously. Parliament's vote in favour of this strategy is part of the revitalisation of a Europe of solidarity ready to overcome differences and difficulties and to allow the development of areas of great cultural and environmental value. Full development, however, can also be achieved through an adequate transport infrastructure network, which is why I strongly supported the amendment that will allow the completion of the Adriatic-Ionian rail and motorway network to the south going beyond Ravenna.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on the EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region because I believe that the Commission, through the Investment Plan and the European Fund for Strategic Investments, will focus on strengthening investment, which represents a great opportunity for countries in the Adriatic and Ionian region to fill their lack of investment from previous years. EuSAIR is also an opportunity to focus these investments in a way that is beneficial to the whole region.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour as we did in committee, bearing in mind that much of our proposals were made as commitments. We understand that an EU strategy in the Adriatic and Ionian region is expressed in multi-level coordinates that sometimes forget specific spaces for action and green and blue policies for the region; that's not the case. We still understand that some of the parts of the dossier need to be more concrete; above all, those that serve sectors such as tourism, which have to be guaranteed in a sustainable way and which, we understand, require dossiers to the side.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The report poses two main problems: - It addresses the European Union's macro-regional strategy. By making local authorities the target of European policy, this report strengthens the regionalisation of Member States and weakens the power of national governments. Moreover, it is not useful to create a European policy if it concerns only a small number of States. These issues should therefore be dealt with bilaterally. This text reveals the hegemonic attitude of the Union and the Commission, which no longer treat Member States as sovereign countries but as provinces, dependent on the direction of European policy.  It promotes the enlargement of the European Union. In his report, Mr Jakov-i-IO pointed out that the Commission had repeatedly stated that there would be no further enlargement in the near future. However, he does not mind pointing out, in several paragraphs, a dimension of integration of the EUSAIR strategy.  I vote AGAINST this text.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The December 2012 European Council invited the Commission to present the European Union Strategy for the New Adriatic and Ionian Region (EUSAIR) by the end of 2014. The Commission duly complied with this request and presented EUSAIR on 17 June 2014. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour as we did in committee, bearing in mind that much of our proposals were made as commitments. We understand that an EU strategy in the Adriatic and Ionian region is expressed in multi-level coordinates that sometimes forget specific spaces for action and green and blue policies for the region; that's not the case. We still understand that some of the parts of the dossier need to be more concrete; above all, those that serve sectors such as tourism, which have to be guaranteed in a sustainable way and which, we understand, require dossiers to the side.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region (EUSAIR) because it will provide for more cooperation among the participating countries of the Adriatic and Ionian region, focusing on regional assets with the aim of preserving and developing them further.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on an EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region, which is based on the new EU Strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Region (EUSAIR). The EUSAIR covers eight countries equally represented by EU Member States (Croatia, Greece, Italy and Slovenia) and non-EU countries, all of which have either ‘candidate’ (Albania, Montenegro and Serbia) or ‘potential candidate’ membership status (Bosnia and Herzegovina). The region is home to more than 70 million people and plays a key role in strengthening geographical continuity in Europe, which also has a direct impact on my own country, Slovenia. With this strategy we can take advantage of the exceptional opportunity given to the countries in the region to turn a page on past economic and political problems by working together, with the Commission’s guidance, to pursue prosperity and sustainable development.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. In December 2012, the Council invited the Commission to present a strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region by the end of 2014. The Commission presented this proposal in June 2014. Based on this proposal, the report recognizes the added value of the strategy and identifies several development priorities for its four pillars: blue growth, region connectivity, environmental quality and sustainable and competitive tourism. We are talking about a report which has reached broad consensus in the Committee on Regional Development and which touches on very important issues for the region, so I think it is necessary to vote in favour of this report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I believe that this report mixes positive and negative elements in the EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region. On the one hand, there is a commitment to support the economic development of these regions, with an impact on aspects such as sustainability or support for SMEs and traditional sectors such as tourism or fisheries.  On the other hand, the EU is endowed with a leading role in a region in which not even all States are members, imposing the adoption of the European acquis and favouring private investment in sectors as sensitive as energy or transport. As a result, I abstained.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report values regional development factors that are integrated and sustainable. It values the principles of the Blue Economy and the promotion of sustainable fishing that values traditional means. It promotes the protection of environmental quality and biodiversity and advocates the establishment of sustainable tourism and less dependent on seasonality. The notion of macro-regions, involving EU countries and others outside this context, contributes to the acquisition of scale benefiting development. This framework and the scope of this territory, however, concern that strategic and cohesion investments, being absorbed by the macro-region, cannot be lacking, resulting in a lack of strategic and cohesion funding for the Member States concerned, i.e. to the detriment of the specific needs of each Member State.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Both an early warning system, which is being set up to prevent natural or industrial, transport or other activities, such as floods, fires and raw material extraction activities in the Adriatic, and the improvement of transport infrastructure are important changes. The report makes mostly sensible environmental policy proposals for the development of the region. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU strategy for the Adriatic-Ionian macro-region. The regions concerned face similar challenges, from lack of infrastructure to threats to the environment. These challenges can only be overcome through cross-border cooperation, the identification of best practices and the sharing of know-how.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. Unlike my group, I voted against the 'EU strategy for the Adriatic Ionian Region'. This report exceeds the powers of the European Parliament. It advocates the implementation of an overall framework for policy and territorial cooperation coordination. This is a clear violation of the principle of subsidiarity, and it is also the main reason why I voted against this report.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on a common European strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region. The individual countries of these regions share common cultural features as well as a common history, and it is therefore important that they cooperate with each other in all areas, be it the area of territorial, economic or political cooperation. The report identifies gaps and potential difficulties that may result in delays in meeting single market and environmental commitments. The report also looked at promoting so-called blue growth – that is, sea-related sectors, including sustainable fisheries, recreational activities and research.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 A Parliament resolution that is finally a staple in the Adriatic-Ionian Macroregion project. This is a very important territory in our Union, because it unites East and West and forms a great gateway for all those who escape war and suffering from Africa or the Middle East and seek salvation in Europe. It is also important because it also includes four states which are not currently members of the European Union but which wish to become part of the European Union and which are trying to leave behind years of civil wars in order to open up to policies of mutual development and cooperation with the aim of joining our Union. A very important project then for the communities overlooking the sea, which will value blue tourism, with the aim of extending the season in the direction of sports tourism aimed at young people but also at the elderly. Another important aspect is infrastructure: both maritime and energy infrastructure, with a plan for connections between the two shores of the Adriatic and the production of energy from renewable sources. It is also a good thing that a new fisheries management plan has been planned.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is quite positive, valuing the development factors of the region that are integrated and sustainable. Values the principles of the Blue Economy and the promotion of sustainable fishing that values traditional means; promotes the protection of environmental quality and biodiversity as a fact; sustainable and less seasonal tourism. The notion of macro-regions, involving EU countries and others outside this context, contributes to the acquisition of scale, which benefits development. We voted for it.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. The report addresses the maritime economy sectors: 'blue growth', land-sea transport, energy connectivity, protection of the marine environment and sustainable tourism. This is the EU's first macro-regional strategy involving non-EU countries such as Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro and Serbia, which are called upon to cooperate with EU member countries (Croatia, Greece, Italy and Slovenia). The report stresses the importance of the 'three-way principle': no to new rules, no to new institutions and no to new funds.  Although some of our proposals to promote the economic development of the area have passed, focusing on its environmental and tourist peculiarities rather than on the oil industry, I abstained in the vote because important issues remained, especially in two paragraphs of the text. In one of the financing possibilities made available for the development of projects in the Adriatic and Ionian regions, Italy presented the general restructuring of ilva. In the other, joint investment planning for the development of liquefied natural gas (LNG) terminals and trans-Adriatic pipeline (TAP) networks is planned, which can have serious environmental consequences.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy is directly anchored in the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. The report presented by Fernanda Ruas is the first report provided by the European Parliament on the mid-term review of the strategy, with a particular focus on cohesion policy. Indeed, the European Commission is currently engaged in the review of the mid-term strategy. The Commission is encouraged to continue a dialogue that rewards territorial cooperation more at different levels, also in order to identify indicators that better reveal the progress made in achieving the objectives of the strategy within the framework of reference programming. The call is to strengthen the involvement of regional and local authorities, as well as the participation of civil society, so that public investment can be better directed according to the actual needs of the territories. In addition to the interesting ideas provided, the report touches not lastly on the sensitive issue of broadening the process of economic governance. However, the main problem is the treatment of the relationship between cohesion policy and the new European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI- so-called Juncker Plan). That is also why I abstained in the vote.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report is based on the 2014 European Commission Communication on the balance sheet of the Europe 2020 Strategy, which set out five main targets for 2020 in employment, research and development, polluting emissions, school failure and poverty reduction. To achieve this, so-called economic governance has been promoted and implemented through country-specific recommendations that have brought disastrous consequences for the population. Parliament's report regrets that the key role of cohesion policy has not been mentioned in this Communication; calls for the inclusion of indicators other than GDP to measure progress; taking into account rural areas, areas affected by industrial transition, etc.; calls for greater involvement of Parliament in policy oversight, etc. However, it is serious that cohesion policy incompatibility with the European Strategic Investment Fund (Juncker plan) is not observed. In addition, it calls for more attention from public-private partnerships, covert sources of privatization, more expensive for the public age and less efficient. Finally, there is once again no criticism of the European Semester's austericide policies with cohesion policy. That's why I've decided to abstain.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which considers that the Europe 2020 strategy and cohesion policy would contribute to economic development through job creation or increased investment. Indeed, this text does not add any added value to the debate on the review of the Europe 2020 strategy and the willingness of the European institutions to weaken the Member States by strengthening the power of local authorities is clearly underlined here.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This is the first European Parliament report on the mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy, focusing on the cohesion policy dimension of the strategy. It examines the progress already achieved, the scope of the review and the challenges to be addressed from a cohesion policy perspective. The report makes some criticism of the results of the Europe 2020 strategy to date and as well as several positive references.  However, cohesion policy is presented as a policy at the service of Europe 2020 and it connects cohesion policy with the EU Economic Governance framework and its implementation mechanism, the ‘European Semester’. Moreover, the report links the allocation and effectiveness of structural and investment to ‘sound economic governance’ – so-called ‘macro-economic conditionalities’ – by the Member States, and therefore to austerity politics. I therefore abstained on this report.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, as I consider cohesion policy to be a key point in the fulfilment of the EU 2020 strategy. The report highlights the importance of governance at many levels, the monitoring and evaluation of the strategy, the reception of information from NGOs and the need for the EU 2020 targets to be adapted to the reality and needs of each region.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This text praises the Europe 2020 strategy, which would contribute to economic development and job creation in Europe, without ever addressing the shortcomings of this strategy.  Beyond the fact that the results are well below the expectations expected, there is still in this report the desire to reduce the role of states for the benefit of local communities.  I also note that none of the amendments tabled by my colleague during the committee's work have been adopted. However, these amendments would have strengthened the principle of subsidiarity, made a balance sheet to optimise funds or reduced the delay in launching investments based on structural funds. I therefore voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Cohesion policy in the European Union has consistently failed and should not be further supported. Member states should be the ones to subsidise their own regions, where necessary.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution. Cohesion policy is an integral part of this very important strategy aimed at boosting growth and jobs under Europe 2020. Reducing the disparities between the regions will help less-developed European countries to catch up with the standards of the European economy and help to achieve such overarching goals as the digital single market, the energy union and the single capital market.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal by which the EP presents its position on EU cohesion policy and the forthcoming mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy. Cohesion policy accounts for more than a third of the EU budget and is the EU's main investment instrument. This report is the european Parliament's first report on the mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy, which focuses on the cohesion policy dimension of this strategy. I agree with the need for a timely and comprehensive debate on the future EU cohesion policy after 2020 and its alignment with the revised future long-term EU strategy and the new MFF.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report makes concrete proposals for the revision of cohesion policy and the EU 2020 strategy, assesses their current functioning and identifies future challenges. It also underlines the importance of a close relationship between the two: the EU 2020 serves as a strategic framework for the development and programming of the European Structural and Investment Funds for the period 2014-2020. In some parts of the report, it highlights elements of the strategy and cohesion policy and makes recommendations, criticisms and proposals to the Commission, in part to provide clues to the Commission's review of the EU 2020 strategy before the end of 2015.  Although there are positive ideas in the report (positive emphasis on the role of cohesion policy as one of the most important investment instruments, encouraging multi-level governance involving local and regional authorities), I did not support its adoption. Cohesion policy is the most important tool for overcoming differences between regions. As peripheral countries, we would be more fortunate if the EU sought to remedy the problems of the region by adapting cohesion policy instruments as much as possible to certain regional needs. Instead, it aligns cohesion policy with the purple misty EU 2020 'imperial' targets.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Cohesion policy has been ineffective in several Member States due to the draconian financial burden placed on Member States by the ECB and the IMF. Due to the report neglecting to mention that this had a larger impact on Member States’ growth than cohesion policy itself we voted against the report.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I approved this resolution which underlines the importance of cohesion policy for many Member States, particularly in the area of investment in times of crisis, in the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy. It is intended to be a comprehensive strategy for sustainable growth and jobs and is based on the key objectives of employment, innovation, climate change and energy sustainability, education and the fight against poverty and social exclusion. At the same time, the resolution also stresses that these goals are likely to be boosted by advances in gender equality.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on cohesion policy and the review of the Europe 2020 strategy extols the merits of the Europe 2020 strategy, which would contribute to the economic development of EU countries through increased investment and employment. Unfortunately, it is impossible for me to know what data allow the rapporteur to reach such a conclusion when we know the lack of investment and employment in the EU compared to the other major regional groups in the world...  Of course, he welcomes the Strategic Investment Fund, which is struggling to get started and whose leverage is greatly overestimated. This report, which was supposed to focus on the review of the Europe 2020 strategy, actually gives only satisfactions to EU policy, and leaves room for limbo when it comes to addressing reform proposals. So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although too "Euro-enthusiastic" references are present in this own-initiative report, I believe that it is balanced and dwells on concepts that I have always considered fundamental, such as investments more targeted towards the support of our citizens, revision of the 2020 strategy, the importance of macro-regional policies and the always taking into account the different territorial specificities, for all these reasons I supported it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. This report focuses on the progress made in view of the mid-term review of the Europe 2020 Strategy at the end of 2015. Cohesion policy is a key instrument for achieving the 2020 Strategy, being closely aligned with its objectives of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. However, due to the crisis, European funding became the only source of public funding in many Member States and regions. The report hopes that synergies between the various European funds will improve, while drawing attention to the need to use the objectives of the 2020 Strategy for each region and to better adapt to their different needs. It also underlines the need for a strategic debate on future cohesion policy, bearing in mind that the new cohesion policy legislative package will come in 2018-2019, along with the 2019 European elections. The review of the EU strategy after 2020 should also be aligned with the new Multiannual Financial Framework. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it presents Parliament's position on the EU Cohesion Policy and the upcoming mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy. Cohesion policy is the EU's main investment and development policy, which is aligned with the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. Today, the EU continues to face the effects of the economic and financial crisis, with high unemployment and uneven and slow economic recovery. This policy aims to reduce regional disparities and promote convergence and amount eur 351.8 billion by the end of 2020. The budget of EUR 100 million shall be Unfortunately, it has to be acknowledged that progress at EU level towards their objectives, such as combating unemployment, remains limited. Stresses that the EU should pay more attention to sustainable growth and development, as well as to creating decent jobs, so that its investments bring long-term benefits. Parliament noted the still necessary to address the challenges of further coordination and synchronisation of member states' fiscal policies and structural reforms by better aligning national budgetary policies with EU and national objectives relating to economic growth and job creation, thereby supporting the implementation of the strategy.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 I support this report. The current cohesion policy is closely aligned with the objectives of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth in the Europe 2020 strategy. This report focuses on progress made by 2015, as cohesion policy is the main instrument for delivering the Europe 2020 strategy. Therefore, in order to see the real state of the Europe 2020 strategy, it is proposed, inter alia, to use the tailor-made Europe 2020 targets for each region, in order to better adapt to reality, e.g. the financial and economic crisis.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This is the first European Parliament report on the mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy, focusing on the cohesion policy dimension of the strategy. It examines the progress already achieved, the scope of the review and the challenges to be addressed from a cohesion policy perspective. The report makes some criticism of the results of the Europe 2020 strategy to date and as well as several positive references.  However, cohesion policy is presented as a policy at the service of Europe 2020 and it connects cohesion policy with the EU Economic Governance framework and its implementation mechanism, the ‘European Semester’. Moreover, the report links the allocation and effectiveness of structural and investment to ‘sound economic governance’ – so-called ‘macro-economic conditionalities’ – by the Member States, and therefore to austerity politics. I therefore abstained on this report.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution on cohesion policy and the review of the Europe 2020 strategy because I believe that cohesion policy and Europe 2020 can be two extremely important instruments for restarting our continent's economy and that they have not been properly exploited. I therefore believe that they need to be reviewed in order to ensure greater effectiveness and an even greater impact on the economies of the Member States.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Eu ropean Union's cohesion policy is an important part of the EU budget (around 1/3) and is the Community's main investment. The smart, sustainable and inclusive growth outlined in the Europe 2020 strategy is the guide for cohesion policy and must continue to be so. The European Parliament can only call for governance that is multi-level and truly territorial for investment funds. The objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy must be identified, evaluated and then monitored in a mixed approach (top-down and vice versa) defining them tailored to each region, taking into account the territorial and socio-economic specificities of the various regions of Europe. Crucial, in order to avoid indirect territorial discrimination, is the adaptation of regional objectives for each area covered by cohesion policy, with particular attention to technical support and quantitative analysis and evaluation of the projects financed. The promotion of the sense of belonging and the contitolarity of the Europe 2020 strategy by local and regional authorities, Member States and stakeholders, thereby increasing the visibility, importance and effectiveness of the strategy in its territorial application.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report considers that the Europe 2020 strategy and cohesion policy would contribute to economic development and job creation. It calls for strengthening the power of local authorities at the expense of Member States. Like national governments, local authorities would have the opportunity to participate in the negotiations in the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy.  I have tabled 11 amendments on this text. They aim to strengthen the principle of subsidiarity and to underline that cohesion policy is ineffective and has little impact on economic development and in the fight against social exclusion. None of them have been adopted.  This text brings no added value to the debate on the review of the Europe 2020 strategy. The pompous and technocratic terms used in this report do not mask the sidereal void of their proposals. Finally, I cannot stand in sufficient way with the european institutions' desire to weaken the Member States in order to better impose on the peoples their globalist and communitarian vision. So I voted against this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy require a detailed analysis in the interim review process so that their achievement takes full account of the reality on the ground. We take into account the fact that some changes have taken place during the implementation of cohesion policy, due to the new global challenges we face and which influence the objectives of the strategy. The ambitious targets set out in the 2020 Strategy must contain concrete and easy-to-achieve objectives, and in order to achieve the desired outcome, measures are required such as: increasing the accountability and participation of partners, by improving transparency and involving authorities at several levels in the process of developing, implementing and evaluating the strategy.  Unsatisfactory results on the ground reveal that lack of administrative capacity causes serious delays in the implementation of the objectives set. The establishment of the Structural Reform Assistance Service is a key impetus for many Member States facing failures in the implementation process.  I voted for this report because the operative role of the support instrument aims to improve the spending of EU funds by providing technical assistance to Member States for a more effective implementation of structural reforms, taking into account the country-specific recommendations.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. This own-initiative resolution merely paints a picture of the relationship between cohesion policy (one third of the EU budget) and the EU 2020 strategy. Despite the fact that there are too many 'euro-enthusiastic' references, the report is balanced and often highlights many concepts dear to me: more targeted investments, proper review of the 2020 strategy, action at macro-regional level, and take account of different territorial specificities.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on cohesion policy and the revision of the Europe 2020 strategy, as cohesion policy is the key instrument for the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy. It is the EU's main investment, growth and development policy, set in line with the Europe 2020 objectives for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, which aims to reduce disparities between regions and promote convergence. I must mention that, after the 2008 crisis, cohesion policy became the only financial resource for development policy in some Member States or regions. This demonstrates that, thanks to cohesion policy, some investments have continued, despite the drastic decline in public funding.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Cohesion policy is paramount for the European Union. It is through this policy that structural funds are distributed. Structural funds directly benefit European citizens. They enable them to set up their projects and establish a certain level of equality between the different regions of the Member States. Cohesion policy is a sign of solidarity between Member States. The Europe 2020 strategy highlights the objectives of the Intelligent, Sustainable and Inclusive Growth Union. Europe 2020 provides the European Union with a structure to ensure that European legislation and policies are used to achieve these common objectives. As part of the cohesion policy, the Europe 2020 strategy has made it possible to better calibrate the management of funds. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This is the first European Parliament report on the mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy, focusing on the cohesion policy dimension of the strategy. It examines the progress already achieved, the scope of the review and the challenges to be addressed from a cohesion policy perspective. The report makes some criticism of the results of the Europe 2020 strategy to date and as well as several positive references.  However, cohesion policy is presented as a policy at the service of Europe 2020 and it connects cohesion policy with the EU Economic Governance framework and its implementation mechanism, the ‘European Semester’. Moreover, the report links the allocation and effectiveness of structural and investment to ‘sound economic governance’ – so-called ‘macro-economic conditionalities’ – by the Member States, and therefore to austerity politics. I therefore abstained on this report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Cohesion policy has been ineffective in several Member States due to the draconian financial burden placed on Member States by the ECB and the IMF. Due to the report neglecting to mention that this had a larger impact on Member States’ growth than cohesion policy itself we voted against the report.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The mid-term review is an important milestone to take stock of the goals that Europe 2020 was meant to deliver. The public consultation which took place last year showed that there is scope and a need to improve the delivery of the strategy through enhanced ownership and involvement on the ground. I voted in favour of the report as I believe that the mid-term review will offer a unique opportunity to give the strategy a new energy boost that will help us to reach our objectives.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report deals with cohesion policy in connection with the smart, sustainable and inclusive growth goals set out in the Europe 2020 strategy. The Commission is in fact working on the mid-term review of the strategy, which is likely to be presented at the end of 2015. The report contains interesting elements, particularly with regard to analytical indicators and a different dialectic between territorial levels. There is also a problem of negotiating timing, which would require an early definition of programming. The critical issues in the report relate to the reference to linking cohesion policy – and the 2020 strategy – to a broader process of economic governance, through measures that link the effectiveness of EIS funds to good economic governance; in one paragraph, the Member States are openly invited to act in a 'fully responsible' manner in order to prevent specific interventions. There are also multiple references to coordination and synergy between cohesion policy and EFSI. For these reasons, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The report welcomes the establishment of a task force to better implement EU funds. It welcomes the creation of the "Structural Reform Support Service", which officially began its work on 1 July 2015 and will provide technical assistance to Member States for the more effective implementation of structural reforms and country-specific recommendations.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution. Cohesion policy is one of the key instruments for implementing the Europe 2020 strategy. It continues to contribute positively and substantially to achieving the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. The proposal identifies four priorities: (a) to implement greater synergies between cohesion policy and the Europe 2020 strategy with the specific aim of increasing the quantity, quality and impact of investments in research and innovation through coordinated use of cohesion policy instruments; (b) to create a greater interconnection between the European Fund for Strategic Investments and the Structural Funds for European Investments; (c) adopt enhanced multi-level governance so that local, regional and other civil society actors are better involved in the Europe 2020 strategy and (d) improve the territorial approach of the Europe 2020 strategy so that the direct effects of this policy are greater and more felt at local level. Finally, there is an explicit call for the EP to be involved in all major discussions on the planning, implementation and evaluation of the strategy in good time.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as cohesion policy is the EU's main method of investment, growth and development, in line with the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, which aims to reduce regional disparities and promote convergence. I also want all energies and capacities to be mobilised and geared towards the pursuit of the Objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy on sustainable growth and employment. The aims of cohesion policy have evolved over time to support investment in the EU's main priorities, demonstrating its adaptability and effectiveness, while maintaining as a central objective the reduction of disparities between the levels of development of the various regions, strengthening regional potential and promoting sustainable development. On the other side, the review of the Europe 2020 strategy should take into account the serious and unequal effects that the economic and financial crisis has had on Member States and regions. Finally, I would like to stress the need for a truly territorial approach to the Europe 2020 strategy in order to adapt public interventions and investments to the different specific territorial characteristics and needs. I believe it is really important to link the overall approach of the Europe 2020 strategy with the territorial approach of the 2020 Territorial Agenda.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Cohesion policy has been ineffective in several Member States due to the draconian financial burden placed on Member States by the ECB and the IMF. Due to the report neglecting to mention that this had a larger impact on Member States’ growth than cohesion policy itself we voted against the report.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Cohesion policy has been ineffective in several Member States due to the draconian financial burden placed on Member States by the ECB and the IMF. Due to the report neglecting to mention that this had a larger impact on Member States’ growth than cohesion policy itself we voted against the report.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy is responsible for more than a third of the EU budget as well as the main investment, growth and development policy, in line with the Objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy for Smart, Sustainable and Inclusive Growth. It aims to reduce regional disparities and promote convergence. Therefore, given the importance of this instrument, I can only fully support what Mr Ruas has proposed, namely that it is necessary: to increase the quality, quantity and impact of investment in R&I; to encourage the interconnection and coordination of EIS Funds with other Union instruments and policies; strengthen multi-level governance, taking into account the appropriate peculiarities and differences between the different regions.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy is closely aligned with the objectives set out in the Europe 2020 strategy. FSI funds for the period 2014-2020 are linked to the Europe 2020 strategy. The Ruas report on the mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy, based on a cohesion policy of this strategy, urges the Commission and the Member States to commit themselves to greater cooperation in the development of inclusive indicators to supplement GDP, so as to be able to have greater traceability of progress made, increase the size of responsibility, ownership and transparency also through the involvement of local authorities , civil society and all interested parties. The report also emphasises the need for a territorial approach, the problem of timing of negotiations. I am abstaining pending new possibilities for debate which may lead to more clarification on linking measures linking the effectiveness of EIS funds to good economic governance.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report is based on the 2014 European Commission Communication on the balance sheet of the Europe 2020 Strategy, which set out five main targets for 2020 in employment, research and development, polluting emissions, school failure and poverty reduction. To achieve this, so-called economic governance has been promoted and implemented through country-specific recommendations that have brought disastrous consequences for the population. Parliament's report regrets that the key role of cohesion policy has not been mentioned in this Communication; calls for the inclusion of indicators other than GDP to measure progress; taking into account rural areas, areas affected by industrial transition, etc.; calls for greater involvement of Parliament in policy oversight, etc. However, it is serious that cohesion policy incompatibility with the European Strategic Investment Fund (Juncker plan) is not observed. In addition, it calls for more attention from public-private partnerships, covert sources of privatization, more expensive for the public age and less efficient. Finally, there is once again no criticism of the European Semester's austericide policies with cohesion policy. That's why I've decided to abstain.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report approved is part of the debate on the future of cohesion policy. Indeed, it has become the key instrument for implementing the Europe 2020 strategy. In addition, due to the economic crisis, ESI funds have become the only source of public funding in many states and regions. These two elements must not, however, in any way make us forget that the objective of the Structural Funds is, first and foremost, European economic and territorial cohesion. In this sense, to recover some of the functionality of the funds, it was important to emphasize that one of the problems is the real implementation of multi-level governance and a bottom-up approach. The objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy need to be redefined tailor-made for each region, in order to better adapt to the reality of a variety of areas with different needs. Furthermore, there is still a need for a strategic political debate on the future of cohesion policy, bearing in mind that the new legislative package will arrive between 2018-2019, and the European Parliament elections will be in 2019. The two revisions will have to be aligned, also together with the new multiannual financial framework. It is only by marching through all the strategies that the Union's objectives can best be achieved.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Cohesion policy is an essential instrument for deepening European integration, achieving m.in. by reducing economic, social and territorial dissees in all REGIONS of the EU. The current eu growth and development targets are largely expressed in the Europe 2020 strategy. The resolution voted on is a de facto report on the mid-term review of this strategy, drawn up by the European Parliament's Committee on Regional Development, of which I am a member. The main conclusions and demands of the resolution concern the need for Member States to be involved in the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy and to link the activities of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) to it, while defining their subsidiarity towards cohesion policy, in particular the inability to change the financial allocations to Member States agreed under Heading 1b of the 2014-2020 MFF in response to the potential needs of the Fund. It also underlines the importance of EU investment policy for regional and national development and called for more work to be done on the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy due to the delay in current programming. I believe that the adoption of the resolution will have a positive impact on the effective implementation of cohesion policy and the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy and will set out the lines of work of other EU bodies in this regard.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report focuses on the progress achieved so far in view of the mid-term review of the strategy foreseen for the end of 2015. The report deals with the effect that the recent economic, social and financial crisis has had on this process. Another issue highlighted in this report is the importance of multi-level governance and the existence of an effective mixed top-down/bottom—up approach in Member States. This includes – throughout all governance layers – defining, implementing, monitoring and evaluating the strategy application, feedback from NGOs and other interested stakeholders. The report calls for a necessity to use tailor-made EU 2020 targets for each region, to better adapt to the reality of a variety of regions with different needs. While I fully support the 2020 targets and strategy I also believe that this reports highlights very realistic issues that we need to address in reaching these goals, hence I supported it in plenary.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In this period of economic crisis, the only source of investment for many Union states has been and remains cohesion policy. It represents considerable support for EU states for the implementation of the 2020 strategy.  However, we must not forget that an important role in overseeing the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy and cohesion policy lies with the European Parliament, which is why I consider it beneficial for the legislative forum to be involved in the evaluation of the policies included in the strategy, as well as in the monitoring process, in order to identify cases of combining funding granted by various existing European funds.  On the other hand, there is a need for a consistent and continuous evaluation process, allowing for a regular analysis of the progress made towards the Europe 2020 targets, as well as the launch ingethrough of appropriate proposals to achieve the objectives, where appropriate, as well as recommendations for the cohesion policy after 2020. It must remain one of the EU's main investment instruments for economic growth, job creation and climate protection, while ensuring balanced and harmonious development across the EU as a catalyst for change and an incentive for prosperity.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report expresses the European Parliament's position on the mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy, which is at the heart of cohesion policy. As an instrument of investment and solidarity, the Union's cohesion policy contributes to the implementation of the objectives of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth set out in the Europe 2020 strategy. Aiming for a better interconnection between the five objectives of the strategy, the rapporteur reiterates the importance of multi-level governance, in order to include as many actors as possible at all stages of the project. Considering that a better synergy between the various development programmes, including rural development, and European funding is needed, I voted in favour of the report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Cohesion policy has been ineffective in several Member States due to the draconian financial burden placed on Member States by the ECB and the IMF. Due to the report neglecting to mention that this had a larger impact on Member States’ growth than cohesion policy itself we voted against the report.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on cohesion policy and the revision of the Europe 2020 strategy at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg. The report underlines the crucial role of cohesion policy in achieving the Europe 2020 objectives.  Cohesion policy is the only EU policy contributing to all three objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, through its 11 thematic objectives, which are in line with the five main objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. The role of cohesion policy in the 2008 crisis, in particular its continued capacity to finance investments in the face of a strong reduction in public funding, reinforces the long-term importance of the policy and demonstrates its resilience to external influences.  Given that the implementation of the programmes for the 2014-2020 cycle has barely begun, it would not be effective if either this year's revision of the Europe 2020 strategy or the MFF next year brought about substantial changes in cohesion policy.  I agree with the reporter that the mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy should be limited and focus on possible ways of better implementation without further increasing the administrative burden.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of the report on cohesion policy and the revision of the Europe 2020 strategy at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg. The report underlines the crucial role of cohesion policy in achieving the Europe 2020 objectives. Cohesion policy is the only EU policy contributing to all three objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, through its 11 thematic objectives, which are in line with the five main objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. The role of cohesion policy in the 2008 crisis, in particular its continued capacity to finance investments in the face of a strong reduction in public funding, reinforces the long-term importance of the policy and demonstrates its resilience to external influences.  Given that the implementation of the programmes for the 2014-2020 cycle has barely begun, it would not be effective if either this year's revision of the Europe 2020 strategy or the MFF next year brought about substantial changes in cohesion policy.  I agree with the reporter that the mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy should be limited and focus on possible ways of better implementation without further increasing the administrative burden.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This mid-term review report takes stock of the 'Europe 2020' strategy, and although it has many biases, no corrections are proposed. By putting the European Commission, member states and local authorities on an equal footing, this strategy blurs institutional legitimacy and demeans nation-states. While this report should instead take into account the need to strengthen the principle of subsidiarity and to note the ineffectiveness of such strategies both economically and socially, it makes only an unwelcome praise. Attached to the principle of subsidiarity, to the proper management of European funds, as well as to the cessation of inefficient and costly integration policies, I objected to this report.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The Europe 2020 strategy and its interconnection with cohesion policy have been shown, both by the Cohesion Report and by the serious and unequal consequences of the financial crisis in the Member States, to have failed in the ambitious objectives set. The fact is that the Treaty of Lisbon and the Europe 2020 governance have lost the support of the Member States over time. This, combined with austerity policy and serious socio-economic problems as a result of the crisis, have led a large part of EU citizens to Euroscepticism. The review of cohesion policy has lost momentum. The implemented reform policies imposed through the structural reform support service providing technical assistance to Member States and country-specific recommendations (troika and technical steps in Greece) are destroying any attempt at sustainable development.  The effort to revive investment and to revive the investment gap in the EU through the EFSI on the one hand is not clearly linked to the Europe 2020 strategy, on the other hand it does not complement the existing ESI Funds. The report underlines the crucial role of cohesion policy in achieving the Europe 2020 objectives. I agree with the reporter that the mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy should be limited and focus on possible ways of better implementation without further increasing the administrative burden.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Cohesion policy has been ineffective in several Member States due to the draconian financial burden placed on Member States by the ECB and the IMF. Due to the report neglecting to mention that this had a larger impact on Member States’ growth than cohesion policy itself we voted against the report.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. Cohesion policy accounts for more than one third of the EU budget and is its main investment instrument. Therefore, since cohesion policy 2014-2020 is fully aligned with the achievement of the objectives of the strategy and contributes to it, it is very important to examine the progress already made, the scope of the review and the challenges that need to be addressed from the point of view of cohesion policy. The Europe 20-20 strategy is a comprehensive long-term "growth and jobs" strategy built on five objectives: employment, innovation, climate change and energy sustainability, education and the fight against poverty and social exclusion. The review of this strategy, which will precede the presentation of the proposal for a mid-term review of the Multiannual Financial Framework for 2014-2020, will provide the basis for the future cohesion policy architecture after 2020.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because the report brings no added value to the debate.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report, on several points, is quite clear on what it wants: the reconciliation of cohesion policies within the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework with the achievement of the objectives of the EU2020 strategy - understood as being in line with cohesion in the EU. It therefore advocates ex ante constraints and links country-specific recommendations to the programming of funds. In other words, it defends one of the worst aspects of the current cohesion policy – its submission to a neoliberal agenda, the withdrawal of rights and the weakening of the state and its social functions, privatisation, which is the EU2020 strategy. That is, the submission to an agenda that is itself a generator of divergence and not of cohesion. The objectives of the EU2020, markedly indented for example at the social level, have a federalist framework and an artificial and bureaucratic definition, leading to the reduction of cohesion in the sociological and territorial context. In conjunction with cohesion policies, the European Structural Investment Funds and the Multiannual Financial Frameworks, is making these conditional on the EU's macro objectives and not on the specific development needs of the Member States. Obviously, we can only vote against it.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained because of the Macroeconomic conditionalities contained within the report.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy is a key tool for meeting the objectives of the EU 2020 strategy. Unfortunately, however, it is suffering as a result of the economic and economic crisis. The revised Europe 2020 strategy should be strengthened in its governance, using different layers of multi-level governance according to the partnership principle. The importance of having an effective top-down/bottom-up mixed approach in Member States under multi-level governance should be stressed. This includes earmarking, implementing, monitoring and evaluating the implementation of the EU 2020 strategy through multi-level governance agreements, by involving local and regional authorities, other civil society actors and stakeholders. There must also be an improvement in multi-level governance in order to achieve the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy more uniformly and effectively, not only at Member State level, but also at European level.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The Europe 2020 strategy and its interconnection with cohesion policy have been demonstrated, both by the Cohesion Report and by the serious and unequal consequences of the financial crisis in the Member States, for having failed in the ambitious objectives set. The fact is that the Treaty of Lisbon and the Europe 2020 governance have lost the support of the Member States over time. This, combined with austerity policy and serious socio-economic problems as a result of the crisis, have led a large part of EU citizens to Euroscepticism. The review of cohesion policy has lost momentum. The implemented reform policies imposed, through the structural reform support service providing technical assistance to Member States and country-specific recommendations (troika and technical steps in Greece), are destroying any attempt at sustainable development. The effort to revive investment and to revive the investment gap in the EU through the EFSI, on the one hand, is not clearly linked to the Europe 2020 strategy, on the other hand, it does not complement existing ESI Funds. We therefore need a comprehensive redefinition of the Europe 2020 strategy and not just a review. For all the above reasons I am voting against the report on cohesion policy and the revision of the EU 2020 strategy.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ To achieve its objective of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth for Europe, the 2020 strategy correctly relies on five headline targets: employment; research and development; climate and energy; education; and the fight against poverty and social exclusion, translated by each Member State into national targets. Halfway to the 2020 deadline, however, the delivery of the jobs and growth objectives is still mixed, and much more needs to be done in order to achieve these goals, especially on the social aspects of the strategy. I believe that if the Union wants to make progress with regard to the social and employment targets laid down in the Europe 2020 strategy, the Commission should come forward with an ambitious social agenda and complement the European Monetary Union with a strong social dimension.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the reporter's position in the light of the fact that cohesion policy is a key instrument for the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy. It will continue to make a positive and significant contribution to achieving the Europe 2020 goals of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. During the previous programming period 2007-2013, cohesion policy contributed to the achievement of the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, as shown by the results of the Sixth Report on Economic, Social and Territorial Cohesion. Furthermore, cohesion policy is the main financial instrument for the EU's contribution to the EU's 2020 objectives. I still consider it important, in the context of multi-level governance, to adopt a real territorial approach to the Europe 2020 strategy, and stresses, in this regard, the need to align the regional objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy with the specificities of each region. We must also take into account the fact that different regions have different realities and specificities, and thus set themselves different development goals within the Member States, and quality analysis and evaluation are needed. When the objectives of different regions within a Member State are the same, the implementation of the strategy can have asymmetrical results. In agreement with the rapporteur, I believe that specific objectives tailored to a given region can solve this problem.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of cohesion policy as more than a third of the EU budget and is its main investment instrument. Given the scale of the changes the EU has made as a result of the crisis, it is necessary to establish the best way to develop the Europe 2020 Strategy over the next five years.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. Although the Europe 2020 strategy has uncontestably encountered a series of delays compared to the planned action diary, I hope that a mid-term review of its plans could prove to be a useful tool for designing future lines, capable of giving new life and perspective to the initial vision. I therefore agree in particular with the examination of the success and acceleration that could provide a multi-level restructuring of the governance of the strategy, thanks to a higher involvement of local, regional and civil society actors, allowing the objectives to be 'tailored' according to the target territories, in order to achieve results adapted to their specificity, deploring the possible risk of asymmetric results resulting from fragmented and independent objectives.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP own-initiative report on cohesion policy and the review of the EU 2020 strategy, because I believe it is very important for the EP to make known to the Commission in good time its position on the mid-term review of the EU 2020 strategy, expected by the end of 2015. Cohesion policy and the EU 2020 strategy are closely linked, so much so that cohesion policy is closely aligned with the objectives of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth underlying the EU 2020 strategy, through the eleven thematic objectives of the common regulatory provisions. Cohesion policy through its funds is the key instrument for waiting for the objectives of the EU 2020 strategy, but the continuation of the economic and social crisis has proved to be the only source of funding in many Member States and regions. There is therefore an urgent need for a link between the Cohesion Funds (ESI) and EFSI, as well as the effective complementarity and additionality between the two sources of investment in the coming years, in order to emerge from the crisis and promote sustainable growth and quality employment. I therefore agree that the review takes account of the specific characteristics of the regions and that it uses appropriate targets.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on cohesion policy and the review of the Europe 2020 strategy, as I have already accompanied this issue as shadow rapporteur in the Social Committee. I would like to stress the importance of demographic factors. These must be taken into account far more than before in the strategy.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Cohesion policy is a crucial part of the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy. This is the only way to achieve the objectives of more growth and employment. That is why I voted in favour of aligning the existing cohesion policy with the EU's growth targets. In the future, therefore, the focus will be more on practical work and will be held up less by cumbersome procedural regulations.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which includes important measures to boost quality jobs and growth, including in the UK. The future EU budget provides a significant contribution to job creation through the European Social Fund (ESF) and the European Regional Development Fund. At least EUR 70 billion will be available under the ESF for this, complementing national action in this field. The new COSME programme will furthermore provide EUR 2.3 billion in support to SMEs to foster their competitiveness and boost growth and jobs in Europe.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: In writing. This report recalls the progress made since the launch of the Europe 2020 strategy, of which cohesion policy is one of the pillars. The resolution proposes a balanced review for the revision of the Europe 2020 strategy by the end of the year, in order to meet the European objectives on employment, innovation, education and sustainable development in the next five years. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on cohesion policy and the review of the Europe 2020 strategy. This report is the panegyric of the Europe 2020 strategy which would contribute to economic development and job creation in Europe. It focuses only on the positive aspects of the strategy in pompous and technocratic terms, without masking the emptiness of the report's proposals. In addition to the fact that the results do not live up to expectations, there is once again in this report the desire to reduce the role of states for the benefit of local communities. Divide to rule better. I would also note that none of the amendments tabled by my colleague Steeve Briois during the committee's work in the Regions committee have been adopted, whereas these amendments would have strengthened the principle of subsidiarity, drawn up a balance sheet to optimise the allocation of funds or reduced the delay in launching investments based on structural funds.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained in the report on cohesion policy and the revision of the Europe 2020 Strategy. We understand that the Union's medium-term policies, and especially those with broad budget items, require broad consensus and need to go in line with eliminating the abosmal differences between development and quality of life in different areas of the Union. We can only be entirely in favour of the reports on this subject when inequalities are the political a priori constituting the approach to medium-term strategies.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my S&D colleagues, I voted in favour of this report. This report will have an impact on the UK and people looking for work in the North West, and Britain as a whole. It will allow jobseekers support from the future EU budget, which provides a significant contribution to job creation through the European Social Fund (ESF) and the European Regional Development Fund. At least EUR 70 billion (i.e. about 10 billion per year) will be available under the ESF for this, complementing national action in this field.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. It proposes a balanced review of the Europe 2020 strategy in order to better link the five objectives of the strategy and assess their implementation without creating additional levels of complexity and excessive administrative burden. Employment and growth will not be achieved by adding such burdens, so we must be very vigilant. I am therefore pleased that the European Parliament is involved in the debates aimed at defining the policies covered by this strategy, their implementation and evaluation.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the cohesion policy and a review of the Europe 2020 strategy because cohesion policy accounts for over one third of the EU budget and is the EU’s main investment instrument. It is closely aligned with the objectives of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth set out in the Europe 2020 strategy.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on cohesion policy and the revision of the Europe 2020 strategy at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg. The report underlines the crucial role of cohesion policy in achieving the Europe 2020 objectives. Cohesion policy is the only EU policy contributing to all three objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, through its 11 thematic objectives, which are in line with the five main objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy.
