The role of cohesion policy in the 2008 crisis, in particular its continued capacity to finance investments in the face of a strong reduction in public funding, reinforces the long-term importance of the policy and demonstrates its resilience to external influences.  Given that the implementation of the programmes for the 2014-2020 cycle has barely begun, it would not be effective if either this year's revision of the Europe 2020 strategy or the MFF next year brought about substantial changes in cohesion policy.  I agree with the reporter that the mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy should be limited and focus on possible ways of better implementation without further increasing the administrative burden.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I decided to support this report due to the fact that cohesion policy, as the main EU investment instrument and as an expression of European solidarity, is closely aligned with the objectives of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth set out in the Europe 2020 Strategy. It should be noted that after the 2008 crisis, due to the lack of national public funding, cohesion policy became the only financial resource for growth policy in some Member States or regions. This shows that, due to the cohesion policy, some investments continued, despite a huge decrease in public funding. It confirms the long term importance of this policy and its resistance to different external economic factors.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Cohesion policy has been ineffective in several Member States due to the draconian financial burden placed on Member States by the ECB and the IMF. Due to the report neglecting to mention that this had a larger impact on Member States’ growth than cohesion policy itself we voted against the report.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the revision of the Europe 2020 Strategy, as the situation in the EU in recent years and the analysis of its implementation unalternatively demonstrate the need to do so. I am not a supporter of its "reform", as there are also proposals. I believe that the European Union needs to concentrate its growth efforts.  The Europe 2020 strategy allows for this. It is encouraging that some of the goals in it seem achievable at this stage. However, it is necessary to focus on the other objectives by revising the seven flagship initiatives to stimulate progress on each of the priority topics. We must step up our efforts so as not to repeat the mistakes of the Lisbon Strategy, but to strengthen citizens' trust in the path we follow.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the proposal for an EU Parliament resolution on cohesion policy and a review of the Europe 2020 strategy, as the revision of the Europe 2020 strategy should take into account the serious and unequal effects of the economic and financial crisis on Member States and regions; given that this document calls on the Commission to provide information on the focus of cohesion policy on results and its concrete contribution to the achievement of the Objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy as part of the subsequent evaluation of the 2007-2013 programming period; points to the fact that at the time of the mid-term review during the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy, data on the application of the ESI Funds for the period 2014-2020 may still be missing, as there are delays in the implementation of cohesion policy during the current programming period and implementation remains at a very early stage even though most operational programmes have been agreed.  Furthermore, it regrets that cohesion policy is insufficiently mentioned in the strategy review process by publishing a communication entitled 'Europe 2020 Progress Check for Smart, Sustainable and Inclusive Growth'; calls for the scope of the mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy to be smartly determined and balanced and aimed at better interconnecting the five objectives of the strategy and its flagship initiatives.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This text praises the Europe 2020 strategy, which would contribute to economic development and job creation in Europe... This text focuses only on the positive aspects of the Europe 2020 strategy, obscuring its shortcomings... Beyond the fact that the results are well below the expectations expected, there is still in this report the desire to reduce the role of states for the benefit of local communities.  I also note that none of the amendments tabled by my colleague Steeve Briois during the committee's work have been adopted. However, these amendments would have strengthened the principle of subsidiarity, made a balance sheet to optimise funds or reduced the delay in launching investments based on structural funds. I voted against this report.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Cohesion policy has been ineffective in several Member States due to the draconian financial burden placed on Member States by the ECB and the IMF. Due to the report neglecting to mention that this had a larger impact on Member States’ growth than cohesion policy itself we voted against the report.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Experience shows that the Europe 2020 strategy and cohesion policy are very often side by side, although they should be very closely interlinked. This is best demonstrated by the fact that the rules on programming or reporting under cohesion policy do not provide for mechanisms for the flagship initiatives of the strategy and the contribution of the European Funds to their implementation. The European Commission, on the other hand, does not sufficiently address cohesion policy in its review of the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy. Employment and social policy areas undoubtedly suffer from this, as the objectives of creating quality jobs and combating social exclusion present in the strategy are not sufficiently achieved through cohesion policy.  Of course, it is to be pleased that the amounts allocated to these objectives are higher in the current programming period than in the previous one. However, this increase is insufficient given the problems faced by most Member States. It seems that the fundamental problem of not interscholing these two areas is that they are prepared and implemented at other times. I therefore welcomed the report by Fernando Ruas on cohesion policy and the review of the Europe 2020 strategy, which points to the opportunity offered by the medium-term reviews of cohesion policy and the Europe 2020 strategy, and to the need for an even stronger link between the two areas.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Fernando Ruas' report on the review of the Europe 2020 strategy from the point of view of cohesion policy. Cohesion policy is indeed the European Union's main investment instrument and closely corresponds to the objectives of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth set out in the Europe 2020 strategy. The Ruas report proposes a balanced and intelligent review of the strategy without creating additional levels of complexity, which is an essential condition for me. It focuses on multi-level governance, recommends, if necessary, the setting of optional regional targets and reminds us of the importance of involving the European Parliament. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to push the European Commission to a balanced review of the cohesion policy of the Europe 2020 strategy. In particular, the report stresses that cohesion policy is an essential element of European solidarity and that, as such, multi-level governance, involving both local actors and the European Parliament, must be developed.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I do not agree with this report. It makes little criticism of the real shortcomings of cohesion policy.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have backed this report as it is essential for investment growth and job creation throughout the EU. To help EU citizens, at least EUR 70 billion will go towards job creation, and to help small to medium-sized enterprises EUR 2.3 billion will be allocated to them.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. – Europe 2020 is a long-term strategy built around five objectives: employment, innovation, climate change and energy sustainability. Cohesion policy is the EU's main instrument, extended to all regions, for investment in the real economy and is the very expression of European solidarity. There is therefore a need to strengthen governance regarding the Europe 2020 strategy, through the use of multi-level governance, involving local and regional authorities, as well as other civil society actors and stakeholders. On the basis of this, I have decided to support the Ruas report, as giving these actors greater ownership will certainly help to achieve the objectives set.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. This Ruas report concerns cohesion policy and the review of the Europe 2020 strategy. This text extols the merits of this Europe 2020 strategy, which would contribute to the economic development of the EU countries by increasing investment and employment. I do not know what data allow the rapporteur to reach such a conclusion, when we know the union's lack of investment and employment compared to the other major regional groups in the world... Of course, he welcomes the European Fund for Strategic Investments, which is struggling to get started and whose leverage is greatly overestimated.  This report, which was supposed to focus on the review of the Europe 2020 strategy, gives only satisfactions to EU policy and leaves room for limbo when it comes to addressing reform proposals. So I voted against it.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report is based on the 2014 European Commission Communication on the balance sheet of the Europe 2020 Strategy, which set out five main targets for 2020 in employment, research and development, polluting emissions, school failure and poverty reduction. To achieve this, so-called economic governance has been promoted and implemented through country-specific recommendations that have brought disastrous consequences for the population. Parliament's report regrets that the key role of cohesion policy has not been mentioned in this Communication; calls for the inclusion of indicators other than GDP to measure progress; taking into account rural areas, areas affected by industrial transition, etc.; calls for greater involvement of Parliament in policy oversight, etc. However, it is serious that cohesion policy incompatibility with the European Strategic Investment Fund (Juncker plan) is not observed. In addition, it calls for more attention from public-private partnerships, covert sources of privatization, more expensive for the public age and less efficient. Finally, there is once again no criticism of the European Semester's austericide policies with cohesion policy. That's why I've decided to abstain.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The purpose of the report is to highlight the importance and link between cohesion policy and the Europe 2020 Strategy. The implementation of cohesion policy contributes to meeting the objectives defined in the Europe 2020 Strategy. If we revise the Strategy, it is also important to develop new mechanisms within the policy. I supported the report because it underlines the importance and opportunity provided by cohesion policy, encourages its correct use and the compatibility of Member States with cohesion policy principles and instruments. The data show that the implementation of cohesion policy is the correct path towards the recovery of the real economy and regional cooperation, so I am sorry that Croatia did not take advantage of its opportunities.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 European regional policy, also often referred to as cohesion policy, is one of the largest components of the European Union's annual budgets: only the common agricultural policy is usually larger. The main idea is to align regions at Union level, thereby increasing the overall level of prosperity and overall development and, of course, making regions more competitive. Europe 2020 is closely linked to cohesion policy, with objectives such as employment, innovation, climate change and energy sustainability, education and the fight against poverty and social exclusion at its centre. But while it would be very much prefer that, by the end of this decade, the regions of the Member States would become much more similar in terms of their multilateral development, especially by the levels of income of the population, it will take a few more decades to become a reality. This report noted, by the way, that in various cases no detailed information on the development of the regions and the situation in the various areas is available. It is hoped that this will change for the better in the near future, as it is not possible to develop and correlated regional policy effectively enough without a specific and specific knowledge of the facts about the functioning of each individual sector in the regions of the Member States.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU spends a third of its budget on cohesion policy. The achievement of the objectives has been affected in the last programming period by a number of adverse factors, in particular the consequences of the economic and financial crisis, the lack of resources in public finances to co-finance innovative projects promoting economic growth and employment. I therefore consider it right to present a report on the achievement of the objectives and tasks of cohesion policy and the Europe 2020 strategy. It will be important for the next period what measures we can take to eliminate the shortcomings and mistakes of the past and how sufficiently, flexibly and well we are prepared to address future challenges.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from voting on the report on cohesion policy and the review of the Europe 2020 strategy because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. This report glorifies the Europe 2020 strategy and the Cohesion Policy, which they believe would contribute to economic development, increased investment and job creation. At a time when Europe is going through the worst political, social, economic and financial crises in its history, we cannot be pleased to know that "everything is fine". In practice, this report has absolutely nothing to do with the debate on the Europe 2020 strategy, since it focuses (voluntarily?) only on the positive points.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Cohesion policy is the EU strategy for reducing disparities between regions and Member States and supporting economic and social development in poorer regions of the EU. This report by Parliament is analysing implementation over the last few years. I particularly welcome the focus on how we can best use the European Social Fund and the European Regional Development Fund to match national funding for investment to regenerate areas of Europe. The focus on SMEs is also important as they provide 2 out of 3 private sector jobs. I support the new funding schemes at EU level to support SMEs.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Favourable to the report on the mid-term review of the 2020 strategy on cohesion policy. Cohesion policy is the EU's main investment, growth and development policy as it aims to reduce regional disparities and promote convergence, having become the only financial resource for growth policy in some Member States or regions. It is important to increase the quantity, quality and impact of investments through the coordinated use of cohesion policy instruments and Horizon 2020. Actions not planned in advance could lead to further delays in the implementation of the new post-2020 cohesion policy and the European Union's long-term strategy to replace Europe 2020.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy is aimed at implementing smart, inclusive and sustainable growth and is one of the fundamental pillars for achieving the European strategy objectives for 2020. It is a policy aimed at implementing integrated development through a mixed approach based on different levels of governance. Mr Ruas' report, which I support by voting in favour, highlights precisely the importance of finding suitable methodologies for implementing this integrated development policy for 2020. Strategies, for example, are the coordination of EIS funds and EFSI funds. It is stressed that EFSI funding should be additional and complementary to the EIS Funds, in order to create real added value, always bearing in mind that while EFSI funds are geared towards specific themes, cohesion policy must remain a horizontal and comprehensive EU investment policy.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report overlooks the shortcomings of cohesion policy. Only minor criticism is made, while the real problem points are omitted. I therefore do not support the report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Cohesion policy accounts for more than a third of the EU budget and is the EU's main investment instrument. This report focuses on the mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy. He notes that disparities within the EU have increased with the economic crisis but without proposing remedies. On the contrary, the new cohesion policy is in line with the objectives of Europe 2020. It is moving away from the objectives of reducing disparities between regions to "smart, sustainable and inclusive growth". I am voting against this text which does not meet the expectations of the most disadvantaged regions.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I welcome the adoption of the cohesion policy report and the review of the Europe 2020 strategy. I congratulate the rapporteur on his work in an area that accounts for more than one third of the Eu budget. Cohesion policy, by covering all regions, is one of the most important instruments for promoting growth and competitiveness, reducing disparities and asymmetries that characterise the different regions.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report as it highlights the importance of a territorial approach within the Cohesion Policy based on qualitative analysis. Due to regional differences within the Union and within Member States the effectiveness of the Cohesion Policy may be asymmetric due to these different regional characteristics. The rapporteur advocates the need for regional, tailor-made objectives which in turn would lead to a greater level of engagement and participation of local and regional authorities.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Report on Cohesion policy and review of the Europe 2020 strategy, which underlines a need for a strategic, political discussion on the future cohesion policy and highlights the importance of multi-level governance and the existence of an effective mixed top-down/bottom-up approach in the Member States. This includes tailor-made EU2020 targets for each region, to better adapt to the reality of a variety of regions with different needs.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy is more than one third of the EU budget and is the EU's main investment instrument. It is closely aligned with the targets set in the Europe 2020 strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. The Commission is currently working on a mid-term review of the strategy and is expected to present proposals for further development of the strategy at the end of 2015. The report of Parliament's Committee on Regional Development focuses on the cohesion policy dimension of the Europe 2020 strategy. As cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020 is fully aligned with and contributes to the objectives of the strategy, the report argues that account should be taken of the progress made so far, the scope of the review and the challenges that need to be addressed for cohesion policy. I supported the motion for a resolution.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. Cohesion policy for 2014-2020 is the EU's main investment and development policy aligned with the Europe 2020 objectives for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. It is intended to reduce the disparities between regions and promote convergence, with a budget of EUR 351.8 billion by the end of 2020 I therefore vote in favour of this progress review report of the Europe 2020 strategy which advocates a better interconnection between the five objectives of the strategy - employment, innovation, climate change and energy sustainability, education and the fight against poverty and social exclusion - and its flagship initiatives. I believe that in the review of Cohesion Policy, a new impetus must be given to the Outermost Regions suffering from natural economic and social constraints as explained in Article 349 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This Ruas report concerns cohesion policy and the review of the Europe 2020 strategy. This text extols the merits of this Europe 2020 strategy, which would contribute to the economic development of the Countries of the Union by increasing investment and employment. I do not know what data allow the rapporteur to reach such a conclusion when we know the union's lack of investment and employment compared to the other major regional groups in the world... Of course, he welcomes the Strategic Investment Fund, which is struggling to get started and whose leverage is greatly overestimated. This report, which was supposed to focus on the review of the Europe 2020 strategy, gives only satisfactions to EU policy and leaves room for limbo when it comes to addressing reform proposals. So I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as this would have an impact on the UK and British people looking for a job. They could count on support from the future EU budget, which provides a significant contribution to job creation through the European Social Fund (ESF) and the European Regional Development Fund. At least EUR 70 billion (i.e. about 10 billion per year) will be available under the ESF for this, complementing national action in this field. Also as small and medium-sized enterprises are the backbone of Europe’s economy, accounting for around 99% of all European businesses and providing two out of three private sector jobs. Thanks to the new COSME programme, they can expect EUR 2.3 billion in support to foster their competitiveness and boost growth and jobs in Europe.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on cohesion policy and the review of the Europe 2020 strategy currently being prepared by the Commission. This text proposes a balanced review of the strategy without creating additional levels of complexity. It reiterates the importance of involving the European Parliament and recommends to the Commission the setting of optional regional targets that take into account the specific characteristics and constraints of rural areas, regions affected by industrial transition, island, cross-border and mountain regions as well as the outermost regions of the Union.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. Cohesion policy is one of the cornerstones of EU policy, which is why it is necessary that the strategy underpinning this policy be a well-developed document. It should serve as a starting point which, in addition to the plans, already includes concrete steps to pursue a cohesion policy that guarantees harmonious territorial, economic and social development. The 2020 strategy is also important because it must re-ingage a Europe after an economic crisis and also ensure its continued development.  The five areas indicated in the strategy in which the EU wants to make the biggest changes are well selected, current, in line with reality, the priorities of the Member States and the EU as such. Reality, on the other hand, needs to be taken into account in detail and areas and objectives that actually contribute to development. However, it is necessary to implement cohesion policy on the basis of the principle of subsidiarity, so that regional and local bodies have an effective say in the use of EU aid. A well-functioning cohesion policy can make a major contribution to successful European integration and improve confidence in the EU.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will provide an EU-wide public consultation gathering the views of all interested parties on how to develop the Europe 2020 strategy over the next five years.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this initiative report because it underlines both the importance of cohesion policy in the 2007-2013 budget year and its importance for the 2014-2020 budget.  In this context, given that many countries have used these European funds to make investments and thus reduce the impact of the economic crisis, I believe that these funds will remain in the coming period the main source of investment and development for countries such as Romania.  The review of the Europe 2020 strategy, as the rapporteur also states, is necessary because it has been negotiated and approved in a different economic and development period than today, so the current strategy is not fully compatible with the realities of cohesion policy.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This is the first European Parliament report on the mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy, focusing on the cohesion policy dimension of the strategy. It examines the progress already achieved, the scope of the review and the challenges to be addressed from a cohesion policy perspective. The report makes some criticism of the results of the Europe 2020 strategy to date and as well as several positive references.  However, cohesion policy is presented as a policy at the service of Europe 2020 and it connects cohesion policy with the EU Economic Governance framework and its implementation mechanism, the ‘European Semester’. Moreover, the report links the allocation and effectiveness of structural and investment to ‘sound economic governance’ – so-called ‘macro-economic conditionalities’ – by the Member States, and therefore to austerity politics. I therefore abstained on this report.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report on cohesion policy and the review of the Europe 2020 strategy unfortunately makes little criticism of the real shortcomings of cohesion policy. This lack of criticism and recognition of facts, as well as the inflating of budgets called for in the report, have received my vote against.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This initiative report focuses on the mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy currently being worked at the Level of the European Commission, and in particular on cohesion policy in this strategy.  While it recognises and warns the Commission of the inadequacy of progress in employment, social inclusion and poverty, thus calling on the Committee to rely on indicators more revealing than GDP to account for the growing disparities between Member States and their regions, it does not call for the cohesion policy objectives to be taken into account in the economic policies at work in this Europe 2020 strategy.  I welcome the references made to the social and environmental progress made by this strategy but condemn the inadequacy on the concept of solidarity and the cohesive objectives in this report, which is why I abstain.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Cohesion policy and the Europe 2020 strategy are important tools for achieving growth in the EU, creating jobs, reducing poverty and social exclusion and harmonising the development of different regions.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – Cohesion policy must be fully aligned with the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. It is therefore essential to take into account the perspective of cohesion policy in the context of the strategy review. It should be noted that cohesion policy is one of the main instruments for the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy. It is essential to ensure that resources are invested effectively to support smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. The revised strategy must focus more on stronger multi-level governance and a more efficient territorial approach. Specific tailored strategy objectives must be applied to each region in order to reduce disparities in the development of different regions of the EU, by stimulating economic growth, market competitiveness and job creation.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Cohesion policy has been ineffective in several Member States due to the draconian financial burden placed on Member States by the ECB and the IMF. Due to the report neglecting to mention that this had a larger impact on Member States’ growth than cohesion policy itself we voted against the report.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Taking into account the tight time constraints and delays in the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy, I strongly support the proposal for enhanced multi-level governance of the strategy itself, through the involvement of local and regional authorities, civil society and other stakeholders, in order to ensure its full and effective implementation. For these reasons, I am voting in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Cohesion Policy as the EU's main investment instrument should have clear and measurable objectives and a very strong and controlled strategy. It must focus on agreed priorities and improve synergies between the funds.  Over the coming years, we need to invest in ESI Funds that are immensely important for smart, sustainable and green growth. EU cohesion and investment policy is an expression of European solidarity and assistance from those with more to those with less to reduce the development gap between rich and developed Western Europe and Eastern Europe, which is constantly behind it in all segments of development – both in GDP and in the employment rate.  So, we need to put an end to liquidity-related problems, paying backlogs and late adoption of a programme that creates an additional burden on Member States' budgets so that projects targeting investment and cohesion funds are adopted more quickly and provide the funding that is essential for the development of regions that have not yet been able to recover from the devastating economic crisis that has engulfed the entire world economy.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This Ruas report concerns cohesion policy and the review of the Europe 2020 strategy. This text extols the merits of this Europe 2020 strategy, which would contribute to the economic development of the EU countries by increasing investment and employment. I do not know what data allow the rapporteur to reach such a conclusion, when we know the union's lack of investment and employment compared to the other major regional groups in the world... Of course, he welcomes the European Fund for Strategic Investments, which is struggling to get started and whose leverage is greatly overestimated.  This report, which was supposed to focus on the review of the Europe 2020 strategy, gives only satisfactions to EU policy and leaves room for limbo when it comes to addressing reform proposals. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒The current cohesion policy is the EU's main investment and development policy aligned with the Objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy for Smart, Sustainable and Inclusive Growth, but regional disparities and uneven development in the fields of employment, innovation and the fight against social exclusion remain significant. The synergy of cohesion policy with other EU policies such as the Digital Single Market, the Energy Union, the Single Capital Market and social policy is therefore necessary.  In particular, it emphasises the necessity of linking cohesion policy, the EU's main instrument for investment in the real economy, and to create solidarity by fostering uniform growth and progress, with investment and structural funds. Here, a new EU investment instrument, the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), is crucial to bridge the investment gap in the EU.  I also strongly support the proposal to strengthen multilevel governance, the combined top-down and vice versa approach and public-private partnerships, in order to allow cooperation between all local and regional stakeholders, including the civil sector. Finally, I support the need for a truly territorial approach to the Europe 2020 strategy with a view to adapting investment to the different characteristics of individual areas. It is these revisions of the Europe 2020 strategy that are important in order to successfully prepare the requirements and strategies for new financial and legislative periods.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I agree with my colleague Fernando Euas' report on cohesion policy and the revision of the Europe 2020 Strategy. The revision of the Europe 2020 Strategy provides an opportunity to assess and recognise the contribution of cohesion policy to achieving the objectives of the Strategy and improving the existing interaction of different policies with the EU budget.  Serious and unequal effects of the economic and financial crisis on Member States and regions should be taken into account. Cohesion policy with a budget of EUR 351.8 billion by the end of 2020 is the EU's main instrument for investing in the real economy, as it covers all regions and acts as an expression of European solidarity by expanding growth and progress and reducing economic, social and territorial inequalities. The new approach will also contribute to increasing the efficiency of consumption.  The establishment of a performance framework and the introduction of ex ante conditions and links to country-specific recommendations in the 2014-2020 cohesion policy programming period will be able to deliver a better investment environment to make cohesion policy's contribution to the achievement of the key objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy as possible. The EU should certainly focus in the coming period on sustainable growth and development as well as on man-worthy jobs to make long-term profits from its investments.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Cohesion policy is paramount to the success of the European Union, and the Europe 2020 strategy is a helpful tool to continue making the EU better. I would like to reiterate that this tool is a long term growth and jobs strategy to help push the EU forward in terms of employment, innovation, climate change and energy sustainability, education, and fighting poverty and social exclusion. I would also like to point out that although the broad strokes have been agreed upon, the implementation is still in the early stages due to some delays. I would like to stress that we cannot afford any more delays with a topic as important as this one. I believe that by working together we can ensure full coherence and synergy between all instruments within the EU.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy, the EU's main investment, growth and development policy with a budget of EUR 351.8 billion until the end of 2020, aims to ensure that all energies are mobilised and geared towards the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, with particular regard to smart growth and employment.  Europe is going through a period of great change following the crisis that broke out in 2008. Therefore, the Commission considered it necessary to propose a mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy, addressing the challenge of coordinating strategic instruments, including EFSI, so as to use all available resources more effectively and thus achieve the expected results with regard to overall strategic objectives. I am in favour of this revision and that is why I have chosen to vote in favour of its approval.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Cohesion policy is today closely linked to the objectives of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth set out in the Europe 2020 strategy. The Commission is currently working on a mid-term review of the strategy and is expected to make further proposals by the end of 2015. I support the pursuit of the Europe 2020 objectives, particularly those relating to the eradication of poverty and social exclusion and the fight against unemployment. I would remind you, however, that the Structural Funds have a specific task to fulfil, which is to support the regions and, more specifically, to compensate for the differences with the richer, more developed regions. I therefore warn against any attempt to 'blur' the original shape of cohesion policy and to treat the Structural Funds only as implementing tools of the Europe 2020 strategy. With this reservation, I supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. At the moment, the European Commission is reviewing the Europe 2020 strategy. The European Parliament has adopted a report on aspects of cohesion policy as part of the review of the Europe 2020 strategy. In particular, Parliament encourages the Commission to ensure that cohesion policy is not more complex and emphasizes the importance of multi-level governance and optional regional objectives. I voted in favour of this report and I stress the importance of involving Parliament in this process. We are in regular contact with local regions and communities, our point of view is important.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Cohesion policy has been ineffective in several Member States due to the draconian financial burden placed on Member States by the ECB and the IMF. Due to the report neglecting to mention that this had a larger impact on Member States’ growth than cohesion policy itself we voted against the report.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. This report focuses on the progress made in view of the mid-term review of the Europe 2020 Strategy at the end of 2015. Cohesion policy is a key instrument for achieving the 2020 Strategy, being closely aligned with its objectives of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. However, due to the crisis, European funding became the only source of public funding in many Member States and regions. The report hopes that synergies between the various European funds will improve, while drawing attention to the need to use the objectives of the 2020 Strategy for each region and to better adapt to their different needs. It also underlines the need for a strategic debate on future cohesion policy, bearing in mind that the new cohesion policy legislative package will come in 2018-2019, along with the 2019 European elections. The review of the EU strategy after 2020 should also be aligned with the new Multiannual Financial Framework. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report dealt with an important policy pursued by the European Union, namely cohesion policy. This policy, a key instrument for the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy, aims to reduce regional disparities and promote convergence. It has a budget of 351.8 billion euros by 2020. In voting for this report, I support the definition of thematic objectives that will maximise the effectiveness of this policy.  The report also covered the Europe 2020 strategy for which the Commission launched the review process in 2014. With regard to the mid-term review of this strategy, this report makes a series of recommendations. In the future, the future cohesion policy and the future long-term strategy of the Union must be developed before the end of the current Commission's mandate. Indeed, the elections to the European Parliament will take place in 2019, which imposes constraints on the timetable.  In line with all these remarks, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. It was with great satisfaction that I saw the Own-Initiative Report i made on "Cohesion Policy and the Review of the Europe 2020 Strategy" adopted with great satisfaction that I approved the own-initiative report on "Cohesion Policy and the Review of the Europe 2020 Strategy" by more than 80% of the votes cast (530 votes in favour, 75 against and 54 abstentions). The importance of this report goes far beyond the political issues dealt with by the Committee on Regional Development, as it is the first document with the European Parliament's seal on the revision of the Europe 2020 strategy, it also launches the interinstitutional debate on this matter (which begins with the Commission in this Plenary Session), as well as the discussion on the mid-term review of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). Because 2019 is a full year of European political events and coincides with the end of the current MFF and the current Europe 2020 strategy, we hope that these discussions we are now starting will also take into mind a longer time horizon and very concretely look into the future Post-2020 European legislative framework. I wanted to carry out a comprehensive document, but affirmative and simple reading. Thanks to the positive and cooperative attitude of the shadow rapporteurs and colleagues who have tabled amendments to the document, I believe I have achieved the objectives i set myself.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. This report comes as the Commission prepares for the mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy. It is important to remember that cohesion policy is the EU's main investment instrument and reflects European solidarity; it also meets the smart, sustainable and inclusive growth targets set out in the Europe 2020 strategy.  This report sends several messages about these two points.  With regard to the Europe2020 strategy, first of all, it is important to establish a better interconnection of the five objectives of the strategy without creating a new administrative burden or level of complexity. In addition, it is important that stakeholders become more involved in all stages from planning to evaluation; setting regional targets could also be an important element for the involvement of all stakeholders. With regard to the future cohesion policy and the EU's future strategy for growth and employment, these will have to be presented before the end of the current Commission's mandate. I have therefore supported this report, which also reminds us of the importance of involving Parliament in the cohesion policy and the review of the Europe 2020 strategy.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I support the Eu ropean Union's objective of implementing a strong and united cohesion policy between the Member States, aimed at overcoming economic, social and territorial imbalances. Cohesion policy is not only the European Union's main investment instrument but also an essential element in implementing the Europe 2020 strategy. The European Union must pursue the objectives of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because the report is balanced overall and rightly calls for more targeted investment, a review of the 2020 strategy, actions at macro-regional level and taking into account the different territorial specificities.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained in the report on cohesion policy and the revision of the Europe 2020 Strategy. We understand that the Union's medium-term policies, and especially those with broad budget items, require broad consensus and need to go in line with eliminating the abosmal differences between development and quality of life in different areas of the Union. We can only be entirely in favour of the reports on this subject when inequalities are the political a priori constituting the approach to medium-term strategies.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report is based on the 2014 European Commission Communication on the balance sheet of the Europe 2020 Strategy, which set out five main targets for 2020 in employment, research and development, polluting emissions, school failure and poverty reduction. To achieve this, so-called economic governance has been promoted and implemented through country-specific recommendations that have brought disastrous consequences for the population. Parliament's report regrets that the key role of cohesion policy has not been mentioned in this Communication; calls for the inclusion of indicators other than GDP to measure progress; taking into account rural areas, areas affected by industrial transition, etc.; calls for greater involvement of Parliament in policy oversight, etc. However, it is serious that cohesion policy incompatibility with the European Strategic Investment Fund (Juncker plan) is not observed. In addition, it calls for more attention from public-private partnerships, covert sources of privatization, more expensive for the public age and less efficient. Finally, there is once again no criticism of the European Semester's austericide policies with cohesion policy. That's why I've decided to abstain.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy is responsible for more than a third of the Eu ropean Union budget and is its main investment instrument. It aims to reduce regional disparities and promote convergence and has a budget of EUR 351.8 billion until the end of 2020. It is closely aligned with the smart, sustainable and inclusive growth goals set out in the Europe 2020 strategy.  I voted in favour of this own-initiative report because I believe that the mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy offers an opportunity both to assess and recognise the contribution made by cohesion policy and to ensure better complementarity and more effective synergies between EU investment instruments. I hope, however, that the forthcoming proposals will also take account of the serious and unequal effects that the economic and financial crisis has had on the Member States and that they will promote the setting of tailor-made objectives for each region in order to adapt the interventions to the characteristics of each territory.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 As a result of the economic and financial crisis that some Member States cross the funds that give part to cohesion policy and which are intended to finance projects aimed at promoting it have taken on a decisive importance. They have guaranteed investment capacity to relaunch the economy of countries with macroeconomic imbalances. Economic governance recommendations should take this into account and ensure that regions are safeguarded as receivers of these funds. In this mid-term review of Europe 2020 the unequal impact of the crisis should be taken into account. The different territorial and social characteristics determined differentiated resilience. Attention to youth unemployment in the outermost regions. Multi-level governance mechanisms should recognise regional and local authorities' ability to intervene. I end with an alert: although the operational programmes are agreed, their implementation is still incipient, which has generated difficulties.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this policy as cohesion policy in the EU has consistently failed; I am also against cohesion policy of any sort from the EU.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Cohesion Policy is the EU's main investment facility. It allocates one third of the EU budget. In view of the alignment of the Structural and Investment Funds for the 2014-2020 programming period with the europe 2020 objectives, cohesion policy should be seen as an EU financial instrument that contributes very strongly to the achievement of the strategy's objectives. The contribution of cohesion policy to the europe 2020 objectives has also been demonstrated in the previous programming period 2007-2013.It is worth noting that, after the 2008 crisis, cohesion policy was, due to the lack of public funding at national level, the only source of funding for growth policy in some Member States or regions.  There is a need to fully implement the Common Strategic Framework provided for in the Common Rules Regulation, which aims to achieve integrated development by coordinating the European Structural and Investment Funds with other Union instruments and with Union policies in other areas.  Recent voices, particularly from southern European countries, are worrying about the revision of cohesion policy in order to redistribute resources more to the countries most affected by the economic crisis at the expense of the less developed regions of Central and Eastern Europe. There can be no agreement on such attempts to dismantle cohesion policy, which, after all, aims to reduce development dissasembles, not to help the anti-crisis.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 EU cohesion policy funding occupies one third of the EU budget and is the EU's main investment instrument. I believe that cohesion policy should remain the main horizontal investment policy. I also consider it important to create synergies between Cohesion Policy and Horizon 2020 (Horizon 2020). I therefore supported this resolution.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ Cohesion Policy represents more than one third of the EU budget, making it its main investment instrument. It also continuously contributes to the objectives of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth from the Europe 2020 strategy and is aimed at reducing regional disparities.  Furthermore, cohesion policy aims and encourages synergies with other EU policies, such as the Digital Single Market, the Energy Union, social policy and, through its instruments and objectives (such as macro-regional strategies, territorial agenda, investment in SMEs), significantly contributes to strengthening the single market and achieving the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. The revision of the Europe 2020 strategy will focus on the implementation of flagship initiatives and will aim to strike a balance between financial, fiscal and economic measures on the one hand and on the other hand social, educational and environmental aspects, as well as aspects of equality, in particular gender.  I have therefore decided to support the cohesion policy resolution and the revision of this strategy, as it is a comprehensive and long-term Strategy of the European Union that invests in the main European priorities, strengthens the potential of regions and promotes sustainable development.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ As the EU’s main instrument for economic growth and job creation, cohesion policy is best placed to help achieve the Europe 2020 strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. It can achieve this through its substantive budget and through its decades-long experience. Unfortunately, not all Member States can easily succeed in making use of the opportunities offered by the policy. This is the case of my country, which barely used 65% of the budget put at its disposal in the last programming period. Therefore I can only hope, just as the report emphasizes, that the stronger link between Structural and Investment Funds and the European Semester process, the setting-up of the task force for better implementation of EU funds and the establishment of the ‘Structural Reform Support Service’ will ensure that no more opportunities for development and social cohesion are wasted in any of the Member States.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Cohesion policy is the main policy for investment growth and EU development policy. It is aligned with the Europe 2020 objectives for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, which aim to close regional disparities and promote convergence. The EU is still facing the consequences of the economic and financial crisis (high unemployment, uneven and slow economic recovery), and it is therefore essential that the various EU initiatives for growth, jobs and environmental and climate protection maintain a coherent approach. I believe that the review of the Europe 2020 strategy should take into account the serious and varied consequences of the economic and financial crisis for the Member States. In the current programming period, there are delays in the implementation of cohesion policy, as, despite the already existing specificity of most operational programmes, the implementation of these programmes is still at a very early stage. Cohesion policy is a key EU instrument for investment in the real economy and is an expression of European solidarity, as it increases growth and prosperity and reduces economic, social and territorial disparities. I welcome the drafting of the report, as it has given a better insight into the current course of cohesion policy towards the Europe 2020 strategy and has shown that a better investment environment could be provided for the greatest contribution of cohesion policy to the achievement of the strategy's flagship objectives. For the sake of what I described, I supported the report.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report analysing the cohesion policy dimension within the Europe 2020 strategy and being the European Parliament's first text on the mid-term review of this strategy. As the current cohesion policy is fully aligned with Europe 2020 and contributes to the achievement of its smart, sustainable and inclusive development goals, it is very important to take stock of the progress already made and the challenges that lie ahead from the point of view of cohesion policy. The latter is, in fact, an essential element in achieving the Europe 2020 objectives, all the more so in recent years, when, due to the continuing economic and financial crisis, cohesion policy funds have often become the only source of public funding available in many regions and Member States. We now need better synergies between the 'traditional' cohesion funds and the Juncker Plan fund, in order to reinvigorate investment at local level. The report also highlights the importance of strengthening multi-level governance for the implementation of the strategy, with the involvement of all stakeholders, and the need for a territorial approach that allows the definition of Europe 2020 strategy objectives tailored to each region.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy is the main investment and development policy. It is in line with the Europe 2020 strategy objectives for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. As we are faced not only with the consequences of the economic and financial crisis, but also in the migration and refugee crisis, it is important to focus all the more on reducing disparities between regions and reviving the economy. All energy and capacity should be used to ensure growth, increase employment, support for small and medium-sized enterprises, as well as environmental and climate protection. Meeting the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy will thus make the European Union more competitive and better positioned in the global economy.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report because it complies with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and, in particular Article 4, Article 162 and Articles 174 to 178. It is also consistent with the Regional Development Committee report (A8-0277/2015).  I think it is essential that different EU growth and environmental initiatives maintain a coherent approach, as the flagship initiatives of the Europe 2020 strategy play a key role in improving coordination at local and regional level in the implementation of cohesion policy. Over time, cohesion policy objectives have become better developed to support investment in Europe's priorities and are therefore important to support.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the reformed cohesion policy will help to invest in Europe’s regions, cities and the real economy. I recognise that small and medium-sized enterprises are the backbone of Europe’s, and Britain’s, economy, providing around two out of three private sector jobs. Thanks to the new COSME programme, they can expect EUR 2.3 million in support to foster their competitiveness and boost growth and jobs in Europe.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Cohesion Policy is the EU's main instrument for investing in the real economy, covering all regions and acting as an expression of European solidarity by expanding growth and progress and reducing economic, social and territorial inequality. It is aligned with the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy and provides the necessary framework for investment, not just an instrument for implementing the strategy. In this regard, it is pointed out that the thematic concentration directs the European Structural and Investment Funds under the new structure to 11 thematic objectives resulting directly from the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy and that certain preconditions are directly linked to these thematic objectives in order to ensure maximum effective investment. The Commission is currently preparing a mid-term review of the strategy, and this report represents the European Parliament's first position on this topic, focusing primarily on the strategy's cohesion policy.  I fully support this report as it enables a balanced and smart review of the existing strategy, anticipating better interconnection of objectives within the strategy itself.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting. I do not agree with the measures presented, which aim to increase the effectiveness of redistribution in cohesion policy programmes as well as in other programmes. The problem with this redistribution is not only ineflection, but that this redistribution is, as a matter of principle, detrimental to the economy, since it only shifts resources from productive citizens to less productive.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on cohesion policy and the review of the Europe 2020 strategy. This is mainly reflected in the high unemployment among young people. The Europe 2020 strategy aims at smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. I join the concern in the report that there are delays in the implementation of cohesion policy, even though most operational programmes are already set out. At the same time, I welcome the fact that the European Commission is constantly working to improve the Europe 2020 strategy. The objectives are relevant, but we still have a lot to do to achieve these objectives. Responsibility for achieving the objectives must be assumed primarily by local, regional and national authorities.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted against the report, because instead of promoting solidarity to expand growth and prosperity to address economic and social inequalities in the Member States, as defined by cohesion policy, it is limited to the objective of aligning cohesion policy with austerity policies. It is important that cohesion policy is not aligned with the Single Economic Governance framework, otherwise states will be blackmailed into following the harsh austerity measures provided for in the European Semester so as not to interrupt their financial support.  In such a case, cohesion policy will be completely neutralised. We also disagree with the attempt to make cohesion policy a tool of the Europe 2020 strategy, which provides for enhanced competitiveness, flexible forms of employment and privatisation. On the contrary, we must promote a new social development policy. Support public investment and finance projects that meet the needs of society and contribute to the creation of new quality jobs. Only in this way will we combat the economic, social and territorial disparities that exist in Europe.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The Europe 2020 strategy and its interconnection with cohesion policy have been shown, both by the Cohesion Report and by the serious and unequal consequences of the financial crisis in the Member States, to have failed in the ambitious objectives set. The fact is that the Lisbon Treaty and the Europe 2020 governance have lost the support of the Member States over time. This, combined with austerity policy and serious socio-economic problems as a result of the crisis, have led a large part of EU citizens to Euroscepticism. The review of cohesion policy has lost momentum. The implemented reform policies imposed, through the structural reform support service providing technical assistance to Member States and country-specific recommendations (troika and technical steps in Greece), are destroying any attempt at sustainable development.  The effort to revive investment and to revive the investment gap in the EU through the EFSI, on the one hand, is not clearly linked to the Europe 2020 strategy, on the other hand, it does not complement existing ESI Funds. We therefore need a comprehensive redefinition of the Europe 2020 strategy and not just a review.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution, as I believe that cohesion policy is the EU's main investment and development policy, coordinated with the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, with the aim of reducing interregiobency and promoting convergence.  It is therefore important that we express our views on the review. The report highlights the principle of multi-level governance, an integrated approach and the importance of transparency. I trust that civil society will be involved in the implementation. I believe that anti-EU practices, such as those of the Government of Hungary, where it allocates EU funds to its friends solely on political grounds, should be avoided. This raises no less than the fact of the misuse of common resources, since instead of cohesion, for example, more than 4 million people in Hungary live below the living wage and more than 500 000 people are starving. I find this regrettable and unacceptable.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 EU cohesion policy requires the solidarity of the Member States in order to equalise the development of their regions. This objective is congruent with the EU's Europe 2020 strategy, which focuses on increasing employment, increasing investment in research and development, digitising the economy, reducing polluting emissions, energy efficiency, reducing school drop-out, reducing poverty.  However, in the context of the financial and economic crisis of recent years, the implementation of the Strategy has been affected, in particular as regards financing, available only through the European Structural and Investment Funds. The creation of the European Fund for Strategic Investments has provided a new breath of oxygen in this regard.  However, a segmentation of the Strategy is required in order to adapt to the particularities of each region of the Union. Only in this way will investment be directed to truly deficient areas involving optimal decision-making levels. Following such a debate, the framework for a new cohesion policy can be shaped which is in sync with the Multi-annual Financial Framework and which truly meets the needs of citizens in the various parts of the European Union.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour on cohesion policy and the review of the Europe 2020 strategy.  Cohesion policy is the EU's main investment, growth and development strategy, aligned with the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy for Smart, Sustainable and Inclusive Growth, which aims to reduce regional disparities and promote convergence and has a budget of EUR 351.8 billion by 2020, so that the European Union continues to cope with the effects of the economic and financial crisis high unemployment, uneven and slow economic recovery. Cohesion policy aims to ensure that all energies and resources are mobilised and dedicated to achieving the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, namely sustainable growth and jobs.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I endorsed adoption of this report, which is the first European Parliament’s report on the mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy, focusing especially on the cohesion policy dimension of it. With a budget of EUR 351.8 billion until the end of 2020, the cohesion policy is the EU’s main investment growth and development policy and it is therefore important to examine it rigorously. Based on the review, the Commission is expected to submit by the end of 2015 its proposals for developing it further. In this report, Parliament calls on the Commission to provide information on the concrete contribution made to the Europe 2020 objectives by cohesion policy and demands that the review is focused on better interlinking the strategy’s five objectives. It also notes the importance of the new EU investment instrument, the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), which will support the mobilisation of up to EUR 315 billion in investments and regrets that it is not clearly linked to the Europe 2020 strategy.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 In today's vote, I supported the report by Mr Ruas, a Member of the European Parliament on the review of cohesion policy and the Europe 2020 strategy, which is particularly important for the long-term strategy of the European Union for growth and job creation. And, most importantly, the report makes recommendations on combating poverty and social exclusion and on increasing the funding for education for the younger generation. The pressure that the report puts on the Commission is fully justified, as future decisions and legislative texts may be delayed without pre-planned actions. And this would directly influence long-term strategies. I would like to make it clear that these activities should first take into account the population of those regions who are in an economic disadvantage, because this strategy will make sense when its aid is aimed at harmonising living standards between economically different Member States in the European Union.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on cohesion policy and the review of the Europe 2020 strategy, as I believe that the European Union's long-term strategy for growth and jobs will bring new jobs, innovation, prevent climate change and ensure energy sustainability and new education opportunities, and will be even more active in the fight against poverty and social exclusion.  This policy is therefore a key instrument of the EU for investment in the real economy and is an expression of European solidarity that increases growth and prosperity and reduces economic, social and territorial disparities.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained in the report on cohesion policy and the revision of the Europe 2020 Strategy. We understand that the Union's medium-term policies, and especially those with broad budget items, require broad consensus and need to go in line with eliminating the abosmal differences between development and quality of life in different areas of the Union. We can only be entirely in favour of the reports on this subject when inequalities are the political a priori constituting the approach to medium-term strategies.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report glorifies the Europe 2020 strategy and cohesion policy that would contribute to economic development, increased investment and job creation. It also advocates strengthening local authorities at the expense of Member States. It even suggests putting local and national authorities on an equal footing in the negotiations, proposing to sign a pact between the Commission, Member States and local authorities, in order to ensure their participation in the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy. Finally, he welcomed the creation of the European Fund for Strategic Investments. I am opposed to all of these considerations.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy is more than one third of the EU budget and is the EU's main investment instrument. It is closely aligned with the targets set in the Europe 2020 strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. The Commission is currently working on a mid-term review of the strategy and is expected to present proposals for further development of the strategy at the end of 2015. This process fits with the current report, which I supported.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained in the report on cohesion policy and the revision of the Europe 2020 Strategy. We understand that the Union's medium-term policies, and especially those with broad budget items, require broad consensus and need to go in line with eliminating the abosmal differences between development and quality of life in different areas of the Union. We can only be entirely in favour of the reports on this subject when inequalities are the political a priori constituting the approach to medium-term strategies.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this file, the review of Europe 2020 should not lead to the creation of obstacles for Cohesion Policy implementation, but should tackle deficiencies such as lack of ownership by better involvement of actors from regional and local level and civil society.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on cohesion policy and the review of the Europe 2020 strategy. Cohesion policy is the EU’s main investment growth and development policy aligned with the goals of the Europe 2020 strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth and aimed at reducing disparities between regions and promoting convergence, with a budget of EUR 351.8 billion until the end of 2020.  A mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy affords above all an opportunity to assess (and acknowledge) the contribution of cohesion policy to achieving the strategy’s targets and to improve existing interactions and links between various EU policies and with the EU budget, with a view to them acting as an effective driving force for the implementation of the strategy. I therefore consider this stage essential for shaping future cohesion policy, as an EU-wide investment policy, while prioritising the reduction of development disparities and re-accelerating the convergence process.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a report proposing a review of the Europe 2020 Strategy in a balanced and intelligent way, focusing on building greater links between the five priority objectives and identifying methods to see how they could be better implemented and better assessed without creating additional administrative burdens. It is a balanced report which has reached great consensus in the Committee on Regional Development, so I consider it necessary to vote in its favour.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report is based on the 2014 European Commission Communication on the balance sheet of the Europe 2020 Strategy, which set out five main targets for 2020 in employment, research and development, polluting emissions, school failure and poverty reduction. To achieve this, so-called economic governance has been promoted and implemented through country-specific recommendations that have brought disastrous consequences for the population. Parliament's report regrets that the key role of cohesion policy has not been mentioned in this Communication; calls for the inclusion of indicators other than GDP to measure progress; taking into account rural areas, areas affected by industrial transition, etc.; calls for greater involvement of Parliament in policy oversight, etc. However, it is serious that cohesion policy incompatibility with the European Strategic Investment Fund (Juncker plan) is not observed. In addition, it calls for more attention from public-private partnerships, covert sources of privatization, more expensive for the public age and less efficient. Finally, there is once again no criticism of the European Semester's austericide policies with cohesion policy. That's why I've decided to abstain.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 We agree with the strategic objectives of cohesion policy. We cannot understand why the poorest countries and regions differ in the European average. This is the case of Portugal, which, since the euro came into operation, has not stopped diverging with the European Union average in terms of GDP per capita. Something is therefore wrong. There is no cohesion. Policies don't work. Because the macroeconomic framework is not consistent with regional development policies. In other words, policies of austerity, of containment of public spending, whether good or bad, do not allow the establishment of virtuous dynamics of local or regional development. I can give you examples of projects that don't come out of the paper, because there's no funding. Because the bank prefers to speculate. We can see funds that do not form used in Portugal because of the impositions of the Troika and the necessary adjustment aimed at the so-called consolidation of public finances. The result is in sight. After almost thirty years of integration, Portugal is poorer, dependent and with the largest public debt in its history.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report overlooks the shortcomings of cohesion policy. Only minor criticism is made, while the real problem points are omitted. I therefore do not support the report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution because I consider cohesion policy to be a very important investment resource as well as a means of pursuing smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. In recent years, due to the economic crisis that has gripped Europe, EIS funding has been the only public financing instrument for many states and regions. Recent economic difficulties have shown the strategic importance of this instrument and highlighted the need to guarantee all the resources necessary for its maintenance.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. Unlike my group, the ECR, I voted against the report on 'Cohesion policy and the review of the Europe 2020 strategy'. Cohesion policy accounts for more than a third of the EU budget and is the EU's main investment instrument. In my view, this is a violation of the principle of subsidiarity, which is why I voted against this report.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the Report on Cohesion Policy and the revision of the Europe 2020 strategy. I agree with the rapporteur's view that cohesion policy contributes significantly to the achievement of the Europe 2020 objectives on smart, sustainable and inclusive growth.  I welcome the fact that the report calls, taking into account the delays and time constraints that occurred at the beginning of the current programming period, for a timely comprehensive discussion on the future of EU cohesion policy after 2020 and for it to be aligned with the revised long-term strategy with regard to the EU and the new MFF.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report, on several points, makes clear what it wants: the reconciliation of cohesion policies, under the 2014-2020 Funding Framework, with the achievement of the Europe 2020 Objectives - understood as being in line with cohesion in the EU. It intends to create ex ante constraints and link country-specific recommendations to the programming of funds for 2014-2020. If, on the one hand, from a Union perspective, it is rational to reconcile the various investments, avoiding overlaps and contradictions, on the other hand, the definition of the Europe 2020 Objectives has a federalist framework and an artificial and bureaucratic definition, leading to the reduction of cohesion in the sociological and territorial context. The fact that the European Structural Investment Funds and multiannual financial frameworks are combining with cohesion policies is making them conditional on the EU's macro objectives and not on the specific development needs of the Member States. We voted against it.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I am concerned about the practical implications of European rescheduling and suspensions under Article 23 of the Common Provisions Regulation, in accordance with the so-called 'macroeconomic conditionality' rejected by the S&D Group, but incorporated in the last parliamentary term; and this, from the perspective that cohesion policy is often, in the context of the crisis, the only source of public investment in many regions.  The report gives an impact on guarantees for Article 23 to be used as a measure of last resort, considering that European solidarity should not be hindered by economic governance mechanisms. Beneficiaries of funds, regions and municipalities cannot be harmed by macroeconomic failures at higher levels of the Administration.  According to the report, the Eurochamber must be the main democratic guarantor of the proper application of the macro-conditionality of Article 23, with the Commission having to take into account its positions. The need for constant, clear and transparent interinstitutional collaboration is therefore underlined.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report focuses on the Communication made by the European Commission on the guidelines for linking the Structural Funds with Article 23 of Regulation No 1303/2013, in which the Commission itself announces that aid from the Structural Funds must be closely linked to compliance with EU governance.  It thus justifies the rescheduling and suspension of funds to regions where the Member States to which they belong do not meet the criteria set by the European Semester to correct the degree of indebtedness (policies for cuts and reforms that close rights in labour law, among others).  Parliament's report legitimises the existence of so-called 'macro-conditionality' as a last resort. In addition, the vast majority of the Eurochamber voted in favour of declaring that economic governance instruments contribute to a 'stable macroeconomic environment', ignoring the dramatic effects of austerity measures on the European population, and on Spain in particular.  In fact, it was not even voted in favour of the proposal to eliminate the Structural Funds from a state's overall public deficit count. That is why, obviously, I voted against it.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
