text: in writing. ‒ Article 23 of the Common Provision Regulations is a destructive mechanism that further entrenches austerity by linking cohesion funding to ‘sound economic governance’ – also known as ‘macro-economic conditionalities’. It allows funding programmes at a local or regional level to be suspended or ‘reprogrammed’ because of factors outside the control of those affected, such as national budget deficits. This would cause significant harm, particularly to vulnerable regions and Member States still suffering from the economic and social crisis. While the report is mildly critical and recommends some safeguards, it ultimately accepts the premise of ‘sound economic governance’ in the context of cohesion funding. For this reason, my colleague Martina Anderson tabled an alternative resolution on behalf of the GUE/NGL group calling for the mechanism not to be used and for its review, which unfortunately did not succeed. I also voted for a specific amendment, tabled by more than 76 MEPs, calling for the decoupling of this important funding from the calculation of national deficits. This amendment was also unsuccessful. As the report therefore endorses - if critically - a mechanism that will impose austerity policies on local and regional communities, I voted against the report.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of the report is to clarify the use of Article 23 of the Regulation on common provisions for European Structural and Investment Funds. The text of the report insists that the application of this article should be done in a balanced manner. For this reason, it rightly states that there should be no unrelenting reprogramming and that the suspension of payment mechanism which is a discretion of the Commission must remain exceptional. In addition, the report calls on the Commission to present a white paper which analyses the benefits and effectiveness of long-term public investment. Together with my colleagues, we hope that this will force the Commission. However, an independent study would be welcome.  Among the negative aspects of the report, I note that it places all the responsibility for the increase in public debt on the budgetary policies of the Member States, while the European Union also has its share of responsibility, notably through its aberrant monetary policy. The cohesion policy touted in the report has brought neither prosperity nor growth.  Because this text limits the Commission's room for manoeuvre, I abstained despite my disagreement on European economic governance.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ It is consistent with my principles as a UKIP MEP to oppose this resolution on the European Structural and Investment Funds.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. Macro-conditionality is an instrument whose scope remains very limited (see exceptional budget measures for Greece). Commendable this principle is still too tied to the logic of just return.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 A stable macroeconomic environment, including high-quality management at all levels, enables the successful use of the European Structural and Investment (ESI) Funds. However, objective criteria need to be applied to assess whether a Member State has taken effective action in the use of the ESI Funds. I agree that it is important to respect the principles of proportionality and equal treatment in the application of Article 23 and to ensure a more sustainable and effective cohesion policy.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal makes recommendations for Article 23 of the Regulation on the European Structural and Investment Funds. Pursuant to Article 23, the Commission may request a Member State to review its partnership agreement or certain of its programmes and, if the Member State considers that it is not taking effective measures, may propose to the Council that payments to the programmes or priorities concerned be wholly or partly suspended.  Parliament will endeavour to ensure that these measures are taken only in the most edinated case and in the most balanced way possible. In the event of a possible suspension, Parliament proposes a cautious approach, pointing out that during the crisis, improvements in some areas can only be made with EU resources. It also notes that it considers the suspension of aid to be particularly counterproductive in certain areas. The report also recommends that Parliament be involved in the adoption of the decision or proposal in the event of a reprogramming or suspension. On this basis, I supported the report.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Article 23 of the CPR demonstrates the lack of democracy in the EU. The fact that the Commission can tell the Council to withdraw funding from a Member State without consulting the elected Parliament highlights the democratic deficit. The reality with this report is that there will be no change; if Parliament received more powers of ‘scrutiny’ from the Commission they would only be allowed to give an opinion and not fully go against the judgment of the Commission. Therefore we were against this legislation.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. It is essential that we do not lose sight of the original role and objectives of cohesion policy and its importance as an instrument for maintaining investment in European regions, particularly in a context of economic crisis and instability. Economic governance mechanisms should not impede the pursuit of broader objectives of economic, social and territorial cohesion by penalizing regional or local entities. I have approved this text as it is vital to support the work of regional and local entities, although I regret the failure to adopt the amendment I have co-signed calling for the investment clause to be revised so that regional and national investments co-financed under ESI funds can be excluded from the calculation of national deficits within the framework of the European semester.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerns the European Structural and Investment Funds for Good Economic Governance, which echoes the Commission's communication on "guidelines on the application of measures linking the effectiveness of the European Structural and Investment Funds".  While this text aims to limit the Commission's power over the macroeconomic conditionality of aid, it does not remove these unacceptable provisions and thus strengthen the Commission's grip with austerity. On the other hand, this report places the increase in public debt solely on the policies of the Member States, while the majority comes from a transfer of private debt to the public (particularly from the euro or laws prohibiting 0% borrowing from national banks), reinforced by the austere policy demanded by Brussels. However, I abstained because it diminishes the scope of the text presented by the Commission.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the poor results regarding the implementation of the country-specific recommendations for cohesion policy, I would like to see the whole review of the concept of cohesion policy and its policies in place. That is why I abstained from voting.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I am concerned about the practical implications of European rescheduling and suspensions under Article 23 of the Common Provisions Regulation, in accordance with the so-called 'macroeconomic conditionality' rejected by the S&D Group, but incorporated in the last parliamentary term; and this, from the perspective that cohesion policy is often, in the context of the crisis, the only source of public investment in many regions.  The report gives an impact on guarantees for Article 23 to be used as a measure of last resort, considering that European solidarity should not be hindered by economic governance mechanisms. Beneficiaries of funds, regions and municipalities cannot be harmed by macroeconomic failures at higher levels of the Administration.  According to the report, the Eurochamber must be the main democratic guarantor of the proper application of the macro-conditionality of Article 23, with the Commission having to take into account its positions. The need for constant, clear and transparent interinstitutional collaboration is therefore underlined. Although in favour of the revision of the Stability and Growth Pact, I have not supported the amendment tabled in this regard, a red line for EPP and ALDE, for escaping the subject-matter of the report and endangering the progress it contains.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it presents Parliament's position on certain aspects of the European Structural and Investment Funds and sound economic governance. EU cohesion policy is an expression of European solidarity, which aims to strengthen economic, social and territorial cohesion in the EU and, in particular, to reduce regional disparities by promoting balanced and sustainable socio-economic development. Cohesion policy is also an investment policy that contributes to the smart, sustainable and inclusive growth of the EU and its Member States. Good governance and effective public institutions in the Member States are essential for sustainable and long-term economic growth, job creation and social and territorial development, and, on the contrary, economic and financial unpredictability and legal uncertainty can lead to a decline in public and private investment, thus jeopardised by the achievement of cohesion policy objectives. However, Parliament is very strongly in favour of applying macroeconomic conditions to the provision of structural assistance in the Member States. Macroeconomic irregularities at other levels of administration cannot be allowed to penalise regional or local authorities for the reprogramming or suspension of the use of funds, which would impair their respective economic and social situation. Parliament therefore calls for macroeconomic conditionality to be used only as a last option for the use of structural funds in the Member States in order to contribute to the effective implementation of the European Structural and Investment (ESI) Funds.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 As you know, the European Structural and Investment Funds have the important objective of supporting the economic development of all EU Member States by addressing the strategic investment gap that the private market cannot cover. The need to coordinate and work synergistically with other European policies requires that these funds be accompanied by sound economic management.  I support this report, which calls on the Commission to make limited, exceptional and responsible use of Article 100a of the Treaty. Article 23 of the Regulation laying down common provisions (DRCs), which deals with so-called macroeconomic conditionality and provides, where necessary, for macroeconomic adjustment, reprogramming or, ultimately, suspension of the European Structural and Investment Funds.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 I support this report. In the current programming period, cohesion policy is closely linked to the objectives of the EU2020 strategy and economic governance mechanisms. I agree that local and regional authorities should not be penalised by reprogramming or suspending funding due to macroeconomic failures of national governments and that a balance should be held between an efficient economy and governance objectives.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Article 23 of the Common Provision Regulations is a destructive mechanism that further entrenches austerity by linking cohesion funding to ‘sound economic governance’ – also known as ‘macro-economic conditionalities’. It allows funding programmes at a local or regional level to be suspended or ‘reprogrammed’ because of factors outside the control of those affected, such as national budget deficits. This would cause significant harm, particularly to vulnerable regions and Member States still suffering from the economic and social crisis. While the report is mildly critical and recommends some safeguards, it ultimately accepts the premise of ‘sound economic governance’ in the context of cohesion funding. For this reason, my colleague Martina Anderson tabled an alternative resolution on behalf of the GUE/NGL group calling for the mechanism not to be used and for its review, which unfortunately did not succeed. I also voted for a specific amendment, tabled by more than 76 MEPs, calling for the decoupling of this important funding from the calculation of national deficits. This amendment was also unsuccessful. As the report therefore endorses - if critically - a mechanism that will impose austerity policies on local and regional communities, I voted against the report.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that, given the multiannual and long-term nature of the programmes and objectives of the EIS Funds, it would be more useful to decouple them from the various mechanisms put in place to ensure sound economic governance at both European and national level, which, on the other hand, have a much more limited, mostly annual, time horizon. This solution would make it easier to allocate resources and would lead to an improvement in the investment situation on the European continent, especially in the areas most affected by the economic crisis.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Article 23 CPR needs to be revised for the risky concrete consequences of reprogramming and suspending EIS funds. The original objectives of the European Union's cohesion policy, concerning the development and adjustment of growth in the various areas of the Union, have made it one of the main instruments in maintaining territorial investment in times of crisis and socio-economic instability.  The importance of pursuing territorial, social and economic cohesion cannot be put into the background in the name of an abstract efficiency of governance. Local and regional authorities cannot be penalised by suspending the Funds, which would lead to a rapid deterioration in the social and economic situation of the affected territories if other levels of administration with adequate available resources are unable to act quickly.  The Union's action must always be supportive and sustainable, careful to provide proportionate responses to real needs and to prevent regions already disadvantaged or affected by the economic crisis from paying the highest price for changes in European economic planning. Reprogramming must therefore be limited to the bare minimum and cannot ignore the socio-economic situation of the territory being implemented, with transparency and objectivity of the procedure and respect for the original objectives of EU cohesion policy.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. Article 23 of the Common Provisions Regulation (DRC) links the effectiveness of the EFSI to the good economic governance of Member States. This article aims to condition the receipt of European structural funds on the macro-economic performance of Member States, particularly in terms of deficit or public debt. If a state does not implement the structural reforms recommended by the Commission, it may have payments suspended. That is why the rapporteur proposes to ensure that these provisions are applied in a balanced and exceptional way.  Nevertheless, the rapporteur recognises that the sharp increase in the debt ratio of Member States since 2008 is mainly the result of the budgetary mismanagement of national governments and does not sufficiently highlight the Commission's responsibility through the austerity measures it has imposed on the peoples of Europe. Moreover, this report explains that cohesion policy has enabled us to respond to current macroeconomic and fiscal constraints, which we formally dispute. I therefore abstained on this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy is a policy that is based on the provisions of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and is an expression of European solidarity, aimed at strengthening economic, social and territorial cohesion. At the same time, cohesion policy wants to bridge the gap between regions, while trying to promote socio-economic development in the most balanced and harmonious way. Since there was a majority concerned that the practical implications of the reprogramming and suspension of the European Structural and Investment Funds were raised, this report sought to strike a balance between different visions of the macroeconomic conditionality mechanism from the perspective of its application as a last resort within the system. I voted in favour of the Report on the European Structural and Investment Funds and good economic governance: guidelines on the application of Article 23 of the Common Provisions Regulation because the European Parliament must guarantee democracy in the application of the macroeconomic conditionality provisions, and moreover, a constant reliable exchange of information between all stakeholders and full transparency at every stage of the process.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Abstention vote. The understanding of the macroeconomic framework in the definition of cohesion policy is positive, not to be seen as respecting austerity parameters. In general, given that member states' performance in implementing SRRs (country-specific recommendations) is poor, as evidenced by the Commission's assessments of the progress made in implementing the 279 SRRs issued in 2012 and 2013, I do not support a more general and comprehensive review of all cohesion policies.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I am concerned about the practical implications of European rescheduling and suspensions under Article 23 of the Common Provisions Regulation, in accordance with the so-called 'macroeconomic conditionality' rejected by the S&D Group, but incorporated in the last parliamentary term; and this, from the perspective that cohesion policy is often, in the context of the crisis, the only source of public investment in many regions.  The report gives an impact on guarantees for Article 23 to be used as a measure of last resort, considering that European solidarity should not be hindered by economic governance mechanisms. Beneficiaries of funds, regions and municipalities cannot be harmed by macroeconomic failures at higher levels of the Administration.  According to the report, the Eurochamber must be the main democratic guarantor of the proper application of the macro-conditionality of Article 23, with the Commission having to take into account its positions. The need for constant, clear and transparent interinstitutional collaboration is therefore underlined.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The Structural and Investment Funds have a considerable impact on the daily lives of European citizens. Thanks to them, citizens can undertake and implement their projects. However, it is very important to ensure that these funds are managed rigorously, so that they can actually serve their objectives. Macroeconomic conditionality has been instituted from this perspective. Good governance of a Member State is a prerequisite for the Structural Funds to be returned to local entities. These measures to reschedule or suspend funds by the European Commission are nevertheless very rare and subject to many criteria for determining a breach of the principle of good governance.  The aim of macroeconomic conditionality is to encourage Member States to implement the structural reforms necessary to turn the EU's economic activity around. The principle is laudable. However, care must be paid to ensure that decentralized, regional or municipal entities with some management autonomy do not suffer from poor decisions by a central state. I therefore voted in favour of this report, which stresses the need to exercise a high degree of caution in the use of macroeconomic conditionality.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the European Structural and Investment Funds and sound economic governance which contains guidelines for the implementation of Article 23 of the Regulation laying down common provisions. The report points out that Parliament is in favour of the total abolition of the provisions on macroeconomic conditionality, which places greater pressure on Member States already suffering from financial difficulties. Furthermore, macroeconomic conditionality and its application should not jeopardise or threaten the implementation of the fundamental principles of cohesion policy, such as economic, social and territorial cohesion. However, due to resistance from the Commission and the Council, the principle of macroeconomic conditionality has once again been incorporated into the Regulation laying down common provisions (DRCs). With this own-initiative report we cannot remove or amend the provisions of Article 23 CPR in the way that they appear in the regulation. However, the report can ensure that they are applied in the most justified and balanced way possible.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Article 23 of the Common Provision Regulations is a destructive mechanism that further entrenches austerity by linking cohesion funding to ‘sound economic governance’ – also known as ‘macro-economic conditionalities’. It allows funding programmes at a local or regional level to be suspended or ‘reprogrammed’ because of factors outside the control of those affected, such as national budget deficits. This would cause significant harm, particularly to vulnerable regions and Member States still suffering from the economic and social crisis. While the report is mildly critical and recommends some safeguards, it ultimately accepts the premise of ‘sound economic governance’ in the context of cohesion funding. For this reason, my colleague Martina Anderson tabled an alternative resolution on behalf of the GUE/NGL group calling for the mechanism not to be used and for its review, which unfortunately did not succeed. I also voted for a specific amendment, tabled by more than 76 MEPs, calling for the decoupling of this important funding from the calculation of national deficits. This amendment was also unsuccessful. As the report therefore endorses - if critically - a mechanism that will impose austerity policies on local and regional communities, I voted against the report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Article 23 of the CPR demonstrates the lack of democracy in the EU. The fact that the Commission can tell the Council to withdraw funding from a Member State without consulting the elected Parliament highlights the democratic deficit. The reality with this report is that there will be no change; if Parliament received more powers of ‘scrutiny’ from the Commission they would only be allowed to give an opinion and not fully go against the judgment of the Commission. Therefore we were against this legislation.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report covers the scope of the regulation concerning the mechanism of economic macro-management; this is the possibility for the Commission to ask a Member State to review and propose amending its partnership contract and relevant programmes, where necessary to implement Council recommendations or to maximise the impact on growth and competitiveness of the European Structural and Investment Funds (EIS) in Member States receiving financial assistance. The report could have expressed a clear and clear opposition to the mechanism itself, whereas it confines itself to a number of weak recommendations. An amendment we proposed calling for the demeri exchange of resources for cofinancing for the use of funds from the calculation of the public deficit in order to respect budgetary parity was also rejected. I therefore voted against the report.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The guidelines published by the European Commission on the implementation of macroeconomic conditionality give rise to many concerns and rekindle the political debate that had animated the approval of the regulations establishing the EIS Funds (for the 2014-2020 programming) subject to compliance with economic governance procedures. The Commission's power to require States with macroeconomic imbalances to reprogramme part of the funding and (as laid down in Article 23 of the Regulation on common provisions) to suspend payments could, if implemented, severely penalise the effectiveness of the Union's cohesion policy and affect the economic development of the regions, for many of which the Structural Funds are the only source of public funding. I believe that we must return to reopening, in the appropriate forums, the question of the possibility of excluding from the calculation of public deficits investments cofinanced by the ESI Funds; A request that my country has been asking for for some time. In view of the effects on the territories of the provisions of Article 23, I agree with Parliament's request to the Commission for Parliament to participate, also as an advisory body, in the processes of reprogramming and possible suspension of funds in order to ensure the correct application of the macroeconomic conditionality clause.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The report stresses the importance of cohesion policy instruments and resources in order to maintain the level of European value-added investment in member states and regions, as well as to enhance the creation of new jobs and improve socio-economic conditions, especially where investment has fallen significantly as a result of the economic and financial crisis.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I agree with the vast majority of my fellow Members about concerns about the practical consequences of reprogramming and suspending the EIS Funds under Article 23 CPR: a fair balance should be struck between the different visions of the macroeconomic conditionality mechanism. I am also convinced that it is appropriate to formalise Parliament's participation, as the main democratic guarantor of the correct application of the provisions - in line with Article 23 - and to give parliament the power to be consulted at all stages with regard to the adoption of requests for reprogramming or any proposals and decisions on the suspension of commitments or payments.  I stress the need for constant, clear and transparent cooperation at international level. Finally, regional or local authorities cannot be allowed to be penalised by reprogramming or suspending the Funds, with the consequent deterioration of their economic and social situation. I am convinced that these changes will ensure a proportionate response in order to avoid further disadvantages for regions already in difficulty.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Article 23 of the CPR demonstrates the lack of democracy in the EU. The fact that the Commission can tell the Council to withdraw funding from a Member State without consulting the elected Parliament highlights the democratic deficit. The reality with this report is that there will be no change; if Parliament received more powers of ‘scrutiny’ from the Commission they would only be allowed to give an opinion and not fully go against the judgment of the Commission. Therefore we were against this legislation.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Article 23 of the CPR demonstrates the lack of democracy in the EU. The fact that the Commission can tell the Council to withdraw funding from a Member State without consulting the elected Parliament highlights the democratic deficit. The reality with this report is that there will be no change; if Parliament received more powers of ‘scrutiny’ from the Commission they would only be allowed to give an opinion and not fully go against the judgment of the Commission. Therefore we were against this legislation.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. Cohesion policy has so far played the key role of promoting employment and improving socio-economic situations within Member States, and has also stimulated investment in line with the achievement of the Union's macroeconomic objectives. However, there are still many concerns about Article 23 of the regulation laying down common provisions, which would provide for the reprogramming and suspension of the EIS Funds. I agree with the rapporteur that frequent reprogramming would be counterproductive and that it should be avoided in order not to disrupt the management of the fund or to undermine the stability and predictability of the multiannual investment strategy. Therefore, the application of Article 23 should only take place in exceptional situations in order to achieve a sustainable and effective cohesion policy under the supervision of the European Parliament, as the main democratic guarantor of the correct application of the RCD's macroeconomic conditionality provisions.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report focuses on the scope of Article 23 of Regulation 1303/2013 on the mechanism of economic macro-conditionality, i.e. the possibility for the Commission to ask a Member State to review and propose to amend its partnership contract and relevant programmes, where necessary to support the implementation of the relevant Council recommendations or to maximise the impact on the growth and competitiveness of EIS funds in the Member States receiving financial assistance. Already during the negotiation of the regulation, in 2012-2013, the subject had been the subject of much criticism, as, in this way, the economic policy of a Member State could adversely affect the implementation of individual regional and national operational programmes. Following the weak report by the rapporteur, who preferred to confine himself to making a series of rather weak recommendations, without in any way calling into question the link between cohesion policy and sound economic governance and following the rejection of an amendment on the revision of the investment clause, I decided to vote against it.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report focuses on the Communication made by the European Commission on the guidelines for linking the Structural Funds with Article 23 of Regulation No 1303/2013, in which the Commission itself announces that aid from the Structural Funds must be closely linked to compliance with EU governance.  It thus justifies the rescheduling and suspension of funds to regions where the Member States to which they belong do not meet the criteria set by the European Semester to correct the degree of indebtedness (policies for cuts and reforms that close rights in labour law, among others).  Parliament's report legitimises the existence of so-called 'macro-conditionality' as a last resort. In addition, the vast majority of the Eurochamber voted in favour of declaring that economic governance instruments contribute to a 'stable macroeconomic environment', ignoring the dramatic effects of austerity measures on the European population, and on Spain in particular.  In fact, it was not even voted in favour of the proposal to eliminate the Structural Funds from a state's overall public deficit count. That is why, obviously, I voted against it.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am sorry to say, but I voted against the report because I thought, and I believe, that it was an excellent opportunity to relaunch the issue of a golden rule of investments made as cofinancing of the Structural Funds. We have wasted an excellent opportunity to give concrete form to the words that, all too often rashly and without fully understanding its meaning, we are repeating. We, as a Parliament, have spoken out against macroeconomic conditionality from the first moment. After a long battle, we have suffered that rule, at the behest of the Commission and the Council. We, first and foremost Socialists&Democrats, remain convinced that the Stability and Growth Pact, as it is, undermines a real investment policy and we therefore call for its revision, first and foremost to exclude the resources of cofinancing ESI funds. Unfortunately, we have lost, but the battle to allow states and regions to make the best use of the funds, free from the rigidities of austerity that has led to loss of investment and jobs, certainly does not end here.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Article 23 of EU Regulation No 1303/2013 provides for a procedure for reprogramming or optional suspension of structural and investment funds in its first part. There are legitimate concerns that the linguistic interpretation of a standard may lead to a breach of the principles of subsidiarity and partnership which underpin cohesion policy and to macroeconomic instability, to expose local and regional authorities directly or indirectly to negative economic and social consequences or to financial instability of regions in poor economic situation. The aim of this regulation was to ensure the most balanced and effective cohesion policy, which today is largely implemented in the Europe 2020 strategy. The current partnership agreements and programmes with the Member States focus on the implementation of that strategy, so the application of Article 23 when adopting a functional interpretation seems possible only in a situation justified by specific exceptional circumstances.  In view of my shared concern about the potential consequences of applying Article 23 in practice, I voted in favour of the resolution, which aims to ensure a reasoned and balanced application of the reprogramming procedure and to draw attention to the undefined role and insufficient participation of the European Parliament in this procedure.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the REGI Committee resolution since it highlighted the practical implications of the reprogramming and suspension of funding as a result of the macroeconomic failings of a national government. I believe that a balance should be kept between the need for effective economic governance and cohesion policy goals and this vote reflected exactly this.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the active role of the European Parliament in the application and control of the application of Article 23 must be highlighted and supported by transparent cooperation and efficient exchange of information throughout the process.  On the other hand, better institutional coordination between all administrations, together with simple and transparent reprogramming processes, are essential things to achieving the objectives of cohesion policy, given its role in maintaining investment in European regions.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report aims to clarify the conditions for the implementation of good governance measures concerning the effective use of European Structural and Investment Funds. The report calls on Member States to make the most of the flexibility provided by the current rules of the Stability and Growth Pact in the use of European Structural and Investment Funds. It also considers it essential to ensure transparency and accountability by giving Parliament democratic control of the governance system. Finally, the report calls for the creation of a Council configuration specifically dedicated to cohesion policy. Supporting these objectives, I voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Article 23 of the CPR demonstrates the lack of democracy in the EU. The fact that the Commission can tell the Council to withdraw funding from a Member State without consulting the elected Parliament highlights the democratic deficit. The reality with this report is that there will be no change; if Parliament received more powers of ‘scrutiny’ from the Commission they would only be allowed to give an opinion and not fully go against the judgment of the Commission. Therefore we were against this legislation.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report as I support the macroeconomic conditionality as a prerequisite of an effective cohesion policy. Member States should be applying the EU Economic Governance rules. These will enable them to increase the value for money of the cohesion policy. If they do not follow the rules the Commission will be able to request Member States to reprogramme funds or suspend them if the Member States do not take the required measures. It is a balanced compromise between different stakeholders.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report "European Structural and Investment Funds and Sound Economic Governance: Guidelines for the Implementation of Article 23 of the Common Provisions Regulation" during the plenary vote in Strasbourg. Article 23 is probably the most contented part of the Regulation on common provisions. The European Parliament's report recommended the deletion of all macroeconomic conditionality provisions from the text, but macroeconomic conditionality was nevertheless included in the final text of the common provisions. José Blanco López's report applies only to the first part of Article 23 (optional reprogramming, optional suspension of structural and investment fund payments). The European Commission also recognises that reprogramming should be strictly reduced to the minimum necessary and that the application of Article 23 should take into account the specific economic and social situation of the Member State.  The application of macroeconomic conditionality should be justified in order to achieve the objectives of cohesion policy for the region or regions in question. It is not acceptable for local and regional authorities to be penalised for reprogramming or suspending funds because macroeconomic conditions are not met at other levels of administration. The European Parliament should play an active role in monitoring the application of Article 23 on common provisions, which requires a constant, reliable flow of information between all relevant actors and full transparency at all stages of the process of possible application.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. I wished regarding the guidelines on the implementation of macro-economic conditionality in the frameworks of the Structural Funds to make, through my vote, a critique of this text which establishes a direct link between cohesion policy and the provisions of economic governance introduced by the Stability and Growth Pact, despite the constant opposition of local and regional authorities who point out that they are not responsible for the excessive national public deficits, since most of them are constitutionally obliged to balance their budgets. The ESI funds, which have a proven positive impact on growth, are one of the most concrete examples of the principle of European solidarity, the principle that underpins the Socialists' European commitment. They must be resolutely preserved. An overly dogmatic approach to convergence criteria is, in this case, to be excluded. How can we explain to the inhabitants of a territory that Europe does not support them because the burden of debt - for which they are not responsible but simply heirs - is considered too great? It is an unfair and unjustified double punishment. As a former regional president, I cannot bring myself to do that.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the Structural and Investment Funds consists mainly of a relaxation of the rules for suspending payments from those Funds. However, in advocating a case-by-case analysis, this report is unsatisfactory. Thus, it ignores opposition to a globalized economy and further perpetuates the policy of integrating the economic policies of sovereign countries into a macroeconomic package without legitimacy or effectiveness. Despite some interesting ideas, inconsistency dominates this report, which is why I abstained.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Good economic governance and its interconnection with the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIFs) has contributed to the ineffectiveness of cohesion policy, in particular Article 23 of the KKD and the suspension of punitive payments, since the situation of states and regions facing socio-economic difficulties as a result of the crisis is not taken into account. Practice has shown that the principles of proportionality and subsidiarity do not apply in the case of ESI Funds, in particular to country-specific recommendations, which fail to achieve economic growth and create sustainable growth and new jobs, which entails measures (additional austerity and reductions) contrary to cohesion policy objectives.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's co-rapporteurs for the Common Provisions Regulation have proposed the deletion of all provisions on macroeconomic conditionality. Several amendments have been tabled, for example, on behalf of several political groups in Parliament which also proposed the deletion of these provisions. However, macroeconomic conditionality was eventually incorporated into the Regulation. The agreement reached by Parliament, the Council and the Commission was adopted without it being possible to put to a vote the amendments aimed at its deletion. This own-initiative report does not make it possible to delete or amend the provisions of Article 23 of the DRC as set out in the Regulation. It can only ensure that those provisions are applied in the most justified and balanced way possible. I voted for it.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this vote because this report is not intended to remove the provisions on macroeconomic conditionality.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report proposes a reconciliation of the Strategic and Investment Funds (ESIF) and other EU cohesion instruments with what it calls "good economic governance", under the framework of the European Semester and its entire arsenal of conditioning of states' activity and macroeconomic policies – country-specific recommendations, reform plans, etc., without forgetting the "macroeconomic conditionality" itself , provided for in the Funds Regulation, which provides that payments and commitments of investment funds be suspended in the event of "non-compliance". The report contains positive aspects, such as: criticism of the suspension of funding (which admits, however, that it should be applied in exceptional cases and reveal greater "flexibility") and the recognition that the mechanisms associated with the European Semester affect the operationality and implementation of the ESI Funds and that the implementation of the mechanisms should not affect the policy objectives and targets of the ESI Funds. In a sense, you want to square the circle.  But the cross-cutting objective of the report is to ensure that the Mechanisms of the European Semester have a territorial and integrated dimension, also ensuring that it is more "democratic" (through control by the European Parliament), more flexibility and tolerance towards member states' non-compliance. In other words, in practice, the report accepts and wants to legitimise the unacceptable and illegitimate. We voted against it.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is essential that we do not forget the original mission and objectives of cohesion policy and its importance as a tool for maintaining investment in European regions, especially in times of economic crisis and instability. It is inconceivable that regional or local authorities should be punished by re-programming or suspending funds to the detriment of their economic and social situation due to failure to meet the relevant macroeconomic requirements at other levels of government. In the current programming period, cohesion policy is closely linked to the strategic objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy and to economic governance mechanisms such as the European Semester. This means that, in principle, partnership agreements and programmes introduced during this period should already be in line with the Union's broader macroeconomic objectives, as a result of which re-programming under Article 23 CPR should only be required in truly exceptional circumstances.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Good economic governance and its interconnection with the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIFs) has contributed to the ineffectiveness of cohesion policy, in particular Article 23 of the KKD and the suspension of punitive payments, taking into account the situation of States and regions facing socio-economic difficulties as a result of the crisis. Practice has shown that the principle of proportionality and subsidiarity do not apply in the case of ESI Funds, in particular to country-specific recommendations, which fail to achieve economic growth and create sustainable growth and new jobs, which entails measures (additional austerity and reductions) contrary to cohesion policy objectives. For these reasons I am voting against the European Structural Funds, the Investment Funds and good economic governance.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The provisions regarding measures between effectiveness of the ESI Funds and sound economic governance – the so called macro-economic conditionality – was a very controversial aspect of the Common Provisions regulation (CPR) during the last EP legislative term, which S&D and most of the political Groups rejected. However, the adopted CPR contain provisions (Art. 23) on sound economic governance. Many safeguards were obtained by the EP to make sure that this provision is only used as a ‘last resort’ measure. In the current programming period cohesion policy is closely linked with the goals of EU 2020 strategy and economic governance mechanisms. Partnership Agreements and Operational programmes for 2014-2020 should already be in line with EU macro-economic goals, making a (frequent) reprogramming unnecessary. Any reprogramming, if needed, should be kept as simple and transparent as possible. Regional and local authorities should not be punished, through reprogramming or suspension of funding, as a result of macroeconomic ‘failings’ of a national government. A balance should be kept between the need for effective economic governance and cohesion policy goals.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because, during the current programming period, cohesion policy is closely linked to the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy and to the mechanisms of economic governance, such as the European Semester. This means that the partnership agreements and programmes under this period should in principle already be in line with the wider macroeconomic objectives of the Union, which means that reprogramming under the Common Provisions Regulation is unnecessary and can only take place in exceptional circumstances. I welcome the prioritisation of the principles of subsidiarity, transparency and proportionality, as well as the subethical dimension of cohesion policy. Finally, we need to limit the possible additional administrative burdens and expenses that may result from the application of Article 23 of the Common Provisions Regulation. In agreement with the rapporteur, Parliament should play an active role in overseeing the application of Article 23 of the Common Provisions Regulation, which requires a constant and reliable flow of information between all relevant actors and full transparency at all stages of the process.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour considering that it is imperative that we take into account the original role and objectives of cohesion policy and its importance as an instrument for maintaining investment in europe's regions, especially in times of economic crisis and instability.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. – I am concerned about the practical implications of rescheduling and suspension of European funds under Article 23 of the Common Provisions Regulation, in accordance with the so-called 'macroeconomic conditionality' rejected by the S&D Group, but incorporated in the last parliamentary term; and this, from the perspective that cohesion policy is often, in the context of the crisis, the only source of public investment in many regions.  The report gives an impact on guarantees for Article 23 to be used as a measure of last resort, considering that European solidarity should not be hindered by economic governance mechanisms. Beneficiaries of funds, regions and municipalities cannot be harmed by macroeconomic failures at higher levels of the Administration.  According to the report, the Eurochamber must be the main democratic guarantor of the proper application of the macro-conditionality of Article 23, with the Commission having to take into account its positions. The need for constant, clear and transparent interinstitutional collaboration is therefore underlined.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted strongly in favour of the resolution on simplifying cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020, because it is a pressing necessity to increase the spending capacity of the regions and the effectiveness of cohesion policy as a whole. The new regulations already offer opportunities for simplifying and lightening administrative burdens. The Commission's initiative aims to help Member States make effective use of funds and invest, emphasises strengthening the administrative capacities of implementing bodies, reducing territorial disparities and helping regions experiencing a slowdown in growth to enable them to catch up, and assessing simplification measures. Nevertheless, the national and regional managing authorities are faced with an excess of rules to be followed, hence the urgent need for greater rationalisation and harmonisation of standards, but also flexibility, proportionality and results-based management. The current context based on a multi-fund strategy is welcome. It would be desirable to move on to common procedures, just as there should be a single flow of funds that meets all needs at local level, a one-stop shop with a single source of funding up to local and regional level.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on structural and investment funds and sound economic governance. Macroeconomic conditionality can also be an effective step towards successfully implementing and adapting cohesion policy.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ European Structural and Investment Funds are a crucial tool for strengthening economic, social and territorial cohesion in the EU and for reducing disparities between regions, promoting a balanced and harmonious socio-economic development. I voted in favour of this report given the close linkage between the ESI funds and the economic governance of the EU is needed to ensure that the effectiveness of EU expenditure is underpinned by sound economic policies. I welcome the fact that EU support can, if necessary, be redirected to address new emerging economic and social challenges.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: In writing. This report highlights the importance of European Structural Funds, which accounted for up to 80% of public investment in some Member States between 2007 and 2013. It also draws attention to the need for good governance of these European funds in order to maximise their positive effects on economic, social and territorial cohesion. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the report on the European Structural and Investment Funds proposed by José Blanco López. We understand that it does not take charge — given the final composition adopted by the text during the vote, in its amendment phase — of the problems and debt crises of countries with severe economic crises. Our amendments had to do with funds for countries with severe crises not counting as the country's debt. We understand that, without this extra mechanism, the functioning of the Structural Funds loses meaning and simply becomes another mechanism, not of solidarity, but of tying in the form of debt of the States participating in the fund.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with my colleagues in the EPLP, voted in favour of this report. The close link between the ESI funds and the economic governance of the EU ensures that the effectiveness of EU expenditure is underpinned by sound economic policies. EU support can, if necessary, be redirected to address new emerging economic and social challenges.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that cohesion policy is essential as an instrument to maintain investment in European regions, particularly in a context of economic crisis and instability. While good economic governance is necessary, such mechanisms should not impede the pursuit of the broader objectives of economic, social and territorial cohesion. It is in this same spirit that I also voted in favour of Amendment No 1, which I co-signed, calling for the exclusion of regional and national investments, co-financed under the ESI funds, from the calculation of national deficits, within the framework of the Stability and Growth Pact. I am in fact opposed to this mechanism of macroeconomic conditionality which can only impose a double unfair sanction on local and regional authorities, which are not responsible for excessive national public deficits, since most of them are constitutionally obliged to balance their budgets.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the report on European Structural and Investment Funds and sound economic governance because it emphasises the importance of cohesion policy instruments and resources in maintaining the level of European added-value investment in Member States and regions for enhancing job creation and improving socio-economic conditions, especially where investment has fallen significantly owing to the economic and financial crisis

text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report as it successfully manages to clarify several elements of the application of the first strand of Article 23 and intends to ensure that the provisions are applied in a justified and balanced manner. While recognising the need for effective economic governance, such mechanisms should not hinder the pursuit of the broader goals of economic, social and territorial cohesion.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ On behalf of the local enterprise partnerships, businesses and local authorities in my East of England constituency, I want to record my concern about any provisions for suspension of European Structural and Investment funding.  I have been proud to work to help attract one third of a billion to my own region in the last six years, which has played a crucial role at a time of economic crisis. Already, Britain’s Conservative Government has been last in line to get agreement for its operational plan to spend this EU funding in the next period.  We must not allow regions to be punished, via the reprogramming or suspension of funding and consequent further deterioration for jobs and business, because of delays and obstructions which are the responsibility of government not of the region. The British Government may be reluctant to claim and spend this money. On behalf of my region, we are not.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Proposal for a Resolution of the European Parliament on european structural and investment funds and good economic governance: guidelines for the application of Article 23 of the Regulation. the CSR, as this document recalls that decisions concerning reprogramming or suspension in accordance with Article 23 of the Regulation are not a good idea. CSOs may apply only in exceptional situations and must be measured and thoroughly justified and implemented cautiously, with a clear indication of which programmes or priorities they relate to.  It is further emphasised that such decisions should not exacerbate the difficulties encountered by regions and Member States due to the socio-economic environment or the geographical location and specifics within the meaning of Articles 174 and 349 of the TFEU.  Furthermore, this document stresses that, in principle, reprogramming should be avoided in the medium term if economic conditions do not deteriorate significantly, that frequent reprogramming would be counterproductive and should be avoided so as not to hamper fund management or undermine the stability and predictability of the multiannual investment strategy, and to avoid any negative effects, including on the utilization of ESI Funds.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report provides details on the use of Article 23 of the Regulation on Common Provisions for European Structural and Investment Funds.  Substantially, Mr Lopez's report insists that the application of this article should be done in a balanced manner. For this reason, it rightly states that constant reprogramming should be avoided and that the suspension of payment mechanism, which is a discretion of the Commission, remains exceptional. In addition, the report calls on the Commission to present a white paper which analyses the benefits and effectiveness of long-term public investment. In the hope that it will force the Commission, an independent study would nevertheless be desirable.  Nevertheless, this report places all the responsibility for the increase in public debt on the budgetary policies of the Member States, while the European Union has a great deal of responsibility, notably through its monetary policy... The cohesion policy touted in the report has not been a factor in growth.  I abstained.

Therefore we were against this legislation.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by my colleague José Blanco Lopez on the link between European structural funds and good economic governance. This report follows the publication by the European Commission of guidelines on provisions linking the effectiveness of structural funds to good economic governance, contained in Article 23 of the Regulation on provisions common to the various funds. In other words, this is "macroeconomic conditionality," the principle of which was enacted in the last Parliament. The report as we voted for it is a good report which has been the subject of a compromise between socialists and centre-right. On the one hand, he remains firm on the question of the stability of the macroeconomic environment, stability which can only increase the effectiveness of cohesion policy. On the other hand, it argues that the reprogramming or suspension of funds should apply only as a last resort in order to contribute to the effective implementation of the funds. In this sense, it reminds us that regions and beneficiaries should not be penalised for the mismanagement of their Member States.  The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to ensure a justified and balanced application of the provisions conditioning the Structural Funds on compliance with the Stability and Growth Pact. Structural funds should only be used in a context of good economic governance at a time of fiscal restraint.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I do not agree with this report, although it seems to bring improvements and efficiency improvements. Nevertheless, it does not lead to a change in cohesion policy.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as the close linkage between the ESI funds and the economic governance of the EU ensures that the effectiveness of EU expenditure is underpinned by sound economic policies.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the current legal framework of the European Structural and Investment Funds (ISF Funds) aims to strengthen coordination with other EU policies and instruments. We must not lose sight of the original role and objectives of cohesion policy, as well as its importance as a means of maintaining investment in Europe's regions, especially in times of crisis and instability. I have therefore decided to vote in favour of the report, believing that the achievement of the strategic objectives of the EIS Funds should not be hindered by economic governance mechanisms.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. This Blanco Lopez report concerns the European Structural and Investment Funds for Good Economic Governance, which echoes the Commission's communication on "guidelines on the application of measures linking the effectiveness of the European Structural and Investment Funds".  While this text aims to limit the Commission's power over the macroeconomic conditionality of aid, it does not remove these unacceptable provisions and will effectively strengthen the Commission's grip by promoting blackmail to austerity. Moreover, this report rests the increase in public debt solely on the policies of the Member States, while the majority comes from a transfer of private debt to the public, reinforced by the austere policy demanded by Brussels. However, I abstained because it diminishes the scope of the text presented by the Commission.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report focuses on the Communication made by the European Commission on the guidelines for linking the Structural Funds with Article 23 of Regulation No 1303/2013, in which the Commission itself announces that aid from the Structural Funds must be closely linked to compliance with EU governance.  It thus justifies the rescheduling and suspension of funds to regions where the Member States to which they belong do not meet the criteria set by the European Semester to correct the degree of indebtedness (policies for cuts and reforms that close rights in labour law, among others).  Parliament's report legitimises the existence of so-called 'macro-conditionality' as a last resort. In addition, the vast majority of the Eurochamber voted in favour of declaring that economic governance instruments contribute to a 'stable macroeconomic environment', ignoring the dramatic effects of austerity measures on the European population, and on Spain in particular.  In fact, it was not even voted in favour of the proposal to eliminate the Structural Funds from a state's overall public deficit count. That is why, obviously, I voted against it.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The reprogramming or suspension of structural and investment funds pursuant to Article 23 of the Common Provisions Regulation should only be used in exceptional circumstances. It is a sanction measure and that is why we need such decisions to be carefully assessed and explained in a transparent manner. Cohesion policy is an essential tool in maintaining investment in European regions. As the Commission states, reprogramming should only take place in cases where it is very clear that it has a greater impact than the existing allocation of funds. Romania is one of the countries for which the absorption of structural funds is an important objective. At the end of this year we will no longer have access to unused money from the 2007-2013 programming period. Part of the failure is related to economic governance mechanisms, but part is certainly reflected in the bureaucratic mess and the change in the rules during the game. That is why, when we are talking about sanctions, I believe that we must do so in the light of the multiannual and long-term nature of the programmes and the objectives of the funds, adapting ourselves to the socio-economic conditions of each country. Responsible solidarity, that is my message.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Good economic governance and financial stability are prerequisites for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth and development – the ultimate goal of all EUROPEAN Union policies and strategies. The ESI Funds are essential for the implementation of cohesion policy, which is the EU's main investment and development policy. A stable fiscal and economic environment is a basic precondition for the effective and successful implementation of cohesion policy in practice. To ensure this, our common objective must be to function well, simplify procedures, better coordinate and connect all EU policies and connect between Member States. In this context, it is also important to launch all mechanisms to prevent the loss of funds, namely the revocation of appropriations granted to Member States. I supported the ESI Funds And Good Economic Governance Report, as no EU policy can succeed in the long term without good economic governance, unity and partnership.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Structural and Investment Funds are an integral and one of the most important part of cohesion policy, investing resources in the development of economic, social and other sectors on a regional basis. Therefore, rational and general analysis-based action on economic governance is very necessary in the context of the implementation of Article 23 of the Common Provisions Regulation. Article 23 shall apply, among other things, to national action in the use of the European Structural and Investment Funds, where it may be necessary to take decisions on the rescheduling of the resources of the Funds or to suspend non-compliance with certain provisions by the beneficiaries of such resources. While the European Union, like any other body, is occupied by transparency and the promotion of enforcement, it is often precisely because of very strict rules that the bureaucratic burden and the associated costs increase significantly. As the thematic concentration rules for the 2014-2020 EU Cohesion Policy allow for a certain degree of flexibility in realising the needs of EU Member States and regions, the full implementation of Article 23 in practice may not result in this flexibility, which in part undermines the effective implementation of the cohesion policy measures themselves. In the light of the above, and in the report itself, I join in calling on the European Commission to respect, as far as possible, the principle of proportionality in the application of Article 23, so that, incidentally, it does not conflict with other aspects of its coordinated policies, including cohesion policy in particular.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the European Structural and Investment Funds and good economic governance: guidelines for the implementation of Article 23 of the Regulation laying down common provisions, because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report. Some good points emerge because it tends to limit the power of the Commission and recalls the exceptional nature of the payment suspension mechanism, as well as the counter-productivity of frequent reprogramming. However, it also refuses to acknowledge the Commission's responsibility for increasing public debt and falsely claims that cohesion policy has played a crucial role and has made it possible to respond significantly to current macroeconomic and budgetary constraints!

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support these guidelines for this European-level funding which is of crucial importance for regeneration across the EU including in Scotland and the rest of the UK. The funds aim to strengthen economic, social and territorial cohesion in the EU by reducing inequalities between regions. Learning from best practice with these funds is important, as is redirecting them when needed so the EU can respond to emerging economic and social challenges.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr Lopez's report stresses the importance of investment and economic cohesion instruments to promote development and employment levels in the Member States. I consider these issues to be of fundamental importance in view of the serious socio-economic situation that characterises the European Union at the moment and, therefore, I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution. Among other things, with this in mind, it reiterates the need to clarify the mechanisms for implementing the multiannual EIS Funds in stark contrast to the Annual European Cycle.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report makes justified criticisms. Also some improvements and an increase in efficiency. However, the report does not bring any change to cohesion policy, which we are opposed to. That is why I do not support this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report deals with Article 23 of the Cohesion Policy Regulation (RPC), the macro-economic conditionality, which links cohesion policy to the rules of economic governance. That is, the rules of the authorities. These macro-conditionalities have been renamed "measures linking cohesion policy to economic governance" after trilogues, but that doesn't change anything! The report criticises this mechanism, for example, by acknowledging the risks it poses to regions, particularly the most vulnerable. The criticism comes a little late and after the Socialist Group has supported these macro-conditionalities that chain the structural funds to austerity. I am voting against this hypocritical text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of the report is to clarify the use of Article 23 of the Regulation on common provisions relating to the European Structural and Investment Fund. The text of the report insists that the application of this article should be done in a balanced manner. For this reason, it rightly states that constant reprogramming should be avoided and that the suspension of payment mechanism, which is a discretion of the Commission, remains exceptional. In addition, the report calls on the Commission to present a white paper which analyses the benefits and effectiveness of long-term public investment. Together with my colleagues, we hope that this will force the Commission. However, an independent study would be welcome.  The report places all the responsibility for the increase in public debt on the budgetary policies of the Member States, while the European Union also has its share of responsibility, notably through its aberrant monetary policy. The cohesion policy touted in the report has brought neither prosperity nor growth.  Because this text limits the Commission's room for manoeuvre, the Member abstained despite his disagreement on European economic governance.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I share the view that the existence of a stable macroeconomic environment is conducive to the correct and successful implementation of the European Structural and Investment Funds. The reprogramming process can be costly and difficult to manage by national, local and regional administrations, so the use of the Article 23 procedure of the Regulation should be done in exceptional cases, avoiding the creation of situations of financial instability and uncertainty. I voted in favour of the report submitted, regretting that the European Parliament does not play a more active role in monitoring the implementation of the mechanism of that article.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as the goals of the European Structural and Investment Funds should not be hindered by economic governance mechanisms, especially since the current ESI Funds should be in line the strategic goals of the Europe 2020 Strategy. Even though I am firmly in favour of a stable macroeconomic environment, macroeconomic conditionality should be applied in the most justified and balanced manner possible. I also support the idea that the Parliament should be involved when it comes to ensuring that the provisions on macroeconomic conditionality within the Common Provisions Regulation are applied correctly.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The legal framework of the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI Funds) aims to strengthen coordination between the various EU instruments. Good governance is essential for effective economic growth and for creating stable jobs.  This report aims at a proper implementation of the reprogramming of Article 23 of the Common Provisions Regulation (DRC). The aim is to make the most fair and balanced use of the article 23 measures. It is essential not to lose sight of the role of cohesion policy as an instrument to maintain investment in European regions. Cohesion policy is essential because it covers all regions. By focusing on reducing territorial, social and economic disparities, it is aimed directly at investment in the real economy.  Even if good economic governance is necessary, Article 23 of the DRC should not lead to further financial uncertainty and instability, which in turn would exacerbate the precarious situation of disadvantaged regions or those most affected by the crisis. That is why it seems necessary that the measures written in this report be implemented quickly.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the European structural and Investment Funds and sound economic governance, because in the current programming period cohesion policy is closely linked with the goals of EU 2020 strategy and economic governance mechanisms. Any reprogramming, if needed, should be kept as simple and transparent as possible. Moreover, regional and local authorities should not be punished, through reprogramming or suspension of funding. A balance should be kept between the need for effective economic governance and cohesion policy goals.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The rules on measures linking the effectiveness of the European Structural and Investment (ESI) Funds with sound economic governance laid down in Article 23 of the Regulation adopted during the previous legislative term are rather contradictory. In their co-rapporteur report on the Regulation on common provisions, the European Parliament proposed that all provisions on macroeconomic conditionality should be deleted. The same was proposed by the amendment tabled by several political groups in Parliament. Opponents of macroeconomic conditionality were overwhelmingly opposed. Nevertheless, macroeconomic conditionality appears to have ultimately remained part of the Regulation. If the Regulation is adopted at first reading as a result of an agreement between Parliament, the Council and the Commission, amendments to their abolition shall not be voted on. Parliament's Committee on Regional Development stresses that this own-initiative report is not capable of either abolishing or amending the provisions of Article 23 of the Common Provisions Regulation. Its aim is only to ensure that they are applied in the most reasoned and balanced way possible. I supported the motion for a resolution.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the previous period of cohesion policy negotiations, the various groups of the European Parliament expressed their reservations about the introduction of macroeconomic conditionality which allows a suspension of structural fund payments to be activated when a Member State is in breach of European economic rules. However, macroeconomic conditionality was eventually introduced into the Cohesion Policy Fund Regulation and several amendments to the initial mode of operation were adopted. I therefore vote in favour of this report which allows for greater interconnection between the Funds and Economic Governance, while safeguarding that the achievement of the policy objectives and targets of the European Funds should not be undermined by economic governance mechanisms.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This Report whiteo Lopez concerns the European Structural and Investment Funds for Good Economic Governance, which echoes the Commission's communication on "guidelines on the application of measures linking the effectiveness of the European Structural and Investment Funds". While this text aims to limit the Commission's power over the macroeconomic conditionality of aid, it does not remove these unacceptable provisions and will effectively strengthen the Commission's grip by promoting blackmail to austerity. Moreover, this report rests the increase in public debt solely on the policies of the Member States, while the majority comes from a transfer of private debt to the public, reinforced by the austere policy demanded by Brussels. However, I abstained because it diminishes the scope of the text presented by the Commission.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report; the close linkage between the ESI funds and the economic governance of the EU ensures that the effectiveness of EU expenditure is underpinned by sound economic policies. EU support can, if necessary, be redirected to address new emerging economic and social challenges.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI) and good economic governance. The text calls on Member States to make the most of the flexibility provided by the existing rules of the Stability and Growth Pact, while stressing the need to involve local and regional authorities in any reprogramming exercise. However, it recommends that these reprogrammings be limited to the bare minimum. It is indeed important to ensure the stability of the macroeconomic environment, which can only increase the effectiveness of cohesion policy.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will ensure that the main objective of cohesion is not affected and will gather and analyse data on the interactions between European economic governance processes and the aims and results of cohesion policy.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Article 23 of the Common Provision Regulations is a destructive mechanism that further entrenches austerity by linking cohesion funding to ‘sound economic governance’ – also known as ‘macro-economic conditionalities’. It allows funding programmes at a local or regional level to be suspended or ‘reprogrammed’ because of factors outside the control of those affected, such as national budget deficits. This would cause significant harm, particularly to vulnerable regions and Member States still suffering from the economic and social crisis. While the report is mildly critical and recommends some safeguards, it ultimately accepts the premise of ‘sound economic governance’ in the context of cohesion funding. For this reason, my colleague Martina Anderson tabled an alternative resolution on behalf of the GUE/NGL group calling for the mechanism not to be used and for its review, which unfortunately did not succeed.
