I also voted for a specific amendment, tabled by more than 76 MEPs, calling for the decoupling of this important funding from the calculation of national deficits. This amendment was also unsuccessful. As the report therefore endorses - if critically - a mechanism that will impose austerity policies on local and regional communities, I voted against the report.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I think this report is a useful one because it highlights the importance of the Structural and Investment Funds for the economies of many Member States, but at the same time draws attention to the need for good governance in order for these funds to bring the maximum benefits.  It is also very important to understand that certain economic governance mechanisms, while relevant to macroeconomic stability, can prevent ESIFunds from achieving their objectives. At the same time, it is important that the measures taken at both EU and Member State level have long-term stability and clarity, as most of the projects financed by these funds extend over long periods of time and can be easily affected by current economic decisions.  In this context, we considered this report to be coherent and useful for the debate on the 2014-2020 budget year.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report on the European Structural and Investment Fund and sound economic governance, while at first sight, includes improvements and an increase in efficiency, but does not change the associated shortcomings in cohesion policy. On the contrary, it strengthens them, which made me vote against this report.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report deals with Article 23 of the Cohesion Policy Regulation dealing with macroconditionalities. Macroconditionalities allow the European Commission to block the funding of European programmes for a Member State entering excessive deficit proceedings under the Stability and Growth Pact. The report makes some criticisms against the application of these macroconditionalities on cohesion policy, which by its nature should not be subject to a logic of fiscal austerity, given its solidarity and investment dimension. But these criticisms do not go far enough and come very late. We had tried, during the negotiations on the cohesion policy regulation, to protect the most vulnerable and dependent regions of the European Structural Funds, but our institution has not managed to exclude them from this scheme. In addition, I wanted to include in this initiative report a proposal to exclude national co-financing of the European Funds from the calculation of the Member States' deficit. This proposal was not accepted. For these reasons, I am voting against this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. It is important that decisions on reallocation or suspension are used only in exceptional circumstances and must be considered and justified.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – Particular attention must be paid to economic governance mechanisms. It should be noted that a stable macroeconomic environment ensures the successful use of the European Structural and Investment Funds. Clarity on the mechanisms for implementing the European Semester must be ensured. However, this mechanism should only be used as a last resort and in strict compliance with the principles of proportionality and equal treatment. Any reprogramming in the medium term should be avoided, as this process is costly and difficult to administer. It is essential to ensure that the support provided is properly distributed and exploited in order to achieve the implementation of a results-oriented cohesion policy. It should be noted that the suspension of payment appropriations would have a particularly negative impact on economically vulnerable countries. Moreover, it would not be appropriate to stop funding from EU funds supporting education, training and job creation.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Article 23 of the CPR demonstrates the lack of democracy in the EU. The fact that the Commission can tell the Council to withdraw funding from a Member State without consulting the elected Parliament highlights the democratic deficit. The reality with this report is that there will be no change; if Parliament received more powers of ‘scrutiny’ from the Commission they would only be allowed to give an opinion and not fully go against the judgment of the Commission. Therefore we were against this legislation.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Reiterating also in this Chamber that, in an era marked by economic crises and financial instability, Europe must make every effort to ensure the full implementation of cohesion policy, I have decided to give my vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. The CSR 1303/2013/EU provides for a mechanism by which the European Union monitors the efficient use of funds and the fulfilment of budgetary finance priorities from the European Structural and Investment Funds. Precisely because of the importance of controlling the fulfilment of the objective and purpose of European policies, the Committee on Regional Development submitted a report on its own initiative, stressing the importance of the application of Article 23 of the EEU. regulation to verify sound economic governance. Given the need to ensure a stable macroeconomic environment that can only increase the efficiency of cohesion policy, I support the adopted position so that the efficiency of the use of funds must be valued through the process of verifying good economic governance in accordance with the guidelines for the application of Article 23. Regulations on common provisions, but only as a last resort due to the necessary flexibility and consistently applying the order of steps laid down in that Article, taking into account in particular the existing rules agreed by the Stability and Growth Pact. Namely, precisely because of the necessary stability, it should not be allowed uncontrollably that significant reprogramming of the use of structural and investment funds is taking place, and I welcome the observance of the precautionary principle represented by the Commission by introducing mandatory consultations if the need for such reprogramming arises, which is well regulated by the aforementioned Article of the Regulation.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This Blanco Lopez report concerns the European Structural and Investment Funds for Good Economic Governance, which echoes the Commission's communication on "guidelines on the application of measures linking the effectiveness of the European Structural and Investment Funds". While this text aims to limit the Commission's power over the macroeconomic conditionality of aid, it does not remove these unacceptable provisions and will effectively strengthen the Commission's grip by promoting blackmail to austerity. Moreover, this report rests the increase in public debt solely on the policies of the Member States, while the majority comes from a transfer of private debt to the public, reinforced by the austere policy demanded by Brussels. However, I abstained because it diminishes the scope of the text presented by the Commission.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ In the case of linking the efficiency of the European Structural and Investment Funds and sound economic governance under Article 23 of the EIA, Regulation on common provisions, the main challenge is to ensure how to limit macroeconomic conditionality in terms of reprogramming and suspension of structural and investment funds. Since it cannot be expelled, I agree with the rapporteur and support the requirement that it be used solely as a last resort.  The task of economic, social and territorial cohesion is particularly important in times of crisis and should not be questioned by the demands for effective economic governance. As cohesion policy is closely linked to the objectives of the EU 2020 strategy, it should already be aligned with broader economic objectives, which calls into question the need for further restructuring.  Particularly important is the regional, sub-state level of cohesion policy at which the security of funds should be preserved, especially given the crisis and the fact that this is often their main source of funding and cannot be held accountable for the national macroeconomic situation.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ It is necessary to stress that we are in a crisis period where investment levels are decreasing and cohesion policy is considered essential to increase investment in Member States and regions. At the same time, multiannual programmes financed by structural and investment funds need a stable macroeconomic environment, including high-quality governance at all levels.  I therefore welcome the Commission's cautious approach, which is necessary when it comes to reprogramming and its intention to limit reprogramming to the necessary minimum. Frequent reprogramming would be counterproductive and I believe that it should be avoided in order not to be prevented from managing the funds and to avoid any negative effects, among which those relating to the usability of the ESI Funds should definitely be singled out. I agree that all decisions concerning reprogramming or suspension in accordance with Article 23 of the Regulation are not agreed. The CSOs should be used in exceptional cases, thoroughly justified, measured and swiftly implemented to ensure transparency and allow for screening and auditing. Parliament's involvement should be formalised for the purpose of a clear procedure allowing parliament to be notified at all stages in relation to the adoption of reprogramming applications or any proposals and decisions suspending obligations or payments.  Consequently, I support the report.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the European Parliament should play an active role in overseeing the implementation of Article 23 of the Regulation laying down common provisions (DRCs). The guidelines examined in this report relate exclusively to the first part of Article 23 of the Regulation on the reprogramming or suspension of optional European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIEs). Bearing in mind that regional or local authorities can be penalised, by reprogramming or suspending these funds, with the consequent deterioration of their economic and social situation, we must ensure a proportionate response in order to avoid harming regions that are already in difficulty. I voted in favour of this report because the Commission seems to agree that reprogramming must be reduced to the bare minimum. In my opinion, the only objective of Article 23 CPR should be to achieve a more sustainable and efficient cohesion policy.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Allowing funds to be suspended by countries that do not respect budgetary discipline, in accordance with Article 23 of the CIS, is the most controversial and unsupported provision of the package of regulations. Without being able to amend this Regulation, the European Parliament shall endea slyly to ensure that it is applied in the most justified and balanced manner. It is worth pointing out that the guidelines in the report refer only to the first part of Article 23 and concern the optional reprogramming or suspension of the Structural and Investment Funds and not to the second part on the mandatory suspension of funds. Furthermore, the report stresses the need to reduce reprogramming to the minimum necessary and stresses that the specific and important economic situations of the Member States must be taken into account when Article 23 is applied. Any proposal for macroeconomic conditionality should be transparent, justified and clearly beneficial for the objectives of cohesion policy for the region or regions concerned. I therefore supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has spoken in favour of the text on European Structural and Investment Funds and good economic governance. I voted for this text and I stress the importance of good economic governance enabling healthier management of European funds.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Article 23 of the CPR demonstrates the lack of democracy in the EU. The fact that the Commission can tell the Council to withdraw funding from a Member State without consulting the elected Parliament highlights the democratic deficit. The reality with this report is that there will be no change; if Parliament received more powers of ‘scrutiny’ from the Commission they would only be allowed to give an opinion and not fully go against the judgment of the Commission. Therefore we were against this legislation.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I am concerned about the practical implications of European rescheduling and suspensions under Article 23 of the Common Provisions Regulation, in accordance with the so-called 'macroeconomic conditionality' rejected by the S&D Group, but incorporated in the last parliamentary term; and this, from the perspective that cohesion policy is often, in the context of the crisis, the only source of public investment in many regions.  The report gives an impact on guarantees for Article 23 to be used as a measure of last resort, considering that European solidarity should not be hindered by economic governance mechanisms. Beneficiaries of funds, regions and municipalities cannot be harmed by macroeconomic failures at higher levels of the Administration.  According to the report, the Eurochamber must be the main democratic guarantor of the proper application of the macro-conditionality of Article 23, with the Commission having to take into account its positions. The need for constant, clear and transparent interinstitutional collaboration is therefore underlined.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Article 23 of Regulation 1303/2013, with common provisions, relates to measures linking the effectiveness of ESI Funds to good economic governance. This article is very important because it allows the Commission to ask a Member State to review its partnership agreement and the programmes concerned in certain circumstances or to suggest to the Council the suspension of part of the payments and commitments. I have decided to vote in favour because I believe in particular that decisions to reschedule or suspend Article 23 of the DRC should only be taken in exceptional cases. I also welcome the Commission's statements, which intend to limit them to the bare minimum.  However, I regret the rejection of Amendment No 1 by a majority of the European Parliament calling for the investment clause to be revised, so that regional and national investments co-financed under the ESI Funds can be excluded from the calculation of national deficits under the European Semester. It is sometimes difficult or impossible for a country to free up money to co-finance a project (co-financing that is mandatory) given the EU's accounting rules.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In an area where ideological divisions are quite evident, this own-initiative report has gained broad support from this House, with 482 votes in favour - a fact that shows well the effort of balance and unity made by the rapporteur. The adopted text seeks to clarify a number of elements relating to the implementation of the first part of Article 23 of the Regulation on Common Provisions (on the practical implications of the reprogramming and suspension of the European Structural and Investment Funds - ESIF), adopted in the previous mandate. In this sense, the rapporteur calls for them to be applied "in the most justified and balanced way possible" and that the provisions of this article be used only as a "last resort" and only to give greater efficiency and effectiveness to the ESI Funds. Further involvement is also called for the local and regional authorities to be involved in reprogramming exercises, but also of the European Parliament, in the context of the process of scrutinising the whole governance system provided for in Article 23. Because I believe that the rapporteur has proposed a weighted text and which expresses a comprehensive position of the European Parliament, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which sets out several elements concerning the application of the first part of Article 23 and aims to ensure a justified and balanced application of the provisions. Article 23 of the Regulation on Common Provisions contains provisions on measures linking the effectiveness of European structural and investment funds to good economic governance.  We have always stressed the importance of the stability of the macroeconomic environment as this stability increases the effectiveness of cohesion policy, but it should also be noted that provisions linking the effectiveness of ESI funds to good economic governance should apply only as a last resort, following all the steps enshrined in Article 23.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that good economic governance and an effective cohesion policy are fundamental instruments for dealing with and overcoming the economic crisis affecting the Member States of the European Union. The report urges the European Parliament to be the main democratic guarantor of the correct implementation of Article 23 of Regulation 1303/2013 on the mechanism of macro-economic conditionality.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the report on the European Structural and Investment Funds proposed by José Blanco López. We understand that it does not take charge — given the final composition adopted by the text during the vote, in its amendment phase — of the problems and debt crises of countries with severe economic crises. Our amendments had to do with funds for countries with severe crises not counting as the country's debt. We understand that, without this extra mechanism, the functioning of the Structural Funds loses meaning and simply becomes another mechanism, not of solidarity, but of tying in the form of debt of the States participating in the fund.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report focuses on the Communication made by the European Commission on the guidelines for linking the Structural Funds with Article 23 of Regulation No 1303/2013, in which the Commission itself announces that aid from the Structural Funds must be closely linked to compliance with EU governance.  It thus justifies the rescheduling and suspension of funds to regions where the Member States to which they belong do not meet the criteria set by the European Semester to correct the degree of indebtedness (policies for cuts and reforms that close rights in labour law, among others).  Parliament's report legitimises the existence of so-called 'macro-conditionality' as a last resort. In addition, the vast majority of the Eurochamber voted in favour of declaring that economic governance instruments contribute to a 'stable macroeconomic environment', ignoring the dramatic effects of austerity measures on the European population, and on Spain in particular.  In fact, it was not even voted in favour of the proposal to eliminate the Structural Funds from a state's overall public deficit count. That is why, obviously, I voted against it.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. The Structural Funds are a key instrument for promoting territorial and economic cohesion and for the recovery of the economy of countries with macroeconomic imbalances. Economic governance recommendations in these cases should take this into account and ensure that regions are safeguarded as a recipient of these funds.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as it would hand more power to the EU Parliament, which I do not wish to see happen.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The current programming period for the cohesion policy is closely linked with the goals of the EU 2020 strategy and economic governance mechanisms. The rapporteur, from my group, did a very good job on this report and I’m happy to see it pass in Plenary. The implications of the ESI Funds are massive in my region, and will strengthen the need to see a devolved assembly in the West Midlands.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the case of the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the European Structural and Investment Funds and sound economic governance, on guidelines for the implementation of Article 23 of the CCT Regulation, I voted in favour of adopting this resolution, in line with the position of the ECR. We must not forget the mission and objectives of cohesion policy and its role in maintaining investment in the European Union. Although we need more effective economic governance systems, such systems should not be an obstacle to achieving the more general objectives of economic, social and territorial cohesion.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ Cohesion Policy is a policy based on the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and an expression of European solidarity, aimed at strengthening the EU's economic, social and territorial cohesion and reducing disparities between regions by promoting balanced and conforming socio-economic development. It is also an investment policy that contributes to achieving the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth.  In plenary, I supported this resolution precisely because good economic governance and effective public institutions are a basic precondition for sustainable and long-term economic growth, job creation and social and territorial development, as well as reducing differences between European regions. A stable macroeconomic environment, including high-quality governance at all levels, contributes to the successful implementation of the ESI Funds and thus contributes positively to the investment rate affected by the economic and financial crisis.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the link between the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI Funds) and the European Semester in the Common Provisions Regulation (CPR) might seem controversial, there is evidence that sound economic governance can increase the impact of investment in economic development and job creation. If we add to this the low level of implementation of Country Specific Recommendations, the need for such a correlation seems all the more useful. However, I agree with the view from the report that, given the long-term nature of the challenges that ESI Funds are intended to solve in Member States, reprogramming or suspension under Article 23 of the CPR should only be used in exceptional situations. I therefore welcome the cautious approach from the Commission’s communication and hope that such reprogramming will be kept to the minimum necessary.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Article 23 of the CPR (Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013) provides that, in order to enable the focus on performance and achievement of the objectives of the Union strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, a performance reserve of 6% of all resources allocated to the Investment for growth and jobs goal and for the EAFRD and actions financed under the EMFF Regulation should be established for each Member State. In the current programming period, cohesion policy is closely linked to the strategic objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy and economic governance mechanisms. The measures to link the performance of the European Structural and Investment Funds to the sound economic governance referred to in Article 23 of the CPR are controversial, as the macroeconomic conditionality of the vast majority of parliamentary groups was not favourable. I agree that economic governance mechanisms must not hinder the achievement of the policy objectives of the European Structural and Investment Funds and that Article 23 of the Regulation should only be used as a last resort for a more effective implementation of the European Structural and Investment Funds. This must not lead to financial uncertainty and instability that would jeopardise an already precarious situation, especially in the vulnerable regions or regions most affected by the crisis. As I believe that efforts are needed towards the fair and balanced implementation of the provisions of the regulation as fairly and balancedly as possible, I supported the report.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The provisions on macroeconomic conditionality, i.e. measures to link the European Structural and Investment Funds to sound economic management, were a very controversial aspect of the Regulation laying down common provisions for cohesion policy 2014-2020, which a broad political spectrum had rejected in the previous legislature. However, since the final text of the regulation contained this principle, Parliament had ensured that the corresponding provisions were used only as a last resort. I therefore agree with the rapporteur's approach, which has highlighted the need to apply the provisions on macroeconomic conditionality in the most justified and balanced way possible, in exceptional cases. While recognising the need for effective economic governance, I believe that these mechanisms should not hinder the pursuit of the wider objectives of economic, social and territorial cohesion, especially in times of economic crisis and instability. It would not be acceptable for regional or local authorities to be unfairly penalised, by reprogramming or suspending the Funds and the consequent disappearance of a fundamental source of public investment, due to macroeconomic shortcomings on the part of central governments for which they have no responsibility. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy is an expression of European solidarity. We should continue to strive to reduce disparities between regions and promote balanced socio-economic development. Through cohesion policy, we also contribute to achieving the Europe 2020 objectives, in particular to increasing competitiveness through quality job creation, business development and entrepreneurship across the Union.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report, as cohesion policy expresses European solidarity and focuses on strengthening the EU's economic, social and territorial cohesion and in particular reducing disparities between regions by promoting balanced and harmonious socio-economic development.  Good governance and effective public institutions are essential preconditions for sustainable and long-term economic growth, job creation and social and territorial development. Economic and financial unpredictability and legal uncertainty can lead to decreasing rates of public and private investment, the thus jeopardised the achievement of cohesion policy objectives. The importance of cohesion policy is of utmost importance in areas where investment rates have fallen significantly as a result of the economic and financial crisis.  The current legislative framework for cohesion policy is subject to specific tasks, objectives and horizontal rules. The European Structural and Investment Funds aim to strengthen coordination, complementarity and synergies with other EU policies and instruments.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Taking into account, inter alia, the focus of the current legal framework of the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI Funds) on strengthening coordination, complementarity and synergies with other EU policies and instruments, as well as the Commission Communication on the application of measures linking the effectiveness of the ESI Funds and good economic governance, the European Parliament calls on the Commission to report on the results achieved by applying Article 23 TB. regulation on common provisions. Furthermore, Parliament welcomes the information on the impact of the application of the article in the context of the revision of its application in accordance with paragraph 17 of the same Article, including the provision of more detailed information on the extent to which reprogramming requirements were based on the implementation of relevant country-specific recommendations and Council recommendations, or have improved the impact of the ESI Funds available to Member States under the Financial Assistance Programme for Growth and Competitiveness , as well as providing information on all discontinued amounts and relevant programmes.  I support this report.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. I consider it not only minor weaknesses or the setting up of this redistribution system to be a fundamental problem for the European Structural and Investment Funds, but I also see redistribution itself as a problem aimed at boosting growth and employment. Given that every single euro spent on boosting growth comes from taxpayers' money, redistribution is more damaging to the economy than it helps.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the European Structural and Investment Funds and good economic governance. The European Structural and Investment Funds bring together 5 funds, one of which aims to promote the harmonious development of the European Union and reduce regional disparities. I support the simplification of the management of these funds, which is a major effort by the European Commission to speed up job creation and improve socio-economic conditions.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The own-initiative report concerns Article 23 of the ESI Fund Regulation on the definition of common provisions (ESIFs) for the 2014-2020 programming period, known as macroeconomic conditionalities. In accordance with Article 23, the Commission is given the opportunity, when it considers that macroeconomic conditions are not met, to request a rescheduling of the Partnership Agreement (FSA) and, if the State does not respond, to request a suspension of payment of funding.  The report stresses the need for single economic governance and calls for close cooperation between the ESI Fund and the European Semester. At the same time, the punitive nature of any suspension of payments is stressed and the Commission is asked to use its discretion to propose the suspension of payments where and where necessary.  We have therefore voted against the report because, instead of promoting solidarity to extend growth and prosperity in order to tackle economic and social inequalities, it is in favour of introducing blackmail measures against the Member States in the financing process.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Good economic governance and its interconnection with the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIFs) has contributed to the ineffectiveness of cohesion policy, in particular Article 23 of the KKD and the suspension of punitive payments, taking into account the situation of States and regions facing socio-economic difficulties as a result of the crisis. Practice has shown that the principle of proportionality and subsidiarity do not apply in the case of ESI Funds, in particular to country-specific recommendations that fail to achieve economic growth and create sustainable growth and new jobs, which entails measures (additional austerity and reductions) contrary to cohesion policy objectives.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that, on the one hand, the mechanisms of economic governance should not hinder the achievement of the objectives of the ESI Funds and, on the other hand, that these mechanisms actually contribute to the stability of the macroeconomic environment and to an effective and results-oriented cohesion policy. I agree that good governance and effective public institutions are essential for sustainable and long-term economic growth, job creation and social and territorial development, but little attention has been paid to macroeconomic factors affecting the way cohesion policy is run.  I share the view that the application of the macroeconomic conditionality provisions of the Regulation on common provisions must be democratically guaranteed above all by the European Parliament. I believe it is important to ensure transparency and that control and review are becoming increasingly important, while opposing any measure that disproportionately increases the administrative burden and the resulting costs at any level of the administration concerned.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Structural and Investment Funds are the essential instrument by which the European Union's cohesion policy is achieved. With these funds, the development differences between the regions of the Member States can be mitigated, creating the framework for a unified development of European construction at socio-economic level.  One of the conditions for the allocation of these funds remains, however, the need for good economic governance, which implies that the State is complying with basic rules, generally laid down in the Stability and Growth Pact. Those rules relate to certain criteria of institutional coordination, transparency and accountability. Otherwise, the suspension of payments for that State, decided by the Council on a proposal from the Commission, may be suspended.  In the context of the economic difficulties faced by a number of Member States in recent years, however, it is necessary to apply these regulations more carefully, because in many cases those who suffer are the very ones who need assistance most. Those measures must be implemented in such a way that the purpose of cohesion policies is not affected.  In this respect, the European Parliament, as the direct representative of citizens, should have a harder word in assessing Member States' compliance with economic conditions.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text of my eminent colleague Blanco Lopez. A vast majority of us share concern about the practical implications of reprogramming and suspending ESI Funds under Article 23 of the DRC. In this report, your rapporteur has tried to strike the right balance between the different conceptions of the macroeconomic conditionality mechanism in terms of its application as a last resort.  It is essential that we do not lose sight of the original role and objectives of cohesion policy and its importance as an instrument for maintaining investment in European regions, particularly in a context of economic crisis and instability. While good economic governance is necessary, such mechanisms should not impede the pursuit of the broader objectives of economic, social and territorial cohesion.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which comes in response to the Commission guidelines on the application of the measures linking effectiveness of the European Structural and Investment Funds to sound economic governance according to Article 23 of Regulation (EU) 1303/2013 on the common provisions (the CPR). The guidelines pertain to a reprogramming and a suspension of payments which are not compulsory. The report states that the achievement of the ESI Funds’ policy objectives should not be hindered by the economic governance mechanisms and that Article 23 of the CPR should only be used as a last resort to contribute to an efficient implementation of the ESI Funds. Therefore, the report calls on the Commission to deliver a comprehensive analysis of all available options other than the application of Article 23 CPR to address issues that may trigger a reprogramming request.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy aims to strengthen the EU's economic, social and territorial cohesion and, in particular, to reduce the gap between regions by promoting balanced and harmonious socio-economic development, in order to achieve the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. During the last parliamentary term, one of the most controversial aspects of the negotiation process for the regulation laying down common provisions of the Structural Funds and investments was the 'macroeconomic conditionality' defined in Article 23. The practical implications of renegotiation and the possible suspension of funds due to the macro-conditionality clause must be carefully assessed, and given the sharp decline in investment that we are seeing, only cohesion policy can guarantee to maintain the commitments of Member States and regions in order to reduce disparities and improve employment. It is our duty to continue to insist that the flexibility clause on investments be applied. We need a full relaunch of public and private investment in work, business and the well-being of citizens.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. -u2012 Report on the European Structural and Investment Funds and good economic governance: I supported the guidelines for the implementation of Article 23 of the CPR, as I believe that measures to link the performance of the European Structural and Investment Funds with the good economic governance referred to in Article 23 of the CPR are perhaps the most contentious aspect of this regulation, and I believe that the new guidelines are imminent.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the report on the European Structural and Investment Funds proposed by José Blanco López. We understand that it does not take charge — given the final composition adopted by the text during the vote, in its amendment phase — of the problems and debt crises of countries with severe economic crises. Our amendments had to do with funds for countries with severe crises not counting as the country's debt. We understand that, without this extra mechanism, the functioning of the Structural Funds loses meaning and simply becomes another mechanism, not of solidarity, but of tying in the form of debt of the States participating in the fund.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to clarify the context in which Article 23 of the DRC can be used. This article, which deals with measures linking the effectiveness of ESI funds to good economic governance, is far from unanimous. During the legislative process, the rapporteurs even proposed to remove the macroeconomic conditionality provisions. They were eventually included in the regulations.  Mr Blanco Lopez's report aims to ensure that the provisions of Article 23 are applied in a balanced manner.  This is an unsatisfactory text but calls for a more flexible application of the provisions on the reprogramming of ESI funds and calls on the Commission to take into account the economic and social situation of each Member State before suspending payments.  I choose abstention on this text.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The rules laid down in Article 23 of the Regulation on common provisions relating to measures linking the effectiveness of the ESI Funds with sound economic governance, adopted during the previous legislative term, are likely to constitute the most controversial acre of the Regulation. I supported this report today.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the report on the European Structural and Investment Funds proposed by José Blanco López. We understand that it does not take charge — given the final composition adopted by the text during the vote, in its amendment phase — of the problems and debt crises of countries with severe economic crises. Our amendments had to do with funds for countries with severe crises not counting as the country's debt. We understand that, without this extra mechanism, the functioning of the Structural Funds loses meaning and simply becomes another mechanism, not of solidarity, but of tying in the form of debt of the States participating in the fund.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because, through it, Parliament will send a clear and important message that the introduction of macroeconomic conditionality was not the best decision made in this Multiannual Financial Framework.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the ‘European Structural and Investment Funds and sound economic governance: guidelines for the implementation of Article 23 of the Common Provisions Regulation’ because I am aware of the importance of cohesion policy also as an expression of European solidarity, aimed at strengthening economic, social and territorial cohesion in the EU, and in particular at reducing disparities between regions, promoting a balanced and harmonious socio-economic development. The cohesion policy is also an investment policy contributing to achieving the goals of the Europe 2020 strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. Therefore it is essential to address the question of the reprogramming of article 23 CPR that may avoid financial uncertainty and instability and the worsening an already precarious situation particularly in disadvantaged regions or those hit hardest by the crisis. We must ensure a proportionate response in order to avoid further disadvantaging regions already experiencing difficulties.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The provisions on measures linking the effectiveness of the European Structural and Investment Funds under Article 23 of the Common Provisions Regulation are probably the most contentious issue of this Regulation.  While the report has been the subject of a number of amendments, work in the Committee on Regional Development resulted in a consensus document dealing with key issues in a successful manner. I therefore consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted against this parliament report on the application of Article 23 of the Regulation on the European Structural and Investment Funds, which introduced a macroeconomic conditionality mechanism to link the disbursement of these funds to compliance with budgetary constraints and to the implementation of the economic recipes indicated by the Commission in the country-specific recommendations. A mechanism which would trigger the suspension of funds for the regions in the event of unsatisfactory progress in the implementation of structural reforms by central governments, with the counterproductive effect of worsening the economic situation and exacerbating social tensions in regions already in economic difficulties. This is an absurd and unacceptable ploy, which has been heavily criticised in recent years, designed to put further pressure on central governments that show difficulty in meeting budgetary constraints or delays in implementing reforms that are unachimmable or otherwise unsustainable from a political, economic and above all social point of view.  Already in the ECON Commission, which was called upon to draw up an opinion on the subject, which was then rejected because it was inconsistent and contradictory, confirming the split of this Parliament on all governance issues, I strongly opposed any principle of macro-conditionality, calling in particular for the power of suspension to be limited exclusively to cases of fraud, corruption and mafia infiltration.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report focuses on the Communication made by the European Commission on the guidelines for linking the Structural Funds with Article 23 of Regulation No 1303/2013, in which the Commission itself announces that aid from the Structural Funds must be closely linked to compliance with EU governance.  It thus justifies the rescheduling and suspension of funds to regions where the Member States to which they belong do not meet the criteria set by the European Semester to correct the degree of indebtedness (policies for cuts and reforms that close rights in labour law, among others).  Parliament's report legitimises the existence of so-called 'macro-conditionality' as a last resort. In addition, the vast majority of the Eurochamber voted in favour of declaring that economic governance instruments contribute to a 'stable macroeconomic environment', ignoring the dramatic effects of austerity measures on the European population, and on Spain in particular.  In fact, it was not even voted in favour of the proposal to eliminate the Structural Funds from a state's overall public deficit count. That is why, obviously, I voted against it.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ European Structural and Investment funds are critical to my constituents in Wales, to develop and improve our local economy in partnership with the EU. To get the best value for money for the European taxpayer, and to ensure that Wales can move forward as rapidly as possible, it is critical that the ESI is underpinned by a sound economic strategy. Furthermore it is important that this support can be redirected to meet emerging economic and social challenges as they develop. This is very important to ensure that the European Union continues to work towards addressing the economic disparities that exist between many of the European regions.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report proposes a reconciliation between the Strategic Investment Funds (ESIF) and other EU cohesion instruments with the Framework of the European Semester, macroeconomic policies and specific recommendations for Member States, specifically in reference to Article 23 of the DRC (which advocates that payments and commitments of investment funds be suspended in the event of non-compliance). The report presents positive points, such as criticism of the suspension of funding in reference to Art. 23 of the DRC. It recognises that the mechanisms associated with the European Semester affect the operationality of cohesion policy and in particular the implementation of the Structural Funds. This report is therefore unacceptable in that it legitimises an instrument that should be banned from the EU.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report makes justified criticisms. Also some improvements and an increase in efficiency. However, the report does not bring any change to cohesion policy, which we are opposed to. That is why I do not support this report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report regulating the application of macroeconomic conditionality. Parliament has obtained the safeguards it requested, so that, in the event of macroeconomic imbalances in the Member States, the Commission will only be able to request the suspension of payments as a measure of last resort. Faced with the objectives of economic governance, we must not ignore the objectives of cohesion policy.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on the European Structural and Investment Funds and good economic governance: guidelines on the application of Article 23 of the Common Provisions Regulation.  I welcome the rapporteur's concern about Article 23 of that regulation, which introduces macroeconomic conditionality, which should be eliminated. I agree with its approach, which shows that Article 23 of the Regulation must not create uncertainty and financial instability, aggravating an already precarious situation, particularly in disadvantaged regions or regions most severely affected by the crisis.  I also support his view that the situation in which local or regional entities can be penalised with the reprogramming or suspension of funds must be rejected, damaging their economic and social situation due to macroeconomic failures at other levels of administration.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. I agree with the application as an exceptional remedy of Article 23 of the Common Provisions Regulation, as I am in a position to prioritise transparency and trust within the Member States, as I believe it is the best form of success. I believe that the European Union should enhance these two concepts, as in my opinion they are key to the effective and efficient management of the European Structural and Investment Funds. In addition, I believe that, at first, the Stability and Growth Pact contains rules sufficiently well founded to be able to control each Member State's use of the European Structural and Investment Funds, as it consists of tax supervision with a sanctioning regime in the event of non-compliance with its conditions. Thus, the simultaneous application of Article 23 would, in my view, be an over-control, with consequent negative consequences.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report proposes a reconciliation between the Strategic Investment Funds (ESIF) and other EU cohesion instruments with the Framework of the European Semester, macroeconomic policies and specific recommendations for Member States, specifically in reference to Art. 23 of the DRC (which advocates that payments and commitments of investment funds be suspended in the event of non-compliance). The report argues that such suspension should be applied in exceptional cases and reveal greater flexibility; further acknowledges that the mechanisms associated with the European Semester affect the operationality and implementation of the ESI Funds. However, the cross-cutting objective of the report is to ensure that the mechanisms of the European Semester have a territorial and integrated dimension, creating the illusion that their democraticity is possible (through control by the European Parliament in particular). It is therefore a question of legitimising EU governance policies by giving it a more democratic and "development-concerned" outfit, recognising that compliance with them has been detrimental. We voted against it.

name: Presidente. –
text: That concludes the explanations of vote.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The first item on the agenda is oral questions to the Council and the Commission on a package of measures on smart border management, submitted by Claude Moraes, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (O-000106/2015 - B8-0766/2015) – (O-000107/2015 - B8-0767/2015) – (2015/2868(RSP)).

name: Claude Moraes
text: author. – Mr President, I am not in my usual seat because I have had a small injury and am on crutches, so I am not even in the proper political part of the Chamber. This is just to explain to everyone where I am sitting/standing. However let us get on to the very important issue of ‘smart borders’.  On behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE), allow me to present the oral question which we have tabled to the Council and to the Commission. It is good to see again Commissioner Avramopoulous and, of course, our Presidency, which we know has been working incredibly hard over the past few days.  The Smart Borders Package is one which we have debated on a number of occasions in the past, including in this Chamber. The reason for this is very simple. The original proposal that the Commission presented in 2013 had so many technical problems that in the committee we did not even proceed to the stage of preparing draft reports.  Since then, we have been in a discussion process with the other institutions and in a process of verifying what technical options we have. It is this process that we are continuing today. We have presented a series of questions to the Council and Commission and we are looking forward to their responses. From the Commission we would like to receive an update regarding the new proposals. Specifically, does the Commissioner intend to present a single legislative proposal which would be complemented by a modification of the Schengen Borders Code to take account of the systems at the border, or would it present two separate proposals which would also be complemented by a modification of the Schengen Borders Code? Also, when does it intend to present the announced revised proposals, and could the Commission outline its main ideas for the revised proposals and its intended purpose? The following questions are also addressed to both the Council and the Commission.  We are interested to know whether they consider an envisaged entry/exit system and registered traveller programme to be appropriate and adequate responses to the current and future situation at the EU’s external border, given the constant increase in the number of border crossings and, if so, why? Do they consider the envisaged entry and exit system to be an appropriate instrument for reducing the number of so-called overstayers and, if so, why? What are the views of the Council and Commission as regards access for law enforcement purposes? What are their views as to the intended purposes and what are their thoughts on the systems as regards the architecture, biometric identifiers and data retention periods? And to what extent may the European Court of Justice’s ruling on data retention impact on the proposals as they stand? What are their views regarding upgrading the existing tools to achieve the intended objectives of the entry and exit system and the registered traveller programme, regarding the interoperability and compatibility of various IT systems that already exist with regard to the Smart Borders Package? Finally, for the Council specifically, what is the Council’s view on the costs of the Smart Borders Package, in particular those that are not fully covered by the Internal Security Fund? This Smart Borders package, which will take us into the next Presidency – where there is a lot of interest in this matter, and I have spoken briefly to the Minister – is one which has many deep civil liberties implications, but as you have heard from my questions – and we have one of our rapporteurs here, Ms Fajon – has many technical aspects. We in the LIBE Committee want to get these technical aspects discussed openly and transparently, but we are also concerned with the many civil liberties aspects, so I look forward to the debate today and I am very pleased that the Members here present will give their best to ensure that the Smart Borders Package begins to make sense to all of us today.

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let me, first of all, thank Mr Moraes and the two rapporteurs, Mr Diaz de Mera and Mrs Fajon, for this issue, but above all for the efforts they have made to ensure Parliament's active participation in this important European project.  In the 2009 Stockholm programme, the European Council called on the Commission - and I quote - to "submit proposals for an entry and exit system coupled with a rapidly procedureed passenger registration programme, with the aim of ensuring that such a system is operational as soon as possible". This request has become urgent in the current context, which I do not need to remind and describe, indeed, the European Council of 15 October last called - I quote again - to "develop technical solutions to strengthen the control of the external borders of the European Union in order to achieve the objectives pursued, both in terms of migration and security, without harming the fluidity of movements". The creation of a European entry/exit system is a necessary step to preserve the Schengen area. Currently, there are twelve countries that use national entry/exit systems, but the value added remains limited.  If no system is established at EU level, Member States will continue to act on their own, without the efficiency and harmonised approach that the Smart Borders package can provide. Such a system should lead to harmonization and standardization of border controls, and lead to a higher level of security. This system will provide more certainty for calculating the authorized period of stay. Border guards now spend a lot of time looking at the composting of travel documents and calculating the authorized period of stay. If this system works properly, border guards will have more time to identify passengers who pose a migratory or security risk. In addition, the fact that composting is no longer required will allow the use of automated border control systems to be extended to a portion of travellers, for whom the border crossing will be more fluid.  The European entry/exit system will make it easier to identify people at the border and within the territory. This could not have been achieved by an upgrade to SIS II. The technical study presented by the Commission a year ago also showed that it would not be realistic to overhaul the visa information system, which is still being deployed and applies only to third-country nationals who need a visa, to achieve these objectives. A European system would act as a deterrent for third-country nationals who intend to exceed the length of their allowed stay. The fact that Member States will have a clear view of the number and nationality of these people would also allow for more appropriate measures to counter this phenomenon. This information will also be relevant in the negotiation of visa facilitation agreements, when considering the granting of a visa exemption for third countries and when considering the application of the visa waiver suspension mechanism.  As for the frequent flyer program, the Commission has always been in favour of such a program. At this stage of the discussion, a majority of Member States are in favour of such a programme with flexibility as to how it should be applied according to the type of border. During the discussions, a majority voted in favour of a lean RTP, presented by the Commission in its technical study.  On the question of access to the European entry/exit system, a very large majority of Member States have expressed support for such a possibility from the very beginning of the system's operation. The purpose of such access would be to prevent or detect terrorist offences or other serious criminal offences or to carry out investigations in this area. Moreover, this was also the wish of a large majority of representatives of national parliaments, at the meeting organized by the Committee on Civil Liberties last February. For Member States, access by law enforcement to the European system would be introduced on a secondary basis, as in the case of the VIS and Eurodac. This access should be subject to strict conditions and procedures. To this end, the Commission endeavours to identify the necessary elements for future provisions as well as the list of safeguards necessary in accordance with the jurisprudence of the Court of Justice.  As regards architecture, based on the technical study that preceded the pilot project, a majority of Member States favoured the implementation of the passenger registration programme and the entry/exit system as a single system. A majority in the Council prefers, at this stage, a progressive approach to integrating the entry/exit system and the RTP into the VIS. The interoperability between future European and existing national systems and the introduction of the possibility of reusing existing elements in the VIS system will help to reduce the final cost of this project. In terms of the type and number of biometric identifiers, we are awaiting the results of the pilot project, which will be decisive for future discussions.  For data retention periods, a large majority of Member States are in favour of a uniform five-year retention period, in order to harmonize all the systems and for all the objectives mentioned: this would be in the interest not only of the authorities, but also of travellers, as this would reduce the number of cases where their data should be recorded. The Council is fully aware of the importance of the Court of Justice's ruling of 8 April 2014 which overturns the Data Retention Directive. All the debates in the Council on the establishment of a smart border system have taken full account of the principle of doing only what is necessary and proportionate to achieve the objectives pursued.  Regarding the potential cost of the Smart Borders package, the Council shares Parliament's concerns not to exceed the budget strictly necessary for the efficient operation of the system.  The Council believes that this legislative package is vital for the Schengen area, and I should also congratulate the Commission, since yesterday the first Vice-President of the Commission announced it in the work programme for 2016, which includes three regulations concerning this area. We all, of course, count on cooperation with Parliament to bring this important project to a successful place.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by wishing the Chair of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs a swift recovery. I want you to know, Claude, that we need you to be fully operational for months to come. We have a lot of work to do together. (Applause) I would like to thank the honourable Members for this further opportunity to reflect with you on ‘smart borders’. I know how sensitive the Parliament is on this issue. As announced in both the Agenda on Security and the Agenda on Migration, and as already mentioned at our previous exchange on 9 June, it is our intention to present a modified proposal on smart borders by the beginning of next year. In our upcoming 2016 proposal we aim to present a solution that is operational and cost effective. We will propose a system that performs well and quickly and that meets the European Union’s security and migration policy objectives, improves the traveller’s experience, does not increase the workload for border guards and stands the test of our data protection legislation. The Commission will modify the existing proposals in the Smart Borders Package to deliver a single legislative proposal complemented by a targeted modification of the Schengen Borders Code. It will be supported by a new impact assessment in order to incorporate and justify the changes to the original proposals. These changes will be limited to the following issues assessed: the architecture of the system; the biometric identifier to be used; the facilitation of border crossings; the retention time for the storage of data; and access for law-enforcement purposes. The current border control system is neither efficient nor effective given increased travel flows and Member States’ financial constraints. The smart borders proposal will, when implemented, lead to a reduction in border guards’ repetitive manual tasks, and release resources where they are urgently needed. It will also facilitate the crossing of EU external borders by third-country nationals through a semi-automated or fully automated system. The modified smart borders proposal will allow for a more effective EU policy against irregular migration and notably the phenomenon of over-stayers. It will help border guards in detecting travellers who did not observe the terms of their stay in the Schengen zone and will allow them to undertake appropriate action. This is also expected to have a preventive effect on over-staying. Data generated at entry/exit could also be of use to law enforcement authorities in the fight against terrorist offences and other serious criminal offences in specific cases. Should access for law enforcement purposes be granted, the necessary substantive and procedural safeguards will obviously be introduced.  Subject to the results of the new impact assessment, some preliminary conclusions can already be presented. As I have said on previous occasions, it seems preferable to build a single system, with functionalities for both an entry/exit system and registered travellers’ programmes, instead of two different systems. It reduces the development and operating costs, avoids the duplication of travellers’ personal data and reduces the impact on national systems. As for possible synergies with existing systems, the re-use of certain elements from the visa information system, such as the common biometric matching system, seems to be the preferred option. Such an approach presents a lower level of risk and will be cheaper than the option of full and immediate integration to a biometric identification and authentication system. The possibility of limited interoperability between the entry/exit system and the visa information system is under assessment: it would prevent registration of the same data concerning the same persons in two different systems. The 2013 proposal was for the use of 10 fingerprints and biometric identifiers. However, the technical study showed that a facial image is sufficient for verification of the identity of a traveller, while the combination of fingerprints and facial image gives the best results for traveller identification. The ongoing test phase will need to compare how these options work out in practice. However, it is clear to me that the biometric identifier used for the entry/exit system has to be as light and non—intrusive as possible. A major challenge for us is to ensure that the introduction of a smart borders system will accelerate the border-control process. To complement the functionalities for a registered travellers’ programme, increased scope for using process accelerators, such as self-service kiosks or mobile device applications, could be promoted. This would facilitate border crossing for a wider group of travellers. The impact assessment will look into the details of this important question.  On the subject of data retention, it is clear that if records of previous data are deleted too quickly travellers would have to re-enrol more often. It would also mean that border guards can see only a very short period of the traveller’s history. Remember that, in today’s situation with stamped passports, border guards can reconstruct several years of travel history when looking at the passport of the person standing in front of them. In this context I want to underline once again that the Court of Justice ruling on the Data Retention Directive has no direct effect on other EU legal instruments. However, it is very clear that a strict assessment of the proportionality and necessity of measures that constitute serious restrictions to fundamental rights is needed. These key points raised in the Court of Justice judgment will be fully addressed in the smart borders proposal.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, yes, Mr Moraes' approach to the question and the intervention of the Presidency of the Council and Mr Avramopoulos has been very timely. I want to start by saying that these systems are effectively designed to control, facilitate and expedite passenger traffic. And not to be confused, we are talking about a type of passenger that normally comes with his passport in hand, he is not a passenger who arrives in a hard and terrible way to a beach in Turkey or to a beach in Greece. This is something that has led to a lot of confusion here, and this confusion has come from the Presidency of the Council and the Presidency of the Commission. Currently it is estimated that in the Schengen area there are between three and five million people who have exceeded the time stay limit established to remain in our territory. It is therefore very necessary to put an end to these practices and these procedures, which are a clear violation of the Schengen area. I naturally support the access of State Security Forces to the system, as an added value, provided that it is a matter of clarifying a few things, such as which authorities would access; provide these authorities with the necessary guarantees for access to be provided and limited for purposes; and finally, I am reassured that the judgment is taken into consideration and that, even if it has no impact on the legislative acts of the European Union, it will indeed be taken into account. As you will understand, Mr President, after so much work we have been doing, limiting our work to a minute and a half is a real barbarity.

name: Tanja Fajon
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. Several things have happened in recent weeks and months that need to be clarified. We are talking about the introduction of smart borders at the Union's external borders, a project worth almost €800 million, which is supposed to facilitate the crossing of borders for travellers from third countries, introduce easier control over them, automate border procedures and the like. Unfortunately, all of you, including you, Commissioner, Mr Schmit, are in a difficult situation. There are various proposals circulating between Member States. For some of my colleagues, we find out by chance that some countries want the recast legislative proposal to be published as early as December, because they clearly link the introduction of smart borders to extreme migratory pressures on Europe and security risks. We cannot allow this to happen, and that was not the purpose of the European Commission's proposal. Yes, we share serious concerns about developments in Europe, over the apparently poor or uncontrolled arrivals. My country Slovenia is under extreme pressure these days. Austria announced this morning the construction of some kind of fence or barrier on the border with Slovenia. Schengen will be seriously threatened by such a measure. I'm afraid of how Slovenia will react. She will be forced to consider similar measures at the border with Croatia. These are all the concerns we share on a daily basis, and also the view that fences within schengen countries, as well as the construction of a European fortress with smart borders, may not be the best solution. However, it is indeed harmful to the current situation with the need to introduce smart borders. When we talk about new solutions to the management of European borders, we need a thorough reflection. However, when we talk about smart borders, we need smart proposals, and I sincerely hope that when presenting the recast proposal, the European Commission will take into account the concerns of the European Parliament. On behalf of the Socialists and Democrats, I would like to highlight in particular the following: firstly, what is the purpose of the proposal and is it really proportionate to the dizzying costs? Analyses showed lower costs. Have we taken advantage of all the possibilities of existing systems such as VIS or SIS II? Are we against any access by the judicial authorities to the new system? We are facing major challenges when it comes to the issue of borders, and what I do not want is for us to build some complex and expensive system that would become just a kind of police tool, with no added value for those for whom it is intended, for passengers who are therefore coming to Europe and from whom we have not only economic benefits. The same as you would expect for Europeans elsewhere. Above all, I would like the cooperation between the institutions in this complex operation to be transparent, because it is the only way that we can find the best common solutions.

name: Jussi Halla-aho
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the Schengen area is based on trust between the Member States. However, although the same Schengen Code applies to all Member States, its implementation varies from one country to another. The external border does have weak points, and this should not be the case. Certain Member States have their national entry/exit systems and registered travellers’ programmes, but their usefulness is limited as they do not communicate with each other. While free movement is one of the great achievements of European integration, it also offers many possibilities to criminals, terrorists, human traffickers, illegal immigrants and so on. These risks must be compensated by better management of the external border. The Smart Borders Package does not mean ‘Fortress Europe’. It is a technological update that enables us to more effectively enforce the legislation and rules that we already have. But the Smart Borders Package is not only about security. It is also about facilitating smoother border crossing. The number of travellers to the European Union will grow dramatically. This will mean long queues at border crossing points, if nothing is done. It is also in the interests of bona fide travellers that we bring our border management into the 21st Century. If we do not control the external borders we cannot have free movement of people within the European Union. This has become evident during the migration crisis, but it would be a true also in a normal situation. The Smart Borders Package is not linked to the current crisis on the external borders of the EU, rather its components are something that should have been in place before the abolition of internal border controls and the creation of the Schengen area.

name: Angelika Mlinar
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Today we wanted to discuss the topic of smart borders and thus also in the original planning about modern technology, IT details and travel facilitation for frequent travellers. Now, however, the reality of the management of the EU's external borders or the non-existent management of the EU's external borders is moving in the direction of stupid borders, namely very old border security methods. Hungary has already built a fence, Slovenia, Austria and Germany are thinking about it. While in Germany only local politicians dream about this nonsense, in Austria it is the interior minister who seriously believes that she will win a few populist votes in this way. Not so long ago, we celebrated the anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall or the fall of the Iron Curtain. And now, in all seriousness, do we want to build fences and walls again in 2015? Even then, this did not help and only brought suffering and will not help in the present time. Our Schengen system is in serious jeopardy and the free movement of persons, which is a great achievement, is also at risk. If we do not succeed in actually finding a way for people to seek asylum legally outside the EU's borders, then people will continue to come and will continue to try to overcome fences in a simple way in order to gain a foothold on EU soil in any way. The money used here for alibi actions should be used to set up and secure refugee camps in Turkey, Jordan and Lebanon. There we can build walls, walls to protect the war refugees. Walls that may ensure that people can stay closer to home. That would actually help in our situation. In this sense, I also support the approach of using the money budgeted for smart borders and the money not used in this context in the current crisis, thereby supporting the coordination of Mediterranean activities, but also activities along the Balkan route. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". You have just compared the EU's external borders with the GDR border.  Are you aware that the GDR border was a border that locked people up so that people could not leave, and that the EU's external borders do not prevent people from leaving, but from entering the country? Do you see that this is something else or is it the same for you?

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I just think the same thing is that fences, borders – walls in this form – and shooting orders are not the right way. Neither in GDR times 30, 40 years ago and still today in 2015, Mrs. von Storch. I think you will agree with that.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, as I said in June, this project is a symbol of the paradoxes of the European Union. The aim of making it more attractive and facilitating traffic will further strengthen control at the external borders. Who will be the beneficiaries? When is it time? And who will be the victims? Since the last Council, and you have just confirmed this, there is no longer any doubt.  First, the migrants. When indeed, we are unable to open legal avenues. And there is no problem in finding funding, unlike what happens to rescue at sea and the reception of migrants and refugees. One must question the relevance of this new device, knowing that it already exists in plethora Eurosur, Eurodac, SIS, VIS, etc. What interests ultimately serve this safe forward leak? Why this inability to evaluate existing devices? What will be the coordination between all these devices? Where is the concern for public finances? The sums involved remain colossal. And I am not even talking about how the European Parliament is treated when one of our rapporteurs discovers by the band a third option of the Commission. So it's all there: financial gabegie, security leakage, disregard for fundamental rights, lack of serious evaluation. And I'm talking about political evaluation, incorporating all the parameters, not purely technical evaluation. All this lacks seriousness.  As with the PNR, we are told, "there is an emergency." But let us not be wrong, Commissioner, Minister. So at the GUE/NGL, we will continue to oppose this unnecessary, dangerous and contrary to the so-called values of the European Union.

name: Ska Keller
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the After all, the Member States have not thought smart borders so that journeys can go faster, so that travellers can get through faster, or just to abolish the old stamp ingestable system. Smart borders certainly can't be quicker. Instead, these intelligent borders, as you would like to say, are about using another building block in Fortress Europe. The police should have access to the fingerprints of third-country nationals. All non-EU citizens should enter this database in order to see if the fingerprints of these people may match fingerprints of crime scenes. This is contrary to fundamental law, because the European Court of Justice has just once again established that the mass storage of data without cause is simply not feasible under European law.  Police access to fingerprints is also discriminatory, because who is inside?  There are all those who do not have EU citizenship who want to enter. We would not be able to clean up EU citizens for good reason. However, the same must also apply to all foreigners.  As the Heads of State and Government recently decided, the smart-border system is now also there to tackle the refugee crisis. But that is probably just a bad joke, because if smart borders are to come, then the Member States must put millions of euros into fingerprint scanners, facial recognition devices and otherwise a lot of technology, so that the whole system can work at all. This will certainly benefit the monitoring industry, but certainly not the refugees. We only heard from Mr Juncker yesterday that the EU budget is running out of money for refugees.
