By 2020, the EU has set aside almost EUR 800 million for smart borders in its medium-term financial planning. I think that we could make much better use of this money – indeed, for the refugees, for housing, for the current problems that we have – and not to come up with expensive measures that do not fit at all, because we still have an expensive discriminatory solution here that does not fit any problem in Europe.

name: Diane James
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I would be delighted if we could speed things up somewhat in the Chamber, having been here until nearly midnight last night – not fun, and quite frankly a waste of everybody’s time, not to mention our taxpayers’ money. When this proposal was first launched there was a big question: where was the specific just cause for it? We heard earlier that it looks as though some attempts have been made to address that. Do I have confidence? No I do not. What exactly does facilitating entry of frequent pre-vetted third-party nationals into the European Union mean? Absolute gobbledygook! It does not take account of anything to do with identity theft, criminal intent, cyber-attacks or, as has been mentioned, the mass migration that is now underway. Three weeks ago we heard that Schengen was effectively dead. I cannot remember whether it was Ms Merkel or Mr Hollande who said that, but if that is the case then the fundamental premise of this whole proposal is gone: it has evaporated, it has disappeared. Border controls need to return to the ownership and responsibility of Member States. This proposal is now outdated; it is not fit for purpose; and it is certainly not value for money.

name: Edouard Ferrand
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, you are living fully in the illusion. War, I don't teach you, is at our borders. And there is no smart border, because your smart borders don't even fulfill their primary role, that of controls and bans. It is still a term coined by technocrats: "smart border". Your borders are not smart, because since Schengen, you have been dismantling them. Since the creation of your Smart Borders package, borders have never been more cross-managed. I would even say that borders in Europe have become sieves. Your project is not smart, it is just dangerous. What you will gain is that every European state, by listening to you, will take back sovereignty and control of its borders, because today no one has confidence in this European Union.  Long live the free nations of Europe!

name: Heinz K. Becker (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, representatives of the Council, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for the work he has Thank you for your answers. It is imperative that Europe draws conclusions from the events of the recent past. One of these consequences, of course, concerns the safeguarding of the European area. If we know that the largest number of people who are in Europe illegally alone exceed their permitted length of stay, appropriate controls must be introduced. The smart borders package, based on two pillars, therefore has my full support and that of the European People's Party. I believe that the preservation of data protection is, of course, an integral part of this project. With regard to the feared costs, the increases in expenditure, it must be said that security is a policy responsibility towards the citizens. Therefore, an effort is justified. And, of course, linking up with other tasks, such as facilitating the prosecution of the most serious criminals and terrorists, is useful and supportive. I therefore believe that it is necessary for this work of the smart borders package to enter the implementation phase as soon as possible.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the delays and the change in the objective of the Smart Borders Package are showing us that the crisis that shakes the European Union was not the euro crisis, but the crisis of the free movement of people, the crisis of trust between Member States. Because what was designed to be an instrument for the smarter management of the Union's borders is now presented to us as a tool to make them more rigid and, of course, to the service of security. And we therefore have the right to know what is in this new initiative that will affect data retention and data retention guarantees, as interpreted by the Court in relation to the protection of the fundamental rights of Europeans, especially after the judgment on safe harbour. We have the right to know what the cost will be, and whether an alternative is possible that validates the information system provided by DIS to avoid an investment that is directed back to the security objective. In the short term, more fingerprinting and less fingerpointing must be done, it is true, but in the medium term we must change the suicidal view on immigration, asylum and the union's own border management.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Today we are talking about the EU's plan to introduce smart borders – smart borders – where fingerprints and personal data are stored for prosecutors or intelligence services. But the problem is that intelligent borders only draw for legal arrivals. The main problem, however, is the illegal entry. While we scrutinise the legal scanands and store their data, the EU's external borders for illegals are completely or almost completely unrestricted. Without a passport, without any control, without nothing, you can enter us. Until we get to grips with the hundreds of thousands of illegal border crossings, we should not invest money and time in the full coverage of legal arrivals. At the moment, we do not need intelligent borders, but a lot of simple, stupid limits, if you will. Borders are just enough. Stupid limits and ceilings.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with regard to this measure on intelligent borders, it seems clear and indicative to me how much confusion is being made in the European Union with regard to border management and the management of instruments, because this instrument was designed to make our lives easier, to make border controls simpler and therefore to move faster and modernise us, in in quotation marks. Because of the tensions, because of the constant discussions on the subject of refugees, on the subject of these great migratory flows, it has now become an instrument that was supposed to serve one thing into another type of instrument, which serves to raise this wall that the Member States seem so good to build.  I believe that we should first focus on what was the initial objective of this measure and try to reduce its costs, because it is absurd to think of spending EUR 800 million on something that could probably be done with a tenth of the cost and with a goal that should be what it was intended for, not try to use it to build a wall.  (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: "blue card" question. I wanted to ask my colleague whether it is not appropriate, precisely in view of the dramatic situation and for security reasons, to store passports and stamps, which are lost, and to move towards innovation, as Smart Borders demands and as it intends to do.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: answer to a "blue card" question. I would like to reply to Mrs Mussolini by saying that, of course, the aim was to modernise, to speed up these procedures, because it is clear that in 2015 we would not want to waste time in very long lines at airports to put more manual stamps, and we can modernise with the technological tools that are there quickly. The problem with this package, I repeat, is that it costs a disproportionate amount and that the objective has been shifted in trying to close borders and use data without being very clear, so it also touches on the concept of fundamental rights. That's the point.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Better control of Europe's border traffic? I am not quite sure whether you are serious about this discussion here, because today we are in a situation in which border traffic is no longer controlled at all. I think that at the moment it is even downright cynical to talk about smart borders, because what we actually need are hard borders, ladies and gentlemen. If you look at the situation in Austria, in particular the situation in the south of Austria, in Styria, in Spielfeld – I was there last Sunday – where thousands of refugees are currently breaking through every day, it is no longer a question of legal border traffic. The refugees break through without any registration. The situation on the ground is intolerable for the people and it has completely spiralled out of control for the Austrian Federal Government. The Austrian Federal Government is no longer even capable of protecting its own territory. Some even call the federal government smugglers, and the law and the law are overridden – and we are talking about smart borders here? That won't change any time soon, don't be under any illusions about it.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Minister, Commissioner, these clarifications were necessary, because this debate is marked by a number of misunderstandings.  First, there is a misunderstanding of the purposes. As many have already recalled, the main objective of this proposal was to control so-called overstayers. Today, it seems to be diluted in broader security goals. Secondly, there is a misunderstanding about the current situation, as Mr Díaz de Mera and Tanja Fajon have already had the opportunity to stress: this debate has nothing to do with the issue of the migratory pressure we feel, but more and more people are making demagoguery with the issue of borders and wanting to mix up the debates. And finally, there is a misconception about costs. Mr Minister, it is not enough to say that the budget has to be controlled and that costs have to be limited. We have to understand what the real value of this investment is, both for the Community budget and for the budgets of the Member States, so that this Parliament and the other parliaments can decide whether the value of this investment is justified in view of what this system will bring. I would like to make it clear that I want the Commission to ensure systematic checks of fundamental rights throughout the legislative process and for the Council to be clear in its objectives and to fully involve this Parliament. We all want Schengen, we all want freedom of movement. We know that there is no freedom without security, but we also know that oversecurity can stifle freedom.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, seven years have passed since the first idea of smart borders and the geopolitical framework has changed strongly since then. It is undeniable that in recent months borders have been affected by an unprecedented migratory flow which has re-proposed the need for smarter and more technologically advanced management of both the external borders and the entire Schengen system, especially with a view to the collection and continuous exchange of information.  Important news may be there with regard to the phenomenon of overstayers, even if the Smart Borders package, with its automatisms and with its not insignificant costs, cannot be seen as the only answer to such a delicate problem due to the social and legal implications that derive from it. The sensitivity of the matter, which is most evident after the judgment on data retention, also requires careful regulation of the collection of biometric data and the retention of sensitive data, in line with the constraints deriving from the Charter of Fundamental Rights.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has The smart-border concept is intended to support the organisation of the legal entry and exit of the Schengen system. But in the light of current developments and uncontrolled migration, we need to consider how we can use the smart border system to stop illegal migration. The Commission admits that the smart border system is not intended and is capable of intervening in illegal migration, and that this requires additional staff control. However, there is certainly an approach to using this system. In my view, it is important to have the central coverage of people who have not yet properly documented their entry into the EU, or those who exceed their residence permit. We need to get travellers and migrants with their biometric data into the system and non-EU foreigners informed that they have to register in this system. We must impose sanctions on people who refuse to register. It is clear that the Schengen system is not working because too many people are moving unregulated across the external borders.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I recently learned interesting information in Eurostat statistics that the largest gateway for irregular migrants to european Union countries is not the Balkan route, but the international airport. With the current information on the incredible number of refugees in the Mediterranean and at the borders of Hungary, Slovenia or Croatia, I was literally surprised by this information. However, it is true and is a direct consequence of the fact that the European Union has no functioning single system for registering entries and exits from the European Union, and that there is no registration of the length of residence of a given person. These irregular migrants are the result of nothing more than our own inability to control who moves and when they move on our territory. I therefore consider this smart border package to be a fundamental and lengthy revision or prolongation of negotiations will only aggravate this situation.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the Union, as you said, must ensure more efficient, modern and faster management of its borders, while strengthening verification procedures at crossing points. Thirteen Member States are already operating their own entry/exit system, but there is a lack of structured and systematic cooperation within the Union; the status quo is no longer an option, we must move forward. I will raise four aspects. Firstly, the establishment of a smart border system will enable us to exchange data effectively, not only between the various national authorities but also with Europol or Interpol, to detect, for example, the use of stolen passports through automatic and automated access to their files. It is therefore clear, today, that we must change the modus operandi by making cooperation the rule and not the exception. Second, the full potential of this system must be harnessed by allowing access to law enforcement and by considering a retention period sufficient for this system to have added value. The SIS and vis are already available to national authorities and Europol. So the question I ask myself is: why not smart borders? Thirdly, this system must be adapted to all types of borders: both maritime, land and air. The news shows us that we cannot prioritise the protection of certain borders over other types of borders. Finally, the Union's credibility on the international stage also depends on its ability to fully ensure security on its territory. Yes, so, mobility, but yes also to security. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for accepting the question. My question is simple. Why must there be EU border control? The EU is not a country. Why can border control not be done by sovereign, independent nation-states, who might be members of the EU but have their own borders to control. The EU is not a country, so I am really confused by the whole concept of why something that is not a country should look to control borders that do not exist.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE)
text: "blue card" answer. Thank you for the question. I think that Mr Etheridge really needs to draw the main conclusion of what has been going on for months, that if the Union had reacted together with joint actions, we could have dealt better with the current crisis and we would have had better management. So we now see how member states are managing this crisis on their own. So I am opting for the 'European Union together' option with a common approach.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: – Smart borders are an extremely important issue precisely in the context of the events of recent months. And, as in other areas, whether it is a common asylum policy or other common solutions that we need to adopt at European level, smart borders are also a subject that the European Union urgently needs to address. I agree with the majority of my previous speakers, who have very clearly identified the problems for which smart borders are one of the solutions to ensure the safety of the people and citizens of the Member States of the European Union. I believe that we will be able to implement this issue as quickly as possible, so that we can also announce from today's meeting to the people of our countries that we have once again taken a step towards making their safety better protected.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, Commissioner, the intelligent borders strategy, when it was launched, had a different social and geopolitical environment. So now, with the massive refugee flows, the situation has, I would say, been complicated. What we need to make clear first of all is that the responsibility for guarding the borders lies solely with the Member States, and this must be made clear because in various respects – and by Mrs Merkel – a situation of co-management of the Greek borders in the Aegean is being attempted. Let's get this straight.  The second is that, indeed, in this new system which you are attempting, the judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union of April 2014 should be fully implemented. That is to say, to apply the principle of proportionality and to create such an environment where fundamental rights are guaranteed. Under these conditions, the policy of intelligent borders will be able to work.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: " Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, the migrant crisis has shown the complete sensitivity, rather, of the vulnerability of our borders. No one can say with certainty that people who are not registered and people who we do not know are with us have not entered the territory of the European Union because let's face it, let's put our hand on our hearts, in many ways citizens who have fled war and from atrocities have entered the territory of the European Union.  We need smart borders because surely barbed wire or other wires or other fences are not smart borders. That is why I support this intention to clear up as quickly and efficiently as possible at our external borders together and in cooperation with Member States so that we can truly guarantee the citizens of the European Union the security that we are unfortunately feeling less and less today.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank everybody very much for this fruitful exchange of views. This debate we had today confirms the vital importance, I would say, of the input of Parliament into our joint efforts to create a smart borders system that meets its objectives and that offers genuine value for money. Since we all know that in the years to come the flow of travellers will continue to grow, we need a better and smarter border management system. There is no doubt about it. If we do nothing, we will either have to face much longer queues at the borders, or we will have to employ more border guards in the near future. Neither of these options seems acceptable or feasible. I notice that many Members made reference to Schengen. I avail myself of this opportunity to state and repeat: we will not allow isolated, one-sided actions taken under the state of fear to put into question the greatest achievement of Europe during our times.  This Commission, as I had committed during the hearing one year ago, took the time to carefully evaluate the Smart Borders proposal, and we shall come back with a new proposal in order to modify proposals based on a new impact assessment. I do not, therefore, agree that we are acting under pressure or urgency. On the contrary, we took into account your considerations, which will be reflected in the modified proposal.  The Commission is looking forward to continuing its close work with Parliament in this important file and really counts on its support and cooperation to find the right balance.

name: n/a
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, I am quite hearing what the Commissioner is saying. First of all, the current situation is an exceptional situation, so the wrong conclusions should not be drawn from it now. Secondly, I believe that what the Commissioner has said about Schengen is absolutely important. But we all know that Schengen needs a system that works better at the external borders, hence the proposals that will be made. We need an effective, more effective system, too - and I say this - to combat phenomena such as terrorism and serious crime. And knowing that the 21st century will be the century of mobility, there will be people who move from one country to another, hence the need also to have an effective system, which not only allows mobility, but also prevents or proposes measures to combat, among other things, the phenomena of crime or other phenomena of illegal mobility.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. – We must not forget that our European external borders are being crossed daily by hundreds of thousands of travellers such as tourists and business people, who arrive at the proper border crossings with the appropriate documents. They are growing in number and they are a precious resource to our Member States. Free movement of persons is one of the most important achievements of the European Union since its foundation. The absence of internal borders makes it therefore crucially important that our common external borders are controlled reliably and consistently. In order to better manage the growing flow of travellers, we need to modernise the European border control system, by increasing its efficiency and effectiveness. The result should be smooth and easy travel for the majority of third country travellers who cross the European borders yearly on one side, and an impossible mission for those who abuse free movement, such as organised crime and terrorist organisations, on the other side. I trust that the establishment of an efficient and cost effective integrated management system for external borders will serve the safety of our citizens and support the work of our law enforcement authorities.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the establishment of a European Union agency for the provision of law enforcement training (ESA) and on the repeal and replacement of Council Decision 2005/681/JHA, by Kinga Gál, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (COM(2014)0465 - C8-0110/2014 - 2014/0217(COD) (A8-0048/2015))

name: Kinga Gál
text: Artist. " Officer, I'm sorry. Dear Colleagues, I would like to express my delight that, only a year after the start of the legislative process, the European Parliament will hold a final vote on the new CEPOL legislation tomorrow. I would like to thank all the shadow reporters, in particular Mrs Flasikova-Benova, whose support and cooperation has been of great help in the negotiations, for the smooth running of the process. Likewise, I appreciate the work of the Latvian Presidency, and I would like to thank Mrs Indra Bule, who has helped through the tripartit negotiations with her constructive approach and proactive approach. We all know that the Union's internal security has been seriously challenged recently and we can look like this in the future. We therefore desperately need properly trained law enforcement officers and law enforcement agencies who can respond quickly and effectively at Pan-European level to challenges such as cross-border crime, cybercrime and terrorism. We need law enforcement officers who can act with full professionalism in today's migration crisis. Cepol can therefore serve as a tool for consolidating a culture of professionalism between professional law enforcement officers, strengthening mutual trust between Member States and cross-border cooperation. It can contribute to the realisation of a genuine European policing culture based on respect for fundamental rights and European values. That is why we in Parliament believe that the existence of a modernised, efficient, independent and adequate cepol agency is vital.  In the negotiations with the co-legislators, it remained important that cepol's basic architecture – its reliance on and close cooperation with national police academies – remained unchanged. Cepol had to have the mandate and mandate in place for the Treaties as soon as possible. Cepol's governance structure has been made operational, taking into account the proposals made during the debate on the new Europol Regulatory Framework. We believe that with this new regulation, we have created the conditions for CEPOL to contribute to building a genuine European policing culture. This new regulation, which we are about to vote on, modernises the legal foundations of CEPOL. It brings it into line with the treaty of Lisbon and mandates CEPOL to put into practice the principles of the law enforcement and police training programme proposed by the Commission in March 2013. This should include assessing the needs of strategic training at Union level, accreditation of training courses, a common curriculum, sharing positive examples and identifying the minimum knowledge that all police academies should include in their education programmes. Cepol should therefore be able to provide training and trainers at EU level. In recent years, CEPOL has been viewed by everyone as a network. However, a network is not a legal entity and is not accountable. This is precisely why CEPOL needed to become an agency of the Union, with clear mandate, tasks, responsibility and, most importantly, accountability.  As far as the use of taxpayers' money is concerned, CEPOL has come a long way to demonstrate its cost-effectiveness. It has increased the number of people taking part in its training, the demand for its training is increasing and it will be worth adjusting its budget for this. We will therefore continue to push for the provision of adequate resources, which is a necessary precondition for a well-functioning EU agency, and for the overlaps to be eliminated with other EU institutions. That is why I am asking for your support in tomorrow's vote for this institution.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by thanking the rapporteur, Ms Kinga Gál, who has worked very hard to find common ground among the shadow rapporteurs and to expedite the adoption of the regulation.  When it comes to the substance of the reform of CEPOL, we can all welcome the final outcome, as this would reinforce CEPOL’s ability to prepare police officers to cooperate effectively, to develop a common law enforcement culture and to become the centre of excellence of training of law enforcement officers in the European Union.  Training is key in this respect. The European Agenda on Security underlines that this is an essential element to enhancing the security of our Union. Training is essential to allow authorities on the ground to utilise our law enforcement cooperation tools in an operational situation. The CEPOL regulation is an evolution rather than a revolution. The network-based character of CEPOL is maintained. The agency will continue to bring together the network of training institutes of the Member States and liaise with a single national unit in each Member State. CEPOL is now entrusted with the task of coordinating the implementation of the law enforcement training system. The overall objective of the scheme is to present a coordinated policy approach ensuring high-quality training for law enforcement officials. This new role widens the opportunities for CEPOL to support, develop, deliver and coordinate training for law enforcement officers of all ranks, and not just senior officers. The reform also provides for the professionalisation of CEPOL’s management. The members of the management board will be appointed taking into account their knowledge of training for law enforcement officers, and they will be assisted by a scientific committee for training to further ensure the quality and coherence of training programmes. CEPOL’s work will come in addition to the welcome initiative taken by the Member States in the field of training for law enforcement personnel.  I am also very encouraged by the strong role ensured for the European Parliament in this CEPOL regulation. Parliament will receive the agency’s annual planning documents, and is the budgetary authority for all EU bodies. In addition, the management board shall consult Parliament on CEPOL’s multiannual work programme. The idea is to provide the opportunity for a strategic debate on the direction the agency should take. The Parliament will also receive all activity reports and accounts and all evaluations commissioned. The director of CEPOL will additionally report to the Parliament on the performance of his duties when invited to do so. That said, the Commission has misgivings on two central aspects of this reform, and this comes before us today. These two aspects are the governance of the agency and respect for the European Union’s budgetary principles, which are of course very important for the Commission. On both these aspects, the outcome of the negotiation process is not in line with what the Commission has proposed or with the trilaterally-agreed common approach on EU decentralised agencies.  Let me take this opportunity to recall the institutional commitment to use such revisions of the agency’s founding acts – as with CEPOL and Europol – as opportunities to implement and to comply with the common approach. This common approach includes the reinforcement of the supervisory role of the management board, including by ensuring full participation by the Commission, ensuring a transparent selection procedure for directors and the necessary adoption of programming document with a multiannual component, the possible setting up of an executive board to ensure more assured more efficiency and the obligation to better follow-up of evaluations and audits.  The Commission regrets the lack of political commitment to ensure respect for the common approach on EU decentralised agencies, in particular regarding the role and composition of the agency’s management structures. On these two points the Commission wants to table a statement to make clear its position. I would ask you, therefore, to add the Commission’s statement to the minutes of this meeting. So allow me now to proceed to the reading of the Commission statement: ‘The Commission takes note of the political agreement reached between the European Parliament and Council. The Commission regrets that this agreement is not fully aligned with the principles of the Common Approach on the EU decentralised agencies nor with the financial rules applicable to these agencies and considers that the agreed text on the governance of the agency and on its funding is without prejudice to any future legislative texts. The possibility of funding part of CEPOL’s tasks through ad hoc grants or delegation agreements contradicts the fundamental principle that the tasks of an agency, as described in its constituent act, are financed by the annual contribution from EU budget and not through ad hoc grants or delegation agreements. The Commission underlines that the respect of this principle is essential to allow the budget authority to take an informed decision about the annual contribution foreseen for each agency in the annual budget. The Commission refers to the Framework Financial Regulation for agencies, which limits the possibility for agencies to receive funding through ad hoc grants or delegation agreements to exceptional cases, in line with the principle of transparency and sound financial management.’  Thank you very much for your attention.

name: Jens Geier
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has As permanent rapporteur for the Committee on Budgets for Agencies, Let me highlight a number of fundamental aspects. We would still have thought it more useful if the original proposal to merge Europol and CEPOL had found a majority. CEPOL is a very small agency with just 27 posts in the establishment plan of the 2015 budget. Agencies of this size have to spend a disproportionate proportion of their staff on the necessary administrative backbone, i.e. finance and human resources, IT, logistics, communication and the like, so that the part of the staff working in the actual operational area, i.e. on the tasks specified in the basic regulation, is the responsibility of the basic regulation. , is not reasonably related to the total number of posts. Larger units are therefore more sensible and cost-effective. In theory, this could also be achieved if agencies, especially those working in related subject areas, share these administrative units. However, it would be helpful if these agencies were then located in the same place. Unfortunately, this opportunity was also undone by the Council's decision to move CEPOL to Budapest. I therefore welcome the fact that the committee responsible has taken up our proposal that the Commission should submit a cost-benefit analysis with regard to the seat after two years at the latest. I also welcome the approach of pushing for further cooperation between the various agencies in the field of internal and judicial policy. I am convinced that further efficiencies and thematic spillover effects can be achieved here. However, I do not want to confine myself to this request only to the agencies in the field of internal and judicial policy. On the contrary, I believe that we should also achieve increased cooperation between agencies in other policy areas. I would also like to call on the Commission to always consider the possibility of merging or even streamlining the remit in the event of forthcoming amendments to basic regulations. Because there is one thing that cannot be done: we cannot, on the one hand, insist on the independence of all the agencies, and we can always give them new tasks, and on the other hand we can ask them to do all this with fewer and fewer staff. A little more honesty in the debate on the agencies would be good for all the institutions involved.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, the internal security of the European Union is becoming increasingly important, as is the security of European citizens themselves. I do not know whether Cepol itself can solve the situation, but I am sure that quality and continuous training of law enforcement police officers will lead not only to a more effective fight against cross-border and organised crime, but also to better cooperation between national components throughout the European Union. And it is not only about law enforcement the hard way, but also about educating police officers on soft skills, such as privacy, data protection, victims' rights or the rights of children, the disabled and the infirm. Cepol is undoubtedly an agency that we must support and create the conditions for it to function as effectively as possible.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová
text: for the S&D Group – Let me begin by thanking the rapporteur, Kinge Gál, for the excellent work she has done on this report and for the very honourable battle she has seduced in the trilogue for her position as European Parliament.  In this context, I therefore welcome the proposal in question, as it was the European Parliament that asked the Commission on several occasions to bring Cepol's existing legal framework into line with the Treaty of Lisbon and the new ambitions set out in the European enforcement training scheme. The high quality of training of officers of anti-crime or law enforcement authorities is essential for combating serious and organised cross-border crime, and a modern and efficient Cepol agency with sufficient staff is essential. The proposal for a new regulation to reform Cepol comes at a time when the European Union is forced to face ever new pitfalls in protecting its internal security. Their successful management will require an extension of the academy's powers and will not go without increasing financial resources. The refugee crisis facing the European Union and its Member States has shown us all that the demand for the quality of police forces and cooperation between its forces within individual Member States must be improved in the future so that the European Union can better cope with crisis situations and be able to protect its people. I therefore believe that Cepol should be given sufficient powers to properly coordinate law enforcement training at European Union level and to apply the principles enshrined in the enforcement training scheme. This should include the identification of strategic training needs at European Union level.

name: Timothy Kirkhope
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, criminals do not respect national legal jurisdictions. Cross-border criminality is a feature of the modern world of increased travel and new technology. The number of prosecutions of serious crimes that involve cross-border cooperation between law enforcement authorities must increase in future. And, as the Commissioner has said, good cooperation between law enforcement authorities across Europe is an essential tool in carrying out effective and expedient investigations, resulting in the capture and prosecution of criminals.  The European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Training (CEPOL) offers a valuable platform for the exchange of best practice and skill sharing for all law enforcement officers across the EU. When it comes to the training and running of national law enforcement authorities, account must always be taken of, and respect accorded to, national sovereignty, subsidiarity and the differing pressures and crime trends in Member States, and I believe that in the area of police cooperation the EU should offer the hand of support rather than compulsion. I would like to thank my friend, the rapporteur, Ms Gál, for her hard work and I congratulate her on this report.

name: Cecilia Wikström
text: On the other: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I would also like to thank the whole team of colleagues, the rapporteur, the Commission and, of course, the Presidency, which unfortunately is conspicuous by its absence here today. We have all worked very nicely and constructively over the past few years. Sometimes there have been tough, sometimes tough, discussions between us. Now, however, we are in the finish line, and I think we should all be happy about what has happened.  The challenge now will be to strengthen cooperation, to exchange experiences and best examples between the Member States and the various law enforcement authorities across our Union. Of course, I regret what we, as liberals, had as a guiding principle, namely merging CEPOL with Europol. That would have meant positive synergies, and it would have saved our taxpayers across Europe a lot of money. Now, however, this did not happen, and we must realise that it was a majority that looked different.  What is particularly positive now is that CEPOL now has in its job descriptions and the conditions to strengthen respect for fundamental human rights and freedoms and to engage in cross-border law enforcement cooperation in a different and more up-to-date way. As we know, criminals do not know of any borders between countries, and then it is very crazy that our law enforcement authorities should not be able to work at least as effectively cross-border as the criminal gangs they are set to fight. So now there are conditions. I think we are putting history behind us and realising that we have everything to gain from working together even more. Once again, I thank all those concerned for their fine cooperation. Ευχαρίστως, κύριε Πρόεδρε. (Η εισηγήτρια δέχεται να απαντήσει σε ερώτηση με γαλάζια κάρτα (άρθρο 162 παράγραφος 8 του Κανονισμού))

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – I listened with interest about the greater cooperation that you suggest between the police forces in the different countries. How far would you take this? How far would this cooperation go before you decide: stop, enough, national sovereignty comes into this, and you have to control your own borders and your own country’s space? So just how far would you take this cooperation then you say: hold, enough, this is our countryʼs own business?

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – As I put it in my speech, what we are seeing today is that criminal transnational gangs do not feel those borders between nations. I find it quite remarkable that there are still, in this globalised world where we are, and also in this Union, people like yourself who believe that putting up fences, working nation by nation, would be efficient. I believe in an enhanced cooperation between nations in order to combat these transnational criminal gangs that are actually putting ordinary people in a very difficult situation.

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the CEPOL report has not been a controversial one. We, the Greens/EFA, basically disagree with the majority of the report on one point, already mentioned by our colleague, namely that the seat of CEPOL should not be in Budapest but Den Haag, where Europol is based. This would be more efficient and would make more sense. We have presented an amendment on this issue. On the other hand, there are two aspects in the report which we welcome. First, the inclusion of an overall framework on respect for human rights. Second, the inclusion of the reference to the desired gender balance in the main managing structure of CEPOL, the management board. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. – I have, frankly, accompanied this debate several times to explain why this agency should be or should not be in Budapest. I am Hungarian, so I am probably somewhat biased in this sense, but I would like to say honestly that, on this stereotype, which agency resembles what, practically sooner or later everything could be taken to Brussels, The Hague, anywhere, even the Parliament in Strasbourg, to Brussels, so let us face it, that a distribution, a distribution, should be between the agencies.

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – Of course we can distribute agencies, but only with some coherence and unity, and since Europol is in The Hague it would be good if the training of our police be where the central police building is. It is nothing against Hungary or against Budapest, which I like very much. That is not the problem. It is to have a rational organisation of our agencies.

name: Vicky Maeijer
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – The European Police Academy we are talking about today is part of the larger brussels dream: one major European law enforcement system. Because if it is up to Brussels, our agents will soon be trained at the European Police Academy, the European Public Prosecutor's Office will prosecute the criminals and the European Union will decide what punishment they will be given. The Party for Freedom, my party, therefore says no to a European police academy and to no to any further domination of our legal system by the European Union. There is nothing wrong with police cooperation between sovereign states, but we do not need Cepol for that. Let us leave the police work to the officers in the nation states and not hand it over to the European Union.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Mr President, the design to tackle serious forms of crime, terrorism and forms of crime affecting the interests of two or more States must be simple, applicable and lead to tangible results. The cross-border dimension of crime and law enforcement respectively as well as the attempt to create a clearer Union added value should not conflict with the internal security strategy at both Union and Member State level. Clearly enhanced cooperation between national policing authorities is necessary and intended, but it must be based on principles and regulations, especially when reflected in the organisational chart of European law enforcement institutions. Finally, the opinion of Parliament's Committee on Budgets on merging the European Police College with Europol should be discussed not only for reasons of savings but mainly for reasons of academy synergy and operational police.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I had prepared a speech, but I would like to respond to the debate that has taken place in this House on the location and on the amalgamation between CEPOL and Europol.  We believe that at a time of such serious difficulty, given the changed needs, because, as cepol is well known, it was established in 2005, we should not talk about where the headquarters will be – in The Hague or budapest – and whether there can be a deal with Europol on a budgetary and economic issue as well. The most important thing is the training of police people who have to combat serious organised crime, illegal migratory flows and terrorism. Then we have to focus on that. That is why we believe that having an entity, an autonomous agency that is untied, is of fundamental importance.  Nevertheless, there absolutely must be cooperation, an ever stronger network, in order to overcome what the rapporteur said about duplication or overlap with Europol, Eurojust and Frontex, which, among other things, will also have to be remodulated. It is therefore clear that we must get in hand with CEPOL, because the Treaty of Lisbon says so and, lastly, I want to do so, so that there is also respect for fundamental rights in law enforcement activities, as must be done, and in the protection and assistance of victims, with particular regard to children, children.

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I am forked before cepol's be or not to be. On the one hand, the situation in which the Member States find themselves in greater police cooperation requires, and on the other hand, I realise that the major cause of this need is precisely the open borders that the European Union has forced. This is a case in point of how the brains behind the European project first create a problem and then present a solution that, as a rule, also has the effect of empowering europe.  In the situation we find ourselves today with a Schengen regulation that allows people to travel freely, we are seeing an increase in drugs, trafficking in human beings, trafficking. How can CEPOL train our police officers when politicians cannot even overcome the problems we see today and, above all, do not even want to admit the cause of them? In order to make it easier for our police officers, it should be reasonable to allow Member States to maintain their border protection.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF).
text: Mr President, CEPOL is a European agency responsible for training police officers, customs officers, border guards and prosecutors in the Member States. Created in 2005, it has a disappointing track record. I strongly condemn the proposal made to us today to renovate it.  CEPOL is an unnecessary and expensive agency. Rather than renovating it, it should be merged into Europol, as the Brussels Commission had advocated. If it is kept under the status of an agency, it is only to please Hungary, where it is located.  CEPOL is a gas plant that the British had the wisdom to expel from their territory. It is consubstantial to the calamitous Schengen agreements and deserves the same fate as them, death.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to support the rapporteur in my speech. I have been Minister of Justice of the Czech Republic for many years and have devoted myself to training judges and prosecutors and preparing them for cross-border cases, and I know how important cooperation with the European Judicial Academy was. The same applies to the training of police officers and customs officers. It is not possible to educate only nationally on the territory of individual states, in short, and it has been said here several times, crime today has a cross-border character, and it is therefore not only a matter for individual countries to prepare their police officers, customs officers and prosecutors. It is now a matter for the whole of Europe and it is necessary to work together on it, and to do that, an agency is needed. I am deeply convinced of this as a person who has addressed this issue at the Czech political level. I therefore want to support the rapporteur's position, I want to support the renovation of this agency. I hope that this agency will not only be about communication between academies in individual national states, but that it will be able to develop a common curriculum and recommend how to educate police officers and customs officers in the fight against cross-border crime. It is, in my opinion, very important. For me personally, it is not important where the agency is based, how it will be funded, but what it will do to help to educate police officers who are fighting cross-border crime. If this agency is in Hungary, I personally have no problem with it.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that we all feel today, in terms of security, the need for police forces and law enforcement authorities to be increasingly qualified and interconnected by virtue of an integrated system of lifelong learning. This is why I consider it useful to consolidate the structure and role of CEPOL, an institution which, with a limited budget and staff, has managed, thanks to interaction with the national academies, the training of tens of thousands of officials with hundreds of activities.  Cepol's framework as an autonomous agency of the Union is consistent with the objective of building a common European law enforcement culture, based on respect for rights, and can also guarantee a good cost-benefit ratio. This will be all the more true by concentrating resources on certain thematic areas with a clear European and cross-border dimension and strategic importance, first and first and for all the fight against organised crime.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, CEPOL, that is to say the European Police College, is responsible for law enforcement training and should therefore operate transparently and under the democratic control of the European Parliament. CEPOL is invited, using the appropriate tools, to provide training to police forces in order to carry out their tasks in a professional and lawful manner.  However, in view of police action in various countries, we often see increased violence against citizens, especially in marches and demonstrations against austerity policies; violence which is disproportionate and which leads to a violation of the fundamental rights of citizens. Cepol's training must therefore necessarily include teaching and appropriate training in order to eliminate frequent incidents of illegal police violence. The European Parliament and the Commission are therefore called upon to ensure that CEPOL contributes to the building of genuine European law enforcement education based on respect for fundamental rights.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, while we belong to those who advocate that Europol and CEPOL and other agencies dealing with security issues in the European Union be merged in some way or at least coordinate their work vigorously, I must say here first of all that the fight against cross-border smuggling, terrorism and all that organised crime carries, which, of course, knows no borders, is important.  Mr. Commissioner, I want to warn you about the fact that this migrant crisis has also shown that the Western Balkans are one of those areas where we have major problems. Organised crime, Balkan routes, whatever you call it, really definitely exist. And that is why it is important that all those police forces and other institutions of candidate countries and potential candidates are included in CEPOL, as cross-border crime and terrorism know no borders, and these countries are at the heart of the European Union.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – I would like to receive an answer from the Representative of the European Commission present – I am very pleased that he knows Hungarian because he does not have an interpreter on it, so I am sure he understands what I am saying – so I would like to ask him exactly how much money it costs the European taxpayer to tackle organised crime across borders, either in the form of this CEPOL institution or in the form of Europol, and what he receives in return. Because what we're seeing is that cross-border crime, organized crime, thank you very much, it's doing very well, it's thriving.  What many call a migration crisis or refugee crisis can be said in criminal terms anyway: the flourishing of organised crime, the flourishing of people smuggling despite the existence of CEPOL, Europol and other bodies. What explanation can the Representative of the European Commission have for this? I'm waiting for your answer.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I strongly believe that, in order to ensure its effectiveness and impact, CEPOL’s limited resources should be focused towards a few thematic areas with a clear European added value, taking into consideration the current situation of the European Union with migratory waves and other challenges to our stability, by no means duplicating the work done at the level of the Member States and in line with the principle of subsidiarity. Focusing on a more limited number of thematic areas would free resources to put more effort into quality and attractiveness. In order to use scarce resources efficiently, a more effective coordination among JHA agencies providing training is important, exploiting synergies and eliminating duplication. Finally, I believe that sufficient funding should be safeguarded for CEPOL to properly execute its new tasks.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, today we deliver one important element of the European agenda on security. There is no doubt that training is key to our common law enforcement culture. Today, we ensure that we give CEPOL the right means and the structure to perform its mission.  We can all welcome the final outcome, as this would reinforce CEPOL’s ability to become the centre of excellence of training of law enforcement officials and officers of the European Union. The Commission maintains its misgivings on two important points of the text, as it emerged from the interinstitutional negotiations, and underlines the importance of maintaining the common approach as agreed trilaterally between the institutions. My thanks once again to the rapporteur Ms Kinga Gál for her hard work on this fight.

name: Kinga Gál
text: Artist. - Commissioner, Colleagues! This debate has demonstrated, and I thank you for your comments, that we have come to fruition after a great few fights and different positions have been coordinated. However, they must take into account that the new legislation will finally put an end to the uncertainty that has cast a shadow over CEPOL in recent years. As you may remember, CEPOL had to find a new headquarters instead of its base in Bramshill. Moreover, the Commission has proposed that CEPOL and Europol be merged in the interest of cost savings. Thus, CEPOL had no registered office for a while, but even its very existence was called into question. As far as the merger is concerned – you all know it, because we voted on it here – the European Parliament and the Council have flatly rejected the Commission's proposal for a merger. As regards the seat, a number of Member States have offered to provide a home for CEPOL. In the end, budapest was chosen after Hungary the best deal in the world. We all know that we need professionally trained law enforcement officers, especially now, in these times, who can respond quickly and effectively at Pan-European level. We have now laid the foundation for this with this new regulation and we can create the conditions for CEPOL to contribute to the development of a genuine European policing culture. I believe that this is what we need, 100% of the time, in order to be effective in combating cross-border crime. And once again, I would like to thank all the shadow reporting staff, advisers and the LIBE Secretariat for their dedication, as we are after a successful series of negotiations.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday 29 October 2015.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the oral questions to the Council and the Commission on the follow-up to the European Parliament resolution of 12 March 2014 on mass electronic monitoring of EU citizens, tabled by Claude Moraes, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs ((O-000114/2015 - B8-0769/2015) – (O-000115/2015 - B8-0770/2015) – (2015/2635(RSP))

name: Claude Moraes
text: author. – Madam President, again I am not in my usual seat for the reasons I mentioned earlier. The oral question which I present today to the Commissioner – he is not yet in his place – but I am going to present the questions first and then explain this very sensitive and important topic to colleagues. The questions that we are going to present in the oral question are first of all: what is the Council’s and Commissionʼs general political assessment as to any electronic mass surveillance EU citizens are subject to? Do the Council and Commission consider EU citizens to be sufficiently protected against unnecessary electronic mass surveillance? What measures have the Council and Commission undertaken since the adoption of the resolution of 12 March 2014 in order to protect fundamental rights in a digital age, and what further measures do the Council and Commission plan to take? I am very conscious – Commissioner, I am sorry that you have just taken your seat, but I am sure you will catch up – that these are very broad questions, but what I want to say to colleagues present in the Chamber is that one of the most surprising things about the inquiry of March 2014 into mass surveillance was the outcome of the plenary vote – an extraordinary 544 Members in this plenary across the political spectrum voted for a very sensitive and far-reaching report. They did it because they were acting in a very mature way; they understood that what was happening was that we were not just dealing with one of the most important issues that all individual sovereign countries have to deal with – that is: the protection of their citizens, and therefore intelligence agencies have to do their work – but we were dealing with one of the biggest growth areas in the confidence, in the privacy of individual citizens, you and I. And we have seen in recent days massive data breaches of major telecom companies like Talk Talk. We have seen the judgment on Safe Harbour; and it is very prescient that such an important vote took place in March 2014 because human rights in a digital age were taken very seriously by this Parliament for a reason, and that is that privacy is not a soft option; privacy is fundamental to consumer confidence; privacy is fundamental to human rights in the digital age. So the resolution that we present to Members and to the Commission and Council is about what follow-up we have. In this follow-up resolution, if I take one example, the Safe Harbour judgment of the European Court of Justice, we have a situation where the European Parliament warned incessantly that Safe Harbour was not safe, that the transfers of mass data from the European Union which had higher standards of data protection compared to the United States, which had lower standards, would end up with this kind of situation and a negative situation. We warned of mass surveillance, not for security and purposes of protecting individuals, but simply mass surveillance, very expensive mass surveillance, which was uncontrolled, which has negative implications. Since then the Council of Europe and individual Member States, individual parliaments of Member States, have gone into great detail with their inquiries. And I am very proud that this Parliament went into great detail in the post-Snowden era on digital rights and human rights in the digital era, because we were able to say, on the one hand, that this is vital to tackle terrorism, it is vital to tackle security threats, but that it is incredibly important to understand that we will not do this if there is no credibility in the way that mass surveillance is carried out.  I think we set some good standards in March 2014. What we are now trying to do in this oral question is to see, with the four questions I have put to both Council and Commission, what follow up we actually have on all of these key points. For the European Union, with the trilogues currently running on data regulation, and on the question of the Data Directive, but also on the agreements on PNR, on SWIFT and so on, it is very important that we understand that the European Union is itself invested in transferring data as a European Union to other places; and for that reason we have the competence and we have the need to understand these issues and get these issues fixed. But most importantly it is about the privacy of the citizen, paramountly, and we need to represent the citizen, ensure they are confident in their privacy and ensure they have the confidence to go forward, and they feel they are represented. Look around you and see whether that is necessary and then look at this resolution and see whether it is worthy of support. So I hand over to the Commission and Council to tell us what they are now doing on this resolution and the questions I have put.

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, let me also wish- as I had forgotten in the previous question - a speedy recovery to the chairman of the LIBE committee. The Council shares Parliament's concerns about secret surveillance programmes and their impact on the privacy and personal data of EU citizens. This has been highlighted several times by previous presidencies, in the context of the plenary debates on this subject. States must take steps to protect their citizens, of course, from terrorism and other attacks on their sovereignty; however, these measures must also protect fundamental rights. International approaches to balancing data protection and security vary from country to country. At EU level, the starting point is first and foremost respect for the Charter of Fundamental Rights, including the right to the protection of the personal data of European citizens. In the United States, the appreciation of security and protection is linked to the experience of that country, and therefore different from what it is in Europe. Nevertheless, the United States is placing increasing emphasis on data protection considerations, as evidenced by the Freedom Act, passed in June 2015, and the Judicial Redress Act, recently introduced before Congress. Given the increasing volume of data flow on both sides of the Atlantic, it is clear that the balance between protection and security requires a constant debate between the Union and the United States. For our part, the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, each acting according to their competences, must play their full role. The report you presented, Mr Moraes, in 2014, rightly pointed out that the increasing use of mass surveillance has not been preceded by any democratic public debate. To ensure the proper protection of data, constant vigilance is required. The European Parliament had been vigilant, moreover, regarding the Safe Harbor agreement. I will not return here to the debate we had on this subject at the mini-plenary on 14 October in Brussels, it is up to the Commission to reserve the appropriate follow-up to the Court's judgment. Let me cite two positive international developments in the field of surveillance. First, the text of the Framework Agreement on Data Protection was signed in September. This is a step forward in ensuring data protection and providing EU citizens with mechanisms in the United States for judicial remedies in law enforcement matters. The Council is awaiting the Commission's proposal for the conclusion of the framework agreement and the European Parliament will be asked to give its approval to this proposal. Second, the Judicial Redress Act, which was introduced before Congress. These two developments help to protect the fundamental right of EU citizens to protect their data. Let us now return to the question you asked, Mr Moraes, namely the measures taken following the resolution of 12 March 2014. I would like to recall the following. First, the protection of fundamental rights in the digital age is an issue that is constantly on the agenda of meetings between the European Union and the United States, both at the senior official level and at the political level. These meetings restored confidence in the handling of personal data and led the US authorities to present the Judicial Redress Act specifically to Congress. Secondly, I would also like to recall the meeting that took place in Riga on 3 June 2015 between the Ministers of Home Affairs and Justice of the Union and the United States. The meeting culminated in the Riga Declaration, which sets out specific cooperation actions for the next five years to address these issues more effectively. These actions include data protection measures and a commitment by both sides to strengthen the implementation of the mutual legal assistance agreement they have concluded, so that law enforcement agencies can better cooperate in a manner that respects, precisely, data protection. Finally, with regard to data protection within the Union, the Council has given priority to intensifying negotiations with the European Parliament on the data protection package. I am particularly pleased with the intensive work that is currently being carried out devoted to both the General Data Protection Regulation and the Data Protection Directive for law enforcement purposes.  Both the Council and Parliament are committed to adopting a strong data protection framework by the end of the year. On this basis, the Council will continue to work with Parliament and the Commission to strengthen privacy rights and develop Europe's digital economy.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission remains concerned about media reports on surveillance programmes of the Member State intelligence services which appear to enable large—scale access to, and processing of, the data of Europeans. At the same time, the area of national security falls within the competence of Member States. However, these exception clauses for national security need to be interpreted strictly in the light of settled Court of Justice case law. In its ruling of 6 October 2015 in the Schrems case, the European Court of Justice further clarified that any legislation permitting public authorities to have access on a generalised basis to the content of electronic communications must be regarded as compromising the essence of the fundamental right to the respect of private life as guaranteed by Article 7 of the Charter. Likewise, legislation not providing for any possibility for an individual to pursue legal remedies in order to have access to personal data relating to him or to obtain the rectification or erasure of such data compromises the essence of the fundamental right to effective judicial protection, as guaranteed by Article 47 of the Charter.  As regards the protection of fundamental rights within the scope of EU law, let me point out the following. As Members know, two proposals for our data protection reform are at the last stage of interinstitutional negotiations. They will increase the standard of the protection of personal data within the European Union. Furthermore, on 8 September 2015, the Commission initialised with the US the ‘umbrella agreement’. The agreement covers all personal data exchanged between the EU and the US for the purpose of prevention of and prosecution for criminal offences, including terrorism. The Commission will propose signature and conclusion of the agreement only after the US Judicial Redress Bill, granting judicial redress rights to EU citizens, has been adopted. The bill has just passed through the House and we hope for rapid progress in the Senate as well. The umbrella agreement will guarantee a high level of protection of all personal data when transported between law enforcement authorities across the Atlantic. It will, in particular guarantee, that all EU citizens will have non-discriminatory access to US courts under the Privacy Act. Regarding Parliament’s request for the development of the European strategy for greater IT independence, the Commission is working to address the main points of the strategy by establishing the contractual public—private partnership on cybersecurity. The goal of this initiative, to be launched in 2016, will be to stimulate the competitiveness and innovation capacities of the digital security and privacy industry in Europe. Research and innovation projects on privacy and cyber security have already been launched using Horizon 2020 funding, and these activities will be pursued under the PPP. Moreover, the negotiations of the Network and Information Securities Directive, which aims to increase Member States’ capacity to react to cyber threats in a coordinated manner while imposing security requirements on critical infrastructure providers, should be completed by the end of this year.  The Commission further announced its intention to reform the ePrivacy Directive in the Digital Single Market strategy as soon as the general data protection reform has been adopted, with a focus on ensuring a high level of protection for data subjects and a level playing field for all market players. This includes a high degree of confidentiality of communications in Europe.  The Commission is also committed to increasing trust in cloud computing by launching a series of initiatives in 2016 covering certification, contracts, switching providers and a research open science cloud, as well as the support of the free flow of non-personal data. Also in the Digital Single Market strategy, the Commission announced that it will undertake a comprehensive assessment of the role of intermediaries in tackling illegal content online.  Finally, the Commission would like to underline that it has been for many years a major user of open source systems, for example its data centre. It would also like to refer to the strategy for internal use of Open Source Software, which was updated in July 2015. Security and confidentiality are systematically considered when defining the tendering specifications in the Commission’s IT contracts. All Commission contracts contain a clause referring to the applicable data protection legislation. The legal framework for procurement does not, however, allow favouring particular business models or limiting the award of contracts to EU companies. A thorough review and assessment of the Commission’s exposure in terms of IT security has been launched with a view to establishing an IT security reference framework to structure and prioritise a range of short-term actions and a longer term IT security strategy. Against a threat landscape that is becoming ever more challenging with increasingly sophisticated attacks, the Commission’s Chief Information Security Officer collaborates closely with the CERT-EU to prevent cyber threats, detect them at an early stage and work towards a quick resolution. CERT-EU collaborates with the European Union Agency for Network and Information Security on lessons learned to improve the protection of networks and with the European Cybercrime Centre in the context of threat assessment.

name: Axel Voss
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Thank you very much, Madam President. In 2013, we started to deal with the mass surveillance of our citizens because of the NSA incidents. That was right and that was important.  We have also committed ourselves to continuing to monitor the issue – and that is also true. However, what has now emerged in this motion for a resolution is, in my view, largely ideological demands which are no longer connected with mass surveillance at all. We should be more concerned here with the balance between general security and the privacy of individuals.  We are therefore in favour of mobile security standards or online communications, we are in favour of protecting the EU institutions and the relevant national or European actors, we are in favour of a trustworthy European cloud, we are also in favour of strengthening Europol's cyber centre, we are in favour of encryption in this area, we are in favour of balanced data protection, we are also in favour of auditing the intelligence services. perhaps even to the point of establishing a European secret service. But what does this have to do with TTIP or the TFTP programme? What is the point of demanding that our citizens be prosecuted if we do not even have the competence to do so? What is a sunset clause for all legislative texts here, without sufficient monitoring, when it would be enough to make an adjustment? This is totally disproportionate and completely irrelevant to the protection of our citizens. That is why I believe that this is also negligent in terms of general safety. We need to adapt even more and better to change and implement the right structures to safeguard Europe's security.

name: President. –
text: There are blue cards but we are running a little late so we will not accept them at this point, but will take catch-the-eye.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, at the end of the last parliamentary term the outbreak of the Snowden case shocked, in the right title, European citizens and made them aware of their fundamental rights, which were more vulnerable than ever. I had the honour to chair, as chairman of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, the monitoring committee, which produced relevant conclusions, including, the first, the impetus to the data protection package, which is still to be completed; In addition, regulate the figure of the whistleblower, the delator, to offer you criminal and procedural guarantee. In addition, to require the European Commission to put in place all measures to shield itself against third-party espionage, but also, above all, to suspend the Safe Harbour agreement, which has been declared invalid by the Court as incompatible with the fundamental European rights proclaimed by the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. The meaning of this question is to know exactly how the Commission intends to ensure that this judgment is binding not only on the bilateral relationship with the United States, but also on the mass surveillance that has been practiced by the Member States of the European Union themselves. Because the sentence goes beyond the bilateral relationship with the United States. The judgment also binds the Member States of the European Union themselves and also compromises illegitimate practices incompatible with European law of massive violation of citizens' privacy.

name: Timothy Kirkhope
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, our rights and our freedoms must always be the compass which guide society. These rights must always be defended with equal force to that which we use to defend our borders and our safety. Robust data protection and digital privacy laws must be constantly updated for the modern world, and accountability and effective and meaningful oversight of the agencies and the institutions charged with keeping us safe must form part of the fabric of democratic norms.  Of course, independent and thorough investigation must take place where any potential wrongdoing is revealed. This is essential if citizens are to have confidence in the people entrusted with protecting us. However, I cannot support this resolution. I will never regard Edward Snowden or his actions as ‘heroic’. I cannot bestow the label of hero upon a person who has endangered the lives of so many citizens across the world and those individuals serving overseas who risk their lives, day in and day out, to protect ours.  In my opinion the language in this resolution does little to offer a sensible approach but instead just seeks to escalate the rhetoric. I fail to see how producing a report from an investigation conducted in the political arena, with no access to official documents, with no powers to call relevant individuals to give evidence, and with no competence under EU law, can produce recommendations with even the smallest perceived amount of objectivity.  I cannot in conscience ever support a resolution of this Parliament that calls for the suspension of important anti-terror agreements with the United States given the security situation in Europe at present. A resolution of this kind, in my view, is something that can never be credible, relevant or responsible in the legitimate quest to provide real oversight and protection of individual rights for the people of Europe as a whole.

name: Cecilia Wikström
text: On the other: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Now is the time that we left the rhetoric and the feast speeches and instead stand up for and seriously defend fundamental human rights, where mass surveillance is absolutely not included. For liberals, there is no room for mass surveillance of citizens.  Developments are worrying across Europe. We are seeing several steps backwards in fact with regard to the particular view of privacy and data protection. Instead, the starting point seems increasingly to be based on the mistaken assumption that the more data we collect, the safer the citizens become. Nothing could be more wrong!
