My group deeply regrets that the Council and the Commission have consistently refused to answer Parliament's questions, which we asked for the first time over a year ago in the context of the debate on mass surveillance. We are also very concerned about the legislation now being passed in several Member States, where bulk mass data storage is now becoming the practice. Britain passed a law in 2014 which it now has to review, as the Supreme Court, the High Court, has annulled it. Germany has just decided on new data retention legislation, and France has introduced the possibility of mass surveillance of citizens for its intelligence services. We are also deeply concerned about Dutch intelligence legislation. I strongly urge my Liberal colleagues in the Dutch Government here and now to take careful account of yesterday's judgment in the Prakken d'Oliveira case. That ruling prohibits the monitoring of lawyers' communications until an independent review is carried out. The European Court of Justice's decision the other week on Safe Harbor should also be a wake-up call for everyone. That ruling states that AMERICAN mass surveillance is not compatible with EU laws and principles.  We must now start sweeping our own door and not depend on the courts to put right the legislation that we should jointly take responsibility for ensuring that it actually puts fundamental rights at the centre. It is up to all of us not to protect governments but to protect the fundamental rights of our citizens and the defence of European values.

name: Cornelia Ernst
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Not only is the NSA continuing to spy, spying on millions of people– things are no better in national states either.  In June 2015, the Bundestag decided to amend the law so that the BND can legally monitor the Frankfurt Internet node. Also in June 2015, France passed a law to massively expand the surveillance powers of the intelligence services. Austria has a new state protection law in place, and the Dutch government also wants to extend the powers of the secret services and no longer control them. The fact that we, as the only parliament in the world, have – if you can say – produced an investigation report on the NSA mass surveillance and a follow-up report, thereby urging an end to mass surveillance, is of no interest to either the Commission, nor the Council, and certainly not any government in Europe. And at that moment, one really seriously asks: what about the relationship between citizen and state? It is precisely this relationship that determines whether a community can be regarded as democratic or dictatorial.  How free is a citizen in a state if he can be monitored all around? What remains of freedom of expression, communication and freedom of the press? The rule of law includes the freedom of citizens, which means that the state must be there for the people and not the other way round. What is left of a representative democracy when the will of a freely elected Parliament like ours no longer counts? If it doesn't matter that hundreds of thousands of people are campaigning against mass surveillance in petitions? And when courts rule on data retention and declare it null and void and demand the protection of personal data as a fundamental right to be implemented, here in Europe and beyond? What is happening here is the incapacitation of the people of Europe, and it is precisely this that we, as democrats, really have to fight. My last sentence is: I thank Edward Snowden for what he has done, and I also thank Max Schrems.

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, it is now two years and four months ago since Edward Snowden revealed his knowledge about massive infringements by intelligence services of EU states and the United States. I think this is the moment, at least, where Heads of States and the European Commission should act and take their responsibilities. Until now there have been only two reactions to the revelations by Snowden, both of them taking seriously what he has said. The first is the US administration: Obama has conducted an investigation and changed the surveillance measures, but with regard to its own citizens, not with regard to European citizens or anyone else in the world where its intelligence services are spying on us. That is the problem. The second reaction is not by any politician in the European Union, not by any head of state, nor by any minister has there been taken action on behalf of the Snowden revelations, but here it was the highest court which took the action three weeks ago with the judgment on Safe Harbour. There it clearly referred to the facts revealed by Edward Snowden. If the highest court of the European Union says there is something which Edward Snowden rightfully said is an infringement to the Fundamental Rights Charter to our Treaties, should we not take that seriously? Should not the Commission start infringement procedures against those Member States which obviously still cooperate with those intelligence services, or even have intelligence services doing the same unlawful activities? This is not any more in the area of national security, which in Europe is obviously becoming the black hole of the rule of law. Every single Member State – and I looked at the count – says that the European Union and the law does not apply to national security. But does that mean that fundamental rights and the rule of law do not apply? Where is the activity by the Council, and where is the activity with regard to common rules and standards for intelligence services in Europe and for the protection of each individual’s fundamental right before the courts, effective judicial protection? That will be brought up by the Strasbourg Court if you do not act, at least in some years, because there are cases. Relying on individuals to fix the rule of law, this is not the right way.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it seems clear to me that we are currently faced with a huge contradiction on this issue on the part of the European Union as a whole, because while we want to proclaim ourselves as pioneers, as a bulwark institution in the defence of fundamental rights, on the other hand I listen to comments from conservative colleagues or colleagues in the people's area that these protections of fundamental rights can easily be renounced or suspended. , and on the other hand I also see a Commission that is not interested in this issue.  And we have had to wait for the Court of Justice to tell us that, on this case brought out by Snowden, on mass surveillance, on mass espionage by the American intelligence services, the attitude taken by the Commission is not good. This deal we have with them, this safe harbour, is not good.  I therefore expect, believe and hope that after this debate the approach will change, change attitudes and put back the fundamental rights and protection of these fundamental rights of European citizens before other types of interests.

name: Janice Atkinson
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – Madam President, I also would like to wish Mr Moraes a speedy recovery.  It is clear that the privacy of our citizens and our fundamental rights should be adequately protected. Institutions snooping on all of us without proper controls is something that has no place in a democratic society, but it is up to our national parliaments and national courts to strike the balance between upholding civil liberties of our citizens and ensuring our nationʼs security. Let us not forget that it is exactly the EU Commission’s Safe Harbour Agreement with the USA that gave citizens a false sense of security and national supervisory authorities that had such a passive role. This is one of the main conclusions of the ECJ ruling.  While I hear the European Parliament pointing out the dangers of mass surveillance of citizens by the US in Member States, what actually worries me more is the EUʼs ambitions to set up its own secret service agency – in fact, a spy agency. Indeed, it was even Mr Juncker who has suggested earlier this year that he would like to establish an EU spying agency. The last thing we want is Big Brother spying on the EU Member States and their citizens. The European Parliament has no jurisdiction whatsoever to involve itself in any way in how the nation states are running their security agencies. It is up to the Member States, not the EU, to uphold their own data protection laws and negotiate proper agreements with the countries.  However, I do pose an alternative. I strongly suggest that the Commissioners watch the new James Bond film, Spectre. Perhaps Mr Juncker would consider applying for Mʼs position and Mr Timmermans, with his many languages, might apply to replace Daniel Craig as 007. If so, they will be under the control of the British Government and not the EU, which is as it should be.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). Madam President, the mass, continuous and uncontrolled monitoring of European citizens is, unfortunately, still a reality today. The governments of the Member States, even with the knowledge of the European institutions, are constantly following all of us. They demonstrate their hypocrisy and at the same time how false the face of their so-called humanism is, and how false their words are when they refer to the protection of citizens' rights.  Leaked documents have revealed the consistent practice of some European countries to systematically monitor both citizens' conversations and communications, as well as policy talks, without a legal mandate from the judicial authorities. The reluctance of the judiciary to proceed with investigations into the various complaints has also been revealed. Typical examples: the monitoring of a large number of European politicians by the German secret services, on behalf of the US National Security Agency;  In any case, the European political establishment is once again revealed as a mere trustee of its across the Atlantic partners. We, as Greek nationalists and at the same time elected representatives of the Greek people in the European Parliament, call for the immediate cessation of any such illegal activity. Furthermore, in order for no shadow to be cast on the judicial authorities throughout the Union, we call for the immediate and exemplary punishment of those responsible for these intercepts, as well as of all those who have been covering them up for so long.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, first of all, let me wish Claude Moraes a recovery soon and thank him for this excellent report. This issue has been debated in the European Parliament for several years. Unfortunately, however, I have not seen much progress, even after our committee's resolution in May this year. Personally, I don't think we have anything to wait for. We do not have to have a debate here as to whether or not the protection of Citizens of the European Union from mass electronic surveillance is sufficient. It's not enough. This is a problem that is very urgent, and I am sorry that neither the European Commission nor the Member States are willing to deal with it seriously. In this respect, I am very disappointed by the lack of response and inaction on the part of the European Commission. And I believe that at least these questions put forward will sing it to more activity.

name: Marju Lauristin (S&D).
text: – Madam President, as a rapporteur on the Data Protection Directive, I have to say that we are now working on providing European citizens with the highest level of protection of their basic rights, and it is only this which could give us some moral right also to demand the same from all other partners in the world.  But at the same time, as this report shows, things are not in line with those high standards in some or many of our Member States – we do not know how many. The big problem is what was already referred to by my colleague Jan Albrecht, and what also I am very glad was mentioned by the Commissioner, namely that, as national security is under the competence of Member States, we really do not have common EU standards to understand where the borders lie in respect of national security issues, and how a citizen can understand how his rights can be protected when carrying out certain actions, when crossing this border, because the border is not visible.  We in the LIBE Committee have asked the Commission several times to give us a common definition, a common framework, of how in the EU we understand what is national security and what is not, and we have not had a clear answer. Now I ask the Council too, because when we are working on the directive, then we come to this grey area between public security and national security, and it is really very difficult to reach a solution without knowing where this border is and what are the guarantees for the other side of the border, the national security area, so that we really can say to our citizens: yes, we have the highest standards; yes, every EU citizen’s fundamental rights are protected above all other considerations, irrespective of the situation. So I urge the Commission and Council to provide us with this kind of clear knowledge of what we mean by national security.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR).
text: – We must do everything we can to avoid waking up in a world where the government intervenes disproportionately in privacy. Nevertheless, the N-VA delegation will vote against the motion for a resolution tomorrow. The European Parliament reacts wrongly because it does not respect the division of powers. National security is a national competence and it is the EU Member States that need to seriously investigate allegations of sneaky large-scale electronic surveillance. What the EU does, on the other hand, must do is continue to value data protection. Yesterday, trialogue negotiations were launched on the data protection directive in the criminal justice sphere. That should be and will remain the focus, rather than, for example, suspending valuable instruments, such as the terrorist financing tracking programme, in a cramp.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, the words we are speaking here are constantly 'concern' and 'disappointment'. And we have to thank Mr Moraes for the questions he is asking, because all of us need to answer European citizens as well. The violation of privacy is so great that criminals, intelligence agencies and telecommunications companies know all the details of our lives. And of the abuses that are happening every day, a small part come to light. The Commission is talking about a difficult and sophisticated environment;  True. Of course, the environment is difficult and sophisticated. We're not sure. And we are disappointed by the lack of urgency shown by the institutions and Member States since the adoption of the report adopted in March 2014 in our Parliament. If the question is sophisticated and difficult, why don't we go any further, why don't we put equal weapons on the threat to the way of life we should have as free citizens in a democracy? Equal weapons, therefore, to threats to our freedom. How many staff do you have to meet this challenge? The Commission has many things to answer to us: what timetable, what instruments and what staff it needs. If our freedom has been put on the windows by algorithms, with what algorithms and with what judicial control will we be able to defend it in a constant, correct and precise way? Answer us, please.

name: Eva Joly (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I want to first salute Edward Snowden's courage. He chose to give up his freedom to inform us of the nsa's massive surveillance. What have you done with these revelations? Almost nothing. The Commission's silence is deafening. No lessons have been learned. After the time of indignation, everyone prefers to ignore that these most fundamental rights are being violated every day; worse, under the guise of security, states, including France, adopt repressive laws where the prerogatives of the intelligence services are expanded, judicial and parliamentary control is almost non-existent and every citizen becomes a potential suspect.  As for whistleblowers, the Commission has not even deigned to consider the possibility of creating a European statute protecting them. Snowden will have sacrificed his freedom to see the building of the society he feared so much, a society that dismisses and freezes its citizens, which, far from protecting them, suspects them and, far from freeing them, forces them. Mr Dombrovskis, will the Commission finally follow Parliament's recommendations?

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the ruling of 6 October of the Court of Justice striking down the Commission’s Adequacy Decision on the US Safe Harbour Agreement confirms the longstanding doubts on the level of protection provided by this instrument. The decision was to be expected as the 2013 espionage revelations had already exposed the uselessness of the Agreement’s provisions in view of the citizen surveillance programme’s massive scale. As stated by the Court, permitting public authorities to have access on a generalised basis to the content of electronic communications compromises the essence of the fundamental right to privacy, while the lack of provisions on the right of citizens to complain about their data compromises the essence of the right to effective judicial protection. Against the backdrop of the recent invalidation of the Data Retention Directive, this new ruling calls for urgent action to strike the right balance between security measures and the protection of fundamental rights. Considering, on the one hand, the European conviction that security measures must be pursued under the rule of law and, on the other hand, the vital importance of EU-US counter-terrorism cooperation for both partners, it is of extreme importance that we swiftly take steps to establish common standards in the field of data protection.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I support the balanced resolution drawn up by LIBE President Claude Moraes. Edward Snowden, who as a whistleblower deserves to be protected and not persecuted, has allowed us to learn about the Prisioner programme and everything else we came to find out afterwards and which has greatly shaken transatlantic relations.  To restore confidence, the United States must accept a change in standards in building its own legal data protection system, which is incompatible with ours and international standards, and must ensure effective means of judicial and administrative recourse to Europeans and other citizens, including Americans.  The new bill that was just passed by the Senate yesterday, the CISA, Cybersecurity Information Sharing Act, also cannot leave the European Union indifferent. There are many voices in the United States of America who fear that this law will also be against the Freedom of Information Act.  It's not just the Responsibility of the United States. European governments and parliaments have been conniving, or at least complacent, allowed massive clandestine surveillance of our citizens, lived with an inadequate Safe Harbour agreement, overtook national data protection commissions or made them passive, neglected democratic control over the intelligence services and have shown an unacceptable lack of political will and a sense of urgency.  What is now the global status on data protection between the European Union and the United States after the legal vacuum created by the Decision of the European Court of Justice in the Max Schrems case?  We absolutely must ensure that the high levels of protection of fundamental rights enshrined in the European Union are respected and the Commission must enforce the Court's decision now in negotiations with the United States and must confront European governments and parliaments with their responsibilities.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has We decided literally in March 2014: the European Parliament called on the EU Member States to ban blanket mass surveillance. That sounded great - kind of. But this suggests the mass surveillance of citizens, which is in principle permitted by the state, to the extent or because it is not expressly prohibited. This is the opposite of a liberal rule of law. In a liberal constitutional state, the state is prohibited from interfering with the rights of citizens, unless it is expressly permitted. In our own estimation, therefore, we no longer seem to have a liberal constitutional state. But this is the core idea of the state-thinking of the Western world. This thought has been lost to us. We are in the process of forgetting our values and our roots. These are in our Christian-Western culture. We must find or preserve them. That seems to me to be the order of the day.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The Committee of Inquiry into the NSA affair was certainly one of the highlights of the last parliamentary term. Not only has it produced new results, but it has, above all, strengthened citizens' confidence in democratic institutions. That is why I believe it is necessary to continue this very young tradition of this House. To strengthen citizens' confidence in the Internet through legislation that European data should also have the same protection in third countries. This political insight was confirmed by the Safe Harbour judgment. We must not now move on to the agenda and turn a blind eye, but we must fill this vacuum that has now arisen with substance. Citizens, consumers and businesses have the right to safety. We need consistent steps. I believe that the report by Claude Moraes shows this line in line with Parliament's tradition, and I hope that the Council and the Commission can endorse this vision.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the judgment of 6 October on safe harbour has shown that the concerns often expressed in this Parliament about the level of protection of european citizens' personal data under the agreement on the transfer of data from Europe to the United States are well founded.  As has already happened in the field of data retention, the Court has had to make up for the continuing difficulties, if I may say so, for the Commission and the Council to adopt, on sensitive issues of privacy and data protection, regulatory measures and international agreements in line with the Charter of Fundamental Rights. A difficulty that needs to be overcome.  To this end, the Commission and the Council will have to follow the Court's lead in negotiating a new agreement with the United States, replacing the logic of pure self-regulation with a more reactive and proactive surveillance system, thanks in part to the role to be accorded to our Data Protection Authorities, but they will also have to follow up more vigorously the European Parliament resolution of 12 March 2014 in its many aspects. , without waiting for further action by the Court.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the electronic mass surveillance of citizens of the European Union has been decisively condemned by the European Parliament in a resolution in March 2014. But what were the practical results of this resolution? The deep state in the various Member States of the Union is trying to legitimise the practices of mass surveillance of citizens in the name of supposedly security. However, the pursuit of citizens' safety must not lead to the violation of fundamental rights. It must not lead to the violation of the privacy and personal data of Union citizens. It must not lead to surveillance of citizens and politicians by Germany's secret services.  At the same time, the judgment of the Court of Justice of the Union in Safe Harbour has shown that there is no guarantee of protection of data transmitted to the USA. So how will European citizens be compensated? We need legislation that imposes severe penalties on those who make illegal surveillance and mechanisms for seeking and awarding compensation for personality damage and moral damage.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, when we are talking about electronic mass surveillance, we live in dangerous times and it is undoubtedly right that counter-terrorism and anti-organised crime agencies do need to be vigilant in the digital world as well as in the real world. Having said that, I am a libertarian at heart and really do not like being spied on by government agencies of any government or any state. My mistrust of the state is magnified to a huge level when it comes to my mistrust of the EU superstate. So please excuse me if I do not place my trust in the EU to protect my personal freedom, as everything in this place is all aimed at, and targeted round, the power of the state over the individual. So when it comes to this kind of thing about mass surveillance and individual rights, I have to ask for leave not to support the EU to do anything. I think I would rather put my trust elsewhere.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: " I did not initially want to speak in this debate, because I have spoken so many times about Snowden, and we have said so many times what Edward Snowden has found practically at the risk of his life, that in Western democracies, masses of citizens are being monitored by secret services, eavesdropping, reading their emails, collecting data, and then arbitrarily using the so-called phishing method, when business interests, economic interests or political interests so require. , this data will be misused.  Why did I ask for the floor? During the lunch break, I was talking to someone about the Béla Kovács case. I told him that I still couldn't get on the agenda, that an elected representative had been monitored, wiretapped and all that for four years by secret service tools, and that when they found out that phishing or not they could commit any crime, they retroactively created one. Commissioner, Mr Moraes, I would like to thank you for your support. Is it possible that we elected MEPs may be wiretapped by secret service means? I look forward to your response and also how this is possible!

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I strongly believe that when giving special powers and capabilities to intelligence services in democratic societies, this should be done in order to protect fundamental rights, democracy and the rule of law, citizensʼ rights and the fight against internal and external threats, and those powers must be subject to democratic accountability and judicial oversight. Their application should be strictly scrutinised, as otherwise they lose legitimacy and they risk undermining our democracy. I therefore support the request for the Council and the Commission to let us know if they consider EU citizens to be sufficiently protected against electronic mass surveillance. It is of utmost importance that EU citizens know if there is any electronic mass surveillance they are subjected to, and in this case that institutions work together to ensure that citizensʼ fundamental rights are respected.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: Madam President, this instrument, as well as computers, tablets and all communicative objects, can be the best or worst of things. If I use it to work, inform myself, cultivate myself or give news to my family, that is of course the best, and it is useful. If I use it to organize trafficking, an attack or an attack on society and people, that is the worst, and it is detestable. And of course, all the mass information in these communicating objects ends up in the cloud. How do you tell the difference between good grain and chaff?  It is the whole question of the balance between security and freedom that is being asked today. This is a recurring issue that we have been debating for a very long time. I believe that the citizens themselves are asking themselves a number of questions, depending on the current situation, and if they want to keep their freedom today - and this is unavoidable from my point of view - and also want to be protected, we must find a way to ensure that technology meets the law.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, I have heard a lot this afternoon about individual rights, democracy and democratic accountability, but when you look at the record of this place, this Chamber, this Union, they have ignored referendums, they have sought that democratic governments be toppled – and we need only look at the Portuguese election where, as Nigel Farage said, if you had replaced in the Brezhnev doctrine ‘socialist’ with ‘European Union’, it’s the same thing. This place has no right to lecture anyone on any of those principles, because you lot put the interests of the European Union first. You have the euro, which has created mass unemployment. You have the desire for ever closer union, which rejects democracy. You have created the borders crisis. You have no right whatsoever to lecture any of the governments or any of the peoples of this European Union, because if you keep doing that, we will break free. Britain will be free, and after that, many other nations in this Union will be free.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: "Indeed, the wolves are already in our yard. I would like to remind the Commissioner that, in my country, Hungary, the Government of Viktor Orban has already introduced a series of measures towards the establishment of a police state, which severely restricts the rights of Hungarian citizens, while combating so-called illegal migrants. Now, under the pretext of protecting public order, it has announced a further package of measures to implement almost unlimited police control of the communications of individuals and even a general facial recognition system not linked to a specific law enforcement purpose for the general population.  Officer, I'm sorry. Madam President, I would like to thank you for This is what is going on in a Member State of the European Union today, and Viktor Orban is using it to monitor opposition organisations. Today, masses of people say they refuse to take part in demonstrations because they will be retaliated against by police the next day precisely because of mass surveillance. Be nice to deal with that.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, this was a very necessary and useful debate. I would like to underline that the Commission is taking the issues raised in the draft solution seriously. Where it is within our competence, the Commission is already acting in order to ensure the fundamental rights enshrined in this Charter are fully respected. This comprises a speedy conclusion of the Data Protection reform, as well as various projects under the Digital Market initiative. It also includes a swift response to the Court of Justice judgment on the Commissionʼs Safe Harbour decision in the Max Schrems case. To this effect, I assure you that the Commission is engaged in intensive discussions with our US counterparts. I am confident that we will find the right answers and solutions to ensure an adequate protection of the fundamental rights guaranteed by the Charter.

name: PUHEMIES. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday 29 October 2015.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: Madam President, I'm not sure if it's exactly point of order, but I have a little request. Can it be verified whether this room is by far the healthiest room in the European Parliament? Namely, here I see several colleagues who already have tissues. I ask you colleague, don't laugh because it's a very serious question, and funny is what you're saying otherwise. I had a big problem last time and I got sick the last time I was in plenary because I am one of those who most often sits in plenary session. Please try to check, this room is by far the healthiest room in this house.

name: President. –
text: We will contact a technician.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, I dare say my colleague would feel warmer had this place not passed such ridiculous energy legislation that puts bills up.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The opening of borders, the unregion of communication networks and the massification of digital data are at the root of a global regulatory flaw. The risk would be to believe that we can control this space dominated by new information and communication technologies, by surveillance rules.  Yet this is the dramatic and liberticidal dynamic that has been borrowed by many governments, whether for political, military or economic purposes. Mass surveillance is a reality and there is no reason to believe at this time that states will backtrack on this issue. Because without being able to control the flow of people and being able to control the use of computer data around the world, most governments have opted for the pre-totalitarian formula of the end of privacy and individual espionage, soon to be legal, alas.  I fear to see here the latest tension in a world strangely mixed with neoliberalism and authoritarian socialism. Being attached to freedoms, I will remain uncompromising with the integrity of the privacy of my countrymen.

name: Ramona Nicole Mănescu (PPE)
text: in writing. – This is a topic that has given rise to a lot of debates all over Europe. As AFET co-rapporteur for this resolution, I advocated the necessity to maintain equilibrium in the final text between the two priorities that seem to collide in this situation. I consider that the amendments proposed by the Socialists and the left-wing political groups represent a significant modification of the text in relation to the initial goal. A resolution dedicated to the issue of mass surveillance of European citizens cannot end up by calling for the suspension of the TFTP agreement, TTIP agreement negotiations or the replacement of proprietary software with open-source software in all the EU institutions. There is the justified need of privacy for the 500 million European citizens. And there are the new security threats, from cybernetic war to online recruitment and proselytising by terrorist groups. In the middle lies a reality: the same way the USA needs the EU, the EU needs to have a strong and healthy relation with the United States. These partnerships, despite the inevitable disagreements, give strength to both sides of the Atlantic and are envied by all of those who are promoters of ‘divide et impera’.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Mr Rosati on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: implementation of 2015 priorities (2015/2210 (INI) – (A8-0307/2015) and the Commission statement on Steps towards completing the Economic and Monetary Union (2015/2907(RSP)).

name: Dariusz Rosati
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, the recent financial and economic crisis has demonstrated that the European Union economies are strongly interdependent and that national policies in one Member State can have important spillover effects on other Member States. We have realised that more coordination of national economic policies is needed within the EU in order to prevent imbalances, ensure convergence and exploit potential synergies. The European Semester, introduced in 2011 within the Six—pack, is the most important instrument for national policy coordination and surveillance in the EU. Each year the Commission undertakes a detailed analysis of EU Member States’ budgetary, macroeconomic and structural reform plans and provides them with policy recommendations for the next 12 to 18 months. These country—specific recommendations (CSRs) provide guidance and advice to Member States on how to stimulate growth and jobs in conformity with the Europe 2020 Strategy, while at the same time avoiding excessive imbalances. Each year the European Semester cycle starts with the annual growth survey published by the Commission in the late autumn, in which key policy priorities are specified for Member States and the EU a whole. It is then followed by an assessment of draft budgetary plans and country report analyses. On that basis the Commission proposes country—specific recommendations, which are then discussed with national governments and are then endorsed by the European Council and adopted formally by the Council. Drawing on experience from the previous cycles, this year the Commission has proposed to shorten and streamline the whole process in order to give Member States more time to react and also to focus on key priorities. We welcome these changes, while underlining the fact that further action is needed to make the coordination process more efficient and less bureaucratic. This year, priorities focus on the most important growth drivers and include investment for growth and jobs, growth-friendly fiscal consolidation, structural reforms in the labour, product and services markets, and active employment policies. We support these priorities, but we think that more effort is needed to implement them effectively, especially in the area of structural reforms that are necessary for increasing potential growth in Europe. These reforms should concentrate on removing barriers in the product and services markets and on making labour markets more flexible, while balancing this with the adequate protection of employees’ rights. Equally important is the need to radically improve access to finance, especially for small and medium—sized enterprises, and to make the legal and administrative environment more friendly for businesses and to deal effectively with excessive indebtedness in the private sector. We share the Commission’s view that continued fiscal consolidation is needed in Member States with unsustainable debt levels and that strict compliance with EU fiscal rules under the reformed Stability and Growth Pact is absolutely crucial for sustainable recovery. However, we also recognise that countries with sufficient fiscal space have the potential to further accelerate domestic investment. We also share the Commission’s opinion that the actual implementation of CSRs by Member States leaves much to be desired. Less than 15% of all CSRs were actually fully implemented in 2014. Thus the potential positive impact of coordination is seriously diminished.  In this context, we call on Member States to radically improve the implementation record through faster transposition, more active political support and, above all, strengthened national ownership. The European Semester offers an opportunity for securing faster growth in Europe and avoiding devastating crises in the future. I call on this House to support our report.

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr rapporteur, I welcome this opportunity to debate the European Semester with you. We have all just received the Commission's proposals for a renovated Semester. The Council will consider this issue in the coming weeks to draw conclusions, already, for the 2016 financial year.  The three institutions share - and I have listened to you, Mr rapporteur - the analysis of the main challenges facing the European economy, namely the high level of debt, the unacceptable unemployment rate, a global competitiveness which suffers particularly from an insufficient level of research and development and a dangerous investment gap which weighs on the growth potential of the European economy. We propose similar solutions, more effective and broader implementation of structural reforms, growth-oriented fiscal consolidation, better access to finance for small and medium-sized enterprises, education systems that better meet the needs of labour markets, and above all - and above all - a revival of investment.  Since the first European Semester of 2012, we have made progress, and the 2015 edition is a good example. This year, country-specific recommendations are more limited in number and better targeted at key country-specific macroeconomic problems. In addition, while calling for long-term reforms, the recommendations also focus on short- and medium-term actions. The scope of the recommendations is reinforced. The 2015 recommendations are also anchored in stronger country-based analyses. The presentation of these analyses ahead of the recommendations, as early as February, allowed the Commission to examine them in depth, including through the peer review method, the so-called "peer review".  The Commission also had more time to work on the recommendations themselves. In this way, we have been able to better align the Commission's proposals with the realities on the ground. This less tight timetable has also allowed Member States to involve national stakeholders and parliaments in the process of economic coordination at national level. This contributes to the appropriation of the recommendations and to the more effective implementation of them.  The Council discussed this fall the lessons to be learned from the 2015 Semester. And we are pleased with the progress made in organizing this Semester. Our discussions also highlighted other improvements that could further strengthen the process. This concerns above all the transparency of the procedure of macroeconomic imbalances, on which the Commission has just presented its ideas, as well as the link between the European Semester and the supervision provided for in the Stability and Growth Pact. We will consider the Commission's new proposals on these aspects without delay. So what policy will this coordination process take us to? In what areas did we use this tool? At the macroeconomic level, I would like to focus on investment and access to finance. At the same time last year, the Commission presented the investment plan and the co-legislators adopted the proposal on the European Fund for Strategic Investments in record time. Secondly, in reviewing the country-by-country recommendations of 2015, Member States welcomed the Commission's emphasis on growth-enhancing fiscal policies, whether it be efficient spending, public investment and stimulating private investment, or more appropriate taxation. This autumn, at the ministerial level, work on the Commission's action plan for a capital markets union began. The Council will adopt conclusions on this issue in November. The Presidency is committed to progress in the work on the securitisation proposal. We are counting on the cooperation of Parliament to move this issue forward. With regard to employment and social policy, in approving country-specific recommendations last summer, the Council also recognised the realities on the ground. Unemployment and social inclusion continue to pose major challenges in a number of Member States. For their citizens, the improvement in the economic outlook in Europe has not yet been felt in terms of employment or the social situation. Increasing poverty remains a major issue, particularly poverty affecting children. The renovated 2020 strategy, which will have to be presented by the Commission in the months ahead, I think, will have to provide for more effective targets and actions in this area.  We need to step up efforts to reduce still significantly high levels of unemployment in many Member States and improve the functioning of labour markets and social protection systems. Progress in these areas is also essential to consolidate growth. The political stakes are high. Citizens expect policies to resolve their problems from Europe. Progress in the fight against youth unemployment is still insufficient. Even if there is progress, we need to strengthen our instruments, such as the youth guarantee, and go beyond that. We need more economic convergence, we also need more social convergence. And to move social Europe forward, certain themes, such as worker mobility, will be the subject of Commission proposals at the end of this year.  The exchange of good practices and peer review, or the definition of common benchmarks, as we are establishing for the integration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market, are useful in such an approach.  In the area of competitiveness, the Council's work confirms that Member States share the same analysis on the main challenges. With regard to the country-specific recommendations, the Council was very pleased to find the theme of investment, whether it was the opening up of markets for goods and services, the regulatory framework, a better business environment or increased efficiency of public administration. The Council will also continue its work, which includes improving the functioning of the internal market. I think it is a major asset that we do not always get the full benefits of.  In this context, the digitisation of the single market is certainly one of our major projects, not to mention smart regulation and support for innovation hubs. Strengthening research and development - I recall that we have made a commitment to invest 3% of GDP in research and development - promoting innovation through a better articulation between the public and private sectors, supporting business creation, as well as investing in human capital are essential to a European economy that is renewing and positioning itself in relation to its main competitors.  Before concluding, I would like to return briefly to the implementation of the country-specific recommendations. You highlight this issue by recommending that the Commission present a detailed overview of the progress made by the Member States, or that it consider the introduction of an incentive mechanism. I would like to assure you that the implementation of the recommendations remains the Council's top priority. We are convinced that the reforms of the European Semester introduced last spring are already bringing us closer to this goal. But the most important thing remains to be done, and we will consider the Commission's new proposals on a renovated Semester with this in mind.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, let me start by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Rosati, as well as the shadow rapporteurs and all Members involved in the work for their engagement and dedication. The Commission welcomes Parliamentʼs constructive contribution by way of its timely reports such as those of Mr Rosati and the June report by Ms Berès. Today I have an opportunity to present to you the package of measures adopted by the Commission last week aiming to make the economic and monetary union more effective, transparent and democratic. Our package intends to restart economic and social convergence by implementing key short- to medium-term elements of the Five Presidents’ report: revamping the European Semester, improving the toolbox of economic governance rules, improving the voice of euro area internationally, completing the financial union, and preparing for stage two on more far-reaching measures that could require a Treaty change. Let me start with the European Semester. This is the heart of Europeʼs efforts to coordinate economic policies and deliver reforms. Nevertheless, as you rightly stated, Member States have demonstrated varying degrees of commitment to the process. The Commission has constantly been improving the EU Semester to strengthen Member States’ implementation of reforms. In 2015 we have streamlined it to sharpen its focus, better involve national stakeholders and strengthen its social dimension. We value your support in recognising our efforts. Building on these developments, some further adjustments can bring additional benefits. Firstly we share your view that many Member States, in particular in the euro area, are faced with inter—dependent macroeconomic challenges. Therefore we intend to better integrate the euro area and national dimensions. Recommendations for the euro area will come out earlier than before, so that common challenges can be reflected in recommendations for individual euro area countries. Second, on several occasions Parliament also called for the social dimension of the European Semester to be strengthened. The Commission has already taken steps to do so, on which we will build further. Specifically, more attention will be given to employment and social performance in the macro-economic imbalances procedure. Moreover, we intend to further improve involvement of EU and national social partners. Social fairness will also get more attention in the context of macroeconomic adjustment programmes, and we have already put this into practice for the Greek programme, for the first time preparing the social impact assessment of the programme. Third, you asked the Commission to support Member States’ exchange of best practices. We agree that this is a valuable tool to achieve convergence. We will launch new efforts to promote greater use of benchmarking and cross-examination across policy or thematic areas.  First, in order to focus EU structural and investment funds on supporting reforms, the Commission will enhance their links to key priorities in the CSRs. Effective reform implementation will also be supported through the progressive roll-out of technical assistance by the Commission structural reform support service.  Last week the Commission also presented concrete measures to improve our toolbox of economic governance. The Commission is not proposing a legislative reform. More evidence and experience with reform governance structures are necessary before embarking on such a road. But the Commission has listened to your calls to improve transparency and to reduce the complexity of available instruments and tools, so we will take action. We will notably increase the documentation on the methodologies we use, publish more information and data backing our decisions under the Stability and Growth Pact and the macroeconomic imbalances procedure, and work to streamline the indicators for assessing compliance with the Stability and Growth Pact. Moreover, as you have rightly stated in the report, the foundations of the recovery are fragile owing to the EU’s underlying structural weaknesses, lack of competitiveness and low investment. The capacity to compete and to adjust is essential for economies to deal with shocks and structural changes and to prosper within a monetary union. It is therefore a focus of our economic policy coordination already today; but we suggest that more be done to strengthen national ownership. We are therefore proposing that national competitiveness boards be set up in all euro area Member States. They would be independent bodies that provide expertise on competitiveness, performance and reforms. The definition of competitiveness in the Commissionʼs proposal is broad, covering both cost and non-cost competitiveness drivers. Our objective here is to strengthen and support national processes and the role of social partners – not to hamper them.  National traditions are very different. We have therefore considered it better to start with a recommendation to Member States and not move straight to legislation. But even so the European Parliament must be fully part of this debate from the start, and your views will be important to shape the debate on the competitiveness boards.  The Commission has also decided to set up an Advisory European Fiscal Board. This board will provide advice on the implementation of fiscal rules, taking into account both national and euro area developments. But let me be clear: any proposals for fiscal decisions under the Treaty remain fully with the Commission, and we are politically responsible for them to this Parliament.  We are also taking steps to complete the banking union. We need to implement what was agreed with strong support from this Parliament, and we need to finish what we have started. This includes full transposition of the BRRD Directive and implementation of the Deposit Guarantee Schemes Directive; and the agreement on bridge financing for the single resolution fund must be completed swiftly.  We plan to present a legislative proposal on first steps towards a European deposit insurance scheme by the end of the year, based on the reinsurance approach. We also plan to set out ways to reduce further risk in the banking sector and ensure a level playing field. A strong EMU must go hand in hand with a strong, single voice on the global stage. We therefore propose to gradually develop a unified representation of the euro area in the IMF. We propose that the President of the Eurogroup should ultimately represent the euro area internationally.  Finally, the Commission considers effective democratic legitimacy and accountability to be an indispensable element of the process to complete EMU. Steps have been taken towards that in the recent past, and the Commission is proposing concrete steps to move further along the lines of the Five Presidents’ report. We expect the European Parliament to take part in shaping the debates to define the economic and social priorities of the EU. This is why we propose to engage in frequent debates throughout the European Semester, for instance in the plenary debate after the publication of the AGS package and upon presentation of the Commissionʼs proposals for country-specific recommendations. The Commission and the Parliament are in permanent contact, and I am confident we can further refine the details of our cooperation in these matters. To ensure ownership, legitimacy and accountability, we also aim to engage with a broader range of actors. In the lead-up to this European Semester, which will start with the annual growth survey next month, we have been consulting social partners, both trade unions and business representatives, on the priorities for the year ahead. During this year, I and my fellow Members of the Commission have also travelled to many capitals and met national parliament representatives.  We want national parliaments to be more deeply involved in the adoption of national reform and stability programmes. This is essential to strengthen the ownership, and thereby implementation, of reforms. The last package should be seen as a first stepping stone towards completing economic and monetary union, but we also need more far-reaching measures – those requiring Treaty change. We are talking here about the preparation for stage two of the Five Presidents’ report. We will need to shape consensus on those more fundamental changes, so we will launch a broad consultation gathering ideas from across Europe.  Next year we will appoint a dedicated expert group to explore legal, economic and political implementation for the long term. All this will feed into the Commissionʼs White Paper in spring 2017. The European Parliamentʼs input will be a crucial contribution to the next stages in the process of completing EMU. I am looking forward to hearing your views on the proposed approach.

name: Nils Torvalds
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. – Madam President, Commissioner Dombrovskis and Minister Schmit, I would like to begin by thanking theresa May for her excellent work. I sometimes get worried about the way in which the European Parliament works. This concern also sometimes extends to concerns about the way in which the Commission works.  I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Rosati, for the way in which he has worked. When we got this assignment, the first draft statement was actually a pretty good piece of paper. It was concise, and there were quite a few issues that I wanted to improve on that in that context. I was, of course, concerned that the implementation percentage of the CSRs was almost non-existent, i.e. we produce a lot of paper that we send out to our Member States, and then the Member States browse these papers. That's it. Anything else doesn't come out of it. We should therefore have really focused all our attention on how to improve this process, but in Parliament something rather strange is happening in this context. To use an expression that has now become popular in Finland, it suddenly seems that the 'Moomins had fled the valley', i.e. as if all understanding had disappeared from Parliament as well. Instead of sticking to a concise paper, there are an endless bunch of proposals that have quite a bit to do with the actual mission. It is really just a way for members of this House to somehow show that they are staying awake and doing their work.  So we have an irrational process that does not lead us forward. Inside the proposal, we get everything between heaven and earth, but no improvements to the country-specific recommendations. In this irrational process, it may also be the case that the proposals made by my colleague Sven Giegold, which are, at least to some extent, quite sensible, fall away. There are also some proposals in which we really should think about the future – how, for example, education for young people in the various Member States works. How do these things come into our recommendations? To sum up this brief, I think we should try to gather our Moomins so that we would have a slightly simpler and better process in the future as well.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto
text: drafts member of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. – Madam President; Commissioner, Minister Schmit, from the Committee on Employment we have made a proposal report for a situation which remains critical. Criticism, because one more year we have to say that the economic recovery remains slow and fragile. We must continue to talk about the fact that unemployment exchanges continue, one more year, in a situation that is totally unbearable from a social and economic point of view; an unemployment situation that also leads more and more Europeans to long-term unemployment, which illuminates today's pockets of poverty. And also the problem of inequality because, according to the OECD report, there are still more people today who accumulate more wealth at the expense of more people accumulating more situations of extreme difficulty. Today's stock market, the gap between the 10% that has the most compared to the least 10% in the European Union has multiplied in some countries by up to seven, and that is mainly due to fiscally unfair policies, to the detriment of socially redistributive policies, and also, of course, how not , to the lack of quality in employment, to the precariousness of employment through the European Union as a whole. That is why I agree with Mr Schmit that great analysts are needed in the European Parliament, that we need greater coordination, but above all we need changes, profound changes. Because we are talking about youth unemployment, but we have an underfunded Youth Guarantee; we are talking about long-term standing, but we only remember the European Social Fund's 10 billion; we are talking about labour poverty, but the Commission blocks the European minimum wage framework. Citizens don't need words or analysis. They need changes, actions and, above all, solutions, which is what we come to claim with the European Semester, in the report of the Committee on Employment.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. – As a reporter for the IMCO Committee, I would first like to thank Mr Rosati for his work. You've done a great job.  Overall, this European Semester– I agree with commissioner – I think it has evolved a great much since its insanity, it has evolved a great much, and we are now slowly reaching our goal. However, there are main priorities on which it would be good to focus more, such as the internal market as a major reserve, and I believe that strengthening the pillar of the internal market should be reflected in this report. We are focused on increasing economic growth, but we are talking very little about our biggest reserve, the reserves of the functioning of the internal market.  However, I am pleased that the SME and even its lack of funding have been mentioned, which is still a pressing problem. I'm happy for FSI when it came out as an alternative tool. I would like to see such an alternative instrument for SMEs, which could work much more efficiently. Overall, what I can say is that it would be much better for tangible development if we had a stronger and better view of the internal market. I hope you'll be more involved in the next report.

name: Ernest Urtasun
text: draftser of the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. – Madam President, the first thing is to thank Mr Rosati for his work and for the good attitude — I have to say - throughout the negotiation process, and for his open-up, even though we are obviously not happy with the final outcome of the report, for some of the issues I am going to cite. Firstly, because of all the issues we have introduced in the opinion that was voted on in the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality — and, by the way, I would also like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs of the opinion in committee — many of them have not been incorporated into the report. It's taken a long time for the Semester to have a gender perspective. The truth is that in the latest reports there was not even an opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality in the Semester. It's great that we've been able to reintroduce it. It would be very nice now if, in the next report, the Committee on Economic and Budget affairs took more account of many of the issues we are pointing out. Because, look, many of the reforms pushed through REP have a very, very important effect on gender equality. And I can talk about labour market reforms, pension reforms — which have been driven by many in the context of the Semester — which have had a very negative effect in terms of equality: if we are talking, for example, about the reform of the listed years and their impact on pensions; if we talk, for example, about the effect that many labour reforms have had on the ability to reconcile work and family; and that is jeopardizing years of progress in increasing the rate of female labour activity and therefore there are many negative aspects to this issue. We had put in the opinion a whole range of elements: that there be a gender assessment when the reforms are carried out; that the European Institute for Gender Equality could play a role in the process of recommendations... Well, a whole list of proposals which unfortunately have not been included, but which are obviously important, are on the table and my group will continue to insist on them because they are so important. I go to the general framework of the report, once we have mentioned the issues we have raised from the Committee on Women's Rights. I believe that the report shields an economic policy model in recent years in Europe that has not worked, and on top of that all the things that have not been done right - and which we know have not been done well - we refuse to recognise them. Having too low investment, having relied too much on external demand, having applied extreme internal devaluations and extreme budgetary adjustments in some Member States, which have made things worse; all these issues are not recognised as such in the report and I have to say that the vision given is extremely triumphant. There are some proposals that we had made and which we have been calling for for many years: for example - and that is one thing I would like to stress to the Commission - that there have been social indicators in the PDM is one thing that the Commission has repeatedly promised us, social indicators and also environmental indicators, energy efficiency indicators. Where's that reform? Where are those indicators you've promised us so many times? We haven't seen them. And, therefore, other issues, for example, which have to do with democracy and democratic control: What about the issues of the little transparency that exists right now in the Eurogroup? Well, all these issues worry us. And I end up with one thing, and with this I'm done, which is all you've presented to us about reform. Surely my colleague Sven Giegold will insist on it, but the first package presented to us by the five presidents, which is very timid, is extremely timid in implementation of the report and does not contain the substance or what we need for eurozone governance reform. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for your contribution. Two quick questions: the first is, you talk about new economic instruments. How about the best economic instrument this Parliament and this Union can promote? Ditch the euro. Let currencies devalue, decouple, and actually start growth again. You also talked about democracy. I would like to know your views on the ‘coup d’état’ in Portugal, where a democratically—elected parliament was overruled by a president who decreed that the European Union and the euro zone were more important than the wishes of the Portuguese people. What are your views on that?

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: "blue card" response. "Well, I don't know exactly what I was wondering. In any case, on eurozone governance issues, I don't think we agree on many of the things. And on Portugal, look, I am not Portuguese, but in any case, I regret the attitude of President Cavaco Silva, who seems to me to be absolutely undemocratic. Since it gives me the opportunity to have an opinion on this issue, then I would allow myself to do so.

name: Burkhard Balz
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her As the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, we very much welcome the opinion of the ECON Committee, because we believe that it sets the right priorities. It calls for the consistent implementation of structural reforms, in particular comprehensive reforms in the labour market, in order to achieve flexibility while reconciling wages and competitiveness, better starting conditions for the real economy, less bureaucratic hurdles and, most importantly, greater support for small and medium-sized enterprises. A look at the eurozone, as the Commission is now planning separately in the European Semester, can certainly be helpful. But it must be clear and it must also remain clear where the responsibilities lie for a sustainable budgetary policy, for a successful reform agenda and, therefore, for greater competitiveness and growth, namely the individual Member States. We know that the Member States have a 'deficiency' in their testimonies in complying with the country-specific recommendations. The Commission, Mr Dombrovskis, must act on this, and urgently. The European Semester is for budgetary surveillance, and that must remain the focus. The early warning system available to us with the European Semester must also be used, on the basis of the individual Member States, not on an aggregated basis. That is why we are calling for the existing rules to be applied and also to be enforced, both for large and small Member States.

name: Elisa Ferreira
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Commissioner Dombrovskis, the crisis has shown that economic and monetary union must be completed, and quickly. But the Commission's recent communication does not contribute to this objective, quite the contrary.  In 2012, at the height of the crisis, we know that the three institutions converged on a long-term vision: Parliament made the report of Marianne Thyssen, her colleague now in the Commission, there was the text of Herman Van Rompuy, or the four presidents plus one, and the european commission's blueprint, and the condition for the election and confirmation of Jean-Claude Juncker was that this process be relaunched — and it was through the report of the five presidents. But now that we are taking the first steps of implementation, it is with great surprise and disappointment that we find that the first test of this commitment is not working. And it is not working because the European Commission says it wants to hear from the European Parliament. But, for example, in the European Semester, at what stage and how is the European Parliament heard, and the European Semester itself is based and built on the six-pack and two-pack, which were legislative texts in which this Parliament was an active co-legislator? The European Commission takes refuge in an intergovernmental framework, which is what has not worked, and therefore misses the opportunity, for example, to frame the European Stabilisation Mechanism in a Community-based context. And it goes so far as to hand over the external representation of the euro area to the President of the Eurogroup who, as we know, does not report to this Parliament or any Community institution. So, Commissioner, what agenda is the European Commission following? Because it is certainly not an answer to either Marianne Thyssen's report in the past or to the Berès report, which was adopted here by this Plenary.  I hope that the agenda will still be corrected and that the Commission will realise that, in order to make progress in the euro area, the two Community institutions - Parliament and the Commission - must work hand in hand, and not only with the so-called lip service in English, which in practice does not guarantee any accountability or any democratic control. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. "I applied because I feel very, very similar and rather vehement that we have to say that we are dissatisfied. Because, seeing this debate, watching the comments and reading everything that one had to read here in preparation for the European Semester, I notice that Europe and the European Member States do not realise how difficult we are. And I am thinking, in particular, that, for example, in reducing unemployment, in the development plans of individual Member States next year, we do not seem to want to move forward. I ask you nicely to continue calmly what you just started to say, because I wonder how you would push the process forward.

name: Elisa Ferreira (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – I think this Parliament has been extremely active in trying to contribute to the completion of the monetary union, and we have strong suggestions, as noted recently in the Berès report and previously in Marianne Thyssen’s report, that the Commission knows this. This is not what we expect from the Commission in this first phase. This first phase is too inter-governmental and it does not solve the problems in terms of growth, combating imbalances and bringing forward true employment and true convergence.  So please, Commissioner, look at back at the text and try to correct it before it is too late; because Parliament is supporting you provided you do the right thing.

name: Stanisław Ożóg
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Each year, the Commission undertakes a detailed analysis of member states' budgetary, macroeconomic and structural reform plans and makes recommendations to them for the next 12, 18 months, and we in Parliament, also every year, assess the state of play and the degree to which Member States implement the recommendations made to them by the Commission. The Report on the European Semester aims to analyse the overall economic situation in Europe, the state of implementation of reforms and possible future economic initiatives of the Union. If we want a real improvement in the economic situation, we must frankly debate these changes that should take place and openly acknowledge that some of the steps taken so far in the European Union or in individual Member States have not had the desired effect. I will say more, we must also admit many mistakes. On the occasion of the debate on the European Semester, I lack a fact-based opinion. This is mainly a clash of political positions, not a documented analysis of the reforms needed. In this way, we will not achieve the desired results and allow the European Union to collapse even further in its competitiveness vis-à-vis other economies in the world.

name: Antanas Guoga
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I think the implementation of the existing single market legislation in the European Semester process is a priority for us. The single market is one of Europe’s greatest achievements. In the last 50 years it has generated new opportunities, created jobs and offered greater choice at lower prices for consumers. But the work is far from finished. However, it is very important for us to concentrate on the positives that have been achieved so that we can also look to a positive future.  I am also disappointed that the Commission did not publish the single market integration report as part of the Annual Growth Survey this year. We should take note of that. The Commission should ensure that Member States implement the European legislation adopted on the single market, in all its dimensions, and place stronger emphasis on the implementation of existing single market legislation. The European Semester process is a perfect tool for that. We should use it more efficiently.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. – You, in fact, too, although you mention emphatically that there is some kind of economic growth in Europe, if I understand your words well. I would be a little more cautious here, and I would also like to criticise the report, because to say things like that, that economic growth seems to be kicking in, I think that is an unnecessary optimism, especially with the other claims made in the report. I'm sure you'd agree with me.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you very much. What I stressed  is that there have been a lot of achievements with the Single Market over the last 50 years. Economic growth is not doing great – obviously we know that – and for that we need structural reforms and serious reforms for that to be achieved.  I do not think we can have just a financial stimulus from the ECB. So if we all unite and carry out further reforms that are necessary, and Member States carry out those reforms, growth rates would be significantly higher.

name: Marisa Matias
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur Rosati's efforts on the European Semester - I genuinely thank you - but I would like to talk about the reasons why I cannot support this report, and I am dedicated to a fundamental issue, which, in my view, is one of the real fundamental problems for which we continue to face so many difficulties: it is that, with each report of the European Semester, we continue to deal with beliefs and not political reality or even reasonableness.  The belief is that we have to treat trade surpluses differently in relation to deficits. As I said, I am talking about this issue of trade surpluses and deficits, because more and more deficits are being carried and trade surpluses are becoming more naturalised. However, the issue of surpluses and deficits is not a political issue, it is a matter of logic: international trade is a zero-sum game — in order to have surpluses on one side, there must be deficits on the other. And in this sense, continuing this path, with a very strong hand with the weakest, of punishment, of penalization, and a very light hand with the strongest, is a way for the disaggregation of monetary union and of the European Union itself. Furthermore, I do not think that we can continue to bet on the deregulation of the labour market, and I would like to make one last comment: please do not ask the Committee for Women for the European Semester for opinions if they do not take into account any of the proposals on gender inequality.

name: Sven Giegold
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. –  Mr President, first of all, the European Semester is shaped among other things by its attachment to fulfilling the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy, and it is one of the major tools in order to make the Union achieve these objectives.  Unfortunately, this round of the European Semester’s recommendations basically do not show any serious measures to reduce poverty, and all the environment-related measures were totally taken out of the European Semester. While in previous periods there were always strong structural reforms suggested by the Commission in order to increase resource efficiency, to generate competitive new business in the green sector, this time everything is gone.  I would like to ask you, Commissioner, whether you are still attached to the 2020 objectives and to the role of the European Semester in order to achieve these objectives, and I also would like to know why you took out all the environment-related measures, which have always been there in the past.  Secondly, I think the key problem here is that, even if you do not agree with all of these measures as they are proposed, it is clear that the euro in particular, but also Europe as a whole, needs the European Semester process. We all know that the level of accomplishment of the country-specific recommendations is appallingly low. Mr President of the Council, Mr Schmit, from my perspective you did not address the key question: what did you do in order to increase the number of recommendations, which the Council – which is voting on these recommendations – is really implementing?  Where is your decisive action to make your fellow Member States, including Germany and many others, truly reforming in the sense of the European Semester?  We make a joke of the European Semester. Nobody takes it seriously any more if the Council does not manage to implement. And to the Commission: I feel your proposals on the Semester lack a clear enforcement strategy. I cannot see a tough enforcement strategy, and that is really a shortcoming. I have one last point concerning your proposal, one which really needs its own debate, but the European Fiscal Board is an advisory body, which you could have had proposed under the ordinary legislative process. Now you create what is almost a new institution without a proper legal base and without giving Parliament and the co-legislator the right to co-decide on that. That is a lack of European democracy and a lack of commitment to European democracy from your side.

name: Marco Valli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, what I would like to highlight about this report is still the total lack of democratic involvement in the decision-making processes of the European Semester and the very one on which this Commission is pushing. We have seen how democracy is proving to be opposed to the six months, to reforms, to liberalisations, to austerity, to private investment.
