Democracy is reacting violently, and you continue to impose, as you did in Italy in 2011, as you did in Greece, as you did just now in Portugal, these same failed policies. We have, of course, demonstrated our democratic disagreement, because we had this mandate from the citizens, who gave us the vote to try to bring about this change. But it will never happen. Because? Because, unfortunately, austerity is linked to the euro. We have seen how we cannot think of another Europe, different and without austerity, by remaining in the euro, and Tsipras and his failure are precisely the example that should prove it to everyone. And also because only German is spoken in this Europe. Let us see how the procedures are applied for the weak countries, whereas for Germany, which has had a trade surplus of more than 6% for 7 years, Commissioner, no sanctions are imposed and no rules apply to ensure that Germany fulfils its moral obligations towards what is an internal market that it is destroying. So do something about it, but we don't believe it now because you take a completely different line from common sense.  (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for your comments. We have heard all the previous speakers waffle on about instruments here and economics there, and so on, but do you agree with me that they are blind and ignorant to the solution staring them in the face, in that the euro has to go? It does not matter what you all are talking about: you are blind to the fact that the euro is causing the misery that is angering your constituents. So would you agree with me that, before anyone else speaks, the first thing they say to solve the economic problems in this Union is that the euro must go?

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: answer to a "blue card" question. Thank you for your question. I would like to highlight a factor that has happened just these days. We have seen elections in the eurozone, in Portugal, where the President has imposed himself by saying that in order to guarantee the stability of the financial markets, he could not allow a government against austerity to question the project of this Europe. But we have seen that Poland, a country that does not have the euro, can still afford to have a political force that is even a little opposed to these crazy and unholy eurozone policies. So those who have monetary sovereignty also have the democratic opportunity to decide their own future. Those who do not have it remain slaves to this eurozone system.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: Mr President, I do not want to interfere with your mastery of this plenary, but we are two hours late and every intervention in this debate causes a blue card, which obviously does not help to revive the discussion but simply allows new speakers to fit into the list that was originally planned.  Could you not stop handing out blue cards so that registered speakers can normally speak in this debate?

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: Thank you very much. You do not want to, but you are trying to interfere. I would like to inform you that the genesis, the source of the word parliament is parlare – to speak. And as long as I am president, I will give a voice to those Members who want to speak in accordance with the procedure. We actually have a time delay. It is not due to the fact that I preside, because I have only been chairing for a few minutes.

name: Bernard Monot
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, Commissioner, according to the ENF, the finding is unfortunately damning to refer to the European Semester 2015. Despite successive reports and coordination cycles, macroeconomic indicators are still in the red. The divergence in growth, borrowing, unemployment and inflation rates in the 19 eurozone economies is proof that the euro has never been, ex post, the optimal monetary zone that the ultraliberal elites promised to citizens from the beginning.  Therefore, in a frantic flight forward to escape the sad realities of this policy destructive of wealth and jobs, the disoriented European leaders push the experience to the point of economic federalism. To complete the Economic and Monetary Union, the report of the five presidents thus proposes more restrictive country recommendations or, worse, a single representation of the euro area. As if having, tomorrow, Mr Dombrovskis or Mr Moscovici as European Minister would change anything to the structural economic decline of our eurozone countries. The same causes will have the same effects: austerity that kills domestic demand, free trade, the ECB's hyperlaxism, the laissez-faireship of states in the face of multinationals and banks, privatisations, deregulation of the labour market, mass immigration will lead Europeans to social misery. Your policy is one of deadlock, it is time to get out of it, otherwise, do not be surprised by the rise of the Euroscepticism of the peoples.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – The INSTITUTIONS of the Union say that they want to be close to the population. Then why do they use the term European Semester? What does that say to the average person? Call it by name. This is about the central approval of the Member States' budgets. As a member of the Hungarian Parliament and a member of the COMMITTEE on EU Affairs, I was informed of the so-called convergence programme when the Government sent it to Brussels. And when we get it back at the end of the semester, they're practically the main budget numbers. This system deprives the parliaments of sovereign countries of budgetary law. And the reporter is amazed that the country-specific recommendations are not being met. That's because they're not really specific. The Union wants to put the same economic policy on all countries, not the real economic policies that are important to the countries. Parliaments' budgetary rights must be returned.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE).
text: – Mr President; Commissioner, ministers, ladies and gentlemen, as you all know, the coordination of economic and budgetary policies within the European Union are the keys to the European Semester. It is therefore our responsibility to contribute to ensuring the convergence and stability of the European Union; contribute to ensuring healthy public finances; encourage economic growth; prevent excessive macroeconomic imbalances and implement the Europe 2020 strategy. But, I stress, the first priority, without a doubt, is to boost growth and job creation. And to do this we must all be aware that the most immediate formula, without a doubt, is structural reforms. Spain is an example of this. It has been one of the most ambitious countries in this regard and is the fastest growing country in the eurozone as a whole — it grows twice as much as the rest of the countries — and it is also the one that generates the most jobs. But let us not forget, either that we will not have a consolidated and lasting economic recovery over time until we create a true and genuine economic union.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D).
text: – Mr President, at the end of the Semester cycle one still wonders whether our approach is as effective as the claim originally made for it. True, deficits have been curtailed in a majority of Member States and, arguably, national debt levels are going down – but would that not have happened anyway, given normal economic and financial pressures? Not so, we are told.  Our procedures were designed to forestall financial Armageddon among Member States. In this they have succeeded by ensuring that rule-based methods compatible with free markets apply to all national players. However, these methods have not led to economic growth at the desired level. Such growth, as there has been, remains fragile. Despite the quantitative easing programme run by the European Central Bank, its President Mario Draghi stated again that he is prepared to do anything to keep the system on track. Saying that once was necessary; having to say it twice becomes less effective. So perhaps we need to evaluate critically the Semester cycle of surveillance. Member States must now satisfy rules that in practice impose more constraints than exist on states in the USA under a federal system, which is not the case for the EU. Other rules such as those for the banking union, necessary though they are, have also introduced down the line new costs and delays in the circulation and mobilisation of funds. One—size—fits—all criteria for pension issues seem to be proliferating. Meanwhile, social considerations which were a backbone of European macroeconomic policies are frequently side-lined. Beyond critically evaluating the Semester procedures, perhaps we also need to change perspectives. We need to get over the fixation that the priority should remain that of not letting 2008 happen again.

name: Sander Loones (ECR).
text: I have taken the rapporteur's original report and there are some very good things in it. We need to streamline the European semester, put budgets in order, make the labour market more flexible and structurally reform. Many of these good points are still in this report, but they have been watered down. As a result, this report suffers somewhat from the same ailment as the European semester itself. This report lacks focus, it's about anything and everything. That is exactly what the European semester should do: focus on strengthening European economies and on giving member states sufficient policy space to pursue an adapted economic policy.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, Mr Dombrovskis, I am afraid that the optimism and embellishment that characterized your speech and Mr Dombrovskis' speech. Schmit is far from the reality, showing an increase in unemployment, an increase in poverty, an increase in social inequalities, a reduction in investment and anemic and flimsy economic recovery, and this is due to the failure of dogmatic unilateral austerity, which would supposedly bring investment and bring disinvestment, and to a distorted deficit architecture of the euro area, which you refuse to see to correct these deficits. I ask you: Where is the Eurogroup accountable? The Eurogroup is the boss of the euro area, the Commission is the extra and the European Parliament is on the sidelines. Mr Dombrovskis, on 16 September you were with Mr Dombrovskis. Moscovici in the Economic Committee of the European Parliament and Said Pierre Moscovici that he is a strong believer in the Community method and that he does not believe in the intergovernmental method, and on 21 October you presented proposals, ignoring the European Parliament, on how the five presidents' proposal would proceed. If we want the euro zone to go in favour of the citizens, then you will have to abandon the intergovernmental method and everyone and the Eurogroup in the European Parliament will have to be held accountable.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR)
text: "blue card" question. – The Greek colleague is rightly critical of the euro area and what is happening in the euro area. But I don't hear him offering solutions. Why are you not considering leaving the euro area? You then negotiate a substantial debt write-off and at the same time ensure that you can continue to enjoy the European funds. That way you can make a restart outside the eurozone, which I'm sure is really best for your country. Why don't you argue that?

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (
text: GUE/NGL), answer a blue card question. – Thank you for the suggestion, you are not original, you repeat Mr Schäuble's proposal, which is rejected by the vast majority of Greeks, rejected and rejected by the Commission, and rejected by Mrs Merkel and the Summit. As for the Brits who applauded you, I recommend them if they want an exit to work on Brexit in the 2017 referendum. We Greeks want to change Europe, not escape it.

name: Jean Lambert (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I wanted to start by just making the point that austerity is not a philosophy or a practice restricted to the eurozone. Those living in the UK should well understand that it is a matter of political choice. I wanted to say that Parliament has long stressed the need for the economic and social dimension of the Semester to carry equal weight, and of course I agree totally with my colleague Sven Giegold on the environmental dimension there. We need to care about our natural capital as well. But the social dimension is about more than employment. We are risking coming back as if somehow employment is the be—all and end—all. It is important, of course, and we should recognise that labour market flexibility, for example, does not mean that all power passes to the employer. Employers are expected to flexible as well as workers. We need to recognise that shifting work patterns must not mean that people lose their social rights, and that trickle-down, as mentioned by one or two other speakers, is a very poor form of social irrigation. We know that, if you really want things to grow, you water from the roots up and you look after the people first. When we are talking about the Social Impact Assessment linked to the Semester, I think it really is time that we saw it operating so that we are looking at the widest impact of the potential policies that are actually being pursued, and so that we are not actually destroying what we claim to be protecting.

name: Patrick O'Flynn (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, the Semester report is a very curious detective story. For the most part the evidence of the abominations that have been visited on the peoples of Europe is expertly sifted by Mr Rosati. He notes, for instance, the destructive influence of an overvalued currency on exports, production, employment, wages and much else. At last I think the euro is being prosecuted as the villain of the piece. The report calls on the Commission to explore innovative ways of lessening the need for a painful internal devaluation. Hurray, I think, this must be code for letting the southern periphery leave the euro. The next paragraph notes that a currency union in a currency area that is far from optimal necessarily leaves some of its members trapped with a currency that is overvalued. Yes, I now think, Hercule Poirot, I love you! But then comes the crushing baffling disappointment.  Mr Rosati lets the villain of the piece off the hook. In fact he makes the villain chief of police. He says all EU Member States should be engaged in each stage of completing economic and monetary union. To quote a famous British voice: ʻNo, no, noʼ. The report notes a persistently high unemployment rate across most Member States. This will indeed persist, notwithstanding some short-term cyclical improvements, so long as you all persist with the euro. Case closed, Your Honour!

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF).
text: Ladies and gentlemen, you must stop all this nonsense. I understand, of course, that in your philosophy – in that almost religious world of your currency union – you have to slowly but surely, semester after semester, move foot after foot towards an impossible unitary economy, in the honor and glory of your religion, ad majorem dei gloriam. Otherwise, it won't work. Then you find that your system is still not stable and that it is further streamlining the member state and cultural differences that were once the richness and strength of the European continent in a distant past but which, as it should be, have now been declared a sin, which nationalism and populism are called and set aside. Please stop all this nonsense. You're alchemists who're going to make the place explode. Only European cooperation between free, strong Member States can provide a solution.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI). Mr President, the report under discussion shows that the European Semester is a powerful unpopular tool for enforcing the European Union's strategy for the benefit of monopolies, which cruelly attack the people. In this context, the Greek people are facing the barbaric attack with the third left-wing memorandum of the SYRIZA-ANEL government. Structural reforms, supervision and budgetary discipline are being promoted in the context of the deepening of EMU that they require: flexible, transparent working relationships, facilitating mass redundancies; dramatic wage reductions at the minimum income level; maintaining tax breaks for business groups, burdening people with new burdens; demolishing the social-insurance system, making it more employer-friendly, smashing pensions and the right to free health and welfare. If these objectives are not achieved, the financial councils will automatically reduce salaries and social expenditure.  This unpopular attack, in order to be tackled, requires well-organized struggles to meet popular needs, a struggle against its capital and power.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE).
text: – Mr President, indeed, the European Semester has become an effective tool for coordinating the economic policies of the Member States, and I would like, here, to point out that the Vice-President of the European Commission, Mr Dombrovskis, has noticed a weakness in this process, namely the role of national parliaments.  He promised to go to the member states to discuss these issues with national parliaments. Why is that? Because in some Member States national parliaments are not involved in the European Semester since spring. Governments shall submit proposals for national reform programmes, as well as proposals for convergence or stability programmes, as appropriate, directly to the European Commission without national parliaments having any idea what is proposed in these programmes. As a result, national parliaments only appear in the process in the autumn, when governments present themselves with draft budgets for adoption and then surely the reaction is usually negative: "we are required to take some measures from somewhere in the European Commission and so on".  I therefore welcome Mr Dombrovskis' initiative to have more communication with national parliaments.

name: Maria João Rodrigues (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I will focus my comments on the recent package presented by the Commission to streamline the European Semester and to complete Economic and Monetary Union. The Commission announced the purpose – which I very much support – of promoting upward convergence, but I am afraid that the solutions which are being proposed will not be enough to deliver these goals. If you really want to deliver upward convergence, you need first of all to change the targets, starting with competitiveness. It is very important to focus improvement in competitiveness on factors for the future, meaning innovation, education, energy and public administration, rather than just controlling labour costs. Then you also need to change the social targets because it is important to take into account not only unemployment rates, but also social inequalities, because they are increasing in Europe. Then you need to change the priorities in the country—specific recommendations. Yes, we need reforms; but the reforms which should be prioritised concern education, innovation and public administration. Above all, we need much more investment and, finally, we need to raise demand, particularly asking surplus countries to spend more. So this means quite a change in the priorities the Commission is recommending.  We also need to increase financial support with a real fiscal capacity. Without that it is difficult to have real upward convergence.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). – Mr Dombrovskis, a few days ago you visited Athens to check the implementation of the Third Memorandum, a memorandum imposing a tax break on the pockets and fortunes of poor Greek citizens, reducing wages and pensions, breaking up the insurance and primary sectors, taxing farmers savagely, leading the country into recession, increasing unemployment, closing small and medium-sized enterprises and launching the sell-off of public property. At the same time, Mr Dombrovskis, you have caused great concern with your statements about so-called bail-in if the banks are not recapitalising by the end of '15, a recapitalisation which, as you said, can only take place after the completion of the first evaluation, i.e. after the imposition of the memorial measures that will turn Greece into a social graveyard.  Mr Dombrovskis, the memorandums implemented in Greece failed and gave birth to the country with armies of unemployed people; So where did the money go, Mr Dombrovskis?

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the European Semester has become a by—term for an economic platform that has undermined sovereignty, undermined democracy, and has absolutely eroded public confidence in the European Institutions. But, above all, it is a failed economic platform. It is interesting to hear today some MEPs crying crocodile tears over the fact that Parliament has been denied legislative powers in the European Semester when this House has conspired to deny the democratic rights of citizens to determine the economic direction of their countries.  The European Semester is simply reinforcing a set of policies that have entrenched the democratic deficit and disillusioned citizens even further. It is a set of policies that have created unequal societies and has failed to address the underlying problems of boom and bust economics that have beset countries like Ireland.  The European Semester and the document that we are discussing today are a failed economic policy. We need to accept what our citizens already accept: that it is time for a new direction for European economics and European politics.

name: David Coburn (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, most people in this place talk about one of three things: themselves, their own amendments or how wonderful the EU is, or indeed all three at once. I am not going to do any of them. I am going to talk about someone else’s amendments. The Greens – lovely people, a little confused, hearts in the right place, all that – but most of their policies are not on the same planet as the one they want to save. How, for example, is the EU meant to meet their amendment to ‘monitor progress towards decoupling economic development from the use of natural resources’? Well, however, we can agree on the amendment which says ‘we deplore the Eurogroup’s absence of democratic legitimacy and accountability when it assumes executive powers’. The Eurogroup should not meet behind closed doors, nor keep the minutes private, but the kind-hearted Greens are probably the only people in this place who would believe the EU is going to change this.

name: David Casa (PPE).
text: – Nibda billi anki jiena nirringrazzja lir-Rapporteur is-Sur Rosati għax-xogħol tajjeb illi għamel f'dan ir-rapport. U nilqa' b'mod partikolari wkoll il-fatt illi hemm pajjiżi membri li għamlu avvanz fir-rigward tal-politika dwar l-impjiegi, u li dawn huma waħda mill-erba' prijoritajiet prin大ipali illi l-Kummisjoni identifikat fi-ikeiklu ta' din issena. Napprezza wkoll l-isforzi li għamlet il-Kummissjoni sabiex, dan is-semestru, tiffoka speikeifikament fuq suġġetti ta' prijorità partikolari. Madankollu rridu nżidu l-momentum tal-isforzi tagħna sabiex insaħħu il-pro大ess tal-pussess nazzjonali tas-CSRs billi nżidu l-involviment tal-imsieħba soħjaħli u nazzjonali matul il-pro大ess kollu, eżatt kif irrimarkat tajjeb dan l-aħħar il-Kummissjoni.  Għalkemm hemm sinjali ta' titjib fil-problema tal-qgħad fost iż-żgħażagħ, din xorta għadha problema kbira ħafna, u rridu naraw in-numri tagħhom jonqsu. Tajjeb li noħolqu studji, tajjeb li nitkellmu dwar din il-problema, però issa ejja nibdew ngħaddu għall-fatti ħalli naraw iktar żgħażag jidħlu fid-dinja taxog xħħol. Naqbel perfettament ma' dak li qalet Jean Lambert illi l-problema tax-xogħol mhix biss l-unika problema li nħabbtu magħha dittadini Ewropej, imma għandek problema wkoll so大jali illi ġabet magħha il-kriżi ekonomika, u anki din irridu nibdewdirizzawha b'aktar serjetà. U allura nemmen li għandna bżonn il-pajjiżi membri jikkommettu ruħhom serjament biex jaffrontaw dawn il-problemi olistikament u jimplimentaw politika dwar ix-xogħol li tkun effettiva u li tolqot kemm lil dawk li qed ifittxu x-xogħol, kif ukoll lil dawk li qegħdin jimpjegaw.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: Mr President, Mr President of the Council, I invite you to look carefully at this package which the Commission has just put on the table, because it does not, it seems to me, correspond to the objectives of the Luxembourg Presidency.  Commissioner, I have the impression that you are ignoring a letter that was sent by the President of this institution to the President of your institution and saying: 'On behalf of the Conference of Presidents I would therefore like to formally ask you as President of the European Commission to reconsider the package in light of the point raised here'.  I do not have time to go back to the points that were raised by the President of Parliament in this letter, but I do draw your attention to it.  Thank you for mentioning the Berès report, but you seem to be ignoring its essence. For the essence of the Berès report is to show that treaties do many things. However, it seems that the roadmap you have just proposed is your answer to this question: what can be done without treaty revision? If we can only do what you have proposed to us, the euro is in very bad shape. For what do you say about the need to redefine the priority in terms of investment for the euro area or in terms of real convergence, which implies fiscal and social harmonisation? What do you say to that famous social dimension which the President of the Commission has told us will be the triple-A of his mandate? And then I worry because sometimes, listening to you and reading what you are saying, I get the impression that you are actually responding to a political and institutional roadmap of your political family. This is not acceptable to my political family, whose support is essential to the exercise of power by your Commission.  (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation)

name: Patrick O’Flynn (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – I am very grateful, as I know the lady is not keen on blue cards. For once, she has made the points about the European level of governance and I suppose I made similar points earlier, but she should be looking at her own national government because her political party, with the French President’s party, has ruined the economy of France. It has chased all the wealth creators away – some of them have come to Britain and to London, and we are grateful for that. Surely the key to improving the French economy would be a much lower tax economic outlook than the one her disastrous Socialist President has imposed.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D)
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, I thank the British citizen for taking an interest in the situation of the French economy, and I invite him to look at the latest unemployment figures, which are the result of the policy initiated by the President of the Republic, François Hollande.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, I asked you to get the word simply because I am constantly in this hall and different presidents are running this session differently. This gentleman just spoke, he had his own speaking time. Now he's asking questions. He's already set up the blue card three times, they're setting each other up. Some presidents who preside do not allow such practice, so I ask that you establish practice as a presidency, not ask each other questions from the club just to promote each other. Or the man who just spoke sets a blue card for this lady. Well, that doesn't make any sense. We'll be here by tomorrow morning.

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR).
text: – In almost all European Member States, the European Union is struggling with its image. It is not possible to get the citizens excited about Europe. Unfortunately, too few groups in this House are drawing any real conclusions. We also see this in part in the Rosati report. On the one hand, rapporteur Rosati makes good suggestions, for example to better involve the national parliaments in the whole process. On the other hand, he also calls for more Europe, for example when referring to the five-president plan or a new system of own resources in the European Union. We don't have to go that way. Agreements of the Stability and Growth Pact have been violated with impunity for years, for example by France. Deficits are also running out of budgets for next year. It's not supposed to be like that anymore. We have to do what's agreed. Only then will we regain the trust of the citizens, not by advocating more and more Europe. (The speaker is prepared to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules)).

name: Paul Tang (S&D)
text: "blue card" question. – Mr van Dalen's argument actually amounts to 'rules are rules'. Let us be, Mr Van Dalen, you must also acknowledge that this policy has not worked, not in an economic sense but also in the political sense. Since when has the premise of "rules are rules" brought enthusiasm? How is this supposed to fuel enthusiasm for the European Union? I wonder how many hands you get together for that.

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR)
text: "blue card" answer. – The great flaw of Europe is that many colleagues here are always thinking 'more Europe must, more Europe is doing you good'. But what is not being done is to finally live up to the things we have agreed upon. That's not going to happen. For years, the standards of the Stability and Growth Pact have simply been exceeded. The Commission is not inseizing. Day in and day out, these measures are simply violated. We need to change that. That is the crux of my plea. We must honour what we agree before we start shouting: more Europe must be done, it will all solve it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the European Semester operationalises economic governance and therefore represents the real weapon of submission of national states to the neoliberal creed. Not only does it not solve anything, it aggravates economic and social problems. In Portugal, fiscal consolidation has generated more unemployment, more poverty, more social inequalities and a public debt never seen in the history of our democracy. But Europe, with 25 million unemployed and 120 million poor, is also not moving forward, despite the BILLIONS of THE ECB's euros injected into the financial system.  The European Fund for Strategic Investments, the document of the five Presidents or the intention to align the calendar of the European Semester are only deatory maneuvers, aimed at avoiding confrontation with reality. Economic governance promotes a macroeconomic framework incompatible with any recovery policy. Look at the Finnish example, once a model of virtues when it comes to budgetary discipline, but which did not escape recession and also ended up breaking the deficit limits. How long will the European institutions remain blind to reality?

name: Andreas Schwab (PPE).
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the European Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for his excellent work and for the work he has I believe that today's debate on the European Semester is indeed largely determined by the fact that a few weeks ago, on the basis of the five Presidents' report, we received new proposals, which the European Commission also included in its strategy. Secondly, the European Commission today presented the Internal Market Strategy. I would like to anticipate this, because I believe that it does not help us in this Chamber at all if each of us believes that we know everything better and that the others are to blame for the problems. In the end, we will only return to the economic phase of growth in the euro area, in Europe, if we try to achieve the necessary steps together. One thing is obvious: on all the macroeconomic issues that exist in this area and about which there is also controversy, an important element, which can in any case ensure joint growth, is better implementation of the common internal market rules. That is why I think it is important that we focus more on the idea that Michel Barnier put forward in the last Commission, the so-called single market governance strategy. Because if, in the context of the European Semester, we want to talk to the representatives of the national parliaments as European parliamentarians, we will not reasonably be able to do so if we only talk about macroeconomic issues, but the national parliamentarians – I fully agree with Mrs Rodrigues of the S&D Group – will only participate if they are involved. This is what the Internal Market Strategy serves to do. I believe that we can make progress on this together with the national parliamentarians. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, I would like to thank the Yes, I would like to thank Mr Schwab, because it is quite simply also a question of how we shape the future.  I wanted to ask him how he sees the effect of incentives for employment and for small and medium-sized enterprises, especially for start-ups, and whether this could possibly be anchored in this European Semester?

name: Andreas Schwab (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Rübig points to the important question of what small and medium-sized enterprises can achieve in the European internal market. If we have uniform rules that are applied and implemented in the same way in all the Member States of the European Union, this is the best growth concept for small and medium-sized enterprises in Europe – and throughout Europe. Especially for those countries where unemployment is particularly high at the moment.  It is our common objective in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats to work actively to reduce unemployment, particularly among young people, as My colleague David Casa has pointed out. That is why we need to strengthen small and medium-sized enterprises, which can be engines of growth. The honourable Member is absolutely right.

name: Paul Tang (S&D).
text: – Economic governance, it still sounds a bit dusty to many, but it is about democracy. The administration must never consist of bureaucratic rules. That's death in the pot for politics. Nevertheless, politics and this European Parliament must not shy away from choices. Because yes, we want policies that help stabilize the economy and at the same time we want policies that make public debt sustainable. We want countries to take responsibility for austerity, reform and investment. But we also want countries not to be left to fend for themselves. How do we combine that? That is difficult, especially if one of the elements is not recognised. At the outbreak of the euro crisis, it was not possible to take responsibility for one's own responsibility. Countries and banks would have overthrown each other and so debts were not written off, at the expense of Greece and in favour of private creditors. Debts could have been written off, but they didn't. Such a situation must not occur again. We also need to ask ourselves what we can learn from the United States, where a state like California or a city like Detroit can get into financial trouble without the question of whether that state or city should be out of the dollar zone. Rules must not give the impression that debt and deficit are being restricted and controlled by Brussels. Brussels is not credible. Democracy and economic governance require clear choices.  (The speaker is prepared to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules)).

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR)
text: "blue card" question. I must certainly use a blue card here, because Mr Tang is saying something very startling here. He's pleading guilty. I totally agree with that. However, he would be delighted if he were to tell this to his finance minister, Mr Dijsselbloem, because in the negotiations with Greece there was one man who did not want to talk about debt write-off at all and that was his party colleague Mr Dijsselbloem. I therefore think this is a good speech by Mr Tang. Let him forward this to his party colleague, please.

name: Paul Tang (S&D)
text: "blue card" answer. Of course, I do not need the European Parliament to speak to Mr Dijsselbloem. But I will do it at the request of Mr van Dalen. His message has certainly arrived. There were no grounds for being against debt depreciation, but there were also political circumstances. In countries such as Germany, Spain and Portugal, governments were in power which are obviously very opposed to this, and Jeroen Dijsselbloem is chairman of the entire eurogroup. I can add, moreover, that in 2010, when you were still a member of the national parliament, you also called for depreciation. That was not to be realised then, because we were in a situation where a country would knock down banks. That is a situation that we must prevent from happening again.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we welcome the concern shown by the insufficient economic recovery and the permanence of serious levels of inequality and poverty in Europe, but we believe that greater and better sustainable green investment is urgently needed to change the productive model and combat unemployment and low wages. Europe's neoliberal model of the five presidents project aims to recentralise public resources in Brussels to ensure the business of large companies, which is quite the opposite of what needs to be done, because social needs continue to be permanently neglected. This week we have seen how the Commission is prepared to make the Stability Pact more flexible in order to reward countries that demonstrate their submission to austerity policies and their willingness to act as guardians of the borders of Europe-fortress. We are committed to another Europe, which democrats the economy and is based on the popular sovereignty of Europeans, and not on economic imposition and blackmail. (He agreed to answer a question posed in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation)).

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – In fact I would like to ask our friend Mr Urbán Crespo, who was mentioning equalities and poverty and so on and so forth, what his opinion is about the expansion of zero-hour contracts, because I believe first of all that all types of contractual arrangements should give workers access to a core set of rights and adequate social protection.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" response. – Mr President, the problem, what I am seeing — and I believe that, unfortunately, my country is a good example of this — is that what is being done right now is to fairly distribute the work down, work without rights. We are seeing how for the first time in my country there are workers who are working poors, poor workers. Before, when you had a job you had rights, you had the ability to live; now, quite the opposite. The job that is being created in my country is that where there used to be a job – where 1 200 euros were charged – there are now two jobs that charge 500 euros, and with that, of course, you can't live. Obviously, I am in favour of rights at the labour level, but it is essential to distribute the work but also to distribute the wealth and remuneration that entails that very thing.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Budget policy is always a work programme in figures. The European Semester gives the Commission the opportunity to publicly put its finger on the wounds created by the contradiction between objectives and deeds. However, the European Semester does not replace the further development of the monetary union into fiscal, economic and social union. It does not replace the creation of a European Finance Minister, it does not replace the implementation of the Presidential Paper on the future of European budget policy, economic and social union. And it does not replace the implementation of all the decisions we have taken in this House, in the Council and in the Commission. I feel like there is always a lack of seriousness.  On Sven Giegold's homepage we can read that so far only seven out of 528 country-specific recommendations have been fully implemented. Structures of the past are still being defended against the future for power and party political reasons, thereby making debts for the sake of debt, and the sell-off of the future is being pursued. There is still a lack of political will for too many to implement what has been decided.  Barriers in the internal market are still being defended. I therefore demand an implementation strategy, an enforcement strategy and a report on each Member State, which is done with the country-specific recommendations.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Every year, when it comes to the European Semester, we have a very similar, almost identical, discussion here. We Social Democrats, we Social Democrats, want the direction to be changed radically: away from a one-sided policy of cuts, towards a balanced economic and financial policy. Flexibility yes, but not one-sided ones, which is more or less always at the expense of workers. Even more so-called zero-hours contracts – as my colleague mentioned – or other precarious forms of employment do not solve the problem, they lead to rising poverty rather than work and to people turning away from Europe. It is now good that employment indicators are taken into account in the macroeconomic imbalance simline, but there are no social indicators, for example to combat poverty and social exclusion. In short, we need an immediate change of direction. Social and employment policy must be as binding as financial and economic policy.

name: Tom Vandenkendelaere (PPE).
text: I think we should first thank Mr Rosati for his excellent work again. A sensible policy is by definition a multi-track policy. I therefore welcome the Commission's strategy to use the country-specific recommendations on investment, on structural reforms, on budgetary responsibility and on improving employment policy. But making a correct analysis is not enough. Of course, you also have to get them sold and that's where things often go wrong today. But here, Too, I think, the key to success lies in a multi-track approach. On the one hand, at the appropriate time, the Commission must dare to enforce the rules and also follow macroeconomic imbalances more rigorously. On the other hand, the prior efforts to ensure much greater responsibility for these recommendations must be fully addressed. I am therefore very pleased with the Commission's recommendation to set up competitiveness boards in all euro area countries. Such independent expert bodies can also play a key role in creating social support for necessary reforms through their expertise and natural authority. I also believe that the closer involvement of national parliaments in the various phases of the process is an absolute must. Finally, I believe that the upgrading of certain social indicators, such as youth unemployment and the degree of activity, will also contribute to greater involvement in the semester process.

name: Roberto Gualtieri (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that this report positively reflects the correction of the direction of eurozone fiscal policy that is pursued by the Juncker Commission through real fiscal consolidation that is friendly to growth and therefore through measures that balance the effective reduction of deficit and debt with the better use of the flexibility provided for by the rules. We therefore naturally encourage the Commission to be consistent with this approach, which is clearly expressed in our report and also in the views they will express on the stability laws of the Member States.  Then there is a second element, which is that of improving our governance, which is absolutely necessary and which goes hand in hand and must go hand in hand with a correction of the direction of economic policy. Here the package presented contains undoubtedly important and positive measures, such as a recommendation on the overall fiscal stand of the eurozone.  At the same time, I believe that there are limits of ambition, because I believe that we must clearly recognise that there are more ambitious measures that can also be implemented in constant treaties in order to strengthen the coordination of the economic policy of the Member States and to build an embryo of fiscal capacity.  Secondly, I believe that we need to strengthen the parliamentary dimension of the European Semester. There are certainly limits, gaps, here in the Commission's package. Parliament is also ready to engage in dialogue and fight for a strengthening of its role, which is essential for building effective governance of the eurozone, because without full democratic legitimacy the euro will not have effective governance.

name: Verónica Lope Fontagné (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the passage of time has shown us that the policies implemented in the European Union have been the right ones. The deficit is relatively controlled and forecasts point to growth of more than 2%. Therefore, structural reforms must continue, maintaining budgetary responsibility but compatible with job creation, as is the case in Spain.  However, we have several challenges. The first is to reduce the high level of debt, which will have a positive effect on investments, which are so necessary for our SMEs, and the second is job creation. High unemployment rates hurt the recovery and, in this respect, I have listened with satisfaction to the interventions by Minister Schmit and Commissioner Dombrovskis, who have emphasized the social dimension of the Semester. I hope it will be a reality, because we need to focus on the most affected groups, such as women, young people and, more specifically, the long-term parades, which we will discuss next.  The importance of flexisecurity must also be emphasized, but with greater attention to safety, as workers need greater job security. In conclusion, I would like to stress that the further objective is the 2020 Strategy: its revision, as well as country-specific recommendations, will need to be better geared towards regional and local realities and their specificities. In a region like mine, Aragon, which is ten times larger than Belgium in size and with a much smaller population, it is essential to take this into account, other than if not, it will produce results other than those desired.

name: Siegfried Mureşan (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I too welcome Parliament’s report, and I would also like to talk about the European Semester in broader terms and to reflect on how we could further integrate the process of economic policy coordination, because the economies of EU Member States are so interdependent. The country-specific recommendations (CSRs) are, of course, an important tool. However, we complain that they are not respected by Member States and that Member States are not ambitious enough.  I believe we need to ask ourselves why this is happening. It is not only the content of the CSRs, but also the design of the process. The question is, how shall we design a better economic policy coordination process? We should eliminate the perception that it is a top-down process from the level of the EU. I believe we should have two stages of the European Semester. A first round of recommendations which sets out the reasons why the country-level recommendations need to be fulfilled in the second stage, and in addition we need more parliamentary control and involvement in this process. Secondly, in order to have more concrete solutions, we need a comprehensive evaluation of the European Semester and the CSRs in order to understand their relevance to Member States and to adjust the process. Member States also need incentives for action. The question is, how can we make Member States own the process more? I think a more in-depth evaluation that looks at improving the behaviour of the Member States and the process is much needed.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE).
text: – I supported the idea of the Semester from the outset because we need European instruments that will contribute to the greater efficiency of the European Union and, in particular, its economy. We know that a union cannot, as such, operate permanently in the case of economic, monetary and fiscal harmonisation between its members. I am concerned about the lack of implementation of the recommendations. The framework makes no sense if it is not followed by a responsible and consistent compliance with the recommendations. I am pleased that the Commission has focused on the economic aspect and set priorities for economic growth, such as increasing investment, implementing structural reforms, fiscal responsibility and improving business policies. In the context of this debate, I would like to draw attention once again to the opportunity offered by the framework of the European Semester for other issues on which the efficiency of the economy also depends. I have long suggested that a health semester should also be established within the existing semester to create positive levers for governments to reform health systems that are necessary for more health in our societies. The sustainability of health systems is in great question. If we do not address this issue urgently, with the added value that the European Union can offer, the effects on public finances will be very quickly ahead of us.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent work. Sometimes it is important to remind yourself of what you know so that you can find a solution to the problems. What is known? The European Union is not a country. We do not have a central government or a serious budget that will help us overcome any crisis. Instead, we are 28 independent states that cooperate with each other, and we have 28 different national budgets.  But it is also a fact that we are all connected to each other. This means that if there is a crisis in one Member State, it inevitably affects others, perhaps even all the Member States of the European Union. It is therefore important for us to agree on those things that make our cooperation stronger and more resilient to any future crises.  Firstly, it is important for us to continue the so-called European Semester, in which we coordinate the procedure for adopting national budgets. But that is not enough! We must go further, both by strengthening our banking union and by strengthening our economic supervision. I therefore support the Commission's initiative to strengthen our economic union. We do not need to become a country, but we must be aware that we are closely connected to each other. Only in this way can we avoid future crises. Thank you!

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, I welcome The Vice-President of the European Commission, Mr. Dombrovskis, and I would like to congratulate him on his efforts to accelerate the European Semester procedure and also on the changes he has made to the exchange of best practices and knowledge between Member States with a view to accelerating the implementation of reforms across Europe. I congratulate my colleague Rosati on his excellent report and important messages for all Member States, but also for all of us.  We have a shared responsibility to create an innovative Europe that is growing at significantly higher rates than previous ones, retaining and attracting talent, leading the way in innovation, technology and creativity. The European Semester, i.e. the European Commission, cannot do the job on the ground, i.e. in the Member States. The European Semester is a strategic mechanism for linking economic policies and encouraging Member States to change, and for us, i.e. it is up to the Member States to implement the changes and be successful together.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to welcome Mr Rosati’s own—initiative report. Taking into account the latest budgetary measures adopted, it has been necessary to introduce them in the objectives of the Annual Growth Survey. Although the economic recovery is slowly gaining ground and we face tremendous challenges – and I refer here to migration – the fundamentals of the recovery are delicate due to European Union structural weaknesses and regional economic discrepancies. Therefore, I am glad that the report includes several elements of a new economic policy direction that strengthens the synergy of Member States’ national policies – more investment and less austerity, recognition of the real consequence of front—loaded austerity measures, and surplus countries to make more effort in pushing demand. I also consider the removal of further fiscal consolidation, and of criticism of rigid labour laws and trade unions, to be an improvement in the report.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, coordinating 28 economic and social policies is certainly not a grateful job and is not an easy job. However, there is no objective alternative. That is why I see the European Semester as a real mechanism that, if anything, allows us to see what the differences are between us and how we can achieve better development.  What I want to emphasize on this occasion is certainly the necessity that you mentioned Mr. Commissioner, which is access to the financial resources of medium and small enterprises. We can't build the whole economy on small and medium-sized enterprises, of course we need big business as well. However, I would like to emphasize the vitality, importance and flexibility of medium and small enterprises. That is why I invite you to focus our efforts on financing medium and small businesses precisely in this desire to kick-start the European economy, especially in those countries that still cannot find a way out of the crisis.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: Mr President, Vice-President Dombrovskis, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his work. In its spring 2015 economic forecast, the Commission expects growth of 2.1 percent for the European Union and 1.9 percent for the eurozone. Economic growth is a key driver of the four key priorities of the 2015 Country-Specific Recommendations. These are the promotion of investment, the implementation of structural reforms, the creation of employment, and responsible fiscal policies – in other words, growth-oriented fiscal consolidation.  However, the Member States hardly adhere to it. We have already heard today that almost 11 per cent of country-specific recommendations are being implemented, although the data on which the country-specific recommendations are based comes from the Member States, namely through the Council, in the Annual Growth Survey. That is why it makes sense for the rapporteur to now focus on the report and say that there must be a greater focus on the core priorities and that the country-specific recommendations must be published earlier.  Together with the push to involve the national parliaments more closely, because they will then also have to implement them, it will perhaps be possible to achieve better implementation at national level.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I was here in the last mandate when we were making efforts to grapple with the unprecedented recession which we have had, particularly in my own country. Month after month, Commissioner Barnier in particular has been putting forward proposals. Many criticised him, but I think now they are seen to be pretty effective and sensible, and now we are concluding with the banking union, etc. But the European Semester is a very important aspect of it, because it means that there will be outside guidance rather than supervision of the broad targets in budgets. With elections coming up, there is always a tendency for parties – be they in government or out of government – to try to buy the electorate, and this is not good in the long-term. Aspects like this Semester are good in the overall term, and also the exchange of best practices, something that has been mentioned, is obviously good for the Member States and creates a sense of the Union as well.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the European Semester is essential for the European Union to become a smart, sustainable and inclusive economy. Having set very clear targets to be achieved by 2020 for employment, productivity and social cohesion, we can welcome the signs of growth in the Union and the reduction in the unemployment and youth unemployment rate. However, we must not forget that these rates are still alarming in many Member States and many regions, such as unemployment in my region, the Azores, where it is above 30%. I agree that the European Semester should focus on what is its action: the coordination of the European Union's economic policies. But we cannot allow these guidelines not to promote the balance between a market economy and the social economy, but should primarily target the empowerment of young Europeans to meet the demands of the labour market, the number of people at risk of poverty and social exclusion, the difficulty of businesses in accessing finance and removing barriers to their activity.  Commissioner, Minister, this is a Europe of regions and, as such, we must not ignore the need for more investment to improve their growth potential and ensure their sustainability, and this cannot be forgotten in the European Semester.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank Members for this fruitful debate. Parliament has an important role to play in the debating of European economic policies and the future of EMU, so I have carefully taken note of Members’ remarks and the points raised today. While different views and opinions were expressed during the debate, I note that there is also certain support for a new Commission approach to the revamped European Semester, and there are certain elements which still need to be fine—tuned to find the right way forward. On some of the issues which have been raised during this debate: firstly, environmental measures or environmental policy-related measures in the European Semester bring us to the next debate on the Europe 2020 Strategy. But I would emphasise that we are streamlining the European Semester, we are trying to focus on key social economic challenges in the Member States and we are applying the ʻtell only onceʼ principle, so we are not doubling some of the advice that we are giving to the Member States in the context of other EU policies. The low CSR implementation is a cause of concern. It is something we need to address, but we believe the best way to address this is through improved membership in the Member States so that Member States, stakeholders, national parliaments, governments and social partners are better involved in decision-making and are better informed about the economic challenges both at the euro area level and the EU level, and how it goes in a national context. Then on some of the questions of surplus versus deficit countries which were raised here, I must note that excessive current account surpluses are indeed also considered as a macroeconomic imbalance by the European Commission, as outlined in our macroeconomic imbalance procedures. That is why countries like Germany, for example, are also in macroeconomic imbalance due to a large and sustained current account surplus. We recommend strengthening investment and strengthening and stimulating the demand side of the economy. Indeed the demand side of the economy is part of our economic strategy, so what we need to focus on is how to strengthen the economic recovery in Europe, and of course the demand side is one of the answers. Some questions were raised on the ambition of this current Commission proposal and reference was made to some specific instruments, for example fiscal capacity. It must be noted that some of those elements were, for example, in the Five Presidents’ Report where there is a reference to euro area stabilisation. This extends a similar concept since this used to be referred to in some earlier documents as fiscal capacity, and this is foreseen for Stage 2 of the Five Presidents’ Report. I have been outlining also the Commissionʼs preparation of that Stage 2 of the Five Presidents’ Report so this is going to be part of that work. Indeed the Commission is open to looking at ways of how to ensure stronger involvement of the European Parliament in the European Semester and macroeconomic policy decision-making, and indeed I sense also from today’s debate that there is some further work and consideration needed.

name: n/a
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank you first of all for this exchange, which has been sometimes critical, but overall always constructive.  As your draft resolution indicates, we share the same priorities and, above all, and I think it is crucial, we share the same will for action, because indeed the economic results and especially the employment situation are not satisfactory. The European Semester must be placed in a broader perspective, that of work to complete the Economic and Monetary Union. It is an essential tool in strengthened governance. The Luxembourg Presidency has also discussed the proposals of the five presidents in several ministerial meetings this autumn and we have just reported to the European Council in October.  The Commission made proposals a few days ago, which will also be on the agenda of either Council. I can already tell you that at the EPSCO Council on 7 December, we will discuss, among other things, the social aspect contained in the Commission's proposals. Because this social dimension needs to be deepened, it must enable the establishment of an inclusive space with high social and employment performance for all citizens. This is a high priority for this Commission, which, I have noted, finds a great deal of support in Parliament. It requires concrete measures to promote upward convergence and here I would say that the best indicators, the best benchmarks will not suffice alone. We do need policies, we need reforms, and we also need resources, resources, investments in human capital, of course, and in innovation, research and education. This is the future of the European economy. I also agree - I think the person who mentioned it is no longer there - that investments in the green economy in relation to climate change, also in relation to the promotion of renewable energy and energy transition can not only create jobs - the so-called green jobs - but also redirect growth in Europe. The Council will have to continue discussions on deepening EMU and we will have to be more ambitious, closer to realities and real problems. I agree with what has also been said by one or the other, namely that the euro area is not simply the addition of the Member States. The eurozone needs to act more globally - that is what we call, what one or the other has called the eurozone tax stances. In any case, I thank you once again for this evening's debate, which shows that we need a broad democratic exchange both in the European Parliament and in the national parliaments. Moreover, this need for democratic exchange is also highlighted and underlined in the Commission's recent proposals.

name: Dariusz Rosati
text: rapporteur. – Thank you Mr President, Minister Schmit, Commissioner Dombrovskis, dear colleagues. I would like first of all to thank all the participants who took part in this debate and all the colleagues who have expressed their views. We have not agreed on everything, of course – that would have been impossible in this House – but at least I have seen involvement and indeed a genuine willingness to discuss important matters. This debate has also shown that the issue is politically very sensitive and, indeed, this has been reflected in the process of our work on this report because we have been confronted with different expectations, different opinions, on such elementary things like: What is the actual economic situation of the Union? What measures need to be taken in order to put the EU economies on a sustainable growth path? What are the reasons for the current slowdown? And so on and so forth. So we have been unable to agree on everything but, as I said, I tried very much to come up with a compromise – of course at the cost of some clarity and perhaps insufficient focus on all important matters, but still I thought that having a broad majority in favour of this report would be important. I would like to express my thanks to all the shadow rapporteurs who have participated in this difficult negotiation process. As I said, we have not agreed on everything, but at least they have shown consistently their willingness to cooperate, willingness to discuss, and I would like to express my appreciation. Now one problem with this kind of report comes with the application of Rule 54 which obliges the rapporteur to include the opinions presented by other parliamentary committees. Sometimes those opinions are longer than the report itself, so of course this always comes at the cost of conciseness. Some of the voices we have heard are saying that the report possibly lacks sufficient focus. If so, it is probably due to this. I am flagging up this issue to our distinguished colleagues because I think that we should probably have a look into this part of our Rules of Procedure. I would like to ask all Members to support the report in tomorrow’s vote.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 29 October 2015.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the debate on: – the oral question to the Council by Thomas Händl, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on the Council recommendation on the integration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market (O-000121/2015 - B8-1102/2015 - (2015/2820(RSP))).

name: Thomas Händel
text: Author. Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Today's question from the Committee on Employment deals with the Council's last recommendation on the integration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market – indeed the most difficult group. As a result of the economic crisis, the number of long-term unemployed has doubled since 2007. They make up half of all the unemployed: more than 12 million people, 5% of the unemployed in Europe, not yet registered. The shortcomings of data collection and sometimes creative data design play a role here. Official statistics underestimate the situation of long-term unemployment. More than 60% of the long-term unemployed are unemployed for at least two years in a row, and we have long-term unemployment rates in the Member States with marked differences. The rates are highest in countries that have had austerity policies, in the programme countries that have been overrun by austerity – I will mention this personally. The consequences are well known: long-term unemployment often leads to inequality, poverty and social exclusion, and it affects particularly disadvantaged groups. The downward spiral, the erosion of abilities, discouragement and alienation, increased psychological and physical problems, social exclusion and withdrawal from society are palpable throughout societies. This is becoming increasingly common: unemployment and poverty are increasingly being inherited into the next generation. We note that enormous social and economic consequences, the waste of skills, higher social expenditure, the loss of social cohesion and growing old-age poverty also have to do with the consolidation of long-term unemployment. The questions addressed to the Council are relatively clear: how does the Council intend to deal effectively with the multiple barriers for many long-term unemployed? How does the Council intend to create conditions for permanent jobs for the long-term unemployed, especially in regions with high structural unemployment? Are employment-enhancing tax measures recommended? How do you intend to make better use of skills and employment opportunities to enable the reintegration of the long-term unemployed? How should Member States create quality jobs for the long-term unemployed and prevent them from ending up in precarious employment? The Member States are certainly very different in terms of their social, economic and budgetary conditions. At the same time, the long-term unemployed form a very heterogeneous group, that is clear. What is the Council's assessment of this for successful implementation in the Member States? How should the identification and exchange of best practices be ensured in order to combat this situation? How does the Council intend to improve the situation of those who have been unemployed for more than 18 months or those who are not registered, if we want to focus only on those who are unemployed for 12 to 18 months? What specific measures does the Council intend to take to involve all relevant actors, including NGOs and employment services, be they private or public, in the process of integration? These are questions that are addressed to this recommendation. True, EU labour markets are showing some signs of improvement, and yet the unemployment rate among the long-term unemployed remains high. We see the highest growth in precarious employment. However, this also means an additional burden on public budgets, taxpayers and social security funds. Continued high long-term unemployment not only threatens the Europe 2020 headline targets, from which we are further away than ever: to reach 75% of 20-64 year olds in employment and to have at least 20 million fewer people in poverty and social exclusion at the end of the period. It also jeopardises people's confidence in a more social Europe, it leads to a loss of confidence that hurts us, which casts doubt on the further development of this European Union in the spirit of the people, in the sense of a better life, and that does Europe no good.

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, finally, your question is an illustration of the debate we have just had. I believe that you have put your finger on a very concrete, very specific issue, which affects - and you have recalled the figures - millions of Europeans who are waiting for something concrete from the European Semester. The European Semester is not an exercise in style, a theoretical exercise. But, in the end, if the European Semester has any real political significance, it must reach those who, in fact, have been unemployed for a long time and suffer from all the evils you have described. Indeed, the 12 million that we quote are statistics. But, as we often say, behind these statistics, there are people, there are families, there are broken lives, there are despairs, and I think that is what we will actually have to deal with. Long-term unemployment is already a kind of failure, because how is it acceptable for someone not to find a job for a year, two years? And when you cross the two-year mark, it becomes a sometimes impossible affair, a matter of real despair. And what does this long-term unemployment produce? It is a kind of vicious circle that, in a way, adds unemployment to unemployment. And the longer the duration of unemployment, the less favourable the prospects of finding a job become. And among these long-term unemployed, there are often women, often seniors and slightly older people who have lost their jobs and whose qualifications are no longer adapted to the labour market. Unfortunately, there are also young people and, it must be said, sometimes the youth guarantee is not enough to reintegrate these people. And if we are actually talking about a crisis, if the economic crisis has ended, if the debt crisis is under control, if the financial crisis is behind us, with billions and billions, and indeed the real losers, the real victims of the crisis, it is these unemployed, those who have no prospects. Indeed, these workers facing long-term unemployment are gradually losing, and I think that is really the hardest problem, their skills and, subsequently, their employability. In the event of an economic recovery, which we are seeing today, they will be the last to be hired. And they even run the risk of not being hired at all. And in these circumstances, it is very likely that they will leave the labour market, that they will no longer be registered, as you said, and that they will join the ranks of the inactive, with all the spiral of poverty that this entails, and which directly affects them, but which often - I do not need to repeat, as you said - also concerns their families. , their children, in some way replicating the same pattern of exclusion.  The long-term unemployed must therefore be treated as a priority category. And the policy to be implemented must include reforms in both social and employment policies, but also broader strategic action in the economic and fiscal sphere. A real economic recovery and demand-driven measures are essential to reduce long-term unemployment, because, you know, the best recipe against unemployment in general and especially against long-term unemployment is job creation and, ultimately, what creates jobs is growth, with business creation, the creation of business. And so we need a more sustainable, stronger recovery, since we are increasingly facing this type of structural unemployment, and this, of course, in the countries that have been affected the most by the crisis, but even in countries where, in the end, the level of unemployment remains relatively low.  But growth alone is not going to solve this problem, we need a major investment in human capital. This is the most decisive action to enable these people to re-acquire skills or restore their skills, which they need to re-enter the labour market. It is also important to focus on a preventive approach. Because you become a long-term unemployed because you have lost your job very often or because you have not been able to find a job, but often because you have lost your job. I think that here, when we discuss flexicurity, well we forget a little about the "security" aspect. And when we talk about the long-term unemployed, it is because finally this security component did not work. Because it should have allowed those people who had lost their jobs, in the end, to rehabilitate themselves, to be trained in order to be able to reintegrate more quickly the job market.  Therefore, training, re-qualification, continuing education for those who have a job are key policies to avoid, effectively, long-term unemployment.  And long-term unemployment, we're talking about 18 months, we say we should start acting when someone has been unemployed for 18 months. And perhaps it is also the reproach that I make a little to this document that was presented by the Commission: well no, we must not wait 18 months when someone is unemployed, we must take action as quickly as possible, we must act quickly, as soon as possible, because, indeed, if we wait 18 months already , we've wasted a lot of time, way too much time.  It is in this context that work is taking place on the Council's proposed recommendation on the long-term unemployed. The Luxembourg Presidency wants the Council to reach a political agreement at the EPSCO Council session in December. A policy debate on this proposal has already taken place at the EPSCO Council session in October.  As you pointed out, we do need to modernize, adapt and strengthen our public employment services, which often resign in the face of the long-term unemployed because they feel that there is not much left to do, so these people are a little left behind. And it is important to develop an approach, perhaps not exactly the same, but comparable to what has been implemented with the youth guarantee. So we don't just have to rely on more fluid labour markets to reintegrate these job seekers. We need to build real bridges to employment. The creation of specific jobs that would facilitate their reintegration should be promoted, including public sector jobs. Investing more in employment than inactivity, because inactivity rhymes with exclusion, with distress, with precariousness, with poverty.  Let us also think of families, children, as you said. I am also thinking of the social and solidarity economy, which has a specific role to play in reintegrating the long-term unemployed, because it obeys other rules and can act at that level. And I am referring to the social innovation projects of the Commission's EaSI programme to make better use of the means to reintegrate the long-term unemployed.  So I think there are different approaches: job creation, investment in training, investment in re-qualification, social support - it's also important because often the long-term unemployed have no income or very low incomes, have housing problems, and then the vicious circle is going to take an extremely dangerous turn.

name: David Casa
text: f'isem group PPE. – Aħna konxji mill-fatt li dawk li ilhom mingħajr impjieg għal żmien twil jiffa大大jaw ħafna ostakoli. Issa smajt lil Ministru jitkellem hawn, kważi kważi għandi aptit inpoġġi bil-qiegħda għax, dak kollu li qal il-Ministru, naqblu miegħu, però l-verità meta ser nibdew naraw dawn in-numri niżlin. Jitilfu l-fidu大ja fihom infushom illi jistgħu jidħlu fid-dinja tax-xogħol. U din hija naħseb l-ikbar problema illi qed jiffa大大jaw dawn in-nies illi mgħandhomx xogħol fl-Unjoni Ewropea, u allura, iva nħeġġeġ għal aktar koordinazzjoni, inħeġġe għal aktar aktariikejj anka minn naħa tagna, anka minn naħa tal-Kummissjoni, anka minn naħa tal-Kunsill, għaliex saru wisq studju, qed isiru wisq studju, analiżi, però issa ejja ngħaddu għa fatti, għaliex dawn in-nies sakeħamna qed nistudjaw , sakemm aħna qed nanalizzaw għadhom bla xogħol u qed ibatu huma u l-familji tagħhom, allura nistenna din id-darba azzjoni u mhux studji u paroliktar i.

name: Javi López
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, there are twelve million Europeans who live and have lived for the last few years in frustration, in hopelessness, and today they live in despair, absolute despair. That's what long-term unemployment means. Twelve million, more than double what we had before the 2007 economic crisis. They have not stopped growing and, in some countries – as in mine, in Spain – we have more than three million people unemployed for long duration.
