And the effects are huge, negative, very very negative; economic effects, because we deteriorate a lot of human capital; social effects, because we push, drag, millions of people into poverty, marginality or social exclusion; effects on health, public health, with enormous deterioration also in the psychosocial sphere, and a huge difficulty in returning to the labour market, very difficult, and with consequences for life once entering the labour market. That is why the European Commission has put forward a recommendation, a work plan, a framework that is positive. That is why the Council also addressed us today with the words of the Minister, whom I welcome, which I share, but everything we do will not be enough as long as we have this problem in front of us. That is why, from the Socialist Group, what we are asking for is, first of all, that there be more resources, as we have had for some sectors, such as for youth, for youth unemployment; secondly, that we devote more efforts to detection, registration: there are many people who have given up, it is invisible; third, that we personalize our performance: it is not the same a long-term stop of more than 45 years as of less than 25 years; and that we combine active employment policies with social policies, because training of the person is as important as the social environment, and never at the price of having a precarious job.

name: Jana Žitňanská
text: for the ECR Group – Several Member States, among them, unfortunately Slovakia, have a serious problem. We are at the forefront of europe in the number of long-term unemployed people of active age. The bad news is that we will not eliminate this problem with the Council's guidance. In particular, we will eliminate it by better education or creating the conditions for entrepreneurship and removing barriers for the people who create jobs. However, council guidance can alleviate the problem and that is exactly how it needs to be understood. As an effort to improve the quality of support services for people out of work. Let us also remember that when working with the unemployed, those who work directly with communities on the ground and have their trust often achieve the best results. I will therefore support the involvement of such active mayors or motivated NGOs in the inclusion of the unemployed, as well as calling on the Member States to strengthen the quality and capacity of human resources that help the long-term unemployed to integrate into working life.

name: Yana Toom
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the fight against long-term unemployment is a great challenge to all Member States as this phenomenon is harmful to economic and social development. The ALDE Group supports the initiative by the Commission on the integration of long-term unemployed people into the labour market and the three main elements of the proposal. Fighting unemployment requires more efficiency, consistency and cooperation regarding the integration of the long-term unemployed. An individual approach, assessing people’s abilities and needs, is also crucial, and a written job integration agreement can be beneficial. However, on the basis of some negative experiences of the European Youth Guarantee, we call on the Member States to consider regional differences. In some regions the fight against unemployment is limited by the narrowness of the local labour market. This problem may be addressed by creating a favourable business environment, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises. Unfortunately, labour taxation systems in some Member States do little to promote the creation of new jobs. Another important aspect of the fight against long-term unemployment is labour-force mobility at three levels – regional, national and EU. There should be no obstacles to freedom of movement in the European Union, and the Commission should react swiftly where it sees such obstacles. For instance, in the Baltic region, workers’ freedom of movement is compromised by disproportionate professional linguistic requirements. The fight against long-term unemployment is heavily dependent on the ability of both the Commission and Member States to cooperate in an efficient way. There should be no artificial obstacles for job seekers on national labour markets. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: blue card issue. – Thank you, Mrs Toom, for your question to my blue card. You talked about language requirements for the unemployed. Perhaps you could tell more about what requirements are being implemented within 30 seconds – which I understood – in your home country of Estonia? Thank you!

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – I will just give you one short example: taxi drivers in the city of Narva, where we have 87% Russian speakers, have to speak Estonian on B1 level. At the same time, they do not have Estonian-speaking people using these taxis and they are not able to do this exam. It means that they are unemployed or, in the worst cases, unemployed in the long term.

name: Paloma López Bermejo
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank you for the collective work that has been done on this subject and which has enabled us to profile the axes of a strategy to try to end long-term unemployment. Two points are important to us. The first, structural in nature and directly addressed to the Council, is to point out that countries with the highest long-term unemployment rate are most affected by austerity policies and competition generated between Member States, which has contributed to a virulent deterioration in employment and living conditions since the onset of the crisis. Mr Schmit, we share the diagnosis, but with the policies implemented, long-term unemployment has continued to grow. So what we want is to reverse neoliberal policies; other hand, we will not be able to find a solution to this serious problem. Be brave, stand up to the financial system, it's okay. And start talking about labor time sharing, public sector expansion, reinforcement and social protection resources. The second axis is the implementation of active policies that are really effective, and I believe that in this I share a lot with my colleagues in this Parliament. Errors that have already occurred in the implementation of the Youth Guarantee should not be repeated. Public resources must be secured, european funds are available, especially in those countries suffering from cuts, and these funds must be used effectively, requiring the participation of the social partners... (The Chairperson interrupts the speaker)

name: Karima Delli
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, tackling youth unemployment, too, tackling long-term unemployment in Europe is a huge challenge, but to do so is better to have the means to do so and this is not the case. I heard Mr Juncker, I heard Mr Hollande, in front of the European trade unions, they all say 'social Europe', but they only have that word in their mouths and behind them, there is nothing! So I tell them: chick, it's now! That's the first thing. So I do not understand why today we are content with a debate, a recommendation from the Council, which does not oblige the Member States to follow its content. We have seen the limits of this method with the youth guarantee. When you leave the field open to the states, they do nothing or so little. Yes, you are right, we need a European initiative.  You talk about concrete, let's go in the concrete! We talked about the Juncker plan, we talked about investment plans, today no news! We are talking about China, which could perhaps invest in the Juncker plan. Is it serious? You are really talking about the real issues, Minister. But we will not be able to deal with this issue of unemployment if we do not deal with social dumping, tax dumping, because behind tax dumping, we have the money to create the jobs of the future.  And I end, because that's where it's most important: job creation. We are one month away from the last chance summit to save the climate, COP 21. It is up to us to reconcile the economy and the climate, the economy and ecology, to put the package on renewable energies, the social and solidarity economy. Let us build together an industrial European policy with new tools, because this is where there will be local jobs that will not be relocated for citizens.

name: Laura Agea
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Dombrovskis, Mr Schmit, we woke up late, I hope you are aware of this – I do not know if you want to listen to me. We are collapsing, because we have waited to see a figure such as 12 million European citizens who are reduced to exhaustion and starvation, and we will replicate a model such as the guarantee for young people, which you know was a total failure because the states that implemented it have failed. They missed the organization.  Can you explain to me and explain to me how we want to retrain the long-term unemployed, who may be 45-50 years old and a family, with a training course paid EUR 4 per hour? Is that what you want to do? Because I ask myself: is it guaranteeing dignity? You talked about families. Well, a family with 4 euros per hour of training does not feed us children.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D).
text: – Normally, the first thing you ask when you meet someone new is, "Who are you and what kind of work do you do?". Work provides people with an income but also provides them with an identity and leads to satisfaction and development. So people lose a lot when they lose their jobs. I am therefore very pleased with the Commission's initiative to tackle long-term unemployment and the stated ambition to help everyone get to work. I am also pleased with the Council's support. I welcome the agreement on labour integration, but I do wonder how we are going to implement it. How do we provide good quality jobs that people can also live on? It seems clear to me that the Commission must ensure sufficient funding and that it should be made available to the Member States quickly and easily, just as is happening now with the Youth Initiative. My main concern is that while the economy is creeping out of the valley again, the number of jobs is lagging behind. At the same time, we are seeing companies hoarding money and also trying to keep tax payments in their pockets. I also believe that companies should take responsibility for creating jobs. Hence my question: what measures will the Commission and the Council take to encourage both the Member States and industry to create more jobs. I am pleased that the Minister is saying that the government should invest, but I also expect an investment from ordinary business.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Realistically, it must be acknowledged that among those affected by long-term unemployment there is a group for which it is difficult, if not impossible, to be motivated to work, that they do not want to improve their situation in life and, in fact, little can be done for them. Others, however, can be helped by reaching for better methods. This requires deliberate effort and individualised application of sociological and psychological knowledge. General training, such as computer operation and assertiveness, is so often not available. People should be trained in specialised fields and such training should be much more individualised, I would say, intelligent. The way in which the efficiency of labour offices and other training centres for the unemployed should be assessed should be substantially changed. The measure should be the actual results in the activation of the unemployed.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, long-term unemployed workers are an easy target for policies that want to make labour cheaper and more exploited. If a worker is more than twelve or eighteen months without being employed, he should already be very happy with any crumb. This is the thinking of governments, such as the previous right-wing government of my country, which created an internship program for the long-term unemployed, directly contributing to the replacement of employment with precarious employment rights, to the direct reduction of wages and, moreover, subsidizing this reduction in wages with Social Security money. Now, this is the example that should not be followed.  It is urgent to boost sectors of the economy, such as industry, that create jobs, but it is also necessary to fulfill the principle that a permanent job corresponds to an effective employment link and that all these precarious work models are converted into effective contracts when they correspond to permanent needs. It seems simple and obvious. Then why don't you do it? (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. "I don't want to teas you a bit, so I can feel your commitment, but just to give you an example: can you imagine that in Hungary, in my country, the Hungarian Government is conducting public works programmes with an hourly rate of less than EUR 1? Can you imagine that?

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: response according to the "blue card" procedure. – Mr Szanyi, it is precisely that type of work that i was talking about, that is, work that corresponds to permanent needs, particularly in the public administration, and which is paid differently from other workers, and long-term workers are a preferred target for this type of exploitation.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, the British Government defines long-term unemployment as someone who is out of work for 12 months or more. However, I am sure that many families and individuals view this definition as far too lengthy. Over the last six years, long-term unemployment in Europe has swelled. Around half of Europe’s 25 million unemployed have been jobless for over a year. Over 12% have not worked for more than four years. The EU writes legislation which pushes up the price of energy and sets renewable targets which do not provide a secure future for any sort of industry, let alone heavy industry. The British taxpayer will end up picking up the bill for the extra people who find themselves unemployed again. The north of England suffered under the Conservatives during the 1980s and 1990s, and is doing so again. The ‘northern powerhouse’ promised by David Cameron is a total myth, and it is a Brussels powerhouse that we should worry about and have to deal with.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D).
text: – Madam President, there are 50 000 long-term unemployed people in my constituency of the West Midlands, and 50% of long-term unemployed people in the UK are from black, Asian and minority ethnic backgrounds. I thought, well 50% – that is a lot. When I sat down to read the papers for this debate I thought I would turn to the section on the 50% – the black, Asian and minority ethnic long-term unemployed – and see what the Council and the Commission and Parliament have to say about them. I thought I would make a cup of tea as it was going to be a long section, since this is very important. But no. No section! Actually no sentence; not a word about the black, Asian and minority ethnic people that make up 50% of the long-term unemployed people in the United Kingdom. I thought, well that is odd, as there are all the black, Asian and minority ethnic people who work for the Commission and the Council – except, oh no, there are none! These are white institutions that do not care about black unemployment!

name: Elena Gentile (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in the interweaving of the many events of deprivation of the right to work, that of the long-term unemployed tells dramatic stories of new poverty. Twelve million workers out of work, an army of new poor people, a great human capital that risks loseing of skills and skills of work.  It is up to us, it is up to Europe, to build the conditions whereby the most sore segment of the unemployed can usefully be relocated to the business system. We need to promote a modern vision of active labour policies by reviewing the infrastructure structure of the competences of the public and private system of worker relocation, which is still inadequate today.  Development and growth plans must be combined with active labour policies, in line with new training needs. In short, we need intelligent policies that dialogue and build a modern outpost for growth, starting precisely from human capital. We are therefore on the eve of major choices affecting Europe. Within a non-dreamlike vision of development, starting with the suggestions also offered by the new economies, a change of course is required which the Council recommendation certainly encourages.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D).
text: " We will certainly not be able to overcome long-term unemployment if we are not able to offer quality jobs to the unemployed. It is therefore essential, first and foremost, to promote investment in quality jobs in every way. Secondly, it is indeed very important to provide some incentives to employers so that they take people who have not worked for a long time into those quality jobs. We will not overcome long-term unemployment if we do not work patiently and consistently with every unemployed person individually, because these people have lost any motivation to work, who have lost their professional skills, and therefore need to invest extremely heavily in them. Finally, we need to register these people so that we really know how many of them there are so that we can work with them. And it is necessary to encourage the same unemployed to work, not to live out of social benefits. So a lot of questions. Answers are in your hands and works.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Madam President, Minister, Commissioner. I come to Austria, a country that is often cited as a positive example when it comes to the long-term unemployment rate. Of course, the 1.5 per cent long-term unemployed are too much for us, but in relation to Greece, where we are talking about 19.5 per cent, it is much better. Long-term unemployment therefore has a great deal to do with the crisis. Those countries that are in crisis have the highest long-term unemployment rate. But of course not everything in Austria is so rosy. Overall, we also have the highest unemployment rate since the Second World War. However, I would like to draw attention to an element which is particularly positive and which is also very good for a percentage of the long-term unemployed, and which, accordingly, should be taken up much more strongly at European level, but which should also be lived in the papers – and that is social partnership.  We have comprehensive collective agreements, and if employers and employees really sit at the table and negotiate seriously, then they can also better resolve the issue of long-term unemployment. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Andreas Schwab (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Madam President, Mrs Regner, I would like to thank Mrs Regner for her work on this report. I have listened very carefully to what you have said, which have been very much related to Austria. As a Social Democrat, you are certainly also familiar with the Danish example. Perhaps you can also mention things that you are more pleased about in the Danish example – where a Social Democrat Prime Minister is currently in power.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr Schwab, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for his excellent work. I would like to say this to you: I do not want to interfere in Danish domestic policy. I only know which elements are certainly good at European level, and that clearly includes social partnership.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to use my minute to express a clear and simple concept. The European Commission's proposal on long-term unemployment contains some positive elements, but it can only produce results if it becomes a complement to the existing instruments to deal with the employment crisis in Europe, above all the Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative.  It is therefore urgent to launch this initiative, building on the experience of the Guarantee for Young People on the ground, avoiding the slowness and errors that have also been highlighted in the resolution on which we will vote tomorrow, just as it is urgent to strengthen the instruments, including financial ones, to support the fight against long-term youth unemployment.  Let us look at the mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework, included in the Commission's work programme presented yesterday, as the opportunity to be accepted in order to shape an overall strategy to combat unemployment, which will repair the social fabric in European countries and between European countries without worsening the intergenerational dimension of the economic crisis. The figures are still very worrying, let us not forget that.  (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Laura Agea (EFDD)
text: "blue card" question. Mr Benifei, briefly and without controversy: how can measures be implemented to support the long-term unemployed when – as you well know – in a country like ours there is a lack of forms of social protection that make it possible to retrain and relocate the long-term unemployed? How can we support them before we reintegrate them into the world of work? What do you think are the forms and tools to support these people?

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: answer to a "blue card" question. I believe, in particular, that two aspects need to be emphasised. Compared to Italy, in particular, which was at the center of the demand, there is to continue a work already begun in recent months with the latest decree implementing a reform of our country, the so-called Jobs Act, which concerns the reform of employment centers and employment services. The functionality of these structures is fundamental and is also at the heart of many European recommendations. In addition, European welfare instruments are needed: I am thinking, for example, of unemployment benefit for the euro area.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Mr Schmit on behalf of the Council spoke in very robust and impassioned terms about the long-term unemployed. Much of what he said makes sense: the difficulties with qualifications, skills, older people getting a job and the need for lifelong learning. But I think his portrayal was somewhat one-dimensional: as well as those who want to work there are also those amongst the long-term unemployed who do not want work and others who cannot work. Regarding  those who do not want to work – my own Prime Minister Enda Kenny referred to that subject at the EPP meeting in Madrid last week and he said that we have to make work pay because in too many instances people can actually earn more by not working than by working, and that makes no sense. Of course, for those who cannot work, often because of disability or circumstances, we have to look at innovative ways, maybe part-time work etc., to give them the opportunity to get self-worth and self-esteem. I do not think that we should  forget those people either among the long-term unemployed.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the It is touching how long-term unemployment is being discussed here. But you have to look at the countries where the biggest unemployment is ever. This is in Greece, in Spain, in Portugal – in countries that have far too strong a currency. The eurozone, or the European Commission, is trying to force this so-called internal devaluation. You can see that it doesn't work. The result is that entire economies are being destroyed because they simply have a currency that is far too strong. Tens of billions, hundreds of billions of euros are being spent to keep this far too strong currency, the euro, in these economies. But it's like a straitjacket. Countries will have this high unemployment and long-term unemployment as long as they have this strong currency.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Thank you. In short, I accept only one speaker per group for the catch-the-eye procedure, and those who have not spoken before in the catch-the-eye procedure. (End of catch-the-eye process)

name: n/a
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, I would like first of all to thank the author of the question, but also Parliament for this extremely stimulating debate. Indeed, this issue of long-term unemployment is an issue that will have to be integrated, and which is also integrated into the procedures and actions of the European Semester.  Countries with high levels of unemployment, especially long-term levels, must indeed be encouraged to implement appropriate solutions, actions and policies. It is true that there are people who do not want, who cannot work, these are categories that exist; it may also be necessary to see, if work does not pay, to adapt this imbalance between benefits on the one hand and wages on the other, because it is true that the problem exists.  Nor should we expect everything from the Council, because in fact the real employment policies are first and foremost at the level of each Member State. Of course, national policies will have to be better matched, on the one hand, and the actions of the European Union on the other. I believe that this is also the meaning of this recommendation proposed by the Commission. This recommendation is to put this issue on the agenda that concerns us all. But policies also require resources, and it is especially countries that do not have resources, that are experiencing budgetary difficulties, that need help in this area. And I believe that, as we have done in favour of the Youth Guarantee, with the implementation of targeted actions on countries with particularly high youth unemployment rates, which are generally also the most serious budgetary problems, we should also consider targeting resources to countries that are experiencing the greatest difficulties in terms of long-term unemployment. I believe that the European Social Fund should integrate a real dimension in the fight against long-term unemployment. We all agree that in order to employ a long-term unemployed person, jobs must be created and that economic policy is primarily concerned. If there is no job creation, if there is no growth, if there is no demand, if there is no investment, there will be no jobs, and unemployment will become increasingly high and structural unemployment. Of course, employers should also be held accountable for their actions , and I believe that this is also part of their social responsibility , but perhaps the authorities must also help employers to hire long-term jobseekers, through specific aids or measures.  I do not like to cite my country as an example, but on Friday I will launch a new measure, which was suggested to me by the Commission's recommendation, by creating a real reintegration contract for the most vulnerable groups, to try to bring these people back to work and, of course, to grant aid to the companies that hire these people. At the same time, I will allow these companies to also have measures to supervise these people, to train, etc.  I therefore believe that we must help employers, encourage them, but also call on their responsibility to give a chance to the long-term unemployed, because what we are actually talking about is also an aspect of the European social model, it is social cohesion, because this number of people - twelve million - represents a wound in European societies.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: At the end of the debate, a motion for a resolution was tabled in accordance with Rule 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday 29 October 2015. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. The economic crisis is at the root of a very high number of unemployed and, due to the closure or downsizing of historic companies, in many cases these are people who find it difficult to compete with the current world of work and retrain. It is therefore essential to draw attention to the importance of targeted action, which is adapted to the different social and employment realities. Also important, from this point of view, are the incentives offered to employers to hire the long-term unemployed, so that no one is left out of the world of work for too long. The aim is to signal to the Council the importance of a targeted contribution adapted to the specific needs which have emerged as a result of the exponential rise in unemployment over the last decade.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – Long-term unemployment has significant negative social and economic consequences. It can lead to skills depreciation, loss of motivation and higher incidence of health problems. Long-term unemployment is one of the most important causes of poverty. Long-term unemployed people are often facing reluctance from potential employers and consequently lower career advancement prospects. Many of them, unemployed for a year or more, risk leaving the labour market altogether. Workers with low qualifications, third country nationals, and people with disabilities are disproportionately affected. The diversity of situations requires support tailored to the needs of each person. This trend needs to be reversed to ensure that the long-term unemployed can benefit from the economic recovery. Tackling long-term unemployment can contribute to sustainable growth and would reduce the impact of higher social assistance. We need to open a way out of poverty for both the workers affected and their families. Besides ensuring adequate financial support from the European Social Fund, we need effective administrative measures. The EU needs to assist Member States to exchange good practices to improve their policies and services focusing on better assessment of the unemployed person’s skills and designing a personalised job integration agreement.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. – I would like to grasp this opportunity to urge for action on the steel crisis taking place in the UK and my region of the West Midlands that risks driving hundreds of thousands into unemployment. 1 700 jobs are in the balance in Caparo, coming on top of around 6 000 jobs that were lost nationwide, including in Tata Steel. That is not to mention 100 000s of people working in the Midlands supply chain. This has not developed overnight, yet the UK Government failed to prevent this social bloodbath. EU funding is available to support the affected workers, but the Tories failed to apply.  Still, there are other ways in which the EU can and should help: it should swiftly grant state aid approval so the industry can receive compensation for high energy prices – especially given the Tories are hiding behind the Commission rather than securing retrospective EU approval later. The EU should also take a firm stance against China dumping steel on our markets. 42 companies have shown interest in taking over Caparo, but we can only prevent a similar tragedy from happening again if we address these structural problems. Here, the EU has a key role to play where the government is failing to step up to the plate.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The problem of long-term unemployment affects all Member States and the challenges associated with it are extremely difficult. I am all the more pleased that an attempt has been made to create a comprehensive approach to this subject at European level. Although the proportion of the long-term unemployed varies considerably between Member States, this group is quite heterogeneous across the Union and I believe that a uniform strategy can be developed. I consider it important that the Commission, together with other activities, focus on building the capacity of competent, well-prepared staff in public employment services. This is a very important issue, especially in the context of the creation of 'points of single contact', a new approach in many Member States, and the preparation of points will require considerable time and resources for training. I therefore look forward to presenting further concrete proposals from the Commission.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Many countries are trying differently to cope with the phenomenon of long-term unemployment, but so far no perfect answer has been found to this challenge. I am convinced that, as with many other problems, the creation of new jobs is a key issue in the case of long-term unemployment. Only if the European economy grows in a sustainable and stable way will we be able to improve employment rates. This, on the other hand, creates a friendly environment for investors and businesses and that is what The Member States should focus on. The second equally important issue is adequate and personalised support for the long-term unemployed. More efficient and decentralised employment services are part of the answer to this challenge. It is also very important to activate the unemployed by addressing solutions tailored to their needs, as well as to the situation on local labour markets. In this context, structural reforms are also needed to adapt labour markets to new challenges and, as has been emphasised so often recently, better cooperation between employment services and educational institutions. In addition to support and self-esteem, the long-term unemployed need the right skills and qualifications for which there is currently demand in local markets.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. – It is a great pleasure that, on the basis of my proposal, in the preparation of the current draft text, the coordinators have accepted that the decision to be adopted by the European Council by the European Parliament has included the need to take into account local and regional conditions in the fight against long-term unemployment, in addition to respecting the current treaties. This message is particularly important as it makes recommendations for the next European Council meeting on employment policy in order to address long-term unemployment.  The novelty of the decision comes as the Union has finally recognised the need to address the situation of more than 10 million European citizens who have been out of work for a long time, as their numbers and proportions have increased significantly in recent years, in particular as a result of the financial and sovereign debt crisis. The decision also name specific EU Member States with particularly severe employment crises: Portugal, Slovakia, Croatia, Spain and Greece. Hungary has been able to significantly increase employment in recent years and keep the number of citizens looking for work for more than a year below the EU average, which is a great achievement, but we still cannot sit back and work longer and remain open to all sorts of solutions.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The continuation and intensification of action to combat long-term unemployment is crucial, in particular in the absence of clear progress in this area. In my country, the long-term unemployed make up almost 50% of the unemployed. The consequence of long-term unemployment is often poverty and social exclusion, which further isolates people from the labour market. In the context of the fight against long-term unemployment, I draw attention to the effectiveness of education programmes aimed at the long-term unemployed. I am often approached by people who have taken numerous education and vocational courses and who, despite the many additional skills acquired, still cannot find a job. In order to prevent such cases, we need more effective tools for activating the unemployed and support for public employment services. The proposed vocational programmes and training for the long-term unemployed should take into account the possibility of traineeships and traineeships in the field concerned. This approach will allow the unemployed to verify their skills, gain the experience often already required in a given position, gain confidence and thus increase their employability.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. – The financial crisis of 2008 and the austerity policies imposed subsequently led the countries of Europe to unprecedented unemployment rates, which mainly affect the countries of the European South. In particular, according to Eurostat, Greece ranks first, with the highest long-term unemployment rate (25.6%), followed by Spain with 22.5%, while Germany has one of the lowest rates (4.7%). , only EUR 18.8 billion was made available to the European Investment Bank (EIB). Euro. Moreover, for the countries of the heavily indebted European South and in particular for Greece there will be no investment unless the debt is settled. And this can be done by writing off the shameful debt.

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D)
text: Writing. It seems that the Commission has finally recognised the signs of the times. Instead of cutting aid to deal with the crisis, concrete proposals are finally being made here. It is high time for this, because the problem of long-term unemployment in Europe is more acute than ever. Almost half of Europe's 23 million unemployed have been out of work in the last 12 months and beyond. The statistics clearly show that the longer unemployment lasts, the harder it is for people to re-enter the labour market. We must not forget the psychosocial risks of long-term unemployment. Unemployment in many cases also means exclusion. For many, therefore, simply regaining a job is not enough. Good preparation and support for re-entering the labour market is needed here. Strong social dialogue is therefore all the more important. Well-educated workers do not fall from the sky. This is why employers are also called upon to ensure sustainable training and further education opportunities.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission's statement on the Europe 2020 strategy: perspectives and balance sheet (2015/2904(RSP)).

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members of Parliament, the Europe 2020 Strategy was launched in 2010 as an EU strategy to deliver smart, sustainable and inclusive growth for Europe. It set out five ambitious targets for the EU to achieve by 2020 in the fields of employment, research and development, climate change and energy, education, and the fight against poverty and social exclusion. More than that, the Europe 2020 Strategy has guided the strategic choices of the Commission’s work. The Strategy announced the creation of the European Semester, which has become a powerful instrument to provide guidance for the Member States in their structural reforms and sustainable fiscal policies.  The Strategy also guides EU spending. It has set the direction when preparing the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework, when programing European structural and investment funds and when launching new funding programmes at EU level. A clear example is the creation of the Horizon 2020 Programme, with substantial increases in research, development and innovation funding.  However, Europe 2020 has not always been successful in giving Member States the tools to achieve their objectives. Europe 2020 should not be a process imposed by the EU, but a method for common prosperity. Therefore, full ownership at EU and national level is key to its implementation. This requires the Commission to work more closely with Member States. The European Council needs to be fully involved and to share ownership of Europe’s long-term growth strategy. The European Parliament and the national parliaments are vital partners. Engagement with, and ownership by, civil society and businesses is also important.  The reflection on the Europe 2020 Strategy is ongoing and we are looking into making the best use of the existing Strategy – improving its implementation and monitoring in the context of the European Semester. At the same time we need to reflect on, and develop, a longer-term vision. Therefore, we will present next year a new long-term strategy for jobs and growth, looking beyond the 2020 horizon. With this approach we are ensuring economic growth and social and environmental sustainability beyond the 2020 framework. In this work we are taking into account the Europe 2020 review and the internal and external implementation of the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Before giving the floor to the first speaker for the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, I would like to point out that, because of the late times available, I will no longer accept 'blue cards', because otherwise the sitting will last much longer than 11 p.m., and we do not want that.

name: Andreas Schwab
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Vice-President Dombrovskis, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Madam President, I had already feared that you were going to interrupt the sitting again. But if it is just a matter of not putting any more speakers on the list, I have no problem at all with it. Mr Vice-President, dear Valdis Dombrovskis, I would like to thank The Vice-President for his work. The objectives for the Europe 2020 strategy were broad, they were long-term, and we see time and again that they are somewhat forgotten in the small part of the work of legislation in all areas. In part, the objectives have hitherto been difficult to achieve because, of course, they have demonstrated the necessary flexibility that characterises such longer-term strategies in general. That is why we must, above all, stick to the objectives, which are actually measurable for the success of the European Union and can be used in the European internal market. The three per cent target for investment in research and development is an often underestimated element in increasing competitiveness and strengthening the social market economy in the European Union, because we see that global economies that invest heavily in research and development are significantly better off than others. That is why, dear Vice-President, Valdis Dombrovskis, if we really want to revitalise the Europe 2020 strategy in the coming months, if we want to add another building block to it, we must focus on research and development in order to increase competitiveness.

name: Maria João Rodrigues
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I would say to Vice-President Dombrovskis that it is really important for us that the European Strategy for growth and jobs be relaunched. It has disappeared from our radars, but Europe really needs a bolder strategy for growth and jobs. Europe 2020 should be updated to take into account the new challenges. We believe that what is at stake now is not only energy transition but also promoting a circular economy and providing new kinds of jobs because of that; what is at stake is not only to promote digital telecommunications but the full range of new services, products and the new jobs connected with this; what is at stake is not only to strengthen R&D but to turn R&D into real innovative services and products, and finally, in the social dimension, we believe that beyond quality jobs we also need to tackle social inequalities. So Europe 2020 should be updated like that. But then we are concerned with the means to implement this, because the lesson of the past is that bold visions were not matched by the proper means. So we believe that the European investment plan should be made a central engine to implement the Europe 2020 Strategy, and we also believe that the European Semester should provide the coordination of economic and social policies which we need to deliver the Europe 2020 Strategy properly. So my question for you, Mr Vice-President, is the following: so far, we have a kind of divorce between the Europe 2020 Strategy on the one hand and the European Semester on the other, and we need to marry them again, I would say, so this means that the next European Semester cycle should take fully on board the Europe 2020 targets, should take fully on board Europe 2020 goals when encouraging Member States to prepare their national reform programmes, and then the country-specific recommendations should push in the same direction. We believe this is a central problem to be solved, to reconnect the European Semester with the Europe 2020 Strategy.

name: Richard Sulík
text: for the ECR Group – The basic objective of the 2020 strategy, which has been in force since 2010, thus these basic objectives include an increase in employment from 70 to 75 %, the reality being 68. Reducing the number of poor from 116 million to 96, the reality is 121. Also increasing the number of university educated people to 40%, the result is that today you can sweep the streets with them slowly. The Europe 2020 strategy has failed. Europe would not be any worse off today if no strategy existed. This is also because the strategy has conflicting objectives – you want to reduce unemployment, at the same time increase climate targets and so on. Commissioner, I suggest, forgive yourself for the whole strategy, take on more important matters. This theatre does not need Europe.

name: Pavel Telička
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, when we went to launch the Europe 2020 Strategy I saw it as a chance. To be honest, I think that we missed the opportunity, and I will tell you why. For me, the Strategy is a document that really focuses on absolutely key issues, provides the necessary means, provides tools and monitors, creates benchmarks and has some kind of internal review. In fact, what we got out of Europe 2020 was, if not shopping list, a Christmas tree. Everyone had to be happy. Everyone contributed, and we again created a compromise.  I really appreciate what you have said, that the strategy has met certain objectives, and that it did help. You mentioned guiding EU spending: I think if we look at EFSI it also reflects that. But I would also like to emphasise what you have said, and that is that you will be preparing a longer-term vision for next year. This is once again an opportunity, but I think that this time we cannot afford to miss the opportunity. We should be looking for absolutely key priorities – a limited range – create the resources, have the right tools and have the courage. Also, when you speak of ownership on behalf of the European Council, I could not agree more. But what we have today is a Strategy which was too much owned by the European Council. I know that the Commission missed out on the opportunity to be a little bit more pushy, courageous and address the topical issues, but then the European Council created a document about which, shortly after it was approved, colleagues both from the Commission and the Council kept telling me ‘We did not want that! This is not a good document’, and we need to avoid that situation. So my plea would be to focus on the key issues, both on growth and creating jobs, adjusted to the needs of this year – post-recession, post-crisis – to tackle exactly the areas that will contribute to growth. Some of them were mentioned by colleagues; some of them might not have been mentioned. I would invite you to enter into a real dialogue with us in preparing it, because I think that it does not have to be just ownership of the European Council, it has to be a co-ownership by the European Parliament, and we will come to you with concrete ideas.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Commissioner, what strategy are we talking about when the people of Europe are currently experiencing this situation? The economic crisis deepened inequalities in the Union, while harsh measures deregulated industrial relations, took out the social state and sold off public wealth. The poverty rate is constantly rising, the figures call for reality: 123 million Europeans live below the poverty line, of whom 26 million are children and young people. Only in Cyprus, although harsh memorial policies are in place, one in four people is facing poverty and child poverty is at 27% . Greece and Spain and Portugal and Ireland face the same problems, although the last two countries have theoretically emerged from the Memorandums, while the same policies continue. It is no coincidence, of course, that 1% of Europe's population currently holds a third of its wealth.  As wealth gathers in the hands of the few, the gap and inequalities grow. That is why cohesion policy should not be a tool of the EU 2020 strategy, which provides for enhanced competitiveness, flexible forms of employment and privatisation. It is important that cohesion policy is not aligned with the framework of single economic governance, otherwise states will be blackmailed into following the harsh austerity measures provided for in the European Semester, so as not to interrupt their financial support. In such a case, cohesion policy will be completely neutralised.  Commissioner, we need to promote a new social development policy, to support public investment, to finance projects that meet the needs of society and to contribute to the creation of new quality jobs. Only in this way will we combat the economic, social and territorial disparities that exist in Europe. That is why, Commissioner, we believe that we need to change course, a strategy must have objectives for social well-being, it must have objectives for more public investment, it must also have objectives for economic cohesion and growth.

name: Jean Lambert
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I welcome the review of the 2020 Strategy. The very fact that we are even having a debate ahead of it is an improvement on where it came from, where Parliament had to fight to find a way into have any sort of sense of ownership with it – let alone wider civil society, social partners and others that were supposed to be engaged – so I hope that we manage a very good and broad consultation on this. I also very much welcome the linking with the new Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), because I think that gives us some new sets of dimensions, not least a more global one. The SDG on sustainable consumption and production, which links to the proposals coming up on the circular economy, will be important in terms of how this fits with sustainability within the European Union and really develops the ideas on new skills for new jobs, issues around just transition, and indeed the investment that others have spoken of. However, I would say that I think that targets are important. One of the things that we have learned in this process is that, if there is not a target and if it is not measured, it is not visible. The anti-poverty target has been very important and should not be forgotten, even if we want to consider framing that now more in terms of reducing inequalities and looking at what we are doing there to improve our societies overall.

name: Jane Collins
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, here we are again in Strasbourg, having travelled to this building that we occupy only 50 days a year, at a cost of millions to the taxpayer, discussing another strategy for growth and jobs – when it is EU legislation from this building that has cost my constituents in Scunthorpe and Rotherham their jobs. The obsessive green agenda has led to increased energy prices. Even the outgoing boss at Tata Steel in Scunthorpe has said those levies cost them 130 million a year. Thanks to our EU membership the British Government’s hand is well and truly shoved up its back. Now we are even using Swedish steel to make British military equipment: steel that defeated Hitler is no longer good enough for our armed forces. I say we should ignore the Commission and put our own people first. If Brussels does not want us to have a steel industry, it is something we can talk about after the referendum in 2017. I imagine that conversation is going to be very brief, as polls keep showing us a win for ‘leave’.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: Mrs Lunacek, my predecessor, said there would be no blue card procedure because it was very late. I don't want to change that.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI). Mr President, Europe 2020 reflects the priorities of European capital for an even more favourable framework for increasing its profitability and competitiveness by exploiting innovation; Anti-labour measures and memoranda promoted by the European Union and governments are not a temporary derogation. It is a long-term tool to meet the capital's needs for profitability. Anisometry is like acute competition intertwined with the capitalist path of development. Deepening EMU with the text of the five presidents means strengthening the mechanisms of the unpopular capital-European Union strategy with measures such as the Financial Council, strengthening the Eurogroup, strengthening supervision and escalating the anti-labour offensive.  The example of Greece in the third left-wing MEMORANDUM of SYRIZA proves that the European Union and capitalism can only be made worse. The only way for the people is to become the owner of the wealth they produce. On this road it will be released from the European Union, it will unilaterally write off the debt.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent work. Five years ago, we set very high targets in the European Union, which we want to achieve by 2020. I am going to only talk about one of these objectives at the moment. For the fact that we want to increase investment in science and development to 3% of Europe's gross domestic product. Where are we now? We are only at about 2% of gross domestic product for investment in science and development. And I believe that this is a problem for us. Why is this a problem? In Europe, we are not in a vacuum. We are not self-sufficient, including all the nearly 550 million that we have. The European Union is in competition with the United States, with China and with the rest of the world. And where is this competition going, and how does she take place in the most comprehensive way? It is with products, products that are manufactured with high added value or based on high technology. And for these technologies to be, there must be a science base. So, in order to increase our competition, we need to pay serious attention to the fact that this money for science and development must be through programmes such as Horizon 2020.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: – Madam Vice-President, it is clear, and the committee recognises that the first five years of the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy have failed, the strategy for growth has lost influence and has been submerged by the focus given to fiscal policy. There has been an excess of financial focus and a huge lack of economic focus. Correcting this imbalance has to be the priority of the review of the Europe 2020 strategy and, in to do so, we must be ambitious and bold.  The combination of the Energy Union and the Digital Union is one of those paths. The smart combination of the Energy Union and the Digital Union is a path of sustainable development on which the European Union can lead. This leadership means a new vision of the future of the world, based on the focus on scientific research, innovation, skilled employment and new models of social organization and mobility.  I dare not, in the brief seconds of this intervention, describe this view. I sum it up in an idea i would like to inspire the review of the 2020 Strategy. We have to put a strategy into place for people and, to begin with, we must get people to discuss the strategy. Let us make this process an inspiring process for the future of the European Union.

name: David Casa (PPE).
text: – Irrid nibda billi nirringrazzja l-Kummissarju tal-ħsibijiet u l-analiżi tiegħu. Ir-reviżjoni ta' nofs it-terminu hija importanti ferm sabiex nanalizzaw is-sitwazzjoni u l-qagħda tal-miri li ttina l-Ewropa 2020 u li din suppost kellha tilħaq. Naħseb li l-konsultazzjoni pubblika li kien hemm is-sena l-oħra wriet li hemm bżonn li nagħmlu iktar biex titjieb is-sitwazzjoni u li niedu l-messaġġi illi aħna rvesvejna. Fil-każ tal-partit tiegħi, il-Partit Popolari Ewropew, it-tkabbir u l-impjiegi huma prijorità fuq l-aġenda tagħna. Aħna qegħdin naħdmu sabiex nilħqu l-objettivi tagħna b'mod sostenibbli u responsabbli. Aħna wkoll, b'dan il-mod, qegħdin insostnu l-ambjent illi jkun iktar soảjalment ġust, u għalhekk adattajna għal mod ġodda li saru disponibbli bl-avvanz tat-teknoloġija. Sfortunatament, il-kriżi finanzjarja ta' dan l-aħħar snin kienet daqqa ta' ħarta fejn jidħlu l-impjiegi u l-objettivi ta' tkabbir speảjalment fit-tnaqqis tal-faqar u l-esklużjoni soảjali. Fost il-ħames objettivi ambizzjużi li għandna quddiemna, attenzjoni speảjali għandha tingħata fuq it-tkabbir tax-xogħol, l-edukazzjoni u l-inklużjoni soảjali. Ma sarx biżżejjed f'dawn l-oqsma u nemmen li mingħajr governanza economics b'saħħitha, li tgħin biex tmexxi 'l quddiem l-economics tagħna, ma jkunx possibbli li nilħqu l-objettivi li kienu ppjanati permezz ta' din l-istrateġija.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the idea of reproposing a long-term strategy is acceptable. However, we cannot talk about the future without learning some lessons from the past, and it must be said quite frankly that the experience we have in these five years behind us, relating to the Europe 2020 strategy, has failed. The ambitious objectives indicated have not been achieved, because in the meantime the crisis penalised all the economies of European countries and increased unemployment and people's suffering. So we have to imagine the possibility of correcting cammin by also taking the point of view that was initially defined.  And then the priorities must be identified. It is no coincidence that my colleagues have spoken repeatedly about research, development and innovation, which were at the heart of the Lisbon proposal of the year 2000. Think how long it has been without concrete results. Growth and competitiveness must be based on research and innovation, and on the other hand citizens must be protected. Social protection gives cohesion and cohesion is an extraordinary factor of competitiveness, as we have been taught by the years that we have behind us and in which many countries, using cohesion, have made their economies strong.

name: Lambert van Nistelrooij (PPE).
text: – Commissioner, today in a long, long vote – we have already voted on the Ruas report on the Europe 2020 Strategy and the Structural and Investment Funds and the European Semester, which concerns about one third of our European EU budget.  We have concluded that this investment in the real economy forms the main investment budget for attaining the Europe 2020 objectives. Up until 2020 we have some EUR 460 billion, including co-financing, available for growth and jobs, and, as I said before about research and development, there will, for the first time, be EUR 43 billion available for that goal under the Structural Funds.  But for all that the Europe 2020 Strategy is, like the Lisbon Strategy, in danger of missing its objectives. The Europe 2020 strategy needs to change from a highly top-down approach to a bottom-up approach. This will be discussed at the Seventh Knowledge and Innovation Summit in December, innovation, that is, leading to a pact,  a pact on innovation, an approach to which Commissioners Moedas and Katainen have already committed themselves. This will really connect industrial regions and cities and education and knowledge institutes with citizens and provide a platform for specific projects. The EU project being pursued by this Juncker Commission hardly reaches citizens. That is why this approach is needed and I think that we can introduce it into the upcoming debate.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, halfway through the Europe 2020 strategy, when it was revised, you were right, Vice-President, to admit that not everything worked at all. It is right to set ourselves long-term, long-term objectives: we are asked for 'vision'. But we also need to take consistent action to achieve the goals we set ourselves. For example, if we want growth, as we have said, to be intelligent, sustainable and inclusive and if we want to increase employment to 75%, then we cannot implement for years, in a recessionary economic phase, only austerity policies that have in fact blocked the competitiveness and development of our system.  As Mr Rodriguez said very well, the European Semester was conceived as the driving force behind this strategy for economic growth and employment, but today it has become above all the means of checking whether the Member States have done their homework well on the objectives of fiscal and budgetary consolidation.  We must learn from the past and from the mistakes we have made in the past. Today we have before us new instruments for growth and public investment, starting with the Juncker plan, but also new challenges. I am referring to migration, but also to the transition to a circular economy. Well, I hope that all this will be taken into account in the review and updating of the strategy.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The Europe 2020 strategy has identified two educational objectives. The first is to reduce the proportion of young people who drop out of education prematurely to less than 10%. And this is a goal that does not raise any doubts. The second objective is to increase the share of young people with tertiary education to 40% by 2020, and in this respect we are very close to reaching the formal level, as in 2014 the EU average was almost 38%. However, the problem is that these young people do not find work according to their academic education. This, of course, gives rise to their frustration. Hence the question to the Commissioner: do you not think that it will be useless to formally achieve the objective if we do not ensure the quality of education, its coherence with the needs of the labour market and, above all, job creation?

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D).
text: – The social divide in Europe is widening, between young and old, between the southern and northern Member States. 26 million children and young people in the European Union are also threatened by poverty and social exclusion. That is in the social justice index presented yesterday. In fact, like the Europe 2020 strategy, the fight against poverty has become a neglected child. We are far behind schedule and the austerity measures have only made the situation worse. This is all the worse for children because poverty lasts a lifetime. That is why I want to know what the Commission is going to do to use the renewed Europe 2020 strategy as a means of making people more resilient. How will these objectives become part of the social pillar and what concrete action will the Commission take to achieve the poverty target and break the vicious cycle of poverty for families?

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: – In the eyes of European citizens, the failure of the Lisbon Strategy was at the heart of effective and socially just crisis management, including a lack of mass and meaningful job creation. The experience of the last five years shows that the EU's competitiveness and economic recovery are most threatened by intertwined practices of corruption and tax evasion, with different weights from one Member State to another. It is a major challenge for the EU as a whole that this is also the case at government level in some Member States, and is almost institutional, and significant EU and national instruments have been taken away from important social objectives. This is why it is essential that effective action by governments against all forms and levels of corruption and tax evasion is prioritised in the framework of the EU-2020 requirements.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ‘history will judge us by the difference we make in the everyday lives of children’, to quote Nelson Mandela and, let me add, ‘young people’. They are still paying the price of the economic and debt crises. The study already referred to yesterday underscores the point. In the EU, 26 million children and young people are threatened by poverty and social exclusion. This is a reality that we are painfully aware of in the UK, in the same way as elsewhere in Europe. We have 750 000 young people out of a job and they are three times more likely to be unemployed than the rest of the population, the largest gap in more than 20 years. So let this review should be a wake-up call to get our priorities right. Yes, we do have a Youth Guarantee, but more needs to be done. If the Commission had a more ambitious reform of economic governance rules that gave employment and the social agenda a higher priority, at least one that put them on par with economic and fiscal governance, then we might get some progress. The same goes for the migration crisis, which has to be one of our EU 2020 goals, because only an ambitious humanistic approach can resolve this and make a difference.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D).
text: – Mr President, 1 700 jobs in my constituency in the West Midlands are seriously threatened by the collapse of Caparo Steel. Are these naturally threatened, outdated jobs in a declining industry? No, there are actually lots and lots – dozens, we hear – of potential buyers for these businesses, because these are very competitive, often high-tech, good businesses. So why has Caparo Steel collapsed, we ask? Well, not because the businesses are not competitive: it has collapsed because of price, because of dumping on the international market that the UK Government and our institutions here are not doing anything about. Let the Commission have strength in this matter. Let us not confuse competitiveness with price, and let us not compete on price, because we cannot. Let us compete on the competitiveness that we should pride ourselves on.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, there is nothing wrong with the 2020 targets. In fact, in the general sense, we are not doing too badly in trying to reach them, especially in the areas of employment, R&D, greenhouse gas emissions and education. I think they are all reachable by 2020. Two areas where we are not doing too well, and some have referred to this, are, firstly, poverty and social exclusion – that certainly has to be looked at and we have to redouble our efforts to reach our targets in that area – and, secondly, an area of importance to me particularly, energy efficiency. This is a win—win. But we are not doing enough, particularly in the area of housing. I think we need to incentivise customers, householders, young people and, of course, developers to build energy-efficient houses. That is a win-win for everybody in the long term. One other target which I think we should add – as the Commission was talking about reducing bureaucracy and red tape – is a target to reduce it by 20% by 2020. That would also be a very good idea.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, despite the ambitious objectives of the EU 2020 strategy for employment, research & development and hitting social exclusion and poverty, so far the European Union is moving away from these targets. In particular, in the countries of the European South and especially in Greece, at a time when the European Union is talking about economic growth, it is imposing even stricter austerity measures on the Greek people. At the same time, in Greece the unemployment rate is reaching 25%, a rapid increase since 2012, while the youth unemployment rate exceeds 50%. We therefore see that mercelian austerity instead of growth has brought even higher unemployment rates to Greece and has not promoted growth in areas such as health, education and research, which are supposed to be objectives of the EU 2020 strategy. In order for growth in the countries of the heavily indebted European South and in Greece, the policy of austerity must be abandoned and the exorbitant shameful debt must be written off, and this message is being sent by the Greek people to the troika and to the loan lenders.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the EU 2020 strategy, in line with what had already happened with the Lisbon Strategy, has not responded to the serious problems we face. On the contrary, the policies contained in these strategies are responsible for these same problems. The goal of full employment and the eradication of poverty has been abandoned. The priority was for the interests of large economic and financial groups. Social and labour situation, poverty and social exclusion have reached unacceptable levels, precarious unemployment has become widespread, exploitation, liberalisation and privatisation of strategic sectors and public services have increased – financial services, energy, transport, postal services and others.  It is time to change policies, it is time to seriously solve the social problems facing Europe, it is time to end the debt, economic governance, European Semester, budgetary treaty.  It is time to regain public, democratic control over companies in strategic sectors of the economy.  It is time to resurrect productive public investment, create jobs, create wealth, distribute, in a socially just way, the created wealth.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his work Europe 2020 is a 2010 strategy that should create sustainable, inclusive and smart growth. In time for the mid-term review, an evaluation of the five key issues of employment, research and development, climate and energy, education and poverty reduction was carried out last year, as part of a public consultation. Unfortunately, we have to say that this evaluation did not produce a very good result, because on some key points Europe is not very good at the halfway point. There is a need for action if we are to catch up here. On the one hand, there is the employment rate: we want to achieve 75%. Action is needed here, it is getting worse rather than better, and we have to make up for it.  Research and development are not looking so bad, but things are looking bad at climate targets, greenhouse gas emissions, renewable energy and energy efficiency. Here, too, the utmost efforts are required. Perhaps COP21 will now be able to set binding targets in Paris. Similarly, little has happened in the area of poverty reduction. In the area of higher education qualifications, too, the figure of 40% has not been reached. We need to act - let us act.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, At the beginning of my speech, I just want to express my astonishment that the Commissioner is here all the time, and while some Members are asking questions and critical remarks about him and then leaving after his contribution. I find it a little disrespectful that they won't even wait for the Commissioner's response. I would like to say that, of course, the European strategy for growth and jobs needs updating. These targets are set correctly, but it is clear that they need to be updated in view of the changed situation. I believe that we need to connect the growth movers. We need to strengthen their partnership in order to really achieve the objectives set out in the strategy, and I would like to point out that the Blanco López report that we have approved today also contains a reference to the continued validity of this EU 2020 strategy.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I wish to thank Members for this debate. The European Commission’s political guidance provides a clear roadmap and a guide for action that is perfectly consistent and compatible with the Europe 2020 Strategy, which remains fully valid as our long-term strategy for jobs and growth. The Commission will therefore implement the 2020 Strategy focusing on concrete tools and deliveries, which underpin the current multiannual financial framework and the European Structural and Investment Funds, with the European Semester as an implementation and monitoring tool. The Europe 2020 Strategy and the political guidelines are two sides of the same coin. The first sets out the medium to long-term vision and the latter provides a clear roadmap to guide the way. It is evident that these two must be coherent and interact well with each other. The political guidelines are constantly complemented and updated to meet new challenges as the Five Presidents’ Report and the Commission’s responses to new challenges, such as the current migration crisis, show. The Strategy, however, provides strategic guidance when the EU enters uncharted waters beyond the priorities of the coming year. At the same time, reflection will continue on the vision beyond 2020 and the results will be presented next summer.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.  Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – The Europe 2020 strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth is based on five key objectives of equal importance. However, the progress made in achieving the objectives is uneven, especially the poverty reduction target is far from being achieved. The mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy therefore gives all of us responsible for EU policy-making an excellent opportunity to re-focus on a European model that is tailored to all its populations. The countries of the European Union will undoubtedly achieve more and better results than acting alone in their immediate challenges. If this is not done, increased poverty and social exclusion will lead to even greater alienation and division in our region and will further undermine the idea of a united Europe. I would therefore very much like to ask the Commission whether it intends to maintain the EU poverty reduction target in the review of the Europe 2020 strategy and classify it by age and gender, or does it intend to set additional targets, such as reducing child poverty? The latest UNICEF report reveals shocking figures on how many children are in poverty in Europe and around the world. Unfortunately, the greatest impact on the change of poverty has been the indiscriminate austerity and, above all, at the expense of children. Therefore, does the Commission not believe that, in the forth-mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy, it is necessary to set an additional target for reducing child poverty, because that is the only way we will get out of the vicious circle of poverty in our Europe?

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Renato Soru, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the notification and transparency of securities financing transactions (COM(2014). )0040 - C7-0023/2014 - 2014/0017(COD)) - (A8-0120/2015).

name: Renato Soru
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, we have almost reached the end of the legislative process that has involved me over the last year and a half, but which had already begun in the last parliamentary term and which I hope will come to an end tomorrow with the final approval: legislation, in fact, on securities financing transactions in English literature. I am rather pleased with this path, not only because this is the first legislative report on which I had the pleasure of working, here in the European Parliament, but also because I believe that a good compromise has been found between the two main objectives of this rule, which is to ensure an efficient and liquid market for securities financing operations, but even more so to ensure transparency and clear rules in order to prevent systemic risks in the financial market.  The crisis that broke out in 2007 in the United States, in fact, and then quickly transmitted virulently throughout Europe, clearly highlighted not only how the world banking system is now strongly interconnected, but also how there were many connections between the traditional banking system and the so-called shadow banking system, shadow banking, that is, that set of entities that, although performing functions similar to those traditionally carried out by banks , do so outside the system of rules to which credit institutions are subject.  The ECB Board said it was "too big and too indebted, this shadow banking system." In fact, some of the operations carried out by the shadow banking system can result in a level of excessive indebtedness, thus increasing the risk and danger of the whole system. It has been estimated that shadow banking may have accounted for around EUR 51 000 billion in 2011, four times the GDP of the whole of Europe.  Securities financing operations are one of the main link between the shadow banking system and the traditional banking system, which is why the Financial Stability Board and the expert group led by Mr Liikanen, first, and then the European Commission, have made a number of recommendations aimed at ensuring transparency and security, while preserving the necessary liquidity of this market. , which is, however, an important market in ensuring the possibility of financing and also the possibility of using liquidity. The regulation that we are going to adopt aims to improve three important aspects of this market. Firstly, the proposed regulation requires all transactions to be reported in a central database, which will make it possible to know the size and link between shadow banking and the traditional financial system. Secondly, there is a need for greater transparency between investment funds engaged in this market and investors, and finally better regulation of the reuse or rehypothecation of securities.  Efforts have also been made to simplify and take advantage of other regulations affecting financial markets, such as EMIR. There has also been an attempt to agree on the need for transparency, but also for the security of the operations carried out by the European Central Bank.  In short, I believe that a good compromise will be presented to the House for the vote tomorrow.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
