text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I am very pleased to have the chance today to discuss the Securities Financing Transactions Regulation (SFTR) and to congratulate Mr Soru and the shadow rapporteurs for the work they have done in taking this proposal forward.  This regulation is a central part of our response to the need to increase the safety and transparency of financial markets. It will help us to manage the risks in the shadow banking sector, in line with Financial Stability Board recommendations endorsed by G20. It sits alongside a number of measures we have already taken to regulate the shadow banking sector. For example, the European Market Infrastructure Regulation reduces risks in derivatives markets, and the Alternative Investment Fund Managers Directive ensures that investment funds are regulated. As those of you who have followed this proposal know well, securities financing transactions are transactions in which securities are used as collateral to borrow cash, or vice versa. They are an important source of funding on Europe’s financial markets. They support investment and allow for better risk management. They are integral to European Central Bank monetary policy operations. During the financial crisis, it became clear that we did not know enough about what was going on in these markets. Without reliable data, oversight was more difficult. The European Systemic Risk Board, the European Central Bank and the Financial Stability Board all argued that transparency in these markets would allow risks to be managed better and would enable better-informed investment decisions. This was also our analysis in the Commission. So I am delighted that we are on the verge of reaching a final agreement on legislation that will improve transparency. I am grateful to Parliament for its hard work on this issue, and I believe that the political agreement you have reached with the Council strikes the right balance.  It will enhance transparency in three main ways. Firstly, it will introduce the reporting of securities financing transactions to centralised databases known as trade repositories. This will allow supervisors to identify risks better and, if necessary, to take targeted action.  Secondly, funds will have to become more transparent for investors both in their regular reports and in pre-investment documents. This will give investors the information they need to make sound investment decisions. Thirdly, the regulation will improve transparency around the re-use of securities as collateral. This should help reduce domino effects when a default on one transaction can cause other defaults if the same collateral has been used more than once. The legislation builds on the experience of establishing the European Market Infrastructure Regulation. A detailed implementation table will give European markets time to adjust. The proposed reporting system will reduce the burden on small and medium-sized enterprises, and it limits reporting of existing transactions to those strictly necessary for regulatory and supervisory purposes. The proposal enlarges the list of supervisors who can access data in trade repositories, and the European Market Infrastructure Regulation has been modified to ensure consistency. The European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) will prepare draft regulatory technical standards setting out the requirements for reporting. We will work with ESMA to ensure consistent application of the rules across the European Union. The Commission is committed to legislating in a proportionate manner in a way that strikes the right balance between managing risk and encouraging growth. Transparency is an important part of this agenda. By making the right information available we can help investors make sound decisions; we can encourage responsible behaviour; we can avoid unnecessary burdens; and we can take targeted action, if and when it is needed, on the basis of evidence. The Securities Financing Transactions Regulation will be an important step in this direction. I look forward to this debate and to the plenary vote on Thursday.

name: Danuta Maria Hübner
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, this new regulation will certainly bring an additional dose of transparency to the ways in which the financial sector functions. We will have a better view of what is going on in the shadow banking system – who transacts with whom, when, with what type of assets and under what conditions. This will certainly help market participants. I also trust that transparency might prevent activities migrating from the banking system to the less regulated non-bank system. In this respect I find it particularly important that information on the securities financing transactions entered into by funds – and I am thinking here of undertakings for collective investment in transferable securities (UCITS) and structured financial instruments (SFIs) – is disclosed to investors. The good news is also that the three institutions agreed to use the opportunity of this regulation to make two amendments to the European Market Infrastructure Regulation (EMIR). One will give the resolution authorities established after the entry into force of EMIR the right to access information retained in trade repositories. We all know the importance for resolution authorities of having good quality supervisory data. We have also made a technical change which is expected to make it easier for the Commission to declare the supervisory arrangements of a third country as equivalent under EMIR. I am personally happy that we agreed on the exemption of SMEs from the reporting requirements: when they transact with a fund, a bank or an investment firm, it is the counterparty that will deal with reporting on behalf of both parties.

name: Jonás Fernández
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur, Renato Soru, for the work during these months to get here, to the House, and to vote tomorrow on this Regulation, which I believe is a very important step in ending opacity and agreements outside regulated markets. Our group's effort to incorporate new operations into the analysis monitoring system is important. It is also important to improve the information that market operators are going to have to offer and, therefore, I believe that our group, the Socialist Group, has made significant progress in the text on the Commission. I just wanted to add a final note and that is that, within this great ambitious capital markets union project, we need this union not to involve giving new avenues of financing to shadow banking, to out-of-control operations, and it is important that this philosophy to have an organized, transparent, monitored market by supervisory institutions is the basis on which we build the Capital Markets Union.

name: Stanisław Ożóg
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – The main objective of the report was to increase financial stability in the European Union. This objective can be achieved by increasing the transparency of market activities such as securities financing transactions, pawning and other financing structures with economic effects equivalent to those of securities financing transactions. The ECR Group, in cooperation with the EPP and the ALDE, has tabled amendments which seem to us to have succeeded in alleviating the tone of many of the controversial issues raised in the original draft report: among other things, reducing the requirements for making information of listed companies to the public to a minimum, it has also succeeded in introducing a gradation in the obligation to report transactions, and removing the provision on the reduction of the value of collateral. Personally, however, I am very careful about some of the mechanisms for achieving the goal.

name: Philippe De Backer
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, this debate tonight may not be the fiercest that we will see here in this Parliament today, but I think that with this file we are creating more financial stability in a very important market for our European economy. Securities financing transactions (SFTs) play an important role in financial markets and the financing of our economy. I would like to congratulate the negotiating team for its very balanced approach. By a balanced approach I mean that the result has considered all SFT stakeholders, whilst achieving financial stability. At the end of the day, we wanted to ensure that the reporting is actually being used and is useful for its intended purpose. The proposed regulation delivers binding transparency and reporting requirements in three key areas. First, all securities financing transactions have to be reported to trade repositories, and here the burden for non-financial parties, such as SMEs, was reduced by allowing their financial counterparties to do the reporting for them. Second, we have ensured transparency towards investors. Funds have to inform investors of their SFT activities in the prospectus, and this will enable them to assess the risk as part of their investment decisions. Third, the report addresses transparency around re-use of assets. Parties have a responsibility to communicate the risks and consequences in the event of a default. Assets can only be reused within certain parameters and with prior consent, except for Title Transfer Collateral Arrangements (TTCAs) where the legal title has already been transferred. Another important point is that we came up with a realistic implementation timeframe. We wanted to avoid the mistakes that we have seen with the implementation of EMIR and we rectified some of the shortcomings. All parties should now have sufficient time to implement the necessary requirements. To conclude, I believe that we have come up with a very balanced approach. We have created transparency in a difficult and technical market, both towards supervisors and investors with a minimal burden for all the stakeholders. Therefore, I hope that Members can join me in voting in favour tomorrow.

name: Bernard Monot
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, shadow banking, which is constantly infused by central banks, is a danger to the stability of the world economy. Artificial swelling of toxic derivatives, such as CDS swaps, only worsens the economic situation. Apart from any regulation and supervision of the banking authorities, trillions of dollars or euros of off-balance sheet assets circulate in the greatest opacity.  The proposed regulation on securities financing transactions obliges players to play the game of transparency in terms of transactions and listed companies. But it lacks ambition and could be more restrictive, particularly with regard to the prohibition on the reuse of security, which is a major factor in the dissemination of risk, and by taking into account the operations of public institutions.  Above all, the only effective reform is the real separation between deposit-taking and investment banks - but the end of the universal banking model, using deposits to speculate, will not take place until there are irresponsible politicians subject to the banking lobby - with the aim of no longer making financial contributions to either citizens or customers to bail out insolvent private banks.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: – The global crisis has also shown us, in addition to everything else, the shortcomings and vulnerability of our financial systems. In particular, it has shown gaps that can lead to large-scale fraud and, consequently, high costs. We are all aware that speculation in financial institutions can make huge profits. This is an area that is characterized by rapid earnings. But like fast earnings, there are quick and painful losses. And we have to stop it. We must avoid taxpayers paying for this speculation.  I agree that there needs to be more transparency over the financial system, not only in banks, but also in other financial institutions. I would like to draw attention to something that worries me very much. In Slovenia, we had major problems with the banking system. It has cost taxpayers a lot, but to this day we do not know who is responsible for this. When my client in Slovenia repeatedly demanded answers to what was happening in the banking system, we always came across the same answers: that is banking secrecy. I respect the principle of banking secrecy when it is used in the right cases. However, I cannot allow and accept that this principle is being exploited. Obviously at EU level, this is regulated differently. I wish there was such order everywhere.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to congratulate my good colleague Renato Soru, the rapporteur, for an excellent report. He is responsible for ensuring that securities financing transactions will be more transparent in the future. The underlying reason for the securities financing transactions report is to make our banking system safer, increase transparency and improve supervision.  These instruments play a significant role in the financial sector in that they ensure liquidity in the secondary debt market, contribute to an efficient settlement and allow for better employment of capital. This agreement not only strengthens the reporting obligation, it also improves the collection of data on the transactions, enabling better monitoring of risk concentrations and identifying counterparty exposures.  I welcome this report on shedding light on the shadow banking sector, because in my opinion you cannot just regulate the banking sector alone and allow other means through which highly risky activities continue within our financial services sector, which is critical for the success of the capital markets union.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has At least since the onset of the financial crisis, it has become clear that transparency and control need to be improved not only in the traditional banking sector, but also in the shadow banks. Shadow banks now handle a quarter of financial assets in the global financial system, and thus a large proportion of securities financing transactions. Increased transparency and reporting requirements for securities financing transactions – as foreseen in this report – help reduce systemic risks, help reduce the risk of contagion in the regulated banking sector in the event of a failure of shadow banks, help by establishing a single index of securities financing transactions to increase transparency for investors and supervisory and regulatory authorities, as credit institutions and listed companies will publish securities financing transactions in the business reports. The rapporteur has paid great attention to minimising the operational costs of these new reporting and transparency obligations. The new rules and standards will also use existing infrastructures and procedures in the field of over-the-counter derivatives. This is better regulation, and the rapporteur is particularly grateful for that.

name: Thomas Mann (PPE).
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for his work The EU has made visible progress towards the Banking Union. However, supervision and regulation need to be improved in addition to the traditional non-banking sector. Let us shed light on the shadow banking system. A number of measures are needed to ensure that the competent authorities, such as ESMA in Paris, the EBA in London or the ECB in Frankfurt am Main, effectively assess possible risks. On this basis, investors will gain a better understanding. Securities financing transactions can affect the stability of the financial system as a whole, for example by increasing undesirable lifting effects. My colleague Danuta Hübner of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats is right to point out that the increased regulation adopted in recent years must not lead to bank-like activities being outsourced to the shadow banks. New accountability must be introduced, as must clearly defined sanctions. I welcome the agreement after the good trialogue negotiations to achieve a regulation with substance. And the Commission, Vice-President Dombrovskis, has described the result as a major step forward in achieving transparency. I fully agree with that. Securities financing operations play an important role in the economy. This makes it all the more urgent to reduce the risks involved and, at the same time, to minimise the additional burden on small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D).
text: – Mr President, we obviously need banks and financial institutions that operate according to transparent rules that take full account of prudential concerns. However, we are also experiencing deflation. Europe faces a huge investment gap. Transparency and prudence should not lead to an increase of viscosity in European financial systems. A fine balance needs to be maintained between potentially divergent concerns. The introduction of new systems of surveillance, as with this report covering security financial transaction markets, may be necessary. Yet we need to ensure that it is consonant with the economic needs of the times. Most measures contemplated here go back to the banks. They are still expected to be behind the big investment leap forward that Europe needs to take. Such a leap could falter if the EU seems to be sending mixed messages: on the one hand telling banks and the financial institutions to be proactive in their approach to proposals for economic expansion, and on the other hand also telling them that they must follow new prudential ways of doing business. We would like to have greater assurance that what we are doing here – necessary as it is – will not serve to further encourage risk aversion among our financial institutions.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I think we have all agreed here that we need a little more light on the area of shadow banking, the grey area where banks are unfortunately located today. What has come from a colleague on the right side of the spectrum, the separation of the speculative part of banking from those classic banking houses, I think is no longer the way. There is no doubt that we really need more transparency in the activities of banks, which I think we all really agreed on. And we should really suppress the unwanted, very risky speculation that is accompanied by the leverage. There, after all, the risk of the system collapsing like a house of cards is undoubtedly much greater. Last but not least, I would like to commend the proposal, which remembers the separation of administrative duties for SMEs. I think that's exactly the path we need to take.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: – Indeed, we are facing one of the greatest dangers that the former European Commission has actually realised, and it has been doing the exploratory work of mapping this whole shadow bank system for practically three years. Indeed, this report is now a very important milestone, because it seems that we now know much, much more about this than, say, before, although the absorption capacity of the shadow banking system is growing much faster than the European institutional system has been able to respond to. I would just like to encourage the European Commission to move very quickly down this path, which it has now presented to us. We're going to support that. I am only because there are indeed very fears that today's economic challenges facing Europe may make the growth of unregulated areas even faster. So I propose to the Commissioner, and I ask that you continue this work in a very rapid manner.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the banking crisis of 2008 and the mortgage and subprimes bubble have brought to light the need for transparency in securities financing transactions in order to strike a balance in the financial system and avoid new crises in the future. Transparency also means detailed reports on collateral for the various securities; transparency means an obligation for credit institutions to notify issuers of all potential risks; transparency means control over the so-called shadow banking system, which is growing at breakneck speed and creating excessive leverage of capital; transparency means knowing the society in which the funds are directed. Are they directed at financing the productive economy or speculation? Because in order to have growth and employment we have to put an end to the casino economy.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the shadow banking system since the great crisis of 2009 is the system in which systemic risk has largely been concentrated. That is why we would have needed a much more radical approach, not a compromise approach, because unfortunately transparency is not enough. The use of leverage and the reuse of collateral had to be further restricting to ensure more financial transactions.  Since the 2009 crisis, the Commission has taken the right direction towards real regulation of finance. Unfortunately, the last two measures, namely the Banking Structural Reform and the measure we are dealing with now, have been shelved and there has been a lack of political will to make real regulation, because we prefer to move towards a Capital Market Union and deregulation with the still use of systemic products, such as financial securitisations, which are not reminiscent of the lessons learned in 2009. We must not bow to the financial markets which impose conditions on us, because politics must be able to regulate finance.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, we are delighted that so many Members are able to support this legislation, which will increase transparency in the financial markets. Looking ahead, the Commission is keen for the reporting rules to be finalised as rapidly as possible. This will enable us to get the system properly up and running. Once the data has been collected, we can get started with our analysis, hone in on potential risks and make sure that these are effectively managed. This legislation provides for a report to be drawn up by the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) by the end of 2016 that will assess the Financial Stability Board (FSB) recommendations on minimum haircuts. The Commission will publish its report a year later, setting out progress in international efforts to mitigate the risks associated with securities financing transactions. This will include a view of the appropriateness of the FSB recommendations for EU markets. But today I would urge Members to support this legislation to increase transparency so that we can have an oversight that is proportionate, help investors make informed investments and make our markets safer.

name: Renato Soru
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the comments I have heard in this House this evening about everyone's substantial support for the measure we are going to vote on tomorrow are very welcome. I have also understood the concerns of some of my fellow Members, and in particular mr Valli, who spoke last, who was perhaps a little too strict about the fact that we missed the opportunity to limit the level of leverage that can be used, while also limiting the amount of time that instruments can be reused and reused. In fact, the Financial Stability Board is dealing with this and we are waiting for what, as a result of this analysis, may emerge, because it is too risky to regulate 'over', above all to misre regulate a market that is also valuable in guaranteeing liquidity to the financial markets. In short, I believe that we can be satisfied with the current text, on which There has been broad convergence of Parliament, and I would therefore like to begin by thanking my colleagues, the shadow rapporteurs, for their truly constructive contribution, and their staff. I would also like to thank the European Commission, in particular DG FISMA, and finally the Council, the Italian and Latvian Presidency, with which this important result was taken home.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.  Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. The recent financial crisis has highlighted the existence of an excess of speculative activities, as well as the existence of serious regulatory gaps in the financial system. The EU has taken a number of measures to increase the soundness and stability of the banking system, including strengthening capital requirements, rules to improve governance, supervision, crisis resolution regimes. However, transparency and control need to be improved not only in the traditional banking sector, but also in sectors where non-banks carry out credit activities, the so-called 'shadow banking system', the size of which is alarming. We cannot, therefore, ignore the risks posed by securities financing operations. In particular, the lack of transparency has prevented regulators and supervisors, as well as investors, from properly assessing and monitoring risks similar to bank risks and the level of interconnection in the financial system in the run-up to or during the financial crisis. This regulation responds to the need to increase this transparency through stricter disclosure rules for counterparties on re-use. In order to ensure their compliance, effective and dissuasive sanctions and administrative measures should be provided for, in accordance with the principle of proportionality.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the Commission statement on access to finance for SMEs (2015/2906(RSP)).

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission attaches great importance to the issues faced by SMEs, in particular access to affordable financing, which is at the core of the Capital Markets Union Action Plan and the review of the Capital Requirements Regulation. I therefore welcome that so many Members have raised this issue by way of oral questions. In particular, I would like to thank Vice-President Tajani for his involvement and contribution, and there is some time to discuss it today in plenary.  The Commission is committed to thoroughly assessing how EU financial regulations impact access to finance for SMEs and for banks and, in particular, how they impact local and regional banks. We have just closed a target consultation on the potential impact of the banking regulation on the financing of the economy, which covers the impact on SME lending as well as issues of proportionality and simplification.  The responses are currently being analysed by the services of the Commission. With the recent publication of a call for evidence, the Commission has also launched a comprehensive review of the cumulative impact and overall coherence of financial legislation, in particular to assess interactions and whether they give rise to any unintended consequences. As regards assessing the potential benefits and strengthening alternative forms of lending, it is the Commission’s standard practice as part of the Better Regulation Agenda to conduct impact assessments in support of our proposals. This includes an analysis of the potential benefits and costs to different stakeholders, including SMEs. This was also the case for the CRR and CRD IV proposals in 2011.  Thanks to an amendment introduced by Parliament, the Capital Requirements Regulation contains a requirement for the Commission to assess the impact of own funds requirements on lending to SMEs and natural persons and to report back to you and the Council by 28 June, 2016. We are currently carrying out that analytical work, and the issue will be debated in the conference scheduled for 14 December on the impact of CRR and CRD IV on bank financing of the economy in which Members of the European Parliament are also warmly invited to participate.  Early next year, the European Banking Authority will provide technical advice to the Commission. We will use this, as well as evidence from different sources, to deliver an objective and a reliable report to Parliament and the Council by the deadline.  Our first priority in the Capital Markets Union Action Plan is to facilitate the financing of innovative companies, start-ups and non-listed firms. We will create an appropriate framework to enable innovative forms of business financing such as crowd—funding, private placements and loan originating funds to grow, while at the same time responding to the key risks. We will also launch a comprehensive package of measures to support venture capital and risk capital financing in the EU. We will explore ways to build a pan-European approach to better connect SMEs with a range of funding sources. With respect to work currently conducted by the Basel Committee to review the approach to credit risk, the goal is to reduce the importance of ratings provided by external credit rating agencies in determining regulatory capital requirements. This needs to be done without affecting the conservative capital requirements. The Basel Committee’s consultation paper includes ideas on how to replace ratings with other risk indicators and contains a preliminary illustrative calibration.  In light of the predominantly negative responses received, we understand the Basel Committee is currently reviewing its approach but maintaining the original objective of reducing mechanical reliance on external ratings. The Commission is closely following this debate as an observer at Basel and generally shares the goal of reducing mechanical reliance on ratings. The Commission will take a position once the final rules have been published.

name: Antonio Tajani
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, access to credit is the main obstacle to the growth of small and medium-sized enterprises, which account for 98% of the European entrepreneurial fabric. I, Mr Vice-President, thank you for the commitments you have confirmed in your speech, and the Group of the European People's Party will support your and your colleagues in the Commission's action in all the actions they will take in support of small and medium-sized enterprises, especially on the very sensitive issue of access to credit, because the useful support programmes are not enough to solve this difficulty. , such as COSME, or the funds made available by Horizon 2020.  New strategies must be developed to make access to credit systematic and continuous, and It seems to me that during your speech a path has been drawn up that goes in the right direction. It is necessary to release unused capital through alternative – as you also mentioned – and traditional forms of financing, strengthening the credit capacity of banks, especially popular banks and cooperative banks.  That is why, in the oral question at the origin of today's debate, we asked the Commission to report on the effectiveness of instruments such as the SME Supporting Factor and Venture Capital. If the European Union had used risk capital, as is the case in the United States, almost EUR 90 billion could have financed businesses in the worst years of the crisis, between 2008 and 2013. We also call for an assessment of the impact of recent financial regulation on access to credit, as we call for an assessment of the new definition of credit risk, which will be contained in the regulation coming from Basel. And then we must also do more to free small and medium-sized enterprises from unnecessary bureaucratic constraints, including those for access to credit. Public administrations must support small and medium-sized enterprises, especially start-ups and young entrepreneurs, and they must do so by reducing red tape but also by paying off their debts: almost 60% of businesses in Europe say they have liquidity problems due to delayed public administration payments. We call on the European Commission to monitor the implementation of the late payment directive. States must set a good example: all too often they do not apply this good EU legislation.

name: Patrizia Toia
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too very much appeal to the Vice-President of the Commission, who is here as the whole Commission, to make a request. We believe that this part, which we are dealing with this evening, relating to credit for SMEs must be absolutely linked to a relaunch of the Commission's action, which should intervene fully to support all the realities of our business, manufacturing and industrial world in Europe, something that we see has weakened somewhat.  That is why, even more so, we must insist on the issue of access to capital, since this is one of the causes that have held back the strength of this entire production sector in recent years, or weakened in some way. It was mentioned earlier how many SMEs are as a percentage of production units: I would like to mention the almost 90 million people employed who are absorbed by SMEs and the contribution they make to European GDP, which is 28%. So we absolutely cannot overlook this important area.  And with regard to access to capital, we must be very clear about the things that we need to do: it must be possible for small and medium-sized enterprises to find capital, to find it in the traditional banking market, with appropriate requirements, with an assessment of the risk factors that relate to this type of reality, to its characteristics, also to the weaknesses inherent, but also taking into account the strength of these small realities. , and then also in the innovative capital market. We have great confidence that the Capital Market Union will also be able to provide new forms of capital, to which you referred: venture capital and other forms that are less banking and more than financial realities.  But we cannot wait for these new directives to be concluded. We absolutely must act earlier. You have made a number of proposals: they are to be welcomed, but what I recommend – two more seconds, Mr President – what I recommend is that everything should not be resolved, as is often the case, by a certain bureaucratic nature of the Commission, which makes impact assessments, studies and consultations but does not change the actual state of affairs. We are asking for concrete action. We call for exactly useful measures to be taken to change the reality of things and therefore the reality of smes' access to credit.

name: Amjad Bashir
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I am very pleased to discuss this topic as it is the main concern I hear from SMEs based in Yorkshire and the Humber. Though the situation has improved, the success rate of small firms applying for bank loans in the UK is around 62%, while over 80% of European SMEs receive finance from banks.  Our SMEs need access to more diverse funding tools, as our over-reliance on bank loans really is the spanner in the works. Achieving this requires sharing best practices, financial education and cultural change. Lord Hill’s CMU proposals are promising, and existing tax incentives stimulate investment in SMEs. However, they are not the only solution. We need to let our constituents know about all the options available to them. Venture capital, business angels and looking at equity rather than bank debt should all be considered. There are also other sources of funding such as peer—to—peer lending and using IP to leverage finance. These are just some of the examples of financing options that our SMEs could tap into in order to unleash their potential, encourage innovation and boost job creation. Going forward, we must hammer home this message to make sure the right tools are in place for our burgeoning small and medium—sized businesses.

name: Philippe De Backer
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. I am pleased that this issue is once again on the agenda. Two years ago, I wrote an initiative report in this House on this subject. It contained very concrete recommendations for the Commission, the Member States and entrepreneurs themselves to gain better access to new forms of funding. After all, we know that our SMEs are very much dependent on bank financing. Certainly the smaller ones are struggling to get funding in any other way. I think this is one of the things we should try to change. We must try to create a culture of equity among SMEs as well so that they can grow faster, create more jobs and weigh more economically. My own professional experience also plays a part in this. I have seen how new forms of financing clearly allow companies to grow much faster and rise up the funding ladder much faster. It's about creating diversity in the market. We need to look at venture capital and new forms of financing, such as crowdfunding, but we should not forget private placements as sources of funding for our SMEs. It is a thing of the european authorities to create a clear and stable regulatory framework that encourages long-term investment. In addition, we must do everything we can to prevent fragmentation in our European Union. Commissioner Hill's proposal on the capital market union is a good example of this. We must break down national barriers, prevent over-regulation and ensure that we have a genuine single European market. SMEs obviously need not only financing opportunities but also jobs, skills, the right people, the right customers and also much more equity than might have been the case in the past. So we must do everything we can to create an ecosystem that can bring together investors, entrepreneurs and SMEs in a good way. It is the only way we have at European level to guarantee investment in SMEs, which are nevertheless the backbone of our economy.

name: Paloma López Bermejo
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, SMEs are a source of employment and growth in Europe, but they have a funding problem. I do not share the Commission's diagnosis of the causes of lack of credit and which serves to guide its financing programmes to SMEs. We are witnessing a huge concentration of the banking sector in a few private transnational oligopolies. It is a development favoured by the Commission, as seen in its model of banking union or under the conditions of financial bailouts, for example the one that was established for Spain. But without public banking, without a bank linked to territory and industry, what happens is a shift of financial activity towards speculation. Seeking to respond to this problem with further liberalization of finance, such as the Capital Markets Union, is a false answer, because not only is this business still in the hands of the same large financial groups, but it also strengthens its ability to impose its conditions and transfer its risks to SMEs, which are the first to suffer the impact of increased volatility and uncertainty. I would like to conclude by adding that the financial asphyxiation of SMEs is also due to stagnant demand and the lack of prospects for recovery in many countries, especially on the European periphery. I stress that economic policy must be moved away from financial interests because, if not, we will continue to suffer from great macroeconomic instability, a lack of growth that will hinder access to SME credit and thereby job creation and much-needed growth for Europe.

name: Margot Parker
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the discussion this evening reminds me of the old adage, ‘Give a man a fish and you feed him for a day; teach a man to fish and you feed him for a lifetime’. While we discuss access to finance for SMEs, we are in fact only delaying the discussion of the real everyday problems that SMEs in the EU face. For is not the lack of money from the EU that hampers SMEs, but the ridiculous amounts of red tape and burdensome regulations that come from this Parliament. SMEs are the backbone of our economy: they represent over 99% of businesses and help provide millions of jobs and deliver crucial services to our citizens. To ensure that the long-term prosperity and growth of SMEs is not stifled, we must put SMEs at the heart of all future decisions and we must ensure that harmful, costly and bureaucratic legislation is repealed. If the Commission is serious about assisting SMEs for the future, it must prioritise addressing the foundations of the problem rather than sugarcoating the situation with taxpayers’ money.

name: Markus Pieper (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Why this debate on financing for SMEs again today? I would like to begin by thanking Antonio Tajani, who brought this issue to the SME circle of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, right up to the debate here in the European Parliament today. More innovative instruments were mentioned: COSME, Horizon, venture capital. Europe really does a lot for SMEs here. Yes, and we also have the Capital Markets Union in front of our chests. But here really isn't all the gold that shines. Facilitation for securitisation – okay, air-to-IP facilitation is good. But all of this is only really profitable after certain sales limits, starting from a hundred million. Unfortunately, companies are hardly interested in these new instruments. Traditional credit financing still counts. But what is the ECB doing, what is the Commission doing with the large remainder of the medium-sized companies that rely on this credit financing? Commissioner, there will be 150 new data sets for loans starting at EUR 25 000. AnaCredit is a nightmare for every medium-sized company, for every Volksbank, for every savings bank. And the review of credit collateral, the questioning of real estate as collateral, and the distrust of SME loans – that is, what is now going on in the review of the Basel 3 criteria – is not progress either. All these things would really be a step backwards for the financing of small and medium-sized enterprises. I therefore really ask that we proceed very carefully on these matters. Commissioner, please do not cut at the strongest branches on which we sit! These are the medium-sized enterprises, that is credit financing, these are the small banks and savings banks.

name: Dawid Bohdan Jackiewicz (ECR).
text: – 99% of companies in the European Union are SMEs. They play a key role in the eu economy as a whole, creating more than 90 million jobs. That is why we must create favourable conditions for their functioning and development, especially when it comes to their ability to raise capital for day-to-day operations and investments. The European Commission needs to step up its work in this area. Small and medium-sized enterprises need to be helped to become more independent of the need for bank debt. Conditions must be created for better access to finance in the form of grants and loans or loan guarantees. SMEs should be assisted in their efforts to improve access to markets around the world and look for ways to reduce the risk of economic activity. It is necessary to simplify procedures for access to financial instruments, to introduce clear and comprehensible eligibility criteria. Controls on the use of funds are intended to eliminate mistakes and not to eliminate economic operators from the market. A comprehensive vision is needed to support entrepreneurship, because without it, the EU economy will sooner or later face further problems.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent work. In Latvian we have such a saying — ar threads nav aršanas. If we think about business, all of us who have been entrepreneurs know that without funding you cannot develop a business.  In the EU, small and medium-sized enterprises employ more than 90% of all workers. In fact, SMEs are the backbone of our economy. If we want our economy to develop, we need small and medium-sized entrepreneurs to grow. Where's the difficulty? The difficulty is that, for 75% of their funding, small and medium-sized enterprises depend on bank loans. But the banks now, especially after the crisis, do not want to give this money, and those loans are becoming more and more expensive.  So what can we do to help our small businesses? I think two main things need to be done. Firstly, access to bank loans needs to be improved. But secondly and very importantly, we need to help small and medium-sized enterprises find non-bank financing through such investment mechanisms in their share capital through venture capital and capital market mechanisms. I therefore very much support the Commission's initiative to build this capital market union.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR).
text: – Discussions with small and medium-sized enterprises show that in Central and Eastern Europe the biggest problem is securing the liquidity of these companies (and there are many) that cannot obtain dues from their customers on time. There are also no crisis financing instruments – for example guarantee and loan – for entrepreneurs who are insolvent but have the capacity to repair and restructure. It should therefore be the Union's task to create appropriate instruments and to encourage Member States and the banking sector to look for ways to solve this problem. It is worth noting that the lack of convenient funding limits the expansion of our region's companies within the common market and makes the introduction of new standards at European level a threat to their existence on a case-by-case basis. This creates differences in the conditions for competing in the common market, which are discriminatory for companies in our region.

name: Paul Rübig (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the SMEs are always concerned with taking more than what they sell. It is not always easy because consumers are often difficult, very picky, and that is why it is important that an SME cannot always generate the same returns. That is why it is also a question of the public authorities sharing the risk with SMEs. If, on the one hand, taxes are paid for profits and wages, then we must also be prepared to invest in the risk that small and medium-sized enterprises have to bear. Ultimately, 60% of liquidity problems arise from late payments. In this respect, I would like to ask Commissioner Dombrovskis, in particular, for us to analyse the European Union and the European Union's budget, as is also the way in which late payments are made in research programmes and in many other areas. I do not want to know how many SMEs have already gone bankrupt, because the bureaucratic rules and the administrative procedures are so complicated that small and medium-sized enterprises do not get their liquidity and therefore do not do so. I would also like to point out that the Joint Research Centre has now carried out a study on tax incentivs, which should lead to more equity capital of private individuals also in the companies. I believe that this would be an excellent interlinking between the public sector and the private sector for the creation of new jobs.

name: Bendt Bendtsen (PPE).
text: Mr President! Financing large companies is often not the big problem. They have the ability to go to the stock market, they have the possibility of issuing corporate bonds, but when we talk about small and medium-sized enterprises, we know that it is important that they have access to markets. We also know that it is important that we combat administrative burdens, including in this House, but the most important thing is actually to obtain financing, and on top of the financial crisis and the banking crises, we know that the banking market is frozen for many of our small and medium-sized enterprises. We have also worked on this in this House. We have been working on both Cosme and Horizon 2020, but I have to say that the funds allocated in these areas are, after all, just a drip in the bucket. Funding of a completely different order of magnitude is needed. What I am trying to say with this is that public money is not enough! We need private money to be locked up and get into work. There is no doubt that the Capital Markets Directive and also Juncker's investment plan are a good step in the right direction, with 21 billion euros geared to 315. But there is a need for us to open up our pension funds in Europe. They have gigantic funds going to work, and we need to look at some securities so we can get this money to work.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. We have rightly mentioned that much has been created for small and medium-sized enterprises, including the new European Fund for Strategic Investments. However, I very much welcome the fact that you have announced an evaluation of all existing banking regulations with their impact on the financing of small and medium-sized enterprises. This evaluation also includes national and regional legislative measures. This evaluation includes the review of the Late Payments Directive and also the implementation of the small business act. A second point, Commissioner, you mentioned, is the Basel Committee. You pointed out that the Commission is an observer. I call on you not only to be an observer, but to make yourself the spokesman and coordinator of the Member States of the European Union on the Basel Committee. At the same time, we must also be careful that ESMA and EBA do not make many of the measures we have put in place for SMEs more difficult afterwards via technical standards. The next step is the Capital Markets Union, the support for start-ups, the securitisations, the expansion of SMEs' access to finance alongside loans. But the most important asset is to reduce bureaucratic obstacles and hurdles.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE).
text: – According to Commissioner Elżbieta Bieńkowske, access to finance is not the most pressing problem for SMEs. At least that's how she answered my parliamentary question. But entrepreneurs in Slovenia and the data say otherwise.  I quote the European Commission's report on the business of SMEs in 2013 and 2014: 'Access to finance remains a major obstacle for SMEs, despite a number of activities and initiatives for improvement.'  Bank credits, for example, are not relevant to many entrepreneurs because of excessive interest, the European Commission's survey on access to finance shows. This is what 22% of Slovenian entrepreneurs believe, while the European Union average is 11%, while in Finland and Sweden only 1% of entrepreneurs think so.  This shows that we have large differences between Member States and too few effective programmes. In order to change this, the financial and institutional characteristics of the Member States need to be better taken into account. Instead of standardized we need tailored solutions or, in the language of fashion, instead of pret-à-porter we need sur-mesure measures.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, ós rud é gur mise na cainteoir deireanach anseo tá mé chun é a rá i mo theanga dhúchais féin mar baineann an t-ábhar seo le mo thír féin ach go háirithe.  Tuigimid go léir cé chomh tábhachtach is atá fiontair bheaga agus mheánmhéide. Tá na figiúirí de ghlanmheabhair againn anois: dá bhféadfadh gach aon fhiontar beag agus meánmhéide oibrí amháin eile a fhostú thiocfadh deireadh le dífhostaíocht san Eoraip. Freisin, fostaíonn siad 90% dár n-oibrithe agus cabhraíonn siad le suas le 30% den GDP.  Ach tá fadhbanna móra acu. Agus bhí siad go huafásach i rith an chúlaithe eacnamaíochta. Chonaic mé é sin, go háirithe i rith an toghcháin dheireanaigh agus mé ag dul ó shráid go sráid; bhí siopaí agus gnóthaí á ndúnadh de bharr easpa custaiméirí agus easpa airgid. Cé go bhfuil rudaí ag dul i bhfeabhas faoi láthair, tá an easpa airgid orthu go fóill. Níl na bainc ag tabhairt amach an t-airgead, mar tá a gcuid fadhbanna féin acu.  Dá bhrí sin molaim agus fáiltím roimh na hionstraimintí nua atá á dtabhairt isteach ag an gCoimisiún, go háirithe an CMU, COSME agus mar sin de. Ach ní haon mhaitheas ionstraimintí nua a thabhairt isteach muna mbíonn na SMEs ar an eolas fúthu. Agus chonaic mé é sin go minic i mo thír féin. Dá bhrí sin, is maith an rud é ionstraimintí a bheith againn ach caithfimid na SMEs a chur ar an eolas fúthu chomh maith.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I also welcome the instruments presented here by the Commissioner to increase access to finance for businesses. However, I think that my colleague Rübig also raised a very important question here, pointing out the importance of even the most incidental circumstances making it difficult for SMEs to access or grow on the European market or the global market. It's a secondary default. Indeed, this is a very fundamental issue for jeopardling the functioning of businesses. Businesses then very easily fall into insolvency, which I think are the real problems that SMEs face. I would also like to point out that the various European support programmes, instead of reducing administration, are multiplying it. I will give a concrete example of the Rural Development Programme to serve entrepreneurs in agriculture, where the programme methodology contains 780 pages. A farmer said to me, "I'd rather do it the same way than read it." I guess that's cause for reflection, too.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, during the five-year memorandum period 230 000 small and medium-sized enterprises have been closed in Greece, sending seven hundred thousand people into unemployment. So while in previous decades small and medium-sized enterprises have created thousands of jobs, they have started to shrink as an industry because of memoranda, fiscal adjustment and austerity, which have reduced demand and consumption. Moreover, both in Greece and in the rest of Europe, access to banking credit for small and medium-sized enterprises is deteriorating, while there are wide divergences in bank lending between large and small enterprises. Unfortunately, the European Union does not have sufficient resources to finance small and medium-sized enterprises, to support and support their exports and to access credit through cooperative banks. Finally, for Greece, in order for small and medium-sized enterprises to recover, our country must be rid of the vise of the memorandums and the troika.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his work SMEs' access to finance is a key driver of growth in Europe's employment. 99% of European companies are SMEs. These companies create 50% of the value added of business and 80% of the new jobs in Europe. SMEs are therefore the backbone of the European economy.  The European Union is helping with initiatives here, but it is also a co-investor. It is the Structural Funds that are essential to help SMEs, it is the COSME programme, it is the Horizon 2020 SME instrument and it is in particular the activities of the European Investment Bank, which last year passed on more than EUR 20 billion in loans to small and medium-sized enterprises.  In this context, I welcome the Commission's initiative announced today, namely to evaluate financial legislation for SMEs. That is certainly necessary. We must always be up-to-date, and this evaluation is also important. The conference on 14 December will also be important, but the evaluation is essential. 80% of SME lending comes from banks. This is important, but it needs to be extended. Europe needs alternative forms of financing, SMEs need alternative forms of financing, and risk and equity capital in particular is necessary for start-ups and growth companies, as well as a reduction in bureaucratic barriers.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, let me first respond to some of the concerns expressed during this evening’s debate. First, capital markets union (CMU) should not be seen as in competition or contradiction with a strong banking system. Banks have strong local relationships and knowledge about micro, small and medium—sized enterprises. Bank lending will remain the principal source of external finance for SMEs. The measures provided for in the Capital Markets Union Action Plan will not interfere with, or detract from, local banking networks. On the contrary, CMU provides for measures that will strengthen the banking system. It seeks to make it easier for banks to refinance their traditional lending business by selling securities and bonds to the capital markets. The larger and more efficient funding market for banks will help them, including the local relationship banks, to focus on their core business, notably lending to micro-businesses and SMEs. There are, however, Member States where bank loans are difficult to obtain. There are also companies – start—ups with limited physical collateral or firms in an expansion phase – whose needs may not always be catered for by the banks. CMU proposes a way to help firms in these situations to raise funding through other channels. CMU will complement, rather than compete with, bank finance by adding to the diversity of funding sources.  By promoting more diverse funding channels and reducing Europe’s dependency on banks, CMU should increase the resilience of the financial system. Nevertheless, we also need to be alert to financial stability risks that may emerge as a result of efforts to further develop Europe’s capital markets. Recent measures, such as the European Market Infrastructure Regulation (EMIR), the Alternative Investment Funds Managers Directive (AIFMD), the Markets in Financial Instruments Directive (MiFID) and the Securities Financing Transactions Regulation, will make capital markets more transparent, well-regulated and robust. The European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) will play an important role in ensuring consistent implementation and application of these laws.  As markets develop, it will be important to ensure that any risks associated with the deepening of capital-market-based financing are monitored and mitigated. Work is underway, within the EU and internationally, to improve understanding and monitoring of systemic risks. The Commission will examine the need for changes to the macroprudential framework in the context of the forthcoming review of the European Systemic Risk Board (ESRB) and, if it appears necessary, will allow for effective intervention to contain and mitigate risks arising from market—based finance.  Let me conclude today by saying that it is my pleasure to continue discussions with you on ongoing issues in relation to SMEs’ access to finance, which are important for all of us. Improving access to finance for SMEs is one of the mainstays of the implementation of the Commission’s strategy for growth and jobs. The issues are relatively complex but, through our shared determination, I believe we are moving in the right direction.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.  Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The Commission’s statement on access to finance for SMEs was sorely lacking in fairness, vision and ambition. There was no real attempt to assist Small and Medium sized Enterprises (SMEs) in any meaningful way. Small and Medium sized Enterprises (SMEs) are the life blood of the Irish economy. SMEs are one of the main employers and are at the heart of communities across Europe. Therefore, what is required are policies that will enable SMEs to grow, create local employment and as a result circulate money into our economy. Europe can not only provide practical financial assistance to companies, but it can also enable Member States to capitalise on the positive aspects which membership of the European Union brings. It is quite clear that Europe does provide opportunities to open up lucrative export markets for our SME sector. Huge opportunities exist in Europe to support our SME sector. However, these businesses need support, encouragement and investment to allow them to continue to grow. This will only happen with the necessary commitment, ambition and political will. Unfortunately, none of these qualities were present in the Commission’s Statement.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. – The first achievements of the greatest rigour in the EU's economic and budgetary management are already seen, and the European economy is slowly beginning to return. According to the European Commission's forecasts, gross domestic product (GDP) will grow by 1.8% in 2015 – compared to the 1.1% it had forecast last year – and 2.1% in 2016 — while last year's forecast was 1.7%. Europe, however, can aspire to more: we can still make much more of our potential. The important thing is to generate a positive investment climate for our companies and, in general, to improve the predisposition to entrepreneurship across the EU. Small and medium-sized enterprises are the backbone of our economy and are the ones creating jobs in the European Union; it is essential to continue to support SMEs to ensure the exit from the crisis.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. Since the beginning of the crisis, the Commission has launched several initiatives to facilitate credit for SMEs. These include the SUPPORTING Factor PMI in the regulation of capital requirements, which allows banks to take advantage of a capital discount factor to be set aside for SME financing and the EU Passport to increase confidence in European SMEs.  Recently, the Commission stated that it wanted to activate measures to support SMEs within the Capital Markets Union. However, these initiatives seem to be disjointed and also do not seem to have had the desired effect given the persistent difficulties of European SMEs in accessing credit.  It would therefore be appropriate for the Commission to launch an overall impact assessment of EU financial regulation to assess its impact on European SMEs. It would also be appropriate for the Commission to assess the benefits achieved with the instruments used so far and to look for new forms of financing alternative to the classic banking channel - such as peer to peer lending and crowdfunding. Given the crucial role of SMEs in the European economy and the crucial role they will have to play in economic recovery, it is necessary to establish a more coordinated, effective and rational framework that really increases the possibilities for financing and at the same time decreases the administrative burden.
